div.head: To the Right VVorshipfull IVLIVS CAESAR Doctor of the Lawes, Iudge of the High Court of Admiralty, Ma≈øter of Reque≈øts to the Queenes Maie≈øty, and Ma≈øter of Saint Katherines.
div.p:
RIGHT VVORSHIPFVLL: The manyfolde Curte≈øies, which it hath plea≈øed you from time to time to multiply vpon mee, haue made me ≈øo greatly beholden vnto you, that they can neuer dye, but remaine fre≈øh in my remembrance during my Life: So that I mu≈øt enforce my ≈øelfe with all my be≈øt Endeuours openly to acknowledge the ≈øame, and by all the meanes that po≈ø≈øibly I can, to bee thankefull for them; otherwi≈øe I might iu≈øtly be noted with the blacke ≈øpotte of Ingratitude, the mo≈øt odious vice that can raigne among≈øt men: which vice to auoyde, I haue ≈øtudied earne≈øtly to finde out ≈øome way, wherby I might make knowne vnto your Wor≈øhip that duetifull reuerence and affection, which I owe vnto you in that re≈øpect. But hauing hitherto had no fit oportunitie or good occa≈øion to declare the ≈øame, I haue beene con≈øtrayned
to remaine in this debt, vntill now at la≈øt it hath plea≈øed God to offer me a meane which I hope will not be di≈øplea≈øing vnto you. About a Tweluemonth agoe, a learned Gentleman brought vnto mee the Voyages and Nauigation of John Huyghen van Lin≈øchoten into the Indies written in the Dutche Tongue, which he wi≈øhed might be tran≈ølated into our Language, becau≈øe hee thought it would be not onely delightfull, but al≈øo very commodious for our Engli≈øh Nation. Vpon this commendation and opinion, I procured the Tran≈ølation thereof accordingly, and ≈øo thought good to publi≈øh the ≈øame in Print, to the ende it might bee made common and knowen to euery body. And calling to minde the v≈øuall cu≈øtome of Writers and Printers in the≈øe daies, who do commonly ≈øhelter and ≈øhrowde their works vnder the credit of ≈øome ≈øuch as are able to Patronize the ≈øame, your Wor≈øhip repre≈øented it ≈øelfe before mee, and did (as it were of right) challenge the Patronage hereof, as being a Matter that appertaineth to your Iuri≈ødiction. For this Dutchman arriuing here in England after his long trauell and Nauigation, and bringing rare Intelligences with him from Forreyne parts, good rea≈øon it is that hee ≈øhould bee examined by ≈øuch as are in place and Authority appointed for ≈øuch purpo≈øes. And to whome can hee be directed better then to your ≈øelfe, whome it hath plea≈øed her mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie to authorize for Iudge in Sea matters and Admirall cau≈øes. And therefore I haue brought him vnto you, with earne≈øt reque≈øt, that you will be plea≈øed to examine him accordingly, and if you ≈øhall finde him any way beneficiall to our
Countrey and Countrey men, vouch≈øafe him your good countenance, and giue him ≈øuch intertainment as he ≈øhall de≈øerue. Thus am I bold with your wor≈øhip to acknowledge my dutie after this homely manner, hauing none other meane to ≈øhew my ≈øelfe thankefull, but by pre≈øenting you with this ≈ølender fruite of my abilitie & facultie, which I be≈øeech you to accept in good part, and I ≈øhall not cea≈øe to pray to God, that hee will ble≈ø≈øe you with long life, and pro≈øperous health, to the great comfort of many her Maie≈øties Subiects and Suppliants that are daylie to bee relieued by your good meanes.

closer.signed: Your Wor≈øhips euer mo≈øt bounden. IOHN VVOLFE.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
LVcian in one of his Dialogues intituled „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or Surueyers, writeth of Charon the old Ferrie-Man of Hell, that vpon a great de≈øire which he had conceiued to view this world and the Actions of men therein, hee begged leaue of Pluto, that hee might haue a playing day, and bee ab≈øent from his boat, to the end he might ≈øatisfie his thir≈øty humor, that troubled him ≈øo eagerly. Meeting with Mercurie his fellow Boat≈øwayne, (for he al≈øo conducteth Soules in Charons Barge) they two concluded together, like the two Sonnes of Alc√´us, to clap the Mountaine Pelius vpon Mount O≈ø≈øa, and when they found that they were not high inough to take the ≈øurueigh, they added Mount O Eta vnto them, and Parn ‚Ä¢ us ouer them all. Vpon the toppe wherof, hauing ≈øetled them≈øelues, they did at ley≈øure and plea≈øure take a view not onely of the Seas, and Mountaines, and Cities of the world: but al≈øo of the Inhabitants therof, together with their Speeches, Actions and Manners. The ≈øame Author in another Dialogue called Icaro-Menippus di≈øcour≈øeth of the Cinike Menippus, who being troubled with the ≈øame humor tooke vnto him the right wing of an Eagle, and the left wing of a Vulture, and hauing fa≈øtened them to his body with ≈øtrong and ≈øturdie thongs, mounted vp fir≈øt to the Acropolis or Capitol of Athens, and then from Hymettus by the Gerania to Acro-Corinthus, and ≈øo to Pholo√´, and Erymanthus, & Taygetus, and at la≈øt to Olympus: where he grew ≈øomewhat more bragg and audacious, then before he was, and ≈øoared higher vpwards till he had reached the Moone, and then the Sunne, and from thence the Habitation of Iupiter and the re≈øt of the Gods: a ≈øufficient flight (as he ≈øaith) for a well tru≈ø≈øed Eagle to performe in a day. There he re≈øted him≈øelfe, and di≈øcouered all the world and euery particularity thereof, to the end he might the more freely & like a Scoggan taunt & ≈øcoffe at the Actions of men in their ≈øeuerall kinds. But to leaue the≈øe Poeticall Fictions, and vaine Fables, which doo but declare the Nature of Man to bee de≈øirous of Nouelties, and curious to know tho≈øe things whereof he is ignorant; let vs come to tho≈øe that being neither coniured out of hell, nor rapt into the heauens, but of their owne honourable di≈øpo≈øition and in≈øtinct of Nature, haue not onely compa≈ø≈øed Sea and Land in their own per≈øons to learne and beholde Nations, Realmes, Peoples & Countries vnknowne, for the augmentation of their owne priuate skill and cunning, but al≈øo haue committed their knowledge and labours to writing for the propagation of the ≈øeruice and glorie of God in Pagan and Heathen places, and the great plea≈øure, profit & commodity of their Countrymen. Of this kinde and ≈øort of famous men, there hath beene great ≈øtore in al ages, but ≈øpecially at the fir≈øt, Homer, Anaximander, Hecataeus, Democritus, Eudoxus, Timaeus, Eratosthenes, Polybius, Pos≈øidonius, Diony≈øius, Strabo, Solinus, Pomponius Mela, Maximus Tyrius, Ptolom√©e, & an infinite number of other ancient Authors, that haue imployed
their wits & indu≈øtries in this behalf to the ≈øingular benefit of our later times, wherein there haue beene mo≈øt excellent and exqui≈øite followers of them, as Munsters, Mercators, Theuets, Belonies, Ortelies, Villamonts, & many moe, that by the light and good meanes of tho≈øe their Predece≈ø≈øors, haue run beyonde them many degrees, and di≈øcouered ≈øuch New worlds as were neuer knowne to our Fathers & Forefathers; and therefore doo de≈øerue the greater commendation. No doubt, it is very trouble≈øome and laborious to iourney by land for the attaining to this knowledge: but to trauell by Sea, is not onely mo≈øt dangerous, but al≈øo in a maner almo≈øt a de≈øperate e≈øtate, con≈øidering e≈øpecially the great perils wherevnto it is hourely ≈øubiect, as namely, Rockes, Flats, Sandes, Gulphes, Stormes, Tempe≈øts, be≈øides the continuall Watching and care in ob≈øeruing the Poles Arctike, and Antarctike, the Aequinoctiall Line, the Altitude and Degrees of the Meridian, the Circle of the Zodiake, the Horizon, the Tropikes, the Longitude and Latitude of Heauen and earth, the Paralleles, the Hemi≈øphere, the Zenith, the Centre, and a Rablement of ≈øuch curio≈øities, that are able to breake the braines of the ≈øounde≈øt man aliue. To the≈øe if you will add the intollerable paines, and infinite di≈øea≈øes that doo ≈øpend their bodies, you mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that they are the mo≈øt mi≈øerable Creatures of the worlde: So that you cannot choo≈øe but bee of the opinion of Anachar≈øis that Noble Philo≈øopher, who beeing demaunded whether Number was the greater, that of the dead or that of the Liuing, did redemaund againe, In which Number do you recken tho≈øe that trauell on the Sea? Signifiyng thereby, that ≈øuch as trauell vpon the Sea are in ≈øo great danger of death, that they doo continually dye liuing, and liue dying. And therefore well ≈øayd Bias (one of the ≈øeuen Sages) that Saylers vppon the Sea were alwayes within two ynches of their death: & true it is, which the Latyn Lyrike Poet writeth, That Man had a Hart of Oke, and was fenced with a triple Cor≈ølet of Bra≈ø≈øe, that fir≈øt aduentured to commit a ≈ølender Boat to the raging Sea. A Type and Patterne of all which mi≈øeries, together with the cunning and skilfull Art of Nauigation, is compri≈øed in this Volume which wee haue in hand, being a mo≈øt perfect de≈øcription of the Ea≈øt and We≈øt Indies, or (as they are commonly called) the Portugall and Spani≈øh Indies: A Worke a≈ø≈øuredly very profitable, and commodious for all ≈øuch as are de≈øirous & curious louers of Nouelties.

Of the≈øe Indies, though not in di≈øtingui≈øhed tearmes of Ea≈øt and We≈øt, ≈øundry Hi≈øtoriographers and Authors of the old World haue made an honourable Mention, & left an exceeding commendation thereof, for the wonderfull and rare matters, that were di≈øcouered by the ≈øeuerall Trauels & Nauigation of diuers famous Captains: as namely, Alexander the great, Seleucus, Antiochus, Patrocles, and One≈øicritus, who had been all in the ≈øaide Indies, in≈øomuch as one of them held them to be the Third part of all the Land that is inhabited, in regard of the great Prouinces, pui≈ø≈øant Cities, and vnmea≈øurable Ilands that are found therein: all very fruitfull, and yeelding ≈øuch trea≈øure and rich Merchandize, as none other place of the whole world can afford. And althogh the curio≈øity and labour of the≈øe auncients was very great, yet greater hath beene the trauell and indu≈øtry of tho≈øe which of late time, and in our age hath beene imployed therein. For the auncient Trauellers had in deede a certain kind of knowledge of this Countrey and People; but it was very vncertaine and vnperfect: Whereas we in our times are thoroughly learned and in≈øtructed by our owne experience, in the Prouinces, Cities, Riuers, Hauens and Trafficks of them all: So that nowe it is become knowne to the whole world. Fir≈øt the Portingalls (being great Merchants by rea≈øon of their skil in Nauigation, which in our dayes is growne to a more full perfection, then euer it hath beene in times pa≈øt:) they I ≈øay fir≈øt di≈øcouered
the Wa≈øt and De≈øert Part of the Indies, cau≈øed their King to be entertayned & honoured among the People, encrea≈øed and enhaun≈øed their credit and Name exceedingly, and the ≈øundry commodities of their ≈øeuerall fruits and ≈øpices haue di≈øper≈øed & communicated not onely to their owne Countrymen, but al≈øo to all Nations vnder the Sunne. But here the Matter ≈øtayed not: For then came the Engli≈øh (a People that in the Art of Nauigation giueth place to none other) and they were incited to take this Indian Voyage in hande, and to make it generally knowne vnto their I≈øland: & therevpon Syr Francis Drake, & Ma≈øter Thomas Candi≈øh did not only ≈øayle into the ≈øayde Indies, but al≈øo trauelled round about the world, with a mo≈øt happy and famous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. Who≈øe examples diuers honourable Gentlemen and valiant Captaines of England haue followed, to their vn≈øpeakeable prai≈øe and commendation, & the exceeding glory of their Country: as namely the Right Honourable Earle of Cumberland, the Lord Thomas Howard, Syr Francis Drake, Syr Martin Frobi≈øher, Syr Richard Greenefield, Syr Iohn Hawkins, and Syr Walter Raleigh, with diuers others named and mentioned in this Booke, And la≈øt of all, the People of the Lowe-Countreys beeing in≈øtructed by the diligent ≈øearch and trauell of the Engli≈øh Nation, fell to the like trafficke into ‚Ä¢ he Indies, and haue performed many Honourable and profitable Voyages. Among whom the Author of this B ‚Ä¢ oke, Iohn-Hugh Lin≈øchote of Harlem was one, that continued in India for the mo≈øt part of nine yeares, and had good oportunity of ≈øure and certaine intelligences by rea≈øon of his ≈øeruice vnder Vincentius da Fon≈øeca, a Fryer Dominican, & by K. Philip created Archbi≈øhop of all India. This Man Hugh Lin≈øchote behaued him≈øelfe ≈øo hone≈øtly and warily during the time of his abode there, that he was not onely in high fauour of his Lord and Mai≈øter, but he was al≈øo ≈øingularly and generally beloued of all the Inhabitants of the places where hee was mo≈øt re≈øiant. He did mo≈øt diligently and con≈øiderately ob≈øerue and collect together all occurrents and accidents that happened in his memory & knowledge, and the ≈øame hath committed to writing in the Dutch Tongue with all faithfulnes, to his owne euerla≈øting prai≈øe, and to the benefit of his Countrey, together with the ≈øeuerall Mappes and de≈øcriptions of the Countreys, Cities and Townes, & all the commodities therevnto belonging. Which Booke being commended, by Mai≈øter Richard Hackluyt, a man that laboureth greatly to aduance our Engli≈øh Name and Nation, the Printer thought good to cau≈øe the ≈øame to bee tran≈ølated into the Engli≈øh Tongue.

The Volume conteyneth in it foure ≈øeuerall Treati≈øes: The Fir≈øt is, The Fir≈øt Booke. The Voyage or Iourney by Sea of the ≈øayde Hugh Linschote the Author, into the Ea≈øt or Portingall Indies, together with all the Sea-Coa≈øts, Hauens, Riuers and Cre ‚Ä¢ kes of the ≈øame, their Cu≈øtomes and Religion, their Policie and Gouernement, their Marchandi≈øes, Drugges, Spyces, Hearbs, & Plants, the vertues whereof are explaned by the Annotations of Doctor Paludanus, the learned Phi≈øitian of En ‚Ä¢ khuy≈øen: And la≈øt of all, a Memoriall of ≈øuch Accidents as fell out during the Authors aboade in India.

The Second Treati≈øe is, The Second Booke. The De≈øcription of Guinea, Manicongo, Angola, Monomotapa, &c. with a di≈øcouery of the great I≈øland of Madaga≈øcar, and all the Shallowes, Cliffes and I≈ølands of the Indian Seas: The mo≈øt part whereof was collected before by one Pigafetta from the mouth of Edward Lopez, and publi≈øhed in Engli≈øh the la≈øt yeare.

The Third Treati≈øe is, The Thi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Booke. The Nauigation of the Portingales into the Ea≈øt Indies: & from thence to Malacca, China, Iapon, Iaua and Sunda: And from China to the We≈øterne or Spani≈øh Indies, and all the Coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia, &c.

The Fourth and la≈øt Treati≈øe is, The Fourth Booke. A mo≈øt true & exact Summarie of all the Rents, Demaynes, Tolles, Taxes, Impo≈øts,
Tributes, Tenths, Third-pennies, and generally all the Reuenues of the King of Spayne, ari≈øing out of all his Kingdomes, Lands, Prouinces and Lord≈øhips, as well of Portugall as of Spayne, collected out of the Originall Regi≈øters of his ≈øeuerall Chambers of Accompts: together with a briefe de≈øcription of the gouernment and Pedegree of the Kinges of Portugall.

I doo not doubt, but yet I doo mo≈øt hartely pray and wi≈øh, that this poore Tran≈ølation may worke in our Engli≈øh Nation a further de≈øire and increa≈øe of Honour ouer all Countreys of the World, and as it hath hitherto mightily aduanced the Credite of the Realme by defending the ≈øame with our Wodden Walles (as Themi≈øtocles called the Ships of Athens¬∑) So it would employ the ≈øame in forraine partes, a≈øwell for the di≈øper≈øing and planting true Religion and Ciuill Conuer≈øation therein: As al≈øo for the further benefite and commodity of this Land by exportation of ≈øuch thinges wherein we doe abound, and importation of tho≈øe Nece≈ø≈øities whereof we ≈øtand in Neede: as Hercules did, when hee fetched away the Golden Apples out of the Garden of the He≈øperides; & Ia≈øon, when with his lu≈øtie troupe of couragious Argonautes hee atchieued the Golden Fleece in Colchos.

div.head: THE FIRST BOOKE.
CHAPTER. I.

argument.p: The Voyage and trauailes of Iohn Hugen van Lin≈øchoten into the Ea≈øt or Portingales Indies: Setting downe a briefe di≈øcour≈øe of the ≈øaid Landes, and ≈øea coa≈øtes, with the principall Hauens, Riuers, Creekes, and other places of the ≈øame, as yet not knowne nor di≈øcouered by the Portingales: De≈øcribing withall not onely the manner of apparrell of the Portingales inhabiting therin, but al≈øo of the naturall borne Indians, their Temples, Idols, hou≈øes, trees, Fruites, Hearbes, Spices, and ≈øuch like: Together with the cu≈øtomes of tho≈øe countries, as well for their manner of Idolatrous religion and wor≈øhipping of Images, as al≈øo for their policie and gouernment of their hou≈øes, their trade, and traffique in Marchandi≈øe, how and from whence their wares are ≈øold, & brought thether: With a collection of the mo≈øt memorable and worthie≈øt thinges happened in the time of his beeing in the ≈øame countries, very profitable and plea≈øant to all ≈øuch as are welwillers, or de≈øirous to heare and read of ≈øtrange thinges.

div.p: BEeing young, and liuing idlelye in my natiue Countrie, ≈øometimes applying my ≈øelfe to the reading of Hi≈øtories, and ≈øtraunge aduentures, wherein I tooke no ≈ømall delight, I found my minde ≈øo much addicted to ≈ø√©e & trauaile into ≈øtrange Countries, thereby to ≈ø√©eke ≈øome aduenture, that in the end to ≈øati≈øfie my ≈øelfe I determined, & was fully re≈øolued, for a time to leaue my Natiue Countrie, and my friendes (although it gr√©eued me) yet the hope I had to accompli≈øh my de≈øire, together with the re≈øolution, taken in the end ouercame my affection and put me in good comfort, to take the matter vpon me, tru≈øting in God that he would further my intent. Which done, being re≈øolued, thereupon I tooke leaue of my Parents, who as then dwelt at Enckhuy≈øen, and beeing ready to imbarke my ≈øelfe, I went to a Fl√©et of ≈øhips that as then lay before the Ta≈ø≈øell, ≈øtaying the winde to ≈øayle for Spaine, and Portingale, where I imbarked my ≈øelfe in a ≈øhip that was bound for S. Lucas de Barameda, beeing determined to trauaile vnto Siuill, where as then I had two bretheren that had continued there certaine yeares before: ≈øo to helpe my ≈øelfe the better, & by their meanes to know the manner and cu≈øtome of tho≈øe Countries, as al≈øo to learne the Spani≈øh tongue.

And the 6. of December, in the yere of our Lord 1576 we put out of ye Ta≈ø≈øel,Anno 1576 the 6. of December we ≈øailed from the Ta≈ø≈øell. (being in all about 80. ≈øhips) & ≈øet our cour≈øe for Spain, and the ninth of the ≈øame month, wee pa≈ø≈øed betw√©ene Douer and Callis, & within thr√©e dayes after wee had the ≈øight of the Cape of Finisterra, and the fift√©ene of the ≈øame moneth we ≈øaw the land of Sintra, otherwi≈øe called the Cape Roexent, from whence the riuer Tegio, or Tagus, runneth into the maine Sea, vppon the which riuer lieth the famous citie of Lisbone, where ≈øome of our Fleet put in, and left vs. The 17. day wee ≈øaw the Cape S. Vincent, & vppon Chri≈øtmas day after we entred into the riuer of S. Lucas de Barameda, where I ≈øtayed two or thr√©e dayes, and then trauailed to Siuill, & the fir≈øt day of Ianuarie following, I entred into the citie, where I found one of my brethren,
but the other was newly ridden to the Court, lying as then in Madrill. And although I had a ≈øpeciall de≈øire pre≈øently to trauaile further, yet for want of the Spani≈øh tongue, without the which men can hardlie pa≈ø≈øe the countrie, I was con≈øtrained to ≈øtay there to learne ≈øome part of their language: meane time it chanced that Don Henry (the la≈øt King of Portingale) died: by which meanes a great contention and debate hapned as then in Portingale, by rea≈øon that the ≈øaid King by his Will and Te≈øtament, made Phillip King of Spaine, his Si≈øters Sonne, lawfull Heire vnto the Crowne of Portingal. Notwith≈øtanding ye Portingals (alwaies deadly enemies to the Spaniards,) were wholly again≈øt it, and elected for their king, Don Antonio, Prior de Ocrato, brothers Son to the King that died before Don Henry: which the King of Spaine hearing, pre≈øently prepared him≈øelfe in per≈øon to goe into Portingale to receaue the Crowne, ≈øending before him the Duke of Alua, with a troupe of men to cea≈øe their ≈øtrife, and pacifie the matter: ≈øo that in the end, partly by force, and partly by mony, hee brought the Countrie vnder his ≈øubiection. Whereupon diuers men went out of Siuill and other places into Portingale, as it is commonlie ≈ø√©ene that men are often addicted to changes and new alterations, among the which my Brother by other mens coun≈øels was one: Fir≈øt trauelling to the borders of Spaine, being a cittie called Badaios, ≈øtanding in the frontiers of Portingale, where they hoped to finde ≈øome better meanes, and they were no ≈øooner ariued there, but they heard news that all was quiet in Portingale, and that Don Antonio was driuen out of the countrie, and Phillip by con≈øent of the Land receyued for King. Wherevpon my Brother pre≈øently changed his minde of trauelling for Portingale, and entred into ≈øeruice with an Amba≈ø≈øador, that on the Kings behalfe was to goe into Italie, with whome he rode: and ariuing in Salamanca hee fell ≈øicke of a di≈øea≈øe called Tauardilha, which at that time raigned throughout the whole Countrie of Spaine, whereof many thou≈øands died: and among the re≈øt my Brother was one.

p.hi: This ≈øickne≈ø≈øe being very contagious, raigned not onely in Spaine,

but al≈øo in Italie, Germany, and almo≈øt throughout all Chri≈øtendome, whereof I my ≈øelfe was ≈øicke being as then in Italie, and by them it was called Coccolucio, becau≈øe ≈øuch as were troubled therewith, were no otherwi≈øe troubled then in the throat, like vnto Hennes which haue the pip, after the which followed many pe≈øtilent feuers, with diuers ≈øtrange fits, which continued not aboue foure dayes.

div.p: Not long before, the plague was ≈øo great in Portingale, that in two yeres ≈øpace there died in Lisbone to the number of 80. thou≈øand people: after the which plague the ≈øaide di≈øea≈øe en≈øued, which wrought great de≈øtruction throughout the whole Countrie of Spaine.

The fift day of Augu≈øt in the ≈øame yeare, hauing ≈øome vnder≈øtanding in the Spani≈øh tongue, I placed my ≈øelfe with a Dutch gentleman, who determined to trauaile into Portingal, to ≈ø√©e the countrie, and with him ≈øtayed to take a more conuenient time for my pretended voyage.

Vppon the fir≈øt of September following we departed from Siuill, & pa≈ø≈øing through diuers Townes and Villages, within eight dayes after we ariued at Badaios, This was a twinne of my forenamed brother decea≈øed. where I found my other Brother following the Court. At the ≈øame time died Anne de Au≈øtria Qu√©ene of Spaine, (Si≈øter to the Emperour Rodulphus, and Daughter to the Emperour Maximilian) the Kings fourth and la≈øt wife, for whom great ≈øorrow was made through all Spaine: her body was conuaied from Badaios to the Cloy≈øter of Saint Laurence in E≈øcuriall, where with great ≈øolemnitie it was buried. We hauing ≈øtayed certaine dayes in Badaios, departed from thence, and pa≈ø≈øed through a Towne called Eluas about two or thr√©e miles off, being the fir≈øt towne in the kingdome of Portingale, for that betw√©ene it and Badaios, the borders of Spaine and Portingale are limited: from thence we trauailed into diuers other places of Portingale, and at the la≈øt ariued at Lisbone, about the twenty of September following, where at that time wee found the Duke of Alua beeing Gouernour there for the King of Spaine, the whole Cittie making great preparation for the Coronation of the King, according to the cu≈øtome of their countrie. Wee beeing in Lisbone, through the change of aire, and corruption of the countrie I fell ≈øicke, and during my ≈øicknes was ≈øeauen times let blood, yet by Gods help I e≈øcaped: and being recouered, not hauing much preferment vnder the gentleman, I left his ≈øeruice, and placed my ≈øelfe with a Marchant vntill I might attaine to better meanes. About the ≈øame time the plague not long before newly begunne, began againe to cea≈øe, for the which cau≈øe the King till then had deferred his enterance into Lisbone, which wholly cea≈øed vppon the fir≈øt day of May, Anno 1581 1581. hee entred with great triumph and magnificence into the cittie of Lisbone, where aboue all others the Dutchmen
had the be≈øt and greate≈øt commendation for beautiful ≈øhews, which was a Gate & a Bridge that ≈øtood vppon the riuer ≈øide where the King mu≈øt fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øe as hee went out of his Gallie to enter into the cittie, being beutified and adorned with many co≈øtly and excellent thinges mo≈øt plea≈øant to behold, euery ≈øtr√©et and place within the cittie being hanged with rich clothes of Tapi≈øtrie and Arras, where they made great triumphes, as the manner is at all Princes Coronations.

The ≈øame yere the twelfth of December, the Duke of Alua died in Lisbone in the kings pallace, being high ≈øteward of Spaine, who during his ≈øicknes for the ≈øpace of fourt√©ene dayes, receaued no ≈øu≈øtenance but only womens milke: his body beeing ≈øeared and ≈øpicen was conuaied into his countrie of Alua.

The ≈øame month (the King beeing yet at Lisbone) died Don Diego Prince of Spaine and Portingale, the kings elde≈øt ≈øon: his body b√©eing inbalmed, was conuaied to Madril, after who≈øe death the king had but one Sonne named Don Phillip, and two Daughters liuing.

About the ≈øame time there ariued at Lisbone the kings ≈øi≈øter, widdow to the decea≈øed Emperour Maximilian, and with her one of her daughters who beeing lame was after placed in a Mona≈øterie of Nuns, they with great triumph were likewi≈øe receaued into the cittie. After the death of Don Diego the kings elde≈øt ≈øonne, all the Lordes and States of Spaine and Portingale, as well ≈øpirituall as temporal a≈ø≈øembled at Lisbone, and there in the kings pre≈øence (according to the ancient cu≈øtome and manner of the countrie) tooke their oathes of faith and allegiance vnto Don Phillip the young Prince of Spaine, and next heire and lawfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of the lung his Father, in his dominions of Spaine, Portingale, and other landes and countries.

1582.The next yeare Anno 1582. a great nauie of ≈øhips was prepared in Lisbone, who≈øe generall was the Marque≈ø≈øe de ≈øancta Cruce, accompanied with the principall gentlemen and captaines both of Spaine and Portingal: who at their own co≈øts and charges therein to ≈øhew the great affection and de≈øire they had to ≈øerue their Prince, ≈øayled with the ≈øaid Nauie to the Flemmi≈øh Ilandes, to fight with Don Antonio that lay about tho≈øe Iles with a Fl√©et of frenchmen, who≈øe Generall was one Phillip Strozzi: The≈øe two Fl√©ets m√©eting together, fought mo≈øt cruelly to the great lo≈ø≈øe of both parts, yet in the ende Don Antonio with his French men was ouerthrowne, and many of them taken pri≈øoners: among the which were diuers gentlemen of great account in France; who by the Marquis commandement were all beheaded in the I≈øland of Saint Michaels. The re≈øt being brought into Spaine, were put into the Gallies, Don Antonio him≈øelfe e≈øcaped in a ≈ømall ≈øhip and the General Strozzi al≈øo, who b√©eing hurt in ye battail died of the ≈øame wound. By this victory the Spaniards were ≈øo proud, that in Lisbone great triumph was holden for the ≈øame, and the Marquis de Sancta Crus, receiued therin with great ioy: which done and all thinges being pacified in Portingale, the King left his Si≈øters ≈øonne Don Albertus Cardinall of Au≈øtria Gouernour of Lisbone, and the whole Countrie; and with the ≈øaide Cardinals mother returned, and kept Court at Madrill in Spaine.

div.head: The 2. Chapter. The beginning of my voyage into the Ea≈øt or Portingale Indies.
div.p:
STaying at Lisbone, the trade of Marchandize there not beeing great, by rea≈øon of the newe & fre≈øh di≈øagr√©eing of the Spaniards and Portingales, occa≈øion being offered to accompli≈øh my de≈øire, there was at the ≈øame time in Lisbone a Monke of S. Dominicks order, named Don frey Vincente de Fon≈øeca, of a noble hou≈øe: who by rea≈øon of his great learning, had of long time b√©ene Chaplen vnto Seba≈øtian King of Portingale, who beeing with him in the battaile of Barbari ‚Ä¢ , where King Seba≈øtian was ≈ølain, was taken pri≈øoner, and from thence ran≈øomed, who≈øe learning and good behauiour beeing knowne to the King of Spaine, hee made great account of him, placing him in his own Chappel, and de≈øiring to prefer him, the Archbi≈øhopricke of all the Indies beeing voide, with confirmation of the Pope he inue≈øted him therewith, although he refu≈øed to accept it, fearing the long and tedious trauaile hee had to make thether, but in the end through the Kings per≈øwa≈øion, hee tooke it vpon him, with promi≈øe within foure or fiue yeares at the furthe≈øt to recall him home againe, and to giue him a better place in Portingale, with the which promi≈øe he tooke the voyage vpon him. I thinking vpon my affaires, v≈øed all meanes I could to get into his ≈øeruice, and with him to trauaile the voiage which I ≈øo much de≈øired, which fell out as I would wi≈øh: for that my Brother that followed the Court, had de≈øired his Ma≈øter (beeing one of his Maie≈øties ≈øecretaries) to
make him pur≈øer in one of the ≈øhips that the ≈øame yere ≈øhould ≈øaile vnto the Ea≈øt Indies, which plea≈øed me well, in ≈øo much that his ≈øaid Ma≈øter was a great friend and acquaintance of the Archbi≈øhops, by which meanes, with ≈ømall intreatie I was entertained in the Bi≈øhops ≈øeruice, and among≈øt the re≈øt my name was written downe, wee being in all forty per≈øons, & becau≈øe my Brother had his choi≈øe which ≈øhip he would be in, he cho≈øe the ≈øhip wherein the Archbi≈øhop ≈øayled, the better to help each other, and in this manner we prepared our ≈øelues to make our voyage, being in all fiue ≈øhips of the burthen of fourt√©ene or ≈øixt√©ene hundreth Tunnes each ≈øhip, their names were the Admirall S. Phillip: the Vize Admirall S. Iacob. The≈øe were two new ≈øhips, one bearing the name of the King, the other of his ≈øonne, the other thr√©e, S, Laurence, S. Franci≈øco, and our ≈øhippe S. Saluator.

1583.Vpon the eight of Aprill, beeing good Friday in the yeare of our Lorde 1583. which commonly is the time when their ≈øhips ≈øet ≈øayle within foure or fiue dayes vnder, or ouer, wee altogether i≈ø≈øued out of the Riuer of Lisbone and put to ≈øea, ≈øetting our cour≈øe for the Ilands of Madera, and ≈øo putting our tru≈øt in God, without who≈øe fauour & helpe we can doe nothing, and all our actions are but vaine, we ≈øayled forwards.

div.head: Chapter 3. The manner and order v≈øed in the ≈øhips in their Indian Voyages.
div.p: THe ≈øhippes are commonlye charged with foure or fiue hundred men at the lea≈øt, ≈øometimes more, ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øe, as there are ≈øouldiers and ≈øaylers to b√©e found. When they go out they are but lightly laden, onely with certaine pipes of wine & oyle, and ≈øome ≈ømall quantitie of Marchandize other thing haue they not in, but bala≈øt, & victuals for the company, for that the mo≈øt and greate≈øt ware that is commonly ≈øent into India, are rials of eight, becau≈øe the principall Factors for pepper doe euery yere ≈øend a great quantitie of mony, therewith to buy pepper, as al≈øo diuers particular Marchants, as being the lea≈øt ware that men can carry into India: for that in the≈øe rials of eight they gaine at the lea≈øt forty per cento: when the ≈øhips are out of the riuer, and enter into the ≈øea, all their men are mu≈øtered, as well ≈øaylers, as ≈øouldiers, and ≈øuch as are founde ab≈øent and left on land, being regi≈øtred in the bookes, are marked by the pur≈øer, that at their returne they may talke with their ≈øuerties, (for that euery man putteth in ≈øuerties,) and the goods of ≈øuch as are ab≈øent, b√©eing found in the ≈øhip are pre≈øently brought foorth and pri≈øed, and an Inuentorie thereof b√©eing made, it is left to bee di≈øpo≈øed at the captaines plea≈øure. The like is done with their goods that die in the ≈øhip, but little of it commeth to the owners hands, being imbe≈øeled and priuily made away.

The Ma≈øter and Pilot haue for their whole voyage forth and home againe, each man 120. Millreyes, euery Millreyes being worth in Dutch money ≈øeauen guilders, and becau≈øe the reckoning of Portingale monie is onely in one ≈øort of money called Reyes, which is the ≈ømale≈øt money to bee founde in that countrie, and although it bee neuer ≈øo great a ≈øumme you doe receaue, yet it is alwaies reckoned by Reyes, whereof 160. is as much as a Key≈øers gilderne, or foure rials of ≈øiluer: ≈øo that two reyes are foure pence, and one reye two pence of Holland money‚ñ™ I haue thought good to ≈øet it downe, the better to ≈øhew and make you vnder≈øtand the accounts they v≈øe by reyes in the countrie of Portingale. But returning to our matter, I ≈øay the Ma≈øter and the Pilot doe receaue before hand, each man twenty foure millreyes, be≈øides that they haue chambers both vnder in the ≈øhip, and cabbins aboue the hatches, as al≈øo primage, & certaine tunnes fraught. The like haue all the other officers in the ≈øhip according to their degr√©es, and although they receaue money in hand, yet it co≈øteth them more in giftes before they get their places, which are giuen by fauour and good will of the Proueador, which is the chiefe officer of the Admiraltie, and yet there is no certaine ordinance for their payes, for that it is dayly altered: but let vs reckon the pay, which is commonly giuen according to the ordinance and maner of our ≈øhip for that yeare.

The chiefe Bote≈øwain hath for his whole pay 50. Millreyes, and receaueth ten in ready money: The Guardian, that is the quarter ma≈øter hath 1400. reyes the month, and for fraught 2800. and receaueth ≈øeuen Millreyes in ready money: The Seto Piloto, which is the Ma≈øters mate, hath 1200. reyes, which is thr√©e duckets the month, and as much fraught as the quarter Ma≈øter: two Carpenters, & two Callafaren which helpe them, haue each man foure duckets a month and 3900. Millreyes fraught. The Steward that giueth out their meate and drinke, and the Merinho, which is he that impri≈øoneth men aborde, and hath charge of all the
munition and powder, with the deliuering forth of the ≈øame, haue each man a Millreyes the month, and 2340. reyes fraught, be≈øides their chambers and fr√©edome of cu≈øtome, as al≈øo all other officers, ≈øaylers, pikemen, ≈øhot, &c. haue euery man after the rate, and euery one that ≈øerueth in the ≈øhip. The Cooper hath thr√©e duckets a month, and 3900 reyes fraught: Two Strinceros, tho≈øe are they which hoi≈øe vp the maine yeard by a wheele, and let it downe againe with a wh√©ele as n√©edis, haue each man one Millreyes the month, and 2800. reyes fraught: Thirty thr√©e ≈øaylers haue each man one Millreyes the month, and 2800. reyes fraught, 37. rowers, haue each man 660. reyes the moneth, and 1860. reyes fraught, foure pagiens which are boyes, haue with their fraught 443. reyes the month, one Ma≈øter gunner, and eight vnder him, haue each man a different pay, ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe: The ≈øurgion likewi≈øe hath no certaine pay: The factor and the pur≈øer haue no pay but only their chambers, that is below vnder hatches, a chamber of twentie pipes, for each man ten pipes, and aboue hatches each man his cabbin to ≈øl√©epe in, whereof they make great profit. The≈øe are all the officers and other per≈øons which ≈øayle in the ≈øhip, which haue for their portion euery day in victuals, each man a like, as well the greate≈øt as the lea≈øt, a pound and thr√©e quarters of Bi≈øket, halfe a Can of Wine, a Can of water, an Arroba which is 32. pound of ≈øalt fle≈øh the moneth, ≈øome dryed fi≈øh, onyons and garlicke are eaten in the beginning of the voyage, as being of ≈ømall valew, other proui≈øions, as Suger, Honny, Rea≈øons, Prunes, Ry≈øe, & ≈øuch like, are kept for tho≈øe which are ≈øicke: yet they get but little thereof, for that the officers k√©epe it for them≈øelues, and ≈øpend it at their plea≈øures, not letting much goe out of their fingers: as for the dre≈ø≈øing of their meate, wood, pots, and pans, euery man mu≈øt make his owne proui≈øion: be≈øides all this there is a Clarke and ≈øteward for the Kings ≈øouldiers that haue their parts by them≈øelues, as the ≈øaylers haue.

This is the order and manner of theyr voyage when they ≈øayle vnto the Indies, but when they returne againe, they haue no more but each man a portion of Bi≈øket and water vntill they come to the Cape de Bona E≈øperance, and from thence home they mu≈øt make their own proui≈øions. The ≈øouldiers that are pa≈ø≈øengers, haue nothing els but fr√©e pa≈ø≈øage, that is roome for a che≈øt vnder hatches, and a place for their bed in the or loope, and may not come away without the Viceroyes pa≈ø≈øeport, and yet they mu≈øt haue b√©ene fiue yeres ≈øouldiers in the Indies before they can haue licence, but the ≈ølaues mu≈øt pay fraught for their bodies, & cu≈øtome to the King, as in our voyage home againe we will at large declare.

The 15. of Aprill we e≈øpied the Iland of Madera and Porto Sancto, where the ≈øhips v≈øe to ≈øeperate them≈øelues, each ≈øhip k√©eping on his cour≈øe, that they may get before each other into India for their mo≈øt commodities, and to di≈øpatch the ≈øooner; whereby in the night, and by tides they leaue each others company, each following his owne way.

The 24. of Aprill we fell vpon the coa≈øte of Guinea which beginneth at nine degr√©es, and ≈øtretcheth vntill wee come vnder the Equinoctiall, where wee haue much thunder, lightning‚ñ™ and many ≈øhowers of raine, with ≈øtormes of wind, which pa≈ø≈øe ≈øwiftly ouer, & yet fall with ≈øuch force, that at euery ≈øhower we are forced to ≈øtrike ≈øayle, & let the maine yeard fall to the middle of the ma≈øt, & many times cleane down, ≈øometimes ten or twelue times eueryday: there wee finde a mo≈øt extreame heate, ≈øo that all the water in the ≈øhip ≈øtinketh, whereby men are forced to ≈øtop their no≈øes when they drinke, but when wee are pa≈øt the Equinoctiall it is good againe, & the nearer wee are vnto the land, the more it ≈øtormeth, raineth, thundreth and calmeth: ≈øo that mo≈øt commonly the ≈øhippes are at the lea≈øt two monthes before they can pa≈ø≈øe the line: Then they finde a winde which they name the generall winde, and it is a South ea≈øt winde, but it is a ≈øide wind, and we mu≈øt alway lie ≈øide waies in the wind almo≈øt vntill wee come to the cape de Bona Speranza, and becau≈øe that vpon the coa≈øt of Bra≈øillia about 18. degr√©es, on the ≈øouth ≈øide lieth great ≈ølakes or ≈øhallowes, which the Portingales call Abra ‚Ä¢ hos, that reach 70. miles into the ≈øea on the right ≈øide, to pa≈ø≈øe them, the ≈øhips hold vp mo≈øt vnto the coa≈øt of Guinea, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid Flattes, otherwi≈øe if they fall too low and keepe inwardes, they are con≈øtrained to turne againe vnto Portingale, and many times in danger to be lo≈øt, as it hapned to our Admirall Saint Phillip, which in the yeare 1582. 1582. fell by night vpon the Flats, and was in great danger to be lo≈øt, yet recouered againe, & ≈øayled backe to Portingale, and now this yeare to ≈øhunne the Flats ≈øhee kept ≈øo neare the coa≈øt of Guinea, that by meanes of the great calmes and raynes, ≈øhee was forced to driue vp and downe two months together, before ≈øhee could pa≈ø≈øe the line, & came two months after the other ≈øhips into India: Therefore men mu≈øt take heed, and k√©epe them≈øelues from comming too neare the coa≈øt, to ≈øhun
the calmes and ≈øtormes, and al≈øo not to hold too farre of thereby to pa≈ø≈øe the Flats & ≈øhallowes, wherein con≈øi≈øteth the whole Indian Voyage.

The 15. of May being about fiftie miles beyond the Equinoctiall line Northwardes, we e≈øpied a French ≈øhip, which put vs all in great feare, by rea≈øon that mo≈øt of our men were ≈øicke, as it commonly hapneth in tho≈øe countries through the exc√©eding heate: & further they are for the mo≈øt part ≈øuch as neuer haue beene at Sea before that time, ≈øo that they are not able to do much, yet we di≈øcharged certaine great ≈øhot at him, wherewith he left vs, (after he had played with vs for a ≈ømal time) and pre≈øently lo≈øt the ≈øight of him, wherewith our men were in better comfort. The ≈øame day about euening, wee di≈øcried a great ≈øhip ‚Ä¢ , which wee iudged to bee of our Fleet, as after wee perceiued, for it made towards vs to ≈øpeake with vs, and it was the Saint Franci≈øco, wherewith wee were glad.

The
‚Ä¢ 6. of May, wee pa≈ø≈øed the Equinoctiall line which runneth through the middle of the Iland of Saint Thomas, by the coa≈øt of Guinea, and then wee began to ≈ø√©e the ≈øouth ≈øtar, and to loo≈øe the north ≈øtar, and founde the ≈øunne at twelue of the clocke at noone to be in the north, and after that wee had a ≈øouth ea≈øt wind, called a general wind, which in tho≈øe partes bloweth all the yeare through.

The 29. of May being Whit≈øonday, the ≈øhips of an ancient cu≈øtome, doe v≈øe to chu≈øe an Emperour among them≈øelues, and to change all the officers in the ≈øhip, and to hold a great fea≈øt, which continueth thr√©e or foure dayes together, which wee ob≈øeruing cho≈øe an Emperour, and being at our banket, by meanes of certaine words that pa≈ø≈øed out of ≈øome of their mouthes, there fell great ≈øtrife and contention among vs, which proc√©eded ≈øo farre, that the tables were throwne downe and lay on the ground, and at the lea≈øt a hundred rapiers drawne, without re≈øpecting the Captaine or any other for he lay vnder foote, and they trod vpon him, and had killed each other, and thereby had ca≈øt the ≈øhip away, if the Archbi≈øhop had not come out of his chaÃÑ ber among them, willing them to cea≈øe, wherwith they ≈øtayed their hands, who pre≈øently commaunded euery man on paine of death, that all their Rapiers, Poynyardes, and other weapons ≈øhould bee brought into his chamber, which was done, whereby all thinges were pacified, the fir≈øt and principall beginners being puni≈øhed & layd in irons, by which meanes they were quiet.

The 12. of Iune we pa≈ø≈øed beyond the afore ≈øaid Flats and ≈øhallowes of Bra≈øillia, whereof all our men were exc√©eding glad, for thereby we were a≈ø≈øured that we ≈øhould not for that time put backe to Portingale againe, as many doe, and then the generall wind ≈øerued vs, vntill wee came to the riuer of Rio de Plata, where wee got before the wind to the cape de Bona Speranza.

The 20. of the ≈øame month, the S. Fran≈øi≈øcus that ≈øo long had kept vs coÃÑpany‚ñ™ was againe out of ≈øight: and the eleauenth of Iuly after, our Ma≈øter iudged vs to bee about 5 ‚Ä¢ . miles from the cape de Bona Speranza: wherefore he was de≈øired by the Archbi≈øhop to k√©epe in with the land, that wee might ≈ø√©e the Cape. It was then mi≈øtie weather, ≈øo that as we had made with the laÃÑd about one houre or more, wee perceiued land right before vs, and were within two miles thereof, which by rea≈øon of the darke and mi≈øty weather we could no ≈øooner perceiue, which put vs in great feare, for our iudgement was cleane contrarie, but the weather beginning to cleare vp, we knew the land, for it was a part or bank of the point called Cabo Fal≈øo, which is about fift√©ene miles on this ≈øide the cape de Bona Speranza, towards Mo≈ø≈øambique the cape de Bona Speranza lieth vnder 34. degr√©es ≈øouthward, there wee had a calme and faire weather, which continuing about halfe a day, in the meane time with our lines we got great ≈øtore of fi≈øhes vppon the ≈øame land at ten or twelue fadoms water, it is an excellent fi≈øh much like to Haddocks, the Portingales call them Pe≈øcados.

The twenty of the ≈øame month wee met againe with Saint Franci≈øco, and ≈øpake with her, and ≈øo kept company together till the 24. of Iune, when wee lo≈øt her againe. The ≈øame day wee ≈øtroke all our ≈øayles, becau≈øe wee had a contrarie wind, and lay two dayes ≈øtill driuing vp and downe, not to loo≈øe anie way, meane time wee were again≈øt the high land of Tarradona ‚Ä¢ al, which beginneth in 32. degrees, and endeth in 30. and is di≈øtant from Capo de Bona Speranza 150. miles, in this place they coÃÑmonly v≈øe to tak ‚Ä¢ coun≈øell of all the officers of the ≈øhip, whether it is be≈øt for theÃÑ to ≈øayle through within the land of S. Lauren≈øo, or without it, for that within the land they ≈øayle to Mo≈ø≈øambique, and from thence to Goa, and ≈øayling without it they cannot come at Goa, by rea≈øon they fal down by meanes of the ≈øtreame, and ≈øo mu≈øt ≈øayle vnto Cochin, which lieth 100. miles lower then Goa, and as the ≈øhips leaue the cape, then it is not good to make towards Mo≈ø≈øambique, becau≈øe they cannot come in time to Goa, by rea≈øon of the great calmes that are within the land, but
they that pa≈ø≈øe the Cape in the month of Iuly, may well goe to Mo≈ø≈øambique, becau≈øe they haue time inough there to refre≈øh them≈øelues, and to take in fre≈øh water and other victuals, and ≈øo to lie at anker ten or twelue dayes together, but ≈øuch as pa≈ø≈øe the cape in the month of Augu≈øt, doe come too late, and mu≈øt ≈øayle about towardes Cochin, thereby to loo≈øe no time, yet it is dangerous & much more comber≈øome, for that commonly they are ≈øicke of ≈øwolen legges, ≈øore bellies, and other di≈øea≈øes. The 30. of Iuly, wee were again≈øt the point of the cape called Das Corentes, which are 130. miles di≈øtant from Terra Donatal, and lieth vnder 24. degr√©es Southwarde, there they begin to pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene the Ilands.

figure.head: The Ile Madaga≈øcar, otherwi≈øe called Saint Laurence.

p.hi: (The Iland of S. Lauren≈øo, is by Marcus Paulus named the great Iland of Maga≈øtar, by Andrea Theuet it is called Madaga≈øcar, and is the greate≈øt of all the Ea≈øt Ilandes, for it is greater in compa≈ø≈øe then eyther of the Kingdomes of Ca≈øtile or Portingale, and lieth on the other ≈øide of Africa as we pa≈ø≈øe the cape de Bona Speranza, it containeth in length (as Theuet de≈øcribeth) 72 degrees, and in bredth eleauen degrees, and is in coÃÑpa≈ø≈øe (as ≈øome hold opinion) 3000 Italian miles, and as ≈øome write 4000. which ≈øhould bee ≈øixe or eight hundred Dutch miles. This Iland is iudged to be very temperate, and therefore well peopled, but beleeue in Mahomet. Marcus Paulus ≈øayeth, that the Iland is gouerned by foure ancient men, it is full of wilde bea≈øts and ≈øtrange foules, whereof he writeth many fables, not worthie the rehear≈øall. This Iland hath Elephants & all kind of bea≈øts which haue but one horn, wherof one is called an Indian a≈ø≈øe, with whole feet vncloueÃÑ, an other is called Orix, with clouen feet: it hath many ≈ønakes, efftes, & great ≈øtore of woodes of redde Sandale, which are there little e≈øteemed for the great abundance, there the Sea yeeldeth much Amber: it aboundeth al≈øo in Rice, Barley, Oranges, Lemons, Citrons, & Millons, which are ≈øo great that a man can hardly gripe them, both red, white, & yellow, and better then ours, and much ginger which they eate greene, Hony & Sugar in ≈øuch abundance, that they know not whether to ≈øend it, Saffron, many medicinable hearbs, and Indian nuts. It likewi≈øe yeeldeth Siluer, and hath manie Riuers, beautifull Fountaines, and diuers Hauens, whether many Sara≈øins & Mores doe bring their Marchandi≈øe, as clothes of gold & Siluer, Linnen made of cotton, wooll, and ≈øuch like.)

div.p:
From S. Lauren≈øo to Mo≈ø≈øambique, which lieth from the firme land of Das Corentes 120. miles, and is an Iland of 220. miles long, ≈øtretching north & ≈øouth, and in breadth 70. miles, beginning from the fir≈øt point, vntill you come at the cape in 26. degrees,
and endeth in the North in 11. degr√©es. The people of the Iland are blacke like tho≈øe of Mo≈øsambique, and goe naked, but the haire of their heades is not ≈øo much curled as theirs of Mo≈øsambique, and not full ≈øo blacke. The Portingales haue no ≈øpeciall traffique there, becau≈øe there is not much to be had, for as yet it is not very well known. The 1. of Augu≈øt we pa≈ø≈øed the flats called os Baixos de Iudea, that is, the Flats of the Iewes, which are di≈øtant from the cape das Corentes, 30. miles, and lie betw√©en the Iland of S. Laurence & the firme land, that is from the Iland fiftie miles, and from the firme land ≈øeauenty miles, which Flats begin vnder 22. degr√©es and a halfe, and continue to twentie one degr√©es: there is great care to bee taken le≈øt men fall vpon them, for they are very dangerous, and many ≈øhips haue bin lo≈øt there, and of late in Anno 1585. 1585. a ≈øhip comming from Portingale called S. Iago beeing Admirall of the Fleet, and was the ≈øame that the fir≈øt voiage went with vs from Lisbone for vice Admirall, as in another place we ≈øhall declare.

The fourth of Augu≈øt we di≈øcried the land of Mo≈øsambique, which is di≈øtant from the Flattes of the Iewes nintie miles vnder fifteene degr√©es ≈øouthwards. The next day we entred into the road of Mo≈øsambique, and as we entered we e≈øpied the fore≈øaid ≈øhip called S. Iago which entered with vs, and it was not aboue one houre after we had de≈øcried it, beeing the fir≈øt time wee had ≈ø√©ene it ≈øince it left vs at the Iland of Madera, where we ≈øeperated our ≈øelues. There wee found likewi≈øe two more of our ≈øhips, Saint Laure ‚Ä¢ zo and Saint Franci≈øco, which the day before were come thether with a ≈ømall ≈øhip that was to ≈øayle to Malacca, which commonly ≈øetteth out of Portingale, a month before any of the ≈øhips do ≈øet ≈øayle for India, only becau≈øe they haue a longer voiage to make, yet doe they ordinarily ≈øayle to Mo≈øsambique to take in ≈øweete water & fre≈øh victuals as their voiage falleth out, or their victuals ≈øcanteth: If they goe not thether, theÃÑ they ≈øaile about on the back ≈øide of ye Iland of ≈øaint Lauren≈øo, not ≈øetting their cour≈øe for Mo≈øsambique. Being at Mo≈ø≈øambique wee were foure of our Fl√©ete in company together, only wanting the Saint Phillip, which had holden her cour≈øe ≈øo nere the coa≈øt of Guinea, (the better to ≈øhun the Flats of Bracillia that are called Abrollios, whereon the yere before ≈øhe had once fallen,) that ≈øhe was ≈øo much becalmed that ≈øhe could not pa≈ø≈øe the Equinoctiall line in long time after vs, neyther yet the cape de Bona Speranza without great ≈øtorms & foule weather, as it ordinarilie happeneth to ≈øuch as come late thether, whereby ≈øhee was compelled to compa≈ø≈øe about & came vnto Cochin about two months after we were al ariued at Goa, hauing pa≈ø≈øed and endured much mi≈øery and foule weather, with ≈øicknes and di≈øea≈øes, as ≈øwellings of the legs, and the ≈øcorbuicke, and paine in their bellies &c.

div.head: The 4. Chapter. The de≈øcription of Mo≈ø≈øambique, which lieth vnder 15. degrees on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line vppon the coa≈øt of Melinde, otherwi≈øe called Abex or Abexim.

p.hi: MO≈ø≈øambique is a Towne in the Iland of Pra≈øio with a ≈øafe, (although a ≈ømall) hauen, on the right ≈øide towardes the cape: they haue the golden mines called Sofala, on the left ≈øide the rich towne of Quiloa: and by rea≈øon of the foggie mi≈øtes incident to the ≈øame, the place is both barren & vnhol≈øome, yet the people are rich by rea≈øon of the ≈øituation. In time pa≈øt it was inhabited by people that beleeued in Mahoomet, being ouercom & kept in ≈øubiection by the tirant of Quiloa, & his lieftenant (which the Arabians called Zequen) that gouerned them.

div.p:
Mo≈ø≈øambique is a little Iland, di≈øtant about halfe a mile from the firme land, in a corner of the ≈øaid firme land, for that ye firme land on the north ≈øide ≈øtretcheth further into ye ≈øea theÃÑ it doth, & before it there lie two ≈ømal Ilands named S. George & S. Iacob, which are euen wt the corner of the firme land, and betw√©ene tho≈øe two Ilands not inhabited, & the firme land the ≈øhips doe ≈øayle to Mo≈ø≈øambique leauing the Ilands ≈øouthward, on the left hand, and the firm land ‚Ä¢ n the north, and ≈øo without a Pilot compa≈ø≈øe about a mile into the ≈øea to Mo≈ø≈øambique, for it is d√©epe enough, and men may ea≈øily ≈øhun the ≈øands that lie vpon the firme land, becau≈øe they are openly ≈ø√©ene. The ≈øhips harbour ≈øo neare to the Iland and the ‚Ä¢ ortre≈ø≈øe of Mo≈ø≈øambique, that they may throw a ≈øtone out of their ≈øhip vppon the land, and ≈øometimes farther, and lie betw√©ene the Iland and the firme land, which are di≈øtant halfe a mile from each other, ≈øo that the ≈øhips lie there as ≈øafely as in a riuer or hauen. The Iland of Mo≈ø≈øambique is about halfe a mile in compa≈ø≈øe, flat land, and bordered about with a white ≈øand: Therein growe many Indian palmes or nut tr√©es, & ≈øome Orange, Apple,

Lemmon, Citron, and Indian Figge tr√©es: but other kindes of fruit which are common in India are there verie ≈øcarce. Corne and other graine with Rice and ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øarie marchandizes are brought thether out of India, but for bea≈øts and foule, as O ‚Ä¢ en, ≈øh√©ep, Goats, Swine, Hennes, &c. there are great aboundance and very good and cheape. In the ≈øame Iland are found ≈øh√©epe of fiue quarters in quantitie, for that their tayles are ≈øo broad and thicke, that there is as much fle≈øh vpon them, as vpon a quarter of their body, and they are ≈øo fatte that men can hardlie brooke them. There are certaine Hennes that are ≈øo blacke both of feathers, fle≈øh, and bones, that being ≈øodden they ≈ø√©eme as black as inke: yet of very ≈øw√©et ta≈øte, and are accounted better then the other: whereof ≈øome are likewi≈øe found in India, but not ≈øo many as in Mo≈ø≈øambique. Porke is there a very co≈øtly di≈øh, and excellent faire and ≈øw√©ete fle≈øh, and as by experience it is found, it farre ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all other fle≈øh: ≈øo that the ≈øicke are forbidden to eate any kinde of fle≈øh but onely Porke, becau≈øe of the excellency thereof.

p.hi: MO≈ø≈øambique ≈øignifieth two places, one which is a whole kingdome lying in Africa, behinde the cape of Bona Speranza, betweene Monomotapa & Quiloa, the other certaine Ilands herafter drawne and de≈øcribed, lying on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line vnder 14. degrees and a halfe, whereof the greate≈øt is called Mo≈ø≈øambique, the other two Saint Iacob and Saint George. The≈øe Ilands lie almo≈øt in the mouth of a riuer which in Africa is called Moghincats.

About Mo≈ø≈øambique is a verie great & a ≈øafe hauen, fit to receiue and harbour all ≈øhips that come and goe both to & from Portingal & the Indies, and although both the Kingdome and the Iland are not very great, yet are they very rich and abundant in all kinde of thinges, as appeareth in the de≈øcription of the ≈øame.

Mo≈ø≈øambique the chiefe & greate≈øt of them is inhabited by two maner of people, Chri≈øtians and Mahometanes, the Chri≈øtians are Portingales, or of the Portingales race, there is al≈øo a ca≈øtle wherin the Portingales keepe garri≈øon, from whence al≈øo all other ca≈øtles and fortes thereabouts are ≈øupplied with their nece≈ø≈øaries, ≈øpeciallie Sofala, where the rich mine of Gold lieth: there the Portingale ≈øhips doe v≈øe to harbour in winter time, when of wind or by meanes of foule weather, they cannot accoÃÑpli≈øh their voiage.
The Indian ≈øhips doe likewi≈øe in that place take in new victuals and fre≈øh water.

This Iland beeing fir≈øt di≈øcouered by the Portingales, was the only meanes that they found the Indies: for that froÃÑ thence they v≈øed to take Pilots, which taught them the way: touching the manner and cu≈øtomes of the≈øe people, read the Authors de≈øcription at large, they are good ≈øhooters in musket and caliuer, and expert Fi≈øhermen.

Sayling along further by the coa≈øt towardes the Indies you pa≈ø≈øe by Quiloa (which in times pa≈øt was called Rapta) not great but verie faire by rea≈øon of the great trees that grow there, which are alwaies fre≈øh and greene, as al≈øo for the diuer≈øities of victuals, & it is al≈øo an Ilande lying about the mouth of the great Riuer Coauo, which hath her head or ≈øpring out of the ≈øame lake from whence Nilus doth i≈ø≈øue. This Iland is inhabited by Mahometans, and they are all mo≈øt white apparelled in ≈øilk and clothes of cotton wooll: their women weare bracelets of gold and precious ≈øtones about their neckes and armes: they haue great quantitie of ≈øiluer workes, & are not ≈øo browne as the men, & well membered: their hou≈øes are commonly made of ≈øtone, chalke, and wood, with plea≈øant gardens of all kind of fruit and ≈øweet flowers: from this Iland the kingdome taketh his name. This point asketh a larger di≈øcour≈øe, which you ≈øhal finde in the leafe following.

div.p: They haue no ≈øw√©et water in this Iland to drinke, but they fetch it from the firme land, out of a place called by the Portingales Caba≈øer, and they v≈øe in their hou≈øes great pots which come out of India, to k√©epe their water in.

The Portingales haue therein a verie faire and ≈øtrong ca≈øtle which now about 10. or 12. yeares pa≈øt was fullie fini≈øhed, and ≈øtandeth right again≈øt the fir≈øt of the vnhabited little Ilands, where the ≈øhips mu≈øt come in, and is one of the be≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt built of all the Ca≈øtles throughout the whole Indies, yet haue they but ≈ømall ≈øtore of ordinance or munition, as al≈øo not any ≈øouldiers more then the Captaine and his men that dwel therin. But when occa≈øion ≈øerueth, the married Portingales that dwell in the Iland, which are about 40. or 50. at the mo≈øt, are all bound to k√©epe the Ca≈øtle, for that the Iland hath no other defence then onely that Ca≈øtle, the re≈øt lieth open and is a flat ≈øand. Round about within the Ca≈øtle are certaine

whollie accu≈øtomed therunto as if they were Hor≈øes, Moyles, or A≈ø≈øes. I haue ≈øpoken with men that came from thence, and haue ≈ø√©en them, and affirme it for a truth.

But returning to our matter of the gouernmement and v≈øage of the Portingales and their Captaine, I ≈øay that the Captaine maketh the commoditie of his place within thr√©e yeares ≈øpace that hee remaineth there, which amounteth to the value of 300. thou≈øand Duckets, that is nine tunnes of golde: as while we remained there, the Captaine named Nuno Velio Perena him≈øelfe ≈øhewed vs, and it is mo≈øt in gold that commeth from Sofala & Monomotapa as I ≈øaid before, from Mo≈ø≈øambique they carrie into India Gold, Ambergris, Eben wood, and Iuorie, and many ≈ølaues both men and women which are carried thether, becau≈øe they are the ≈øtronge≈øt Moores in all the Ea≈øt couÃÑ tries, to doe their filthie≈øt and harde≈øt labor, wherein they onely v≈øe them: They ≈øayle from thence into India but once euery year, in the month of Augu≈øt till half September, becau≈øe that throughout the whole countries of India they mu≈øt ≈øayle with Mon≈ø≈øoyns, that is with the tides of the year, which they name by the windes, which blow certaine monthes in the yeare, whereby they make their account to goe and come from the one place to the other, & the time that men may commonly ≈øayle betw√©ene Mo≈ø≈øambique and India, is 30. dayes little more or le≈ø≈øe, and then they ≈øtay in India till the month of Aprill, when the winde or Mon≈ø≈øoyn commeth againe to ≈øerue them for Mo≈ø≈øambique, ≈øo that euery yeare once, there goeth and commeth one ≈øhippe for the Captaine that carrieth and bringeth his marchandi≈øe, and no man may traffique from thence into India, but only tho≈øe that dwel and are married in Mo≈ø≈øambique, for that ≈øuch as are vnmarried may not ≈øtay there by ≈øpeciall priuiledge from the King of Portingall graunted vnto tho≈øe that inhabite there, to the end the I≈øland ≈øhould be peopled, and therby kept and maintained.

Behind Mo≈ø≈øambique lyeth the countrey of Pre≈øter Iohn, which is called by them the countrey of Abexines, wherevpon the coa≈øt of Mo≈ø≈øambique vnto the red ≈øea is commonly called the coa≈øt of Abex, and diuers men of Pre≈øter Iohns land do ≈øend men of that country, ≈øome being ≈ølaues, and others tree into India, which ≈øerue for Saylors in the Portingalles ≈øhippes, that traffique in tho≈øe countries froÃÑ place to place, who≈øe pictures & counterfets, as al≈øo their religioÃÑ, maner of liuing, and cu≈øtomes doeth hereafter follow in the pictures of India. This coa≈øt of Abex is al≈øo by the Portingalles called the coa≈øt of Melinde, becau≈øe that vpon the ≈øame coa≈øt lyeth a towne and a Kingdome of that name, which was the fir≈øt towne and Kingdome that in the Portingals fir≈øt di≈øcouerie of tho≈øe countries, did receiue them peaceably without trea≈øon or deceit, and ≈øo to this day doth yet continue.

Wee ≈øtayed at Mo≈ø≈øambique for the ≈øpace of 15. dayes, to prouide fre≈øh water and victuails for the ≈øupplying of our wants, in the which time diuers of our men fel ≈øicke and died, by rea≈øon of the vnaccu≈øtomed ayre of the place, which of it ≈øelfe is an vnhol≈øome land, and an euill aire by meanes of the great and vnmea≈øurable heat.

The 20. of Augu≈øt wee ≈øet ≈øaile with all our companie, that is, our foure ≈øhippes of one fl√©ete that came from Portingall, and a ≈øhippe of the Captaines of Mo≈ø≈øambique, who≈øe thr√©e yeares were then fini≈øhed, his name was Don Pedro de Ca≈øtro, in who≈øe place the afore≈øaide Nuno Velio Pereira, was then come. The ≈øaid Captain Don Pedro returned wt his wife & family again into India, for that the Kinges commandement and ordinance is, that after the expiration of their thr√©e yeares office, they mu≈øt yet ≈øtay thr√©e years more in India at the commandement of the Vice Roy of India, in the kings ≈øeruice, at their owne charges, before they mu≈øt returne into Portingall, vnle≈ø≈øe they bring a ≈øpeciall patent from the King, that after they haue continued thr√©e yeares in their office, they may returne into Portingal againe, which is very ≈øeldome ≈ø√©ene, vnle≈ø≈øe it be by ≈øpeciall fauour, and likewi≈øe no man may trauell out of India vnle≈ø≈øe hee haue the Vice Royes Pa≈øport, and without it they are not ≈øuffred to pa≈ø≈øe, for it is very narrowly looked into.

The 24. of Augu≈øt in the morning w√©e de≈øcryed two I≈ølandes, which are called In≈øula de Comora, and In≈øula de Don Ian de Ca≈øtro. The I≈ølande Comora lyeth di≈øtant from Mo≈ø≈øambique 60. miles, Northwardes vnder 11. degr√©es on the South ≈øide is a very high land, ≈øo high that in a whole dayes ≈øaile with a good winde wee could not lo≈øe the ≈øight therof, the ≈øame day the ≈øhippes ≈øeperated them≈øelues againe, according to the ancient manner, for the occa≈øions afore≈øaid.

The third of September we once againe pa≈ø≈øed the Equinoctiall line, which runneth betw√©ene Melinde and Braua, townes lying vppon the coa≈øt of Abex, and the line is froÃÑ Mo≈ø≈øambique Northwards 230. miles, and from the line to the Cape de Quardafum are 190. miles, and lyeth vnder 12. degr√©es
on the North ≈øide of the Equinoctiall, vpon this coa≈øt betw√©ene Mo≈ø≈øambique, and the Cape de Guardafum, lyeth the≈øe townes, Quiloa, in time pa≈øt called Rapta Momba≈øsa, which is a towne ≈øituate in a little I≈øland of the ≈øame name, which ≈øheweth a farre off to be high ≈øandie downes, and hath a hauen with two fortes to defende it, Melinde, Pate, Braua, and Magadoxo, each being a kingdome of it ≈øelfe, holding the lawe of Mahomet: the people are ≈øomewhat of a ≈øallower colour then tho≈øe of Mo≈ø≈øambique, with ≈øhining hayre, gouerning their Citties after the manner of the Arabians, and other Mahometanes. This corner or Cape of Guardafum is the ende of the coa≈øt of Abex or Melinde, and by this cape Ea≈øt Northea≈øt 20. miles within the Sea lyeth the rich I≈øland called Socotora, where they find Aloes, which taketh the name of the I≈ølande being called Aloe Socotorina, and is the verie be≈øt, being clo≈øe and fa≈øt, and from thence is it carried and conueyed into al places.

By this corner and I≈øland beginneth the mouth or enterance of the
‚Ä¢ ≈øtreito de Mecka, for that within the ≈øame vpon the coa≈øt of Arabia lyeth the citie of Mecka, where the body of Mahomet hangeth in the ayre in an iron che≈øt, vnder a sky made of Adamant ≈øtone, which is greatly ≈øought vnto, & vi≈øited by many Turkes and Arabians. This entery is al≈øo called the redde ≈øea, not that the water is redde, but onely becau≈øe there are certain redde hilles lying about the ≈øame, that y√©eld redde marble ≈øtones: and becau≈øe the ≈øand in ≈øome places is redde, it is the ≈øame ≈øea which Moy≈øes with the children of I≈ørael pa≈ø≈øed through on dry land.

From the hooke or cape de Guardafum, which le≈ø≈øeneth, and is narrow inwardes towardes Sues, in time pa≈øt called Ar≈øinoe, (which is the vttermo≈øt town where the narrowne≈ø≈øe or ≈øtraight endeth) are 360. miles, and from thence ouer land to the Mediterranean ≈øea in Italie are 90. myles, the ≈øtraight or narrownes is in the entraÃÑce, & al≈øo within the broade≈øt place 40. miles, and in ≈øome places narrower: it hath al≈øo diuers I≈ølands, and on the one ≈øide inwarde by Sues Northward Arabia de≈øerta, on the other ≈øide ≈øouth ward Aegipt, where the riuer Nilus hath her cour≈øe, and ≈øomewhat lower towardes the Indian ≈øeas Arabia Felix: and on the other ≈øide right again≈øt it, the countrey of Abexynes, or Pre≈øter Iohns land, vpon the hooke or corner of Arabia Felix, the Portingals in time pa≈øt helde a fort called Aden, but nowe they haue none, whereby at this pre≈øent the Turks come out of the ≈øtraight or mouth of the redde ≈øea, with Gallies that are made in Sues, and doe much hurt and iniurie vppon the coa≈øt of Abex or Melinde, as when time ≈øerueth we ≈øhall declare.

Hauing againe pa≈ø≈øed the line, we had the ≈øight of the North Star, whereof vpon the coa≈øt of Guinea, from the I≈øland of S. Thomas vntill this tyme, wee had lo≈øt the fight. The 4. of September wee e≈øpyed a ≈øhippe of our owne fl√©ete, and ≈øpake with him: it was the S. Franci≈øco, which ≈øayled with vs till the 7. day, and then left vs. The 13. of September wee ≈øaw an other ≈øhippe which was the S. Iacob, which ≈øailed out of ≈øight again and ≈øpake not to vs.

The 20. of September we perceiued many Snakes ≈øwimming in the ≈øea, being as great as Eeles, and other thinges like the ≈øcales of fi≈øh, which the Portingals call Vintijns, which are halfe Ryalles of ≈øiluer, Portingall money, becau≈øe they are like vnto it: the≈øe ≈øwimme and driue vpon the ≈øea in great quantities, which is a certain ≈øign & token of the Indian coa≈øt.

Not long after with great ioy we de≈øcried land, and found ground at 47. f ‚Ä¢ dome d√©epe, being the land of Bardes, which is the vttermo≈øt ende and corner of the enterie of the Riuer Goa, of being about thr√©e miles from the Citie: it is a high land where the ≈øhippes of India do anker and vnlade, and from thence by boates their wares are carryed to the towne. That day we ankered without in the ≈øea about thr√©e miles from the land, becau≈øe it was calme, and the fludde was pa≈øt; yet it is not without danger, and hath round about a faire and fa≈øt land to anker in, for as then it beganne in tho≈øe places to be ≈øummer.

The 21. being ye next day, there came vnto vs diuers boats called Almadias, which borded vs, bringing wt theÃÑ all maner of fre≈øh victuailes from the land, as fre≈øh bread & fruit, ≈øome of them were Indians that are chri≈øtened: there came likewi≈øe a Galley to fetch the Archbi≈øhoppe, and brought him to a place called Pangijn, which is in the middle way, betw√©ene Goa and the roade of Bardes, and lyeth vpon the ≈øame Riuer: Here hee was welcommed and vi≈øited by the Vice Roy of India, named Don Franci≈øco Ma≈øcarenias, and by all the Lordes and Gentlemen of the countrey, as well ≈øpirituall as temporall: The Magi≈øtrates of the towne de≈øired him to ≈øtay there ten or twelue dayes, while preparation might bee made to receiue him with triumph into the cittie, as their manner is, which hee granted them. The ≈øame day in the afternoone we entred the Riuer, into the roade vnder the lande of Bardes, being the 21. of September Anno 1583. being
fiue monthes and 13. dayes after our putting forth of the Riuer of Lisbone, (hauing ≈øtayed 15. daies at Mo≈øambique (which was one of the ≈øp√©edie≈øt and ≈øhorte≈øt voyages that in many yeares before and ≈øince that time was euer performed: There we founde the ≈øhippe named Saint Laurence, which arriued there a day before vs: The 22. day the S. Iacob came thither, and the next day after arriued the S. Francis.

There dyed in our ≈øhippe 30. per≈øons, among the which, ≈øome of them were ≈ølaues, and one high Dutchman, that had beene one of the King of Spaines garde: euery man had beene ≈øicke once or twice and let bloode. This is commonly the number of men that ordinarily dyed in the ≈øhips, ≈øometimes more ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øe. About ten or twelue years ≈øince it chaunced that a Vice Roy for the King, named Ruy Loren≈øo Detauora ≈øayled for India, that had in his ≈øhippe 1100. men, and there happened a ≈øicknes among them, ≈øo that there dyed thereof to the number of 900. and all throwne ouer borde into the ≈øea, before they came to Mo≈øambique the Vice Roy him≈øelfe being one. Which was an extraordinarie ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and it is to be thought that the great number of men in the ≈øhip were the cau≈øe of br√©eding the ≈øame: therefore in the≈øe dayes the ≈øhippes take no more ≈øo many men into them, for that with the number they carrie, they haue ≈øtinking ayre, and filth enough to clen≈øe within the ≈øhippe.

The 30. of September the Archbi≈øhoppe my mai≈øter with great triumph was brought into the towne of Goa, and by the Gentlemen and Rulers of the countrey, led vnto the cathedrall Church, ≈øinging Te Deum laudamus, and after many ceremonies and auncient cu≈øtomes, they conuayed him to his pallace, which is clo≈øe by the Church.

The 20. of Nouember our Admirall S. Phillip arriued at Cochin without ≈øtaying to land in any place, hauing indured much mi≈øerie by the meanes before rehear≈øed, hauing b√©ene ≈øeuen monthes and twelue daies vnder ≈øaile.

The la≈øt of the ≈øame month of Nouember the ≈øhippes ≈øayled from Goa to the coa≈øt of Malabar, and Cochin, there to receiue their lading of Pepper and other ≈øpices: ≈øome take in their lading on the coa≈øt of Malabar, as at Onor, Mangator, Cananor, &c. and ≈øome at Cochin, which can alwayes lade two ≈øhippes with Pepper. Cochin lyeth from Goa Southwarde about 90. miles: The ≈øhippes vnlade all their Portingall commodities in Goa, where the Marchantes, and Factors are re≈øident, and from thence the ≈øhips do ≈øayle along the coa≈øt to take in their lading in Pepper, and to Cochin as it is ≈øaid before. Each ≈øhippe doeth commonly lade eyght thou≈øande Quintales of Pepper, little more or le≈ø≈øe Portingall waight: euery Quintale is 128. pound. Then they come to Cochin, whither the Factors al≈øo do trauell and lade in them Cloues, Sinamon, and other Indian wares, as in my voyage homewarde I will particularly declare, together with the manner of the ≈øame.

In the monthes of Ianuary and Februarie Anno 1584. 1584. the ≈øhippes with their lading returned from Cochin, ≈øome before, ≈øome after, towards Portingall, with whom my brother went, becau≈øe of his office in the ≈øhippe, and I ≈øtayed with my mai≈øter in India certaine yeares, to ≈ø√©e and learne the maners and cu≈øtomes of the ≈øaid lands, people, fruites, wares, and merchandi≈øes, with other thinges, which when time ≈øerueth, I wil in truth ≈øet downe, as I my ≈øelfe for the mo≈øt parte haue ≈ø√©ene it with mine eyes, and of credible per≈øons, both Indians, and other inhabiters in tho≈øe Countries learned and required to know, as al≈øo the report and fame thereof is nowe ≈øufficiently ≈øpread abroade throughout the world by diuers of our neighbour countries and landes which traffique and deale with them, namely our countrey, the Ea≈øt Countries, England, Fraunce, &c. which likewi≈øe are founde and knowne by the Portingalles them≈øelues, which dayly trafficke thither. But before I beginne to de≈øcribe Goa, and the Indies, concerning their manners, traffiques, fruites, wares, and other thinges, the better to vnder≈øtande the ≈øituation of the Countrey, and of the coa≈øts lying on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, to the la≈øt and highe≈øt part of the borders of China, which the Portingales haue trauelled and di≈øcouered, together with their Ilandes, I will fir≈øt ≈øet downe a briefe note of the Orientall coa≈øtes, beginning at the redde, or the Arabian ≈øea, from the towne of Aden to Chinae and then the de≈øcription of the coa≈øtes before named.

div.head: Chapter 5. The de≈øcription of the coa≈øt of Arabia Felix, or the red Sea, to the Iland and fortre≈ø≈øe of Ormus.

p.hi: ADen is the ≈øtronge≈øt and faire≈øt towne of Arabia Felix,

≈øituate in a valley, compa≈ø≈øed about vpon the one ≈øide with ≈øtrong mines, on the other ≈øide with high mountaines, there are in it
fiue Ca≈øtles laden with Ordinance, and a continuall Garri≈øon kept therein, becau≈øe of the great number of ≈øhippes that ≈øayle before it, the Towne hath about 6000. hou≈øes in it, where the Indians, Per≈øians, Aethiopians, and Turkes doe trafique: and becau≈øe the Sunne is ≈øo extreame hotte in the daye time, they make mo≈øt of their bargaines by night. About a ≈øtones ca≈øt from the towne there is a hill with a great Ca≈øtle ≈øtanding thereon wherein the Gouernor dwelleth. In times pa≈øt this towne ≈øtoode vpon the firme land, but nowe by the labour & indu≈øtrie of man, they haue made it an Iland.

div.p: Aden lieth on the North ≈øide, at the entrie of the red Sea on the coa≈øt of Arabia Felix, or fruitfull Arabia, and reacheth 60. miles more inwards then the corner or Cape de Guardafum the farthe≈øt part or corner of Abex, or Melinde as I ≈øaid before: but the coa≈øt of Arabia, which taketh the beginning from Aden, is much more inwarde. Aden lieth vnder 13. degr√©es on the North ≈øide, and from thence the coa≈øt lyeth Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt till you come to Cape de Ro≈øalgate, which lyeth vnder 22. degr√©es, and is the further corner of the lande of Arabia Felix, lying on the Indian Sea, which is di≈øtant from Aden 240. miles: the towne of Aden ≈øtandeth by the hill called Dar≈øira, which men affirme to bee onely Cliffes of hard ≈øtones, and red Marble, where it neuer rayneth. The people of this coa≈øt of Arabia, are tawnie of colour, almo≈øt like tho≈øe of the coa≈øt of Abex or Melinde, froÃÑ that Countrie they bring great numbers of good hor≈øes into India, and al≈øo Franken≈øence, Mirhe, Bal≈øam, Bal≈øam woode, and fruite, and ≈øome Manna, with other ≈øw√©ete wares and Spices: they hold the law of Mahomet after the Per≈øians manner.

From the Cape of Ro≈øalgate inwardes, following the coa≈øt North-we≈øt to the Cape de Moncado, in times pa≈øt named Albora are 70. miles. This point lyeth right again≈øt the Iland Ormus vnder 26. degr√©es. There beginneth the entrance of the ≈øtraights of Per≈øia, called Sinus Per≈øicus, and the Iland Ormus lyeth betw√©ene them both, hauing on the one ≈øide Arabia, and on the other ≈øide Northward the Countrie of Per≈øia, and is in breadth 20. miles. From the Cape de Moncadon, coa≈øting the Arabian ≈øhore inwardes to the Iland of Barem, are 80. miles, and lyeth vnder 26. degr√©es & a halfe. There the Captaine of Ormus being a Portingal, hath a factor for the King, and there they fi≈øh for the be≈øt Pearles in all the Ea≈øt Indies, and are the right orientall Pearle. Coa≈øting along this ≈øhore from Barem inwardes to the farthe≈øt and outermo≈øt corner of Per≈øia, or Sinus Per≈øicus, lyeth the towne of Bal≈øora, which are 60. miles: this Towne lyeth vnder 30. degr√©es, and a little about it the two ryuers Tigris and Euphrates do m√©ete and ioyne in one, and runne by Ba≈ø≈øora into the afore≈øaide Sinus Per≈øicus. Thereabout do ‚Ä¢ yet appeare the decayed buildings, and auncient Ruines of old Babylon, and as many learned men are of opinion, thereabout ≈øtoode the earthly Paradice. From the towne of Bal≈øora the coa≈øt runneth againe Northward towards Ormus, which is vnder the Dominion of the Per≈øian, this Sinus Per≈øicus is about 40. miles broad, not much more nor much le≈ø≈øe, and hath diuers Ilands, and in the mouth therof lyeth the rich Iland Ormus, where the Portingales haue a Forte, and dwell altogether in the Ile among the naturall borne countrimen, and haue a Captaine and other officers euery thr√©e yeares, as they of Mo≈ø≈øambique.

div.head: Chapter 6. Of the Iland and Towne of Ormus.
div.p: ORmus lyeth vpon the Iland Geru, in times pa≈øt called Ogyris, and it is an Iland and a kingdom which the Portingales haue brought vnder their ≈øubiection, whereas yet their King hath his re≈øidence, that is to ≈øaye, without the towne where the Portingales inhabite. The≈øe people ob≈øerue Mahomets law, and are white like the Per≈øians. And there they haue a common cu≈øtome, that he which is King doth pre≈øently cau≈øe al his brethren and his kin≈ømen of the Male kinde to haue their eyes put forth, which done they are all richly kept and maintained during their liues, for that there is a law in Ormus, that no blinde man may bee their King nor Gouernour ouer them. Therefore the King cau≈øeth them all to haue their eyes put out, ≈øo to be more ≈øecure in their gouernmentes, as al≈øo to auoide all ≈øtrife and contention, that might ari≈øe, and to hold and maintaine their countrey in peace.

The I≈øland is about thr√©e miles great, very full of cliffes and rockes, and altogether vnfruitfull. It hath neyther gr√©ene leafe nor hearbe in it, nor any ≈øw√©ete water, but onely rockes of ≈øalte ≈øtones, whereof the walles of their hou≈øes are made: it hath nothing of it ≈øelfe, but only what it fetcheth from the firme lande on both ≈øides, as well out of Per≈øia as
from Arabia, and from the Towne of Ba≈ø≈øora, but becau≈øe of the ≈øituation, and plea≈øantnes of the Iland there is al things therein to bee had in great abundance, and greate traffique for that in it is the ≈øtaple for all India, Per≈øia, Arabia and Turkie, and of all the places and Countries about the ≈øame, & commonly it is full of Per≈øians, Armenians, Turkes and all nations, as al≈øo Venetians, which lie there to buy Spices and precious ≈øtones, that in great abundance are brought thether out of all parts of India, and from thence are ≈øent ouer land to Venice, and al≈øo carried throughout all Turkie, Armenia, Arabia, Per≈øia and euery way. There are likewi≈øe brought thether all manner of marchandi≈øes from tho≈øe Countries that is from Per≈øia: out of the Countrie named Coracone and D ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ , and other places, great ≈øtore of rich Tape≈øtrie & Couerlets, which are called Alcatiff ‚Ä¢ s: out of Turkie all manner of Chamlets: out of Arabia diuers ≈øortes of Drugges for Po ‚Ä¢ icaries, as Sanguis draconis, Manna, Mirre, Frankin≈øence & ≈øuch like, diuers goodly hor≈øes, that are excellent for br√©eding, all manner of mo≈øt excellent Orientall Pearles out of Ma≈øcatte a Hauen lying betw√©ene the Cape of Ro≈øelgate and Moncadon, vppon the coa≈øt of Arabia, diuers ≈øorts of Dates, and Marmelades, which from Ormus is carried into India, and all places are ≈øerued therewith: likewi≈øe the money called Larynen, (which hath as it were two legges, ≈øtretching out like a p√©ece of ≈øiluer wide that is beaten flat, printed about with certain ≈ømall Characters, which is coyned in Per≈øia at a place called Lary, being fine Siluer) is brought thether in great quantities, wherby there is as great dealing with them, as with other marchandi≈øes, becau≈øe of the greate gaine that is gotten by them and in India they goe very high.

Now to know the cau≈øe of ≈øo great traffique, and concour≈øe of people in this Ilande of Ormus, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that euery yeare twice there commeth a great companie of people ouer land which are called Caffiles or Car ‚Ä¢ anes, which come from Aleppo, out of the Countrie of Surie thr√©e daies iornie from Tripoli which lyeth vppon the coa≈øt of the Mediterranean Sea, this companie of people, or Caffila ob≈øerue this order, that is, euery yeare twice in the months of Aprill and September. There is a Captaine and certain hundreths of
