‚Ä¢ anni≈øaries, which conuaye the ≈øaid Caffila vntill they come to the Towne of Ba≈ø≈øora, from whence they trauaile by water vnto Ormus. The marchants know the times when the Caruana or Caffila will come, ≈øo that again≈øt that time they make and prepare their marchandi≈øes in a readine≈ø≈øe, and then are brought thether diuers Cammels, Dromedaries, Moyles and hor≈øes euerye man his troope, which are there likewi≈øe to bee ≈øolde, ≈øo that there are a≈ø≈øembled at the lea≈øt fiue or ≈øixe thou≈øand per≈øons all together, and ryde all in order like a battell that marcheth in the fielde two and two vpon a Cammell, or el≈øe ware hanging on both ≈øides of the Cammel, as you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e in the Picture that followeth. With a good garde of
‚Ä¢ ani≈øaries, becau≈øe they are often times ≈øet vpon by the Arabians which are great th√©eues, and come to robbe them, for they mu≈øt trauaile in the woods at the lea≈øt fortie daies together, wher in euery thr√©e or foure dayes they finde wels or pits, from wheÃÑce they prouide them≈øelues of water which they carrie with them in bea≈øtes ≈økins tanned, whereof they make Fla≈økes and Botles.

p.hi: The people nowe of late yeares haue left off their robbing and ≈øtealing in the hiph waies, but long before the birth of Chri≈øt, they v≈øed it, as the Prophet Ieremie doth witnes ≈øaying in his third Chapter and ≈øecond ver≈øe, Lift vp your eyes, and behold what fornicatioÃÑ you commit in euery place, you ≈øit in the ≈øtreetes, and ≈øtay for your companions like the Arabian in the woodes &c. I remember that wee fell among many thou≈øande of the≈øe people, which in great pouertie dwell within the woodes, and ≈øandie downes, that are altogether barren, where they liue, in the heate of the Sunnes lying with their Cammels, getting their lyuing only by robbing and ≈øtealing, their meate and be≈øt breade are Cakes which they bake vnder Cammels dung dried in the Sunne, which the Sand maketh hotte, and Cammels Milke and fle≈øh, with ≈øuch like vnprofitable meate, to conclude they liue like mi≈øerable men, as in truth they are.

div.p:
Likewi≈øe ther are certaine victualers that follow this companie, which carrie all kinde of things with theÃÑ ‚ñ™ as Honie, Dates, Sh√©epe Goates, Hens, Egges &c. and all other ≈øorts of victuals and proui≈øion, ≈øo that for money they may haue what they will, euery night they lie ≈øtill and haue their Tents, wherein they ≈øl√©epe, k√©eping good watch, in this manner they trauaile to the Towne of Ba≈ø≈øora, and pa≈ø≈øe through Babylon now called Bagedet, and through other places. Being at Ba≈ø≈øora, they ≈øtay their certaine daies, wher againe they a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues, to returne
home, and trauaile in the like ≈øorte backe againe vnto Aleppo, whereby all manner of marchandi≈øes, out of all places are brought thether in great aboundance, by great numbers of traueling Marchants, of al nations what≈øoeuer, except Spaniards, Portingals, and the King of Spaines ≈øubiects, which are narrowly looked vnto, although diuers times many of them pa≈ø≈øe among the re≈øt, vnder the names of French men, Engli≈øh men, or Venetians, which nations haue their factors and ≈øeruants continually re≈øident in Aleppo, as al≈øo in Tripoli, where their dayly traffique is from Venice, Mar≈øellis and London and in Tripoli they vnlade their wares, and there the ≈øhippes take in their lading, and from thence they ≈øend their marchandi≈øes by land to and from Aleppo, where they v≈øe great traffique, and haue many priuiledges and freedomes graunted them by the great Turke.

And for that wee are nowe ≈øpeaking of Turks, I mu≈øt not forget to ≈øhew you how, and in what ≈øort the great Turke hath euery day newes and letters from all his kingdomes & Countries that are ≈øo great, wild, wa≈øt, and ≈øpread ≈øo farre abroad one from the other. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that throughout the whole Countrie of Turkie, they v≈øe Doues or Pigeons, which are brought vp & accu≈øtomed thereunto, hauing rings aboute their legges. The≈øe Doues or Pigions, are borne from Ba≈ø≈øora, and Babylon, vnto Aleppo and Con≈øtantinople, and ≈øo from thence backe againe, and when there is any great occa≈øion of importance to bee aduerti≈øed or ≈øent, they make the letter fa≈øt vnto the ring, that is about the Pigions f√©ete, and ≈øo let them flie, whereby the letter with the Doue is brought vnto the place whither it ≈øhould goe, and they flie ≈øometimes a thou≈øand miles, which men would thinke impo≈ø≈øible, but yet it is mo≈øt true, and affirmed by ≈øuch as come from thence: I haue ≈ø√©ene of the Doues in India, that a Venetian my good friend ≈øhewed me, which for the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe thereof had brought of them with him into India.

But let vs now returne vnto our matter of the Ile of Ormus, which lyeth vnder 27. degr√©es, and in Sommer time is ≈øo vnrea≈øonable and intollerable hotte, that they are forced to lie and ≈øl√©epe in wooden Ce≈øterns made for the purpo≈øe full of water, and all naked both men and women, lying cleane vnder water ≈øauing only their heads: al their hou≈øes are flat aboue, and in the toppes therof they make holes to let the ayre come in, like tho≈øe of Cayro, and they v≈øe certaine in≈øtruments like Waggins with bellowes, to beare the people in, and together winde to coole them withall, which they call Cat ‚Ä¢ auentos.

p.hi: Cayrus hath very high hou≈øes, with broad peint-hou≈øes, to yeelde ≈øhadowe,

therby to auoide the heate of the Sunne: in the middle of the≈øe hou≈øes are greate Pipes of ten cubites longe at the lea≈øt, which ≈øtand Northward, to conuaye and ≈øpread the colde ayre into their hou≈øes, ≈øpecially to coole the lowe≈øt romes.

div.p: In winter time it is as colde with them as it is in Portingale, the water that they drinke is brought from the firme land, which they k√©epe in great pots, (as the Tinaios in Spaine) and in Ce≈øternes, whereof they haue verie great ones within the fortre≈ø≈øe, which water for a yeare, or a yeare and a halfe, again≈øt they ≈øhall neede, like tho≈øe of Mo≈ø≈øambique. They fetch water by the Iland of Barein, in the Sea, from vnder the ≈øalt water, with in≈øtruments foure or fiue fadome d√©epe, which is verie good and excellent ≈øweete water, as good as any fountaine water.

There is in Ormus a ≈øickene≈ø≈øe or common Plague of Wormes, which growe in their legges, it is thought that they proc√©ede of the water that they drink. The≈øe wormes are like vnto Lute ≈øtrings, and about two or thr√©e fadomes longe, which they mu≈øt plucke out and winde them‚ñ™ aboute a Straw or a Pin, euerie day ≈øome part therof, as longe as they f√©ele them creepe: and when they hold ≈øtill, letting it re≈øt in that ≈øort till the next daye, they binde it fa≈øt and annoynt the hole, and the ≈øwelling from whence it commeth foorth, with fre≈øh Butter, and ≈øo in ten or twelue dayes, they winde them out without any let, in the meane time they mu≈øt ≈øit ≈øtill with their legges, for if it ≈øhould breake, they ≈øhould not without great paine get it out of their legge, as I haue ≈ø√©en ≈øome men doe.

p.hi: Of the≈øe wormes Al≈øaharanius in his practi≈øe in the 11. Chapter writeth thus‚ñ™ In ≈øome places there grow certaine Wormes betweene the skinne and the fle≈øh,

which ≈øickne≈ø≈øe is named the Oxen paine, becau≈øe the Oxen are manye times grieued therewith, which ≈øtretch them≈øelues in great length, & creepe vnder the skin, ≈øo long till that they pearce it, the healing thereof con≈øi≈øteth in purging the body of corrup fleame, &c. Reade further.

div.p: In my ma≈øter the Archbi≈øhops hou≈øe we had one of his ≈øeruants borne in Ormus newly come from thence which drewe thr√©e or

div.head: The 8. Chapter. Of the towne, fortre≈ø≈øe and I≈øland of Diu, in times pa≈øt called Alambater.
div.p: THe Towne and Ilande of Diu lyeth di≈øtant from the ryuer Indo 70. miles vnder 21. degr√©es, clo≈øe to the firme land: in times pa≈øt it belonged to ye King of Cambaia, in who≈øe land and coa≈øt it lyeth, where the Portingals by negligence of the Kinge, haue built a fortre≈ø≈øe, & in proce≈ø≈øe of time haue brought the Towne and the whole Iland vnder their ≈øubiection, and haue made it very ≈øtrong, & in a manner inuincible, which fortre≈ø≈øe hath b√©ene twice be≈øieged by ≈øouldiers of Cambaia and their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, fir≈øt in Anno 1539. 1539. and ≈øecondly in Anno 1546. 1546. and hath alwaies b√©ene valiantly defended by the Portingals, as their Chronicles rehear≈øe. This Towne hath a very great Hauen, and great traffique, although it hath verye little or nothing at all of it ≈øelfe, more then the ≈øituation of the place, for that it lyeth betw√©en Sinde and Cambaia, which Countries are abundant in all kind of things, wherby Diu is alwaies ful of ≈øtrange nations, as Turks, Per≈øians, Arabians, Armenians, and other countrie people: and it is the be≈øt & the mo≈øt profitable reuenue the King hath throughout all India, for that the Banianen, Gu≈øaratten, Rumos and Per≈øians, which traffique in Cambaia, & from thence to Mecca, or the red Sea, doe commonly di≈øcharge their wares, and take in their lading in Diu, by rea≈øon of the ≈øituation thereof, for that it lyeth in the entrance of Cambaia, and from Diu it is ≈øhipped and ≈øent to Cambaia, and ≈øo brought backe againe to Diu.

The Towne of Diu is inhabited by Portingals, together with the natural borne Countrimen, like Ormus and al the townes & places holden by the Portingals in India, yet they k√©epe their fortre≈ø≈øe ≈øtrong vnto them≈øelues. This Iland aboundeth, and is very fruitfull of all kind of victuals, as Oxen Kine, Hogges, Sh√©epe, Hennes, Butter, Milke, Onions, Garlicke, Pea≈øe, Beanes, and ≈øuch like, whereof there is great plentie, and that very good, and ≈øuch as better cannot be made in all the≈øe Low-countries, but that the Fuell is not ≈øo well dre≈øt: they haue likewi≈øe Ch√©e≈øes, but they are very drie and ≈øault, much Fi≈øh which they ≈øault, and it is almo≈øt like vnto ≈øalt Ling, or Codde, and of other ≈øortes they make hanged fle≈øh which is very good, and will continue for a whole Viage: of all the≈øe victuals, and nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øions they haue ≈øo great quantity that they ≈øupply the want of all the places round about them, e≈øpecially Goa, and Cochin, for they haue neither Butter, Onyons, Garlicke, Pea≈øe, Oyle nor graine, as Beanes, Wheat, or any ≈ø√©ede: they mu≈øt all bee brought from other places thether, as in the orderly de≈øcription of the coa≈øt as it lyeth, I will ≈øhew you, what wares, goods, marchandi≈øes, victuals, fruites and other things each lande, Prouince or Countrie y√©eldeth and affordeth.

From Diu ≈øayling along by the coa≈øt about fift√©ene or ≈øixt√©ene miles, beginneth the mouth of the water that runneth to Cambaia, which is at the entrie, and all along the ≈øaid water about 18. miles broade, and 40. miles long, and runneth in North-ea≈øt and by North, and at the farther ende of the water is the Towne of Cambaia, whereof the whole Countrie beareth the name, and lyeth vnder twentie thr√©e degr√©es, there the King or Solden holdeth his Court.

div.head: The 9. Chapter. Of the kingdome and land of Cambaia.
div.p:
THe land of Cambaia is the fruitfulle≈øt Countrie in all India, and from thence proui≈øion of nece≈ø≈øaries is made for all places round about it: whereby there is a greate traffique in the Towne, as well of the inhabitants, as other Indians and neighbors, as al≈øo of Portingals, Per≈øians, Arabians, Armenians &c. The King ob≈øerueth the law of Mahomet, but mo≈øt parte of the people that are dwellers and naturall borne Countrimen, called Gu≈øarates and Baneanem, ob≈øerue Pythagoras law, & are the ≈øubtile≈øt and pollitique≈øt Marchauntes of all India, who≈øe counterfets and ≈øhapes are placed in this booke by tho≈øe of India, with a de≈øcription of their liuing, ceremonies & cu≈øtomes, as in time and place ≈øhall be ≈øhewed. This lande of Cambaia aboundeth in all kinde of victuals, as Corne, Rice and ≈øuch like grain, al≈øo of Butter and Oyle, wherewith they furni≈øh all the Countries round about them. There is made great ≈øtore of Cotton Linnen of diuers ≈øorts, which are called Cannequins, Boffetas, Iorims, Chau ‚Ä¢ ares and Cotonias, which are like Canuas, thereof do make ≈øayles and ≈øuch like things, and many other ≈øortes that are very good and cheape.
They make ≈øome therof ≈øo fine, that you can not perceyue the thr√©edes, ≈øo that for finene≈ø≈øe it ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth any Holland cloth, they make likewi≈øe many Carpets, called Alcatiffas, but they are neyther ≈øo fine nor ≈øo good as tho≈øe that are brought to Ormus out of Per≈øia, and an other ≈øort of cour≈øe Carpets, that are called Banquays, which are much like the ≈øtriped Couerlits that are made in Scotland, ≈øeruing to lay vpon che≈øtes & cubbords: They make al≈øo faire couerlits, which they call Godoriins Colchas, which are very fair and plea≈øant to the eye, ≈øtitched with ≈øilke, and al≈øo of Cotton of all colours and ≈øtitchinges: pauilions of diuers ≈øorts and colours; Per≈øintos that are ≈øtringes or bands, wherewith the Indians bind and make fa≈øt their bed≈øheddes, thereon to lay their beds: all kind of bed≈øteds, ≈øtooles for Indian women, and other ≈øuch like ≈øtuffes, co≈øtly wrought and couered with ≈øtuffes of all colours: al≈øo fine playing tables, and Che≈ø≈øebordes of Iuory, and ≈øhields of Torteux ≈øhelles, wrought and inlaide very workemanlike, many fayre ≈øignets, ringes, and other curious worke of Iuorie, and ≈øea hor≈øe t√©eth, as al≈øo of Amber, whereof there is great quantitie: They haue likewi≈øe a kind of mountain Chri≈øtall, wherof they make many ≈øignets, buttons, beades and diuers other deui≈øes. They haue diuers ≈øorts of precious ≈øtones, as E≈øpinelleÃÑ, Rubies Granadis, Ia≈ønites, Amati≈øtes, Chry≈øolites, Olhos de gato, which are Cattes eyes, or Agats, much Ia≈øper ≈øtone, which is called bloud and milke ≈øtone, and other kindes of ≈øtones: al≈øo many kindes of Drognes, as Amfion, or Opium, Camfora, Bangue, and Sandale wood, whereof when time ≈øerueth, I will particularly di≈øcour≈øe, in ≈øetting down the ≈øpices and fruites of India, Alluijn, Cane Sugar, and other merchandi≈øes, which I cannot remember, and it would be ouer long and tedious to rehear≈øe them all: Annell or Indigo groweth onely in Cambaia, and is there prepared and made ready, and from thence carried throughout the whole world, whereof hereafter I will ≈øay more: but this ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the de≈øcription of Cambaia, and now I will proc√©ede.

At the ende of the countrey of Cambaia beginneth India & the lands of Decam, and Cuncam, the coa≈øt that is the inwarde part thereof on the Indian ≈øide ≈øtretcheth from Cambaia to the coa≈øt of India, where the ≈øaid inward part hath the beginning, which coa≈øt ≈øtretcheth We≈øtwardes, Southwe≈øt, and by South to the I≈ølande lying on the coa≈øt or entry of the ≈øaid place, called In≈øula das Vaquas, being vnder 20. degr√©es, vpon the which corner and countrey, on the firme land ≈øtandeth the towne and fortre≈ø≈øe of Daman which is inhabited by the Portingalles‚ñ™ and vnder their ≈øubiection, di≈øtant from the Towne of Diu Ea≈øt and by South fortie miles.

div.head: The 10. Chapter. Of the coa≈øt of India, and the hauens and places lying vpon the ≈øame.
div.p: THe coa≈øt of India hath the beginning at the entry or turning of the lande of Cambaia from the I≈ølande called Das Vaguas, as it is ≈øaide before, which is the right coa≈øt, that in all the Ea≈øt Countries is called India: but they haue other particular names, as Mo≈øambique, Melinde, Ormus, Cambaia, Choramandel, Bengala, Pegu, Malacca, &c. as when time ≈øerueth ≈øhall be ≈øhewed, whereof a part hath already b√©ene de≈øcribed. Now you mu≈øt vnder≈øtande that this coa≈øt of India beginneth at Daman, or the I≈øland Das Vaguas, and ≈øtretcheth South and by Ea≈øt, to the Cape of Comoriin, where it endeth, and is in all 180. miles, vppon the which coa≈øt lie the towns and hauens hereafter following which the Portingals haue vnder their ≈øubiections, and ≈øtrong fortes therein: fir≈øt Daman from thence fift√©ene miles vpwardes vnder 19. degr√©es and a halfe the towne of Ba≈øaiin, from Ba≈øaiin ten miles vpwardes vnder 19. degr√©es the Towne and fort of Chaul, from Chaul to Dabul are tenne miles, and lyeth vnder 18. degr√©es: from Dabul to the town and I≈øland of Goa are 30. miles, which lyeth vnder 15. degr√©es and a halfe: all the≈øe Townes and fortes afore≈øaide are inhabited by the Portingalles, except Dabul which they had, and long ≈øince lo≈øt it againe: The coa≈øt from Goa to Daman, or the turning into Cambaia, is called by tho≈øe of Goa the Northerne coa≈øt, and from Goa to the Cape de Comoriin, it is called the ≈øouthern coa≈øt, but commonly the coa≈øt of Malabar.

Concerning the towne of Goa and the ≈øituation thereof, as al≈øo the de≈øcription of Decam & Cuncam, as touching their kings and progenies we will in another place particularly declare, with many other memorable thinges, as well of the Portingalles, as of the naturall countrimen. Wherefore for this time we will pa≈ø≈øe them ouer, and ≈øpeak of the other principal towns and hauens, following along the coa≈øt.

You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that all the townes
afore≈øaid, Daman, Ba≈øaiin and Chaul, haue good hauens, where great traffique is done throughout all India: all the≈øe townes and countries are very fruitfull of Ryce, Pea≈øe, and other graines, Butter, and oyle of Indian Nuttes: but oyle of Oliues is not to be found in all the Ea≈øt Indies, onely what is brought out of Portingall, and other ≈øuch like proui≈øions is there very plentifull: they make al≈øo ≈øome Cotton linnen, but very little. The towne of Chaul hath great traffique to Ormus, Cambaia, to the redde ≈øea, to Sinde Ma≈øquate, Bengala, &c. & hath many rich Marchants, and ≈øhippes: there is a place by Chaul, which is the old towne of the naturall borne countrymen, where diuers kindes of ≈øilkes are wouen, of all ≈øortes and colours, as Grogeran, Sattin, Taffata, Sar≈øcenet, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffes, in ≈øo great aboundance‚ñ™ that India and all other places bordering the ≈øame‚ñ™ are ≈øerued therewith: whereby the inhabitantes of Chaul haue a great commoditie, by bringing the raw ≈øilke out of China, ≈øpinning and weauing it there; and againe being wouen, to carrie and di≈øtribute it throughout all India. There are likewi≈øe made many and excellent faire de≈økes, bed≈øteds, ≈øtooles for women, couered with ≈øtuffes of all colours, and ≈øuch like marchandi≈øes, whereby they haue great traffique: There is likewi≈øe great ≈øtore of Ginger, as al≈øo all the coa≈øt along, but little e≈øt√©emed there: This land called the North part, hath a very hole≈øome and temperate ayre, and is thought to be ye ≈øounde≈øt & health≈øome≈øt part of all India, for the towne of Diu, and the coa≈øt of Malabar is very vnhole≈øome. The≈øe Indians, as al≈øo tho≈øe of Cambaia which are called Benianen, and Gu≈øarrates, and tho≈øe of the lande that lyeth inwardes from Decam, which dwell vpon the hill, called Ballagatte, which are named Decaniins, and Canaras, are altogether of yellowe colour, and ≈øome of them ≈øomewhat whiter, others ≈øomewhat browner, but tho≈øe that dwel on the ≈øea coa≈øt, are different and much blacker, their ≈øtatures‚ñ™ vi≈øages and limmes are altogether like men of Europa, and tho≈øe of the coa≈øt of Malabar, which ≈øtretcheth and beginneth 12. miles from Goa Southward, and reacheth to the cape de Comoriin, who≈øe naturall borne people are called Malabaren, which are tho≈øe that dwell vpon the ≈øea coa≈øt, are as blacke as pitch, with verie blacke and ≈ømoth haire, yet of bodies, lims and vi≈øages, in all thinges proportioned like men of Europa: The≈øe are the be≈øt ≈øoldiers in all India, and the principall enemies that the Portingalles haue, and which trouble them continually.

But the better to know the ≈øituation of the countrey, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtande that all the coa≈øt ≈øeuered from India, is the low land lying 8. or 10. miles vpon the coa≈øt, which is that whereof we ≈øpeake, and is called Cuncam, and then there is a high or hilly Countrey, which reacheth almo≈øt vnto the skies, and ≈øtretcheth from the one ende vnto the other, beginning at Daman or Cambaia to the Cape de Comoriin, and the vttermo≈øt corner of India, and all that followeth again on the other coa≈øt called Ghoramandel. This high land on the top is very flatte and good to build vpon, called Ballagatte, and Decan, and is inhabited and diuided among diuers Kings and gouernors. The inhabitants and natural borne countrimen, are commonly called Decaniins, and Canaras, as in the de≈øcription of Goa and the territories thereof ≈øhalbe particularly ≈øhewed, with the ≈øhapes, fa≈øhions and counterfeites of their bodies, Churches, hou≈øes, tr√©es, Plantes, and fruites, &c.

div.head: The 11. Chapter. Of the coa≈øt of India, that is from Goa to the cape de Comoriin, and the furthe≈øt corner of the lande, which is called the coa≈øt of Malabar.
div.p:
THe coa≈øt of Malabar beginneth from Cape de Ramos, which lyeth froÃÑ Goa Southwardes ten myles, and endeth at the Cape de Comoriin, in time pa≈øt called Corii, which is 100. and 7. or 8. miles, whereon lie the places hereafter following, which are inhabited by the Portingals, and kept with fortre≈ø≈øes: fir≈øt from the ≈øaid Cape de Ramos to the fortre≈ø≈øe of Onor are tenne miles, lying full vnder 14. degr√©es, and is inhabited by the Portingalles. There is great quantity of Pepper, for that they are able euery yeare to lade a ≈øhippe with 7. or 8. thou≈øand Quintalles of Pepper, Portingal waight, & it is the be≈øt and fulle≈øt berries in all Malabar or India. This land belongeth to a Qu√©ene named Batycola, which is a towne not farre from thence inwardes wherin ≈øhe k√©epeth her Court: it is ≈øhe that ≈øelleth the Pepper, and deliuereth it vnto the Marchantes Factors, that lie in Onor, but they mu≈øt alwaies deliuer their money ≈øixe monthes before they receyue their Pepper, otherwi≈øe they get it not: then ≈øhe deliuereth the Pepper, which by one of the Factors is
receyued and laid vp within the fortre≈ø≈øe, till the ≈øhippes of Portingall come thether to take in their lading of Pepper: There is likewi≈øe much Ryce. This fortre≈ø≈øe is not much frequented, but onely in the time of lading of their Pepper. which within fewe yeares hath b√©ene v≈øed to be laden there, for before they v≈øed not to lade any in that place.

From Onor to the towne of Bar≈øelor are 15. miles, and lyeth vnder 13. degr√©es: it is al≈øo inhabited by Portingalles as Onor is: there is great ≈øtore of Ryce & Pepper: from Bar≈øelo ‚Ä¢
to Mangalor are 9. miles, and lyeth vnder twelue degr√©es, and a halfe, which al≈øo is a fortre≈ø≈øe inhabited as the others are by Portingals, and hath great ≈øtore of Pepper and Ryce.

From Mangalor to Cananor are 15. myles, which lyeth right vnder 11. degr√©es and a halfe. This is the be≈øt fortre≈ø≈øe that the Portingalles haue in all Malabar, and there is much Pepper: The Malabars without the fortre≈ø≈øe haue a village, with many hou≈øes therein, built after their manner; wherein there is a market holden euery day, in the which all kindes of victuailes are to be had, which is wonderfull, altogether like the Hollanders markets. There you find Hennes, Egges, Butter, Hony, Indian Oyle, and Indian figges, that are brought from Cananor, which are very great, and without exception the be≈øt in all India: of the which ≈øorts of victuailes, with other ≈øuch like they haue great quantities: al≈øo very faire and long ma≈øtes for ≈øhippes, ≈øuch as better cannot be found in all Norway, and that in ≈øo great numbers, that they furni≈øh all the countries rounde about them. It is a very gr√©ene and plea≈øant lande to beholde, full of faire high tr√©es, and fruitfull of all thinges, ≈øo is the whole coa≈øt from Malabar all along the ≈øhore. Among the≈øe Malabars the white Mores do inhabite that bel√©eue in Mahomet, and their greate≈øt traffique is vnto the redde ≈øea, although they may not doe it, neyther any other Indian without the Portingalles pa≈øport, otherwi≈øe the Portingals army (which yearly ≈øaileth along the coa≈øts, to k√©epe them cleare from ≈øea rouers) for the ≈øafetie of their marchants, finding them or any other Indian or nation what≈øoeuer, at ≈øea without a pa≈øport, woulde take them for a prize, as oftentimes it happeneth that they bring ≈øhippes from Cambaia, Malabar, or from the Ile of Sumatra, and other places that traffique to the redde ≈øea. The≈øe Mores of Cananor k√©epe friend≈øhippe with the Portingalles, becau≈øe of the fortre≈ø≈øe which holdeth them in ≈øubiection, yet couertly are their deadly enemies, and ≈øecretly contribute and pay great ≈øummes of money to the other Malabars, to the ende that they ≈øhoulde mi≈øchiefe and trouble the Portingalles, by all the meanes they can deui≈øe, who≈øe forme and images do follow after tho≈øe of Goa and Malabar.

From Cananor to Calecut are 8. miles, which lyeth full vnder 11. degr√©es: This towne of Calecut hath in times pa≈øt b√©ene the mo≈øt famous Towne in all Malabar or India, and it was the chiefe towne of Malabar where the Samoriin, which is the Emperour, holdeth his Court, but becau≈øe the Portingalles at their fir≈øt comming and di≈øcouering of India, were oftentimes deceyued by him, they re≈øorted to the King of Cochin, who as then was ≈øubiect to the Samoriin, being of ≈ømall power. But when the Portingals began to pro≈øper in their enterpri≈øe, and to get po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in the countrey, and ≈øo became mai≈øters of the ≈øea, Calecut beganne to decay, and to lo≈øe both name and traffique, and nowe at this time it is one of the townes of lea≈øt account in all Malabar and Cochin to the contrarie, their King being very rich, and richer then the Samoriin, ≈øo that now he careth noe for him, by means of the fauour and help he findeth at the hands of the Portingalles.
From Calecut to Cranganor are tenne myles, and lyeth vnder tenne degr√©es and a halfe: there the Portingalles haue a Fortre≈ø≈øe.

From Cranganor to Cochin are tenne miles, and lyeth not full vnder tenne degr√©es. The towne of Cochin is inhabited by Portingals, and naturall borne Indians, as Malabars and other Indians that are chri≈øtened: it is almo≈øt as great as Goa, very populous, and well built with faire hou≈øes, Churches, and cloy≈øters, and a fayre and mo≈øt plea≈øant Riuer, with a good channell, and a hauen: a little beyonde the towne towards the land runneth a ≈ømall riuer or water, where ≈øometimes men may pa≈ø≈øe ouer dry footed: on the further ≈øide whereof lyeth a place called Cochin Dacyma, and it is aboue Cochin, which is in the iuri≈ødiction of the Malabars, who as yet continue in their owne religion: there the King k√©epeth his Court: It is very full and well built with hou≈øes after the Indian manner, and hath likewi≈øe a market euery day, where all kind of thinges are to be bought, as in Cananor, but in greater quantities. The land of Cochin is an I≈øland, and it is in many places compa≈ø≈øed about, and through the I≈øle with ≈ømall Riuers.

Right ouer again≈øt Cochin Northwarde lyeth an other I≈øland called Vaypiin, which
is likewi≈øe compa≈ø≈øed about with water, like the fortre≈ø≈øe of Cranganor, all the≈øe landes and Countries are low and flat land like the Countrie of Holland, but haue no ditches nor downes but onely the flat ≈øhore vpon the Sea ≈øide, and within the ≈øhore & the Strand of the ryuer, nor without any high ground or ≈øhelters, and ≈øo it ≈øtill continueth. The Countrie is verye great and plea≈øant to behold‚ñ™ full of woodes and trees, it hath al≈øo woods of Cinamon tr√©es, which are called Canella de Ma ‚Ä¢ es, that is wilde CinamoÃÑ, which is not ≈øo good as the Cinamon of Seylo ‚Ä¢ , for when the Cinamon of Seylo ‚Ä¢
is worth 1 ‚Ä¢ 0. Parda ‚Ä¢ eÃÑ or Dollers that Cinamon is worth but 5‚ñ™ or 3 ‚Ä¢ . Parda ‚Ä¢ wen, and is likewi≈øe forbidden ‚Ä¢ o bee carried into Portingale, notwith≈øtanding: There is euery yeare great quantitie thereof ≈øhipped, but it is entred in the Cu≈øtome bookes for Cinamon of Seylon, whereby they pay the King his full Cu≈øtome for the be≈øt, Cochin hath al≈øo much Pepper, and can euery yeare lade two ≈øhips full, other ≈øhippes lade along the coa≈øt, at the fortre≈ø≈øe afore≈øaid, & v≈øe to come vnto Cochin, after they haue di≈øcharged all their Portingal wares and Marchandi≈øes, at Goa, and thether al≈øo come the Factors and Marchants and lade their wares, as in my Voyage homewards I will declare. Without Cochin, among the Malabares, there dwelleth al≈øo diuers Moores that belieue in Mahomet, and many Iewes, that are very rich, and there liue fr√©ely without being hindred or impeached for their religion, as al≈øo the Mahometans, with their churches which they cal Me≈øquiten, the Bramanes likewi≈øe (which are the Spiritualitie of the Malabares & Indians) haue their Idols and hou≈øes of Diuels, which they call Pagodes. The≈øe thr√©e nations doe ≈øeuerally holde & maintaine their lawes and ceremonies by them ≈øelues, and liue friendly and quietly together k√©eping good pollicie and iu≈øtice, each nation b√©eing of the Kinges coun≈øell, with his Naires which are his gentilmen and nobilitie: ≈øo that when any occa≈øion of importaunce is offered, then al tho≈øe thr√©e nations a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues together, wherein the King putteth his tru≈øt: of the which King and his Naires, Malabare ‚ñ™ and Ba ‚Ä¢ amenes &c. with their maners, cu≈øtomes, aparrell, Idols, pagodes, and ceremonies, in an other place I will ≈øhewe you more at large, together with their pictures & couÃÑterfetes: and for this time I cea≈øe to ≈øpeake thereof, & wil proc√©ede in the de≈øcription of the coa≈øts, which I haue already beguÃÑ.

From Cochin to Coulon are 12. myles, and lyeth vnder 9 degr√©es: it is al≈øo a fortre≈ø≈øe of the Portingals, where likewi≈øe euery yere they lade a ≈øhip with pepper: from Cou ‚Ä¢ on to the cape de Comori, are 20. myles: this corner lieth full vnder 7. degr√©es & a half, which is the end of the coa≈øt of Malabar & of India.

div.head: The 12. Chapter. The de≈øcription of the kings, the diui≈øion of the land and coa≈øt of Malabar, and their originall.
div.p:
TO vnder≈øtand the gouernment and diui≈øions of the laÃÑd of Malabar, you mu≈øt know that in tymes pa≈øt, (but long ≈øithence) the whole land of M ‚Ä¢ labar was ruled by one King, being then but one kingdome, where now are manie, and as the Malabares ≈øaye, the la≈øt king that ruled the whole couÃÑtry alone, was named Sarama Perimal, in who≈øe time the Arabian Mahometanes much frequented the couÃÑtrie of Malabar, becau≈øe of the great trafique of Spices, which as then were ≈øent from thence to the red ≈øea, and ≈øo conueyed into all places of the world. Tho≈øe Arabians by their ≈øubtilties delt in ≈øuch manner with the King, that they per≈øwaded him and many of his couÃÑtry to beleue in the lawe of Mahomet, as they did almo≈øt throughout whole India, and other orientall couÃÑtries and Ilands, which is one of the principale≈øt occa≈øions why they can hardly be brought to beleue in Chri≈øt, but rather ≈øeeke by all meanes to ouerthrowe the Chri≈øtians, and to fight again≈øt the Portingales in tho≈øe countries, as in the Portingal Chronicles and Hi≈øtories of the fir≈øt di≈øcouery and conque≈øt of the Indies‚ñ™ is at large de≈øcribed. But returning to our matter, this King Sarama was ≈øo d√©epely rooted in his new ≈øect of Mahometes law, that he determined in him ≈øelfe to leaue his kingdome, and goe on pilgrimage to Mecca, to ≈øee Mahomets graue and there to ende his lyfe in ≈øo holy an exerci≈øe, thinking thereby to be ≈øaued, which in the end he brought to effect. And becau≈øe he had neither childreÃÑ nor heyres to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe his kingdome, he deuided the ≈øame among his chiefe≈øt & be≈øt ≈øeruaÃÑts & frieÃÑds, giuing to one Cochin, to an other Cananor, to the third Chale, to the fourth Coulon &c. and ≈øo he delt with all the other places of his dominions, making euery one of tho≈øe places a kingdome: The town of Calicut he gaue to one of his be≈øt beloued ≈øeruaÃÑts together with the title of Samoriin, which is as much to ≈øay as Emperour
and chief of al the re≈øt, and commanded that they ≈øhould all acknowledge him as their Soueraigne; and they his va≈ø≈øalles, and at his commandement: whereby, euen vntill this time, the King of Calicut holdeth the name of Samoriin, with the commandement and authoritie ouer the other kings throughout the whole countrie of Malabar, by ≈øuch means as you haue heard before, which done the king weÃÑt on pilgrimage to Mecca, wher he ended his dayes: and the Samoriin with the other kings, continued each man in his newe kingdome, who≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øors vntill this day doe continue, and gouerne the ≈øaid kingdomes, onely the Samoriin is ≈øomewhat imba≈øed, and the king of Cochin exalted, ≈øince the Portingals ariued in the Indies, as it is ≈øaid before.

The≈øe Malabares are excellent good ≈øoldiours, and goe naked, both men and women, onely their priuy members couered, and are the principalle≈øt enemies that the Portingals haue, and which doe them mo≈øt hurt: and although commonlie they haue peace with the Samoriin, and hold ≈øo many forts vpon the land, as you haue heard before, yet the Malabares haue their hauens, as Chale, Calicut, Cunhale, Panane, and others, from whence with boates they mak roads into the ≈øea, and doe great mi≈øchief, making many a poore merchant. The Samoriin likewi≈øe, when the toy taketh him in the head, breaketh the peace, & that by the coun≈øell of the Mahometanes, who in all things are enemies to the Chri≈øtians, & ≈ø√©eke to do them mi≈øchief: and becau≈øe of the Malabares inua≈øions, the Portingall fl√©et is forced euery yeare to put forth of Goa in the ≈øummer-time, to k√©epe the coa≈øt, and to pre≈øerue the merchants that trauaill tho≈øe couÃÑtries from ye Malabars, for that the mo≈øt traffique in India, is in Foi≈øts like galleyes, wherein they traffique from the one place to the other, which is their daylie liuing & occupations, as it ≈øhalbe ≈øhewed at large: and yet there are continuall pyracies committed on the ≈øea, what order ≈øoeuer they take, wherby poore marchaÃÑts are taken pri≈øoners, & robbed of all they haue. The land throughout is very fruitfull, gr√©ene and plea≈øant to beholde, but hath a very noy≈øome and pe≈øtiferous ayre for ≈øuch as are not borne in the countrie, and yet pepper doth onely growe on this coa≈øt, although ≈øome groweth by Mallacca in certaÃÑe parts of the land, but not ≈øo much, for from hence is it laden and conueyed throughout the whole world.

div.head: The 13. Chapter. Of the Ilands called Maldyua, otherwi≈øe Maldyua.
div.p:
RIght ouer again≈øt the cape of Comoriin 60. miles into the ≈øea we≈øtward, the Ilands called Maldyua doe begin, and from this cape on the North ≈øyde they lie vnder 7. degr√©es, & ≈øo reach ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, till they come vnder 3. degr√©es on the ≈øouth ≈øide, which is 140. myles. Some ≈øay there are 11000. Ilands, but it is not certainely knowne, yet it is mo≈øt true, they are ≈øo many, that they can not be numbred. The Inhabitants are like the Malabares: ≈øome of the≈øe Ilands are inhabited, and ≈øome not inhabited, for they are very lowe ground, like the countrie of Cochin, Cranganor. &c. and ≈øome of them are ≈øo lowe, that they are commonlie couered with the ≈øea: the Malabares ≈øay, that tho≈øe Ilandes in time pa≈øt did ioyne fa≈øt vnto the firme land of Malabar, & were part of the ≈øame land, and that the Sea in proce≈ø≈øe of tyme hath eaten them away, & ≈øo ≈øeparated them from the firme land. There is no merchandize to be had in them, but only coquen, which are Indian nuttes, and cayro, which are the ≈øhelles of the ≈øame nuts, & that is the Indian hemp, wherof they mak ropes, cables, and other ≈øuch like commodities: tho≈øe are there to be found in ≈øo great aboundance, that with them they ≈øerue the whole country of India, and al the oriental coa≈øt: of the wood of the ≈øame tr√©es they make them≈øelues boats after their manner, with all things to them belonging: of the leaues they make ≈øayles, ≈øowed together with ≈øtrings made of the nut≈øhelles, without any iron nayles, and ≈øo being laden with the nuttes and other parts of the ≈øaid tr√©es, they come and trafficke with tho≈øe of the firme land, their victuals in the ≈øhip being the fruite of the ≈øame tr√©e: ≈øo that to conclude, the boate with all her furnitures, their marchandi≈øes and their victuals is all of this palme tr√©e, and that maintaineth all the inhabitants of the Ilands of Maldyua, and therewith they trafficke throughout India: there are ≈øome of the≈øe nuttes in the ≈øaid Iland that are more e≈øt√©emed then all the nuttes in India, for that they are good again≈øt all poy≈øon, which are verie faire and great, and blacki≈øh: I ≈øaw ≈øome that were pre≈øeÃÑted vnto the vice roy of India, as great as a ve≈ø≈øell of 2. tuÃÑnes Indian mea≈øure, and co≈øt aboue 300. Pardawen, which were to ≈øend vnto the King of Spaine ‚ñ™ Of this tr√©e and her fruites, together with the v≈øage thereof, I will di≈øcour≈øe more
at large in the declaring of the Indian tr√©es & fruites, meane time I will returne to the de≈øcription of the coa≈øts with their ≈øituations.

From the cape of Comoriin the coa≈øt beginneth North ea≈øt to turne inwards again, till you come to the Cape of Negapatan, which lyes vnder 11. degr√©es, and is 60. myles di≈øtant from the cape of Comoriin.

From the cape of Comoriin South ea≈øt & by South about 40 miles into the ≈øea, lieth the furthe≈øt corner of the great Iland of Seylon, and ≈øo reacheth North and by ea≈øt, vntill you come right ouer again≈øt the cape of Negapatan, being di≈øtant from the firme land & the ≈øame cape 10. miles, and betw√©ene the firme land and that Iland there lyeth ≈øome drie groundes or lytle Ilands, whereby it is manie times dangerous for the Shippes that ≈øayle vnto Bengala and the coa≈øt of Cho ‚Ä¢ amandel, which commonly pa≈ø≈øe through that way. The Iland of Seylon is in length 60. miles, and in breadth 40. miles, from the fir≈øt and vttermo≈øt corner North & by ea≈øt, about 18. miles vnder 7. degr√©es and an halfe, lyeth a fort belonging to the Portingals, called Columbo, which by m√©ere force & great charges is holden and maintained, for that they haue no other place or p√©ece of ground, no not one foot, but that in all the Iland: it is but a ≈ømall fort, yet very ≈øtrong and well guarded: The ≈øoldiers that are therein, are commonly ≈øuch as are bani≈øhed for ≈øome offence by them coÃÑmitted, or ≈øuch as haue de≈øerued death: and ≈øome di≈øhone≈øt women, for ≈øome euill fact, are put in there to beare them company. They fetch al their nece≈ø≈øaries out of India, and are often times a≈ø≈øailed by their enemies, the Inhabitants of the Iland, and often times be≈øieged, but alwaies valiantly defend them≈øelues.

div.head: The 14. Chapter. Of the Iland of Seylon.
div.p: THe Iland of Seylon is ≈øaid to be one of the be≈øt Ilands that in our time hath b√©ene di≈øcouered, and the fruitfulle≈øt vnder the heauens, well built with hou≈øes, and inhabited with people, called Cingalas, and are almo≈øt of ≈øhape and manners like to tho≈øe of Malabar, with long wyde eares, but not ≈øo blacke of colour: they goe naked, onely their members couered: they were wont to haue but one King, but hauing murdered their king, they deuided their countrie into manie kingdomes, and not long ≈øince, a ≈øimple barber murthered their chief king, & with great tyrannie brought the kingdome vnder his ≈øubiection, driuing the other kings out of the countrie, whereof one that was a Chri≈øtian, fled into India, and dwelleth at Goa, where he is kept & maintained at the kings charge. This barber, as it is ≈øaid, hath made him≈øelfe king, and the whole Iland vnder his ≈øubiection, his name was Raju, he liueth verie warily, and is verie ≈øubtill, a good ≈øoldier, but tru≈øting no man: the Chingalans are not his good friends, & yet they liue in obedieÃÑce vnder him, more through force and feare, then for loue or good wil: for that he cau≈øeth them with great tyrannie to be executed, ≈øo that no man dareth ≈øtirre again≈øt him: he is likewi≈øe a deadly enemie to the Portingall, and about a yeare before I came from India, he had be≈øieged the fort of Columbo with a great nuÃÑ ber of Elephants, and men, but by meanes of ye Portingals that came thither out of India, he was con≈øtrayned to breake vp his ≈øiege before the fortre≈ø≈øe.

The Iland is full of hils, and there is one hill ≈øo high that it is reported to be the highe≈øt hill in all India, and is called Picode Adam, The Indians hold for certane that Paradice was in that place, and that Adam was created therein, ≈øaying that yet vntill this daye, there are ≈øome of his foot≈øteps fouÃÑd vpon that hill, which are within the ≈øtones, as if they were ingrauen, and neuer goe out.

The Iland is full of all ≈øorts of Indian fruites and of al kind of wild bea≈øts, as harts, hindes, wild bores, hayres, coneys, and ≈øuch like in great abundance, of all ≈øorts of foules, as peacoks, hennes, doues and ≈øuch like: and for oringes, lemons, and citrons, it hath not onely the be≈øt in al India, but better then any are found either in Spaine or Portingal, to conclude, it hath many and almo≈øt all things that are found in India through all the ≈øeuerall prouinces and places thereof: it hath al≈øo manie Indian palme trees, or nut trees, which are called cocken: and certane credible per≈øons doe affirme, which told it m√©e, that in the ≈øame Iland are nutmegges, Cloues, and Pepper tr√©es, although there is no certaintie thereof, for that as yet they haue not b√©ene brought, or vttered to ≈øell among the Chri≈øtians, but the be≈øt Cinamon in all the ea≈øt countries is there to be had, where it groweth in whole woodes, and from thence is di≈øper≈øed into all places of the world. The Captaine that k√©epeth the fort is forced by ≈øtealth in the night time to i≈ø≈øue forth & fetch this Cinamon into his fort, whereof he maketh his principal profite, for much more profite hath he not. This Iland hath likewi≈øe al kindes of precious ≈øtones, except Diamonds,
but Saphires, Rubies, Topa≈ø ‚Ä¢ es, Sp ‚Ä¢ nelen, ‚Ä¢ ranaden, Rob ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øen. &c. the be≈øt in all the Ea≈øt: it hath likewi≈øe a fi≈øhing for Pearles, but yet they are not ≈øo good as tho≈øe that are at Bareiin by Ormus: it hath likewi≈øe mynes of Gold, ≈øiluer, and other metals. The Kings of the Iland will not digge it forth, but k√©epe it for a great ≈øtate & honor, I thinke rather it is but Latte ‚Ä¢ , becau≈øe no man ventureth for it: it hath al≈øo yron, Flaxe, Brim≈øtone, and ≈øuch like ware, al≈øo many Iuorie banes, and diuers Elephantes, which are accounted for the be≈øt in all India, and it is by daylie experience found to be true, that the Elephantes of all other places and couÃÑtries being brought before them, they honour and reuerence tho≈øe Elephantes: the natural borne people or Chingalas are very cunning workmen in Gold, Siluer, Iuory, Yron, and all kindes of metal, that it is wonderful: they are much e≈øt√©emed for the ≈øame through al India, and beare the name and pray≈øe aboue all the re≈øt of the Indians: they make the faire≈øt barrels for p√©eces that may be fouÃÑd in any place, which ≈øhine as bright as if they were Siluer. My mai≈øter the Archbi≈øhop had a crucifixe of Iuorie of an elle long, pre≈øented vnto him, by one of the inhabitants of the Ile, & made by him ≈øo cunningly & ‚Ä¢ rkmanly wrought, that in the hayre, beard, and face, it ≈ø√©emed to be aliue, & in al other parts ≈øo neatly wrought and proportioned in limmes, that the like can not be done in all Europe: Whereupon my mai≈øter cau≈øed it to be put into a ca≈øe, and ≈øent vnto the king of Spaine, as a thing to be woÃÑ dered at, and worthy of ≈øo great a Lord, to be kept among his co≈øtlie≈øt Iewels. In ≈øuch things they are very expert and wonderful, and maruelous nimble and expert in iugling, as well men as women, and trauell throughout the countrie of India, to get money, carying hobbyhor≈øes with theÃÑ, very ≈øtrange to behold. And this ≈øhall ≈øuffice at this pre≈øent for the de≈øcription of the Ile of Seylon, & now I will proc√©ede to ≈øhewe you of the coa≈øt of Choramandel, where w√©e left before, being at the cape of Negapatan.

div.head: The 15. Chapter. Of the coa≈øt of Choramandel and the kingdome of Nar≈øinga or Bi≈ønagar.
div.p:
THe coa≈øt of Choramandel beginneth from the cape of Negapatan, and ≈øo ≈øtretcheth North & by Ea≈øt, vnto a place called Mu≈øulepatan, which is 90. miles, and lieth vnder 16. degr√©es and a half. Betw√©ene the≈øe two places, vpon the ≈øame coa≈øt, lyeth a place called S. Thomas, vnder 13. degr√©es & an halfe, and is 40. miles di≈øtant from Negapatan. This place and Negapatan are inhabited by the Portingales, and in al the other places along the coa≈øt, they haue traffique and deali ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ The afore≈øaid place called S. Thomas was in time pa≈øt a towne of great traffique, and as then called by the name of Meliapor, and belonged to the kingdome of Nar≈øinga, who≈øe king is now commonly called king of Bi≈ønagar, which is the name of his chief Citie where he k√©epeth his court. This Towne lieth within the land, and is nowe the chief ‚Ä¢ cittie of Nar≈øinga and of the coa≈øt of Choramandel. The naturall countrimen, are for manners, cu≈øtomes & ceremonies, like tho≈øe of Ballagate, decamin ‚Ä¢
& Canaras, for they are al one people, but only ≈øeparate by ≈øeueral places & kingdoms: and ye better to vnder≈øtand wherefore this place was named S. Thomas, the Indians ≈øay, that in the time, when the Apo≈øtles were ≈øent & ≈øpread abroad to preach the Go≈øpell of our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt throughout the whole world, that S. Thomas the apo≈øtle came into that kingdome of Nar≈øinga, after he had bene in diuers places of India teaching & preaching the word of God vnto tho≈øe Indians and vnbeleuing people, but litle profited therein, for ≈øo ≈øay the Chri≈øtians that are come of tho≈øe ≈øame Countriemen, which S. Thomas conuerted and bapti≈øed in the faith of Chri≈øt, whom the Portingals found there at ≈øuch time as they entered into the country and yet find many of them ob≈øeruing the ceremonies of the Gr√©ek Church in the Chaldean tong, that by no meanes will ioine with the Portingales in their ceremonies: but not long ≈øithence at the time of my b√©eing in India, there was one of their Bi≈øhops, that by land trauelled to Rome, and there ≈øubmitted him≈øelf to the Romi≈øh Church, yet ob≈øeruing and holding their ancient ceremonies and cu≈øtomes, which by the Pope was ≈øtill permitted vnto them: and when my Lord the Archbi≈øhop held a prouinciall coun≈øell within the citie of Goa, where his ≈øuffraganes were a≈ø≈øembled, that is to ≈øay, ye bi≈øhops of Cochin, Malacca, and China, to authorize the ≈øame, the afore≈øayd Bi≈øhop was likewi≈øe called thether, who as then was newlie come from Rome, being made an Archbi≈øhop, and was per≈øonally in the coun≈øell, but would not in any ≈øort con≈øent vnto the altering or changing of anie points of his Religion, or ceremonies from the ≈øuffraganes & from his Chri≈øtians, which were commonly called S. Thomas Chri≈øtians. But returning to our matter, they ≈øay that when S. Thomas had long preached, and taught in the kingdome of Nar≈øinga,

From Mu≈øulepatan the coa≈øt runneth again Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, to the kingdom of Bengalen, which is 120. miles, and it is the lande and kingdome of Orixa, which ≈øtretcheth along the ≈øame coa≈øt vnto the Riuer of Ganges, the beginning of the kingdom of Bengalen. This coa≈øt of Nar≈øinga, Bi≈ønagar and Orixa, are by the Portingalles commonly called (as al≈øo the coa≈øt of Negapatan and Saint Thomas) Choramandel, vntil you come to Bengalen, where the Portingalles haue great traffique, for that it is a very rich and plentiful Country of all things, as Ryce and all manner of fowles, and bea≈øts in great abundance. It is al≈øo a hole≈øome countrey and a good ayre for ≈øtrange nations, for that the Portingals and other countreymen can better brooke it then other places in India: From the≈øe coa≈øtes they v≈øe great traffique vnto Bengala, Pegu, Sian, & Malacca, and al≈øo to India: there is excellent faire linnen of Cotton made in Negapatan, Saint Thomas, and Mu≈øulepatan, of all colours, and wouen with diuers ≈øorts of loome workes and figures, verie fine and cunningly wrought, which is much worne in India, and better e≈øt√©emed then ≈øilke, for that it is higher pri≈øed then ≈øilke, becau≈øe of the finenes & cuÃÑning workmaÃÑ≈øhip: they are called Rechatas & Cheylas, wherof the Chri≈øtians & Portingals in India do commoÃÑly make br√©eches. They likewi≈øe make clothes thereof for women to put about them from their nauelles downeward, bound about their bodies, which they weare within the hou≈øe, very finely made, the be≈øt ≈øort are named clothes of Sara≈ø≈øo, ≈øome being mingled with thr√©edes of golde and ≈øiluer, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe of a thou≈øand ≈øortes, very beautifull to behold, wherewith they cloath them≈øelues in very comely manner. In this coa≈øt growe the great and thicke r√©eds, which are v≈øed in India to make the Pallankins, wherein they carry the women, as in the Indian figures you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e, which are ≈øo thicke, that a man can hardly gripe them with both his handes, very faire to looke vpon, and very high, being of diuers colours, as blacke, redde, &c. Whereof in an other place I will ≈øay more.

div.head: The 16. Chapter. Of the Kingdome of Bengalen, and the riuer Ganges.
div.p:
AT the ende of the Kingdome of Orixa and the ‚Ä¢ a≈øt of
‚Ä¢ horamandel beginneth the Riuer Ganges in the kingdom of Bengalen: This is one of the mo≈øt famous Riuers in all the world, and it is not knowne from whence it ≈øpringeth. Some are of opinion that it commeth out of the earthly paradi≈øe becau≈øe of an old ≈øpeech of the Bengalers, which is, that in time pa≈øt a certaine King of Bengalen was de≈øirous to know froÃÑ whence the riuer Ganges hath her beginning, to the which ende hee cau≈øed certaine people to bee brought vp and nouri≈øhed with nothing but rawe fi≈øh, and ≈øuch like foode,A fable of the people of Bengalen concerning the heade or ≈øpring of ye riuer Ganges. thereby to make them the apter to accompli≈øh his de≈øire, which people (hauing made boats fitte for the purpo≈øe) he ≈øent vp the riuer, who were certain monthes vpon the water, ≈øo long til they came where they felt a mo≈øt plea≈øant and ≈øw√©ete ≈øauour, and founde a very cleare and mo≈øt temperate skie, with ≈øtill and plea≈øant water, that it ≈ø√©emed vnto them to bee an earthly paradi≈øe, and being de≈øirous to rowe further vpwardes they could not, ≈øo that they were compelled (≈ø√©eing no remedie) to returne againe the ≈øame way that they came, and being returned, certified the King what they had ≈ø√©ene. They that will not credit this are hard of beliefe, for my parte I leaue it to the readers iudgement.

This Riuer hath Crocodiles in it, like the riuer of Nilus in Aegipt, the mouth or entry thereof lyeth vnder 22. degr√©es, and the coa≈øt runneth Ea≈øt and by South; to the Kingdome of Aracan, which is about 80. miles: it is an vneuen coa≈øt full of I≈ølandes, ≈øholes, hookes, and cr√©ekes, for the lande of Bengalen lyeth inwards of the gulf, which is called Bengala, for that froÃÑ Aracan, the coa≈øt beginneth againe to runne South and Ea≈øt outwardes towardes Malacca, and to the vttermo≈øt hooke which is called Singapura: But returning to Bengala and the Riuer Ganges, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that this riuer is holden and accounted of all the Indians to be a holy and a ble≈ø≈øed water,The ≈øuper≈øttious opinions of the Indians concerning the Riuer of Ganges. and they do certainely belieue, that ≈øuch as wa≈øh and bath them≈øelues therein (bee they neuer ≈øo great ≈øinners) all their ≈øinnes are cleane forgiuen them, and that from thenceforth they are ≈øo cleane and pure from ≈øinne, as if they were newe borne againe, and al≈øo that hee which wa≈øheth not him≈øelf therein cannot be ≈øaued, for the which cau≈øe there is a mo≈øt great and incredible re≈øorte vnto the ≈øame, from all the partes of India & the Ea≈øt countries, in great troupes, where they v≈øe diuers ≈øtrange ceremonies, and ≈øuper≈øtitions, mo≈øt horrible to heare, for they doe mo≈øt ≈øtedfa≈øtly bel√©eue that they ≈øhall thereby merit eternall life.

From th ‚Ä¢ Riuer Ea≈øtward 50. miles lyeth the towne of Chatigan, which is the chief towne of Bengala: The naturall borne people of Bengala are in a manner like tho≈øe of
Seylon, but ≈øomewhat whiter then ye Chingalas: they are a mo≈øt ≈øubtill and wicked people,The „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Beng ‚Ä¢ ns. and are e≈øt√©emed the wor≈øt ≈ølaues of all India, for that they are all th√©eues, and the women whores, although this fault is common throughout all India, no place excepted. They haue a cu≈øtome that they neuer dre≈ø≈øe or ≈ø√©eth meat twice in one pot, but haue euery time a new pot.The Beng ‚Ä¢ lians ‚Ä¢ aw for adultery‚ñ™ When≈øoeuer they are found in adulterie, they haue their no≈øes cut off, and from that time forwarde they mu≈øt leaue ech others company, which is mo≈øt narrowly looked vnto by their law. The countrey is mo≈øt plentiful of nece≈ø≈øary victuails ≈øpecially Rice, for that there is more of it in that countrey then in al the ca≈øt countries, for they do yearly lade diuers ≈øhippes therewith, which come thether from all places, and there is neuer any want thereof‚ñ™ and all other things in like ≈øort, and ≈øo good cheape that it were incredible to declare; for that an O ‚Ä¢ e or a Cowe is there to be bought for one Lari ‚Ä¢ n, which is as much as halfe a Gilderne, Sh√©epe, Hens, and other things after the like rate, a Candit of Ryce,Victuailes good cheap in Bengala. which is as much, little more or le≈ø≈øe as fourteene bu≈øhelles of Flemmi≈øh mea≈øure, is ≈øold there for halfe a Gilderne, and for halfe a Doller: Sugar and other ware accordingly, whereby you may wel conceiue what plentie they haue. The Portingalles deale & traffique thether, and ≈øome places are inhabited by them, as the hauens which they call Porto grande, and Porto pequeno, that is, the great hauen and the little hauen, but there they haue no Fortes, nor any gouernement, nor policie as in India they haue, but liue in a manner like wild men, and vntamed hor≈øes, for that euery man doth there what hee will, and euery man is Lord and mai≈øter, neyther e≈øt√©eme they any thing of iu≈øtice, whether there be any or none, and in this manner doe certayne Portingalles dwell among them, ≈øome here, ≈øome there ≈øcattered abroade, and are for the mo≈øt part ≈øuch as dare not ≈øtay in India for ≈øome wickedne≈ø≈øe by them committed: notwith≈øtanding there is great trafficke v≈øed in tho≈øe partes by diuers ≈øhips and marchants, which all ye year diuers times both go come to and from all the Orientall parts.

Be≈øides their Ryce, much Cotton linnen is made there which is very fine, and much e≈øt√©emed in India, and not only ≈øpread abroad and carryed into India and al the Ea≈øt parts, but al≈øo into Portingal, and other places: this linnen is of diuers ≈øorts, and is called Sarampuras, Ca≈ø≈øas, Com≈øas, Beatillias, Satopa≈ø≈øas, and a thou≈øande ≈øuch like names: They haue likewi≈øe other linnen excellently wrought of a hearbe, which they ≈øpinne like yearne: this yearne is to be ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ene at the hou≈øe of Paludanus: it is yealowi≈øh, and is called the hearbe of Bengalen, wherewith they do mo≈øt cunningly ≈øtitch their couerlits, pauilions, pillowes, carpets, and mantles, therein to chri≈øten children, as women in childbed with vs v≈øe to doe, and make them with flowers and branches, and per≈øonages, that it is wonderfull to ≈ø√©e, and ≈øo finely done with cunning workeman≈øhippe, that it cannot be mended throughout Europe: likewi≈øe they make whole p√©eces or webbes of this hearbe, ≈øometimes mixed and wouen with ≈øilke, although tho≈øe of the hearbe it ≈øelfe are dearer and more e≈øt√©emed, and is much fayrer theÃÑ the ≈øilke. The≈øe webs are named Sarrijn, and it is much v≈øed and worne in India, as well for mens br√©eches, as dublets, and it may be wa≈øhed like linnen, and being wa≈øht it ≈øheweth and continueth as faire as if it were new.

From Bengala commeth much Algallia, or Ciuet, but by the ≈øubtiltie and villany of the Bengalians it is fal≈øifyed, & mixed with filth, as ≈øalt, oyle, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe, whereby it is not much e≈øt√©emed. Al≈øo in Bengala are found great numbers of the bea≈øts, which in Latine are called Rhinocerotes, and of the Portingalles Abadas, who≈øe horne, t√©eth, fle≈øh, blood, clawes, and what≈øoeuer he hath, both without and within his bodie, is good again≈øt poy≈øon, and is much accounted of throughout all India, as in an other place ≈øhall be ≈øhewed more at large. There groweth likewi≈øe marble coloured R√©edes, whereof you may ≈ø√©e many ≈øortes in the cu≈øtodie of Paludanus, which the Portingalles call Canas de Bengala, that is, R√©edes of Bengala: within they are full of pith, and are about the thickne≈ø≈øe of Spani≈øh r√©edes, but ≈øomewhat thinner, and when they are gr√©ene they bowe and bend like Willow twigges: they are outwardly of diuers colours and ≈øpeckled as if they were painted. They v≈øe them in Portingall for olde women to beare in their handes when they goe abroad or vppon the ≈øtones. There is another ≈øorte of the ≈øame r√©eds which they call Rota: the≈øe are thinne like twigges of Willow for ba≈økets, whereof Paludanus can ≈øhewe you great numbers, with the which in India they make many faire ba≈økets, and a thou≈øande other curious deui≈øes, Sugar, Butter, and ≈øuch like ware they haue in great quantitie as I ≈øaid before: but this ≈øhall ≈øuffice for Bengala, whereof we leaue to ≈øpeake, and returne to the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt as it lyeth along the ≈øhore.

div.head: The 17. Chapter. Of the coa≈øts and lands of Aracan, Pegu and Sian, to the Cape of Singapura, & the towne and fortre≈ø≈øe of Malacca.
div.p:
BEyond the kingdome of Bengala, beginneth the kingdomes of Aracan & Pegu, which coa≈øt ≈øtretcheth from Bengala ≈øouth and by Ea≈øt to the town and hauen of Martauan, in the land of Pegu, and is 70. miles: Martauan lyeth vnder 16. degr√©es, from whence beginneth the kingdome or land of Sian: the≈øe kingdomes of Aracan and Pegu are very rich & fruitfull of all things, be≈øides Gold and precious ≈øtones, as Rubies, E≈øpinels, Saffires, Iacinthes, Emeraldes, Granates, and ≈øuch like, as it is well knowne by the great numbers that are dayly brought out of tho≈øe countries into all places. Likewi≈øe they make harde ware, which is carried throughout the world: There are greater number of Elephantes in tho≈øe countries, then in any other place of India, or the Orientall countries; & the Portingalles that traffique there, affirme that the king of Pegu hath a white Elephant which hee prayeth vnto, and holdeth it to b√©e holy. The Peguans haue a cu≈øtome, that when any ≈øtranger commeth into their land to deale and traffique with them,Strange cu≈øtoms of the Peguans. of what nation ≈øoeuer he bee: they a≈øke him how long he meaneth to ≈øtay there, and hauing tolde them, they bring him many maides, that of them he may take his choice, and make contract and agr√©e with the parentes of the maid that liketh him be≈øt, for the v≈øe of her during his continuance there: which done he bringeth her to his lodging, and ≈øhe ≈øcrueth him about all his affaires, both by day & by night, like his ≈ølaue or his wife, but hee mu≈øt take heede that in the meane time hee keepeth not company with other women, for thereby hee may incurre great daunger, and ≈øtand in perill of his life. When the time of his re≈øidence is ended, he payeth the friendes or parents of the maid as much as he agreed for with theÃÑ, which done he departeth quietly away, and the maid returneth with credite home againe vnto her friendes, and is as well e≈øt√©emed of as euer ≈øhe was before: and if after that the ≈øame maide chance to marrie, were it with the principalle≈øt of the Countrey, and that the afore≈øaid ≈øtranger ≈øhold come to traffique in the ≈øame place againe, hee may againe demand his woman, and he ≈øhall haue her without re≈øi≈øtance of her hu≈øband, or any ≈øhame vnto him, and ≈øhe remaineth by the ≈øtranger as long as he abideth there, and he trauelling from thence, ≈øhe goeth home againe vnto her hu≈øband, which among them is holden for a mo≈øt ≈øure and inuiolable law. Likewi≈øe when any gentleman or noble man will marrie with a maide, hee goeth to ≈ø√©eke one of his friendes, or a ≈øtraunger, and intreateth him to lie with his bride the fir≈øt night of their mariage, and to take her maydenhead from her, which he e≈øteemeth as a great plea≈øure & honour done vnto him, that another man wold take vpon him to ea≈øe him of ≈øo much payne: This cu≈øtome is not onely v≈øed among the Gentlemen and chiefe nobilitie of the lande, but by the King him≈øelfe. Al≈øo diuers of the Peguans weare a bell vpon their yarde, and ≈øome two, as bigge as an Acorne, which is made fa≈øt betweene the fle≈øh and the skinne. Of the like Belles Paludanus can ≈øhew you one, which I brought out of India, and gaue it him; which bels haue a very ≈øweet ≈øounde: This cu≈øtome of wearing Belles was ordained by them, becau≈øe the Peguans in time pa≈øt were great Sodomites, and v≈øing this cu≈øtome of belles, it would be a meane to let them from the ≈øame. The women go altogether naked, onely with a cloth before their priuie members, which (as they go) openeth & vncouereth, ≈øhewing all they haue, which is by them ordayned, to the ende that by ≈øuch meanes it ≈øhould tempt men to lu≈øt after women, and to auoid that mo≈øt abhominable & accur≈øed ≈øinne of Sodomie. There are likewi≈øe ≈øome among them that doe ≈øowe vp the priuie member of their female children as ≈øoone as they are borne, leauing them but a little hole to auoid their water; and when ≈øhe marrieth the hu≈øband cutteth it open, and maketh it as great or as little as hee will, which they with a certaine oyntment or ≈øalue can quickly heale. I ≈øaw one of tho≈øe women in Goa whom the Surgeon of my May≈øter the Archbi≈øhops hou≈øe did cut open: men would iudge all the≈øe thinges to be fables, yet they are mo≈øt true, for I doe not onely knowe it by the dayly trafficking of the Portingalles out of India thether, but al≈øo by the Peguans them≈øelues, whereof many dwell in India, ≈øome of them being Chri≈øtians, which tell it and confe≈ø≈øe it for a truth, as al≈øo the neerene≈ø≈øe of place and neighbourhood maketh it ≈øufficiently knowne. The people of Aracan, Pegu, and Sian are in forme, manner, and vi≈øage, much like tho≈øe of China, onely one difference they haue, which is, that they are ≈øomewhat whiter then the Bengalon, and ≈øomewhat browner then the men of China: The pictures
