≈øongs after their manner whereby they are wondred at, which maketh them proude, and hee that dwelleth in India, and can not ≈øpeake the Malayans ≈øpeach, wil hardly with vs learne the French tongue, their forme and figures are heere ≈øet downe, together with tho≈øe of the Ilands of Iaua, whereof hereafter we will ≈øpeake more.

div.head: The 19. Chapter. Of the Iland of Sumatra, in times pa≈øt called Taprobana.
div.p: RIght ouer again≈øt Malacca, Southea≈øt about 20. miles from the firme land by Malacca, wher the ≈øtraight is at the narrowe≈øt, lieth the ‚Ä¢ amous Ilande of Taprobana, now called Sumatra, by ≈øome Hi≈øtoriographers named Cher≈øone ‚Ä¢ o Aurea, others affirme it to be Ophir, from whence Salomon had his Golde, as the Scripture rehear≈øeth, and ≈øay that in times pa≈øt it was firme land, and ioyned vnto the Countrie of Malacca. The Iland beginneth from the fir≈øt pointe which lyeth right again≈øt the Gulfe of Bengala vnder fiue degrees, on the North ≈øide, and ≈øtretcheth al≈øo before Malacca, South Southea≈øt, vntill it pa≈ø≈øeth by the Iland called Iaua Maior, where it endeth vnder 6. degr√©es on the South ≈øide, and is in length 170 miles, and in breadth 60. miles. The Portingals dwell not therein in any place, but deale and trafique in ≈øome places thereof, yet very few, for that the inhabitants them≈øelues doe bring many of their commodities vnto Malacca.

The Iland hath many Kings, the principalle≈øt is the King of D. chem, which lyeth vpon a point of the land, vnder 4. degrees and a halfe on the North ≈øide. This Dachem is very mightie and a great enemie to the Portingals, he hath often be≈øieged Malacca, and done it great mi≈øchiefe, as it happened in the time of my biding in India, by ≈øtopping the pa≈ø≈øage of all victuals and other Marchandi≈øe comming to Malacca, as al≈øo by k√©eping the pa≈ø≈øage of the ≈øtraight betw√©ene Malacca and Sumatra, ≈øo that the ≈øhippes of China, Iapen, and the Ilande of Molucco, were forced to ≈øayle about, whereby they pa≈ø≈øed much danger, to the great di≈øcommoditie and hindrance of trauelling Marchants, and they of Malacca and India, had many Gallies in the ≈øtraights of Malacca, which ≈øome accur≈øed Chri≈øtians that haue no re≈øidence, had taught them to make, whereby they did great mi≈øchiefe‚ñ™ and yet dayly doe, but by Gods helpe and the Portingals ayde out of India, all places were freed, and reduced into their pri≈øtinate e≈øtate, as in another place we ≈øhall declare. It was long ≈øithence concluded & determined by the King of Portingale and his Viceroye, that the Ile of Sumatra ≈øhould bee conquered, and at this pre≈øent there are certaine Captaines, that to the ≈øame end haue the Kings pay, with the title
Malachae incolae ≈øermone et moribus quam reliqui Indi cultioribus et magis comes.
In woonders van Mallacka welcke alle andere Indianen in taele courto≈øije en amoreushc√øt te boven gaen.
In≈øulanus e Iava gens durae cervicis. Een c√ølander wt ‚Ä¢ ava welcks volck is hart: neckich en op≈øtinaet.
of Generals and chiefe Captaines, or Adelantado of this conque≈øt, but as yet there is nothing done therein, although they doe ≈øtill talke thereof but doe it not.

The Iland is very rich of mynes of Gold, Siluer, Bra≈ø≈øe, (whereof they make greate Ordinance) precious ≈øtones, and other mettall: of all kinde of Spices, ≈øweete woode, rootes, and other medicinable Herbes and Drugges: it hath a hill of Brim≈øtone that burneth continually, and they ≈øaye, there is a fountaine which runneth pure & ≈øimple Bal≈øame, it hath likewi≈øe great ≈øtore of Silke. At the la≈øt be≈øieging and troubles of Malacca, the Kinge of Acheijn ≈øent a p√©ece of Ordinance, ≈øuch as for greatnes length and workman≈øhip, the like is hardly to bee found in all Chri≈øtendome, which hee gaue in marriage with his daughter to the King of Ior, a town lying by Malacca, vpon the coa≈øt of Sian, but this p√©ece with his daughter were taken vpon the way by the Portingals, and brought into Malacca, which p√©ece was after laden in the Ship that ≈øayleth euery yeare from Malacca to Portingale, and ≈øent vnto the King for a pre≈øent, being ≈øo heauie that they were forced to lay it in the Bala≈øt of the ≈øhip. The ≈øame p√©ece lyeth at this pre≈øent in the Ile of Tarcera, becau≈øe the ≈øaid ≈øhippe ≈øtayed there, being in our companie as I returned out of India, al≈øo the Towne of Ior vpon the ≈øame occa≈øion was by the Portingals be≈øieged, and at the la≈øt wonne and by them ra≈øed to the ground, and for euer made wa≈øt, wherin they found about 150. Bra≈ø≈øe p√©eces ≈ømal & great, ≈øome of them beeing no greater then a Mu≈øket, and ≈øome greater, and ≈øo of all ≈øorts, verie cunningly wrought with Flowers and per≈øonages, which I haue purpo≈øely ≈øet down to let you know that they haue other kindes of Mettals, and know howe to handle them.

But returning to our matter, There are ≈øome places in this Iland where the Portingales doe traffique, which are tho≈øe that v≈øe to traffique to Malacca, as a Towne called Pedir, which lyeth 20. miles from Achejin, vppon the coa≈øt right ouer again≈øt Malacca, from whence commeth much Pepper and Golde, & from an other place called Campar, which lyeth almo≈øt vnder the Equinoctiall line, vppon the corner on the South ≈øide, on the ≈øame ≈øide on the We≈øt coa≈øt of the Iland lyeth a place called Manancabo, where they make Poinyards, which in India are called Cry≈øes, which are very well accounted and e≈øt√©emed of, and is thought the be≈øt weapon in all the Orient, whereof tho≈øe of Iaua & Malacca do make gret proui≈øion for theÃÑ≈øelus.

div.head: The 20. Chapter. Of the Iland of Iaua Maior, with their wares, Marchandi≈øes, and trades, waights, myntes, and prices thereof with other particularities.
div.p:
SOuth Southea≈øt right ouer again≈øt the la≈øt point or corner of the Ile of Sumatra, on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line lyeth the Iland called Iaua Maior, or great Iaua, where there is a ≈øtraight or narrow pa≈ø≈øage betweene Sumatra and Iaua, called the ≈øtraight of Sunda, of a place ≈øo called, lying not far from thence
within the Ile of Iaua: this Iland beginneth vnder ‚Ä¢ degr√©es on the ≈øouth ≈øide, and runneth ea≈øt and by ≈øouth 150 miles long, but touching the breadth, it is not found, becau≈øe as yet it is not di≈øcouered, nor by the Inhabitants them≈øelues well knowne. Some thinke it to be firme land, and parcell of the countrie called Terra incognita, which being ≈øo, ≈øhoulde reach from that place to the Cape de Bona ≈øperaÃÑce, but as yet it is not certainly known, & therefore it is accouÃÑted for an Iland: the inhabitants ≈øay that within the land there is a Riuer, wherin if any wood doth fal, it turneth into ≈øtone. Through this ≈øtraight or narrowe pa≈ø≈øage Thomas Candi≈øh an Ingli≈øh captaine pa≈ø≈øed with his Ship, as he came out of the ≈øouth parts, from Noua Spaigne. This Iland aboundeth with Rice, and all manner of victuals, as oxen, kyne, hogges, ≈øh√©epe and hennes, &c. al≈øo Onyons, Garlicke, Indian nuttes and with al kind of Spices, as cloues, Nutmegges, and mace, which they carry vnto Malacca. The principall hauen in the Iland is Sunda Calapa, whereof the ≈øtraight beareth the name: in this place of SuÃÑda there is much Pepper, and it is better then that of India or Malabar, wherof there is ≈øo great quantitie, that they could lade yearlie from thence 4 or 5 thou≈øand kintales Portingale waight: it hath likewi≈øe much frankin≈øence, Beniom of Bonien called Folie, Camphora, as al≈øo Diamantes, to which place meÃÑ might very well traffique, without any impeachment for that the Portingales come not thether, becau≈øe great numbers of Iaua come them≈øelues vnto Malacca to ≈øell their wares.

And although it be be≈øyde the matter, yet doe I not e≈øteeme it vnnece≈ø≈øary in briefe to ≈øhewe, in what ≈øort they v≈øe to buy, ≈øell, and deall with ware, money and waight ≈øeing we are now in hand with the ≈øaid Iland of Iaua. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that in Sunda there is no other kind of money then certaine copper mynt called Caixa, of the bignes of a HollaÃÑ des doite, but not half ≈øo thicke, in the middle whereof is a hole to hang it on a ≈øtring, for that commonlie they put two hundreth or a thow≈øand vpon one ≈øtring, wherewith they knowe how to make their accounts, which is as followeth‚ñ™ 200 Caixas is a Sata, and ‚Ä¢ Satas are 1000 Caixas, which is as much as a Cru≈øado Portingale money, or 3 Key≈øars guilders, Netherlandi≈øh money, Pepper of Sunda is ≈øolde by the ≈øacke, and each ≈øacke wayeth 45 Catten waight of China: euerie Catte is as much as 20 Portingale ounces, and euerie ≈øacke is worth, as it is ≈øolde there, 5000 Caixas, and when it is at the highe≈øt, 6 or 7 thow≈øand Caixas, Mace, Cloues, nutmegges, white and bla ‚Ä¢ k Beniamin, & Camphora, are ≈øolde by the Bhar, each Bhar of Sunda weigheth 330 Catten of China. Mace that is good is commonlie worthe 100 or 120 thow≈øand Caixas, and good Cloues after the rate, but bad or foule Cloues of Ba≈øton are worth 70 or 80 thow≈øand Caixas the Bhar. Nutmegges are commonly worth 20 or 25 thow≈øand Caixas the Bhar: white and black Benioin is worthe 150 and 180 thow≈øand Caixas & 200 thou≈øand the Bhar. The wares that are there by them de≈øired in barter for their ≈øpices, are as hereafter followeth, diuers and different ≈øorts and colours of cotton lynnen, which come out of Cambaia, Choramandel and Bengala, as Sara≈øles de G ‚Ä¢ ba ‚Ä¢ es, and painted Tapen from S. Thomas, of fyue elles the p√©ece: they are clothes ≈øo called out of Bengala, white Cotton lynnen, viz Sarampuras, Ca≈ø≈øas, Satepo≈øas, & blacke Satopa≈øen, and ≈øome browne vnbleached lynnen: out of Cambaia black Cannequiins red Turiaes, which are all clothes of cotton lynnen red Beyramen great and litle‚ñ™ which is verie like vnto Cambricke: and I am per≈øwaded, if Clothe of Holland were there to be ≈øoulde, it would be more e≈øt√©emed then Cotton lynnen out of India. The≈øe Iauens are of a verie fretfull and ob≈øtinate Nature, of colour much like the Malayers, brown, and not much vnlike the men of Bra≈øilla, ≈øtrong and well ≈øet, big limmed, flatte faces, broad thicke ch√©ekes, great eyebrowes, ≈ømal eyes, little beard, not pa≈øt 3 or 4 hayres vpon the vpper lippe & the chinne: the hayre on their heades very thyn and ≈øhort, yet as blacke as pitche who≈øe picture is to be ≈ø√©en by the picture of the M ‚Ä¢ layen of Malacca, becau≈øe they dwell & trafficke much together.

Returning againe vnto the coa≈øt, Ea≈øt & by ≈øouth about 25 miles beyond Iaua Maior, beginneth the IlaÃÑd of Iaua Minor or litle Iaua, and ≈øomewhat further the Iland T ‚Ä¢ or, (wher ≈øanders groweth in great abundance) and a thou≈øand other Ilands bordering all about, which I can not particularly ≈øet down, yet are they all inhabited, and full of people, and are like the Iauer.

From Malacca they trauell to the Ilandes of Molucca, Banda & Amboyna, where the Portingales haue both ≈øorts & captaines and trafficke with them: their way is from Malacca ≈øouth ea≈øt and by ≈øouth, aboue 100 miles, betw√©ene many Ilands and th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ugh many ≈øhallowes, ≈øo that they mu≈øt anker euerie night, to auoyd danger of ≈øandes, which continueth almo≈øt all the waye to Mol ‚Ä¢ cca, and hauing in that ≈øort pa≈ø≈øed tho≈øe hundreth miles, they ≈øet their cour≈øe ea≈øtward, and ea≈øt and by north, 250 miles, to the Iland called Banda, which lyeth vnder 5 degr√©es on the
≈øouth ≈øide. In this Iland the Portingales doe trafficke, for in it are the be≈øt Nutmegges & Flowers. There likewi≈øe they doe pre≈øerue nutmegges, and make oyle thereof, which is brought to Malacca, and from thence into all other places: the trafficke there con≈øi≈øteth mo≈øt in bartering, as it doth in SuÃÑda & Iaua, but they are not to be tru≈øted, you mu≈øt k√©ep good watch, and goe not on land, but ≈øtay abord the ≈øhippe, whether the Ilanders bring their marchandi≈øes, and deale with men as I ≈øaid before, for it happeneth diuers times that they deceaue the Portingales, which tru≈øt them ouer much, for that one of my acquaintance and my friend being there, for captaine in a ≈øhippe, the ≈øhippe being ca≈øt away vpon that coa≈øt, was with all his men taken & put in pri≈øon, where for the ≈øpace of two yeares he indured a mo≈øt mi≈øerable life, and in the end was ran≈øomed. All the≈øe voyages to Banda, Moluca, & tho≈øe Ilands, and al≈øo any other way what≈øoeuer in India, may no man make, without licence and ≈øpeciall fauour of the King of Portingall, and their offices are giuen them in recompence of their ≈øeruice in the Indies, as al≈øo all other offices, as in an other place ≈øhall be declared.

About 20 miles beyond Banda North we≈øt, lieth the Iland called Amboyna, where the Portingales haue a ≈ømall fort: this Iland hath not much ≈øpice, but the ≈øhippes that ≈øayle from Malacca to Maluco, doe ≈øtay there, and take in fre≈øh water. From this Iland Northwarde 70 miles, lyeth the Iland Tydor, vnder one degr√©e ‚Ä¢ th, and i ‚Ä¢ the fir≈øt Iland of the Moluca ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ xe miles northward lyeth Malaco, & not farre thence Tarnate, and the Ilands of Cloues.

div.head: The 21. Chapter. Of the Iland of Maluc ‚Ä¢ .
div.p: THe Ilandes of Maluco are fiue, viz. Maluco, Tarnate, Tydor, Geloulo, and an other where the Portingales haue 2 forts, that is in Tarnate and Tydor, which long ≈øince were di≈øcouered and wonne, where they trafficke from Malacca & out of India. The Spaniards haue ≈øought diuers meanes to haue traffique there, and came from thence out of Noua Spaigne, into the Iland called Tarnate, where in a ≈øtorme they lo≈øt their ≈øhippe, and ≈øo could not get from thence againe, whereby they were by the Portingales mo≈øt of them ≈ølayne, and the re≈øt taken and ≈øent pri≈øoners into Portingale, whereupon the King of Spaine and Portingale had a long quarrell and contention, touching the diui≈øion of their Conque≈øts, and di≈øcouery of the ≈øeas, which by the Popes meanes at the la≈øt was ended, in ≈øuch ≈øort‚ñ™ that at this pre≈øent onely the Portingale trafickes to tho≈øe Ilands. The≈øe Ilands haue no other ≈øpice then cloues, but in ≈øo great abundance, that as it appeareth, by them the whole world is filled therewith. In this Iland are found ‚Ä¢ ie hilles, they are very dry & burnt land, they haue nothing els but victuals of fle≈øh and fi≈øh, but for Rice, Corne, Onyons, Garlicke, and ≈øuch like, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries, ≈øome are brought from Portingale, and ≈øome from other places thereabout, which they take and barter for cloues. The bread which they haue there of their owne baking is of wood or rootes like the men of Bra≈øillia, and their cloathes are of wouen ≈øtrawe or herbes, faire to the eye: in the≈øe Ilands onlie is found the bird, which the Portingales call pa≈ø≈øaros de Sol, that is Fowle of the Sunne, the Italians call it Manu codiatas, & the Latini≈øts, Paradi≈øeas, & by vs called Paradice birdes, for ye beauty of their feathers which pa≈ø≈øe al other birds: the≈øe birds are neuer ≈ø√©ene aliue, but being dead they are found vpon the Iland: they flie, as it is ≈øaid, alwaies into the Sunne, and k√©epe them≈øelues continually in the ayre, without lighting on the earth, for they haue neither f√©et nor wings, but onely head and body, and the mo≈øt part tayle, as appeareth by the birdes that are brought from thence into India, and ≈øome from thence hether but not many, for they are co≈øtlie. I brought two of them with me, for Doctor Paludanus, which were male and female, which I gaue vnto him, for his chamber. The≈øe Ilands lie among diuers other Ilands, and becau≈øe there is no ≈øpeciall notice of them, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømall conuer≈øation with them: I let them pa≈ø≈øe, and turne again vnto the coa≈øt of Malacca, which I left at the Cape of Singapura, and ≈øo will ≈øhewe the Coa≈øt along.

div.head: The 22. Chapter. From the Cape Singapura to the towne of Sian, and the coa≈øt of Cambaia, and Cauchinchina, and the Iles of Borneo, Lu≈øons, Manillios or Philippinas.
div.p:
FRom the Cape of Singapura to the hooke named Sino≈øura ea≈øtward, are 18 miles, 6 or 7 miles from thence lyeth a cliffe in ye ≈øea called Pedra bianque, or white Rock, where the ≈øhippes that come and goe to and from China, doe oftentymes pa≈ø≈øe in great danger
and ≈øome are left vpon it, whereby the Pylots when they come thether are in great feare, for that other way then this they haue not.

From this hook Sino≈øura Ea≈øt & by South 40. miles beginneth the fir≈øt corner of the I≈øland Borneo, vnder one degr√©e in ye North, and ≈øtretcheth 120. myles North ea≈øt till you be vnder 7. degr√©es, the breadth as yet is not knowne nor di≈øcouered. This I≈øle is full of tr√©es from whence Camfora is taken, and is the be≈øt in all the Ea≈øt countries. From Sino≈øura the coa≈øt reacheth North 30. miles to the towne of Pan, which lyeth vnder thr√©e degr√©es and a halfe: ten miles further by the ≈øame c ‚Ä¢ ur≈øe the coa≈øt runneth againe North Northwe≈øt for 50. miles, where the towne of Patane lyeth vnder 7. degrees and a halfe: The≈øe two towns Pan and Patane are kingdomes, but contributarie to Sian: From the≈øe places comes the wood called Pala Dagula, and the co≈øtly ≈øw√©et woode called Calamba, which being good, is waid again≈øt Siluer and Gold: they al≈øo haue Camphora, but not ≈øo good as that of the I≈øland Borneo. There is founde ≈øome gold, and the ≈øtone called Bezars ≈øtone, which is very co≈øtly and proued to be good again≈øt poy≈øon. There are likewi≈øe ≈øome Diamants, and al≈øo Nutmegs and flowers, and the wood Sapon, whereof al≈øo much is brought from Sian, it is like Bra≈øill to die withall.

From Patane 120. myles North, the coa≈øt runneth backe againe vnto Sian, which lyeth vnder 14. degr√©es and a halfe from Sian, from the turning in South we≈øt 15. myles: The coa≈øt runneth again ≈øouth ea≈øt 70. miles to the towne of Cambaia: this towne lyeth vnder 10. degr√©es. From thence the coa≈øt runneth againe Northea≈øt 60. miles, and 60. miles Northwe≈øt: froÃÑ whence it runneth We≈øt North we≈øt to the furthe≈øt parte inwarde of the cr√©eke of Cuchinchina: This coa≈øt of Cambaia is al≈øo called the coa≈øt of ChaÃÑpaa, this land hath much of ye ≈øw√©et wood Calamba: Through this kingdome runneth the riuer Mecom into the ≈øea, which the Indians name Captaine of all the Riuers, for it hath ≈øo much water in the Summer, that it couereth and watereth all the countrey, as the riuer Nilus doth the countrey of Aegypt. The people of Cambaia bel√©eue that all creatures both men and bea≈øtes of what ≈øort ≈øoeuer they be, do here receyue reward for their worke whether it be good or bad. Vpwards in the land behind Cambaia and Sian are many ≈øeuerall nations, as Laos, which are a great and a mightie people, others named Auas and Bramas, which dwel by the hilles: others that dwell vpon the hils called Gueos, which liue like wild men, and eat mans fle≈øh, and marke all their bodies with hote iron, which they e≈øt√©eme a fr√©edome: The≈øe countreymen are ≈øuch as are knowne, be≈øides diuers others that are vnknowne.

From the coa≈øt of Cambaia or Champaa Ea≈øt or to ≈øeaward about 100. myles little more or le≈ø≈øe lie ye I≈ølands called the Lu≈ø≈øons or Lu≈ø≈øones, which were fir≈øt di≈øcouered by the Spaniardes out of newe Spaigne, in an‚ñ™ 1564. and were called al≈øo las Manillas or Philippinas, becau≈øe the principalle≈øt Hauen and Towne is called Manillia, and of others Lu≈ø≈øon, whereof al≈øo they are named the L ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øons ‚ñ™ and the Spaniardes gaue them the name of the King of Spaine, calling them ye Philippinas. This towne of Lu≈ø≈øon or Manillia lyeth vnder 14 degr√©es, by this towne and Iland of Lu≈ø≈øon lie a great number of Ilands, which are all called the Manillians, Lu≈ø≈øons or Philippinas, and are all at the commandement of the Spaniardes, who≈øe Gouernour or Captaine lyeth in the towne of Manillia or Lu≈ø≈øon, who was ≈øent thether out of Noua Spaigne in the behalfe of the king of Spaine, and al≈øo a Bi≈øhop, as head ouer all the re≈øt.

All the≈øe Ilands haue in time pa≈øt b√©ene vnder the crown of China, and vpon ≈øome occa≈øion left it, whereby there was no policie nor gouernment among the Inhabitants of the ≈øame, for that he that was the riche≈øt and of mo≈øt power among≈øt them was mai≈øter, and liued together like bea≈øtes, whereby the Spaniardes had „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈ømall labor to ≈øubdue them, whereof manie they bapti≈øed, and made them Chri≈øtians, which euerie day increa≈øed: it is a very fruitful land, and hath much corne and al ≈øorts of wilde bea≈øtes, as harts, hynd ‚Ä¢ , & ≈øuch like: al≈øo cattle, as buffels, oxen, kyne, hogges, goates &c. they haue manie mu≈øke cattes, all kinde of fruites, as in China, abundance of hony and fi≈øh: it is ≈øaid al≈øo that there is all kindes of ≈øpices, but as yet there is no certaintie thereof, but onely that the Spaniardes giue it forth ≈øo: but you mu≈øt thinke they doe it becau≈øe they wil extol and ≈øet forth their things aboue all others, as their maÃÑner is. Tho≈øe of China trafficke with the≈øe IlaÃÑds, and bring thether all ≈øortes of commodities out of their country, as al ≈øilkes, cottons, por≈øelynes, powder for ≈øhot, ≈øulphur, brim≈øtone, yron, ≈øt√©ele, quicke ≈øiluer, and other metals, coper, meal nuttes, cha≈ønuttes, bi≈øquit, dates, al ≈øorts of lynnen cloth, de≈økes, and ≈øuch like, and of all curious things that may be found, & there cometh froÃÑ China thether euery year at lea≈øt 20 ≈øhippes, and from thence is their marchandi≈øe by the Spaniardes ≈øhipped and ≈øent into newe Spaine, & to Mexico, which
„Äà1 page missing„Äâ
countrie of Spaine. The land by meanes of ye good ayre and temperatenes therof is fo fruitfull, that al things are there to be had in great abundance, as Corne, Rice, and other ≈øuch like graine or ≈ø√©edes, and is both ≈øowen and mowed continually al the yeare long. Within the land ther are ≈øome Elephants, Lyons, Tygers, and ≈øuch cruell bea≈øtes. There are al≈øo many bea≈øts of Mo≈øeliaet, that is to ≈øay, Mu≈øke Cattes, which are of the bigne≈ø≈øe and likene≈ø≈øe of a little Dogge, which they kill and burie for certaine daies, and being rotten, and well bru≈øed with blowes, whereby the fle≈øh and bloud are mixed together, they make many round Balles of the ≈øame fle≈øh & bloud ≈øo mixed, each Ball of an ounce waight, by the Portingals called Papo, which they carrie into all places. There are al≈øo in that land many Cattes of Algallia, or Ci ‚Ä¢ et Cattes, and ≈øome Amber. They haue al≈øo hor≈øes, but ≈ømaller then the hor≈øes in Europe. G√©e≈øe, Hennes, Duckes and ≈øuch like, are there in great aboundaunce, ryuer, and ≈øea Fi≈øh are likewi≈øe plentifull, and all kind of nece≈ø≈øaries what≈øoeuer. The countrie hath many mines of Golde and Siluer, but the King letteth it not commonly be carried out of the countrie, but k√©epeth it in his hou≈øe for trea≈øure, therefore they ≈øeeke and procure all things to bee brought into the land: notwith≈øtanding they haue great riches in their hou≈øes, of Gold, Siluer, and other common Iewels, they e≈øteeme more of Siluer then of Golde, becau≈øe the Golde is of many values and prices, and the Siluer is alwaies of one price. It hath al≈øo many Pearles and Alioffar, which come out of the Iland and Prouince of Aynao, al≈øo much Quick-≈øiluer, Copper, Iron, Steele, Blick, Tin, Leade, Brim≈øtone and other ≈øuch like mettales, and Amber, be≈øides all the≈øe riches, and innumerable rents that the King of China hath, it is ≈øaid that he hath in euery chiefe ≈øhire or Prouince towne a great and vnknowne trea≈øurie. It is a common cu≈øtome in that countrie to weare, as we doe here, cour≈øe and common cloth and linnen, as al≈øo Silke‚ñ™ Satin and Brocado, which is cloth of Golde and Siluer, with faire workes and borders, downe to their ≈øhooes, which they commonly v≈øe, becau≈øe of the great quantitie of Silke, that is within the countrie, for it is affirmed for a truth, that only from the town of Canton there is yearely carried into India, aboue thr√©e thou≈øand Quintals of Silke, which are ≈øold by waight, be≈øides the Silkes that are yearely carried to the Ilands of Iapa ‚Ä¢ , Lucon, or Phillippinas, and to the land of Si ‚Ä¢ n, and other countries bordering about the ≈øame: and yet there ≈øtayeth ≈øo much within the countrie, that therewith might bee laden whole Fl√©etes of ≈øhippes, and would not be mi≈ø≈øed: there is al≈øo much Flax and Cotton, and ≈øo good cheape, that it is almo≈øt incredible: the earthen Pots, Cuppes and ve≈ø≈øels that are made there, are not to bee numbred, which are yearely carried into India, Portingall, Noua Spaignia, & other waies, but the fine≈øt ≈øorte may not be carried out of the land vpon paine of death, but ≈øerue onely for the Lords and Gouernours of the countrie: which are ≈øo fine that Chri≈øtall is not comparable vnto it. The≈øe Pots and Cups are made inwards in the lande, of a certaine earth that is verie hard, which is beaten ≈ømal and then layed to ≈øt√©epe in Ce≈øterns of ≈øtone full of water, made for the purpo≈øe, and when it is well ≈øt√©eped and often ≈øtirred, (as we do milke to make Butter) of the fine≈øt thereof which driueth or ≈øwimmeth on the top they make the fine≈øt worke, and v≈øe the cour≈øer accordingly‚ñ™ whereof ≈øome they paint, and then they are dried and baked in Ouens.

p.hi: The maner to make Earthen Pots and Cups (called Porcelleyn-Cuppes) by Scaliger is ≈øet downe in his Booke of Subtilties in this manner. In the 92. Exerci≈øe. The Cups and earthen Pots that are called Porceleynes, whereof al≈øo the Earth hath her name, are fir≈øt beaten to ≈ømall Poulder, which they ≈øteepe in water, and then forme their Pots, Cuppes and ve≈ø≈øels out of the ≈øame, which done they burne them vnder the earth, and hauing layen in the earth 100, yeares, being then full baked and made, they are digged foorth and ≈øoulde, ≈øome ≈øay, that not the Cuppes &c. but the ≈øtuffe is buried, although Iohn Huyghens opinion ≈øeemeth to be true and according to their maner, ≈øaying, that they are made of Earth, as other Pots and Cannes are made in our countrie.

div.p: The land al≈øo aboundeth in Honie, Suger and Waxe, of all ≈øorts of Spices, rootes and plantes as al≈øo fruites, and much more then in Spaine: and other kindes of fruites al≈øo which are not knowne heere: there are Oranges that are ≈øw√©eter then Suger: there is a kind of fruit called Lechyas, which are like Plums, but of another ta≈øte, and are very good & much e≈øt√©emed, whereof I haue eaten, to conclude it hath of all things that man can wi≈øh or de≈øire.

The rents and reuenewes of the King of China are ≈øo great, that it is incredible, for he hath onely in cu≈øtome out of a riuer in the Prouince of Canton, for Salt that is made there, yearly a million and a halfe of Golde, whereby men may e≈øt√©eme the re≈øt accordingly. All the Townes in that Countrie are walled about with ≈øtone walles, and haue
Ditches of water round about them for their ≈øecuritie, they v≈øe no fortre≈ø≈øe nor Ca≈øtles, but onely vppon euery Gate of the Towne they haue ≈øtrong Towers, wherein they place their Ordinance for defence of ye towne. They v≈øe all kinde of armes, as Caliuers, Bowes, Pikes of diuers ≈øortes, Rapiers, like Falceons, Cortla≈ø≈øes and Targets. The ≈øouldiers when they goe to warre, weare Coates downe to their kn√©es, lyned with Cotton, ≈øo that the thru≈øt of a Pike or a Rapier will not readily enter, ≈øuch as are ≈øouldiers are paide by the King, which are knowen by wearing a red or a yellow Hat, whereof there are ≈øo many, that the number is not knowne, they haue Captaines of 10. of 100 of 1000. 10000. 20000. &c. Which Captaines may bee knowne by certaine tokens, one from the other, whereby they know how many men he hath vnder him. Euery month they Mu≈øter and are paide with Siluer money, for they haue no other Coyne, and they are p√©eces of cut Siluer, in which ≈øort they pay & receiue all their money, for the which purpo≈øe they doe alwayes carrie about them a paire of Ballaunce with an in≈øtrument to cut the Siluer. A ≈øouldier hath euery moneth, the value of a Ryall and a halfe of Spani≈øh money in ≈øiluer, which is more in that countrie (as the value and price of all things goeth there) then foure Ducates or twelue Guilders with vs. For Religion and ceremonies they are Heathens, without any ≈øparke or point of Mahomets law, or of any other ≈øects.The men of ‚Ä¢ hina pray the Deuil In many places they pray to the Diuell, onely becau≈øe hee ≈øhoulde not hurt them. When any man lieth on his death bed, they ≈øet the picture of the Diuell before him, with the Sunne in his left hand, and a poinyard in the right hand, which Diuell is painted with a very fierce looke: and therfore they de≈øire the patient or ≈øicke man to looke well vpon him, that hee may bee his friend in the world to come, and that yeare hee may not hurt him. They pray to the Sunne and the Moone, which they thinke, are man and wife, and when any Eclip≈øe happeneth, they make great ≈øacrifices, fearing that God will take their liues from them, and cleane ouerthrow them, whereby they are in great feare. They doe all belieue the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, and that after their deathes, they ≈øhall receiue either good or euill reward in the world to come according to their workes. Wherefore they v≈øe faire and co≈øtly Graues, and bel√©eue that in the world to come men ≈øhall neuer more die, but liue for euer, there are al≈øo in this land many and diuers faire Vniuer≈øities, and Schooles for learning, where they ≈øtudie Philo≈øophie, and the lawes of the land, for that not any man in China is e≈øt√©emed or accounted of, for his birth, family or riches, but onely for his learning and knowledge, ≈øuch are they that ≈øerue in euery Towne, and haue the gouernment of the ≈øame, being ≈øerued and honoured with great ≈øolemnities, and worthine≈ø≈øe, liuing in great plea≈øure and e≈øt√©emed as gods. They are called Lo ‚Ä¢ ias, and Mandorijns, and are alwaies borne in the ≈øtr√©etes, ≈øitting in Chariots which are hanged about with Curtaines of Silke, couered with Clothes of Golde and Siluer, and are much giuen to banketing, eating, drinking & making good cheare, as al≈øo the whole land of China. No man may rule, gouerne, or v≈øe any Office of Iu≈øtice in the Towne or place where he was borne, which they ≈øaye, the King doth, becau≈øe their friendes or parents ≈øhould not mooue or per≈øwade them to doe any thing contrarie to Iu≈øtice, or to the hinderance of the Kings ≈øeruice. When any of the afore≈øaide gouernours or rulers die in China, they kill diuers of their ≈øeruants and wiues, and cau≈øe all kinde of victuals and nece≈ø≈øaries with diuers Iewels to bee put into the Graue with them, whereby they thinke them≈øelues well prouided, and to haue good companie with them, to liue withall in the other world.

The Countrie is verie temperate & good ayre, for it beginneth vnder 19. degr√©es, and is in ≈øome places higher then 50. degr√©es, whereby it is to be pre≈øumed, that it mu≈øt of force be fruitfull, a great helpe thereunto is the earne≈øt and continuall labour the countrimen and inhabitants take, to build hou≈øes in their land, whereby there is not one foote of land lo≈øt, or that lyeth wa≈øt, for euen to the verie mountaines, it is both plowed & planted, becau≈øe there are ≈øo many people in the Countrie. It is not in mans memorie, that euer there was plague in that Countrie, and they haue a law which is very ≈øtraightly holden, that no man may goe or depart out of the Countrie without licence, nor yet that any ≈øtranger may come into the land without leaue vpon paine of death. Likewi≈øe no man may trauaile through the Country to begge, whereof they haue a great care, and looke n√©erely vnto it. The people are well formed, and commonly fat and well liking of body, broade and round faces, ≈ømal eyes, great eyebrowes, broad foreheads, ≈ømall and flat no≈øes, litle beards, ≈øeauen or eight hayres aboue their lippes and vnder their chinnes, and verie blacke haire, which they e≈øt√©eme verie much, & haue great care in ye keming thereof, and in keeping it cleane, as well men as women, and weare it as long as it will growe, and then binde it in a knot on the top of their
heads, and vpon it they put a p√©ece of Silke netting. Tho≈øe that dwell on the Sea ≈øide, with whome the Portingals traffique, that is in Machau and Canton, are a people of a browni≈øh colour, like the white Moores in Africa and Barbaria, and part of the Spaniards, but tho≈øe that dwell within the land, are for color like Netherlanders & high Dutches. There are many among them that are cleane blacke, which haue great eyes and much beard, but verie few of them, as it may well bee thought, and as the men of China them≈øelues report. Their of≈øpring was out of
‚Ä¢ artaria, or from other of their neighbours of ≈øtraunge Countries, at ≈øuch time when they had licence to trauaile into tho≈øe Countries, and to haue conuer≈øation with them by trade of marchandi≈øe, which nowe they may not doe, as it is ≈øaide before. They v≈øe to weare the nayles of their left hands very long, and on the right hand ≈øhort, which they hold for an auncient ceremonie of their law and beliefe. Their apparell (as I ≈øaid before) is mo≈øt of Silke of all colours, that is ≈øuch as are of welth, & indifferent rich, others & ≈øuch as are poore, do weare apparel of Cotton linnen, & of blacke and coloured Sayes, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe: Cloth made of Wooll nor Veluet they can not make in all China, although there wanteth no wooll, and they haue many ≈øh√©epe: notwith≈øtanding, they know not how to v≈øe it, and wonder much at it when the Portingalles bring it thether. The women goe verie richly apparelled, with long and wide Gownes, they weare many Iewels on their heades, within their haire, and al≈øo vppon their bodies, they doe commonly hold their hands couered, they are but little ≈ø√©ene abroad, but ≈øit mo≈øt part within the hou≈øe, and e≈øt√©eme it for a great beautifying vnto them to haue ≈ømall f√©ete, to the which end they v≈øe to binde their f√©ete ≈øo fa≈øt when they are young, that they cannot grow to the full, whereby they can hardly goe, but in a manner halfe lame. Which cu≈øtome the men haue brought vp, to let them from much going, for that they are verie iealous, and vnmea≈øurable leacherous and vncha≈øt, yet is it e≈øt√©emed a beautifying and comline≈ø≈øe for the women. Tho≈øe that are of any wealth or e≈øtate, are born in chaires through the ≈øtr√©ets, hanged and couered with Silke, Sattin, and Dama≈øke Curtins, wouen with ≈øiluer and golde thr√©edes, and haue ≈ømall holes to looke through, ≈øo that they may ≈ø√©e and not be ≈ø√©ene.

div.head: The 24. Chapter. Of the Prouinces, Townes, and other things worthie of memorie in the kingdome of China.
div.p:
THe kingdome of China is deuided into 15 prouinces, euery one being as great (as it is reported & founde written) as the be≈øt kingdome in Europe, and are gouerned by a Viceroye or Gouernour, which by the Chinaes is called Cochin. Two of the ≈øaid Prouinces are ruled by the King him≈øelfe and his Councell, which are Tolanchia and Paguia, wher the King is alwaies re≈øident. The other Prouinces are called Foquiem, Olam, Sin≈øay, Xan≈øay, Oquiam, Aucheo, Hona, Canton, Quicheo, Chequeam, Saxi, Aynaon, Su≈ø ‚Ä¢ an. Mo≈øt of the≈øe Prouinces haue riuers and waters running through them, & haue conference and familiaritie by buying and ≈øelling with each other both by water and by land. It is recorded by the Chinaes them≈øelues in their Chronicles, that in the≈øe fift√©ene Prouinces ther are 591. chiefe Citties 1593. other Citties, be≈øides villages: whereof ≈øome are ≈øo great as Citties: whereby you may con≈øider the greatne≈ø≈øe of the land. Mo≈øt of the Townes are built vppon riuers and running ≈øtreames, and clo≈øed about with broade ditches, and thicke ≈øtone walles, Without the Walles betw√©ene them and the Ditches, is a walke, where ≈øixe men on Hor≈øe backe maye ryde in ranke, and the like within, which ≈øpace is made to mende and repaire the Walles when n√©ede requireth, whereof they are very carefull, and looke warily vnto them. The high waies and foote pathes throughout the whole kingdome, are fairely paued, and all along euen and ≈ømoth till you come to the hils, and the entrance or Fronte≈øpicio of the Citties, verie co≈øtly and workmanly built with thr√©e or foure Gates one by the other, all ≈øtricken ouer full of Iron, and the ≈øtr√©etes within the Citties and Villages very fairely paued, and playned as ≈øtraight as a line, and euen in breadth, ≈øo that if you ≈øtand at the ende of a ≈øtr√©ete, you may ≈ø√©e to the other ende, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtraightnes bee it neuer ≈øo long. At the end of euery ≈øtr√©ete, are certaine Vaults made, wherein are wares and marchandi≈øes of all co≈øtly things, and prices that man can wi≈øh or de≈øire. Ouer euery ≈øtr√©ete there are diuers Arches made of ≈øtone, verie finely and cunningly Painted, which are ≈øet in the
≈øtr√©etes, becau≈øe that all their fea≈ø ‚Ä¢ es, p ‚Ä¢ ayes and ≈øpirituall ceremonies are done by night, and then tho≈øe Arches are placed full of lights and Torches, which maketh a goodly ≈øhew. The hou≈øes commonly haue three doores to goe in at, whereof that in the middle is the greate≈øt, the other ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe, they are commonly low without Sellers vnder grouÃÑd but within very large and broad, with great roomes and faire Gardens, full of all plea≈øure and delight. The towne where the King is re≈øident, is called Xuntien or Taybjin which ≈øome men call Quinzay, this name Xuntien is as much to ≈øay in Chini≈øh ≈øpeach, as heauenly Cittie, and lyeth in the Prouince of Paguia: of the greatne≈ø≈øe whereof they write wonders, for they affirme that within the walles the Towne is as long, from the one end to the other as a man on hor≈øebacke may ride vpon a day, with a thou≈øand other wonders, which for breuitie I omit. In this town the King hath his Palace, with all plea≈øures that may or can bee deui≈øed, both for him ≈øelfe, his wiues, and his Courte. His wiues little or neuer goe abroad, ≈øo that they are ≈øeldome or neuer ≈ø√©ene, thereby to maintaine their authoritie, as al≈øo fearing that any mi≈øchiefe ≈øhould happen vnto them, there are not in all the countrie any Noble men of name or title, as Earles, Dukes, Vi≈øcounts or ≈øuch like, nor that haue any va≈ø≈øales, commandements, Iuri≈ødictions, or proprieties to them≈øelues, other then ≈øuch as are giuen by the King, and when they die, it returneth again ‚Ä¢ vnto the King, and if hee wil, he may take it from the children, but commonly hee letteth them haue it, ≈øo they be fit for the place, and that with a new gi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and bond to ≈øerue the King. In all the principall townes where the Viceroyes or Gouernours hold their ≈øtates, there hangeth a picture of the King, couered with a Curtaine of cloth of Golde, whereunto all Officers, Commaunders, Loi ‚Ä¢ as, Mandorijns &c. dayly re≈øort and doe it all reuerence and honour, ≈øuch as belongeth to a King of ≈øuch e≈øtate, as if the King him≈øelfe were there in per≈øon‚ñ™ the Kings title is, King and Lord of the world, and Sonne of heauen.

No man throughout all China may beare any weapons, nor yet haue them in his hou≈øe but ≈øuch as are appointed thereunto, and receiue the Kings pay, as ≈øouldiers, who≈øe children ≈øucceed their fathers in their places. The men of China are great and cunning workemen, as may well bee ≈ø√©ene by the workman≈øhip that commeth from thence. They make and v≈øe waggons or Cartes with ≈øayles (like Boates) and with wheeles ≈øo ≈øubtilly made, that being in the fielde they goe and are driuen forwards by the winde, as if they were in the water, they are verie wittie in buying and ≈øelling. All the traders that k√©epe ≈øhops, haue a Table hanging at their doores wherein is written euery kind of ware they haue to ≈øell. All Officers or handicrafts men haue either of them a ≈øtreete alone, and dwell by them≈øelues, and their children mu≈øt v≈øe the like trade after their Fathers deaths, whether they were ≈øouldiers, Iu≈øtices or Gouernours. When any man is very rich, he is licenced not to work notwith≈øtanding he mu≈øt keepe workmen, and keepe open ≈øhoppe, the money that is v≈øed throughout all China is Golde and Siluer vn≈øtamped, but cut in ≈ømal peeces to the value of a penie, and ≈øo receiued by waight, and in like ≈øorte payed. Al≈øo all wares, of what ≈øort ≈øoeuer they bee, not ≈øo much as Hennes, G√©e≈øe, Fi≈øh, and ≈øuch like, but are bought and ≈øolde by waight. They haue one wife which they call their lawfull wife, and as many other as they can well maintaine, the ≈øonne of the lawfull wife inheriteth mo≈øt part of their goods, and that which remaineth is equally deuided among the other children, they marrie with whome they will, except it be with their Si≈øters, or their Vncles children. The Bridegrome before he fetcheth the Bride home to his hou≈øe, mu≈øt indowe her with certaine goods, which he giueth to the Bride her ≈øelfe, and ≈øhee giueth them vnto her Father or mother in recompence of their charges for bringing her vp in her youth, which done ≈øhee goeth home with the Bridegrome, and the parents may do what they wil with that which they haue ≈øo receiued for their daughters dowrie, and ≈øpend it as they thinke good, and what remaineth thereof after the parents are deade, returneth againe vnto the daughter, who≈øe hu≈øband gaue the ≈øame for his wife, ≈øo that he which hath mo≈øt daughters, is the riche≈øt, as it is reported, by the Pictures heereafter following you may ≈øee the forme and manner of tho≈øe of C ‚Ä¢ , as wel men as women, as al≈øo of the Mandorijns and mightie men or Gouernours, as they are carried in the ≈øtr√©etes, and goe to ≈øport vppon the ryuers, where they refre≈øh them≈øelues with all kinds of dainties.

The men of China haue manie ≈øp√©eches, but in writing they vnder≈øtand each other in euerie place for they write euerie thing with figures and characters, whereof their alphabets are ≈øundrie and innumerable: the≈øe figures with their paper of diuers colours, as al≈øo penne and inke, you may ≈øee at D. Paludanus hou≈øe, ≈øo that men had need of a good memorie, and long exerci≈øe, before they can vnder≈øtand them all, and read what it is, which
is the cau≈øe that among them ≈øuch as are learned are ≈øo much e≈øteemed. Their paper is like that of Auro ‚Ä¢ a, but not ≈øo white, but thinner and ≈ømoother: they make al≈øo of all colors, which is very ≈øaire, they write with pennes of Reedes, wherein there ≈øticketh a pen≈øell, ≈øuch as Painters v≈øe. Printing, painting & gun-powder, with the furniture thereto belonging, haue beene v≈øed in China many hundreth yeares pa≈øt, and very common, ≈øo that it is with them out of memorie when they fir≈øt began. Their Chronicles ≈øhewe that their fir≈øt king, being a great Nigromancer, who raigned manie thou≈øand yeares pa≈øt, did fir≈øt inuent great ordinance with all things belonging thereunto: Printing is likewi≈øe very auncient with them, for that there are bookes found in tho≈øe countries of China, which were printed at the lea≈øt fiue or ≈øixe hundreth yeares before printing was in v≈øe with vs in Europe, ≈øo that it is not founde when it fir≈øt began there. And there are many bookes in China, for that they are very curious and de≈øirous to write and regi≈øter all thinges, as well that which is done in their kingdome, or which belongeth thereunto, as al≈øo other memorable things, cuÃÑning and fine deui≈øes, lawes and ordinaÃÑces, al policies & gouernments in their townes, wherein they much re≈øemble and ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe the ancient Grecians and Romans. The manner of their banquetings and fea≈øtes are thus, as many per≈øons as are inuited, ≈øo many tables are prepared and made ready, although they be a hundreth: the tables are verie faire and finely painted‚ñ™ with all kynd of imagerie and flowers, mo≈øt plea≈øant to behold, ≈øo that they v≈øe no table-clothes, but round about the edges of the table there hangeth a cloth down to the ground, of ≈øilk, dama≈øke, gold or ≈øiluer, euerie one according to his e≈øtate, and at the corners of the tables there hang diuers faire ba≈økets full of all ≈øorts of ≈øweete flowers, with ma ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ paine ≈øtuffe of all formes and fa≈øhions, gilded & very cunningly made. In the middle of the tables they place the meats, very co≈øtlie and well dre≈øt, and in good order, all in di≈øhes of fine earth, or els ≈øiluer. The meat both fi≈øh and fle≈øh, or what≈øoeuer it is, is all cut in peeces, the bones and ≈øinewes cleane taken forth, which they neuer touch with their fingers, but onely v≈øe to take it vp with two litle peeces of blacke wood made round, whereof you may ≈øee ≈øome at D. Paludanus
‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ ≈øe, that I gaue him: and the≈øe they v≈øe in ≈øtead of ‚Ä¢ orkes, which with them is ≈øo ready, yt there falleth not one bit or cruÃÑme vpon the table, whereby they v≈øe no napkins to wipe their handes, for they need them not, neither doe the ‚Ä¢ ≈øoule either hand or mouth. Their drinke is wyne made of Rice, and brewed as we brew beer. They drinke often, but verie litle at a time, and will drinke at the lea≈øt 20. times in one ≈ømal cup before it be empty: wheÃÑ they are at their Fea≈øts and banquets they haue much mu≈øicke. They haue likewi≈øe many manners & cu≈øtomes of curte≈øies, which are the≈øe: The common people as they m√©et together, they ≈øhut their left hand, and couer it with their right hand, and ≈øo hold them together on their brea≈øt, with much bowing & ≈øtooping with their heads downwards, thereby to ≈øhewe that they loue each other, and are as fa≈øt bound and vnited together in loue, as their hands are fa≈øt knit together, and that with all their harts, wherewith they v≈øe manie courteous ≈øp√©eches. Among the Nobles or Mandoriins, when they m√©et together, they pre≈øently ≈øhut both handes, and lay their fingers each vpon the other, and ≈øo with their armes make a hoop or bowe, and ≈øo ≈øtaÃÑd ≈øtill ≈øtooping and bowing their heads and bodies with great curte≈øie, making choi≈øe who ≈øhal fir≈øt go by, with many other ceremonies v≈øed among the Nobles, which were ouer long to rehear≈øe. Wherefore at this pre≈øent I will leaue them; and cea≈øe to write any further of their ceremonies, and other cu≈øtomes, as nece≈ø≈øitie requireth, for that if I ≈øhould de≈øcribe them all at large, it would be ouer tedious, and a hundreth quiers of paper would not ≈øuffice: yet if any man be de≈øirous to ≈ø√©e more hereof, let him read the booke made by a Spani≈øh Fryer named Fray Iuan Gon≈øales de Mendo≈øa, of the de≈øcription of China, which booke is tran≈ølated out of Spani≈øh into Latine, although there are ≈øome falts, by wrong information giuen vnto the Author: notwith≈øtanding it conteyneth many particular things worthie the reading.

div.head: The 25. Chapter. Of the town and Iland of Machau in China, where the Portingales haue their re≈øidence, and trafficke with their marchandi≈øes, wares, and ≈øome prices therof, and the waight, mea≈øure, and money as well of China, as of Malacea, which continually come thether.
div.p:
THe Iland and Towne of Machau or Makau, is inhabited by Portingales, together with the naturall borne Countrimen of China. They trafficke with the men of Canton, from whence the Chinayes bring all their marchandi≈øes, and re≈øort
