≈øort thether to buy wares, but the Portingals may not goe thither, but as any ≈øhippe commeth out of India to Machau, it is by the Mandorijn or Gouernour of Machau pre≈øently mea≈øured both breadth, length, and depth, which done, they know how to make their account for the receipt of their cu≈øtome, and then they may lade what and how much ≈øo euer they will, without paying more, or concealing any Cu≈øtome. They ≈øuffer the Portingals to chu≈øe a Factor among them≈øelues, who in all their names is licenced to goe to Canton, there to buy what they de≈øire: but in the night time hee mu≈øt lye in the Suburbs without the towne, vpon paine of great puni≈øhment. This towne of Machau, hath a Portingall Bi≈øhop, who is Suffragan to the Archbi≈øhop of Goa, as I ≈øaide before: thither commeth a ≈øhippe yearely out of India, by the King of Portingals particular licence the Captaines place whereof is giuen to a man of great authoritie, as the Captains places of the fortre≈ø≈øes. And from Makau the ≈øaide ≈øhippe ≈øayleth to Iapen and there di≈øchargeth‚ñ™ and then returneth againe to Makan, and from thence to Malacca, and ≈øo to Goa. No man may ≈øayle that way but onely ≈øuch as haue ≈øpeciall licence from the Ringe, ≈øome one time, ≈øome an other, for that there mu≈øt but one ≈øhip ≈øayle that v ‚Ä¢ age euery yere, which is likwi≈øe giuen in recompence of ≈øome ≈øeruice done in India, as all other Officers in like ≈øort are. But to China and Malacca onely, euery Marchant may fraight as many ≈øhips as they can, alwaies remembred, that to Iapen no man may do it but by the Kings permi≈ø≈øion, and in China or Malacca no man may lade nor vnlade, before ≈øuch ≈øhips as are there for the King, haue receiued in the whole fraight, and are ready to depart, and after they haue laden euery man may doe his be≈øt, in what ≈øhips hee will, that is from China to Malacca and Goa. The Captaine of the ≈øhip that ≈øayleth to Iapen doth greatly profit by his Voyage, for hauing a good ≈øumme of money to traffique thither withall, in a good ≈øhip which commonly is of 14. of 16. hundreth Tunnes, hee may well gaine 15 ‚Ä¢ . or 200. thou≈øand Ducats by the Vyage, which continueth at the lea≈øt three yeares. For in April they depart from Goa to Malacca, wher they mu≈øt ≈øtay a certaine time for the winds, which at a certaine time blowe certaine months together: and the≈øe winds are called Mon≈øoins. From Malacca they ≈øayle to Makan, wher they ≈øtay at the lea≈øt 9. Months for the Mon≈øoins, and then they ≈øayle to Iapen, where they mu≈øt likewi≈øe ≈øtay certaine Moneths againe, to returne with the Mon≈øoins to Makau: wher againe they ≈øtay, as in their Viage outwards: ≈øo that the time of three yeares is fully expired before they haue made their Viage to and from Iapen. And all the time of the Captaine of this ≈øhip his re≈øidence as well in Iapen as Makau, he is there chief Ruler and Gouernour of the place, like the Viceroye in India, and the ≈øeuerall Captaines in their Forts, for that when the one departeth from Makau to Iapen ‚ñ™ there commeth an other to Makau from Goa ‚ñ™ to make the ≈øame Viage, after the other hath performed his Viage. And when hee returneth againe from Iapen to Makau, the other ≈øayleth to Iapen, and ≈øo the fir≈øt continueth Gouernour againe at Makau, vntil he departeth from thence to Malacca, and ≈øo to India, and in this ≈øorte there is alwaies a Gouernour within the Towne of Makau, as I ≈øaide before.

The marchandi≈øe or ware that they carrie froÃÑ Makau to Iapen, are ≈øilks, & from Iapen they return nothing but ≈øiluer, whereby they doe greatly profit. And ≈øeing we are in hand with their trafficks, from Makau, I think it not impertinent to rehear≈øe ≈øome of the ware which the Portingals v≈øe commonly to buy there‚ñ™ and to traffique withall, together with the ordinarie prices therof, as al≈øo the waight and monyes, as well of China as of Malacca, becau≈øe of the neerene≈ø≈øe and common traffique that they dayly v≈øe with each other, more then any other places of
‚Ä¢ ndia, which I ≈øet downe in this place, becau≈øe this waight and reckoning differeth from that of Portingall and India. It is to be vnder≈øtoode that in China there are three ≈øorts of Silkes, that is, one ≈øort called Lankijn which is e≈øteemed for the be≈øt. The ≈øecond called Fulcan, which is good al≈øo. The third and wor≈øt Silke is called Lankam, be≈øides the≈øe there are other ≈øorts of Silke, as Silke vn≈øpunne, called raw Silke, and Silke that is ≈øpunne and made in thr√©edes, which the Portingals call Retre ‚Ä¢
The white vn≈øpunne Silke of Lankijn is worth the Pico (which is a certaine waight) which hereafter I will ≈øhew you about 1 ‚Ä¢ 5 or 150. Ryals of eight, or Rikes Dollors accounted after the rate of that money. The white vn≈øpunne Silke of Fulcan is worth the Pico, 140. or 145. Ryals of eight, the vn≈øpunne Silke of Lankam, is woorth the Pico 75. or 80. Ryals of eight, the Retres white Silke of Lankij is worth the Pico 150. or 170. Ryals of eight, the Retres white, and other Silke of Fulcam and Su≈øuam, is worth the Pico 130. or 135. Ryals of eight, the Retres white of Canton is worth the Pico 50, or 55. Ryals of eight, the wrought Silke of al colours at the ≈øame price, the vn≈øpunne Canton Silke in colours
is worth the Pico 50. or 60. Ryals of eight, white Lamparden Silk of 14. Els the p√©ece are commonly worth one yeare with the other, 50. or 55. Ryalls of eight. The hundred, the Mo≈ø≈øeliat or Mu≈øke is commonly worth one yeare with the other the Caete, which is 20. ounces, ≈øixe or ≈øeuen Ryalls of eight, other fine wares and marchandi≈øes of China, haue their different prices accordingly, as the time ≈øerueth, and are not ≈øo common as the≈øe Silkes, for that with the Silks afore≈øaid is the Portingalles trade, and the principalle≈øt riches, that are brought out of C ‚Ä¢ ina to the countries bordering about it.

As touching the waight and money of China and Malacca, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that the waight which in Malacca is called a Bha ‚Ä¢ , is three Picos, and euery Pico is 66 ‚Ä¢ Caetes, ≈øo that ‚Ä¢ . Picos which is a Bhar, are 200. Caetes, as well great as ≈ømall waight, a Bhar of China is 300. Caetes, which waigh as much as 200. Caetes at Malacca ≈ømall waight: for that three Caetes of China, are in Malacca, two Caetes ≈ømall waight: a Caete of China is 16. Taeys Chini≈øh waight, which are 14. Taeys in Malacca which is as much as 20. Ounces ‚Ä¢ Portingall waight. They v≈øe likewi≈øe a waight which they cal a Hant, euery Hant is twelue Caetes ≈ømal waight and euery Caete is 22. Taeyes, and 16. Hantes and 8. Caetes, are iu≈øt 200. Caetes which is a Bhar of ≈ømall waight, ≈øo likewi≈øe a Tael of Malacca is 16. Ma≈øes, and 10. Ma≈øes and ¬º ‚ñ™ is an Ounce of Portingall waight, and an Ounce and a halfe is iu≈øt 16. Ma≈øes, and the eight part of a Ma≈øe, by the≈øe Ma≈øes they ≈øel the Bezars ≈øtones, for euery Ma≈øe two or thr√©e Ducats, according to their greatne≈ø≈øe and goodne≈ø≈øe. In Malacca are two ≈øortes of waights, great and ≈ømall, which heereafter follow. A Bhar great waight, is 200. Cates, and one Cates 26. Taeys, and one Taey is one Ounce ¬Ω ‚ñ™ hard waight of Portingall, the ≈ømall waight is a Bhar, which is al≈øo 200. Caetes, and one Caetes is 22. Taeys, and a
‚Ä¢ ael is a full Ounce and a halfe Portingal waight. With their great waight they weigh P ‚Ä¢ per, Cloues, Nutmegs, Folio, red & white Sanders, Indico, Alum, Sanguis, draconis, Palo Dauguila, Siet, and Sapon. With the ≈ømall waight they waigh Quick≈øiluer, Vermilion‚ñ™ Coper‚ñ™ Blie, Iuorie bones, Silk, Mu≈øke, Amber, Calamba, or Lignum Aloes, Tin, Lead, Lancua, Oyle of Nutmegs, and of flowers, Verdette, Ro≈øamallia, Be≈øoun‚ñ™ and Camphora &c. The marchandi≈øes that the Portingals carrie to China, whereof they make mo≈øt profite is Ryals of eight, which in China are worth aboue ≈øix te≈øtones, not for that they had rather haue it then other Siluer, but for that it is all Siluer‚ñ™ for it is pre≈øently cut in p√©eces, to pay it out after their manner as it is ≈øhewed before, they carrie likewi≈øe ≈øome Wines both Portingal and Indian Wine, and ≈øome Oyles of Oliues, which are there de≈øired. Veluet, Cloth of Scarlet, whereof they haue none, nor yet can make any, although they haue both ≈øheepe and wooll enough. Looking gla≈ø≈øes, Iuorie bones, and all kinde of Chri≈øtall and Gla≈ø≈øe, are well ≈øolde there. But this ≈øhall ≈øuffice for that which concerneth the land of China, now I will proc√©ede to the de≈øcription of the Iland of Iapan, which is the farthe≈øt Viage and la≈øt Orientall place by the Portingals di≈øcouered or at this day knowne.

div.head: The 26. Chapter. Of the Iland of Iapan.
div.p:
THe Iland or the land of Iapan is many Ilands one by the other, and are ≈øeperated and deuided only by certaine ≈ømall Cr√©ekes and riuers, it is a great land, although as yet the circuite thereof is not knowne, becau≈øe as yet it is not di≈øcouered‚ñ™ nor by the Portingalles ≈øought into, it beginneth vnder 30. degr√©es, and runneth till you come to 38 degr√©es, it lyeth Ea≈øt from the firme land of China, about 80. miles, and from Maccau by the waye that the Portingalles trauaile Northea≈øt warde, is about 300. miles, and the Hauen where commonly the Portingals v≈øe to traffique, is called Nanga≈øache. They haue likewi≈øe other places where they traffique and deale. The countrie is cold, proc√©eding of much rayne, Snow and Ice‚ñ™ that falleth therein, it hath ≈øome Corne lande, but their common Corne is Ryce. In ≈øome places the land is verie hillie and vnfruitfull, they eate no fle≈øh but the fle≈øh of wilde bea≈øts, and ≈øuch as is hunted, wherein they are verie expert, although there are Oxen, Cowes, Sheepe, and ≈øuch like Cattell good ≈øtore, yet they v≈øe them to other things about their labours, and becau≈øe it is tame fle≈øh, which they cannot brooke, they refu≈øe it as wee doe hor≈øe fle≈øh, they doe likewi≈øe refu≈øe to eate Milke, as wee doe bloud, ≈øaying that Milke although it is white, yet it is verie bloude. They haue much Fi≈øh, whereof they are verie de≈øirous, as al≈øo all kinds of fruites, as in China. Their hou≈øes are commonly couered with wood, and with ≈øtrawe, they are „Äà‚óä„Äâ and workmanlike builte, ≈øpecially the rich
mens hou≈øes, they haue their Chambers hanged and flowred with Mattes, which is their be≈øt hangings. The Iapens are not ≈øo curious nor ≈øo cleanly as the men of China, but are contente with a meane, yet for the mo≈øt part they goe verie well apparelled in Silke, almo≈øt like the Chinos. The countrie hath ≈øome mines of ≈øiluer, which from thence is by the Portingals yearely brought vnto China, and there bartered for Silke, and other Chini≈øh wares, which the Iapeans haue n√©ede of. The countriemen are verie ≈økilfull to ≈øearch for Siluer, and to ≈øell their wares. They haue among them verie good handicrafts men, and cunning workemen in all kind of handie workes, they are ≈øharpe witted, and quickly learne any thing they ≈ø√©e, as by experience it is found in tho≈øe parts which the Portingales haue di≈øcouered. The common people of the lande are much different froÃÑ other nations, for that they haue among them as great curte≈øie and good policie, as if they had liued continually in the Court, they are verie expert in their weapons as n√©ed requireth, although they haue little cau≈øe to v≈øe them, for that if anye of them beginneth to brawle or to drawe his ≈øworde, hee is put to death, they haue not any pri≈øons, for that who ≈øoeuer de≈øerueth to be impri≈øoned, is pre≈øently puni≈øhed, or bani≈øhed the countrie. When they meane to lay holde vpon a man, they mu≈øt doe it by ≈øtealth and by deceipt, for otherwi≈øe he would re≈øi≈øt and doe much mi≈øchiefe. If it bee any Gentleman or man of great authoritie, they be≈øet his hou≈øe about with men, and whether hee chaunce to ≈ølay him≈øelfe or not, they enter the hou≈øe by force, and kill al they find therin. Which to auoid, he ≈øuffereth him≈øelf often times to be killed by his ≈øeruantes. And it is often ≈ø√©ene that they rip their own bellies open, which often times is likewi≈øe done by their ≈øeruants for the loue of their Ma≈øters, therein to ≈øhew their Ma≈øters the loue they beare vnto them, ≈øo little e≈øt√©eming their owne liues, to plea≈øure and ≈øerue them. The like doe young Boyes in pre≈øence of their parents, onely for griefe or ≈øome ≈ømall anger. They are in all their actions very patient and humble, for that in their youthes they learne to indure hunger, colde, and all manner of labour, to goe bare headed, with few cloathes, as well in Winter as in Summer, and not onely the common people, but the principall Gentlemen and Nobles of the countrie. They account it for great beautie to haue no haire, which with great care they doe plucke out, onely keepe a bunch of haire on the crowne of their heades, which they tie together. Touching their traffique, manners, ≈øpeach, and all their ceremonies, concerning life and curte≈øie, they are cleane contrarie vnto all other nations, ≈øpeciallie from tho≈øe of China, and till this day ob≈øerue the ≈øame as an infallible law, which groweth vpon this occa≈øion.

A long time ≈øince, there was in China a great & mightie familie, which together with all their friends and acquaintance ≈øecretly con≈øpired and agr√©ed to ry≈øe vp again≈øt the King of China, to driue him out of his kingdome and to kill him, and hauing ≈øo done, to place them≈øelues therein: but it could not ≈øo ≈øecretly be contriued and wrought, but in the end it was knowne: whereupon the king puni≈øhed them mo≈øt gr√©euou≈øly, and cau≈øed diuers of the principall con≈øpirators to be put to death, and all others he found to be con≈øenting therunto ≈øhould haue felt the like paine, which gr√©eued the Coun≈øell and other Noble men of the countrie, for that diuers of their n√©ere≈øt kin≈ømen were of that con≈øpiracie, ≈øo that with humble and long petition to the King, they be≈øought him to let them liue, and to puni≈øh them with ≈øome ea≈øier puni≈øhment then death: but that which they ≈øought & de≈øired at the king, all things con≈øidered, was little better then death, which was that he would bani≈øh them and all their po≈øteritie for euer out of the countrie, into the Ilands of Iapen, which as then were not inhabited, and this as they de≈øired was done: whereby there is ≈øo great enuie and hatred betw√©ene them and the men of China, that they hate each other to the death, and doe all the mi≈øchief one vnto the other that they can imagine or deui≈øe, euen vntill this time. The men of Iapen haue done much mi≈øchief vnto the men of China, and many times fallen vpon their coa≈øts, and put all to fire and ≈øword, and now at this pre≈øent haue not any conuer≈øation with them, but onely they trafficke with the Portingales, and to ≈øhewe them≈øelues whollie their deadlie enemies, in all their actions they are cleane contrary vnto the men of China, and to the ≈øame end haue changed all their cu≈øtomes, ceremonies and manners of curte≈øie from the men of China. To recite the particulars would be ouer long, yet I will in briefe ≈øet down ≈øome fewe examples of the cu≈øtomes and manners therein. One is where the China v≈øeth the curte≈øie of ≈øalutation to a man with the head and hand, wheÃÑ they m√©et together: the Iapens to the contrarie put off their ≈øhoes, whereby they ≈øhewe them reuerence, and as the Chinaes ≈øtand vp when they minde to receyue any man‚ñ™ and to doe him reuerence, they to the contrarie ≈øet them≈øelues down, accounting it a verie vn≈ø√©emely thing to receyue or bid a man welcome ≈øtanding on their f√©et: and as we put on
our clokes when we meane to goe abroad into the towne or countrie, they put them off when they goe forth, putting on great wyde br√©eches, and coming home they put them off again, and ca≈øt their clokes vpon their ≈øhoulders: and as among other nations it is a good ≈øight to ≈øee men with white and yealow hayre and white teeth, with them it is e≈øt√©emed the filthie≈øt thing in the world, and ≈ø√©eke by all meanes they may to make their hayre and t√©eth blacke, for that the white cau≈øeth their grief, and the blacke maketh them glad. The like cu≈øtome is among the women, for as they goe abroad they haue their daughters & maydes before them, and their men ≈øeruants come behind, which in Spaigne is cleane contrarie, and when they are great with childe, they tye their girdles ≈øo hard about them, that men would thinke they ≈øhuld bur≈øt, and when they are not with Childe, they weare their girdles ≈øo ≈ølacke, that you would thinke they would fall from their bodies, ≈øaying that by experience they do finde, if they ≈øhould not doe ≈øo, they ≈øhould haue euill lucke with their fruict, and pre≈øently as ≈øoone as they are deliuered of their children, in ≈øt√©ed of cheri≈øhing both the mother and the child with ≈øome comfortable meat, they pre≈øently wa≈øh the childe in cold water, and for a time giue the mother very little to eate, and that of no great ≈øub≈øtance. Their manner of eating and drinking is: Euerie man hath a table alone, without table clothes or napkins, and eateth with two peeces of wood, like the men of China: they drinke wine of Rice, wherewith they drink them≈øelues drunke, and after their meat they v≈øe a certaine drinke, which is a pot with hote water, which they drinke as hote as euer they may indure, whether it be Winter or Summer.

p.hi: The Turkes holde almo≈øt the ≈øame maÃÑner of drinking of their Chaona, which they make of certaine fruit, which is like vnto the Bakelaer, and by the Egyptians called Bon or Ban: they take of this fruite one pound and a half, and roa≈øt them a little in the fire, and then ≈øieth them in twentie poundes of water, till the half be con≈øumed away: this drinke they take euerie morning fa≈øting in their chambers, ‚Ä¢ ut of an e ‚Ä¢ rthen pot, being verie hote, as we doe here drinke aquacompo≈øita in the morning: and they ≈øay that it ≈øtrengtheneth and maketh them warme, breaketh wind, and openeth any ≈øtopping.

div.p: The manner of dre≈ø≈øing their meat is altogether contrarie vnto other nations: the afore≈øaid warme water is made with the powder of a certaine hearbe called Chaa, which is much e≈øt√©emed, and is well accounted of among them, and al ≈øuch as are of any countenance or habilitie haue the ≈øaid water kept for them in a ≈øecret place, and the gentlemen make it them≈øelues, and when they will entertaine any of their friends, they giue him ≈øome of that warme water to drinke: for the pots wherein they ≈øieth it, and wherein the hearbe is kept, with the earthen cups which they drinke it in, they e≈øteeme as much of them, as we doe of Diamants, Rubies and other precious ≈øtones, and they are not e≈øteemed for their newnes, but for their oldnes, and for that they were made by a good workman: and to know and k√©epe ≈øuch by them≈øelues, they take great and ≈øpeciall care, as al≈øo of ≈øuch as are the valewers of them, and are ≈økilfull in them, as with vs the gold≈ømith pri≈øeth and valueth ≈øiluer and gold, and the Iewellers all kindes of precious ≈øtones: ≈øo if their pots & cuppes be of an old & excelleÃÑt workmaÃÑs making, they are worth 4 or 5 thou≈øaÃÑd ducats or more the peece. The King of Bungo did giue for ≈øuch a pot, hauing thr√©e feet, 14 thou≈øand ducats, and a Iapan being a Chri≈øtian in the town of Sacay, gaue for ≈øuch a pot 1400 ducats, and yet it had 3 peeces vpon it. They doe likewi≈øe e≈øt√©eme much of any picture or table, wherein is painted a blacke tr√©e, or a blacke bird, and when they knowe it is made of wood, and by an ancient & cuÃÑning mai≈øter, they giue what≈øoeuer you will a≈øke for it. It happeneth ≈øome times that ≈øuch a picture is ≈øold for 3 or 4 thou≈øand ducats and more. They al≈øo e≈øt√©eme much of a good rapier, made by an old and cunning mai≈øter, ≈øuch a one many times co≈øteth 3 or 4 thou≈øand Crowns the p√©ece. The≈øe things doe they k√©eepe and e≈øt√©eme for their Iewels, as we e≈øt√©eme our Iewels & precious ≈øtones‚ñ™ And when we a≈øke them why they e≈øt√©eme them ≈øo much, they a≈øke vs againe, why we e≈øt√©eme ≈øo well of our precious ≈øtones & iewels, whereby there is not any profite to be had, and ≈øerue to no other v≈øe, then only for a ≈øhewe, & that their things ≈øerue to ≈øome end.

Their Iu≈øtice and gouernment is as followeth: Their kings are called Iacatay, and are ab≈øolutely Lords of the land, notwith≈øtanding they k√©epe for them≈øelues as much as is nece≈ø≈øary for them and their e≈øtate, and the re≈øt of their land they deuyde among others, which are called Cunixus, which are like our Earles and Dukes: the≈øe are appointed by the King, and he cau≈øeth them to gouerne & rule the land as it plea≈øeth him: they are bound to ≈øerue the King as well in peace, as in warres, at their owne co≈øt & charges, according to their e≈øtate, and the auncient lawes of Iapan. The≈øe Cunixus haue others vnder them called Touis, which are like our
Lords and Lieutenants, with whome likewi≈øe they deuide and part the land by the king giuen vnto them. And the≈øe Toms doe yet deuide their parts among their friends & ≈øuch are their ≈øoldiers, and take an oath to be redie at the commandement of their heads and chief gouernors, as wel in peace as in warre at their own proper co≈øtes & charges: & euery one mu≈øt maintayne him≈øelf, and be content with that part which is allotted vnto him: wherewith euerie one of them according to his e≈øtate and qualitie may liue well, and euerie one of them hath ≈øo much power and authoritie ouer tho≈øe that are vnder him, that he may puni≈øh, bani≈øh, and put them to death, and doe with them, if they offend, as it be≈øt plea≈øeth him, be it with right or with wrong, without any appeale or an≈øwering before any man: this power is not giuen onely to the Gouernors, Captaines and Officers ouer their ≈øubiects, Va≈ø≈øalles and Soldiers vnder their charges, gouernments and offices (as I ≈øaid before) but al≈øo to mai≈øters of hou≈øes and fathers ouer their children, ≈øeruants & family: ≈øo that they may kill, beate, ‚Ä¢ acke & hewe theÃÑ as they thinke good, and at their plea≈øures, without any re≈øi≈øtance or correction for the ≈øame.

The rents and reuenues belonging to the King are very ≈ømall, and are nothing el≈øe but rice, which is their liuing: he hath euery yere onelie 500 thou≈øaÃÑd packes or ≈øackes of Rice, and not any other cu≈øtomes, rents and reuenues, whereof he giueth to 10 or 12 Cunixu ‚Ä¢
each man 30 or 40 thou≈øand ≈øackes, the re≈øt is for his owne co≈øtes and charges, to the maintenance of his e≈øtate, and the Cunixus mu≈øt di≈øtribute of their parts among the Toms, and the Toms among the ≈øoldiers, wherewith they maintaine them≈øelues, euery man in his e≈øtate. Their ≈øp√©ech is different from the Chini≈øh, ≈øo that they vnder≈øtand not each other, but in writing they differ not, for that they v≈øe all the ≈øelf ≈øame figures and characters: they v≈øe likewi≈øe manie kindes of vowels, and in their writing manie courteous ≈øp√©eches, to euery man according to his e≈øtate & calling, with ≈øeuerall titles & words: whereby their ≈øp√©ech is hardly to be learned by a ≈øtraunger. Their religion is much like vnto tho≈øe of China: they haue their Idolles and their mini≈øters, which they call Bon≈øes, and hold them in great e≈øtimation: but ≈øince the time of the Ie≈øuites being among them, there haue bene diuers bapti≈øed and become Chri≈øtians, which daylie doe increa≈øe, among the which were 3 Kings, that is the king of BuÃÑgo, which is one of the principalle≈øt kings of Iapan, although there are many in the countrie, wherewith the Portingales, as yet haue had no conference: the ≈øecond the King of Arryma: the third, the King of Omura ‚ñ™ Tho≈øe thr√©e Kings ≈øent their ≈øonnes and Nephewes with the Ie≈øuites into India, from thence to trauell into Portingale, and ≈øo to Rome, to ≈øubmit them≈øelues vnto the Pope, and departing out of Iapan, in anno 1582. 15 ‚Ä¢ 2 they ariued in India, in the citie of Goa An. 1583. 158 ‚Ä¢
the ≈øame yeare that I ariued in India, ≈øo that we found them yet in Goa, and the next yeare after they ≈øayled vnto Portingal, & from thence to Madril, where by the king & nobles of Spaine, they were with great triumph & honour welcomed and receiued, and pre≈øented with many gyftes. From thence they trauelled to Rome vnto the Pope, who likewi≈øe did them great honor, and be≈øtowed many pre≈øents vpon them, as al≈øo all the Cardinals and Lords of Italie, for that they trauelled throughout all Italie to Florence, Venice, Ferrara, &c. which being done, they returned againe vnto Madril, with letters from Pope Sixtus, and ≈øome holie reliques of the cro≈ø≈øe that Chri≈øt died vpon, to pre≈øent the ≈øame vnto the Chri≈øtian Kings of Iapan, as an holie pre≈øent: in the end they ariued in India againe, during my being there, which was in anno 1587, 158 ‚Ä¢
being with great ioy receiued, and ≈øo ≈øet ≈øayle vnto Iapan, where they ariued again with great admiration of all the men of Iapan: which the Ie≈øuites did, to the end (as they ≈øaid) the better to moue the Iapans to be chri≈øtened, and to make them knowe the magnificence of the countrie of Europa, becau≈øe they would not bel√©eue it being ≈øhewed them: but the principalle≈øt cau≈øe and intent of the Ie≈øuites was, thereby to reape great profit, and to get much prai≈øe and commendation, for that mo≈øt of the gifts which the princes of Iapan had giuen them, fell to their ≈øhares: they likewi≈øe obtained of the Pope and the king of Spaine, that no maÃÑ might dwell in Iapan, either Portingale or Chri≈øtian, without their licence and con≈øent, ≈øo that in all Iapan there are no other orders of Munkes, Fryers, Prie≈øts, nor any other religious per≈øons remaining or re≈øident there, but Ie≈øuites alone. They haue onely among them certaine handie crafts men, by them brought out of India, with whome they haue to doe, but for other men, as marchants and others, they may but goe and come, and not ≈øtay there, without the Ie≈øuites licence. They haue almo≈øt all the countrie vnder their ≈øubiection, ≈øuch I meane as are conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, as well ≈øpirituall as temporall, making the Iapans bel√©eue what they li≈øt, wherby they are honored like gods, for that the Iapans make ≈øo great account of them, that they doe almo≈øt pray vnto them,
as if they were Saints. They had obtained ≈øo much fauour of the Pope, that hee granted them a Bi≈øhoppe of their order, (which is contrarie to their profe≈ø≈øion) who came out of Portingale to be Bi≈øhop in Iapon, but dyed in the way, betw√©ene Portingale and India: Since that they haue procured an other, ≈øo that to conclude, they haue all the praye vnder their clawes. As likewi≈øe they doe enioy and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the principalle≈øt places of Religion in all India, where they builde mo≈øt princely hou≈øes, which no man dareth with≈øtand or refu≈øe them, neither any of the Religious orders, haue the meanes or wealth to doe the like. This they know full well howe to bring to pa≈ø≈øe, for that there is not any thing, from whence they will not ≈øucke or draw out ≈øome profit or aduantage, or el≈øe they haue the ≈ølight, and cunning how to get it as well from the King, and from other Noblemen and e≈øtates as al≈øo from the common people, it ≈ø√©emeth in a manner that they bewitch men with their ≈øubtill practi≈øes and deui≈øes, and are ≈øo wel practi≈øed and experimented in trade of marchandi≈øes, that they ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe all worldly men. To conclude, there is not any commoditie to be had or reaped thoroughout all India, but they haue their part therein, ≈øo that the other orders and Religious per≈øons, as al≈øo the common people, doe much murmur thereat, and ≈ø√©eme to di≈ølike of their couetous humors.

A little beyond Iapon vnder 34. and 35. degr√©es, not farre from the coa≈øt of China, lyeth an other great Iland, called In≈øula de Core, whereof as yet there is no certaine knowledge, neither of the greatne≈ø≈øe of the countrie, people, nor wares that are there to be found.

From Makau Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, di≈øtant aboue 90. miles lye certaine Ilandes, called Lequeo Pequeno, or little Lequeo, and lye about 20. miles di≈øtant from the firme land of China, and 90. miles farther in the ≈øame cour≈øe, lye other Ilands, called Lequeo Maior, or great Lequeo. All the≈øe Ilandes are trauelled vnto, and inhabited by tho≈øe of China, whereof we will now cea≈øe to ≈øpeake, till an other time, (hauing particularly made a briefe di≈øcour≈øe in an other place, of all their manners, cu≈øtomes, wares, and marchandi≈øes, according to the true≈øt in≈øtructions I could find) and ≈øo will returne againe to the de≈øcription of Goa, together with the places bordering about the ≈øame.

div.head: The 27. Chapter. A ≈øhort relation of the land lying behind Goa: in the iuri≈ødiction whereof lyeth the ≈øaid towne of Goa, and of the Originall of their Kings and Gouernours, with their names, by true information giuen by the inhabitants them≈øelues, together with their Hi≈øtories.
div.p:
BEfore I begin to write of the towne and Ilande of Goa, with the coa≈øtes, ≈øuper≈øtitions, and other cu≈øtomes of the countrie, lying behinde and rounde about Goa, as well where the Portingales inhabit, as where the natiue countrie men are re≈øident, I thought it conuenient to begin with the ≈øame ≈øomwhat further off, then at the pre≈øent time, the better to vnder≈øtand the originall of the people, together with the principall cau≈øes of the diui≈øions of the ≈øame countries and nations, as al≈øo their Kings names and ≈øurnames. Then you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that about 300. yeares pa≈øt, there was a mightie King of the countrie of Deli, which lyeth within the land behind Goa on the North≈øide, and bordereth vpon the land of Coracone, belonging to the King of Per≈øia, wherein are made the rich Couerlets and hangings, by the Portingales called Alcatyffas, which land of Deli is verie colde, and hath Snow and Ice in it like the Netherlands. This king of Deli brought vnder his ≈øubiection, all the countries bordering about him, among the which were Decam, Cuncam, Ballagate, and the lande of Goa. At the ≈øame time the countrie of Cambaia, which is di≈øtant from Goa about 100. miles Northward, was ouerrunne and taken f ‚Ä¢ rcibly by the Moores, & Mahometans, and brought the naturall countrimen, called Reysbutos being heathens, with great tyranie vnder their ≈øubiection. The land of Ballagate, and Decam was before inhabited by heathens, that were verie mightie and of great power, who≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øors are now called Vene≈øares, and others that yet dwell within the countrie called Colles: which Colles, Vene≈øares, and Reysbutos of Cambaia doe yet liue by robbing and ≈øtealing, and tho≈øe of Cambaia pay tribute to the ≈øaide Reysbutos, becau≈øe they ≈øhould not robbe and ≈øpoyle them, but ≈øuffer them to liue in peace. The Colles and Vene≈øares al≈øo receiue tribute of the men of Decam and Ballagate: for that the Kings could neuer as yet ouercome
them, although they make no ≈øhew thereof, but ≈øtill di≈ø≈øemble with them, for that of what ≈øoeuer they robbe and ≈øteale, they haue their parts. After this King of Deli had brought all the≈øe kingdomes and countries vnder his ≈øubiection: then came the Tartarians, which the Indians call Mogoren, and ouercame mo≈øt part of the countrie of Deli. At the ≈øame time there dwelt in the kingdome of Bengalen a Noble Gentleman, who≈øe brother the King of Bengallen had wrongfully put to death, whereby this Gentleman ≈øought and deui≈øed all the meanes hee could to bee reuenged, and did not onely bring it to pa≈ø≈øe by bereauing the King of his life, but al≈øo tooke the whole kingdome from him, and brought it vnder his ≈øubiection, and being in this ≈øorte become ab≈øolute Lord and King of Bengalla, was not therewith content, but de≈øiring to augment his kingdome, and thereby to win great fame, did inuade the countrie of Deli, (bordering vpon him) with a great armie of men, and by force draue the Tartarians or Mogoros out of the countrie, and ≈øo conquered both that lande and all the countries bordering thereabouts, as Decam, Ballagate, and Cuncam, as farre as to the kingdome of Cambaia, and for a time was the greate≈øt Prince in all tho≈øe quarters. For the Indians affirme that hee had in Compa≈ø≈øe vnder his ≈øubiection aboue 800. miles of land. This King raigning for a time ouer al the≈øe lands and countries, in the end de≈øiring to liue quietly, and to returne vnto his kingdom of Bengala, thinking it too trouble≈øome for him to rule ≈øo great a countrie, did inue≈øt one of his co≈øins, with the countries of Decam, Ballagate, and Cuncam, with the land of Goa, and the countries bordering about the ≈øame, which done, he returned into his land of Bengala, leauing his ≈øaide co≈øin King and commander of the afore≈øaid countries. This man was alwaies a great friende and wel-willer to ≈øtrange nations, as Arabians, Turkes, Ruynes, and Cora≈øones, & parted his countries among Gouernours and Captaines, to on whereof beeing called Idalham, whome the Portingales call Hidalcam, he gaue the Gouernment of Angedina, which lyeth 12. miles from Goa Southwards, ≈øtretching towards the North, till you come to a place called Siffardan which are 60. miles, wherein is contained the towne and Iland of Goa: to an other Captaine called Ni≈øa Maluco, hee gaue the coa≈øt of Siffardan ≈øtretching Northwards, to Negotana which are 20. miles, and lyeth inwards to the land of Cambaia: ≈øo that tho≈øe two Captaines had their gouernments in the countrie of Cuncam, which lyeth on the Sea coa≈øt, and ≈øeperateth it ≈øelfe from the land of Decam, by great and high hils, called Guate. The≈øe hils are verie high, and haue many corners and hookes of land, and doe ≈øtretch towardes Cambaia, to the Cape de Comorin, and from thence backe againe to the coa≈øt of Choramandel. The hill of Guate is ≈øo high, that men may ea≈øily ≈ø√©e it within Goa, and all the coa≈øt along, though commonly it is couered with clouds, and it is the more to bee wondred at, for this re≈øpect, becau≈øe all other hils are vneuen, high and low, and this is faire and flat land on the top, with great & goodly fields: & is by the Indians called Ballagate, that is to ≈øay, aboue the hill, for Balla is aboue, and Gate is a hill, whereby the Portingals doe commonly cal the whole countrie Ballagate, although the principall part, and the land it ≈øelfe is called Decam, and al≈øo Canara, wherof the inhabitants are called Decanijns and Canaras, as the Kings al≈øo in times pa≈øt v≈øed to beare titles, and call them≈øelues Kings of Decam.

But returning to the diui≈øion of the re≈øt of the countries, he deuided likewi≈øe the land of Ballagate or Decam, into Prouinces, giuing one part to Imademaluco, by the Portingales called Madremaluco, and an other part to Cotalmoluco, and an other to Melique Verido. All the ≈øaid Captaines were ≈øtrangers, as Turkes, Ruines, and Cora≈øones, except Ni≈øamalucode, who was Sonne to a Gentleman of the Kings hou≈øe, and becau≈øe the King had laine with the mother of Ni≈øamaluco, therefore hee boa≈øted him≈øelfe to be of the linage of the king of Decam, all the other Captaines were ≈ølaues and ≈øeruants, which the King had brought, and placed in tho≈øe roomes, as putting great tru≈øt in them, thinking that they would acknowledge it, and bee thankfull vnto him for the ≈øame. But it fell out otherwi≈øe, as wee ≈øee it commonly doth, and that good is requited with euill, for the≈øe Captaines in time, getting credite, authoritie and power, were in great e≈øtimation, and as it were, ab≈øolute Kings and Gouernours of their Prouinces, for that the king neuer troubled him≈øelfe therwith, but layde all the charge vppon them, whereby they beganne to bee puffed vp with pride, and determined to v≈øurpe the Prouinces vnder him, for them and their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors: And becau≈øe it grieued them to be in ≈øubiection to an other, and at his commaundement, they all met together, and among them, agr√©ed to take their Lord and King pri≈øoner, and ≈øo euery one of them to be ≈øole commanders of the couÃÑtries they had in charge, which they ea≈øily brought to effect, for that they had all the meanes they would wi≈øh or de≈øire, as
„Äà1 page missing„Äâ
did honour them with the name of Xa, which is to ≈øay a King, whereby they had the names of Adelxa, Ni≈øamoxa, and Contumixa, and all the Kings continued ≈øo with the name of Xa, which in Per≈øia is a King, and I≈ømael is a proper name, whereby Xa I≈ømael, and Xa Thamas are as much to ≈øay as King I≈ømael, and King Thamas, and of the Turkes and Rumes are called Suffy or Soffy, which ≈øignifieth a great Captaine. The Kings of Decam al≈øo haue a cu≈øtome when they will honor a man, or recompence their ≈øeruice done, and ray≈øe him to dignitie and honour. They giue him the title of Nayque, which ≈øignifieth a Captaine, as Salua Nayque and Acem Nayque. And wheÃÑ they will giue a man an honourable title, or ≈øalutation, they call him Rau, as Chitarau, which is to ≈øay, ≈øtrong King, and ≈øuch like titles, which among them is a great honour. Al≈øo Adelham or Hidelcam, is called Sabayo, which ≈øignifieth Seigneur or Lord, for the Iland of Goa had a Captaine or Gouernour, that was Lord of the towne, when the Portingales wanne it fir≈øt, called Sabayo, as the Portingales Chronicles of their Indian conque≈øts doe make mention, who≈øe hou≈øe or Palace to this day in the Cittie of Goa, is the inqui≈øition hou≈øe, and a place which ≈øtandeth betw√©ene the great Church and the ≈øame hou≈øe, is as yet called the Pallace of Sabayo.

div.head: The 28. Chapter. Of the towne and Ilande of Goa, chiefe Cittie of India.
div.p:
THe Citie of Goa, is the Metropolitan or chiefe Cittie of all the Orientall Indies, where the Portingales haue their traffique, where al≈øo the Viceroye, the Arch bi≈øhop, the Kings Councel, and Chauncerie haue their re≈øidence, and from thence are all places in the Orientall Indies, gouerned and ruled. There is likewi≈øe the ≈øtaple for all Indian commodities, whether all ≈øorts of Marchants doe re≈øort, comming thether both to buy and ≈øell, as out of Arabia, Armenia, Per≈øia, Cambaia, Bengala, Pegu, Sian, Malacca, Iaua, Molucca, China, &c. The Cittie and Iland of Goa, lyeth vnder 15. degrees, on the North ≈øide, and is di≈øtant from the Equinoctiall, (by the way that the Portingales ≈øhippes do come thether from Mo≈ø≈øambique) 400. miles. It is an Iland wholly compa≈ø≈øed about with a riuer, and is aboue thr√©e miles great, it lyeth within the coa≈øt of the firme lande, ≈øo that the Iland, with the Sea coa≈øt of the firme land, doe both reach as farre each as other into the Sea. It is only ≈øeperated from the firme land, by an arme of the Sea, or of the ryuer, that runneth in by the North ≈øide of the towne, and ≈øo round about the Iland to the South ≈øide, where it entereth againe into the Sea, and is in forme almo≈øt like a halfe Moone. The ryuer runneth euen vnto the Towne, and is indifferent broade, there are betw√©ene the firme land and the Iland, certaine ≈ømall Ilandes that are all inhabited by the naturall borne countrimen, and on the other ≈øide of the town the ryuer is there ≈øo ≈ømall, that in Summer time, by wading to the kn√©es in water, a man may pa≈ø≈øe it ouer on foote. On the which ≈øide the Iland hath a wall with certaine Bulwarkes, which ye Portingales of late yeares haue cau≈øed to be made, to defend them from the firme land in time of warre, as it often happeneth, for it hath diuers times b√©ene be≈øieged by Dialcan or Hidalcam, at the mouth and the entrie of the ryuer. On the North ≈øide lyeth the land of Bardes, which is high land, vnder which land the Portingales doe Anker ≈øafely out of all danger, and there they haue a place to lade and vnlade their wares. This land of Bardes is al≈øo vnder the Portingall ≈øubiection, and is full of Villages inhabited with people that are of the firme land, lying aboue it, called Canarijns, who for the mo≈øt part are Chri≈øtians, but ob≈øerue their owne manner of apparell, which is to goe all naked, their priuie members onely couered. This land is full of Indian Palme tr√©es, whereon the Indian Nuts called Cocos doe grow, as al≈øo all the other Ilands lying in the ryuer. This land of Bardes, is ≈øeperated from the firme land by a ≈ømall riuer, which is ≈øo little, that it cannot almo≈øt be di≈øcerned from the firme land. On the South ≈øide of the Iland of Goa, wher the riuer runneth againe into the Sea, there commeth euen out with the coa≈øt a land, called Sal≈øette, which is al≈øo vnder the ≈øubiection of the Portingales, and is inhabited, and planted both with people and fruite, like the land of Bardes, and is likewi≈øe parted with a little ryuer from the firme land. Betw√©ene this land of Sal≈øette, & the Iland of Goa, lie al≈øo ≈øome ≈ømall Ilands, all full of Indian Palme tr√©es, and by the mouth or i≈ø≈øue of the ryuer, lyeth an Iland which is called Goa Velha, that is old Goa, from whence there commeth no ≈øpeciall thing, neither is it much inhabited. Tho≈øe lands of Bardes and Sal≈øette, are by the Kings of Portingale let out to farme, and the rents therof are imployed to the payment of the Archbi≈øhop, Cloy≈øters, Prie≈øts,
Viceroy, & other the Kings Officers, yearely ≈øtipends, which is graunted them, by ≈øpeciall Priueledges and Patents from the King. The Iland is verie hillie, and in ≈øome places ≈øo de≈øert and rough, that on ≈øome ≈øides men can hardly trauell ouer land (but with great labour) to the towne of Goa, the Iland euen to the Sea ≈øide is full of Villages, and inhabited by the Canarijus, which are the naturall borne people of the land, and doe altogether liue by working vpon the land, and by their Palme trees. The villages and dwellings of the≈øe Canarijus, are mo≈øt rounde about the Iland, and on the water ≈øides, or by ≈ømall Lakes, whereof there are ≈øome fewe, within the Iland, and the cau≈øe why they dwell thus, is for that the Palme tr√©es will not grow in any other place but vpon low ground, by the waters, ≈øpecially in ≈øandie ground: ≈øo that there are no Palme tr√©es to be found on the high land within the countrie vnle≈ø≈øe it bee vpon ≈øandie groundes on the Sea coa≈øt, or ryuers ≈øides. On the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the towne of Goa vpwardes, into the ryuer, about thr√©e miles from the towne of Bardes, lyeth a place wher the Portingals ≈øhips doe Anker, the ryuer hath ≈øome cr√©ekes, and a ≈øhip of 200. Tunnes or there abouts, may ea≈øily di≈øcharge before the Towne, but the Portingales great ≈øhips mu≈øt di≈øcharge them ≈øelues at Bardes: which being done, they may i ‚Ä¢ they will fr√©ely goe and lie before the town. The towne is well builte with faire hou≈øes and ≈øtr√©etes, after the Portingall manner, but becau≈øe of the heate they are ≈øomewhat lower. They commonly haue their Gardens and Orchards at the backe ≈øide of their hou≈øes, full of all kinde of Indian fruites: as al≈øo the whole Iland through, they haue many plea≈øant Gardens and farmes, with hou≈øes to play in, and tr√©es of Indian fruites, whether they goe to ≈øport them≈øelues, and wherein the Indian women take great delight. The towne hath in it all ≈øortes of Cloy≈øters and Churches as Lisbone hath, onely it wanteth Nunnes, for the men cannot get the women to trauell ≈øo farre, where they ≈øhould be ≈øhut vp, and for≈øake Venus, with whome (≈øo that they may enioy and fulfill their lu≈øtes) they had rather loo≈øe their liues, whereof they make ≈ømall account. The Iland is both winter and Summer all alike gr√©ene, and hath alwaies ≈øome kinde of fruite in ≈øea≈øon, which is a great plea≈øure, the towne lyeth vppon ≈øome hils and dales like Lisbone, it hath in times pa≈øt b√©ene verie ≈ømall, and walled, with a drie Ditch round about it, wherein there is no water, but when it rayneth, the walles are yet ≈øtanding, but no Gates remaining, and the towne is now built round about with hou≈øes, ≈øo that it is, at the lea≈øt twice as big without the walles, as it is within, and lyeth open without walles or clo≈øures, ≈øauing onely that the Iland hath a wal on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, which beginneth ouer again≈øt the land of Sal≈øette, and ≈øo runneth along vntill you come at Bardes, and is onely to defend them from the firme land, where the Portingales haue no commaundement. The whole Iland hath no other defence, but onely vpon the corner of the land of Bardes, at the mouth of the ryuer, where there ≈øtandeth an olde ruinous Ca≈øtle, wherein lyeth two or thr√©e Iron p√©eces, and one man that in the night time k√©epeth the watch, the Iland on the Sea ≈øide is verie high, full of ≈øtonie Cliffes, but the land of Bardes hath on the Sea ≈øide a verie faire white Sand, about halfe a mile long, and ≈øomewhat more: the defence of the Ilande con≈øi≈øteth herein, that on the Ea≈øt ≈øide there are thr√©e or foure pa≈ø≈øages or Gates, that ≈øtand vpon the water ≈øide, on the vttermo≈øt part of the Iland, right again≈øt the firme land, Sal≈øette and Bardes, euerie gate or pa≈ø≈øage hath a Captaine and a clarke, which k√©epe watch, that no man may pa≈ø≈øe into the other ≈øide, but by their licence. And the Indians, Decanijus, and other Moores and heathens, that are re≈øident in Goa, and therein haue their habitation, when they goe into the firme land to fetch their nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øions, comming to tho≈øe places which are called Pa≈ø≈øos, they mu≈øt euerye man haue a marke, which is Printed on their naked armes, and ≈øo they pa≈ø≈øe ouer to the other ≈øide, and at their returne againe they mu≈øt ≈øhew the ≈øame marke, whereby they may fr√©ely enter, for the which they pay two Ba≈øarukes, which is as much as a Hollanders Doit, and this is the profit that the Captain and Clarke of the ≈øaid Pa≈ø≈øos doe make. In the night they haue a Boy, that k√©epeth watch, and hath a ≈ømall Bell, which hangeth ouer the gate, which Boylyeth downe, and tieth the ≈øtring of the Bell at his foote and ≈øo ringeth it often times, to ≈øhew that hee watcheth, which is all the watch they hold thoroughout the whole Iland. There are fiue of the≈øe Pa≈ø≈øos, one vpon the South ≈øide of the Iland, where men pa≈ø≈øe to the firme lande, and to the land of Sal≈øette, and is called Bene≈øterijn, commonly named Pa≈ø≈øo de Saint Iago, becau≈øe the Pari≈øh of Saint Iacobs ≈øtandeth ther: The Tebe de Pa≈ø≈øo is on the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Iland, where men doe onely pa≈ø≈øe into. The firme land called O Pa≈ø≈øo Secco, which is the drie pa≈ø≈øage, for in that place the ryuer is at the narrowe≈øt and ≈øhallowe≈øt. The third Pa≈ø≈øo on the South ≈øide of the Iland, ioyneth almo≈øt to the Towne,
called O Pa≈øso de Daugijn, or of Madre de Deus, and ≈øo farre goeth the wall, beginning at Pa≈øso de Bene≈øterijn, or S. Iago, and from thence the whole Iland is without any wall or clo≈øure: from this Pa≈øso, right ouer again≈øt it, they pa≈ø≈øe ouer to an Iland, which is hard by the firme land, where is al≈øo a Pa≈øso called O Pa≈øso de Norwa: the fift or la≈øt Pa≈øso lyeth in the middle way of the Riuer downwards towards Bardes, which is the ≈øtronge≈øt of them all, and be≈øt looked vnto, but no otherwi≈øe made then all the re≈øt, & is called O Pa≈øso de Pangijn, froÃÑ thence they pa≈ø≈øe to Bardes, and al≈øo all the boates and ≈øhips that pa≈ø≈øe in and out of the riuer, mu≈øt ≈øtay there & be ≈øearched, and this is all their watch and ≈øtrentgh in the Iland.

Touching the Portingales iu≈øtice and ordinances, as well in worldly as ≈øpirituall cau≈øes, they are al one as they are in Portingale. They dwell in the towne among all ≈øorts of nations, as Indians, Heathens, Moores, Iewes, Armenians, Gu≈øarates, Benianes, Bramenes, and of all Indian nations and people, which doe all dwell and traficke therein, euerie man holding his owne religion, without con≈øtrayning any man to doe again≈øt his con≈øcience, onely touching their ceremonies of burning the dead, and the liuing, of marrying & other ≈øuper≈øtitious & deueli≈øh inuentions, they are forbidden by the Archbi≈øhop to v≈øe them openly, or in the Iland, but they may fr√©elie v≈øe them vpon the firme land, and ≈øecretly in their hou≈øes, thereby to ≈øhunne and auoid all occa≈øions of di≈ølike that might be giuen to Chri≈øtians, which are but newlie bapti≈øed: but touching the worldly policie or good gouernement of the countrie, and executing of iu≈øtice, as al≈øo for the ruling of the townes men in the citie: it is common to them all, and they are vnder the Portingales law, and he that is once chri≈øtened, and is after found to v≈øe any heatheni≈øh ≈øuper≈øtitions, is ≈øubiect to the Inqui≈øition, what ≈øo euer he be, or for any point of Religion what ≈øo euer.

The Iland hath nothing of it ≈øelf to nouri≈øh it withall, but onely ≈øome cattle, hennes, goates, doues, &c. but very fewe, becau≈øe of the barrenne≈ø≈øe and euil ≈øituation of the place, which is a mo≈øt hillie, barren, and wild countrie, and full of wa≈øt ground: all their nece≈ø≈øaries, as bea≈øtes, hennes, hogges, egges, milke, &c. come from Sal≈øette and Bardes, but mo≈øt part out of the firme land, Corne, Rice, and other grayne: al≈øo Oyle, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries come from other countries, and are brought in by the Riuer, as froÃÑ Cambaia on the North ≈øide, and from the coa≈øt of Malabar and other places, as in the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt we haue in part declared: of wyne called wyne of palme tr√©es, they haue inough, and ≈øo much that they haue to ≈øpare for other places. They haue but little fre≈øh water, but only one Well called Banganiin, which ≈øtaÃÑdeth about a quarter of a mile with out the Cittie, wherewith the whole towne is ≈øerued, which the ≈ølaues fetch in pots & ≈øel it in the towne, and is verie good to drinke: for water to dre≈ø≈øe meat, wa≈øh, and doe other thinges withall, they commonly haue Wels within their hou≈øes: the land of it ≈øelf is verie ≈øtonie and drie, hauing a kinde of red earth, ≈øo that ≈øome Italian Alchymi≈øtes haue promi≈øed to get Copper & Gold out of the ≈øame, which neither ye king nor Vice-roy would euer coÃÑ≈øeÃÑt vnto, fearing lea≈øt the report of ≈øuch trea≈øure would be occa≈øion of greater troble vnto them by their enemies that are round about them, through the de≈øire that they haue of riches, and therefore they haue deferred to ≈ø√©eke for it: by the mappe hereafter following you may ≈ø√©e the ≈øituation of the Iland and Towne of Goa, with all the ≈øtr√©etes, Churches and places liuely de≈øcribed.

div.head: The 29. Chapter. Of the cu≈øtomes of the Portingales, and ≈øuch as are i≈ø≈øued from them, called Mesticos, or half countrimen, as wel of Goa, as of all the Oriental countries.
div.p:
THe Portingales in India, are many of them marryed with the naturall borne women of the countrie, and the children proc√©eding of them are called Me≈øticos, that is, half countrimen. The≈øe Me≈øticos are commonlie of yelowi≈øh colour, notwith≈øtanding there are manie women among them, that are faire and well formed. The children of the Portingales, both boyes and gyrls, which are borne in India, are called Ca≈øti≈øos, and are in all things like vnto the Portingales, onely ≈øomewhat differing in colour, for they draw towards a yealow colour: the children of tho≈øe Ca≈øti≈øos are yealow, and altogether like the Me≈øticos, and the children of Me≈øticos are of colour and fa≈øhion like the naturall borne Countrimen or Decaniins of the countrie, ≈øo that the po≈øteritie of the Portingales, both men and womeÃÑ being in the third degr√©e, doe ≈ø√©eme to be naturall Indians, both in colour & fa≈øhion. Their liuings and daylie traffiques are to Bengala, Pegu, Malacca, Cambaia, China, and euerie way, both North and South: al≈øo in Goa there is holden a daylie a≈ø≈øemblie or
m√©eting together, as wel of the Citizens and Inhabitants, as of all nations throughout India, and of the countries bordering on the ≈øame, which is like the m√©eting vpoÃÑ the bur≈øe in Andwarpe, yet differeth much from that, for that hether in Goa there come as well Gentlemen, as marchants and others, and there are all kindes of Indian commodities to ≈øell, ≈øo that in a manner it is like a Faire. This m√©eting is onely before Noone, euerie day in the yeare, except Sondayes and holie dayes: it beginneth in ye morning at 7. of the clocke, and continueth till 9. of the clocke, but not in the heate of the day, nor after Noone, in the principal ≈øtr√©ete of the Citie, named the ≈øtraight ≈øtr√©ete, and is called the Leylon, which is as much to ≈øay, as an outroop: there are certain cryers appointed by the Citie for ye purpo≈øe, which haue of al things to be cryed and ≈øold: the≈øe goe all the time of the Leylon or outroop, all behangd about with all ≈øorts of gold chaines, all kindes of co≈øtly Iewels, pearles, rings, and precious ≈øtones: likewi≈øe they haue running about them, many ≈øorts of captiues and ≈ølaues, both men and women, young and old, which are daylie ≈øould there, as bea≈øts are ≈øold with vs, where euerie one may chu≈øe which liketh him be≈øt, euerie one at a certaine price. There are al≈øo Arabian hor≈øes, all kinde of ≈øpices and dryed drugges, ≈øweet gummes, and ≈øuch like things, fine and co≈øtly couerlets, and many curious things, out of Cambaia, Sinde, BeÃÑgala, China, &c. and it is wonderfull to ≈ø√©e in what ≈øort many of them get their liuinges, which euery day come thether to buy wares, and at an other time ≈øel them again. And when any man dieth, all his goods are brought thether & ≈øold to the la≈øt pennie worth, in the ≈øame outroop, who ≈øoeuer they be, yea although they were the Viceroyes goods: and this is done to doe right and iu≈øtice vnto Orphanes & widdows, and that it may be ≈øold with the fir≈øt, where euerie man may ≈ø√©e it, ≈øo that euerie yeare there is great quantitie of ware ≈øold within that Citie, for that there die many men within the Towne, by meanes of their di≈øordered liuing, together with the hotenes of the couÃÑ try: the like a≈ø≈øemblie is holden in all places of India, where the Portingales inhabite. There are ≈øome married Portingales, that get their liuings by their ≈ølaues, both men and women, wherof ≈øome haue 12, ≈øome 20, and ≈øome 30, for it co≈øteth them but little to k√©epe them. The≈øe ≈ølaues for money doe labour for ≈øuch as haue n√©ede of their helpe, ≈øome fetch fre≈øh water, and ≈øell it for money about the ≈øtr√©etes: the women ≈ølaues make all ≈øorts of confectures and con≈øerues of Indian fruites, much fyne n√©edle worke, both cut and wrought workes, and theÃÑ their mai≈øter ≈øend the faire≈øt and the younge≈øt of them well dre≈øt vp with their wares about the ≈øtr√©etes to ≈øell the ≈øame, that by the neatnes & bewtie of the ≈øaid women ≈ølaues, men might be moued to buy, which happeneth more for the affection they haue to the ≈ølaues & to fulfill their plea≈øure with them, then for any de≈øire to the con≈øerues or n√©edle workes: for the≈øe ≈ølaues doe neuer refu≈øe them, but make their daylie liuing thereby, and with the gaines that they by that meanes bring home, their mai≈øters may well k√©epe and maintaine them. There are others that v≈øe exchanging of moneyes, and to buy money when it cometh, as tyme ≈øerueth to fell it againe, for they buy the Rials of eight, when the ≈øhippes come from Portingale, whereof ≈øome buy at the lea≈øt 10 or 12 hundreth, and k√©epe them till the Moneth of April, which is the time when the ≈øhippes ≈øayle to China, for then are the Rials of eight ≈øought for to carry thether, and are commonly worth 25 or 30 in the hundreth profite, and then they receiue for them a certain money, which at the ≈øame time is brought froÃÑ Ormus, called Larriins, that come out of Per≈øia, which they buy for 8 or 10 in the hundreth profite, & k√©epe them til the Portingales on the moneth of SepteÃÑ ber come thether, and ≈øo deliuer them againe for 20 or 25 in the hundreth profite, in exchange for Rials of eight, as I ≈øaid before, for they mu≈øt haue the≈øe Larriins with them to Cochin, to buy pepper and other wares, for that it is the be≈øt and mo≈øt profitable money. There are yet other ≈øorts of money called Pagodes, Venetianers, & Santhones, which are gold, al which they doe likewi≈øe buy & ≈øel, ≈øo yt there are manie that doe nothing els, & become rich, ≈øpeciallie he that hath a good ≈øtocke. This exchange cometh mo≈øt coÃÑmonlie from the Spiritualtie, who do ≈øecretly v≈øe it, by other mens meanes, without any let or hinderance. Some there are that liue vpon their rents which they haue by their palme tr√©es, whereon the Indian nut called Cocus doth grow, whereof they may very well liue and haue well to maintaine them≈øelues, for that it is the principall commoditie of that Iland.

There are ≈øome that let out their tr√©es, and haue euery day for each tr√©e half a Pardawe or more, which is as much as a Carolus Guilderne, and ≈øome haue 300 or 400 tr√©es and more vpon one ground, which they let out vnto the Canariins, as we let out our pa≈øtures, medowes & corn grounds. The Portingales and Me≈øticos in India neuer worke, if they doe, it is but very little,

and that not often, but the mo≈øt part of them liue in ≈øuch ≈øort, as I haue ≈øhewed you, although there are ≈øome handie crafts men, as Hat-makers, Shoe-makers, Saylemakers, and Coopers: but mo≈øt of them haue their ≈ølaues to worke in their ≈øhops, and the mai≈øters when they walke vp and downe the ≈øtr√©etes, goe as proudlie as the be≈øt: for there one is no better then an other, as they think, the rich and the poore man all one, without any difference in their conuer≈øations, curte≈øies and companies. All other handie crafts men and workmen, are mo≈øt Indians, Heathens, and Chri≈øtians of the land: no man is permitted to the liberties of being a fr√©e Citizen of the towne, but ≈øuch as are marryed and re≈øident therein.

There are among them but two manner of people, that is, married men and ≈øoldiers, for that all young men vnmarried are named ≈øoldiers, which is the be≈øt name that a man can haue, not that the ≈øoldiers are any waies bound or vnder the commandement and regiment of any Captain, which throughout India, is not v≈øed but when the Portingalles come into India out of Portingall, and are ariued there, euery man goeth where hee thinketh be≈øt, although in Portingall euery mans name that goeth in the ≈øhippe is written and regi≈øtred, which is done in this ≈øorte: euery man is written vp, both his name and ≈øirname, with a note what pay they receyue of the King, whereof ≈øome beare the tytle of Fidalgo da Caza del Rey no≈ø≈øas Senor, that is, a Gentleman of the Kinges hou≈øe, which is the chiefe≈øt title: there are others named Mozos Fidalgos, which is al≈øo an honorable title, and they are commonly Gentlemens ≈øonnes, or by the kinges fauour aduaunced therevnto: There are yet others that are named Caualhiero Fidalgo, which is not ≈øo much as the other two, yet it is an honorable title, and is the title of a knight, who for ≈øome valiant act by him done is made knight, which they do for a ≈ømall matter: for that if he do any act to be accounted of, or bee in a manner at ≈øuch an action doing, pre≈øently he is of a Captaine or a Gentleman made a knight, whereof they much boa≈øt them≈øelues: and it is nowe growne ≈øo common among them, that very Cookes boyes and others as meane as they, are made knightes: there are others al≈øo that are named Mo≈øos da Camara, do Numero, e do Serui√ßo, which is ≈øeruantes to the King, ≈øome of his chamber, ≈øome of his accounts, and ≈øome for his ≈øeruice, this is the fir≈øt title or degr√©e of credite, whereby through their good ≈øeruice they attaine vnto better, and are more glorious of their titles, then of all the riches in the world. There are al≈øo that are named E≈øcuderos Fidalgos, that is E≈øquires, which is likewi≈øe a degr√©e of credit: Others are named Hommes honorados, which is meÃÑ of honor, and the poore≈øt among them (which are not named by any title) are ≈øet downe for ≈øoldiers, which are the common and ra≈øcall ≈øort: the≈øe are euery man paide their wages according to their titles, and may each man in his qualitie (by long ≈øeruice, or ≈øome good action, but mo≈øt by fauour) ri≈øe to higher degr√©e; for that according to their tytles their ≈øeruice is rewarded. The Portingalles which ≈øaile for India, being thus regi≈øtred & written downe, the ≈øaid Regi≈øter at their arriuall there, is deliuered to be kept by one of the kinges Officers therevnto appointed, which euery three yeares is likewi≈øe changed, as other offices are, and is called the chiefe Clearke of the Matricola Generall, and hath thr√©e or foure vnder Clearks at his commandement. Now in India when ≈øummer time commeth, and that it is n√©edefull or nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend out an armie for ≈øome expedition to be done, or for to k√©epe the coa≈øt, to conuoy and ≈øafe-conduct the trauelling Marchants that dayly ≈øayle to and from India, thereby to defend them and to let the Malabares their enemies from i≈ø≈øuing forth to hurt them (as notwith≈øtanding they yearly doe:) then again≈øt September (which is the beginning of their Sommer) the drum is ≈øtricken vp, and it is proclaimed, that who≈øoeuer will ≈øerue the king in his fl√©ete by ≈øea, let him come to the Matricola Generall to receyue his money, and then by the Viceroy there is ordained a chiefe Captaine, and other vnder Captains for euery Fu≈øte and Galley: and in euery galley there is about a hundreth men, and in euery Fu≈øte thirtie men, little more or le≈ø≈øe. The≈øe are all paide by the Matricola, according to their tytles euery man as they are regi≈øtred, when they come out of Portingal: and this pay is made euery quarter, each quarter contayning thr√©e monthes, that is, the common ≈øoldier ≈øeuen Pardawen, called Xeraffins (euery Pardawe thr√©e te≈øtones Portingall money) and a man of honor nine Pardawen. The Mo≈øo da Camara or ≈øeruant of the chamber eleuen Pardawen, & ≈øo by degr√©es: which done the Captaines bidde their ≈øoldiers to a banket, and of their own pur≈øes giue them ≈øomething be≈øide their pay, for that euery Captaine ≈ø√©eketh to haue the be≈øt ≈øoldiers, and buy much victuailes and other thinges at their owne charges, thereby to haue their ≈øoldiers good willes, and to v≈øe them wel. They ≈øit altogether at one table in the Fu≈øtes or Gallies, where the Captaine v≈øeth the ≈øoldiers with great fauour and curte≈øie, for otherwi≈øe they woulde not much e≈øt√©eme
him, nor yet obay him. The fl√©et being out, it ≈øayleth backewarde and forwards along the coa≈øt, and ≈øometimes into ≈øome hauens till the Month of Aprill, and about the la≈øt of that Month they enter againe into the riuer of Goa, where they winter, and then the ≈øoldiers are fr√©e, and euery man goeth his way, without any further pay of the king. Then the Viceroy maketh a certificate for the Generall of the fl√©ete, wherein he te≈øtifieth that ≈øuch a Captaine by his commaundement hath b√©ene ≈øo many Monthes in the kings ≈øeruice at ≈øea, & hauing done any matter of importance, it is therein ≈øet down at large, and how that hee out of his owne pur≈øe hath ≈øpent and laid out much money for the ≈øeruice of his Maie≈øtie, and according to this certificate the Captaine Generall maketh certificates for euery one of his vnder Captaines and ≈øoldiers, in the ≈øame ≈øort. There are likewi≈øe ≈øome Gentlemen that in winter time keepe open hou≈øhold for all ≈øoldiers that will come thether to meate, whereof al≈øo they haue certificates, and for all things that they doe, which certificates they k√©epe till they be ≈øome ten, twelue, or twentie, and with the Viceroyes licence go therewith to Portingall, a≈øking ≈øome recompence for their ≈øeruices, according to their certificates: withall they mu≈øt bring a certificate from the Matricola General of that their re≈øidence in India, and that there hath not any deui≈øe or ≈øubtilty b√©ene v≈øed about ≈øetting downe their titles. The like mu≈øt they haue from all other officers, receiuers and accountants both for munition and armour wherewith they ≈øerued in warre, for victuails al≈øo and ≈øuch like, whereof many times the captaines and ≈øoldiers doe make but badde accounts, and many of them are aforehande with the king, which is pre≈øently regi≈øtred vnder the title of him that hath committed the fault: from the≈øe Officers al≈øo they mu≈øt haue certificates, that there is no ≈øuch thing committed by them: with the≈øe certificates they ≈øayle to Portingall, where there is an office of remembrances, to a≈øke their rewardes by, as their qualities and ≈øeruices are or ≈øhalbe rewarded: but if they haue any friend in the court to ≈øpeake for them, & by grea≈øing their hands to procure di≈øpatch: then doe they obtaine tho≈øe offices for thr√©e yeares as Captaynes, Factors, Clearkes, Iudges, &c. and all other offices and places in India, but they mu≈øt ≈øerue the place them≈øelues in per≈øon. Some of them by fauour get licences to pa≈ø≈øe them away, to ≈øell them, or to giue them with their daughters in mariage, and then the patent for ≈øuch offices are regi≈øtred in the Kings Chancery, and ≈øent into India where they mu≈øt be confirmed by the Viceroy. The≈øe offices are alwaies giuen in reuer≈øion after him that hath it promi≈øed before them, and then the Regi≈øter is ≈øearched, to ≈ø√©e how many are before him that a≈øketh the ≈øaid places, & when their time is out, or that they chaunce to die before they come to it, or be ab≈øent (as many times it happeneth) then he which is next in reuer≈øion hath the place, and is ready to receyue it. And this in briefe is the manner of their gouernement and policie for martiall affaires: their other gouernment for iu≈øtice and equitie is as they v≈øe it in Portingall. By the table hereafter following you may ≈ø√©e the de≈øcription of the ≈øtrait ≈øtreete in Goa, with the dayly m√©eting therein, which they call Leylon, liuely portrayed.

div.head: The 30. Chapter. Of the Portingalles and Me≈øticos, their hou≈øes, curte≈øies, mariages, and other cu≈øtomes and manners in India.
div.p:
THe Portingals, Me≈øticos, and Chri≈øtians k√©epe wor≈øhipfull and bountifull hou≈øes, hauing commonly (as it is ≈øaid before) fiue, ≈øixe, ten, twentie, ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe ≈ølaues, both men and women, in their hou≈øes euery man according to his e≈øtate and qualitie, I meane maried men. They are very cleanly and ≈øw√©et in all things belonging to their hou≈øes, ≈øpecially in their linnen, for that euery day they change ≈øhirtes and ≈ømockes both men and women, and their ≈ølaues and ≈øeruants likewi≈øe with other thinges that they weare, which they doe becau≈øe of the great heat in that land. The Portingals are commonly ≈øerued with great grauitie, without any difference betw√©ene the Gentleman & the common Citizen, townesman or ≈øoldier, and in their going, curte≈øies, and conuer≈øations, common in all thinges: when they go in the ≈øtr√©etes they ≈øteppe very ≈øoftly and ≈ølowly forwards, with a great pride and vaineglorious maie≈øtie, with a ≈ølaue that carrieth a great hat or vaile ouer their heads, to keepe the ≈øunne and raine from them. Al≈øo when it raineth they commonly haue a boy that beareth a cloke of Scarlet or of ≈øome other cloth after them, to ca≈øt ouer them: and if it bee before noone, hee carrieth a cu≈øhin for his mai≈øter to kn√©ele on when hee heareth Ma≈ø≈øe, and their Rapier is mo≈øt commonly carried after them by a boy, that it may not trouble them as they walke, nor hinder their
