When they m√©ete in the ≈øtr√©etes a good ≈øpace before they come together, they beginne with a great Be≈øolas manos, to ≈øtoope with their bodies, and to thru≈øt forth their foot to ≈øalute each other, with their hattes in their hands, almo≈øt touching the ground: likewi≈øe when they come into the Church where they haue their ≈øtooles ready, which their ≈ølaues haue prepared for them: all that are by him that commeth in do ≈øtande vp, and with the ≈øame manner of bowing of their bodies doe him great reuerence, and if it chaunceth that any doeth him reuerence (as the manner is) & that he to whom it is done doth not greatly e≈øt√©eme thereof, ≈øo that he doeth him not the like curte≈øie, they do altogether for that cau≈øe go after him, and cut his hatte in p√©eces, ≈øaying that he had di≈øgraced the partie, wherein it is not for them to a≈øke wherfore they ≈øhold ≈øo do; for it would bee the greate≈øt ≈øhame and reproch in the world vnto them if they ≈øhould not reuenge ≈øo great an iniury: & when they ≈øeeke to bee reuenged of any man that hath ≈øhewen them di≈øcurte≈øie, or for any other cau≈øe what≈øoeuer it bee, they a≈ø≈øemble ten or twelue of their friends, acquaintance or companions, and take him where≈øoeuer they find him, and beat him ≈øo long together, that they leaue him for dead, or very neare dead, or els cau≈øe him to be ≈øtabbed by their ≈ølaues, which they hold for a great honor and point of hone≈øtie ≈øo to reuenge them≈øelues, whereof they dare boa≈øt and bragge openly in the ≈øtr√©etes, but if they de≈øire not to kil him, they ba≈øte him well about the ribs and all his body ouer with a thicke r√©ede, as big as a mans legge, which is called Bambus, whereby for eyght dayes after and more he hath inough to do to k√©epe his bed, and ≈øometime in that manner they leaue him for deade. This is their common cu≈øtome, and is neuer looked vnto or once corrected. Al≈øo they v≈øe long bagges full of ≈øand, wherewith they will giue ≈øuch blowes each vpon other, that therewith they will breake each others limmes, and for euer after make them lame. When any man goeth to vi≈øite an other in his hou≈øe, although he which is vi≈øited be one of the principal Gentlemen of the Citie, and the vi≈øitor but a ≈øimple ≈øoldier, or ≈øome other man, it is the manner that hee which is vi≈øited commeth vnto the doore of his hou≈øe, with his hatte in his hand, and with great curte≈øie to receyue him that commeth to vi≈øite him, and ≈øo leadeth him vp into his hall or chamber, wherein he will ≈øpeake with him, where hee offereth him a chaire to ≈øitte downe, and then hee him≈øelfe ≈øitteth by him, then hee a≈øketh him what hee woulde haue, which hauing vnder≈øtoode hee bringeth him downe againe to the dore in the like ≈øort, and ≈øo with a Be≈øolas manos biddeth him farewel, and if he ≈øhould not doe ≈øo, or when hee giueth him a ≈øtool, ≈øhold giue him one vnlined, or one yt is le≈ø≈øe or lower then that hee taketh for him≈øelfe, he that vi≈øiteth him woulde take it in euil parte, e≈øt√©eming it a great ≈øcorne, & ≈ø√©eke to be reuenged on him for the ≈øame.

When they haue any weddinges and are married, who≈øoeuer they be if they haue any wealth, all the friendes and neighbours come together, euery man on hor≈øebacke, and hee that hath not a hor≈øe wil borrow one, and are euery man very co≈øtly apparelled, at the lea≈øt ≈øome 50. or 100. hor≈øes little more or le≈ø≈øe, as the per≈øon is of qualitie, and ≈øo they ride altogether in good order vnto the Church with their ≈øeruantes, and euery man his hatte for the Sunne, the parentes and friendes in the hinder part, and in ye la≈øt row the bridegroome betw√©ene two of them, whom they call go≈ø≈øops: after them followeth the bryde betw√©en two Commeres, each in their Pallamkin, which is mo≈øt co≈øtly made, and after them followe the ≈ølaues both men and women going in troupes, as if they ranne to hunt, and ≈øo comming to the Church, and being married according to the order v≈øed in the Church of Rome: they are in the ≈øame order brought home again, and pa≈ø≈øing through the ≈øtr√©ets, the neighbours leaning vppon Indian Carpets looke out of the windowes, and throwe Ro≈øe water vpon the Bryde & Bridegroome, and other ≈øweet ≈ømelling waters, with Ro≈øes and Sugar Comfets, or corne. In the mean time their ≈ølaues play vppon Shalmes and Trumpets mo≈øt plea≈øant and melodious to heare, and comming to the hou≈øe where the Bride and the Bridegroome dwel, with great reuerence and curte≈øie bowing downe their bodies, they take their leaues of all the company, which are all on hor≈øebacke about the dore. And ≈øo the Bride, the Bridegroome and the Commeres go vp & ≈øit with great grauitie in a window, and then beginne the hor≈øemen that led them to Church, in honor of the married couple, one after the other to runne a cour≈øe, the go≈ø≈øops beginning fir≈øt, and the re≈øt following twice or thrice one after the other, with continuall playing on Shalmes, which are very common in India, for that he which is of any wealth hath them of his own within his hou≈øe. This being ended, they all pa≈ø≈øe before the window where the Bride and Bridegroome ≈øit, with a great reuerence, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe on all ≈øauing the Go≈ø≈øoppes, for they go vp to the Bride and Bridegroome, and bid God giue them ioy, then is there ≈øome Comfets and Marchpane brought forth, to drinke a cuppe of water withall, and after ≈øome curteous ≈øalutations and congratulations to the
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ couple, they take their leaues & „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øo there remaineth with the Bride & ‚Ä¢ idegroom but three or four of their neare≈øt friendes and kin≈øemen, for whome there is a dinner prepared, with little meate, yet very co≈øtly, which they pa≈ø≈øe ouer very lightly, and not many wordes, which done they pre≈øently bring the Bride to bed, without any other ceremonies or charges, wherewith the mariage is done and ended. Oftentimes it chaunceth that they go to bed at ye lea≈øt two houres before Sunne ≈øetting, not hauing the patience to ≈øtay ≈øo long as we do in the≈øe countries. When a childe is to be chri≈øtened, it is likewi≈øe in the ≈øame ≈øorte led to Church with hor≈øes, & la≈øt of all commeth the father alone, after whom followeth two men on foote, the one with a great ≈øiluer or guilt ve≈ø≈øell full of bread baked like cracklinges, which in Portingall are called Ro≈øquilhos, and in the middle a great Ware candle, well made and gilded, thru≈øt through with ≈øome peeces of money of golde and ≈øiluer, for an offering to the Prie≈øt that bapti≈øeth the childe, and all ouer ≈øtrowed and couered with Ro≈øes: the other carryeth a great ≈øiluer or gilt ≈øalt≈øeller in one of his handes, and a lampe of the ≈øame ≈øtuffe in his other hande, each with rich and co≈øtly Towels on their ≈øholders: after that followeth two Pallamkins, on the one ≈øide ye Commere, on the other ≈øide the Midwife with the child, couered with a co≈øtly mantle, made for the purpo≈øe, and ≈øo the ceremonies of bapti≈øme being ended in the Church, it is againe in the like ≈øort brought home, and beeing there, they haue the like manner of mu≈øicke and ≈øhalmes, running and leaping with their hor≈øes before the window where the Commere ≈øitteth, with the ≈øame ceremonies as at the wedding. This is the manner and cu≈øtome of tho≈øe that are married and keepe hou≈øe.

But concerning the ≈øouldier that is vnmaried, thus it is. They goe in the ≈øummer time into the Armado lying on the water, and being within the townes and on the land, they are very ≈øtately apparrelled, and goe verie grauely along the ≈øtreets with their ≈ølaues or men hired for the purpo≈øe, that beare a hatte ouer them for the ≈øunne and raine: for there are many IndiaÃÑs that are daily hired for the purpo≈øe, and haue 12. Ba≈øarucos the day, which is as much as two ≈ø ‚Ä¢ iuers or a ≈øtoter, & they ≈øerue ≈øuch as haue no ≈ølaues, and that will not keepe any to that end. The ≈øouldiers dwell at lea≈øt ten or twelue in a hou≈øe, where they haue among them a ≈ølaue or hi
‚Ä¢ ed Indian or two which ≈øerueth them, and wa≈øheth their ≈øhirts, and haue foure or fiue ≈øtooles with a table, and euery man a Bedde. Their meate is Rice ≈øodden in water, with ≈øome ≈øalt fi≈øh, or ≈øome other thing of ≈ømall value (without breade) and cleare fountaine water for their drinke, wherewith they are well plea≈øed. They haue among≈øt them all one or two good ≈øutes of apparell, all of ≈øilke as the manner is there, and when one goeth abroad, the other ≈øtay at home, for in the hou≈øe they haue no n√©ede of clothes, (but ≈øit who≈øoeuer they bee) in their ≈øhirts & a paire of linnen br√©eches, and ≈øo as it were naked by rea≈øon of the great heate, for if ≈øome of them haue occa≈øion to goe out twenty times in one day, they mu≈øt ≈øo often lend him their apparel, and hee mu≈øt likewi≈øe put off his clothes, as often as he commeth home againe. Some ≈øouldiers haue a Gentleman or Captaine to their friendes which lendeth them monie to apparell them≈øelues withall, to the end when ≈øummer time commeth, they may be ready to goe with them in Fl√©et to ≈øea, as al≈øo to haue their friend≈øhip, by night and at other times to beare them company, or to helpe them to bee reuenged of any iniury by them receiued, as I ≈øaid before: for that he which in India hath mo≈øt ≈øouldiers to his friends, is mo≈øt regarded and feared. So that to bee ≈øhort, in this manner they doe maintaine them≈øelues in common, whereby they are able to come in pre≈øence of the be≈øt of the countrie. Manie and mo≈øt of them haue their chiefe maintenance from the Portingales and Me≈øticos wiues, as al≈øo the Indian Chri≈øtians wiues, which doe alwaies be≈øtow liberall rewardes and giftes vppon them to ≈øati≈øfie and fulfill their vncha≈øte and filthie de≈øires, which they know very well how to accompli≈øh, and ≈øecretly bring to pa≈ø≈øe. There are ≈øome likewi≈øe that get their liuings by their friends, trauelling for them from place to place with ≈øome wares and marchandi≈øes, and they are called Chattims. The≈øe doe giue ouer and leaue the office of a ≈øouldier in the Fl√©ete, and the Kinges ≈øeruice: for as it is ≈øaid, there is no man compelled thereunto, although their names be regi≈øtred in the office, yet doe they ≈øtill keepe the name of ≈øouldier, as long as they trauaile abroad and are not married. The ≈øouldiers in the≈øe dayes giue them≈øelues more to be Chattims, and to deale in Marchandi≈øe, then to ≈øerue the King in his Armado, becau≈øe the Captaines and Gentlemen begin to be ‚Ä¢ lacke in doing good vnto them, as in times pa≈øt they v≈øed to doe. Al≈øo they giue them≈øelues to re≈øt and plea≈øure: wherefore if they can deui≈øe any meanes for it, they had rather trauaile & deale in trade of Marchandi≈øe, and to marie and be quiet, in re≈øpect that the common ≈øouldiers in the≈øe dayes are but ≈ølackely paide: for that when they haue at the lea≈øt ten or twenty certificates to ≈øhew
for their former ≈øeruices, then haue they not the meanes to furni≈øh them≈øelues with proui≈øion to make a voyage into Portingale, or to take any pre≈øents with them there to be≈øtow them: for without ≈øuch meanes, they are neyther heard nor yet regarded, and if it fall out that they doe procure the reuer≈øion of any offices, it is ≈øo long before the time commeth that they doe enioy them, beeing many in reuer≈øion, that oftentimes they die before they can obtaine them. Againe the long trauaile and great voyage maketh many to ≈øtay in India, and to employ their time to other trades, as they can be≈øt prouide them≈øelues. By the≈øe meanes the wars in India are not ≈øo hot, nor ≈øo throughly looked into, neyther any other countries ≈øought into or founde out, as at fir≈øt they v≈øed to doe. Now they doe onely ≈øtriue to get prai≈øe and commendation, and to leaue a good report behinde them: and now likewi≈øe they are all giuen to ≈øcraping & catching, as well the Viceroy, Gouernours, and others, as al≈øo the Church men and ≈øpiritualtie, little pa≈ø≈øing or e≈øteeming the common profit or the ≈øeruice of the King, but only their particular profits, making their account, that the time of their abode is but thr√©e yeares: wherefore they ≈øay they will not doe otherwi≈øe then tho≈øe that were before them did, but ≈øay that others which come after theÃÑ ≈øhall take care for all: for that the King (≈øay they) gaue them their offices, thereby to pay them for their ≈øeruices in times pa≈øt, and not for the profit of the common wealth: therefore there is no more countries in India won or new found out, but rather heere and there ≈øome places lo≈øt, for they haue enough to doe, to hold that they haue alreadie, and to defende it from inua≈øion, as al≈øo that they doe ≈øcoure the Sea coa≈øtes, and yet many Marchants haue great lo≈ø≈øes euery yeare, by meanes of the ≈øea rouers, and together with the euill gouernment of the Portingales, and it is to be feared, it will bee wor≈øer euery day then other‚ñ™ as it is euidently ≈ø√©ene. This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the manners and cu≈øtomes of the Indian Portingales, and their warlike gouernments, which is commonly by ≈øea, for by land they cannot trauaile, by rea≈øon of the different kingdomes, and nations con≈øi≈øting of diuers ≈øeuerall ≈øortes of people, which are alwaies enemies, and neuer liue in peace, and ≈øome of them being friends, other enemies to the Portingales: for the Portingales haue only ≈øome Townes, places and fortre≈ø≈øes, with their Hauens on the ≈øea coa≈øt, without holding any thing within the land, as in the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt wee haue alreadie declared.

By the pictures hereafter following may be ≈ø√©ene the formes and portraitures of the Portingales that are maried, and of the ≈øouldiers in India, as they walke in the ≈øtreetes: as al≈øo howe they ride, not onely gentlemen, but euery man that hath the abilitie to keepe a hor≈øe, as well Marchantes as handicraftes men‚ñ™ of what ≈øort ≈øoeuer they bee, and howe they cau≈øe them≈øelues to bee carried in P ‚Ä¢ llamkins, in the ≈øtreetes and throughout the townes, when they will not ride nor goe on foote. You may likewi≈øe ≈ø√©e their fu≈øtes wherwith they go to warre vpon the water which the Malabares their enimies doe likewi≈øe v≈øe, (for they haue no other ≈øorts of ≈øcutes nor ≈øhippes,) and doe much mi≈øchiefe therewith: they are verie light, as well to ≈øaue as to row, they v≈øe them al≈øo for Marchandi≈øe, becau≈øe of the fitnes of the ≈øame, to pa≈ø≈øe from place to place.

div.head: The 31. Chapter Of the maner and cu≈øtomes of Portingale and Me≈øticos women in India.
div.p: THe Portingales, Me≈øticos, and Indian Chri≈øtian women in India, are little ≈ø√©ene abroad, but for the mo≈øt part ≈øit ≈øtill within the hou≈øe, and goe but ≈øeldome forth, vnle≈ø≈øe it be to Church‚ñ™ or to vi≈øit their friends, which is likewi≈øe but verie little, and when they goe abroad, they are well prouided not to be ≈øeene, for they are carried in a Pallamkin couered with a mat or other cloth, ≈øo that they cannot be ≈øeene.

When they goe to church, or to vi≈øit any friend, they put on very co≈øtly apparrell, with bracelets of gold, & rings vpon their armes, all be≈øet with co≈øtly Iewels & pearles, and at their eares hang laces full of Iewels. Their clothes are of Dama≈øke, Veluet, and cloth of gold, for ≈øilke is the wor≈øt thing they doe weare. Within the hou≈øe they goe bare headed, with a wa≈øtcoate called Baju, that from their ≈øhoulders couereth their nauels, and is ≈øo fine that you may ≈øee al their body through it, and downewards they haue nothing but a painted cloth wrapped three or foure times about their bodies. The≈øe clothes are very faire, ≈øome of them being very co≈øtly wrought with loome worke, and diuers figures and flowers of all colours, all the re≈øt of the body is naked without any ho≈øe, but onely bare footed in a paire of moyles or panto≈ø ‚Ä¢ es, and the men in like ≈øort. This is their manner in the hou≈øe both old, and young, rich, & poore, none excepted, for they goe forth but very little, and then they are both couered and carried,
and what they n√©ed abroad, that the ≈ølaues both men and women doe fetch in. The women eate no bread or very little, nor yet the ≈ølaues, not that they refu≈øe it for the dearenes or want of bread, (for they haue enough and great aboundance) but they are ≈øo v≈øed to eate rice, that they de≈øire no other, which they ≈øeeth with water and eate it with ≈øome ≈øalt fi≈øh, or a kinde of ≈øalt fruit called Mangas, or with ≈øome other compo≈øition both of fi≈øh and fle≈øh, with pottage which they powre vpon it, and ≈øo eate it with their handes: for there they eate nothing with ≈øpoones, and if they ≈øhould ≈ø√©e any man doe ≈øo, they would laugh at him. When they drinke they haue certaine pots made of blacke earth very fine and thin, much like tho≈øe that we v≈øe in Holland for flower pottes, hauing in the necke thereof a partition full of holes with a ≈øpout, (and the≈øe cru≈øes are called Gorgoletta,) to this end, that when they drinke, they may hold the potte on high, and touch it not with their mouthes, but the water running from the ≈øpout falleth into their mouthes, neuer ≈øpilling drop, which they doe for cleanline≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe no man ≈øhould put it to his mouth, & when any man commeth newly out of Portingall, and then beginneth to drinke after their manner, becau≈øe he is not v≈øed to that kinde of drinking, he ≈øpilleth it in his bo≈øome, wherein they take great plea≈øure and laugh at him calling him Reynol, which is a name giuen in ie≈øt to ≈øuch as newlie come from Portingall, & know not how to behaue them ≈øelues in ≈øuch graue manner, and with ≈øuch ceremonies as the Portingales v≈øe therein India: ≈øo that at the fir≈øt they are much whooped and cried at in the ≈øtr√©ets, vntill by v≈øe and practi≈øe they haue learned the Indian manner, which they quicklie doe. The men are very iealous of their wiues, for they will neuer bring any man into their hou≈øes, how ≈øpeciall a friend ≈øoeuer hee bee, that ≈øhall ≈ø√©e their wiues or their daughters, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee ≈øome go≈ø≈øip or any other married man with his wife in companie. When they will goe together to ≈øome place to ≈øport and ≈øolace theÃÑ ≈øelues, they are alwaies well garded by their ≈ølaues, both men and women both for their ≈øafety and ≈øeruice. If any man commeth to the doore to a≈øke for the ma≈øter of the hou≈øe, pre≈øently the wiues and their daughters run to hide them, and ≈øo leaue the man to an≈øwer him that ≈øtandeth at the dore: likewi≈øe they ≈øuffer no man to dwell within their hou≈øes, where the women and daughters bee, howe neere kin≈øman ≈øoeuer he be vnto them, being once 15. yeares of age, nor their owne ≈øons, but haue certaine chambers and places beneath, or be≈øides their hou≈øe where they lye, & may in no ≈øort come among the women, and thether they ≈øend them their meate and other proui≈øions, for it hath oftentimes b√©ene ≈ø√©ene in tho≈øe countries, that the vncles ≈øonne hath laine by his aunt, and the brother by the brothers wife, and the brother with his ≈øi≈øter: whereof I haue knowne ≈øome that haue bin taken with the manner, and that both they and the woman haue beene ≈ølaine by the hu≈øbands. The women are verie luxurious and vncha≈øte, for there are very few among them, although they bee married, but they haue be≈øides their hu≈øbands one or two of tho≈øe that are called ≈øouldiers, with whome they take their plea≈øures: which to effect, they v≈øe al the ≈ølights and practi≈øes they can deui≈øe, by ≈øending out their ≈ølaues and baudes by night, and at extraordinary times, ouer walles, hedges, and ditches, how narrowlie ≈øoeuer they are kept and looked vnto. They haue likewi≈øe an hearbe called Deutroa, which beareth a ≈ø√©ed, whereof bru≈øing out the ≈øap, they put it into a cup or other ve≈ø≈øell, and giue it to their hu≈øbands, eyther in meate or drinke, and pre≈øently therewith, the man is as though hee were halfe out of his wits, and without feeling, or els drunke, doing nothing but laugh, and ≈øometime it taketh him ≈øleeping, whereby he lieth like a dead man, ≈øo that in his pre≈øence they may doe what they will, and take their plea≈øure with their friends, and the hu≈øband neuer know of it. In which ≈øort he continueth foure and twentie houres long, but if they wa≈øh his f√©ete with colde water hee pre≈øently reuiueth, and knoweth nothing thereof, but thinketh he had ≈ølept.

Of the de≈øcription of this hearbe and fruit you may read in the Herballes, if any man receaueth or eateth but halfe a dramme of this feed, hee is for a time bereaued of his wits, & taken with an vnme≈øurable laughter.

The women are by nature verie cleanelie and neat, as well in their hou≈øes as in apparell, for that although all what≈øoeuer ≈øhe putteth on her bodie euery day, is both white, cleane and fre≈øh: yet they haue a manner euerie day to wa≈øh them≈øelues all the body ouer, from head to foote, and ≈øome times twy≈øe a day, in the morning and at euening: and as often as they ea≈øe them≈øelues or make water, or el≈øe v≈øe the companie of their hu≈øbands, euerie time they doe wa≈øh them≈øelues, were it a hundreth times a day and a night: they are no great workers, but much delighted in ≈øw√©et hearbs, and in perfumes and frankincen≈øe, and to rub their bodies and their foreheads with ≈øw√©et ≈øaÃÑde ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and ≈øuch like woods, which with water they doe ≈øt√©ep or breake in p√©eces: al≈øo the whole day long they d ‚Ä¢ e nothing, but ≈øit and chawe leaues or hearbes, called B ‚Ä¢ ttele, with chalke and a certaine fruite called Arrequa, whereof in an other place among fruites and hearbs I wil ≈øpeake more. This Arrequa, ≈øome of it is ≈øo ≈øtrong, that it maketh men almo≈øt drunke, & wholly out of ≈øen≈øe, although in ≈øhewe and in ta≈øte it is almo≈øt like wood or rootes: the≈øe 3 thinges they ≈øit all the whole day chawing in their mouthes, like oxen or kyne chawing the cud: they let the ≈øap goe down into their throats, and ≈øpit the re≈øt out of their mouthes, whereby they make their mouthes ≈øo red and blacki≈øh, that to ≈øuch as know it not it is ≈øtraÃÑge to ≈ø√©e: all which, with their wa≈øhing, frankin≈øcence, and rubing with ≈ø ‚Ä¢ nders, they haue learned & receiued of the Indian Heathens, which haue had tho≈øe cu≈øtomes of long time, and yet till this day v≈øe them: they ≈øay it pr ‚Ä¢

div.p: And they are not content therewith, but giue their hu≈øbandes a thou≈øand hearbs for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, to ea ‚Ä¢ e, they not knowing thereof, thereby to fulfill their plea≈øu ‚Ä¢ es, and to ≈øati≈øfie their de≈øires, which can not by any meanes be ≈øati≈øfied. This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for their women now I will proceed to other matters. And the better to vnder≈øtand the ≈øhapes and formes of their women, together with their apparell, you may behold it here, when they goe to Church and els where, both wiues, maids and widdows,

≈øtr√©et, with their women ≈ølaues round about them: al≈øo with their hu≈øbands and ≈ølaues by night, going to anie ≈øport, or els to Church, which they v≈øe after ye maÃÑner of pilgrimes, for theÃÑ thereof, becau≈øe they doe neuer go abroad, but only at ≈øuch times, or to Church on fe≈øtiuall dayes behind their Pallamkins, vpoÃÑ the which dayes they aduerti≈øe their louers, and leaue their and will ≈øteale both from ma≈øter & mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe to giue them, with the which manie Soldiers doe better maintaine them≈øelues, then with the kinges pay: and if it chaunceth that the≈øe ≈ølaui≈øh women be with child, they are their mai≈øters children, who are therwith very wel content, for ≈øo they are their captiues, but if the father be a Portingale, or ≈øome other fr√©e man, when the childe the mother: but if he ≈øtay aboue 8 or 10 dayes, and within that time no man cometh to challenge it, although it be a free mans child, and he after that ≈øhall come to a≈øke it, then it is the mothers The nur≈øing and bringing vp of the Portingales Me≈øticos children is, that from the time of their birth they are kept naked onely with a little ≈øhort ≈øhyrt (like the womens Bain, which they weare about their bodies,) and nothing el≈øe, till they be of yeares to weare breches, or other clothes. div.head: The 32. Chapter. Of the Viceroy of Portingall, and of his gouernment in India.
div.p:
EVerie 3. yeares there is a new Viceroy ≈øent into India, and ≈øome time they ≈øtay longer, as it plea≈øeth the King, but verie few of them, hee continueth in Goa (which is the chiefe Cittie of India) where he hath his hou≈øe and continuall re≈øidence, and from thence all other townes in India: haue their direction and gouernment. From Goa euerie yeare the Portingall armie is prepared and ≈øent out, as I ≈øaid before, he hath his coun≈øell, Nobles, Chancerie, and Iu≈øtices, as they v≈øe in Portingall, and all lawes and Iu≈øtice, are by him executed and fulfilled in the Kings nam ‚Ä¢ , yet if there be any matter of importante, which concerneth the Ciuill lawes, they may appeale to Portingall, but in criminall cau≈øes no man may appeale, but ≈øuch as haue the degr√©e of a Gentleman, ≈øuch the Viceroy may not iudge, but being pri≈øoners, ≈øend them into Portingall, vnle≈ø≈øe it be by the Kings commaundement, he is verie magnificent in his e≈øtate, and goeth little out, but ≈øometimes on Sundaies, or holy daies, when hee goeth to Church, and when hee goeth out of his hou≈øe, the Trumpets and Shalmes, ≈øtanding in the Gallerie of his hou≈øe do ≈øound, he is accompanied by all the Gentlemen and townes men of Goa, that haue or k√©epe hor≈øes, with a Ga ‚Ä¢ de of Halbardiers on foote, both on each ≈øide and behinde him, and being in the Church, he ‚Ä¢ hath his ≈øeate in the Quier, lyned with Veluet, and nayled with gylt nayles, and a cloth with two Veluet cu≈øhins, vnder his f√©ete and kn√©es, and before him a bench, with a Veluet Cu≈øhen to leane his armes vpon, his Gentlemen ≈øit by him, but without the Quier, and by him ≈øtandeth his Chaplen, that prayeth for him. The Archbi≈øhop (when hee is at the Church) ≈øitteth on his left hand, in
the ≈øame manner, vpon Carpets, Cu≈øhens, and bench of Veluet, where they are ≈øerued in all ceremonial order, as the Kings of Portingall in their Churches v≈øe to be, and when he commeth home againe, the Trumpets and Shalmes doe ≈øound, as when he went out. In the hall of his Palace ≈øtand the Gard, and in the great hall, where his Councell ≈øit, are painted all the Viceroyes, that haue gouerned in India, ≈øince the fir≈øt di≈øcouery and conque≈øt thereof, and as they new come, their pictures are likewi≈øe placed there. Al≈øo in the entrie of the Palace are painted al the ≈øhips, that ≈øince the fir≈øt di≈øcouerie of India, euer came out of Portingall into tho≈øe countries, euery yeare by it ≈øelfe, and the names and ≈øurnames of their Captaines, with a note ouer euerie ≈øhippe which was ca≈øt away, or had any mi≈øchaunce, all liuely ≈øet foorth, for a perpetuall memorie, and euerie yeare as any ≈øhip commeth thether, they are ≈øet by the re≈øt.

The Viceroyes in the la≈øt yeare of their gouernment, do v≈øe to vi≈øite the Forts lying round about the countrie, fiftie, ≈øixtie, or eightie miles long, on the North and South ≈øide of Goa, to ≈øee how they are gouerned, they looke well vnto them, but commonly an other ≈øupplyeth their place, and if they doe it them≈øelues, it is more to fill their pur≈øes, and to get pre≈øents, then to further the commonwealth, the≈øe Viceroyes haue great reuenewes, they may ≈øpend, giue, and k√©epe the Kings trea≈øure, which is verie much, and doe with it what plea≈øeth them, for it is in their choy≈øe, hauing full and ab≈øolute power from the King, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that they gather and horde vp a mightie quantitie of trea≈øure, for that be≈øides their great alowance from the King, they haue great pre≈øents & giftes, be≈øtowed vpon them. For it is the cu≈øtome in tho≈øe countries, when any Viceroy commeth newly ouer, that all the Kings bordering about Goa, and that haue peace and friend≈øhip with the Portingales, do then ≈øend their Amba≈ø≈øadours vnto him, to confirme their leagues with great and rich pre≈øents, therewith likewi≈øe to bid the Viceroy welcome, which amounteth to a great ma≈ø≈øe of trea≈øure: the≈øe pre≈øents in this ≈øort giuen, the Ie≈øuites by their practi≈øes had obtained of the King, and for a time enioyed them at their plea≈øure (looking verie narrowly vnto them, that they might not bee deceiued) vntill long time ≈øince, a Viceroy named Don lois de T ‚Ä¢ ide Earle of Atougia came thether, and refu≈øed to let them haue them, ≈øaying that the King being in Portingall knew not what was giuen him in India, and that tho≈øe pre≈øents were giuen vnto the Viceroy and not to the King, and ≈øaid the King had no power to giue them to the Ie≈øuites: ≈øo that hee kept them for him≈øelfe, which the Ie≈øuites tooke in euill part‚ñ™ and ≈øaid, the Viceroy was an hereticke. Yet from his time euer ≈øince, the Viceroyes haue v≈øed to keepe them for them ≈øelues. When the Viceroyes haue continued out their time, which is a≈ø≈øone as an other Viceroy ariueth at Bardes, or any other Hauen in the countrie, they doe pre≈øently di≈øpatch their Leiuetenants‚ñ™ with full power and authoritie in the name of their mai≈øters, to receiue po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the gouernment of India, and prepare the Palace for him, ≈øo that there ≈øtayeth not a ≈øtoole or bench within the hou≈øe‚ñ™ nor one pennie in the trea≈øure, but they leaue the hou≈øe as bare and naked as po≈ø≈øible may be, ≈øo that the new Viceroy mu≈øt make proui≈øion for to furni≈øh it, and gather a new trea≈øure. In the ≈øame ≈øhippe wherein the new Viceroy commeth thether, the old returneth home, and becau≈øe their time of gouernment is ≈øo ≈øhort, and that the place is giuen them in recompence of their ≈øeruice, and thereafter not to ≈øerue any more, there is not one of them, that e≈øteemeth the profit of the commonwealth, or the furtherance of the Kings ≈øeruice, but rather their own particular commodities, as you may verie well thinke, ≈øo that the common ≈øpeach in India is, that they neuer looke for any profite or furtheraunce of the common wealth by any Viceroy, as long as the gouernment of thr√©e yeares, is not altered. For they ≈øay, and it is found to be mo≈øt true, that the fir≈øt yeare of the Viceroyes time, hee hath enough to doe to repaire and furni≈øh his hou≈øe, and to know the manners and cu≈øtomes of the countries, without any further troubling of him≈øelfe. The ≈øeconde yeare to gather trea≈øure, and to looke vnto his particular profits, for the which cau≈øe he came into India. The third and la≈øt yeare to prepare him≈øelfe and ≈øet al things in order, that he bee not ouertaken or ≈øurpri≈øed by the new Viceroy when he commeth, but that he may returne into Portingall with the goods which he had ≈øcraped together. The ≈øame is to bee vnder≈øtoode of all the Captaines in the Fortes, and of all other officers in India. Wherefore it is to bee con≈øidered, how they v≈øe them≈øelues in their places and the Kings ≈øeruice, whereof the inhabitants and married Portingales doe continually ≈øpeake, but they are farre from the Kings hearing, who knoweth not, but that his Officers doe him good ≈øeruice, whereby there is ≈ømall remedie or amendement to be hoped for.

div.head: The 33. Chapter. Of the heathens, Indians and other ≈øtrangers dwelling in Goa.
div.p:
IN the towne and Iland of Goa, are re≈øident many Heathens, Moores (which are Mahometans) Iewes, and all ≈øtrange nations bordering thereabout, euerie one of them v≈øing ≈øeuerall cu≈øtomes, and ≈øuper≈øtitions in Religion. The Moores hold Mahomets law, and the Iewes Moy≈øes law. There are al≈øo many Per≈øians, Arabians, and Abexij ‚Ä¢ s, ≈øome of them Chri≈øtians, and ≈øome of them Moores. There is in Goa many Armenians that are Chri≈øtians, and others that goe and come to traffique there, as Per≈øians, Arabians, Banianes, of Cambaia, Gu≈øarates, and Decani ‚Ä¢ ns &c. The Moores eate all things except Swines fle≈øh, and dying are buried like the Iewes, but the Heathens, as Decani ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, Gu≈øarates, and Canaras, and other Indians being dead, are burnt to a≈øhes, and ≈øome women being aliue are burned with them, that is ≈øuch as are Gentlemen or Noblemen, and the wiues of the Bramenes, which are their Idolatrous Pr√©e≈øtes. Al≈øo for the Marchantes ≈øome of them eate all things, except Cowes or Buffles fle≈øh, which they e≈øteeme to be holy Others eate not any thing what≈øoeuer, that hath either life or bloud in it, as tho≈øe of Gu≈øarata, and the Banianes of Cambaia, which ob≈øerue Pythagoras lawe: mo≈øt of them pray vnto the Sunne and Moone, yet they doe all acknowledge a God that made, created and ruleth all things, and that after this life there is an other, wherein men ≈øhall be rewarded according to their workes. But they haue Idoles and Images, which they call Pagodes, cut and formed mo≈øt vgly, and like mon≈øtrous Deuils, to whome dayly they offer, and ≈øay, that tho≈øe holy men haue b√©ene liuing among them, whereof they tell ≈øo many miracles, as it is wonderfull, and ≈øay that they are interce≈ø≈øors betw√©ene them and God. The Deuill often times an≈øwereth them out of tho≈øe Images, whome they likewi≈øe know, and doe him great honour by offering vnto him, to keepe friend≈øhippe with him, and that hee ≈øhould not hurt them. They haue a cu≈øtome, when any maide is to bee married, and that they will honour their Pagode, for the more credite to the Bridegrome, they bring the Bride with great triumph and Mu≈øicke before their Pagode, which is made with a Pinne of Iuorie bone, to whome the neere≈øt friends and kin≈øwomen of the Bride, together with the Bride doe goe, and by force make the Image to take the Brides maydenhead, ≈øo that the bloud remaineth ≈øtill vpon the Image, for a remembrance thereof, and then after other deueli≈øh ≈øuper≈øtitions and ceremonies, hauing made their offrings, they bring the Bride home, where ≈øhe is deliuered to the Bridgrome, he being verie ioyfull and proud, that their Pagode hath honored him ≈øo much and ea≈øed him of ≈øo much labour. They haue for the mo≈øt part a cu≈øtome to pray vnto the fir≈øt thing they m√©ete withal in the morning, and all that day after they pray vnto it, be it Hogge, or any other thing‚ñ™ And if in the morning when they goe out, they chaunce at the fir≈øt ≈øight to ≈ø√©e a Crow, (whereof there are great numbers in India) they will not goe forth of their doores all that day, no not for all the goods in the world, for they e≈øt√©eme it an euill ≈øigne, and an vnluckie day. They pray likewi≈øe to the new Moone, and when ≈øhee fir≈øt appeareth, they fall vppon their kn√©es, and ≈øalute her with great deuotion, there are among them certaine people called Iogos, which are ≈øuch as we call Hermits, and tho≈øe doe they e≈øt√©eme for holy men, the≈øe men liue a verie ≈øtrict life with great ab≈øtinence, and make the common people belieue many ≈øtrange things. They haue likewi≈øe many South≈øayers and Witches, which v≈øe Iugling, and trauell throughout the countrie, hauing about them many liue Snakes, which they know how to bewitch, and being ≈øhut vp in little ba≈økets, they pull them out and make them daunce, turne, and winde at the ≈øound of a certaine In≈øtrument, wheron they play, and ≈øpeake vnto them. They winde them about their neckes, armes, and legges, ki≈ø≈øing them, with a thou≈øand other deui≈øes, onely to get money. They are al for the mo≈øt part verie ≈økilfull in preparing of poy≈øons, wherewith they doe many ≈øtrange things, and ea≈øily poy≈øon each other, their dwellings and hou≈øes are verie little and lowe, couered with ≈øtraw, without windowes, and verie low and narrow doores, ≈øo that a man mu≈øt almo≈øt cr√©epe vpon his kn√©es to goe in, their hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe is Mats of ≈øtraw, both to ≈øit and lie vpon, their Tables, Table-clothes, and Napkins, are made of the great Indian Figge leaues, they ≈øerue them not onely for Tables, Sh√©etes, and other linnen, but al≈øo for Di≈øhes, wherein they put their meate, which you ≈øhall likewi≈øe ≈ø√©e in the Grocers, and Pothecaries ≈øhops, to put and wrap in all things what≈øoeuer they haue within their ≈øhops, (as we doe in paper.) They likewi≈øe ioyne them together in ≈øuch ≈øort, that they can put both butter, oyle, & ≈øuch liquid ≈øtuffes
therein‚ñ™ and al≈øo what≈øoeuer coÃÑmeth to hand. To dre≈ø≈øe their meat they haue certaine earthen pots wherein they ≈ø√©eth Rice, and make holes in the ground, wherein they ≈øtampe it, or beate it with a woodden pe≈øtel made for the purpo≈øe, and they are ≈øo mi≈øerable, that they buy the Rice in the Hu≈økes, as it groweth on the grounde, and ≈øome of them haue Rice ≈øowen behinde their hou≈øe to ≈øerue their nece≈ø≈øarie v≈øe. They v≈øe to drinke out of a copper Canne with a ≈øpout, wherby they let the water fall downe into their mouths, and neuer touch the pot with their lippes. Their hou≈øes are commonly ≈øtrawed with Cowe dung, which (they ≈øay) killeth Fleas. They are verie cleane on their bodies, for euery day they wa≈øh them≈øelues all their body ouer, as often as they ea≈øe them≈øelues or make water, both men and women, like the Moores or Mahometans. They wa≈øh them≈øelues with the left hand, becau≈øe they eate with the right hand, and v≈øe no ≈øpoones. They doe k√©epe and ob≈øerue their ceremonies and ≈øuper≈øtitions, with great deuotion, for they neuer goe forth without praying, when they trauaile by the way. They haue on euery hill, cliffe, hole, or denne their Pagodes and Idols in mo≈øt diuili≈øh and deformed ≈øhapes, cut and hewed out of the ≈øtones and rockes, with their furni≈øes hard by them, and a ce≈øterne not farre from them, which is alwaies full of water, and euery one that pa≈ø≈øeth by, wa≈øheth their f√©ete therein, and ≈øo fall downe before their Idoll, ≈øome ≈øetting before him for an offering fruits, Rice, Egges, Hennes, &c. as their deuotions ≈øerue, & then commeth the Bramenes their Prie≈øt and taketh it away and eateth it, making the common people bel√©eue that the Pagode hath eaten it.

When they will make a voyage to Sea, they v≈øe at the lea≈øt fourt√©ene dayes before they enter into their ≈øhips, to make ≈øo great a noy≈øe with ≈øounding of Trumpets, and to make fiers, that it may be heard and ≈øeene both by night and day, the ≈øhip being hanged about with flagges, wherewith (they ≈øay) they fea≈øt their Pagode, that they may haue a good Voyage. The like doe they at their returne for a thanke≈øgiuing fourt√©ene dayes long, and thus they v≈øe to doe in all their fea≈øtes, affaires, mariages, childbirths, and at other times of the yeare, as ≈øowing, and mowing, &c.

The heatheni≈øh Indians that dwell in Goa are verie rich Marchants, and traffique much, there is one ≈øtr√©ete within the towne, that is full of ≈øhops kept by tho≈øe Heatheni≈øh Indians, that not onely ≈øell all kindes of Silkes, Sattins, Dama≈økes, and curious workes of Por≈øelyne from China and other places, but all manner of wares of ve ‚Ä¢
uet, Silke, Sattin and ≈øuch like, brought out of Portingall, which by meanes of their Brokers they buy by the great, and ≈øell them againe by the p√©ece or elles, wherein they are verie cunning, and naturally ≈øubtill. There are in the ≈øame ≈øte√©et on the other ≈øide, that haue all kindes of linnen, and ≈øhirts, with other clothes ready made for all ≈øortes of per≈øons, as well ≈ølaues as Portingales, and of all other linnen worke that may bee de≈øired. There are Heathens that ≈øell all kindes of womens clothes, and ≈øuch like wares, with a thou≈øand ≈øorts of clothes and cottons, which are like Canuas for ≈øayles and ≈øackes. There is al≈øo another ≈øtreet where the Benianes of Cambaia dwell, that haue all kinds of wares out of Cambaia, and all ≈øortes of precious ≈øtones, and are verie ≈øubtill and cunning to bore and make holes in all kinds of ≈øtones, pearles, and corrals, on the other ≈øide of the ≈øame ≈øtreet dwell other heathens, which ≈øell all ≈øortes of bed≈øt√©edes, ≈øtooles, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe, very cunningly couered ouer with Lacke, mo≈øt plea≈øant to behold, and they can turne the Lacke into any colour that you wil de≈øire. There is al≈øo a ≈øtr√©et full of gold and Siluer Smithes that are Heathens, which make all kinde of workes, al≈øo diuers other handicrafts men, as Copper≈ømithes, Carpenters, and ≈øuch like occupations, which are all heathens, and euery one a ≈øtr√©et by them≈øelues. There are likewi≈øe other Marchantes that deale all by great, with Corne, Rice, and other Indian wares and Marchandi≈øes, as wood and ≈øuch like. Some of them farme the kinges rents and reuenewes, ≈øo that they are ≈økilfull euery way to make their profites. There are al≈øo many Heathen Brokers, very cunning and ≈øubtill in buying and ≈øelling, and with their tongues to pleade on both ≈øides.

The Heathens haue likewi≈øe their ≈øhops with all kinde of ≈øpices, which they ≈øell by retaile, both by waight and mea≈øure, as Grocers and Potticaries doe with vs, and this is onely v≈øed among them. They haue likewi≈øe of al ≈øorts of wares what≈øoeuer, but yet with le≈ø≈øe curio≈øitie then with vs, for it is mingled with du≈øt and garbi≈øh. The≈øe are commonlie the Brainenes, which ≈øerue likewi≈øe for Prie≈øtes and Idolatrous Mini≈øters, & haue their ≈øhops throughout the Cittie. In euerie place and corner, and vnder penti≈øes, whereby euery man may haue to ≈øerue him at his n√©ed.

There are likewi≈øe many barbers, which in euery end of the ≈øtreetes doe call to tho≈øe that haue cau≈øe to v≈øe them. They k√©epe no ≈øhoppes, but for a ≈ømall peece of money come
