In the Month of September when winter endeth, the bankes of ≈øand doe fl√©ete and vade away out of the Riuer, ≈øo that not onely ≈ømal ≈øhippes may come in and go out, but al≈øo the great Portingall ≈øhips of 1600. tunnes may fr√©ely enter without a Pilot, for it is d√©epe enough and without daunger. In winter it is a heauie and melancholike being there, for there is no other exerci≈øe to be v≈øed, but onely to ≈øitte in their ≈øhirtes, with a paire of lin ‚Ä¢ en br√©eches, and goe & pa≈ø≈øe the time away with their neighbours, in playing and ≈øuch exerci≈øes, for that throughout the whole town there is no other doing. The women and Me≈øticos take great plea≈øure in the winter time when it rayneth, with their hu≈øbandes and ≈ølaues to go into the fieldes, or ≈øome garden, whether they carry good ≈øtore of victuailes, & there in their gardens haue many Ce≈øternes or pondes of water, wherein they take their delightes to ≈øwimme and to bath them≈øelues. In this time mo≈øt of their Indian fruit is in ≈øea≈øon. The ≈øummer beginneth in September, and continueth till the la≈øt of Aprill, and is alwaies clear sky & fair weather, without once or very little raining: Then all the ≈øhips are rigged and made ready to ≈øaile for all places, as al≈øo the Kinges armie to k√©epe the coa≈øt, and to conuoy Marchantes, and then the Ea≈øt winds beginne to blow from off the lande into the ≈øeas, whereby they are called Terreinhos, that is to ≈øay, the land windes. They blow very plea≈øantly & coolly, although at the fir≈øt by chaunging of the weather they are very dangerous, & cau≈øe many great di≈øea≈øes, which do commonly fall in India, by ye chaunging of the time. The≈øe winds blow alwaies in ≈øummer, beginning at midnight, and continue till noone, but they neuer blowe aboue tenne miles into the ≈øea, from off the coa≈øt, and pre≈øently after one of the clocke vntill midnight the we≈øt winde bloweth, which commeth out of the ≈øea into the lande, and is called V ‚Ä¢ ra≈øon. The≈øe winds are ≈øo ≈øure and certaine at their times, as though men helde them in their handes, whereby they make the land very temperate, otherwi≈øe the heate would bee vnmea≈øurable. It is likewi≈øe a ≈øtrange thing that when it is winter vpon the coa≈øt of India, that is from Di ‚Ä¢
to the Cape de Comorin, on the other ≈øide of the Cape de Comorin on the coa≈øt called Choramandel, it is cleane contrarie, ≈øo that there it is ≈øummer, and yet they lye all vnder one height or degr√©es, and there is but 70. miles by land betw√©ene both the coa≈øts, and in ≈øome places but 2 ‚Ä¢ . miles, and which is more, as men trauel ouer land from Cochin to S. Thomas (which lyeth on the ≈øame coa≈øt of Choramandel) and comming by the hill of Ballagatte where men mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe ouer to goe from the one coa≈øt vnto the other: on the one ≈øide of the hil to the top thereof it is plea≈øant clear ≈øunne ≈øhining weather, and going downe on the other ≈øide there is rayne, winde, thunder and lightning, as if the worlde ≈øhould end and be con≈øumed: which is to be vnder≈øtood, that it chaungeth from the one ≈øide to the other, as the time falleth out, ≈øo that on the one ≈øide of the hilles it is Winter, and on the other ≈øide Summer: and it is not onely ≈øo in that place and countrey, but al≈øo at Ormus, on the coa≈øt of Arabia Felix by the Cape of Ro≈øalgatte, where the ≈øhippes lie: it is very ≈øtill, cleare, and plea≈øant water, and faire ≈øummer time, and turning about the Cape on the other ≈øide, it is raine and wind with great ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts, which with the times of the yeare doe likewi≈øe change on the other ≈øide, and ≈øo it is in many places of the Orientall countries.

The ≈øickne≈ø≈øes and di≈øea≈øes in Goa, and throughout India, which are common, come mo≈øt with the changing of the times and the weather, as it is ≈øaid before: there raigneth a ≈øickne≈ø≈øe called Mordexim, which ≈øtealeth vppon men, and handleth them in ≈øuch ≈øorte, that it weakeneth a man, and maketh him ca≈øt out all that he hath in his bodie, and many times his life withall. This ≈øickne≈ø≈øe is very common, & killeth many a man, whereof they hardly or neuer e≈øcape. The bloody Flixe is there likewi≈øe very common and daungerous, as the plague with vs. They haue many continuall feuers, which are burning agues, and con≈øume mens bodies with extreame heate, whereby within foure or fiue dayes they are eyther whole or dead. This ≈øicknes is common and very daungerous, & hath no remedie for the Portingalles but letting of blood: but the Indians and heathens do cure them≈øelues with hearbes, Sanders, and other ≈øuch like oyntments, wherewith they ea≈øe them≈øelues. This ≈øicknes con≈øumeth many Portingalles euery yeare, ≈øome becau≈øe they haue little to eat, & le≈ø≈øe to drink of any meat or drink that is nouri≈øhing, & v≈øe much company of womeÃÑ, becau≈øe ye land is naturall to prouoke theÃÑ thervnto, as al≈øo ye mo≈øt part of the ≈øoldiers by ≈øuch means haue their liuing and their maintenance, which often times co≈øteth them both life and limme, for although men were of iron or ≈øteele, the vncha≈øte life of a woman, with her vn≈øatiable lu≈øtes were able to grinde him to powder, and ≈øw√©ep him away like du≈øt, which co≈øteth many a mans life, as the Kinges Ho≈øpitall can wel beare witnes, wherein they lodge, when≈øoeuer they are ≈øicke, where euery yeare at the lea≈øt there entered 500. liue men, and neuer
come forth till they are dead, and they are only Portingals for no other ≈øick per≈øon may lodge therin, I mean ≈øuch as are called white men, for the other Indians haue an Ho≈øpitall by them≈øelues. In this Ho≈øpitall they are verie well looked vnto by Ie≈øuites, and Gentlemen: whereof euery month one of the be≈øt is cho≈øen and appointed, who per≈øonally is there by them‚ñ™ and giueth the ≈øicke per≈øons what≈øoeuer they will de≈øire, and ≈øometimes ≈øpend more by foure or fiue hundred Duckats of their owne pur≈øes, then the Kings allowance reacheth vnto, which they doe more of pride and vaine glorie, then for compa≈ø≈øion, onely to haue the prai≈øe and commendation of liberalitie. It is no ≈øhame there to lie in the Ho≈øpitall, for many men go thether willingly, although they haue wherewith to keepe them≈øelues in their hou≈øes, and haue both wife and children. The≈øe Ho≈øpitals in India are very nece≈ø≈øarie for the Portingals, otherwi≈øe they ≈øhold con≈øume away like mi≈øerable men, but by ye means they are relieued, what≈øoeuer they haue, eyther ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, wounds, ≈øecrete di≈øea≈øes, pockes, piles, or any ≈øuch like, there they are healed, and ≈øometimes vi≈øited by the Viceroy him≈øelfe, when he thinketh vpon them, and that his commodities come in. He that wil not lie there, and hath any woundes‚ñ™ or priuie di≈øea≈øes, may come thether twice euery day and be dre≈øt, & goe his way againe without any que≈øtion or deniall. When they die therein, they are by two ≈ølaues carried into the Church yarde, without eyther ≈øinging or ringing, onely one man followeth after them, & throweth ≈øome holy water vppon the graue: but if the ≈øicke man chanceth to leaue any goods behind him, and ≈øpeaketh vnto the Prie≈øtes to bring him to his graue, and to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øes for his ≈øoule, then they runne thither by heapes, and burie him like a man of countenance eyther in the Church or chauncell, according to his will, and then hath hee ≈øinging and ringing enough.

But returning to our matter of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, pock ‚Ä¢ s and piles, with other ≈øecret di≈øea≈øes, they are in tho≈øe countries verie common & not hidden or concealed, for they thinke it no ≈øhame, more then to haue any other di≈øea≈øe. They heale them with the roote China: there are ≈øome that haue had them at the lea≈øt thr√©e or foure times, and are not any thing at all ≈øhunned or di≈øliked for the ≈øame, but dare both boa≈øt and bragge thereof. It is not any thing perillous for the bodie, in≈øomuch that they had rather haue them, and feare them le≈ø≈øe then any of the fore≈øaid di≈øea≈øes. The plague hath neuer b√©en in India, neither is it known vnto the Indians, but poy≈øoning, witchcraft, & ≈øuch like, whereby ≈øome lo≈øe their healthes, and ≈øome their liues, is their dayly exerci≈øe, and very common with them. The ≈øtone grauel, and rupture raigneth much among them, ≈øpecially among married men, by rea≈øon of the great quantitie of water that they drinke being giuen to all plea≈øure and riotou≈ønes, enioying all what their hearts de≈øire, ≈øitting alwayes with their bellies open in their ≈øhirtes in a gallerie, recreating them≈øelues with the wind which cooleth them, ≈øometimes hauing a ≈ølaue to ≈øcratch and pare their nayles and f√©ete, another the head, the third holds a Fan to driue away the fl√©es. Their is the common v≈øe for two houres after noone, where likewi≈øe they take an afternoones ≈øl√©epe, and euer as they haue thir≈øt, they bring him a di≈øh of con≈øerues, or other comfets, that the water ≈øhoulde not worke too much in his bodie, but ta≈øte the better. With ≈øuch and the like exerci≈øes they do pa≈ø≈øe the day til night comes on, ≈øo that commonly they haue all ≈øwollen bellies like Bacchus, whereby the ≈øoldiers and other Indians call them Barrigois, that is, bellies, or great bellies.

The day both Summer and Winter is there all of a length, not much difference, onely in the chaunge they haue about an houres difference. The ≈øunne ri≈øeth at ≈øixe, and ≈øetteth at ≈øixe. When it is noone, commonly they haue the Sunne in the middle of the element iu≈øt ouer their heades, and it giueth no ≈øhadowe, although it ≈øtretcheth ≈øomewhat out as the Sunne taketh his cour≈øe. In Goa you may ≈ø√©e both the Poles of the world, the North and South ≈øtarres ≈øtande not farre aboue the Horizon. And this ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the times and ≈øea≈øons of the yeare, ≈øickne≈ø≈øes and other di≈øea≈øes in India, as breuitie requireth.

div.head: The 35. Chapter. Of the money, waight, and mea≈øure of India, and Goa.
div.p:
THe principall and commone≈øt money is called Pardaus Xeraphiins, and is ≈øiluer, but very bra≈ø≈øe, and is coyned in Goa. They haue Saint Seba≈øtian on the one ≈øide, and thr√©e or foure arrowes in a bundle on the other ≈øide, which is as much as thr√©e Te≈øtones, or thr√©e hundred Reijs Portingall money, and ri≈øeth and falleth little
le≈ø≈øe or more, according to the exchange. There is al≈øo a kinde of reckoning of money which is called Tangas, not that there is any ≈øuch coined, but are ≈øo named onely in telling, fiue Tangas is one Pardaw, or Xeraphin badde money, for you mu≈øt vnder≈øtande that in telling they haue two kinds of money good and badde, for foure Tangas good money are as much as fiue Tangas bad money. Wherfore when they buy and ≈øell, they bargaine for good or badde money. There is likewi≈øe a reckoning of Vintiins, which is not likewi≈øe in coyne, but onely named in telling: of the≈øe foure good, and fiue badde doe make a Tangas. The lowe≈øt and ≈ømalle≈øt money is called Bazaruco, the≈øe are fift√©ene badde, and eight√©ene good to a Vintiin, and three Bazarucos are as much as two Rei ‚Ä¢ s Portingal money: It is molten money of badde Tinne, ≈øo that 375. Bazarucos are one Pardaw or Xeraphiin. There is al≈øo a kinde of money out of Per≈øia, called Lariins, which are long, very good and fine ≈øiluer, without any allay. The≈øe are worth 105. and 108. Bazarucos, as the exchaunge goeth, little more or le≈ø≈øe. They haue a kind of money called Pagodes, which is of Gold, of two or three ≈øortes, and are aboue eight Tangas in value. They are Indian and Heatheni≈øh money, with the picture of a Diuell vpon them and therefore are called Pagodes. There is another kinde of gold money, which is called Venetianders: ≈øome of Venice, and ≈øome of Turki≈øh coine, and are commonly 2. Pardawes Xeraphins. There is yet another kind of golde called S. Thomas, becau≈øe Saint Thomas is figured theron, & is worth about 7. & eight Tangas: There are likewi≈øe Rialles of 8. which are brought from Portingal, and are called Pa ‚Ä¢
dawes de Reales: Other money of Portingall is not currant there. They are worth at their fir≈øt comming out of Portingall 436. Reyes of Portingall, and after are ray≈øed by exchaunge, as they are ≈øought for when men trauell for China, but they are worth neither more nor le≈ø≈øe. They v≈øe in Goa in their buying and ≈øelling a certaine maner of reckoning or telling. There are Pardawes Xeraphins, and the≈øe are ≈øiluer. They name likewi≈øe Pardawes of Gold, and tho≈øe are not in kinde or in coyne, but onely ≈øo named in telling and reckoning: for when they buy and ≈øell Pearles, ≈øtones, golde, ≈øiluer and hor≈øes, they name but ≈øo many Pardawes, and then you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that one Pardaw is ≈øixe Tangas: but in other ware, when you make not your bargaine before hand, but plainely name Pardawes, they are Pardawes Xeraphins of 5. Tangas the p√©ece. They v≈øe al≈øo to ≈øay a Pardaw of Lariin ‚Ä¢ , and are fiue Lariins, for euery Pardaw ‚ñ™ This is the money and reckoning of Goa, wherewith they buy, ≈øell, receiue, and pay. Many of them know wel how to gaine by the≈øe kinds of moneys, by exchanging, buying and ≈øelling of them. There is great fal≈øhoode in the Pardawes Xeraphins, which is the principalle≈øt and currante≈øt money: wherefore there are in euery ≈øtr√©ete and corner of the Cittie, Iewes that are Chri≈øtians, called Xaraffes, who for verie ≈ømall profit looke vppon the moneyes, & are ≈øo perfect therein, that as they let the money pa≈ø≈øe through their handes in telling, they knowe the fal≈øe peeces without once looking vpon them, or taking them vp: yea although it lay among a thou≈øande peeces: and if another ≈øhould take it in their handes and tell it a thou≈øande times, yet coulde they neuer perceiue it, but in ringing it, a man may know it very well. The≈øe are coyned in the firme lande by the Heatheni≈øh Indians, to deceyue the Portingalles withall, wherefore no man dares receiue money, were it but halfe a Pardaw, except he ≈øhew it to tho≈øe Xaraffes. They tell money very readily and ≈øwiftly, and telling it do looke vpon it to ≈ø√©e if it be good, and do giue their promi≈øe that if it be found too ≈øhort, or any fal≈øe money therein after they haue tolde it, they will make it good howe much ≈øoeuer it be. They are al≈øo very ready to exchange money, or to doe what≈øoeuer men n√©ede touching the ≈øame. They ≈øitte at the corners of the ≈øtr√©etes, and before mens hou≈øes, and a table with heapes of money ≈øtanding before them, euery heape being a Tanga, which is
‚Ä¢ 5. Bazarucos, & when any man will change a Pardaw, they giue him two or thr√©e, ≈øometimes 8. or 10. Bazarucos more then the 375. Bazarucos, for they know how to make it vp againe, and ≈øo do they with all other money according to the rate.

The waight of Goa is al≈øo in diuers kinds, as in Portingal, with Quintales, Arrobas, and poundes. They haue likewi≈øe another wayght called Mao, which is a Hand, and is twelue pounds, with the which they weigh Butter, Hony, Sugar, and all kind of wares to be ≈øolde by waight. They haue likewi≈øe a waight wherewith they weigh Pepper & other ≈øpices, called a Bhar, and is as much as thr√©e Quintales & a halfe Portingal waight. They haue a mea≈øure called Med ‚Ä¢ da, that is to ≈øay, euen waight. It is about a ≈øpanne high, and halfe a finger broade, whereof 24. mea≈øures are a Hand, and 20. Handes are one Cand ‚Ä¢ il, and one Cand ‚Ä¢ l is little more or le≈ø≈øe theÃÑ 14. bu≈øhels, wherewith they mea≈øure Ryce, Corne, & all graine, or other commodities to be ≈øold by mea≈øure, and the ≈øhips
are fraighted after the ≈øame rate, for they ≈øay a ≈øhippe or ≈øente of ≈øo many Cand ‚Ä¢ ls or ≈øo many P ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ . There is Rice, which they ≈øell by the
‚Ä¢ rden: it is broght in round bundels, wrapped in ≈øtrawe, and bounde about with cordes: Euerie Fardo is commonly thr√©e
‚Ä¢ nd and a halfe. This Rice is better then that which commeth not in Fardens, and is called G ‚Ä¢ ra≈øall, Ryce, which is the be≈øt, and beareth the highe≈øt price: and there is another ≈øorte, which is of a le≈ø≈øe price & ≈ølighter called Chamba≈øal. Ther are al≈øo diuers other ≈øorts of Rice, of a le≈ø≈øe price & ≈ølighter then the other Ryce, and is called Batte, and is almo≈øt like Barley‚ñ™ it hath but little hu≈øke. This is commonly the dayly foode of the countreymen in the villages called Canariins, & of the common and poorer ≈øort which ≈øtampe and beate it them≈øelues. It ≈øerueth al≈øo for Hennes and Doues to eate in ≈øtead of Barley. There are diuers particular ≈øortes of moneyes in many places of India, and inwardes in the lande among the heathens, which are currant onely among them, euery coine in their ≈øeueral places: For by Bengala they haue in place of B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ aru ‚Ä¢ os a ≈ømall kinde of money called Amandeles, wherewith they get their liuings, and buy and ≈øell therewith, and diuers other ≈øuch like coines in ≈øeuerall places of the Orientall countries, but the money waights and mea≈øures afore≈øaid, are tho≈øe which they doe generally and ordinarily v≈øe throughout all „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and principally in Goa, being the heade towne and ≈øtapell of all the Orientall countries.

div.head: The 36 Chapter. Of the Indians called Bramenes, which are the mini≈øters of the Pagodes, & Indian Idoles, and of their manner of life.
div.p: THe Bramenes are the hone≈øte≈øt and mo≈øt e≈øt√©emed nation amonge all the Indian heathens: for they doe alwaies ≈øerue in ye chiefe≈øt places about the King, as Receyuers, Stewards, Amba≈ø≈øadors, and ≈øuch like offices. They are likewi≈øe the prie≈øtes and mini≈øters of the Pagodes, or diueli≈øh Idoles. They are of great authoritie among the Indian people, for that the King doth nothing without their coun≈øell and con≈øent, and that they may be knowne from other men, they weare vppon their naked body, from the ≈øhoulder cro≈ø≈øe vnder the arme ouer their body downe to the girdle, or the cloth that is wrapped about their middle, ‚Ä¢ . or 4. ≈øtrings like ≈øealing thr√©ede, whereby they are knowne: which they neuer put off although it ≈øhoulde co≈øt them their liues, for their profe≈ø≈øion & religion will not permit it. They go naked, ≈øauing onely that they haue a cloth bounde about their middles to hide their priuie members. They wear ≈øometimes when they go abroad a thinne cotton linnen gowne called Caba ‚Ä¢ a, lightly ca≈øt ouer their ≈øholders, and hanging downe to the grounde like ≈øome other Indians, as Benianes, Gu≈øarates, and Decaniins. Vpon their heads they weare a white cloth, wounde twice or thryce about, therewith to hide their haires, which they neuer cut off, but weare it long & turned vp as the women do. They haue mo≈øt commonly rounde rings of golde hanging at their ears, as mo≈øt of ye Indians haue. They eat not any thing that hath life, but f√©ed them ≈øelues with hearbes and Ryce, neyther yet when they are ≈øicke will for any thing bee let blood, but heale them≈øelues by hearbes & ointmentes, and by rubbing their bodies with Sanders, and ≈øuch like ≈øw√©et woods. In Goa and on the ≈øea coa≈øts there are many Bramenes, which commonly doe maintaine them≈øelues with ≈øelling of ≈øpices and other Apothecarie ware, but it is not ≈øo cleane as others, but full of garbi≈øh and du≈øt. They are very ≈øubtil in writing and ca≈øting accounts, wherby they make other ≈øimple Indians beleeue what they will.

Touching the pointes of their religion, wherein the common people bel√©eue them to be Prophetes: what≈øoeuer they fir≈øt meete withal in the ≈øtreets at their going forth, that doe they all the day after pray vnto. The women when they goe forth haue but one cloth about their bodies, which couereth their heades, and hangeth downe vnto their kn√©es: all the re≈øt of the body is naked. They haue ringes through their no≈øes, about their legs, toes, neckes, and armes, and vpon each hand ≈øeuen or eight ringes or bracelettes, ≈øome of ≈øiluer and gilt, if they be of wealth and ability: but the common people of gla≈ø≈øe, which is the common wearing of all the Indian women. When the woman is ≈øeuen yeares olde, and the man nine years, they do marrie, but they come not together before the woman bee ≈øtrong enough to beare children. When the Bramenes die, all their friends a≈ø≈øemble together, and make a hole in the ground, wherein they throw much wood and other things: and if the maÃÑ be of any accompt, they ca≈øt in ≈øw√©et Sanders, & other Spices, with Rice, Corne, and ≈øuch like, and much oyle, becau≈øe the fire ≈øhould burne the ≈øtronger. Which done they lay the dead Bramenes in it: then cometh his wife with Mu≈øike & many of her n√©ere≈øt freÃÑds all ≈øinging certain pray≈øes in commendation of her hu≈øbands life, putting her in comfort, & encouraging her to follow her hu≈øband, & goe with him into the other world. Then ≈øhe taketh
al her Iewels, and parteth them among her frends, & ≈øo with a ch√©erefull countenance, ≈øhe leapeth into the fire, and is pre≈øently couered with wood and oyle: ≈øo ≈øhe is quickly dead, & wt her hu≈øbands bodie burned to a≈øhes: and i ‚Ä¢ it chance, as not very often it doth, that any womaÃÑ refu≈øeth to be burnt with her hu≈øband, then they cut the haire cleane off from her head: and while ≈øhe liueth ≈øhe mu≈øt neuer after wear any Iewels more, & from that time ≈øhe is di≈øpi≈øed, and accounted for a di≈øhone≈øt woman. This manner and cu≈øtome of burning is v≈øed al≈øo by the Nobles and principalle≈øt of the Countrey, and al≈øo by ≈øome Marchantes: notwith≈øtanding all their dead bodies in generall are burnt to a≈øhes, and the women after their hu≈øbands deathes doe cut their haire ≈øhort, & weare no Iewels, whereby they are knowne for widowes. The fir≈øt cau≈øe and occa≈øion why the women are burnt with their hu≈øbandes, was, (as the Indians them≈øelues do ≈øay) that in time pa≈øt, the women (as they are very leacherous and incon≈øtant both by nature and complexion) did poy≈øon many of their hu≈øbands, when they thought good, (as they are likewi≈øe very expert therein:) thereby to haue the better means to fulfill their lu≈øts. Which the king perceiuing, & that thereby his principal Lords, Captains, and Souldiers, which vphelde his e≈øtate and kingdome, were ≈øo con≈øumed and brought vnto their endes, by the wicked practi≈øes of women, ≈øought as much as hee might to hinder the ≈øame: and therevpon he made a law, and ordayned, that when the dead bodies of men were buried, they ≈øhold al≈øo burne their wiues with them, thereby to put them in feare, and ≈øo make them ab≈øtaine froÃÑ poy≈øoning of their hu≈øbands: which at the fir≈øt was very ≈øharply executed, onely vpon the nobles, gentlemen and ≈øouldiers wiues, as al≈øo the Bramenes (for that the common people mu≈øt beare no armes, but are in a manner like ≈ølaues.) So that in the ende it became a cu≈øtome among them, and ≈øo continueth: whereby at this day they ob≈øerue it for a part of their law and ceremonies of their diueli≈øh Idoles, & now they do it willingly, being hartened and ≈øtrengthened thereunto by their friendes. The≈øe Bramenes ob≈øerue certain fa≈øting daies in ye year, and that with ≈øo great ab≈øtineÃÑce, that they eat nothing all that day, and ≈øometimes in 3. or 4. daies together. They haue their Pagodes and Idoles, who≈øe mini≈øters they are, whereof they tell and ≈øhew many miracles, and ≈øay that tho≈øe Pagodes haue b√©en men liuing vpon earth, and becau≈øe of their holy liues, and good workes done here in this world, are for a reward therof, become holy meÃÑ in the other world, as by their miracles, by the Diuel performed, hath b√©ene manife≈øted vnto them, and by their commandementes their formes and ≈øhapes are made in the mo≈øt vgly & deformed manner that po≈ø≈øible may bee deui≈øed. Such they pray and offer vnto, with many diuili≈øh ≈øuper≈øtitions, & ≈øtedfa≈øtly bel√©eue yt they are their aduocates & interce≈ø≈øors vnto God. They bel√©eue al≈øo that there is a ≈øupreame God aboue, which ruleth all things, and that mens ≈øoules are immortall, and that they goe out of this worlde into the other, both bea≈øtes & men, and receyue reward according to their workes, as Pythagoras teacheth, who≈øe di≈øciples they are.

div.head: The 37. Chapter. Of the Gu≈øarates, & Banianes of Cambaia.
div.p:
THe Gu≈øarates and Banianes are of the country of Cambaia: many of them dwel in Goa, Diu, Chaul, Cochin, & other places of India, becau≈øe of their trade and traffick in marchaÃÑ di≈øe, which they v≈øe much with all kindes of wares, as corne, cotton linnen, anil, Rice, and other wares, ≈øpecially all kinde of precious ≈øtones wherein they haue great ≈økill. They are mo≈øt ≈øubtill and expert in ca≈øting of accounts, and writing, ≈øo that they do not onely ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe and goe beyond all Iewes and other nations thereabouts, but al≈øo the Portingals‚ñ™ & in this re≈øpect they haue no aduantage, for that they are very perfect in the trade of marchandi≈øe, & very ready to deceiue men. They eate not any thing that hath life or blood in it, neither would they kil it for all the goods in ye worlde, how ≈ømall or vnnece≈ø≈øarie ≈øoeuer it were, for that they ≈øtedfa≈øtly bel√©eue, ye euery liuing thing hath a ≈øoule, & are next after men to be accounted of, according to Pythagoras law, & know it mu≈øt die: and ≈øometimes they do buy certain fowles or other bea≈øtes of the Chri≈øtians or Portingals, which they meant to haue killed, & wheÃÑ they haue bought them, they let them fl√©e and run away. They haue a cu≈øtome in Cambaia, in the high wayes, & woods, to ≈øet pots wt water, and to ca≈øt corne & other graine vpon the ground to f√©ed birds & bea≈øtes withal: & throughout Cambaia they haue ho≈øpitals to cure and heale all maner of bea≈øts & birds therein what≈øoeuer they a ‚Ä¢ le, & receiue them thether as if they were men, and wheÃÑ they are healed, they let them flie or run away whither they will, which among them is a work of great charity, ≈øaying, it is don to their euen neighbors. And if they take a flea or a Lowce, they wil not kil it, but take or put it into ≈øome hole or corner in the wall, and ≈øo let it go, & you can do them no greater iniury then to kil it in their pre≈øence, for they wil neuer leaue intreating and de≈øiring withall curte≈øie not to kill it, and that man ≈øhoulde not
≈ø√©eme to commit ≈øo great a ≈øinne, as to take away the life of that, to whom God had giuen both ≈øoule and body: yea, and they will offer much money to a man to let it liue, and goe away. They eate no Radi≈øhes, Onions, Garlicke, nor any kinde of hearbe that hath any colour of red in it, nor Egges, for they thinke there is blood in them. They drinke not any wine, nor v≈øe any vineger, but onely water. They are ≈øo dangerous of eating and drinking with other men which are not their Countriemen, that they would rather ≈øtarue to death then once to doe it. It happeneth oftentimes that they ≈øaile in the Portingales ≈øhips from Goa to Cochin to ≈øell their wares, and to traffique with the Portingales, and then they make their proui≈øions for ≈øo long time as they thinke to ≈øtay vpon the way, which they take aboard with them, and thereupon they f√©ede, and if the time falleth out longer, then they made account of their water and proui≈øion beeing all ≈øpent, as it hapned when I ≈øailed from Goa to Cochin, they had rather die for hunger and thir≈øt then once to touch the Chri≈øtians meate, they wa≈øh them≈øelues before they eate, as the Bramenes doe, as al≈øo euery tyme when they ea≈øe them≈øelues or make water. They are of a yellowe colour like the Bramenes and ≈øomewhat whiter, and there are women among them which are much whiter and clearer of complection than the Portingale women. They are formed and made both in face, limmes, and all other thinges like men of Europe, colour only excepted. Their apparrell is a thinne white gowne vppon their naked bodies, from the head to the f√©et, and made fa≈øt on the ≈øide vnder their armes, their ≈øhooes of red leather, ≈øharp at the toes, and turning vp like hookes, their beardes ≈øhauen like the Turkes, ≈øauing only their mou≈øtachios, they weare on their heades a white cloth thr√©e or foure times wrapped about like the Bramenes, and vnder their haire a ≈øtarre vpon their foreheads, which they rub euery morning with a little white ≈øanders, tempered with water, and 3. or 4. graines of rice among it, which the Bramenes al≈øo doe as a ≈øuper≈øtitious ceremonie of their law. Their bodies are commonly annoynted with ≈øanders & other ≈øw√©et woods, which they doe very much v≈øe, as al≈øo all the Indians. Their women are apparelled like the B ‚Ä¢ amenes wiues, they eate like the Mahometans, and all other Indians vpon the ground. In their hou≈øes or a≈ø≈øemblies they ≈øit on the ground vppon mattes or carpets, and alwaies leaue their ≈øhooes without the dore, ≈øo that they are alwaies barefoote in their hou≈øes: wherefore commonly the h√©eles of their ≈øhooes are neuer pulled vp, to ≈øaue labour of vntying or vndoing them; they haue a thou≈øand other heatheni≈øh ≈øuper≈øtitions which are not worth the rehear≈øall, whereof we haue told you the mo≈øt principall and therby you may well enough vnder≈øtand what the re≈øt are.

div.head: The 38. Chapter. Of the Canaras and Decanijns.
div.p:
THe Canaras and Decaniins are of the countrie of Decam, commonly called Ballagate, lying behinde Goa. many of them dwell in Goa, where their wares and ≈øhops are, of all ≈øorts of Veluets, Silkes, Sattins, and Dama≈økes, which they buy by great of the Portingales, al≈øo al kinds of cotton linnen, por≈øelyne, and all kindes of wares and marchandi≈øes of Cambaia, China, Bengalla, &c. which they likewi≈øe buy of the Portingales, and other nations, and ≈øell it againe by retaile: for the which purpo≈øe they haue brokers of their owne Countrimen, which looke for all kindes of wares and commodities. The≈øe bring likewi≈øe all victuals and nece≈ø≈øaries out of the firme land, into the towne and I≈øland of Goa. They haue their Indian ≈øhips wherewith they traffique to Cambaia, Sunda, and the read ≈øea. Many of them are gold and ≈øiluer ≈ømithes, & worke in Copper, wherein they are very cunning. They haue al≈øo diuers other handicrafts, as Barbers, Phi≈øitions, Carpenters, and ≈øuch like, as dwell in Goa, ≈øo that they are almo≈øt as great a number as the Portingale Me≈øticos, and Chri≈øtians. Their apparrell is like the Gu≈øurates & Benianes, except their ≈øhooes, which they weare like Antiques with cut toes, and fa≈øtned aboue vpon their naked f√©ete, which they call Alparcas. They weare their beards and their haire long, as it groweth without cutting, but only turne it vp, and dre≈ø≈øe it as the Benianes and Bramenes v≈øe to doe, and are like them for colour, forme, & making. They eate all thinges except Kine, Hogges, and Buffels, fle≈øh and fi≈øh. They account the Oxe, Cow or Buffel to be holie, which they haue commonly in the hou≈øe with them, and they be≈øm√©ere, ≈øtroke, and handle them with all the friend≈øhip in the world, and f√©ed them with the ≈øame meat they v≈øe to eate them≈øelues, and when the bea≈øtes ea≈øe them≈øelues, they hold their hands vnder their tails and ≈øo throw the dung away. In the night time they ≈øl√©epe with them in their hou≈øes, & to conclude, v≈øe them as if they were rea≈øonable creatures, whereby they thinke to doe God great ≈øeruice. In their eating, ≈øitting in the hou≈øe, wa≈øhing, making cleane, and other
ceremonies and ≈øuper≈øtitions they are altogether like the Bramenes, Gu≈øurates, and Banianes. In their mariages they contract ech with other at 7. yeres, & at 11. or 12. yeares they are maried, and dwell together. When they are to be maried, they begin fourt√©ene dayes before to make a great ≈øound with trumpets, drummes and fires, which continueth day and night for all tho≈øe fourt√©ene dayes, with ≈øo great a noi≈øe of ≈øongs and In≈øtruments, that men can neyther heare nor ≈ø√©e: On the w ‚Ä¢ dding day, all the friends and kindred on both ≈øides doe a≈ø≈øemble together, & ≈øit vpon the ground, round about a fire, and goe ≈øeauen times about it vttering certaine wordes, whereby the wedding is done. They giue their daughters no hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe, but only ≈øome Iewels, as bracelets, eare-rings, and ≈øuch like of ≈ømall valew, wherewith their hu≈øbands mu≈øt bee content, for the Daughters are no heires, but the Sonnes inherite all, but they k√©ep and maintaine their daughters and ≈øi≈øters till they marie: when they die, they are likewi≈øe burnt, and ≈øome of their wiues with them, but not ≈øo many as of the Bramenes. Euery one of them followeth his fathers occupation, and marieth with the daughters of ≈øuch like trades, which they name kindreds. They haue their fa≈øting daies, and ceremonies like the Bramenes, for they are as the laytie, and the Bramenes as the ≈øpiritualty, the Mini≈øters, Prie≈øts, & Prophets of their Idols. They hire and farme the cu≈øtomes and rents of the Portingales, & the Kings reuenewes in the land of Bardes, Sal≈øette, and the I≈øland of Goa, ≈øo that often times for any que≈øtion or ≈øtrife they mu≈øt appeare in law, where they alwaies come without Coun≈øellor or Atturney, and knowe ≈øo well how to place their words, according to the lawes of Portingall, not onely temporall but ≈øpirituall, that they are able to ≈øet downe, and ≈øhew where it ≈øtandeth written, as well as any Coun≈øellor could doe, & make their petitions & reque≈øts without any mans adui≈øe, that the Portingales doe wonder at their readie wits, as I haue oftentimes found in them. When they are to take their othes to beare witnes with any man, they are ≈øet within a circle made of a≈øhes vpon the pauement where they ≈øtand, ≈øtill laying a fewe a≈øhes on their bare heades, holding one hand on their heads, the other on their brea≈øts, and then in their own ≈øp√©ech ≈øweare by their Pagode, that they wil tell the truth without di≈ø≈øimulation, what≈øoeuer ≈øhall bee a≈øked them, for that they certainely beleeue they ≈øhould be damned for euer, if as then they ≈øhould not ≈øay the truth, but conceale it. The≈øe are their principall cu≈øtomes and ceremonies, yet are there many others, which for breuity I omit

div.head: The 39. Chapter. Of the Canarijns and Corumbijns of India.
div.p:
THe Canarijns & Corumbjins are the Countrimen, and ≈øuch as deale with tilling the land, fi≈øhing & ≈øuch like labors, to get their liuings, & look vnto the IndiaÃÑ Palme tr√©es, whereon the Cocos doe grow. There are ≈øome among them that doe nothing els but wa≈øh cloathes, which is there v≈øed like another occupation, they are called Maynattos: there are others that are called Patamares, which ≈øerue onlie for Me≈ø≈øengers or Po≈øts, to carie letters from place to place by land, in winter time when men can not trauaile by ≈øea. The≈øe Canarjins and Corumbjins are the mo≈øt contemptible, and the mi≈øerable≈øt people of al India, and liue very poorely, maintaining theÃÑ ≈øelues with little meate. They eate all kinde of things, except Kine, Oxen, Buffels, Hogs, and Hens fle≈øh, their religion is like the Decanijns and Can ‚Ä¢ ras, for they are all of one Countrie and cu≈øtome, little differing: they goe naked, their priuie members onely couered with a cloth. The womeÃÑ go with a cloth bound about their middles beneath their nauels, and hanging downe to the middle of their thighes, and the other end thereof they ca≈øt ouer their ≈øhoulders, wherby halfe their brea≈øts are couered. They are in a manner blacke, or of a darke browne colour, many of them are Chri≈øtians, becau≈øe their chiefe habitation and dwelling places are on the Sea ≈øide in the countries bordering vpon Goa, for that the palme tr√©es doe grow vpon the Sea coa≈øts, or vpon ye bankes by riuer ≈øides. The rice is ≈øowed vppon low ground, which in winter time is couered with water, wherewith tho≈øe Canarijns doe maintaine them≈øelues: the≈øe bring hennes, fruit, milke, egges and other ≈øuch like wares into the towne to ≈øell. They dwell in little ≈øtraw hou≈øes, the dores whereof are ≈øo low, that men mu≈øt cr√©epe in and out, their hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe is a mat vpon the ground to ≈øl√©epe vpon, and a pit or hole in the ground to heate their rice in with a pot or two to f√©eth it in, and ≈øo they liue and gaine ≈øo much as it is a wonder. For commonly their hou≈øes are full of ≈ømall children, which crall and cr√©epe about all naked, vntill they are 7. or eight yeares old, & then they couer their priuie members. When the Women are readie to trauaile with Childe, they are commonly deliuered when they are all alone, and their hu≈øbands in the fieldes, as it fortuned vppon a time, as I and ≈øome other of my friends went to walke in the fieldes, & into the villages where the Canarijns dwell
and hauing thir≈øt, I went to one of the Canarijns hou≈øes to a≈øke ≈øome water, therewith to refre≈øh vs, (which they commonly drinke out of a Copper Canne with a ≈øpout, thereat to drinke without touching it with their mouthes, which is all the mettell they haue within their hou≈øes,) & becau≈øe I was verie thir≈øtie, I ≈øtooped downe and thru≈øt my head in at the doore, a≈øking for ≈øome water, where I e≈øpied a woman alone within the hou≈øe, tying her cloth fa≈øt about her middle, & before her hauing a woodden trough, (by the Portingales called Gamello) full of water, where ≈øhe ≈øtood and wa≈øhed a childe, whereof as then ≈øhe had newly bin deliuered without any help: which hauing wa≈øht, ≈øhe laid it naked on the ground vpon a great Indian figge leafe, and de≈øired mee to ≈øtay and ≈øhee would pre≈øently giue mee water. When I vnder≈øtood by her that ≈øhe had as then newly b√©ene deliuered of that Child without any help, I had no de≈øire to drink of her water, but went vnto another to a≈øke water, and perceiued the ≈øame woman not long after going about her hou≈øe, as if there had bin no ≈øuch matter, and the children are brought vp in that manner cleane naked, nothing done vnto them, but onely wa≈øhed and made cleane in a little cold water, and doe in that ≈øort pro≈øper and come vp as well as man would wi≈øh, or as any child within the≈øe countries can do with all the tending they haue, & liue many times vntill they be a hundreth yeares old, without any headach, or toothach, or loo≈øing any of their t√©eth. They weare onley a tu≈øke of haire on the toppes of their heads, which they ≈øuffer to grow long: the re≈øt of their haire is cut ≈øhort, they are very expert in ≈øwimming and diuing, they row vp and downe the Riuers in boates called Almadias, whereof ≈øome of theÃÑ are hewen out of a p√©ece of wood, and ≈øo narrow that a man can hardly ≈øit in them, and it chanceth oftentimes that they turne ouer & ouer twice or thrice before they pa≈ø≈øe the riuer, and then they leape out into the water and turne them vp, and ≈øo powring out the water they get into them again. They are ≈øo mi≈øerable, that for a penny they would indure to be whipped, and they eate ≈øo little, that it ≈ø√©emeth they liue by the aire, they are likewi≈øe mo≈øt of them leane and weake of limmes, of little ≈øtrength & very cowardes, whereby the Portingales doe them great outrage and villanie, v≈øing them like dogges and bea≈øts. In their mariages and deathes they ob≈øerue the manner of the Decan ‚Ä¢ ins & Canaras, as al≈øo in their religion & ceremonies. When the man is dead his body is burnt, and the woman cuts her haire off, and breaketh all her Iewels, although they be but few & ≈ømall, for they are mo≈øt of gla≈ø≈øe.

By the pictures following you may ≈øee the Decanijns or Canaras, or the Marchantes of Goa, al≈øo the Banianes or Gu≈øurates of Cambaia, with the Bramenes & his wife, in what ≈øort all the women doe goe, as wel Benianes as Decaniins, Moores & Indian women that inhabite the countrie. How tho≈øe of Goa and Ballagate k√©epe their weddings among the Decaniins and Canaras, with the manner how the liuing women burne them≈øelues with their dead hu≈øbands, what e≈øtate the Emba≈ø≈øador of Hidaleam holdeth in Goa, & how he is caried in the ≈øtr√©ets, al≈øo a true de≈øcription of the Canariin with his wife, & the manner how the Indian heatheni≈øh children are brought vp: al≈øo of the ≈øoldier of Ballagate, which is called La≈øcariin, with the heatheni≈øh whore called Balliadera, who is a dancer, becau≈øe ≈øhee is commonly v≈øed therevnto, in any fea≈øt or open playes, & are ready to be hired for a ≈ømall p√©ece of mony, whereof many of theÃÑ dwell in Goa, with the maner of the dwellings & hou≈øes of the Decaniins, Canariins, & Corumbiins, & how they row in the riuers with their ≈øcutes, whereby I haue placed the maner of the boats v≈øed by tho≈øe of the Malabares in Cochin, ≈øo that I ≈øhall not n√©ede to make a ≈øeuerall Chapter of them by them≈øelues.

div.head: The 40. Chapter. Of the Arabians and Abexiins dwelling in India.
div.p:
THere are many Arabians & Abexiins in India. The Arabians ob≈øerue Mahomets law, & the Abexiins ≈øome are Mahometans, ≈øome chri≈øtians, after their manner, for they are of Pre≈øter Iohns land, which ≈øtretcheth behind Mo≈øambique in Aethiopia vnto the red ≈øea, and the riuer Nilus in Egypt, and by their common traffique and conference with the Moores and Mahometans, there are diuers of them infected with the ≈øame ≈øect. There are many of them in India that are ≈ølaues and captiues, both meÃÑ and women which are brought thether out of Aethiopia, & ≈øold like other Oriental Nations, the Abexiins that are chri≈øtians haue on their faces 4. burnt markes in manner of a Cro≈ø≈øe, one ouer their no≈øe in the middle of the forehead, betw√©ene both their eyes, on each of their ch√©ekes one, betw√©ene their eies, and their eares, and one vnder their neather lip, downe to the chin: and this is their Bapti≈øme, when they are made Chri≈øtians, which they v≈øe in ≈øtead of water. The≈øe Abexiins, and Arabians ≈øuch as are fr√©e doe ≈øerue in al India for ≈øaylers and ≈øea faring meÃÑ, with ≈øuch marchants as ≈øaile from Goa to China, Iapon, Bengala, Mallaca, Ormus, and all the Oriental coa≈øt: for that there they haue no other ≈øaylers, nor there are no other becau≈øe
the Portingalles (although they ≈øerue for Saylers in the Portingalles ≈øhippes that come into India, and haue neuer bene other in Portingale but Saylers, yet are they a≈øhamed to liue in that order, and thinke it a great di≈øcredite vnto them, together with a great dimini≈øhing of their authorities & e≈øtimations, which they account them≈øelues to hold in India, ≈øo that they giue them≈øelues out for mai≈øters of ≈øhippes, and by their captaines are al≈øo called Pilots and chief Bote≈øonnes, but not lower: for if they ≈øhould de≈øcend but one ≈øtep lower, it would be a great blot and blemi≈øh vnto them all their liues after, which they would not indure for anie thing in the world. The≈øe Abexijns and Arabians ≈øerue for ≈ømall money, and being hyred are verie lowlie and ≈øubiect, ≈øo that often times they are beaten and ≈ømitten, not as ≈ølaues, but like dogs, which they beare very patientlie, not once ≈øpeaking a word: they coÃÑ monlie haue their wiues and children with them in the ≈øhippe wherein they are hyred, which continually ≈øtay with them, what voyage ≈øoeuer they make, and dre≈ø≈øe their owne meat, which is Rice ≈øodden in water with ≈øalt fi≈øh among it. The cau≈øe why the women ≈øayle in the ≈øhip, is, for that in Summer and not el≈øe, their ≈øhippes goe to ≈øea, wheÃÑ they alwayes haue calme water and faire weather, with good windes: they haue commonlie but one Portingale or two for Captaine, mai≈øter and Pilote, and they haue a chief Bote≈øon, which is an Arabian, which they cal Mocadon, and he is ruler of the Arabians & Aberijns, that are ≈øaylers, whome he hath vnder his ≈øubiection, euen as if they were his ≈ølaues or ≈øubiects. This Mocadon is he that conditioneth and maketh bargaine with the owners of the ≈øhip‚ñ™ to haue ≈øo manie ≈øaylers, and he receiueth the monethlie money for their wages, and accounteth with the ≈øaylers particularlie, but for gouernment of the ≈øhip he hath not to doe, neither troubleth him≈øelfe therewith. The ≈øhippes when they ≈øayle, v≈øe no ca≈øke for water, becau≈øe there is not any throughout all India, nor any made there, ≈øaue onely ≈øuch as come out of Portingall, and v≈øed in the Portingall ≈øhippes: but in ≈øt√©ed of pypes they v≈øe a great foure cornered woodden ce≈øterne, yt ≈øtaÃÑdeth by the main ma≈øte, at the very foote therof, vpon the keele of the ≈øhippe, which is verie well pitched, and made fa≈øt, wherein they lade as much water as they thinke will ≈øerue them for their voyage. The captaine, mai≈øter or Pilote, Marchants and pa≈ø≈øingers, haue euerie man their meat by them≈øelues‚ñ™ and their water in great Indian pots called Martauans, whereof in ye de≈øcription of Pegu I haue alreadie ≈øpoken. The≈øe people are ≈øo ≈øeruiceable and willing to doe any thing, that if there chanceth but a hat, or any other thing, to be blowen ouer, or fall into the water, they will pre≈øently leape, cloathes and all into the ≈øea, to fetch it again, for they ≈øwimme like fi≈øhes, when the ≈øhips lie within the hauen or riuer, and that they will all goe on land, then they goe into the boate, and ≈øo row to ≈øhore, which done one of them roweth backe againe with the boate, which he tyeth fa≈øt to the ≈øhip and ≈øwimmeth to land: and when they will goe abord again, if any of the ≈øaylers be vnwilling to ≈øwimme to fetch the boate, they are by the Mocadon or the mai≈øter, with ≈øtrokes compelled to doe it: but they coÃÑmonlie neuer ≈øtay till it cometh ≈øo ‚Ä¢ arre, but rather ≈øtriue who ≈øhall be fir≈øt in the water to ≈øhew their diligence: and when they doe any thing abord, as hayling ropes and other things, they ≈øing & an≈øwere each other very ≈øweetlie, ≈øo yt it ≈ø√©emeth to be very good Mu≈øick. Their exerci≈øe on land is, all the day to drinke, and to ≈øit in tipling hou≈øes with their wiues and children, and then they goe hand in hand through the ≈øtr√©ets, r√©eling here and there, making a great noi≈øe with ≈øinging and gaping after their manner: there womeÃÑ weare breeches like the Arabians and Mahometans.

div.head: The 41. Chapter. Of the blacke people of Mo≈øambique, which are called Caffares, and of their manners and cu≈øtomes.
div.p:
THe black people or Ca ‚Ä¢ fares of the land of Mo≈øambique, and all the coa≈øt of Ethiopia, and within the laÃÑd to the Cape de bona SperaÃÑza, go al naked, although tho≈øe of Mo≈øambique, (that is the women) do a little couer them≈øelues, which they do by meanes of the daylie conuer≈øation they haue with the Portingales, who for Gold, ≈øiluer and Iuory bones, and ≈øuch like, doe exchange Cotton lynnen brought out of India, that within the land, and to the cape, they v≈øe in tho≈øe countries: otherwi≈øe they couer them≈øelues with the like apparell that Adam and Eua did weare in Paradice. They are all as black as pitch, with curled and ≈øinged hayre, both on their heads and beards, which is very little, their no≈øes broad, flat and thicke at the end‚ñ™ great bigge lippes: ≈øome haue holes, both aboue & vnder in their lippes, and ≈øome times be≈øides their mouthes through their cheekes, wherein they thru≈øt ≈ømall bones, which they e≈øteeme a bewtifying: there are ≈øome among them that haue their faces and
all their bodies ouer ra≈øed and ≈øeared with irons, and al figured like ra≈øed Sattin or Dama≈øke, wherein they take great pride, thinking there are no fairer people then they in all the world, ≈øo that when they ≈øee any white people, that weare apparell on their bodies, they laugh and mocke at them, thinking vs to be mon≈øters and vgly people: and when they will make any deueli≈øh forme and picture, then they inuent one atfer the forme of a white man in his apparell, ≈øo that to conclude, they thinke and verily per≈øwade them≈øelues, that they are the right colour of men, and that we haue a fal≈øe and counterfait colour. There are among them that file their t√©eth as ≈øharp as nedles, which they likewi≈øe e≈øt√©eme for a great ornament. Many of them hold the law of Mahomet, that is to ≈øay, ≈øuch as dwell on the coa≈øt of Abex or Melinde, and round about tho≈øe places, as al≈øo in Mo≈øambique, by rea≈øon the red ≈øea is ≈øo n√©ere vnto them, together with the Arabian Mahometans, with whome they dayly traffique, as they al≈øo did in al places, & IlaÃÑds throughout the Orientall countries, before the Portingales di≈øcouery and conque≈øt of India, whereby all the Orientall countrie where they trafficked, was infected with their deueli≈øh law, and their poy≈øon ≈øpread and throwne abroad in all places, which is one of the principall occa≈øions that the Go≈øpell taketh no better effect in tho≈øe countries, their pe≈øti≈øerous law beeing as it were rooted and ingrafted in their mindes. There are ≈øome of them that are become Chri≈øtians ≈øince the Portingales came thether, but there is no great paines taken about it in tho≈øe couÃÑtries, becau≈øe there is no profite to be had, as al≈øo that it is an infectious and vnhole≈øome countrie: and therefore the Ie≈øuites are wary inough not to make any hou≈øes or habitations therein, for they ≈ø√©e no great profite to be reaped there for them, as they doe in India & the Ilands of Iapan, & in other places, where they find great quantities of riches, with the ≈øap whereof they increa≈øe much and fill their beehyues therewith to ≈øati≈øfy their thir≈øty & in≈øatiable de≈øires: mo≈øt part of the Caffares liue like bea≈øtes or wild men, yet they haue their hou≈øes in troups or heaps, like couÃÑ try vilages‚ñ™ wher they a≈ø≈øeÃÑble & dwel together and in euery Village they haue a Lord or King, to whome they are ≈øubiect and obedient, they are commonly in warres one with an other, and one place or Village again≈øt an other, and haue law and Iu≈øtice among them with ≈øome ≈ømall Policie, concerning their worldly affaires and gouernment: but as concerning Religion and faith, they know not what it meaneth, but liue like bea≈øtes without any knowledge of God, or any likelyhoode or ≈øhadow thereof, they maintaine them≈øelues by hunting, which they doe in the woods, where they take all that they finde, they eate Elephants fle≈øh and all other kind of wild bea≈øtes, and of the Elephants t√©eth, they make their weapons, in≈øt√©ede of Iron and St√©ele, they doe commonly make warre one again≈øt the other, and ≈øome of them eate mens fle≈øh, and ≈øome there are al≈øo that eate it not, but ≈øuch as deale with the Portingals. When they take any man pri≈øoner in the warres, they ≈øell him to the Portingales, or exchaunge and barter him for Cotton linnen, and other Indian wares. They haue a cu≈øtome among them, that when they goe to warre again≈øt their enemies, if they win the battaile, or ouerthrow each other, he that taketh or killeth mo≈øt men, is holden and accounted for the be≈øt and braue≈øt man among them, and much re≈øpected, and to witne≈ø≈øe the ≈øame before their Kings, of as many as they haue ≈ølaine or taken pri≈øoners, they cut off their priu ‚Ä¢ e members, that if they bee let goe againe, they may no more beget children, which in proce≈ø≈øe of time might mi≈øchiefe them, and then they drie them well, becau≈øe they ≈øhould not rot: which being ≈øo dried, they come before their Kings with great reuerence, in the pre≈øence of the principall men in the Village, and there take the≈øe members ≈øo dried one by one in their mouthes, and ≈øpit them on the ground at the Kings feete, which the King with great thankes accepteth, and the more to reward and to recompence their valour, cau≈øeth them all to bee taken vp and giuen to them againe, for a ≈øigne and token of honour, whereby euer after from that time forwards they are accounted as Knights, and they take all tho≈øe members, wherewith the King hath thus honoured them,A co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e kynde of chaine „Äà‚óä„Äâ women „Äà‚óä„Äâ wea ‚Ä¢ e. and tie them all vpon a ≈øtring like a Bracelet or Chaine, and when they marrie, or go to any wedding, or fea≈øts, the Bride or wiues of tho≈øe knights doe weare that Chaine of mens members about their neckes, which among them is as great an honour, as it is with vs, to weare the golden Fl√©ece, or the Garter of England, and the Brides of ≈øuch Knightes, are therewith as proude, as if they were the mightie≈øt Queenes in all the world.

From Mo≈øambique great numbers of the≈øe Caffares are caried into India, and many times they ≈øell a man or woman that is growne to their full ≈øtrength, for two or three Ducats. When the Portingales ≈øhips put in there for fre≈øh water and other nece≈ø≈øaries, then they are dearer, by rea≈øon of the great numbers of buyers, the cau≈øe why ≈øo many ≈ølaues and Captaines of all nations
are brought to ≈øell in India, is, becau≈øe that euerie ten or twelue miles, or rather in euery Village and towne, there is a ≈øeuerall King, and ruler of the people, one of them not like an other, neither in law, ≈øp√©ech nor manners, whereby mo≈øt part of them are in warres, one again≈øt the other, and tho≈øe that on both ≈øides are taken pri≈øoners, they k√©epe for ≈ølaues, and ≈øo fell each other like bea≈øtes: hee who≈øe euill fortune is ≈øuch, that hee is one of the captiues, mu≈øt be patient, wherein they ≈øhew not much di≈ølike, for when they are a≈øked, how they can content them≈øelues with that yoke of bondage, they an≈øwere that they can beare it well enough, ≈ø√©eing their Planet will haue it ≈øo, and for that their friends and neighbours ≈øhall reuenge their cau≈øe again≈øt tho≈øe that haue done it. Al≈øo in time of pouertie or dearth the fathers may ≈øell their children, as it happened in my time, that there was ≈øuch a dearth, and ≈øcar≈øitie of victualls in the firme lande, and countries bordering vppon Goa, that the men of India came to Goa (and other places where the Portingales are re≈øident) to ≈øell their children, in great numbers, and for ≈ømall prices‚ñ™ to buy them victuals. I haue ≈ø√©ene Boyes of eight, or ten yeares, giuen in exchange for fiue or ≈øixe mea≈øures of Rice, and ≈øome for thr√©e or foure Ducats the p√©ece, and ≈øome came with their wiues and children to offer them≈øelues to bee ≈ølaues, ≈øo that they might haue meate and drinke to nouri≈øh their bodies. And becau≈øe the Portingales haue traffique in all places, (as we haue b√©ene in many) it is the cau≈øe why ≈øo many are brought out of all countries to be ≈øolde, for the Portingales doe make a liuing by buying and ≈øelling of them, as they doe with other wares. What concerneth the Caffares in Mo≈øambique, I haue in an other place declared, in the de≈øcription of Mo≈øambique. Hereafter followeth the pictures of the Arabians and Abexijns, with their wiues, as they goe in India, al≈øo the pictures and manners of the Caffares, both men and women, as they goe in Mo≈øambique, all liuely portracted.

div.head: The 42. Chapter. Of the Malabares and Nayros in India, with their manners and cu≈øtomes.
div.p:
THe Malabares are tho≈øe that dwel on the Sea cao≈øt, betw√©ene Goa, & the Cape de Comorijn Southward from Goa, where the Pepper groweth. They haue a ≈øp√©ech by them≈øelues, and their countrie is diuided into many kingdomes, as in the de≈øcription of the country, we haue already declared, the≈øe are the greate≈øt, and wor≈øt enemies that the Portingales haue, and by Sea doe them great mi≈øchiefe, they are ≈øtrong and very couragious, they goe all naked onely their priuie members couered, the women likewi≈øe haue but a cloth from their Nauell downe to their kn√©es, all the re≈øt is naked, they are ≈øtrong of limmes, and verie arrogant and proude, of colour altogether blacke, yet verie ≈ømoth both of haire and ≈økin‚ñ™ which commonly they annoint with Oyle, to make it ≈øhine; they weare their haire as long as it will grow, tyed on the top or crowne of their heads with a Lace, both men and women: the lappes of their eares are open, and are ≈øo long that they hang downe to their ≈øhoulders, and the longer & wider they are, the more they are e≈øt√©emed among them, and it is thought to bee a beautie in them. Of face, body, and limmes, they are altogether like men of Europ, without any difference, but onely in colour, the men are commonly verie hayrie, and rough vpon the brea≈øt, and on their bodies, and are the mo≈øt leacherous and vncha≈øt nation in all the Orient, ≈øo that there are verie few women children among them, of ≈øeuen or eight yeares olde, that haue their maiden-heades: They are verie readie to catch one from an other, though it bee but for a ≈ømall penie. In their hou≈øes they are not verie curious, their hou≈øes and hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe, differeth not much from the Canarijns & Corumbijns of Goa. Their Idolatrie, ceremonies and ≈øuper≈øtitions, are like the other Heathens. Of the≈øe Malabares there are two manner of people, the one is Noblemen or Gentlemen, called Nayros, which are ≈øouldiers‚ñ™ that doe onely weare and handle armes, the other is the common people called Polias, and they may weare no weapons, nor beare any armes, the Nayros mu≈øt in all places where they goe or ≈øtand, weare ≈øuch armes as are appointed for them, and alwaies bee readie at the Kings commaundement, to doe him ≈øeruice, ≈øome of them doe alwaies beare a naked Rapier or Courtelas in their right hands, and a great Target in their left hand, tho≈øe Targets are verie great, and made of light wood, ≈øo that when they wil they can couer their whole bodies therewith, they are ≈øo well v≈øed thereunto, that they e≈øteme it nothing to beare them, and when they trauell on the way, they may be heard a great way off, for that they commonly make a great knocking with the Hilt of their Rapier, again≈øt the Target, becau≈øe they would bee heard. There are ≈øome that carrie a bow and a venimous arrow vppon
their ≈øhoulder, wherein they are verie expert, others carrie long Pikes, ≈øome P√©eces, with the Match readie lighted, and wound about their armes, and haue the be≈øt lockes that po≈ø≈øible may bee found in all Europe, which they know ≈øo well how to v≈øe, that the Portingales can haue no aduantage again≈øt them. Where≈øoeuer they goe, they mu≈øt alwaies haue their armes with them, both night and day. Not any of them are married, nor may not marrie during their liues, but they may freely lie with the Nayros daughters, or with any other that liketh them, what women ≈øoeuer they bee, yea though they be married women. When the Nayro hath a de≈øire thereunto, hee entreth into a hou≈øe where he thinketh good, and ≈øetteth his armes in the ≈øtr√©ete without the doore, and goeth in and di≈øpatcheth his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, with the good wife or the daughter, the doore ≈øtanding wide open, not fearing that any man ≈øhould come in to let him, for who≈øoeuer pa≈ø≈øeth by, and ≈ø√©eth the Nayros armes ≈øtanding at the doore, although it be the goodman him≈øelfe, hee goeth by, and letteth him make an end‚ñ™ and hauing done, he taketh his armes and departeth thence, and then the hu≈øband may come to the hou≈øe, without making any words, or once moouing que≈øtion about it. In that manner they goe where they will, and no man may denie them. As the≈øe Nayros goe in the ≈øtreetes, they v≈øe to crie Po, Po, which is to ≈øay, take h√©ede, looke to your ≈øelues, or I come, ≈øtand out of the way, for that the other ≈øort of people called Polyas, that are no Nayros, may not once touch or trouble one of them, and therefore they alwaies crie, becau≈øe they ≈øhould make them roome, and know that they come, for if any of the Polyas ≈øhould ≈øtand ≈øtill, and not giue them place, whereby hee ≈øhould chaunce to touch their bodies, hee may fr√©ely thru≈øt him through, and no man a≈øke him why he did it. And when they are once touched by any Polya ‚Ä¢ , or by any other nation except Nayros, they mu≈øt before they eate, or conuer≈øe with other Nayro ‚Ä¢
wa≈øh and clen≈øe their bodies with great ceremonies and ≈øuper≈øtitions. Likewi≈øe they mu≈øt not bee touched by any Chri≈øtian, or any other man. And when the Portingales came fir≈øt into India, and made league and compo≈øition with the King of Cochin, the Nayros de≈øired that men ≈øhold giue them place, and turne out of the way, when they mette in the ≈øtr√©etes, as the Polyas and others v≈øed to doe, which the Portingales would not con≈øent vnto, thinking it to be again≈øt their credits and honors, for them to be compared to the Polyas and vnprofitable ≈øort of people, whereas they e≈øt√©emed them≈øelues better then the Nayros, both in per≈øon and armes: therefore they would haue the Nayros to giue them place, whereby they could not agr√©e, in the end it was concluded, (to pacifie the matter, and to k√©epe peace and quietnes among them) that two men ≈øhould be cho≈øen, one for the Nayros, and the other for the Portingales, that ≈øhould fight body to body, and he that ≈øhould be ouerthrowne, that nation ≈øhould giue place vnto the other, this was done in the pre≈øence of both nations, and the Portingall ouercame the Nayro, whome hee ≈ølew, whereupon it was agr√©ed, that the Nayros ≈øhould giue place vnto the Portingall, and ≈øtand a ≈øide vntill hee be pa≈øt, where ≈øoeuer they meete. The Nayros weare the nayls of their hands very long, wherby they ≈øhew that they are Gentlemen, becau≈øe the longne≈ø≈øe of the nayles doth let and hinder men from working or doing any labour. They ≈øay likewi≈øe that they do it, the better and fa≈øter to gripe a thing in their hands, and to holde their Rapiers, which ≈øome Portingales and Me≈øticos doe likewi≈øe v≈øe, and hold the ≈øame opinion with the Nayros, whereof there are many in India, which let their nayles grow for the ≈øame cau≈øe. The principalle≈øt or chiefe≈øt of tho≈øe Nayros, which are leaders or Captaines of certaine numbers of Nayros, weare a Gold or Siluer bracelet, or ring about their armes, aboue their elbowes: as al≈øo their Gouernours, Amba≈ø≈øadours, and Kings, whereby they are knowne from other men, for otherwi≈øe they goe all naked. Al≈øo their Kings, rulers, and other Captaines and leaders, when they goe abroad, are garded and accompanied by other Nayros. They are verie good and ≈øtout ≈øouldiers, and wil ≈øet vpon a man verie fiercely, they are al≈øo verie full of reuenge, ≈øo that when≈øoeuer they fight again≈øt their enemies either by water or by lande, and that they chaunce to bee thru≈øt into the body with a Pike, they are not pre≈øently therewith content to lie downe, but if they cannot ≈øp√©edily plucke the Pike forth, they will not ≈øpare to pull it forth with both their hands, and draw it through their bodies, therewith to ≈øet vpon them that gaue them the wound, and to be reuenged on them.

div.head: The 43. Chapter Of the Moores and Iewes in India.
div.p: THere are great numbers of Moores and Iewes in al places of India, as at Goa, Cochin, & within the land, ≈øome coming out of other places, and the re≈øt borne of Iewes and Moores in that country, and ≈øo by birth right Indians, who in times pa≈øt by conuer≈øation and company of tho≈øe Iewes & Moores, haue bene brought to their ≈øect and opinion. In their hou≈øes and apparell they follow the manner of the land wherein they are re≈øident: among≈øt the Indians they haue their Churches, Synagogues and Me≈øquitas, wherein they v≈øe all ceremonies according to their law: but in the places where the Portingales inhabite and gouern, it is not permitted vnto them to v≈øe them openly, neither to any Indian, although they haue their families and dwelling hou≈øes, and get their liuings, and deal one with the other: but ≈øecretly in their hou≈øes they may doe what they will, ≈øo that no man take offence thereat: without the townes and where the Portingales haue no commandement, they may fr√©ely v≈øe and exerci≈øe their ceremonies and ≈øuper≈øtitions, euery one as liketh him be≈øt, without any man to let or deny them: but if they be founde openlie doing it in the Portingales townes and iuri≈ødictions, or that they haue any point of Chri≈øtian ceremonies mingled among theirs, both men and womeÃÑ die for it, vnle≈ø≈øe they turne vnto the chri≈øtian faith, as it oftentimes happeneth without the towne of Cochin, where the King k√©epeth his Court: there the Iewes and Moores haue fr√©e libertie to v≈øe their ≈øects and ceremonies openlie, for there the Iewes haue made and built very fair ≈øtone hou≈øes, and are rich marchants, and of the king of Cochins n√©ere≈øt Coun≈øellers: there they haue their ≈øynagogue with their hebrue Bible, and Mo≈øes Lawe, which I haue had in my hand: they are mo≈øt white of colour, like men of Europa, & haue many faire women. There are manie of them that came out of the country of Pale≈øtina & Ieru≈øalem thether, and ≈øpeake ouer all the Exchange verie perfect and good Spani≈øh: they ob≈øerue the Saboth day, and other iudiciall ceremonies, and hope for the Me≈øsias to come.

The Moores like wi≈øe haue their Me≈øquitos, wherein they pray, and aboue the Church they haue manie ≈øellers and galleries, where they learne their children their
principles of Religion before they goe to Church: they wa≈øh their f√©et, for the which purpo≈øe they haue alwaies a ce≈øterne with water ≈øtanding without the Church, & leaue their Alparcos (which are their ≈øhoes) ≈øtanding at the Church dore before they goe in, and being in the Church they fall flat on the ground vpon their faces, and ≈øo with their armes & handes lifted vp, make manie counterfait faces. They are al≈øo circumci≈øed like the Iewes, & eate no hogges fle≈øh, and when they are dead they are buried. In their churches they haue not any Images, but onelie ≈øome ≈øtones or round pillers ≈øtanding vpright with certaine Chaldean letters (out of their Alcaron) grauen vpon them. As I and a friend of myne chaÃÑced to go out of the town, we were de≈øirous to ≈ø√©e their Mahometicall Church, and their manner of ≈øeruice, which was denyed vs by the k√©eper of the dore, that bad vs put off our ≈øhoes, but becau≈øe wee would not, he ≈øaid it was not lawfull for vs to enter in that ≈øort into the Church: but to let vs ≈ø√©e it, he ≈øuffered vs to ≈øtand within the dore, and opened ≈øome of the windowes, that we might ≈ø√©e what was within it: then the Portingale a≈øked him for their God & their Saintes which they v≈øed to pray vnto, becau≈øe he ≈øawe the Church emptie, as I ≈øayd before: then the Moore an≈øwered him, that they v≈øed not to pray to ≈øtockes and ≈øtones, but to the liuing God, which is in Heauen, and ≈øaid that the proude Portingale Chri≈øtians, and the Heathens were all of one Religion, for that they prayed to Images made of wood and ≈øtones, and giue them the glorie which onely appertaineth to the liuing God: with the which an≈øwere the Portingal was ≈øo angrie, that he began to chide & make a great noy≈øe, and to giue him manie hard words, wherewith manie Iewes & Moores a≈ø≈øembled about them, ≈øo that there had growne a great quarrell, had it not bene for me, that got him to hold his peace, and ≈øo brought him away, and let the matter re≈øt in that ≈øort. The≈øe Moores traffique much with ≈øpices to the red ≈øea, and other places, both by water and by land. And although manie of them dwell among the Portingales and traffique much with them, yet ≈øecretly they are their mo≈øt deadly enemies, and doe them much mi≈øchief, and are the principal occa≈øion that there are no more Chri≈øtians conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, ≈ø√©eking all the wayes and meanes they can to withdraw and di≈ø≈øwade them from it, whereby the Indians doe both v≈øe and followe their cu≈øtomes and Religion.

By the Picture following you may ≈ø√©e the ≈øtate and maie≈øtie of the king of Cochin ≈øitting vpon an Elephant, when he rydeth abroad with his Nayros, or Gentlemen and ≈øoldiers that guard and conduct him, al≈øo the other Malabares, both men and women, called Polyas, which the Mores and Mahometans that dwell in Cananor, among the Malabares, as I ≈øaid before. You ≈øhall al≈øo ≈ø√©e the Chri≈øtians that are called S. In that Iland ≈øtandeth an high hill, & on the top thereof there is a hole, that goeth down into the hill, digged & carued out of the hard rock, or ≈øtones as big as a great cloy≈øter: within it hath both places and ce≈øternes for water, very curiou≈øly made, and round about the wals are cut out & formed, the ≈øhapes of ElephaÃÑts, Lions, tigers, and a thou≈øand other ≈øuch like wilde and cruel bea≈øts: al≈øo ≈øome Amazones and many other deformed thinges of diuers ≈øorts, which are all ≈øo well and workmanlike cut, that it is ≈øtrange to behold. In the Iland of Seylon, whereof I haue alreadie ≈øpoken, there is a high Hill called Pico d'Adam, or Adams Hill, vpon the top whereof ≈øtandeth a great hou≈øe, as big as a Cloy≈øter: wherein ≈øtandeth a Pagode of great account.
