Iames in Gali≈øia, and S. Michae ‚Ä¢ s Mount in France, by rea≈øon of the great indulgences & pardons that were there daylie to be had: for which cau≈øe it was ≈øought vnto with great deuotion by all the Indians within 4 or 500 miles round about in great multitudes: but it happened an. 1554 wheÃÑ ye Portingales made a road out of India and entred the Iland of Seylon, they went vp vpon the hill, where they thought to finde great trea≈øure, becau≈øe of the fame that was, ≈øpread abroad of the great re≈øort and offering in that place, where they ≈øought the Cloy≈øter and turned vp euerie ≈øtone thereof, and found nothing but a little Coffer, made fa≈øt with many co≈øtly precious ≈øtones, wherein laye the Apes tooth. This bootie or relique they tooke with them vnto Goa, which when the Kings of Pegu, Sion, Bengala, Bi≈ønagar, and others heard of, they were much grieued that their ≈øo co≈øtly Iewell was in that manner taken from them, wherupon by common con≈øent they ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadors vnto the Viceroy of India, de≈øiring him of all friend≈øhip, to ≈øend them their Apes tooth againe, offering him for a ran≈øome (be≈øides other pre≈øents, which as then they ≈øent vnto him) 700. thou≈øand Ducats in Golde, which the Viceroy for couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the money was minded to doe. But the Archbi≈øhop of Goa called Don Ga≈øpar, my Lords predice≈ø≈øor, di≈ø≈øwaded him from it, ≈øaying, that they being Chri≈øtians, ought not to giue it them againe, being a thing whereby Idolatrie might be furthered, and the Deuill wor≈øhipped, but rather were bound by their profe≈ø≈øion, to roote out and aboli≈øh all Idolatrie and ≈øuper≈øtition, as much as in them lay. By which meanes the Viceroy was per≈øwaded to change his mind,An Ape ‚Ä¢ Tooth had in great e≈øtimation and flatly denied the Amba≈ø≈øadours reque≈øt: hauing in their pre≈øence fir≈øt burnt the Apes tooth, the A≈øhes whereof hee cau≈øed to bee throwne into the Sea. Whereupon the Amba≈ø≈øadors fearing ≈øome further mi≈øchief, tooke their leaue and departed, being much a≈øtoni≈øhed that hee refu≈øed ≈øo great a ≈øumme of money, for a thing which hee ≈øo little e≈øt√©emed that hee burnt it, and threw the A≈øhes into the Sea. Not long after there was a Beniane (as the Benianes are full of ≈øubtiltie) that had gotten an other Apes tooth, and made the Indians and Heathens belieue, that hee had miraculou≈øly found the ≈øame Apes tooth, that the Viceroye had, and that it was reuealed vnto him by a Pagode in a vi≈ø ‚Ä¢ on, that a≈ø≈øured him it was the ≈øame, which hee ≈øaid the Portingales thought they had burned, but that he had b√©ene there inui≈øible and taken it away, laying an other in the place. Which the Heathens pre≈øently belieued, ≈øo that it came vnto the King of Bi≈ønagars eares, who thereupon de≈øired the Beniane to ≈øend it him, and with great ioy receiued it, giuing the Beniane a great ≈øumme of Golde for it, where it was againe holden and kept in the ≈øame honour and e≈øtimation, as the other that was burnt, had b√©ene.

In the kingdome of Nar≈øinga, or the coa≈øt called Ch ‚Ä¢ ramandel, there ≈øtandeth a Pagode, that is verie great, exc√©eding rich, and holden in great e≈øtimation, hauing manye Pilgrimages and vi≈øitations made vnto it from all the countries bordering about it, where euerie yeare they haue many faires, fea≈øtes, and proce≈ø≈øions, and there they haue a Wagon or a Carte, which is ≈øo great and heauie, that thr√©e or foure Elephants can hardly draw it, and this is brought foorth at faires, fea≈øtes, and proce≈ø≈øions. At this Carte hang likewi≈øe many Cables or Ropes, wherat al≈øo all the countrie people, both men and women of pure deuotion doe pull and hale. In the vpper part of this Carte ≈øtandeth a Tabernacle or ≈øeate, wherein ≈øitteth the Idoll, and vnder it ≈øit the Kings wiues, which after their manner play on all in≈øtruments, making a mo≈øt ≈øw√©ete melodie, and in that ≈øort is the Carte drawne foorth, with great deuotions and proce≈ø≈øions: there are ≈øome of them, that of great zeale and pure deuotion doe cut p√©eces of fle≈øh out of their bodies, and throwe them downe before the Pagode: others laye them≈øelues vnder the wh√©eles of the Carte, and let the Carte runne ouer them, whereby they are all cru≈øhed to p√©eces, and pre≈ø≈øed to death, and they that thus die, are accounted for holy and deuout Martyrs, and from that time forwardes are kept and pre≈øerued for great and holy Reliques, be≈øides a thou≈øand ‚Ä¢ ther ≈øuch like bea≈øtly ≈øuper≈øtitions, which they v≈øe, as one of my Chamber fellowes, that had ≈øeene it, ≈øhewed me, and it is al≈øo wel knowne throughout all India.

Vpon a time I and certaine Portingales my friends hauing licence from the Viceroy were at a banket and m√©eting, about fiue or ≈øixe miles within the firme land, and with vs wee had certaine Decanijns, and naturall borne Indians, that were acquainted with the countrie, the chiefe cau≈øe of our going, was to ≈øee their manner of burning the deade Bramene, and his wife with him, being aliue becau≈øe we had b√©ene aduerti≈øed, that ≈øuch a thing was to be done. And there among other ≈øtrange deui≈øes that we ≈øaw, wee came into ≈øome Villages, and places inhabited by the Indians where in the way, and at euerie hil, ≈øtonie Rocke or hole, almo≈øt within a Pater no≈øter length, wee found a Carued Pagode, or rather Deuils, and mon≈øters in helli≈øh ≈øhapes. At the la≈øt wee came into a Village, where ≈øtoode a great Church of ≈øtone, wherein wee entered, and found nothing in it but a great Table that hung in the middle of the Church, with the Image of a Pagode, painted therein ≈øo mi≈øhaped and deformed, that more mon≈øterous was neuer ≈ø√©ene, for it had many hornes, and long t√©eth that hung out of his mouth down to the kn√©es, and beneath his Nauel and belly, it had an other ≈øuch like face, with many hornes and tu≈økes. Vppon the head thereof ≈øtoode a triple Crowned Myter, not much vnlike the Popes triple crown, ≈øo that in effect it ≈ø√©emed to be a mon≈øter, ≈øuch as are de≈øcribed in the Apocalips. It hung before a Wall, which made a partition from an other Chamber, in manner of a Quier, yet was it clo≈øe made vp without windowes, or any place for light, in the middle whereof was a little narrow clo≈øe doore, and on both ≈øides of the doore, ≈øtoode a ≈ømall Furnace made within the wall, wherein were certaine holes or Latti≈ø≈øes, thereby to let the ≈ømoke or ≈øauor of the fire to enter into that place, when any offering ≈øhould bee made. Whereof wee found ≈øome there, as Rice, Corne. Fruites, Hennes, and ≈øuch like things, which the Indians dayly offered, but there came ≈øo filthie a ≈ømoke and ≈øtincke out of the place, that who≈øoeuer went n√©ere it, was almo≈øt readie to choke, the ≈øaid place being all black, ≈ømerie and foule there with Before this doore being ≈øhut, in the middle of the Church, there ≈øtoode a Calfe of ≈øtone, whereon one of our companie leaped, and laughing, began to crie out, which the Bramene that kept the Church, perceiuing, began to call and crie for helpe, ≈øo that pre≈øently many of the neighbours ranne thether, to ≈ø√©e what the cau≈øe might bee, but before the thrung of people came, we dealt ≈øo well with the Bramene (acknowledging our fault, & ≈øaying it was vnadui≈øedly done) that he was well content‚ñ™ & the people went home againe. Then wee de≈øired the Bramene to open vs the doore that ≈øtoode ≈øhut, which after much intreatie he yeelded vnto, offering fir≈øt to throw certaine A≈øhes vpon our foreheads, which we refu≈øed, ≈øo yt before hee would open vs the doore, wee were forced to promi≈øe him that we would not enter further in, theÃÑ to the doore. The doore of their Sancta Sanctorum, or rather Diabolo ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ, being opened, it ≈øhewed within like a Lime kill, being clo≈øe vaulted round about, ouer the heade without either hole or window to ca≈øt in light, but onely at the doore, neither was ther any light in al the Church, but that which came in at the doore we entered by. Within the ≈øaid cell or vault, there hung at the lea≈øt 10 ‚Ä¢ . burning Lamps, in the middle whereof ≈øtoode a little Altar and couered ouer with cloth made of cotton wool, & ouer that with pure golde, vnder the which (as the Bramene told vs ≈øat the Pagode being of cleane golde, of the bignes of a Puppet or a Baby ≈øolde in faires: hard by the Church without the great doore, ≈øtood within ye Earth a great foure cornered or ≈øquare Ce≈øterne,
he wed out of fr√©e ≈øtone, with ≈øtaires on each ≈øide to goe downe into it, full of gr√©ene, filthie and ≈øtinking water, wherin they wa≈øh them ≈øelues when they meane to enter into the Church to pray. From thence we went further, and ≈øtill as we went, in euery place wee found Pagodes hewed out of hard ≈øtones, & ≈øtanding in their holes, of ≈øuch liuely ≈øhapes and figures as wee tolde you before. The≈øe ≈øtand in the waies vnder certaine couertures, without the Churches, and haue hard by each of them a ≈ømall Ce≈øterne of water, cut out of the ≈øtone to wa≈øh their f√©ete, with halfe an Indian Nut, that hath a handle and hangeth there to take vp water withall. And this is ordained for the trauellers, that pa≈ø≈øe by, who commonly at euerie one of tho≈øe Pagodes do fall downe and make their praiers, and wa≈øh their f√©ete in tho≈øe Ce≈øternes. By the ≈øaid Pagodes, commonly doe ≈øtand two little Furnaces, with a Calfe or Cow of ≈øtone, before the which they ≈øet their offerings, which are of ≈øuch things, as are to be eaten, euerie man as his deuotion ≈øerueth, which they think the Pagode eateth in the night, but it is taken away by the Bramene. We found in euerie place ≈øuch offerings ≈øtanding, but we had little de≈øire once to ta≈øte therof, it looked ≈øo filthily, and as we had ≈øufficiently beholden their mi≈øhapen figures and mon≈øtrous Images, we returned againe vnto the village, wherein we ≈øaw the ≈øtone Church, becau≈øe the Bramene. had aduerti≈øed vs, that the ≈øame day about Euening, the Pagode ≈øhould be caried in proce≈ø≈øion, to ≈øport it ≈øelfe in the fieldes, and to fetch a circuite, which we de≈øired to ≈ø√©e. And about the time which he appointed, they rung a little Bell, which they had gotten of the Chri≈øtians, wherewith all the people began to a≈ø≈øemble, and tooke the Pagode out of his diabolicall Cell, which with great reuerence, they ≈øet in a Palamkin borne by the chiefe men of the towne, all the re≈øt with great de
‚Ä¢ otion following after, with their v≈øual noy≈øe and ≈øounds of Trumpets and other in≈øtruments, wherewith they went a rea≈øonable way round about a field, & then brought him to the ≈øtone Ce≈øtern, where wa≈øhing him verie cleane (although he were verie filthy ≈øtinking) they caried him againe into his Cel, leauing him ≈øhut herein withall his Lampes, to make good cheare, and hauing made a foule ≈ømoke and ≈øtincke about him, and euery man left his offering behind him, they went home to their hou≈øes, leauing the Bramene alone, who in ≈øt√©ed of the Pagode, made good cheare at their co≈øts, with his wife and family.

This is the maner of their ceremonies and daily ≈øuper≈øtitions, wor≈øhippings of fal≈øe gods, wherein the Deuill hath ≈øo blinded them, that thereby they are without all doubt per≈øwaded to obtaine eternall life, and tell many miracles of their Idols, whereby wee are mooued and put in mind, to call to remembraunce how much herein we are bound to God, and to giue him thankes, that it hath plea≈øed him to illuminate vs, with the truth of his holy Go≈øpel, and that we are not borne or brought vp among tho≈øe Heathens, and diueli≈øh Idolaters, and to de≈øire God that it would plea≈øe him of his gracious goodne≈ø≈øe, to open their eyes, and to giue them the truth of his holy word among them, as hee is our onely tru≈øt, for they are in all things like vs, made after Gods owne Image, and that when his good plea≈øure is, hee will loo≈øe them out of the bands of Sathan, and giue both them and vs that which is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie for our ≈øoules, Amen. The better to vnder≈øtand the maner of their diueli≈øh ≈øhapes and figures of Pagodes, I haue hereunto annexed the picture thereof, euen as they openly ≈øtand in the high wayes or hilles, with a Cow or Calfe of ≈øtone by them, al≈øo their Church called Meskita, belonging to the Mahometans and Moores, dweling in Malabar, with the Ce≈øterne of water wherein they wa≈øh them≈øelues.

div.head: The 45. Chapter. Of all the kinde of bea≈øtes, Cattell, and foules in India.
div.p:
THere is ouer all India great ≈øtore of Cattell, as Oxen, Kine, Sh√©epe, Hogges, Goates, Kids, and ≈øuch like, and verie good cheape, and in great aboundance, although the fle≈øh is not of ≈øo good a ta≈øt as that in Europe, which proc√©edeth from the heate of the countrie, & therfore it is not much e≈øt√©emed. A man may buy the be≈øt Cow in Goa, for fiue or ≈øixe Pardawes. Oxen are there little killed to eate, but are mo≈øt kept to til the land, all other things as hogges, ≈øh√©epe and goates, are ≈øold after the rate. Mutton is little e≈øt√©emed of, and not much v≈øed to be eaten for it is forbidden to ≈øuch as are ≈øicke, & the Hogs fle≈øh is much better & ≈øounder, which is rather permitted vnto ≈øicke per≈øons then Mutton. Ther are ≈øh√©epe in that countrie of fiue quarters in quantity, for that the tayle is as great, & hath as much fle≈øh vpon it, as any of the quarters, there are many Buffles, but nothing good to be eaten, vnles it be by poore people, but their Milke is very good, and is very well ≈øolde and ordinarily eaten, for you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the ≈ølaues & Canarijns in great numbers, all day going about the ≈øtr√©etes to ≈øell the Milke of Buffles,
and Goates, and excellent ≈øw√©ete Creame, and fre≈øh butter in ≈ømall p√©eces. They make likewi≈øe ≈øome ≈ømall white Chee≈øes, but they are very ≈øalte and drie: wilde Bores, ≈øome Hares, Conies, Harts and Hindes are there al≈øo to be found, but not many‚ñ™ Cockes, Capons, Phea≈øantes and Doues are there in great abundance and good cheape. In the I≈øland of Goa and there about are Sparrows, and ≈øome other ≈ømall birdes, yet not many: but on the coa≈øt of Cochin and Malabar there are very few Sparrows, nor any ≈øuch like ≈ømall birdes. There are in India many Battes, and ≈øome of them ≈øo great, that it is incredible to tell. They doe great mi≈øchiefe to tr√©es, fruites and hearbes, whereby the Canariins are con≈øtrained to ≈øet men to watch in their tr√©es, and yet they can hardly ridde them away. The Indians eate them, and ≈øay they are as good meat as a Partridge. There is a mo≈øt wonderfull number of black Crows, which do much hurt, and are ≈øo bold, that oftentimes they come flying in at their windowes, and take the meat out of the di≈øh, as it ≈øtandeth vpon the table, before them that are ≈øet downe to eate: and as I my ≈øelfe ≈øate writing aboue in a chamber of the hou≈øe, the windowes being open, one of tho≈øe Crowes flew in at the window, and picked the cotton one of mine Inke horne, and blotted all the paper that lay on my table, do what I could to let him. They ≈øitte commonly vppon the Buffles backes, and pecke off their haire, ≈øo that you ≈øhal find very few Buffles that haue any haire vpon their backes, and therefore to auoide the Crowes they get them≈øelues into mari≈øhes, and watrie places, where they ≈øtand in the water vppe to the neckes, otherwi≈øe they could neuer be rid of them. There are likewi≈øe great numbers of Rattes, and ≈øome as bigge as young Pigges, ≈øo that the Cattes dare not touch them. Sometimes they digge downe the hou≈øes, for that they vndermine the walles & foundations through and through, wherby many times the hou≈øes fall downe and are ≈øpoyled. There is another ≈øort of Rattes, that are little and reddi≈øh of haire: They are called ≈øweet ≈ømelling Rattes, for they haue a ≈ømell as if they were full of Mu≈øke. Of Ants or Pi≈ømires there is ≈øo great aboundance throughout al India, and ≈øo noy≈øome, that it is incredible to ≈øuch as haue not ≈øeene it: for that men may ≈øet nothing what≈øoeuer it be‚ñ™ that is to be eaten, or fattie, nor yet their clothes nor linnen, but you ≈øhall pre≈øently find at the lea≈øt a thou≈øand vpon it, and in the twinckling of an eye they wil pre≈øently con≈øume a loafe of bread: wherefore it is the manner throughout India, to make all the Cubbords wherein they k√©ep their victualls, and che≈øts, where their linnen and apparrell lyeth, with foure f√©ete or pillers, and vnder euery foot or piller a ≈øtone or woodden Ce≈øtern full of water, and place the Cubbord or che≈øt in the middle of the roome, not n√©ete the wall, whereby they cannot come at it, otherwi≈øe it would be ≈øpoyled, and if they do neuer ≈øo little forget to powre water into the Ce≈øternes, if it be but a Pater no≈øter while, pre≈øently ther will be ≈øo many Pi≈ømires crawling all ouer it, that it is wonderfull: ≈øo that it ≈ø√©emeth to bee a cur≈øe or plague of God ≈øent vppon that countrey. There are ≈øome likewi≈øe that v≈øe ≈øuch Ce≈øternes of water vnder their bed≈øt√©ed, becau≈øe they wold not be troubled with them as they lie in their beds, and al≈øo vnder their tables. Some men which k√©ep Canary birds, or ≈øuch ≈ømall fowles (that are brought thither from Portingall, or out of Turkey and Per≈øia for their plea≈øures) are forced to ≈øet them on a ≈øticke or pearch made for the purpo≈øe, with a Ce≈øterne of water vnder it, otherwi≈øe it would pre≈øently be killed by the Pi≈ømires: and though it hangeth in the top of the hou≈øe, yet they will come at it, if it haue a ≈øtring, to hold it by. The ≈øoldiers and poore people that haue not the meanes to buy Cubbordes with Ce≈øternes) put the bread and other victua ‚Ä¢ les which they leaue (which is not ouer much) into a cloth tyed on knots, and hang it on a nayle again≈øt a wall, and make a circle about it of Charcoale, ≈øo that the Pi≈ømires cannot get ouer, nor come at it. There is another ≈øorte of Pi≈ømires which are almo≈øt a finger long, and reddi≈øh of colour: they runne into the fields & do great hurt to the herbes, fruites and plants. Moathes & wormes which cr√©epe and eate through mens cloathes, are there in great aboundance, whereby men mu≈øt v≈øe no more cloathes nor linnen in tho≈øe countries then that he nece≈ø≈øarily and dayly weareth on his back, otherwi≈øe they are pre≈øently moatheaten and ≈øpoyled. They can hardly kepe any paper or bokes from wormes, which are like eare wormes, but they do often ≈øpoyle & con≈øume many papers & euidences of great importance. There are al≈øo many Wall-lyce.They are called W ‚Ä¢ -lyce, becau≈øe the breede „Äà‚óä„Äâ wal ‚Ä¢ : B ‚Ä¢ in true E ‚Ä¢
gli≈øh the ‚Ä¢ are called M ‚Ä¢ dges, in Latin, C ‚Ä¢ mice ‚Ä¢ . There is a kind of bea≈øt that flyeth, twice as bigge as a Bee, and is called Baratta: The≈øe creatures al≈øo do much hurt, and are commoÃÑ ly in Sugar, Hony, Butter, Oile, and al fatte wares and ≈øw√©et meats. Many of them likewi≈øe come into their che≈øtes among their clothes and linnen, which they doe al≈øo ≈øpoyle and ≈øpot. They are in great numbers and verie hurtfull. There can bee nothing ≈øo clo≈øe ≈øhut or made fa≈øt, but they wil get in & ≈øpoile it, for where they lie or be, they ≈øpot all things with their egges, which ≈øtick as fa≈øt as ≈øirop vpon a paper, ≈øo that ther may bee e≈øt√©emed

they are to draw, they binde the fat or packe fa≈øt with a rope that he may f√©ele the waight thereof, and then the keeper ≈øpeaketh vnto him: whereuppon hee taketh the corde with his ≈ønout, and windeth it about his teeth, and thru≈øteth the end into his mouth ‚Ä¢ , & ≈øo draweth it hanging after him, whether they de≈øire to haue it. If it be to be put into a boate, then they bring the boate clo≈øe to the ≈øhore of the Key, and the Elephant putteth it into the boate him≈øelfe, and with his ≈ønout gathereth ≈øtones together, which he laieth vnder the fat pipe, or packe, & with his teeth ≈øtriketh & thru≈øteth the packe or ve≈ø≈øell, to ≈øee if it lie fa≈øt or not. It will draw any great ≈øhot or other Iron work, or mettall being made fa≈øt vnto it, be it neuer ≈øo heauie, they draw fu≈øtes, ≈ømall Gallies, and other great boats, as Caruels, and ≈øuch like, as ea≈øily out of the water vpon the land, as if no man were in them: ≈øo that they ≈øerue their turnes there, euen as our ≈ølids or carts with hor≈øes doe here to carrie our wares and marchandi≈øes, their meat is rice and water, they ≈øl√©epe like kine, oxen, hor≈øes, and all foure footed bea≈øtes, and bow their kn√©es and all their members as other bea≈øts doe. In winter when it beginneth to raine, then they are vnquiet, and altogether mad, ≈øo that their k√©epers cannot rule them, and then they are let ≈øome whether out of the towne to a great tr√©e, and there tyed vnto it by the legs with a great iron chaine, where they cary him meate, and ≈øo hee lieth in the open aire, as long as he is mad, which is from Aprill to September, all the Winter time when it raineth, and then he commeth to him ≈øelfe, and beginneth to ≈øerue againe as tamely, that a maÃÑ may lie vnder his bellie, ≈øo you doe him no hurt: but he that hurteth him, hee mu≈øt take h√©ede, for they neuer forget when any man doth them iniurie, vntill they be reuenged. Their t√©eth which is the Iuor bone, is much v≈øed in India, ≈øpecially in Cambaia, whereof they make many curious p√©eces of workeman≈øhip‚ñ™ the women weare manillas, or arme bracelets therof, ten or twelue about each arme, whereby it is there much worne, and are in great numbers brought out of Aethiopia, Mo≈øambique and other places. In the I≈øland of Seylon and Pegu, they fight mo≈øt vpon Elephants, and bind ≈øwords vpon their teeth, they haue likewi≈øe woodden Ca≈øtles vppon their backes, wherein are fiue or ≈øixe men that ≈øhoot out of them with bowes, or peeces, and al≈øo ca≈øt out wildfire. They doo no other hurt but onely ≈øerue to put the enemie out of order, and to ≈øcatter them out of their rankes, but if any one of them once turneth his backe, then they all begin to turne & runne ouer their owne people, and put them all out of order. They are very fearefull of a rat or a mou≈øe, and al≈øo of the Pi≈ømyres, becau≈øe they feare they would cr√©epe into their ≈ønouts. They are likewi≈øe afraide of gunne ≈øhot and of fire, vnle≈ø≈øe by length of time they be v≈øed vnto them. When they haue the companie one of the other, the male Elephant ≈øtandeth vpon the higher ground, and the female ≈øomewhat lower. As they goe along the way, although you ≈øee them not, you may heare them a farre off by the noy≈øe of their f√©et and clapping of their eares, which they coÃÑtinually v≈øe. They are as ≈øwift ingoing almo≈øt as a hor≈øe, and are very proud, and de≈øirous of honour. When there is any great fea≈øt or holiday kept in Goa, with ≈øolemne proce≈ø≈øion, commonly the Elephants go with them, the yong before, and the old behind, and are all painted vppon their bodies with the Armes and Cro≈ø≈øes of Portingall, & haue euery one fiue or ≈øix trumpetters or players vpon the Shalmes, ≈øitting vppon them that ≈øound very plea≈øantly, wherewith they are as well plea≈øed, and goe with as great grauitie, and in as good order as if they were men. It hapned in Goa, that an Elephant ≈øhuld draw a great fu≈øt out of the water vnto the land, which fu≈øt was ≈øo great and heauie, that hee could not doe it alone, ≈øo that they mu≈øt haue another to help him: whereupon the keeper chid him, v≈øing many hard wordes, ≈øaying, that he was idle and weak, and that it would be an euerla≈øting ≈øhame for him, that they mu≈øt fetch another to helpe him, wherewith the Elephant was ≈øo de≈øperate, that he thru≈øt away his fellow (which was brought to help him) and beg ‚Ä¢ n fre≈øhly againe to draw, with ≈øo great a force, more then hee was well able to doe, that with extreame labour hee bur≈øt and fell downe ≈øtarke dead in the place. At ≈øuch time as I was to make my voyage froÃÑ Cochin to Portingall, the Rudder of our ≈øhip was out of order, ≈øo that it mu≈øt of force be brought on land to make it fit againe, and ≈øo it was drawn to the riuer ≈øide at the ≈øterne of the boat, which the Elephant ≈øhould draw on land vppon two bordes, that it might ≈ølide vp, and becau≈øe it was heauie, (as the Rudder of a ≈øhip of 1400. or 1600. tunnes requireth) as al≈øo that the Elephant was as yet but yong, and not growne to his ful ≈øtrength, ≈øo that he could not draw it out alone, yet he did the be≈øt hee could: but ≈øeeing hee could not doe it, he fell on his fore legges, and began to crie and weepe, that the teares ran out of his eyes, and becau≈øe many of vs ≈øtoode vpon the ≈øhore to behold this ≈øight, the k√©eper began to chide him, and with hard words to cur≈øe him, becau≈øe he ≈øhamed him thus in pre≈øence of ≈øo
many men, not to be able to draw vp ≈øuch a thing: but what ≈øtrength or labour ≈øoeuer the Elephant v≈øed, he could not doe it alone, but when they brought another Elephant to help him, they both together drewe it halfe out of the water, ≈øo that it lay partly vppon the bordes. The fir≈øt Elephant, perceiuing that with his head and teeth thru≈øt the other Elephant away, and would haue no more helpe, but drew it out him≈øelfe: whereby it may bee con≈øidered, that they are in vnder≈øtanding, and de≈øire of commendation like vnto men.

They are likewi≈øe very thankefull and mindfull of any good done vnto them. When new yeares day coÃÑmeth, their k√©epers v≈øe of coÃÑmon cu≈øtome to a≈øke new yeres gifts of the Viceroy, the Archbi≈øhop, and other gouernours and Gentlemen, and then the Elephants come to the dore and bow their heads downe, and when any thing is giuen, they kn√©ele on their knees with great lowline≈ø≈øe, and thankefulne≈ø≈øe, for the good d√©edes ≈øo done vnto their keepers (which they thinke to bee done vnto them≈øelues.) They v≈øe as they pa≈ø≈øe by ≈øuch hou≈øes, to bow their heads at the dores, as al≈øo when they pa≈ø≈øe by the Church doores, and by Cro≈ø≈øes, which their Ma≈øters teach them. They haue a cu≈øtome that they goe often into the market where herbes are ≈øold, as Reddi≈øh, Lettice, Colworts, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe, and tho≈øe that are liberall to the Elephant, doe v≈øe to throw ≈øomething before him. Among the re≈øt there was one Hearb wife which alwaies v≈øed to throw ≈øomething of her wares before the Elephant. Now wheÃÑ the time came on that the Elephant groweth mad, as I ≈øaid before, they v≈øe to goe with them thr√©e or foure dayes or a weeke about the ≈øtr√©ets before they bind them vp, (beeing as then but halfe mad) to a≈øk ≈øomething of euery body for the f√©eding of the mad ElephaÃÑt in the winter time. And going thus about the ≈øtr√©etes, the ma≈øter is not able to rule him, for hee runneth about with his head downeward, and by his roaring giueth the people warning to beware, and when he findeth or ≈ø√©eth no man, hee leapeth and ouerthroweth what≈øoeuer he m√©eteth withall, whereby he ‚Ä¢ maketh great ≈øport and pa≈øtime, much like to the baiting of Oxen in Spaine, which neuer cea≈øeth, vntil one, two, or more of them be ≈ølaine, the like rule is kept with the mad Elephant in India. It chanced in this running about, that the Elephhnt ran through the ≈øtr√©ets, and in ha≈øte at vnwares came into the market, throwing downe all that was in his way, whereat euery man was aba≈øht, and leauing their ware, ranne to ≈øaue them≈øelues from being ouer run by the Elephant, and by meanes of the noy≈øe and prea≈øe of people, they fell one ouer another, as in ≈øuch ca≈øes is commonly ≈øeene. Among them was this woman, that alwaies v≈øed to giue the Elephant ≈øome thing to eat, which had a little childe in the market lying by her in a ba≈øket, and by the ha≈øtie ri≈øing vp and throng of the people, the woman ran into a hou≈øe, not hauing time to ≈ønatch vp her Child, and take it with her, and when the Elephant was alone in the market place, where he roared vp and downe, ouerthrowing all thinges that were before him, hee came by the child (that as I ≈øaid) lay ≈øtill in the market, and as euery man looked, ≈øpecially the mother, which cried out, & verily thought that the Elephant had taken it and ca≈øt it on his ≈øhoulder and ≈øpoiled it as he did all other thinges. Hee on the contrarie notwith≈øtanding all his madne≈ø≈øe, b√©eing mindfull of the good will and liberalitie of the childes mother dayly v≈øed vnto him, tooke vp the child hand≈øomlie and tenderly with his ≈ønout, and layde it ≈øoftly vpon a ≈øtall by a ≈øhop ≈øide, which done, hee began againe to v≈øe the ≈øame order of ≈øtamping, crying, and clapping as he had done at the fir≈øt, to the great wondering of al that beheld it, ≈øpecially to the ea≈øe and ioy of the mother, that had recouered her child ≈øound and well againe. The≈øe and ≈øuch like examples do often happen in India, which would be too long to rehear≈øe, and therfore I thought good onely to ≈øet the≈øe thr√©e or foure before your eyes, as things worthy memorie, thereby to teach vs to bee mindfull of all good d√©eds done vnto vs, and with thankfulnes to requite them, con≈øidering that the≈øe dumbe bea≈øtes doe ≈øhew, vs as it were in a gla≈ø≈øe, that wee ≈øhould doe ≈øo as they doe, not onley when they haue their ≈øence and vnder≈øtanding, but (which is more to bee wondred at) when they are out of their wits & ≈øtarke mad: whereas men many times hauing all their vnder≈øtanding, and their fiue wits ≈øouÃÑd, do ca≈øt the benefits, which they haue receiued behind their backs, yea, and at this day doe reward all good d√©edes with vnthankfulne≈ø≈øe, God amend it.

div.head: The 47. Chapter. Of the Abadas or Rhinoceros.
div.p: THe Abada or Rhinoceros is not in India, but onely in Bengala, and Patane. They are le≈ø≈øe and lower than the Elephant. It hath a ≈øhort horne vpon the nole, in the hinder part ≈øoÃÑwhat big, & toward the end ≈øharper, of a browne blew, and whiti≈øh colour, it hath a ≈ønout like a hogge, and the ≈økin vppon the vpper part of his body is all wrinckled, as if it were armed with Shields or Targets. It is a great enemie of the Elephant. Some thinke it is the right Vnicorne, becau≈øe that as yet there hath no other bin found, but only by heare≈øay, and by the pictures of them. The Portingales and tho≈øe of Bengala affirme, that by the Riuer Ganges in the Kingdome of Bengala, are many of the≈øe Rhinoceros, which when they will drinke, the other bea≈øts ≈øtand and waite vpon them, till the Rhinoceros hath drinke, & thru≈øt their horne into the water, for he cannot drink but his horne mu≈øt be vnder the water, becau≈øe it ≈øtandeth ≈øo clo≈øe vnto his no≈øe, and muzzle: and then after him all the other bea≈øtes doe drinke. Their hornes in India are much e≈øt√©emed and v≈øed again≈øt all venime, poy≈øon, and many other di≈øea≈øes: likewi≈øe his teeth, clawes, fle≈øh, ≈økin and blood, and his very dung and water and all what≈øoeuer is about him, is much e≈øt√©emed in India, and v≈øed for the curing of many di≈øea≈øes and ≈øickne≈ø≈øes, which is very good and mo≈øt true, as I my ≈øelfe by experience haue found, but it is to be vnder≈øtood, that all Rhinocerotes are not a like good, for there are ≈øome who≈øe hornes are ≈øold for one, two, or thr√©e hundred Pardawes the p√©ece, and there are others of the ≈øame colour and greatnes that are ≈øold but for three or foure Pardawes, which the Indians know and can di≈øcerne. The cau≈øe is that ≈øome Rhinocerotes, which are found in certaine places in the countrie of Bengala haue this vertue, by rea≈øon of the hearbes which that place only y√©eldeth and bringeth foorth, which in other places is not ≈øo, and this e≈øtimation is not onely held of the horne, but of all other things in his whole body, as I ≈øaide before. There are al≈øo by Malacca, Sion, and Bengala ≈øome goates that are wild, who≈øe hornes are e≈øt√©emed for the be≈øt hornes again≈øt poy≈øon, and all venime that may bee found: they are called Cabras de Mato, yt is, wilde Goates. The≈øe hornes are of great account in India, and much e≈øt√©emed, and are oftentimes by experience found to bee verie good, wherof I my ≈øelf am a good witnes, hauing prooued the ≈øame. In the yeare 1581. as king Phillip was at Lisbone, there was a Rhinoceros and an Elephant brought him out of India for a pre≈øent, and he cau≈øed them both to be led with him vnto Madril, where the Spani≈øh Court is holden. This ≈øhal ≈øuffice as touching bea≈øtes and birdes in tho≈øe countries, although there are many others which are not ≈øo well knowne: therefore I haue heere ≈øet downe none but ≈øuch as are dayly ≈ø√©ene there in the land, and well known by euery man in the countrie.

div.head: The 48. Chapter. Of the Fi≈øhes and other bea≈øtes in the Seas of India.
div.p:
FI≈øh in India is verie plentifull, and ≈øome very plea≈øant and ≈øw√©ete. The be≈øt Fi≈øh is called Mordexiin, Pampano, and Tatiingo. There is a fi≈øh called Piexe Serra, which is cut in round p√©eces as we cut Salmon, and ≈øalt it. It is very good, and wil indure long to carie ouer ≈øea in ≈øhips for victuals. Mo≈øt of their fi≈øh is eaten with rice, that they ≈ø√©eth in broth which they put vpon the rice, and is ≈øomewhat ≈øowre, as if it were ≈øodden in goo≈øeberries, or vnripe grapes, but it ta≈øteth well, and is called Car ‚Ä¢ iil, which is their dayly meat, the rice is in ≈øtead of bread: there are al≈øo good Shads, Soles, and other ≈øortes of fi≈øhes. The Garnaten is the be≈øt & greate≈øt that euer I ≈øaw any, for that with a dozen of them a man may make a good meale. The Crabs and Creui≈øhes are verie good and maruellous great, that it is a wonder to tell, and that which is more wonderful, when the moone is in the full, here with vs it is a common ≈øaying, that then Crabbes, and creui≈øhes are at the be≈øt, but there it is cleane contrarie: for with a full moone they are emptie and out of ≈øea≈øon, and with a new moone good and full. There are al≈øo Mu≈økles and ≈øuch like ≈øhelfi≈øhes of many ≈øorts, oy≈øters very many, ≈øpecially at Cochin; & from thence to the cape de Comoriin. Fi≈øh in India is very good cheape, for ye with the valew of a ≈ø ‚Ä¢ iuers of their money, a man may buy as much fi≈øh and rice to it, as will ≈øerue fiue or ≈øixe men for a good meale, after the Spani≈øh manner, which is very good cheape, in re≈øpect
of their victuals in Spaine and Portingall.

There is in the riuers and al≈øo in the Sea along the coa≈øt of India great ≈øtore of fi≈øhes, which the Portingalls call Tubaron or Hayen. This fi≈øh doth great mi≈øchiefe, and deuoureth many men that fi≈øh for pearles, and therefore they dare not ≈øwimme in the riuers for feare of the≈øe fi≈øhes, but doe v≈øe to bath them≈øelues in ce≈øternes, made for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, as I ≈øaid before. As our ≈øhip lay in the Riuer of Cochin, readie to ≈øayle from thence to Portingall, it hapned that as we were to hang on our rutter, which as then was mended, the ma≈øter of the ≈øhip, with 4 or 5. ≈øaylers, went with the Boat to put it on, and an other Sayler beeing made fa≈øt with a corde about his middle, and tied to the Ship, hung downe with halfe his body into the water to place the ≈øame vpon the hookes, and while he hung in the water, there came one of tho≈øe Hayens, and bit one of his legs, to the middle of his thigh, cleane off at a bit, notwith≈øtanding that the Ma≈øter ≈øtroke at him with an oare, and as the pore man was putting downe his arme to feele his wound, the ≈øame Fi≈øh at the ≈øecond time for another bit did bite off his hand and arme aboue the elbow, and al≈øo a p√©ece of his buttucke.

The Ma≈øter and all the Saylers in the Boate not being able to help him, although they both ≈øtroke and flang at it with ≈øtaues and oares, and in that mi≈øerable ca≈øe the pore man was carried into the Ho≈øpitall, where we left him with ≈ømall hope of life, and how he ≈øped after that, God knoweth, for the next day we ≈øet ≈øayle and put to Sea. The≈øe and ≈øuch like chances happen dayly by tho≈øe fi≈øhes in India, as well in the ≈øea, as in the Riuers, ≈øpecially among the Fi≈øhers for Pearles, whereof many loo≈øe their liues.

In the Riuer of Goa in Winter time when the mouth of the Riuer was ≈øhut vp, as commonly at that time it is, the fi≈øhermen tooke a fi≈øh of a mo≈øt wonderfull and ≈øtrange forme, ≈øuch as I thinke was neuer ≈øeene eyther in India, or in any other place, which for the ≈øtrangenes therof was pre≈øented to my Lord the Archbi≈øhop, the picture whereof by his commandement was painted, and for a wonder ≈øent to the King of Spaine.

It was in bignes as great as a middle ≈øized Dogge with a ≈ønout like a hogge, ≈ømall eies, no eares, but two holes where his eares ≈øhould bee, it had foure f√©et like an Elephant, the tayle beginning ≈øomewhat vppon the backe broad, and then flatte, and at the verie end round and ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe. It ranne a a long the hall vppon the flore, and in euerie place of the hou≈øe ≈ønorting like a hogge. The whole body, head, taile, & legs being couered with ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ales of a thumb breadth, harder than Iron, or ≈øteele: Wee hewed and layd vppon them with weapons, as if men ≈øhould beate vpon an Anuill, and when wee ≈øtroke vppon him, hee rouled him≈øelfe in a heape, head and f√©ete altogether, ≈øo that hee lay like a round ball, wee not beeing able to iudge where hee clo≈øed him≈øelfe together, neyther could wee with anie in≈øtrument or ≈øtrength of hands open him againe, but letting him alone and not touching him, hee opened him≈øelfe and ranne away as I ≈øaid before.

And becau≈øe I am now in hand with Fi≈øhes of India, I will here declare a ≈øhort and true Hi≈øtorie of a Fi≈øh, although to ≈øome it may ≈øeeme incredible, but it ≈øtandeth painted in the Viceroyes Pallace in India, and was ≈øet downe by true and credible witne≈ø≈øes that it was ≈øo, and therefore it ≈øtandeth there for memorie of a wonderfull thing, together with the names and ≈øurnames of the ≈øhip, Captaine day, & yere when it was done, and as yet there are many men liuing at this day, that were in the ≈øame ≈øhippe and aduenture, for that it is not long ≈øince, and it was thus. That a ≈øhip ≈øayling from Mo≈øambique into India, and they hauing faire weather, a good fore winde, as much as the Sayles might beare before the winde for the ≈øpace of fourteene dayes together, directing their cour≈øe towards the Equinoctiall line, euery day as they tooke the height of the Sunne, in ≈øtead of dimini≈øhing or le≈ø≈øening their degr√©es, according to the Winde and cour≈øe they had and held, they found them ≈øelues ≈øtill contrarie, and euery day further backewards then they were, to the great admiration and wondering of them all, and contrarie to all rea≈øon and mans vnder≈øtanding, ≈øo that they did not only wonder theraf, but were much aba≈øht beeing ≈øtedfa≈øtly per≈øwaded that they were bewitched, for they knew very well by experience, that the ≈øtreame or cour≈øe of the water in tho≈øe countries did not driue them backe, nor withholde them contrarie to all Art of Nauigation, whereupon they were all in great perplexity and feare, ≈øtanding ≈øtill and beholding each other, not once knowing the cau≈øe thereof.

At ye la≈øt the chiefe Bote≈øon whoÃÑ they call the ma≈øters mate, looking by chance ouerbord towards the beakhead of the ≈øhip, he e≈øpied a great broad taile of a Fi≈øh that had winded it ≈øelfe as it were about the beakehead the body therof beeing vnder the keele,
and the heade vnder the Ruther, ≈øwimming in that manner, and drawing the ≈øhippe with her again≈øt the wind and their right cour≈øe: whereby pre≈øently they knewe the cau≈øe of their ≈øo going backewards: ≈øo that hauing at the la≈øt ≈øtricken long with ≈øtaues and other weapons vppon the fi≈øhes taile, in the ende they ≈øtroke it off, and thereby the fi≈øh left the ≈øhip‚ñ™ after it had layne 14 dayes vnder the ≈øame, drawing the ≈øhip with it again≈øt wind and weather: for which cau≈øe the Viceroy in Goa cau≈øed it to be painted in his pallace for a perpetuall memory, where I haue often read it, with the day and time, and the name both of the ≈øhippe and Captaine, which I can not well remember, although it bee no great matter.

There are many other fi≈øhes in tho≈øe ≈øeas and riuers. In the Riuer of Bengala called G ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ , and by Malacca there are Crocodiles, and other ≈øea Serpents of an vn≈øpeakeable greatnes, which often times doe ouerturne ≈ømal fi≈øher boates and other ≈øentes, and deuoure the men that are therein: and ≈øome of them creeping out of the water vnto the lande do ≈ønatch vppe diuers men, which they hale after them, and then kill them and eate them, as it dayly happeneth in tho≈øe Countries. There are by Malacca certaine fi≈øh ≈øhelles found on the ≈øhore, much like Scalop ≈øhelles, ≈øo great and ≈øo heauie that two ≈øtrong men haue enough to doe with a Leauer to draw one of them after them. Within them there is a fi≈øh which they of Malacca do eate. There were ≈øome of tho≈øe ≈øhelles in the balla≈øt of the ≈øhippe that came from Malacca, & kept company with vs from the I≈øland of S. H ‚Ä¢ len ‚Ä¢ , to the I≈ølande of Tercera, where the ≈øhippe was ca≈øt away, and ≈øome of the ≈øhelles taken out of her, which the Ie≈øuites of Malacca had ≈øent vnto Lisbone, to ≈øet in the wals of their church and Cloy≈øter, which they there had cau≈øed to bee made, and mo≈øt ≈øumptuou≈øly built. The like happened to a ≈øhippe called S. Peter, that ≈øayled from Co
‚Ä¢
towardes Portingall, that fell vpon a ≈øande, which at this day is called after the ≈øame ≈øhips name S. Peters ≈øande lying from Goa South Southea≈øt vnder 6. degrees vpon the South ≈øide, where it was ca≈øt away, but all the men ≈øaued them≈øelues, and of the woode of the ≈øhippe that was ca≈øt away, they made a ≈ømall Barke or Caruell, wherewith they all arriued in India: & while they were bu≈øied about building of their ≈øhip, they found ≈øuch great Crabbes vpon that ≈øand, and in ≈øo great numbers, that they were con≈øtrained to make a ≈øconce, and by good watch to defend them≈øelues from theÃÑ, for that they were of an vnrea≈øonable greatnes, ≈øo that whom≈øoeuer they got vnder their claws, it co≈øt him his life: this is mo≈øt true and not long ≈øince done, for that in the ≈øame ≈øhippe wherein I came out of India into Portingal, there were two of the Saylors that had beene in the ≈øame ≈øhippe called S. Peter, and affirmed it for a truth, as it is likewi≈øe paynted in diuers places in Goa, for a perpetual memory, which I thought good to ≈øet downe, to ≈øhewe the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe fi≈øhes: and it is to be thought that there are many other fi≈øhes and ≈øea mon≈øters, as yet to vs not known, which are dayly found by ≈øuch as continually v≈øe to ≈øea, and doo often meete with them. And this ≈øhall be ≈øufficient for the fi≈øhes & ≈øea mon≈øters of India.

div.head: The 49. Chapter Of all fruits, trees, plants, and common hearbs in India, and fir≈øt of a certain fruit called Ananas.
div.p:
ANanas by the Canarijns called Anana≈øa, Anno ‚Ä¢ . D. P. by the Bra≈øilians Nana, and by others in Hi≈øpaniola Iaiama: by the Spaniards in Bra≈øilia Pinas, becau≈øe of a certain re≈øemblance which the fruite hath with the Pineapple. It commeth out of the Prouince of Sancta Croce, fir≈øt brought into Bra ‚Ä¢ lia, theÃÑ to the Spani≈øh Indies, and afterwardes into the Ea≈øt Indies, where nowe they grow in great abundance, of the bignes of Citrones, or of a common Melon. They are of a faire colour, of a yellow greene, which greennes when it is ripe vadeth away. It is ≈øweet in ta≈øte, & plea≈øant in ≈ømell, like to an Abricot, ≈øo that by the very ≈ømell of them a man may know the hou≈øes wherein the≈øe fruites are kept. A far off they ≈øhew like Artich ‚Ä¢ kes, but they haue no ≈øuch ≈øharpe prickes on their leaues: the plants or ≈øtalkes whereon they grow are as bigge as a Thi≈øtle, and haue a roote al≈øo like a Thi≈øtle, wheron groweth but one Nut in the middle of the ≈øtalke, and rounde about it certaine ≈ømall ≈øtalkes whereon ≈øome fruite likewi≈øe doeth often times grow. I haue had ≈øome of the Slips here
in my garden, that were brought mee out of Bra≈øilia, but our colde countrey could not brooke them. This fruite is hot and moi≈øt, and is eaten out of wine like a Peach, light of di≈øge≈øture, but ≈øuperfluous in nouri≈øhing: It inflameth and heateth, and con≈øumeth the gums; by rea≈øon of the ≈ømall threedes that run through it. There are many ≈øortes of this fruite among the Bra≈øilians, which according to the difference of their ≈øpeeches haue likewi≈øe differeÃÑt names, whereof three kindes are ≈øpecially named and written of. The fir≈øt called Iaiama, which is the longe≈øt & the be≈øt of ta≈øte, and the ≈øub≈øtance of it yellow. The ≈øecond Bomama, that is white within, and not very ≈øweet of ta≈øte. The thirde Iaiagna, which is whiti≈øh within, and ta≈øteth like Reni≈øh Wine. The≈øe fruites likewi≈øe do grow ≈øome of them≈øelues as if they were planted, and are called wilde Anana≈ø≈øes, and ≈øome growe in gardens, whereof we now make mention. The wilde growe vppon ≈øtalkes of the length of a pike or Speare, rounde, and of the bigne≈ø≈øe of an Orange, ful of thorns: the leaues likewi≈øe haue ≈øharpe pricks, and round about full of ≈øoft „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the fruite is little eaten, although they are of an indifferent plea≈øant ta≈øte. The whole plantes with the rootes are ful of iuyce, which being taken about ≈øeueÃÑ or eight of the clocke in a morning, and drunke with Sugar, is holden for a mo≈øt certaine remedie again≈øt the heate of the liuer and the kidneyes, again≈øt exulcerated kidneyes, mattery water and excoriation of the yarde. The Arabians commend it to be good again≈øt Saynt Anthonies fire, and call it Queura. He that is de≈øirous to reade more hereof, let him reade Co≈øta in the proper Chapter of Ananas, and Ou ‚Ä¢ edius in the eight booke, and eighteenth Chapter: and Theuetius in his ob≈øeruations of America, in the ≈øix and fortieth Chapter. Ananas pre≈øerued in Sugar are like Cocumbers, whereof I haue had many.

Ananas is one of the be≈øt fruites, and of be≈øt ta≈øte in all India, but it is not a proper fruit of India it ≈øelfe, but a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ fruite, for it was fir≈øt brought by the ‚Ä¢ ortingalles out of Bra≈øill ‚Ä¢ , ≈øo that at the „Äà‚óä„Äâ it ‚Ä¢ is ≈øold for a noueltie, at a
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , and ≈øometimes more, but now there are ≈øo many growen in the Countrey, that they are very good cheape. The time when they are rype is in Lent, for then they are be≈øt and ≈øweete≈øt of ta≈øte. They are as bigge as a Melon, and in forme like the heade of a Di≈øtaffe, without like a Pine apple, but ≈øofte in cutting: of colour redde and greeni≈øh: They growe about halfe a fadome high from the grounde‚ñ™ not much more or le≈ø≈øe. the leaues are like the Hearbe that is brought out of Spayne, called Aloe, or Semper viua, becau≈øe it is alwayes greene, and therefore it is hanged on the beames of hou≈øes, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and at the endes ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe, as if they were cut out. When they eate them, they pull off the ≈øhell, and cutte them into ≈øhees or peeces, as men de≈øire to haue them dre≈øt. div.head:
The 50. Chapter. O ‚Ä¢
Iaqua or Iaacca.

p.hi: THis fruite groweth in Calecut, and in ≈øome other places of India, neere to the Sea,

and vpon ryuers or waters ≈øides. It is a certaine fruite that in Malabar is called Iaca, in Canara and Gu≈øurate, Panar and Pana≈øa, by the Arabians, Panax, by the Per≈øians, Fanax. This fruite groweth vpon great trees, not out of the branches like other fruites, but out of the body of the tree, aboue the earth, and vnder the leaues. The leaues are as bigge as a mans hand, greeni≈øh, with a thick hard veine that goeth cleane thorough the length of them. The ≈ømalle≈øt of this fruite, ≈øpecially that which groweth in Malabar, and is the be≈øt of all, is greater then our greate≈øt Pumpians, (I meane of Portingall.) They are without couered with a hard ≈øhell, of colour greene, otherwi≈øe it is much like the Pine apple, ≈øaue onely that the ≈øhell or huske ≈øeemeth to be ≈øet ful of pointed Diamants, which haue certaine greene and ≈øhort hookes at the endes, but at the verie points are blacki≈øh, and yet are neither ≈øharpe not pricking although they ≈øeeme ≈øo to be. The≈øe fruites are like Melons, and ≈øometimes greater, outwardly greene, and inwardly Yelow, with many ≈øoft prickles, apparrelled (as it were) like a Hedgehog. Tho≈øe that grow in Goa are not ≈øo good, nor of ≈øo good a ta≈øte as tho≈øe in Malabar. This fruit being ripe, which is commonly in December, ≈ømelleth very ≈øweete, and is of two ≈øorts, wherof the be≈øt is called Barca, the other Papa, which is not ≈øo good, and yet in handling it is ≈øoft like the other. The be≈øt co≈øt about 40. Maruedies, which is ≈øomewhat more then a Ryall of plate, and being ripe they are of a blacki≈øh colour, and with a hard huske, the outward part thereof which compa≈ø≈øeth the Nut, is of many ta≈øtes, ≈øome times it ta≈øteth like a Melon, ≈øomtimes like a Peach, and ≈øomewhat plea≈øanter, (but in ta≈øte it is mo≈øt like vnto the Peach) ≈øomtimes like a Hony Combe, ≈øometimes like a Citron, but they are hard to dige≈øt, & doe commonly come vp againe out of the ≈øtomacke vndige≈øted, euen as they were eaten. This fruit being cut vp and opened longwi≈øe in the middle, is white within, and full of meate, with many partitions ful of long Nuts, thicker and greater then Dates, with a graye s ‚Ä¢ n, the Nut white, like our Che≈ønuts. Being greene they eate earthy, and ≈øharpe of ta≈øte, and ingender much Wine, but being ro≈øted or ≈øoden they are like our Che≈ønuts & are verie plea≈øant‚ñ™ they increa≈øe lu≈øt, for the which cau≈øe they are mo≈øt v≈øed to bee eaten: They ≈øtop the Flux of the belly, the skin about them is heauie for the maw, and corrupting therein, doth breed many euil and pe≈øtilent humors, wherof ≈øuch as eate much of this fruit, doe ea≈øily get the Plague, which the Indians call Morxi. He that de≈øireth to ≈øee more hereof, let him Reade Lodouicus Romanus, in his fifth Booke and fifteene Chapter of his Nauigations, and Chri≈øtopherus a Co≈øta in his Cap. of Iaca, & Gracia ab Horto, in the ≈øecond booke and fourth Chapter.

div.p:
Iaaca grow on great tr√©es like Nut trees, & onely on the ≈øea ≈øhores, that is to ≈øay, in ≈øuch countries as border on the ≈øeas, cleane contrarie vnto al other fruites, for they grow aboue the earth, vpon the trunkes or bodies of the trees, & vpon the great thick branches, but where the branches ≈øpread abroad, being ≈ømall and full of leaues, there groweth none: they are as big as a great Melon, and much like it of fa≈øhion, although ≈øome of them are as great as a man can well lift vp, and outwardlie are like the Ananas, but ≈ømoother, and of a darke gr√©ene colour, the fruit within is in hu≈økes, like Che≈ønuttes, but of an other forme, and euerie hu≈øke hath a Nutte, which is half white, the re≈øt yealowi≈øh, and ≈øticketh to a mans handes like honnie, when it is in the beehyues among the waxe, and for toughne≈ø≈øe & in ta≈øte for ≈øweetnes not much vnlike. The fruite is on the out ≈øide like a Che≈ønutte, and in forme or fa≈øhion like an Acorne, when the gr√©ene knob that groweth vnder it is taken away, and of that bigne≈ø≈øe and ≈øome what bigger: this fruite that is outmo≈øt
being eaten, the re≈øt is good to be ro≈øted or ≈øodden, and are not much vnlike in ta≈øte to the Che≈ønuts of Europa. There are of the≈øe hu≈økes in euery Iaacca a hundreth and more, according to the greatnes thereof. There are two ≈øorts of them, the be≈øt are called Gira≈øal, and the common and lea≈øt e≈øt√©emed, Chamba≈øal, although in fa≈øhion and tr√©es there is no difference, ≈øaue that the Gira≈øals haue a ≈øw√©eter ta≈øte. By this name Gira≈øal & ChaÃÑ ba≈øal, the Indians doe make difference of their Ryce, and other things: they call the be≈øt Gira≈øal and the wor≈øt Chamba≈øal, after the which names they haue their prices: the Iaaccas continue all the yeare.

div.head: The 51. Chapter. Of Mangas.
div.p:
MAngas growe vppon great trees like Iaca trees, they haue many branches, and are of quantitie as bigge as a great Goo≈øe Egge,Annota. D. Pall. and in ≈øome places of India doe weigh two pounds, and more the peece. And many times there are of ≈øeuerall colours vpon one tree, ≈øome being a light green, others Yelow, & ≈øome a reddi≈øh green, and for ≈ømel and ta≈øte plea≈øant, and not being peri≈øhed, are of better ta≈øt then any Peach. As touching their name, they are commonly called Mangas, in Canarijn Ambo, of the Turkes and Per≈øians, Amba. They beare fruit vpon the trees, from Aprill to Nouember, according to the ≈øituation of the place, they growe in many places, but the be≈øt in Ormus, where before all other fruites they are de≈øired, next vnto them are tho≈øe that grow in Gu≈øarate, which for their goodnes are called Gu≈øarates, they are ≈ømaller then the other, but of better ta≈øte & ≈øauor, within they haue a ≈ømall Nut, or kernell. A thirde ≈øort there is that groweth in Balagatte, and tho≈øe are the greate≈øt, for there are of them that waigh two pound & a quarter, of a verie plea≈øant ta≈øte. Euen ≈øo are tho≈øe that grow in Charanna, Quindor, Madanagor, and Dultabado, being the chiefe townes in the kingdome of Ni≈øamoxa, and like vnto them are the Mangas of Bengala, Pegu, and Malacca. The ≈øhel of them being taken off, is eateÃÑ in ≈ølices with wine‚ñ™ and al≈øo without Wine, as wee eate Peaches, they are al≈øo pre≈øerued; the better to keepe them, either in Suger, Vineger, Oyle, or Salt, like Oliues in Spaine, and being a little opened with a Knife, they are ≈øtuffed with greene Ginger, headed Garlike, Mu≈øtard or ≈øuch like, they are ≈øometimes eaten only with Salt, and ≈øomtimes ≈øodden with Rice, as we doe Oliues, and being thus con≈øerued and ≈øodden, are brought to ≈øell in the market. This fruite is colde and moy≈øt, although commonly they e≈øteeme it to bee hotte, & ≈øay, it ingendereth a paine and griping in the maw, of ≈øuch as eate it, and more ouer the Heathen Phy≈øitians ≈øay, it is hotte, and reiecte, or refu≈øe it, becau≈øe it ingendereth Saint Anthonies fire, Carbuncles, hotte burning Feauers, and ≈øwellings, with ≈øcabbes and ≈øcuruines: which I thinke happeneth to men that eate this fruite, and being eaten, lyeth corrupted in their Mawes, or rather by rea≈øon of the great heate and ≈øea≈øon of the yeare. At the time when this fruite is ripe, many doe fall into the forenamed di≈øea≈øes, although they eate none of this fruite. Before this fruite is fully ripe, it is ≈øomewhat hard of ta≈øte, ≈øpecially the inner part next to the Nut, but being ripe, verie ≈øweete and ≈øauorie. The Nut that is within it, hath a hard huske or ≈øhell, with hard threeds about it, wherein groweth a long Nut, as big as an Acorne, white within, and outwardly couered with a thin white skin. Being raw it is bitter of ta≈øt, therefore it is good again≈øt wormes, and loo≈øenes of the belly: again≈øt wormes when it is eaten raw, and again≈øt loo≈øene≈ø≈øe of the belly when it is ro≈øted, and then it ta≈øteth like a ro≈øted Acorne. There is an other kinde of this fruite without ≈øtones which is very plea≈øant. There is al≈øo a third ≈øorte, which is wilde, called Mangas Brauas, and is verie poy≈øon, wher-with they poy≈øon each other, for who≈øoeuer eateth but a ≈ømall quantitie thereof, dyeth pre≈øently. They doe
≈øometime mingle Oyle with it, to make it ≈øtronger, and being taken in that ≈øort, how≈øoeuer it be, it killeth very quickly, and as yet there was neuer any remedie found again≈øt it. This fruite is light greene, and ≈øomewhat bright, full of white milky Iuice, and but a litle meate. The Nut is couered with a hard ≈øhel as bigge as a Quince.

Mangas groweth vpon tr√©es like Iaaca tr√©es: they are as big as a great Peach, but ≈øomewhat long, and a little crooked, of colour cleere, gr√©en, ≈øomewhat yealowi≈øh, and ≈øome times reddi≈øh: it hath within it a ≈øtone bigger then a Peach ≈øtone, but it is not good to be eaten: the Mangas is inwardly yealowi≈øh, but in cutting it is wateri≈øh, yet ≈øome not ≈øo much: they haue a verie plea≈øant ta≈øte, better then a Peach, and like the Annanas, which is ye be≈øt & ye mo≈øt profitable fruit in al India, for it yeeldeth a great quaÃÑtity for food & ≈øu≈øtenance of the countrie people, as Oliues do in Spaine and Portingale: they are gathered when they are gr√©ene, and con≈øerued, and for the mo≈øt part ≈øalted in pots, and commonlie v≈øed to be eaten with Rice, ≈øodden in pure water, the hu≈øke being whole, and ≈øo eaten with ≈øalt Mangas, which is the continuall food for their ≈ølaues and coÃÑmon people, or el≈øe ≈øalt dryed fi≈øh in ≈øt√©ed of Mangas, without bread, for Rice is in diuers places in ≈øt√©ed of bread. The≈øe ≈øalted Mangas are in cutting like the white Spani≈øh Oliues, and almo≈øt of the ≈øame ta≈øte, but ≈øomewhat ≈øauorie and not ≈øo bitter, yet a little ≈øowre, and are in ≈øo great abundance, that it is wonderful: there are others that are ≈øalted and ≈øtuffed with ≈ømall p√©eces of gr√©ene Ginger, and Garlike ≈øodden: tho≈øe they call Mangas Recheadas or Machar: they are likewi≈øe much v≈øed, but not ≈øo common as the other, for they are co≈øtlie and more e≈øteemed: the≈øe are kept in pots with Oyle and Vineger ≈øalted. The ≈øea≈øon when Mangas are ripe is in Lent, and continueth till the Moneth of Augu≈øt.

div.head: The 52. Chapter. Of Caions.
div.p: THis fruite groweth on great trees, not much vnlike Apple trees (but the yong trees haue leaues, like Lawrell or Bayleaues) they are of a pale greene and thicke, with white blo≈ø≈øoms like Oringe trees, but thicker of leaues, yet not ≈øo ≈øweete of ≈ømell. The fruit is in greatne≈ø≈øe and forme like a Goo≈øe Egge, or a great Apple, verie yellow & of good ≈øauor, moy≈øt or ≈øpungie within, and ful of Iuice, like Lemmons, but without kernels: ≈øweete of ta≈øte, but yet har≈øh in a mans throate, they ≈øeeme not to haue beene common in Ea≈øt India, but brought thether from Bra≈øillia, where tho≈øe Nuts are much eaten, although Theuet in his de≈øcription of America (61. Chapter) writeth otherwi≈øe. At the end of this fruit groweth a Nut, of forme like the Kydney of a Hare, whereof I had many brought me by a Pylot of Portingall of an A≈øh colour, or when they are ripe of a reddi≈øh A≈øh colour. The≈øe Nuts haue two partitions, betweene which two partitions, there is a certain ≈øpongious fattie matter like Oyle, hotte and ≈øharpe, but in the innermo≈øt part thereof is a white kernell very plea≈øant to eate, like Pi≈øtaccios, with a gray skin ouer it, which is pulled off. The≈øe Nuts being a little ro≈øted are eaten in that ≈øort, & v≈øed to prouoke lu≈øt. The fruit and al≈øo the Nuts are v≈øed in bankets, being eaten with wine & without wine, becau≈øe of their good ta≈øte. They are good for the weakne≈ø≈øe of the Maw, and again≈øt perbreaking, and loathing of meate, but ≈øuch as will not v≈øe them to that ende, doe eate them only dipped or ≈øteeped in a little water, the ≈øharpe Oyle betweene both the partitions is verie good for Saint Anthonies fire, and fla≈øhing in mens faces. The Bra≈øilians v≈øe it again≈øt ≈øcurffes, this tree was at the fir≈øt planted of the very Nut but the fir≈øt and greate≈øt fruite, had neither ≈øeede nor kernell, ≈øome thinke it to bee a kind of Anacardy, becau≈øe it is very like it, for the ≈øharpe iuyce that is betweene the partitions. Reade more hereafter in Carolus Clu≈øius his ob≈øeruations vppon Graciam. (fir≈øt Booke and third Chapter.)

Cajus groweth on tr√©es like apple tr√©es, and are of the bignes of a Peare, at one end by the ≈øtalk ≈øomewhat ≈øharp, and at the head thicker, of a yelowi≈øh colour, being ripe they

When they are raw and vnro≈øted, you mu≈øt not open them with your mouth, for as ≈øoone as you put them to your mouth, they make both your tongue and your lippes to ≈ømart, whereby ≈øuch as know it not are deceiued: wherefore you mu≈øt open their ≈øhelles with a knife, or ro≈øt them, and then they wil p√©ele. div.head: The 53. Chapter. Of Iambos.
div.p: IN India ther is an other fruit that for the beautie, plea≈øant ta≈øte,Annota. D. P. ≈ømell, and medicinable vertue thereof, is worthie to bee written of, and is of great account in India, being fir≈øt brought out of Malacca into India. The tree whereon this fruite groweth, is as great as the greate≈øt Orange tree in all Spaine, with manye branches which ≈øpread verie broade, and make much ≈øhadow, and is faire to behold. The bodie and great branches thereof haue an a≈øh colour-gray barke, the leaues are faire & ≈øoft, longer then the breadth of a hand, they are ≈øomewhat like the point of a Speare or Pike, with a thicke threed or veine in the midle, and many ≈ømall veines or branches in the ≈øides: outwardly verie greene; and inwardly ≈øomewhat bleaker, with blo≈ø≈øomes of a liuely darke Purple colour, with many ≈øtreekes in the middle, verie plea≈øant to beholde, and of ta≈øte like the twynings or tendrels of a Vine. The fruite is as bigge as a Peare, or (as ≈øome are of opinion) of the bigne≈ø≈øe and colour of a great Spani≈øh Wal-nut, they tooke their name of a King. Ther are two ≈øorts of this fruit, one a browne red, ≈øeeming as though it were blacke, mo≈øt part without ≈øtones, and more ≈øauory then the other which is a palered, or a pale Purple colour, with a liuely ≈ømell of Ro≈øes, and within it hath a little white hard ≈øtone not verie rounde, much like a Peach ≈øtone, white, and couered with a rough skin. This is not ful ≈øo great as the other, yet are they both fit for ≈øuch as haue daintie and licorous mouthes. They ≈ømel like ≈øweete Ro≈øes‚ñ™ they are colde and moy≈øt, and altogether ≈øoft, couered with a thinne Rinde, which cannot be taken off with a knife. The Iambos tree taketh deepe roote, & within foure yeares after it is ≈øet, doth beare fruit, and that many times in one yeare, and is neuer without fruite or blo≈ø≈øomes, for that commonly euerie branch hath both ripe and vnripe fruit, and blo≈ø≈øomes all at once, contrarie to the nature of all other trees: and euerie day as the blo≈ø≈øomes fall (whereby the earth vnder it ≈øeemeth to bee painted red) there growe new on, and when ≈øome of the fruite begin to grow, then others are almo≈øt ripened, and others being ripe are greater. The tree being lightly ≈øhaken, the ripe fruit falleth ea≈øily off, by reaching the nether bowes. This fruite is ordinarily eaten, before other meate be ≈øet vpon the Table, and al≈øo at all times of the day. The Malabares and Canarijns, call this fruite Iamboli, the Portingales inhabiting there, Iambos, the Arabians, Tupha Indi, the Per≈øians Tuphat: the Turkes Alma, the trees are called by the Portingales Iambeiro. The blo≈ø≈øomes and the fruite are con≈øerued with Suger, and are v≈øed for hotte Agues to c ‚Ä¢ le mans thir≈øt.

The tr√©es whereon the Iambos do grow are as great as Plumtrees, and verie like vnto them: it is an excellent and a verie plea≈øant fruite to looke on, as bigge as an apple: it hath a red colour and ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh, ≈øo cleare
and pure that it ≈øeemeth to be painted or made of waxe: it is very plea≈øant to eate, and ≈ømelleth like Ro≈øe water, it is white within, and in eating moy≈øt and wateri≈øh, it is a mo≈øt daintie fruite, as well for bewtie to the ≈øight, as for the ≈øw√©et ≈øauour and ta≈øte: it is a fruite that is neuer forbidden to any ≈øicke per≈øon‚ñ™ as other fruites are, but are freelie giuen vnto ≈øicke men to eate, that haue a de≈øire thereunto, for it can doe no hurt. The blo≈ø≈øomes are likewi≈øe very faire to the ≈øight, and haue a ≈øw√©et ≈ømell: they are red and ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh of colour. This tr√©e beareth fruite thr√©e or foure tymes euery yeare, and which is more wonderfull, it hath commonly on the one ≈øide or halfe of the tr√©e ripe Iambos, and the leaues fallen off, and on the other ≈øide or half it hath all the leaues, and beginneth againe to blo≈ø≈øome, and when that ≈øide hath fruite, and that the leaues fall off, then the other ≈øide beginneth again to haue leaues, and to blo≈ø≈øome, and ≈øo it continueth all the yeare long: within they haue a ≈øtone as great (and very n√©ere of the ≈øame fa≈øhion) as the fruite of the Cipres tr√©e.

div.head: The 54. Chapter. Of other fruites in India.
div.p: THere is a fruite called Iangomas, which groweth on tr√©es like Cherrie tr√©es: they are in bignes like ≈ømal rouÃÑd pluÃÑmes of a darke red colour, they haue no ≈øtones in them, but ≈øome ≈ømall kernels: they are of ta≈øte much like pluÃÑmes, whereof there are very many, but not much e≈øteemed of. Annota. D. Pall.

The fruit Iangomas groweth on a tree not vnlike in greatne≈ø≈øe and fa≈øhion to our Plum trees, as al≈øo in leaues and white blo≈ø≈øoms, ≈øaue onely that the≈øe trees are ful of Prickles or thornes, they grow of them ≈øelues in euerie place, & al≈øo in gardens at Bachaim, Chaul and Balequala, the fruits are like Sorben ≈ømal and round, they are har≈øh in the throat like Slowes or vnripe Plums, and haue no ≈øtone within them, but ≈øome ≈ømall kernels, when they come fir≈øt out, they are like Pi≈øtaccios. The fruit being ripe, mu≈øt fir≈øt bee bru≈øed and cru≈øhed with mens fingers, before it can bee eaten, yet it loo≈øeth thereby none of his vertue of binding, and therefore they are thought good to ≈øtop the Flux withall, although they are but little e≈øteemed by the Indians. They ≈øay, that this fruite is eaten by certaine foules, and being voyded out againe & ≈øet in the ground together with the ≈øame Birdes dung, it wil grow the ≈øooner and be the fruitfuller.

The fruite which the Malabares and Portingales call Carambolas, is in Decan called Camarix, in Canar, Anno ‚Ä¢
D.

div.p: There is al≈øo a fruite that came out of the Spani≈øh Indies, brought from beyond ye Philippinas or Lu≈øons to Malacca, & froÃÑ thence to India, it is called Papaios, and is very like a Mellon, as bigge as a mans fi≈øt, and will not grow, but alwaies two together, that is male and female: the male tr√©e neuer y√©eldeth any fruite, but onely the female, and when they are deuided, & ≈øet apart one from the other, then they y√©eld no fruite at all. There are likewi≈øe in India ≈øome fig tr√©es of Portingal, although the fruite doth neuer come to good perfection. Grapes are not ther to be found, but onelie vpon ≈øome hou≈øes, as we haue theÃÑ in netherlaÃÑd: yet again≈øt Chri≈øtmas and Lent, there are ray≈øins brought into Goa, by the Decanaes and Indians out of the firme land, and from Ballagate, but they are not ≈øo good as tho≈øe in Spaine, and verie fewe they are, but for price as good cheape as other fruites. There are al≈øo in India manie Melons, but not ≈øo good as tho≈øe in Spaine, for that they mu≈øt be eaten with Suger, if you wil haue any ≈øw√©etnes in theÃÑ: but ther is an other ≈øort like Melons, called Patecas or Angurias, or Melons of India, which are outwardlie of a darke gr√©ene colour, inwardlie white with blacke kernels: they are verie wateri≈øh and hard to byte, and ≈øo moy≈øt, that as a man eateth them, his mouth is full of water, but yet verie ≈øw√©et, and verie cold and fre≈øh meat, wherfore manie of them are eateÃÑ after dinner to coole men. Cucumbers and Radi≈øhes are there in great numbers, al≈øo Colewortes, but not ≈øo good as in Europa, for the Colewortes neuer grow to their full growth, but are loo≈øe with their leaues open. They haue likewi≈øe ≈øome ≈øallet hearbs, but verie little: hearbs whereof men make Porridge are not there to be had, nor manie ≈øw√©et ≈ømelling hearbs nor flowers, as Ro≈øes, lillies, ro≈øemary, or ≈øuch like ≈øorts of flowers & plants there are none, yet they haue ≈øome fewe Ro≈øes, and a little Ro≈øemarie, but of no great ≈ømell. The fields neuer haue any other flowers in them, but onelie gra≈ø≈øe, and that is in Winter when it rayneth, for in SuÃÑmer it is cleane burnt off with the exc√©eding heat of the Sunne. There is onelie a kinde of blo≈ø≈øomes of tr√©es, which grow all the yeare long, called Fulle, that ≈ømell verie ≈øw√©et: the women doe ordinarily throw them among their Lynnen and apparell to make them ≈øw√©et. By the≈øe pictures you may ≈ø√©e the forme and fa≈øhions of the fruites called Iaacka, Ananas, Mangas, Caius, & Iambos, which are the fyue principalle≈øt & mo≈øt e≈øt√©emed fruites in all India, for others are but of ≈ømall account: of Ginger al≈øo as it groweth, whereof in an other place I will ≈øay more, when I make mention of the ≈øpices and drie wares of India: all which are ≈øet down according to the life, although the leaues are not altogether ≈øo proportionable with their ≈øtrings and veynes, as they ≈øhould be, or as the Phy≈øitions and Doctors in their Herbals haue de≈øcribed them, hauing onely ≈øhewed the forme and growth of the fruites, as I haue ≈øeene and v≈øed them,

div.head: The 55. Chapter. Of the Indian Figges.
div.p:
INdian Figges there are manie & of diuers ≈øorts, one better theÃÑ the other, ≈øome ≈ømall, ≈øome great, ≈øome thicke, ≈øome thin, &c. but in generall they are all of one forme and colour, little more or le≈ø≈øe, but the tr√©es are all one, and of the height of a maÃÑ: the leaues are of a fadome long, and about 3 ≈øpannes broad, which the Turkes v≈øe in ≈øt√©ed of browne paper, to put pepper in. In the tr√©e there is no wood, but it may rather be called a r√©ed then a tr√©e. The bodie of the tr√©e (I meane that which couereth the outwardpart when it beginneth ≈øomewhat to grow) is in a manner verie like the inner part of a ≈øyue made of hayre, but in ≈øhew ≈øomewhat thicker, and is (as it were) the barke of it: but when you open it, it is ful of leaues, clo≈øed and rouled vp together, of the hight of half a mans length, and ≈øomewhat higher. The≈øe leaues do open and ≈øpread abroad on the top of the tr√©e, and when tho≈øe that are within the bodie doe in their time thru≈øt them≈øelues forth vpwardes out of the innermo≈øt part of the tr√©e, then doe the outmo≈øt leaues begin to drie, and fall off, vntill the tr√©e be come to his full growth, and the fruite to their perfect ripene≈ø≈øe. The bodie of the tr√©e may be a ≈øpan thicke at the mo≈øt. The leaues haue in ye middle of them a very thick & gray vein which ruÃÑneth clean through them, and deuideth them out of the midde≈øt of the leaues, which are in the innermo≈øt part of the tr√©e at their ≈øpringing vp, there cometh forth a flower, as big as an E≈øtrige egge, of colour ru≈ø≈øet, which in time groweth to be long, with a long ≈øtalke, and it is no wood, but rather like a Coleworte ≈øtalk: This ≈øtalke groweth full of figges, clo≈øe one by the other, which at the fir≈øt are in fa≈øhion like gr√©ene beanes, when they are yet in the hu≈økes, but after growe to half a ≈øpan in length, and 3 or 4 inches broad, as thicke as Cucumbers, which ≈øtalke beareth at the lea≈øt, ≈øome two hundreth figges, little more or le≈ø≈øe, and grow as clo≈øe together as grapes: the clu≈øters are ≈øo great as two men can ≈øcarcely beare vpon a ≈øtaffe, they are cut off when they are but half ripe, that is to ≈øay, when they are as yet half gr√©ene, and half yealow, and hanged vp in their hou≈øes vpon beames, and ≈øo within 4 or 5 dayes they will be fullie ripe and al yealow. The tr√©e or plant y√©eldeth but one bunch at a time, which being ripe, they cut the whole tr√©e down to the ground, leauing only the roote, out of the which pre≈øently groweth an other, and within a Moneth after beareth fruite, and ≈øo continueth all the yeare long, and neuer leaueth bearing: they are in all places in ≈øo great abundance, and ≈øo common throughout all India, that it is wonderfull, being the greate≈øt meat and ≈øu≈øtenance of the countrie: they are of a maruellous good ta≈øte: when they eate them, they pul off the ≈øhelles, for that they haue ≈øhelles ≈øomewhat like the coddes of beanes, but thynner and ≈øofter, within whiti≈øh, and ≈øoft in byting, as if it were meale and butter mixed together, and ≈øw√©eti≈øh, ≈øo that in br√©ef, they are very good and plea≈øant of ta≈øte: they may ≈øerue both for bread & butter, and a man may verie wel liue thereon, without other meate, if n√©ed were, as manie in India doe liue therewith, & haue but little other things to eate. The mo≈øt and commone≈øt ≈øort are by the Portingals called Figos dorta, that is, garden figges, tho≈øe are ≈øomewhat thicke, there are others which are ≈ømaller, and thyn without, and are called Senoriins, which are of the be≈øt ≈øort: they ≈ømell well, and are very good of ta≈øte. There is an other ≈øort called Cadoliins, which are likewi≈øe well e≈øteemed, but the be≈øt of all are called Chincapoloyns, and are mo≈øt in the countrie of Malabar: the≈øe are but a little yealow, but they continue commonlie on the out≈øide gr√©ene, and are ≈ømall and long, with a ≈øpeciall ≈øw√©et ≈ømell, as if they were full of ro≈øe water. There are yet manie other ≈øorts, ≈øome that are verie great, about a ≈øpan long, and in thicknes corre≈øpondent: the≈øe grow much in Cananor, and in the coa≈øt of Malabar, and are by the Portingales called figges of Cananor: and by rea≈øon of the great quantitie thereof are dried, their ≈øhelles being taken off, and ≈øo being drie are caryed ouer all India to be ≈øold. The≈øe when they are ripe are mo≈øt roa≈øted, for they are but ≈øeldome eaten raw, as other figges are, they are ≈øome what har≈øh in ≈øwallowing, and inwardly red of colour, and being roa≈øted they are ≈øhalled or pille like the others, and ≈øo cut in ≈ølices, which done, they ca≈øt ≈øome beaten Sinamon vpon them, ≈øt√©eping them in wine, & theÃÑ they ta≈øte better then roa≈øted Quinces, they are cut vp in the middle, as all the other kynde of figges v≈øe to be, and then boyled or fryed in Suger, which is a very daintie meat, and very common in India: to conclude, it is one of the be≈øt and nece≈ø≈øarye≈øt fruites in all India, and one of the principalle≈øt ≈øu≈øtenances of the common people, they are found in all places of the Indies & Oriental countries, as al≈øo in Mo≈øambique, Ormus, on the coa≈øt of Abex, Malabar, Malacca, Bengala, &c.
