div.head: The 56. Chapter. Of the Palme trees, whereon the Indian Nuts called Cocus doe grow.
div.p: THe≈øe Tr√©es are commonlie called by mo≈øt of the Indians, Per≈øians, and Arabians, Maro, & the nuts Nare ‚Ä¢ . The Malabares call the Trees Tenga Maran, and the fruite being ripe, Tenga, but vnripe, and being as yet greene, „Äà‚óä„Äâ . In Goa ‚Ä¢ anha, the Portingalls call this fruit Coquo, by rea≈øon of the thr√©e holes that are therein, like to a Munkies head. Auicenna calleth the≈øe Ia ‚Ä¢ ial-Indi, that is, Indian nuts. The Malayans of Malacca call the trees Trican, and the fruit Nihor. This is the mo≈øt profitable tree of all India, as in order I will declare vnto you the profit that ari≈øeth thereby, they grow mo≈øt in the I≈ølands of Maldiua, and in Goa, and the countries round about them, as al≈øo through the whole coa≈øt of Malabar, whereby they traffique with them into all places, as to Cambaia, Ormus, &c. The tree wareth very high and ≈øtraight, of the thickenes of a ≈ømall ≈øpanne little more or le≈ø≈øe, it hath no branches but in the vppermo≈øt part thereof, & in the top grow the leaues, which ≈øpread like vnto Date tr√©es, and vnder the leaues clo≈øe to the tree grow the Coquos together, commonly ten or twelue one clo≈øe by another, but you ≈øhall ≈øeldome finde one of them growing alone by it ≈øelf. The blo≈ø≈øome of this fruite is very like the blo≈ø≈øome of a Che≈øtnut. The wood of the tree is very ≈øappy like a ≈øpunge, and is not firme, they doe not grow but on the ≈øea ≈øides, or bankes of riuers clo≈øe by the ≈øtrand, and in ≈øandie grounds, for there groweth none within the land. They haue no great rootes, ≈øo that a man would thinke it were impo≈ø≈øible for them to haue any fa≈øt hold within the earth, and yet they ≈øtand ≈øo fa≈øt and grow ≈øo high, that it maketh men ≈øcare to ≈øee men clime vppon them, lea≈øt they ≈øhould fall downe. The Canarijns clime as nimbly and as fa≈øt vpon them, as if they were Apes, for they make ≈ømall ≈øteppes in the tr√©es like ≈øtaires, whereon they ≈øtep, and ≈øo clime vp‚ñ™ which the Portingales dare not veÃÑ ter, their planting is in this manner. They fir≈øt plant the Coquos or Nuts whereof the trees doe ≈øpring, and when they are about the height of a man, in winter time they plant them againe, and dung them with a≈øhes, and in ≈øummer time water them. They growe well about hou≈øes, becau≈øe commonlie there they haue good earth, and beeing well looked vnto and hu≈øbanded, they yeeld fruit in fewe yeares, which is the Canarijns liuinges that dwell here and there among tho≈øe trees, and haue no other occupation but onely to dre≈ø≈øe tho≈øe trees, which they farme of the Landlords, and by the fruite thereof doe get their liuinges. Tho≈øe trees are more aboundant with them then Oliue tr√©es in Spaine, or willow tr√©es in the Low countries. The profits they reape thereby are the≈øe. Fir≈øt the wood is very good for many things, although it be ≈øpungious and ‚Ä¢ appy, by rea≈øon of the length of it, for in the I≈ølandes of Maldiua they make whole ≈øhips thereof, without any iron nayles in them, for they ≈øow them together with the cordes that are made of the ≈øaid Cocus or Nut, the ropes and cables beeing likewi≈øe of the ≈øame tree, as al≈øo the ≈øayles which they make of the leaues, which leaues are called Olas. They ≈øerue likewi≈øe to make the Canarijns hou≈øes, and for hattes which they v≈øe to carrie ouer their heades, for the ≈øunne or the raine, they make al≈øo mattes or Tents that lie ouer the Palamkins when it raineth, to couer the women when they are caried abroad, and ≈øuch like thinges: they likewi≈øe make thereof very fine Hattes, that are much e≈øteemed, and co≈øt three or foure Pardawes the p√©ece, which they weare in Summer for lightnes. They farme or hire tho≈øe tr√©es for two cau≈øes, one for the Coquos or fruit to eate it, the other to pre≈ø≈øe wine out of them, thereof to drinke. The nuts are as great as an e≈øtrige egge, ≈øome ≈ømaller, and ≈øome greater, and are outwardly couered with a Hu≈øke or Shell, which as long as it groweth on the tr√©e, is gr√©ene with out, like an Acorne with his hu≈øke or cup.

p.hi: The Indian nuts are couered ouer with two ≈øortes of huskes or ≈øhels,

whereof the vttermo≈øt is hayrie, and of it they make Cairo, that is, all their cables and ropes, and ≈øtop and make their ≈øhips clo≈øe with it in ≈øtead of Ocam or tow, for that it keepeth the ≈øhips clo≈øer in ≈øaltwater then our Ocam or Tow, becau≈øe in ≈øalt water it clo≈øeth and ≈øhutteth it ≈øelfe clo≈øer together. Of the other they make not onelie drinking cups, in India, but here with vs al≈øo, for that the common people beleeue there is a certaine vertue in them again≈øt ≈øtirring of the body, but it is not ≈øo.

div.p:
This Hu≈øke beeing drie and pulled off, is haire like hempe, whereof all the cordes and Cables that are v≈øed throughout al India are made, as well vppon the land as in the ≈øhips‚ñ™ it is of colour verie like the ropes of Sparta in Spaine, they are very good but they mu≈øt be kept in ≈øalt water, whereby they continue very long, but in fre≈øh or raine water they doe pre≈øently rot, becau≈øe they are not dre≈øt with pitch, and tarre as our ≈øhips are. The ≈øhip wherein I came out of India into Portingall,
had no other ropes nor cables, nor any ≈øuch kinde of ≈øtuffe, but ≈øuch as were made of the Indian Cocus, called Cayro, which continued very good, ≈øauing only yt we were forced euery fourt√©ene dayes to wa≈øh our cables in the Sea, whereby they ≈øerued vs as well as cables of hemp. The fruit when it is almo≈øt ripe is called Lanha, and within is full of water, and then it is white of colour, thin and ≈øoft, and the longer the Cocus is on the tree, the more the water groweth and changeth into white, which is the meat of the nut within, and ta≈øteth much like a ha≈øel nut, but ≈øomewhat ≈øweeter. The Lanhos haue within them a good draught of water, which is very cleare, ≈øweet, and coole to drink. It is at the lea≈øt halfe a Can full, & when men walke abroad and are thir≈øtie they go vnto the Canarijns, who pre≈øently with a great knife in their handes come vp the tree, and cut off as many Lanhos as a man de≈øireth, ≈øelling them for a Ba≈øaruco or a two peece, which they make very ready and cleare to be drunke, the fir≈øt ≈øhell that is ouer the inward fruit (which as the nut is come to his full ripenes, becometh almo≈øt to bee wood, is then but thin and ≈øoft, and very plea≈øant to eate with ≈øalt, and do ta≈øte almo≈øt like Artichokes, a man may drinke as much of this water as hee will for it will not hurt him, but is a verie plea≈øant drinke, when the fruit is ripe, there is not ≈øo much water in it, and is white within, and ≈øomewhat thicker of ≈øub≈øtance, and then the water is not ≈øo good as it was before beeing Lanhos, for then it becommeth ≈øomewhat ≈øower. The≈øe Cocus being yet in their hu≈øks, may be carried ouer the whole world, and not once hurt or bru≈øed, and it happeneth oftentimes that by continuance of time, the water within the Cocus doth conuert, and congeale into a certaine kinde of yellow apple, which is verie ≈øauorie and ≈øweet. The hu≈øke beeing taken off, the ≈øhel ≈øerueth for many v≈øes, as to make ladles with woodden handles, and al≈øo certaine little pots, which beeing fa≈øtned to a ≈øticke, they doe therewith take and lade water out of their great pots, they make thereof al≈øo ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels to beare wine in when they walke into the fieldes, and a thou≈øand other thinges. The≈øe ≈øhelles are likewi≈øe burnt, & ≈øerue for coales for Gold≈ømithes, which are very good and excellent. Of the white of the≈øe nuts in India they make porrage, and dre≈ø≈øe meate withall, ≈øtrayning and pre≈ø≈øing out the milke, wherin with many other mixtures they ≈øeeth their rice, & to bee ≈øhort, they neuer dre≈ø≈øe any rice, which they cal Carrijl, & is the ≈øauce to their meate thereunto, but they put ≈øome of their Cocus milk into it, els the Cocus is but little eaten, for there it is not e≈øteemed of, but ≈øerueth for meate for the ≈ølaues, and poore people. They likewi≈øe breake the Cocus in p√©eces, and taking off the ≈øhell they drie the fruit or white meat that is within it, and it is caried in great quantities out of Malabar to Cambaia and Ormus & to the Northern coa≈øtes and quarters beyond Goa, as al≈øo to the countrie of Ballagate, & traffique much therewith. Of this white ≈øub≈øtance they make Oyle, which they ≈øtampe in ce≈øterns like Oliues, and it maketh verie good oyle, as well to eat as to burne, which is likewi≈øe very medicinable.

There are two ≈øortes of Oyle made of the≈øe nuts, Annota. D. Pal, one out of the fre≈øh or greene nuts, ≈øtamped and mixed with warme water, which beeing pre≈ø≈øed foorth, the oyle ≈øwimmeth aboue the water ‚Ä¢ this oyle is v≈øed to purge the maw and the guts, for it purgeth very gently, & without hurt ≈øome mixe therewith the iuyce of Thamarindes, & maketh thereof a verie whole≈øome medecine, the other Oyle is pre≈øt out of the dried Cocus, which is called Copra, & is good al≈øo to purge the maw and again≈øt the ≈øhrinking of the ≈øinews, as al≈øo for old aches and paines in the ioyntes and lims. This dried Cocus which is ≈øo caried abroad, is called Copra. When they de≈øire to haue no Cocus or fruite thereof, they cut the blo≈ø≈øomes of the Cocus away, and binde a round Potte with a narrow mouth, by them called Callao, fa≈øt vnto the tree, and ≈øtop the ≈øame clo≈øe round about with pot earth, ≈øo that neyther wine nor aire can eyther enter in, or come forth, & in that ≈øort the pot in ≈øhort ≈øpace is full of water, which they call Sura, & is very plea≈øant to drinke like ≈øweet whay, & ≈øomewhat better.

p.hi: This water being drunke,
is very good again≈øt the heate of the liuer and the kidnies, and clean≈øeth the yard from corruption and filthie matter.

div.p:
The ≈øame water ≈øtanding but one houre in the ≈øunne, is very good viniger, and in India they haue none other. This Sura beeing di≈øtilled, is called Fula, or Nipe, & is as excellent aqua vitae, as any is made in Dor ‚Ä¢
of their be≈øt reÃÑni≈øh wine, but this is of the fine≈øt kinde of di≈øtillation. The ≈øecond di≈øtillation thereof is called Vraca, which is verie good wine, & is the wine of India, for they haue no other wine. It is very hot & ≈øtrong, yet ye Indians drinke it as if it were water, & the Portingales v≈øe it in this ≈øort. They put it into ve≈ø≈øels‚ñ™ and to a pipe of Vraca they put 3. or 4. Hands of rea≈øons that are brought for marchandi≈øe into India from Ormus, euerie Hand is 12. poundes, which beeing wa≈øhed they put into the ve≈ø≈øell leauing the bung opeÃÑ & the pipe not being full, for if it were it wold bur≈øt, by rea≈øon of the heat, becau≈øe therewith
it ≈ø√©etheth in the Pipe like water on the fire, and boyling ≈øo, it is ≈øtirred euery day for the ≈øpace of fourteene or fifteene dayes, in which time the Vraca getteth as faire a redde colour, as if it were Portingall wine, and differeth not much in ta≈øte, but yet ≈øweeter, and hotter of it ≈øelfe, howbeit it is altogether as fayre, and of as good a colour as their Portingall Wyne, ≈øo that they can hardly bee di≈øcerned one from the other: this Wine is called Wine of Pa≈ø≈øa, or Rea≈øons. With this Wine there is great traffique v≈øed to Bengala, Malacca, China and other places, and euery Pipe thereof co≈øteth within Goa 30. Pardawen the p√©ece, little more or le≈ø≈øe. Of the afore≈øaide Sura they likewi≈øe make Sugar, which is called Iagra: they ≈øeeth the water, and ≈øet it in the Sun, whereof it becommeth Sugar, but it is little e≈øt√©emed, becau≈øe it is of a browne colour, and for that they haue ≈øo great quantitie and abundance of white Sugar throughout all India. The innermo≈øt parte of the tr√©e or trunke is called Palmito, and is the pith or hart of the ≈øame trunke, which is much e≈øt√©emed, and ≈øent for a pre≈øent vnto men of great account. It is as thinne as Paper, and al≈øo white, and is as if it were plaited or pre≈øt together, as they v≈øe to plait & pre≈ø≈øe womens huykes in the Low countries: it is al≈øo long and ≈ølender, and hath ≈øometimes 50. or 60. foldes or plaites in it like a paper booke. This the Indians v≈øe for paper, and bookes, which continueth in the ≈øame foldes, whereon they write when it is gr√©ene, and ≈øo let it drie, and then it is impo≈ø≈øible to get the letters out againe, for it is printed therein with a kind of Iron in≈øtrument: The Indians cal it Olla, whereof all their bookes, wrytinges, and Euidences are made, which they can ≈øeale, and ≈øhutte vp as we doe our letters. Of this Paper with the Indian writing vpon it, you may ≈ø√©e ≈øome at D. Paludanus hou≈øe, which I gaue him for a pre≈øent. The≈øe tr√©es are for the mo≈øt part in the I≈ølands of Maldiua, w ‚Ä¢ ere there are Cocus Nuttes, that are excellent good again≈øt poy≈øon.

p.hi: Gar≈øius and Costa e≈øteeme this for a fable. Co≈øta writeth that he hath ≈øearched into it many times but found it contrarie, as I likewi≈øe haue done, and can finde no ≈øuch great effect.

div.p: Tho≈øe I≈ølandes haue no other dealing or liuing, but with Cayro, whereof they make ropes and Cables, and with the Copra, or the white ≈øub≈øtance of the Cocus, whereof Oyle is made, ≈øo yt they doe oftentimes come into India, wheÃÑ the ≈øhip & all the furniture, victuaile and marchandi≈øe is onely of tho≈øe Palme tr√©es, whereby it is wel to be con≈øidered, that it is one of the greate≈øt & principale≈øt traffiques and victua ‚Ä¢ ls in all India, This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the de≈øcription of the particular commodities of this tr√©e, the liuely picture whereof is here to be ≈ø√©ene, together with the Cocus or Nuttes, and the pottes hanging at the ≈øame, to draw ye water out of them, as al≈øo the growing and ≈øprowting of the Fig tr√©es, as well with fruit as with blo≈ø≈øoms, all liuely ≈øet downe.

div.head: The 57. Chapter. Of the Duryoens, a fruit of Malacca.
div.p:
DVryoen is a fruit yt only groweth in Malacca, and is ≈øo much comeÃÑ ded by tho≈øe which haue proued ye ≈øame, that there is no fruite in the world to bee compared with it: for they affirme, that in ta≈øte and goodnes it excelleth all kind of fruits, and yet when it is fir≈øt opened, it ≈ømelleth like rotten onions, but in the ta≈øte the ≈øw√©etnes and daintine≈ø≈øe thereof is tryed. It is as great as a Mellon, outwardly like the Iaacka, wherof I haue ≈øpoken, but ≈øomewhat ≈øharper or pricking, and much like the hu≈økes of Che≈ønuttes. It hath within it certaine partitions like the Iaacka,Annot ‚Ä¢
D. P. wherein the fruit groweth, being of the greatne≈ø≈øe of a little Hennes egge, and therein are the Nuttes as great as Peache ≈øtones. The fruite is for colour and ta≈øte like an excellent meat, much v≈øed in Spaine, called Mang ‚Ä¢ ar Blanco, which is made of Hennes fle≈øh, di≈øtilled with Sugar: The trees are like the Iaacka tr√©es, the blo≈ø≈øoms white, and ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh: the leaues about halfe a ≈øpanne broad, ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe at the end, within light gr√©ene, and without darke gr√©ene.

In Malacca there is a fruit ≈øo plea≈øant both for ta≈øte and ≈ømell, that it excelleth all other fruites both of India, & Malacca, although there are many both excellent and very good. This fruit is called in Malayo (which is the Prouince wherein it groweth) Duriaoen, and the blo≈ø≈øomes Buaa, and the tree Batan: It is a very great tree, of ≈øolide and firme wood, with a gray barke, hauing many braunches, and exce≈ø≈øiue great ≈øtore of fruit: the blo≈ø≈øome is white and ≈øomewhat yellow: the leaues halfe a handfull long, & two or three fingers broad,

rounde and ≈øomewhat hollowe: outwardly darke greene, and inwardly light greene, and ≈øomewhat after a red colour. It beareth a fruit of the bignes of a Mellon, couered with a harde husk, with many ≈ømal and thicke ≈øharpe prickles: outwardly greene, & with ≈øtrikes downe along the ≈øides like the Mellon. They haue within them foure holes or partitions according to the length thereof, in each of the which holes are yet three or foure ca≈øes: in each ca≈øe or ≈øhell a fruite as white as milke, and as great as a Hennes egge, but better of ta≈øte and ≈øauour, like the white meat, which the Spaniardes make of Ryce, Capons fle≈øh, and Ro≈øe water, called Mangiar Blanco, yet not ≈øo ≈øoft nor ≈ølymie, for the other that are yellow, and not white within, are either ≈øpoyled, or rotten, by euill aire or moy≈øture: they are accounted the be≈øt which haue but three Nuttes in each hole, next them tho≈øe that haue foure, but tho≈øe of fiue are not good, & ≈øuch as haue any cracks or cliftes in them. There are likewi≈øe (very ≈øeldome) more then twenty nuts in one apple, and in euery Nutte is a ≈øtone like a Peach ≈øtone, not rounde, but ≈øomewhat long, not ouer ≈øweet of ta≈øte, but making the throat har≈øh, like vnripe Medlers, and for that cau≈øe are not eaten.

This fruit is hot and moi≈øt, and ≈øuch as will eat them, mu≈øt fir≈øt treade‚ñ™ vpon them ≈øoftly with his foote, and breake the prickes that are about them: Such as neuer eate of it before, when they ≈ømell it at the fir≈øt, thinke it ≈øenteth like a rotten Onyon, but hauing ta≈øted it, they e≈øteeme it aboue all other fruites, both for ta≈øte and ≈øauour. This fruite is al≈øo in ≈øuch account with the learned Doctors, that they think a man can neuer be ≈øatisfied therwith, and therefore they giue this fruite an honourable name, and write certaine Epigrammes thereof, & yet there is great abundance of theÃÑ in Malacca: & the apples co≈øt not aboue four Meruedies the peece, ≈øpecially in the Monthes of Iune, Iuly and Augu≈øt, at other times the price is higher. Here you mu≈øt note a wonderful contrarietie, that is betweene this fruit Duriaoen, and the hearbe Bettele, which in truth is ≈øo great, that if there were a whole ≈øhippe, ≈øhoppe or hou≈øe full of Duriaoens, wherein there lay certayne leaues of Bettele, all the Duriaoens wold pre≈øently rotte and bee ≈øpoyled. And likewi≈øe by eating ouer many of tho≈øe Duriaoens, they heat the Maw, & make it ≈øwell, and one leafe of Bettele, to the contrarie, being laide colde vppon the hart, will pre≈øently cea≈øe the inflamation, ri≈øing or ≈øwelling of the Maw. And ≈øo if after you haue eaten Duriaoens, you chance to eat a leafe or two of Bettele, you can receyue no hurt by the Duriaoens, although you haue eaten neuer ≈øo many. Hereupon, and becau≈øe they are of ≈øo plea≈øant a ta≈øte, the common ≈øaying is, that men can neuer be ≈øatisfied with them.

div.head: The 58. Chapter Of the tree Arbore de Rays, that is, root tree, and the Bambus or reede of India.
div.p:
THere is a tr√©e in India called Arbore de Rays, that is to ≈øay, a Tr√©e of rootes: this tr√©e is very wonderfull to beholde, for that wheÃÑ it groweth fir≈øt vp like all other tr√©es and ≈øpreadeth the branches: theÃÑ ye branches grow ful of roots, & grow downwards again towards the earth, where they take roote againe, and ≈øo are fa≈øt againe within the ground, and in length of time, the broader the tr√©e is, and that the branches doe ≈øpreade them≈øelues, the more roots doe hang vpon the branches and ≈ø√©eme a farre off to b√©e cordes of Hempe, ≈øo that in the ende the tr√©e couereth a great peece of ground, and cro≈ø≈øeth one roote within the other like a Ma≈øe. I haue ≈ø√©ene trees that haue contayned at the lea≈øt ≈øome thirtie or fortie paces in compa≈ø≈øe, and all out of the rootes which came from aboue one of the braunches, and were fa≈øt growne and had taken roote againe within the earth, and in time waxed ≈øo thicke, that it could not be di≈øcerned, which was the chief or principal trunke or body of the tr√©e: in ≈øome places you may creepe betweene the rootes, and the more the tree ≈øpreadeth, ≈øo much the more doe the rootes ≈øpring out of the ≈øame
branches and ≈øtill grow downe til they come to earth, and there take roote againe within the ground, and ≈øtill increa≈øe with rootes, that it is a wonder. This tree hath no fruit that is worth the eating, but a ≈ømall kind of fruite like Oliues, & good for nothing but for birdes to eate.

p.hi: Carolus Clu≈øius that hath written very diligently of this tree, nameth it by authoritie out of Plinie, the Indian Fig tree, and ≈øaith, it groweth very high, fir≈øt out of a ≈øtraight thicke trunke, or body that afterwarde yeeldeth many ≈ømall and thinne twigges, which being young and tender, are of a gold yellow colour, and growing downewardes towardes the earth, doe waxe againe like young Ru≈øhes, and ≈øo make as it were new trees again, which in time become as thicke as the fir≈øt, ≈øo that they cannot ea≈øily be di≈øcerned one from the other, ≈øauing onely for the compa≈ø≈øe thereof, which in the ende proceedeth to the thickne≈ø≈øe of three mens fadomes: out of the which roundne≈ø≈øe or circuit on euery ≈øide there groweth other rootes, and ‚Ä¢ o to an innumerable number, ≈øo that this tree doth couer ≈øometimes a little Italian mile, and doth not onely ≈øpread from the lowe≈øt branches down againe into the ground, but al≈øo from the highe≈øt, whereby that one tree ≈øeemeth to be a thicke woode. The Indians that they may go through this tree, do cut away ≈øome of the branches, and make as it were galleries to walke vnder, and to keepe them from the heate of the Sunne, becau≈øe the tree is ≈øo full of branches, that the Sun cannot ≈øhine through it, and by rea≈øon of the many crookinges and wayes that are vnder this tree, there are many ≈øoundes of a great Eccho hearde vnder the ≈øame, ≈øo that in many places it will repeate a mans words three or foure times together. He that tolde Clu≈øius of this tree, ≈øaide, hee had ≈øeene 800. or 1000. men (whereof hee him≈øelfe was one) hide them≈øelues vnder one of tho≈øe trees, ≈øaying further, that there were ≈øome of tho≈øe trees which might well couer 3000. men vnder it: the leaues which the new branches bring forth, are like the leaues of the Quince trees: the out≈øide green, the in≈øide whiti≈øh & rough, as if they were couered with Wooll: who≈øe leaues are much de≈øired by Elephants, who therewith are nouri≈øhed: the fruit is like the fir≈øt ioint of a mans thumbe, and haue the fa≈øhion & forme of little ≈ømall figges, reddi≈øh both within and without, and ful of little greines like common figges: ≈øweet of ta≈øte and good to be eaten, but not ≈øo plea≈øant as our common figs‚ñ™ they grow between the leaues & the new branches, as our Figges doe: it groweth in Goa, and in ≈øome places bordering on the ≈øame: al≈øo Clu≈øius ≈øaith out of Curtius, Plinius and Strabo, that tho≈øe trees were al≈øo knowne of the auncient writers. Hee that de≈øireth to know more hereof, let him reade Clu≈øius in his Chapter of Indian Figges.

div.p: There are in India other wonderfull and thicke tr√©es, whereof ≈øhippes are made: there are tr√©es by Cochiin, that are called Angelina, whereof certaine ≈øcutes or Skiffes called Tones are made: there are of tho≈øe Tones that will lade in them at the lea≈øt 20. or 30. Pipes of water, and are cut out of one p√©ece of wood, without any p√©ece or ≈øeame, or any iointes: whereby men may well coniecture the thickne≈ø≈øe of the tr√©e, and it is ≈øo ≈øtrong and hard a woode, that Iron in tract of time would bee con≈øumed thereby, by rea≈øon of the hardne≈ø≈øe of the woode. There are al≈øo ouer all India many Sugar Canes in all places, and in great numbers, but not much e≈øt√©emed of: & all along the coa≈øt of Malabare there are many thicke Reeds, ≈øpecially on the coa≈øt of Choramandel, which Reedes by the Indians are called Mambu, and by the Portingales Bambu: the≈øe Mambus haue a certain matter within them, which is (as it were) the pith of it, ≈øuch as Quilles haue within them, which men take out when they make them pennes to write: the Indians call it Sacar Mambu, which is as much to ≈øay, as Sugar of Mambu, and is a very medicinable thing much e≈øteemed, and much ≈øought for by the Arabians, Per≈øians, and Moores, that call it Tabaxiir.

p.hi: Tabaxijr is a Per≈øian word,

& ≈øignifieth no other thing but a certaine white or milke moi≈øture, for any ≈øap or moi≈øture cleauing together is called Sacar Mambu, becau≈øe the reeds or branches, which bring forth the ≈øame are called Mambu: the trees whereon Tabaxijr groweth, are ≈øome as great
as a Popler, and ≈øome ≈ømaller, commonly hauing ≈øtraight vpright branches, ≈øauing that ≈øome of the fayre≈øt of them are bowed for their galleries, Arbours, and other walking places: they haue many ioyntes, each of a ≈øpanne length, hauing leaues ≈øomewhat longer then the leaues of the Oliue tree: betweene euery ioynt there is a certain ≈øweete moy≈øture, white and cleauing together like Starch, ≈øometimes much, ≈øometimes little: euery tree or branch doth not bring forth ≈øuch ≈øweet moi≈øture, but ≈øuch onely as grow in Bi≈ønagar, and in ≈øome prouinces of Malabar.

div.p: And therefore commonly in Per≈øia and Arabia, it is weighed again≈øt ≈øiluer, and is a marchandi≈øe much v≈øed & e≈øteemed among ye fore≈øaide nations: this groweth within the ioynts of the reed, & is white, and ≈øometimes blacki≈øh, and ≈øometimes A≈øh colour.

p.hi: It is not therefore reiected or ca≈øt away,

becau≈øe it is blacki≈øh: for this blacki≈øhne≈ø≈øe proceedeth either by rea≈øon of the ≈øuperfluitie of the moy≈øture, or that it was too long inclo≈øed within the tree, & not by burning of the tree, as ≈øome are of opinion. Rha≈øes writeth hereof in his third book, and 36. Chap. and Serapio in his booke of phi≈øicke, in the 342. Chapter, and Auicenna in his 2. booke and 617. Chapter, who are of opinion, that Tabaxijr is made of burnt rootes, but his opinion is hereby proued to be fal≈øe.

div.p: The Indians v≈øe it again≈øt the payne in their priuie members, or ≈øuch like ≈øecrete di≈øea≈øes, as al≈øo again≈øt hotte or burning feauers, the Colerica pa≈øsio, and the redde Mali≈øon, and la≈økines, with ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes. Tho≈øe r√©eds grow mo≈øt in the coa≈øt of Choramandel in Bi≈ønagar, and Malacca in many places, and in great abundance: they growe very high, and are diuided in each ioynt one knot from another, at the lea≈øt a ≈øpanne and a halfe, and rather more and are as thicke as a mans leg aboue the knee: they do commonly grow vpright, and mo≈øt of them as high as the highe≈øt hou≈øe in the Low countries: they bow them many times in growing, that they may bring them into a forme or fa≈øhion to ≈øerue for their Pallamkins, wherein the Portingalles and Indian Lordes are caried, as I ≈øaide before: the leaues of tho≈øe r√©edes or Bambus growe wide one from another, and haue almo≈øt the fa≈øhion of an Oliue leafe.

p.hi: Of the tree or reede called Bambus,

≈øome of the Indians make ≈øcutes or little Skiffes, wherein two men may ≈øitte, which they doe not altogether make hollow within, but leaue two knots or partitions vncarued. In tho≈øe ≈øcutes the Indians ≈øit naked, at ech end one, cro≈ø≈øe legged, & in each hand an oare, wherewith they rule the boate and driue her ≈øwiftly again≈øt the ≈øtreame, ≈øpecially in the riuer called Cranganor: and they are of this opinion, that tho≈øe Scutes are neuer ouerturned by the Crocodiles (although they come about them) as others are, but for the≈øe it was neuer heard of.

div.head: The 59. Chapter. Of the tree called Arbore Tri≈øte.
div.p:
THe Tree called Arbore Tri≈øte, that is, the ≈øorrowfull tree, is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it neuer beareth blo≈ø≈øoms but in the night time, and ≈øo it doeth and continueth all the yeare long: it is a thing to be wondred at: for that ≈øo ≈øoone as the Sunne ≈øetteth, there is not one blo≈ø≈øome ≈øeene vppon the tree, but pre≈øently within halfe an houre after, there are as many blo≈ø≈øomes vppon it, as the Tree can beare: they are very plea≈øant to behold, and ≈ømell very ≈øweet, and ≈øo ≈øoone as the day commeth on, and the Sunne is ri≈øing, pre≈øently all the blo≈ø≈øomes fall off, and couer all the ground, ≈øo that there remayneth not one to be ≈øeene vpon the tree: the leaues ≈øhut them≈øelues clo≈øe together, ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth as though it were dead, vntill euening commeth againe, and then it beginneth to blo≈ø≈øome as it did before: the tree is as great as a Plum tree, and is commonly planted behinde mens hou≈øes, in their gardens for a plea≈øure, and for the ≈øweet ≈ømell: it groweth very quickly vp, for that many young plantes do ≈øpring out of the roote, and as ≈øoone as tho≈øe young plantes be aboue halfe a fadome high, they haue pre≈øently as many blo≈ø≈øoms vppon them as the branches on the trees, and although they cut the tree down to the ground‚ñ™ yet within le≈ø≈øe then halfe a yeare there will branches ≈øpring out of the roote, and likewi≈øe if you breake a branch off from the tree & ≈øet it in the earth, it will pre≈øently take root and grow, & within few dayes after beareth blo≈ø≈øoms: the blo≈ø≈øomes
are in a manner like Orange tree blo≈ø≈øomes, the flowre being white, and in the bottome ≈øomewhat yellow and reddi≈øh, which in India they v≈øe for Saffron, therewith to dre≈ø≈øe their meats, and to die with all as wee doe with our Saffron, but it is neyther ≈øo good nor of ≈øo plea≈øant a ta≈øte, yet it ≈øerueth there for want of the other.

p.hi: Some ≈øay, that the water of this tree being di≈øtilled, is good for the eyes, ≈øteeping linnen clothes in it, and ≈øo laying them to the eyes.

div.p: This tree is found in no place but in Goa, and Malacca, & in ≈øome other places, where the Portingalles inhabiting, haue planted them, for that they fir≈øt came out of Malacca into India, but within the land there is none, they are called in the Malayan tongue Singady, in Decanun, Pari≈øatico, in Decan, Pul, of the Arabians Guart, of the Per≈øians and Turkes G ‚Ä¢ l. The cau≈øe of this name, as the Indians ≈øay, is, that a Gentleman ‚Ä¢ alled Pari≈øatico had a faire daughter, of whom the Sunne became amorous, and in the end obtained his plea≈øure of her, but not long after he fell in loue with another, & for≈øook her, wherupon ≈øhe falling into di≈øpaire killed her≈øelfe, and according to the cu≈øtome of the countrie her body was burnt, of who≈øe a≈øhes they ≈øay this tree ≈øprang vp, and for the ≈øame cau≈øe was called Pari≈øa ‚Ä¢ ico, and therefore they ≈øay by rea≈øon of the hatred it beareth vnto the Sunne, it neuer bringeth foorth blo≈ø≈øome or flowre, but hy night, and in the day time for griefe they pre≈øently fall off.

p.hi: The de≈øcription of this Tree by Chri≈øtopherus de Co≈øta is ≈øet downe in this manner: that it is of the greatnes and ≈øimilitude of a plumme tree, with many ≈ømall branches, ≈øeperated by diuers knots and partitions, the leaues growing two and two together, and as bigge as plumme tree leaues, ≈øoft and rough on the out ≈øide, verie like to leaues of Sage, and inwardlie greene, and ≈øomewhat ≈øharp, but not ≈øo vneuen on the ≈øides as plumme leaues, neyther yet ≈øo full of veines. In the middle betweene the two leaues there groweth a little ≈øtalke, whereon are fiue ≈ømall heads, & out of them foure little rough leaues, out of the midde≈øt wherof there doe ≈øpring fiue ≈ømall white blo≈ø≈øomes, of the greatne≈ø≈øe and forme of Orange blo≈ø≈øomes, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, fairer, and ≈øweeter. The ≈øtalke ≈øeemeth more red than yellow, wherewith the Indians colour their meate, as wee doe with Saffron. The greene fruite is of the greatnes of a Lupyne, and in fa≈øhion like a little hart, ≈øomwhat long and deuided in the middle, hauing two places wherein the ≈øeed doth lie, which is al≈øo like a hart, and as bigge as the ≈øeeds of Saint Iohns bread, couered with a greene Skin, and ≈øomewhat bitter. Of all other Trees the≈øe are the plea≈øante≈øt of ≈ømell, ≈øo that they bee not handled, for if they be, they doe pre≈øently loo≈øe their ≈øweetnes and ≈ømell. The Indians are of opinion, that the≈øe flowers doe quicken and comfort the heart, but they are ≈øomewhat bitter, the Heathens likewi≈øe doe account the ≈øeede among their medicines that ≈øtrengthen the hart. The flowers may be v≈øed in meat, the ≈øeed hath oftentimes bin caried into Portingall, and there ≈øowed, but neuer would grow, what meanes ≈øoeuer they v≈øed, the flowers fall off when the ≈øunne ri≈øeth as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, eyther by rea≈øon of ≈øome contrariety, or becau≈øe of the ≈øubtill nature of the ≈øap, which the beames of the Sunne doe drie and con≈øume: for tho≈øe wheron the Sunne ≈øhineth not, ≈øtay ≈øomewhat longer on the tree. The≈øe flowers are very carefully gathered, whereof a very ≈øweet and plea≈øant water is di≈øtilled, which is called water de Mogli, ≈øome of this ≈øeede was brought me out of India by Iohn Hughen, which I ≈øowed in the grouÃÑd, but it came not forth.

div.head: The 60. Chapter. Of the Bettele leaues, & the fruit Arecca.
div.p:
THe leaues called Bett ‚Ä¢ e
‚Ä¢ e or Bettre, which is very common in India, and dayly eaten by the Indians, doe grow in all places of India, where the Portingals haue di≈øcouerd, not with in the countrie, but only on the ≈øea coa≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee ≈øome ≈ømall quantitie. It wil not growe in cold places, as China ‚ñ™ nor in ouer hot places as Mo≈øambique and Sofala, and
becau≈øe it is ≈øo much v≈øed, I haue particularly ≈øet it downe in this place, although it is already ≈øpoken of in many other places. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that this Bettele is a leafe ≈øomewhat greater and longer out than Orange leaues, and is planted by ≈øticks, wherevpon it climeth like Iuie or pepper, and ≈øo like vnto pepper, that a farre off growing each by other, they can hardlie bee de≈øcerned. It hath no other fruite but the leaues only, it is much dre≈ø≈øed and looked vnto, for that it is the dayly breade of India. The leaues being gathered doe continue long without withering, alwaies ≈øhewing fre≈øh and greene, and are ≈øold by the dozen, and there is not any woman or man in all India, but that euery day eateth a dozen or two of the ≈øame leaues or more: not that they v≈øe them for foode, but after their meale tides, in the morning and all the day long, as likewi≈øe by night, and as they goe abroad in the ≈øtr√©etes, where≈øoeuer they be you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e them with ≈øome of the≈øe leaues in their handes, which continually they are chawing. The≈øe leaues are not v≈øed to bee eaten alone, but becau≈øe of their bitterne≈ø≈øe they are eaten with a certaine kinde of fruit which the Malabares and Portingales call Arecca, the Gu≈øurates and Decanijns, Supari ‚Ä¢ , and the Arabians Fauffel. This fruite groweth on trees like the Palme tr√©es that beare the Nut Cocus in India, but they are ≈øomewhat thinner, with the leaues ≈øomewhat longer, and ≈ømaller. The fruit is much like the fruit that groweth on Cipre≈ø≈øe trees, or like a Nutmeg, though ≈øome of them are on the one ≈øide flat, & on the other ≈øide thicker, ≈øome being ≈øomewhat greater and very hard. They cut them in the middle with a knife, and ≈øo chaw them with Bettele, they are within ful of veines, white, and ≈øomwhat reddi≈øh. There is a kinde of Arecca called Cechaniin, which are le≈ø≈øe, blacker, and very hard, yet are likewi≈øe v≈øed with Bettele, and haue no ta≈øte, but onlie of the wood, and yet it moy≈øteneth the mouth, and coloureth it both red and blacke, whereby it ≈ø√©emeth that the lips and the teeth are painted with blacke blood, which happeneth when the Arecca is not well dried. There is another ≈øort which in the eating or chawing beeing ≈øwallowed downe, maketh men light in the heade, as if they had drunke wine all the day long, but that is ≈øoone pa≈øt. They v≈øe yet another mixture which they eate withall, that is to ≈øay, a cake or role made of a certaine wood or tree called Kaate, and then they annoint the Bettele leaues with chalke made of burnt oy≈øter ≈øhelles, which can doe no hurt in their bodies, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømall quantitie of it, all this being chawed togeather, and the Iuice ≈øwallowed downe into their bodies, for all the re≈øt they ≈øpit forth, they ≈øay it is very good for the maw, and again≈øt a ≈øtinking breath, a ≈øoueraigne medecine for the teeth, and fa≈øtning of gummes, and very good again≈øt the Schorbucke, and it is mo≈øt true that in India verie few men are found with ≈øtinking breathes or tooth aches, or troubled with the Scorbuch or any ≈øuch di≈øea≈øes, and although they be neuer ≈øo old, they alwaies haue their teeth whole and ≈øound, but their mouthes and teeth are ≈øtill as if they were painted with black blood, as I ≈øaid before, and neuer leaue ≈øpitting reddi≈øh ≈øpittle like blood. The Portingale women haue the like cu≈øtome of eating the≈øe Bettele leaues, ≈øo that if they were but one day without eating their Bettele, they per≈øwade them≈øelues they could not liue: Yea, they ≈øet it in the night times by their Beddes heades, and when they cannot ≈øleepe, they doe nothing els but chaw Bettele and ≈øpit it out againe. In the day time where≈øoeuer they doe ≈øit, goe, or ≈øtand, they are continually chawing thereof, like Oxen or Kine chawing their cud: for the whole exerci≈øe of many Portingale women, is onely all the day long to wa≈øh them≈øelues, and then fal to the chawing of their Bettele. There are ≈øome Portingales that by the common cu≈øtome of their wiues eating of Bettele, doe likewi≈øe v≈øe it. When the Indian women go to vi≈øit one an other, the Bettele goeth with them, and the greate≈øt plea≈øure or entertainement they can ≈øhew one to the other, is pre≈øently to pre≈øent them with ≈øome Bettele, Arecca, and chalke in a woodden di≈øh, which they k√©epe onely for that purpo≈øe. This Bettele is to bee ≈øold in euery corner, and ≈øtreete, and ≈øhoppe of the towne, as al≈øo in euery high way for trauellers and pa≈ø≈øengers, and is ready prepared, that is to ≈øay, ≈øo many Bettele leaues, one Arecca & ≈øome chalke, and many times ≈øome Cate for ≈øuch as de≈øire to haue it, which they commonly keepe in their hou≈øes, or beare in their hands in a woodden painted di≈øh, and ≈øo eate in this ≈øort, fir≈øt a peece of Arecca, and Cate, which they chaw, after that a leafe of Bettele, and with the naile of their thumbe, which they purpo≈øely weare ≈øharpe and long, not round as wee doe, they pull the veines or ≈øtringes out of the leafe, and ≈øo ≈ømeare it with chalke, and rowling it together, they thru≈øt it in their mouthes and chaw it. The fir≈øt ‚Ä¢ ap thereof they ≈øpit forth, and ≈øay that thereby they purge the head and the maw of all euill, and flegmaticke humors, and their ≈øpittle being as fowle as blacke blood, which colour proceedeth from the Arecca, the re≈øt of the Iuice they ≈øwallow downe.

The Indians goe continually in the
≈øtr√©etes and waies with Bettele and the other mixtures chawing in their handes, ≈øpecially wheÃÑ they go to ≈øpeake with any man, or come before a great Lord, therby to retaine a good ≈ømell, and to keepe their breathes ≈øw√©et, and if they ≈øhould not haue it in that ≈øort with them when≈øoeuer they meete or ≈øpeake with any man of account, it were a great ≈øhame for them.

p.hi: The women likewi≈øe when they accompany ≈øecretly with their husbands, doe fir≈øt eat a little Bettele, which (they think) maketh them apter to the game. All the Indians eate it after their meales, ≈øaying that otherwi≈øe their meate wold vpbraide them, and ri≈øe in their ≈øtomakes, and that ≈øuch as haue v≈øed to eate it, and leaue it, doe pre≈øently get a ≈øtincking breath. They doe at certaine times forbeare the eating of Bettele, as when any of their neere≈øt friends die, and al≈øo on certain fa≈øting daies, as likewi≈øe ≈øome Arabians and the followers of Ali, Mahomets brother in lawe, doe vpon their fa≈øting dayes. In Malabar, this leafe is called Bettele, in Decam Gu≈øurate, and Canam, it is called Pam, in Malaion, Siri, by Auicenna, Tambul, but better by others. Tambul, Auicenna ≈øayeth, that Bettele ≈øtrengthneth the maw, and fa≈øtneth the fle≈øh of the Gummes, for which purpo≈øe the Indians doe v≈øe it, but where he affirmeth tho≈øe leaues to be cold in the fir≈øt degree, and drying in the ≈øecond, it is not ≈øo, for either his Booke is fal≈øe printed, for hee was deceiued therein, for tho≈øe leaues are hotte and drie in the end of the ≈øecond degree, as Garcius ab Horto him≈øelf hath found out, likewi≈øe the ta≈øte and ≈ømell therof doe affirme it to be ≈øo. This Bettele is like a Citron leafe, but ≈øomewhat longer, ≈øharpe at the ende, hauing certaine veines that runne along the leafe. The rype≈øt are holden to bee the be≈øt, and are of colour yellowi≈øh, although ≈øome women chu≈øe the vnripe, becau≈øe they are plea≈øanter in the chawing. The leaues doe wither by much handling. The Bettele in Malacca, beareth a fruit like the tayle of an Efte, which becau≈øe it ta≈øteth well, is eaten: it is planted like a Vine vpon ≈øtickes, as Hoppes with vs. Some for their greater benefit Plant it among Pepper, and among Arecca, and there of doe make a plea≈øant Gallerie. This Bettele mu≈øt be carefully looked vnto, and often watered. He that de≈øireth to knowe more hereof, let him reade the worthie commentaries of learned Clu≈øius, vppon the Chapter of Garcius touching Bettele.

div.p: The Noblemen and Kings, where≈øoeuer they goe, ≈øtand or ≈øit, haue alwaies a ≈øeruant by them, with a Siluer ketle in their hand full of Bettele and their mixtures, and when they will eat, giue them a leafe ready prepared. And when any Amba≈ø≈øadour commeth to ≈øpeake with the King, although the King can vnder≈øtand them well, yet it is their maner (to maintaine their e≈øtates) that the Amba≈ø≈øadour ≈øpeaketh vnto them by an interpreter, that ≈øtandeth there in pre≈øence, which done, be an≈øwereth againe by the ≈øame interpreter. In the meane time, the King lyeth on a bed, or el≈øe ≈øitteth on the ground, vppon a Carpet, and his ≈øeruant ≈øtandeth by, readie with the Bettele, which he continually chaweth, and ≈øpitteth out the Iuyce, and the remainder thereof, into a Siluer Ba≈øon; ≈øtanding by him, or el≈øe holden by ≈øome one of his ≈ølaues or his wiues, & this is a great honour to the Amba≈ø≈øadour, ≈øpecially if he profereth him of the ≈øame Bettele that he him≈øelfe doth eate. To conclude, it is their common v≈øe to eate it, which becau≈øe it is their dayly exerci≈øe, and that they con≈øume ≈øo much, I haue made ye longer di≈øcour≈øe, the better to vnder≈øtand it, although ≈øomewhat hath b√©ene ≈øaid thereof in other places. The Kings & Lords of India v≈øe pilles made of Arecca, Cate and Camphora, with beaten Lignum aloes, and a little Amber, which they eate altogether with Bettele and Chalke, in ≈øt√©ede of Arecca.

p.hi: Some mixe Bettele with Licium,

≈øome and tho≈øe of the richer & mightier ≈øort with Campher, others with Lignum aloes, Muske and Amber Grijs, and beeing ≈øo prepared, is plea≈øant of ta≈øte and maketh a ≈øweet breath. There are ≈øome that chaw Arecca either with Cardamomum, or with Cloues. Within the lande farre from the Sea, tho≈øe leaues are ≈øolde verie deare. It is ≈øaid, that the King of Decan Mizamoxa ≈øpendeth yearely thereof, to the valew of aboue thirtie thou≈øand Milreyes. This is their banquetting ≈øtuffe, and is giuen
them by trauellers, and the Kings giue it to their Subiects. To the rich they giue thereof being mixed with their owne hands, and to others they ≈øend it by their ≈øeruants. When they ≈øend any man of Amba≈ø≈øage or otherwi≈øe; there are certaine Silke Pur≈øes full of prepared Bettele deliuered vnto him, and no man may depart before it be deliuered him, for it is a ≈øigne or token of his pa≈ø≈øe port.

div.p: By the pictures hereafter following you may ≈ø√©e the figures of the fruites of Malacca called Duryoens, & ye tr√©e Arbore de Rays, or roote tr√©e, likewi≈øe the thicke R√©edes, named by the Portingales Bambu, and by the Indians Mambu, with the tr√©e called Arbore Tri≈øte, or the ≈øorrowfull tr√©e, as it is both by day and by night, and the tr√©e whereon Arecca doth grow, as likewi≈øe the Bettele. And becau≈øe Pepper is oftentimes planted at the foote of the Arecca tr√©e, where it groweth and clymeth vp round about the body thereof, I haue ≈øet it downe, in the ≈øame order as it groweth: The de≈øcription whereof ≈øhall in an other place bee ≈øhewed, among the Spices and drugges of India, as al≈øo the Hearbes, ≈øeruing for Phy≈øicke, and Apothecarie ware &c.

div.head: The 61. Chapter. Of the Hearbe Dutroa, and a Plant called Herba Sentida, or the feeling Hearbe.
div.p: THe Hearbe called Dutroa, is verie common in India, and groweth in euerie fielde: the leafe thereof is ≈øharpe at the ende, like the pointe of a Speare, and is indented on the edges like the leafe of Beares claw, and about that bigne≈ø≈øe, hauing in it many long thr√©edes or veines, it groweth without ta≈øte, or moy≈øture, and ≈øomewhat bitter and ≈ømelling like a Raddi≈øh. The flower or blo≈ø≈øome of this Plant is verie like vnto the blo≈ø≈øome of Ro≈øe-marie in colour: and out of this blo≈ø≈øome groweth a bud, much like the bud of Popie, wherein are certaine ≈ømall kernels like the kernels of Melons, which being ≈øtamped, and put into any meate, wine, water or any other drinke or compo≈øition, and eaten or drunke therewith, maketh a man, in ≈øuch ca≈øe as if hee were fooli≈øh or out of his wittes‚ñ™ ≈øo that he doth nothing el≈øe but laugh, without any vnder≈øtanding or ≈øence once to perceiue any thing that is done in his pre≈øence. And ≈øome time it maketh him ≈øl√©epe as if he were dead, in that ≈øort he continueth for the ≈øpace of twentie foure houres: but if his f√©ete bee wa≈øhed with colde water, then hee commeth to him≈øelfe againe before the twentie fower howers be expired. This Herbe the Indian and Portingall women v≈øe much to giue vnto their hu≈øbandes, and often times when they are di≈øpo≈øed to bee merrie with their ≈øecrete louers, they giue it him‚ñ™ and goe in his pre≈øence and performe their leacherie together, and taking their hu≈øband by the beard, they will call him Cornudo, with other ≈øuch like ie≈øtes, the man not knowing any thing thereof, but ≈øitteth with his eyes open, not doing or ≈øaying any thing, but laugh and grin, like a foole, or a man out of his wits: and when the time commeth that he reuiueth out of his tran≈øe, he knoweth nothing what was done, but thinketh that hee had ≈ølept. This Hearbe the ≈ølaues v≈øe likewi≈øe to giue their ma≈øters and mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes, therby to robbe them and to breake open their Che≈øts, which is oftentimes done, this Dutroa mu≈øt bee v≈øed in mea≈øure, becau≈øe it is a kind of poy≈øon, for if a man giue too much thereof hee may bring a man to his ende, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øome ≈øtrong and pre≈øent remedie be taken, by ≈øome conterpoy≈øon or Purgation.

div.p:

Some men are ≈øo v≈øed to eate and drink Dutroa, not knowing of it, that ta≈øting onely of the Iuice of the leaues, they are pre≈øently in a tran≈øe, and ≈øo the wife is well a≈ø≈øured, and without all feare to ≈øati≈øfie her lu≈øt. This and ≈øuch like Hearbes there are in India, and are much v≈øed, for that all the care & ≈øtudie that ye women and wiues of India haue, is day and night to deui≈øe meanes to ≈øati≈øfie then plea≈øures, and to increa≈øe lu≈øt, by all the deui≈øes they can imagine, and to make their bodies the apter thereunto. which is like the blacke, ≈øauing the fir≈øt outmo≈øt hu≈øke is white and ≈ømooth, without any wrinckle, but hath the verie ≈øelf ≈øame vertue and ta≈øte that black pepper hath. The pepper that groweth in the countries about Malacca is many times al≈øo brought into Portingal, but verie little, for that it is 2 yeares betweene euery ≈øhip that ≈øayleth out of Portingale thither, which being there, taketh in ≈øome pepper, but mo≈øt Cloues and Nutmegges with their flowers and other marchandi≈øes of China: But the mo≈øt part of that pepper is v≈øed in the ≈øame countries, as in Pegu, Syon, & ≈øpecially in China, and other countries bordering on the ≈øame, which deal continually one with an other. Pepper by the Malabares is called Molanga, and in the countries by Malacca Lada: in Arabia, Fil ‚Ä¢ il: the Gu≈øarates of Cambaia and Decamins of Ballagate cal it Meriche: and they of Bengala, Moro ‚Ä¢ s: and the long pepper which groweth onely in BeÃÑ g ‚Ä¢ la and Iaua, is called Pelc ‚Ä¢ m. The leaues of pepper are like Orange leaues, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, they are green and ≈øharp at the ends, in the chawing it biteth the tong, and ta≈øteth much like to Bettele, it growes in bun≈øhes like grapes, but a great deale le≈ø≈øer and thynner, yet ≈øomewhat thicker then Goo≈øeberries: they are alwaies green til they begin to drie and to ripen, which is in DeceÃÑ ber and Ianuary, for at that time they are gathered. The long pepper groweth in Bengala, and ≈øome in the Iland of Iaua, and is an other kinde of tr√©e: the long pepper is of the length of a n√©edle, or the tagge of a point, but ≈øomewhat thicker, and all of a like thicknes: it is outwardly rugged, and of an a≈øhie colour, and within ≈øomewhat white, with ≈ømall ≈øeedes, but in ta≈øte and v≈øe it is like the other black and white pepper. The Pepper called Canariins in the countrie of Goa and Malabar, almo≈øt of the fa≈øhion of Panike: it is of an a≈øhe colour, and holow within, with ≈øome ≈ømal kernels, which in eating ta≈øteth and heateth like other pepper, yet it is v≈øed onely by the poore people, and therefore is called Canariin pepper, that is to ≈øay, Countrie mens pepper, or poore peoples pepper: therefore it is neuer laden away, for it is verie cour≈øe and of little value, neither would it be able to ray≈øe the fraight, and therfore is it left in the countrie. The other pepper is in India and all other Ea≈øtern countries, much v≈øed and ≈øpent by the Indians them≈øelues, and that in greater quantitie then yearelie is carried or laden from thence for other places, for they eate not any kinde of meate, but they put therein handfuls of pepper, al vnbeaten, ≈øo that they wa≈øte the more. div.head: The 63. Chapter. Of Cinamom.
div.p:
CInamon in Latin is called Cinamo ‚Ä¢

china, by the men of Seylon, (where it mo≈øt groweth) Curdo: of the people of Malacca, Cay≈øman: and by the Malabares, Camea: the trees are as great as Oliue trees, and ≈øome le≈ø≈øer, with leaues of Colmi like Baye leaues, but of fa≈øhion like Citron leaues, though ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller. The≈øe trees are in great abundance, for they grow of them≈øelues without planting, in the open fields like bu≈øhes: the roote of this tree yeeldeth a water, which ≈ømelleth like Camphora, it is forbidden to be drawn forth, for ≈øpoyling the trees. div.head: The 64. Chapter. Of Ginger.
div.p:
GInger groweth in manie places of India, yet the be≈øt, & mo≈øt caryed abroad, is that which groweth in the coa≈øt of Malabar: it groweth like thin and young Netherland reedes of two or thr√©e ≈øpannes high, the roote whereof is the Ginger, being greene, it is much eaten in India, for ≈øallets, as al≈øo ≈øodden in Vineger, which they call Achar, as I ≈øaid of pepper, and other fruites that are v≈øed in that maÃÑner throughout al India: the time wheÃÑ they are mo≈øt gathered and begun to be dried, is in December and Ianuarie: they drie it in this ≈øort, that is, they couer it with pot-earth, which they doe to ≈øtop and fill vp the holes, and thereby to make it continue the fre≈øher, for the pot-earth pre≈øerueth it from wormes, without the which it is pre≈øentlie con≈øumed by them‚ñ™ it is little e≈øt√©emed in India notwith≈øtanding there is much ≈øhipped as well to the red ≈øea as to Ormus, Arabia and A≈øia, but little for Portingal ‚ñ™ becau≈øe it will not ≈øaue ye fraught and cu≈øtome: onlie the gunner of the Indian ≈øhippes may lade and bring certaine Quintals without paying any cu≈øtome, which by the King of Portingale was of long tyme granted vnto them, and is yet ob≈øerued: and this they may fel to marchants and ≈øo by this meanes there is ≈øome brought, otherwi≈øe but very little, for that the mo≈øt part of Ginger brought into Spain, cometh from Cabo verde, the Ilands of S. p.hi: Ginger by the Arabians, Per≈øians, and Turkes is called Gengibil, in Gu≈øurate, Decan, Annota. div.head: The 65. Chapter Of Cloues.
div.p:
CLoues are by the Turkes, Per≈øians Arabians and mo≈øt part of the Indians called Ca
‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r, and in the Ilands of Maluco, where they are only found and do grow Chamke. The≈øe Ilands are fine, lying vnder the Equinoctiall line, as in the de≈øcriptions therof is declared. They haue nothing el≈øe but Cloues, which are caried froÃÑ thence, through out the world, the trees whereon they grow, are like Bay-tr√©es, the blo≈ø≈øomes at the fir≈øt white, then greene, and at the la≈øt red and hard, which are the Cloues, and when the blo≈ø≈øomes are gr√©ene, they haue the plea≈øante≈øt ≈ømell in all the world. The Cloues grow verie thicke together and in great numbers, they are gathered and then dried, their right colour, when they are drie, is a darke yelow, and to giue them a blacke colour, they are commonly ≈ømoked. The Cloues that ≈øtay on the tr√©e vngathered are thicke, and ≈øtay on till the next yeare, which are tho≈øe that are called the mother of the Cloues. And in the place where the tr√©es ≈øtand, there groweth not any gra≈ø≈øe or gr√©ene Hearbe at all, but it is wholly drie, for that tho≈øe trees draw all the moy≈øture vnto them. That which the Portingals call Ba≈øton ‚ñ™ or with vs the ≈øtocke of the Cloue, and is the ≈øtalke whereby they hang on the trees is gathered with the Cloues and ≈øo they are mingled together: for that in Maluco they neuer garble their Cloues, but in India they are many times parted, though verie little: for they are mo≈øt part ≈øold and v≈øed with du≈øt, and ≈øtalkes and all together, but ≈øuch as are to bee ≈øent to Portingall are ≈øeuered and clen≈øed The Cloues are ≈øo hotte of nature, that when≈øoeuer them are made cleane, and ≈øeperated from their Garbi≈øh, if there chance to ≈øtand either Tubbe or Payle of water in the Chamber where they clen≈øe them, or any other ve≈ø≈øell with wine or any kind of moy≈øture, it will within two dayes at the furthe≈øt be wholly ≈øoken out and dryed vp, although it ≈øtand not n√©ere them, by rea≈øon of the great heate of the Cloues, that draw all moy≈øture vnto them, as by experience I haue often ≈ø√©ene. The ≈øame nature is in the vn≈øpunne Silke of China, ≈øo that when≈øoeuer the Silke lyeth any where in a hou≈øe vpon the flowre, that is to ≈øay, vppon boordes, a foote or two aboue the ground, and that the flowre is ≈øprinkled and couered with
water, although it toucheth not the Silke, in the Morning all that water will bee in the Silke, for that it draweth it all vnto it. And this tricke the Indians often times v≈øe to make their Silke weigh heauie, when they ≈øel it‚ñ™ for it can neither be ≈ø√©en nor found in the Silke. But returning to our matter, the Cloues grow about the length of a great ≈øhot from the Sea ≈øide, and are neither planted nor ≈øet, and nothing el≈øe is done vnto them, but only when they plucke and gather them, they make the place vnder the tr√©es verie cleane. The tr√©e will not grow verie clo≈øe to the Sea ≈øide, nor farre from it, for the≈øe Ilands are altogether compa≈ø≈øed about with the Sea. When it is a fruitfull yeare, then the Cloues are in greater abundance then the leaues. When they gather them, they do not pluck them with their hands, but with ropes which they fa≈øten about the branches, and by force they ≈øhake them off, and by that meanes the tr√©es are ≈øo ≈øpoyled, that the next yeare after they yeelde but little fruite: but the ≈øecond yeare then after en≈øuing, there grow vp tr√©es of the Cloues that fell vpon the ground, when they gathered them two yeares before, like Che≈ønut tr√©es, and they growe verie ≈øound, becau≈øe of the great rayne that falleth in tho≈øe places: for tho≈øe Ilandes lye vnder the Equinoctiall line, and y√©elde fruite within eight yeares, and ≈øo continue aboue a hundreth yeares. The time when they are gathered and dried, is from September to Ianuarie. When the Cloues are gr√©ene, they make good con≈øerues in Sugar, and are likewi≈øe ≈øalted in Vineger & ≈øo kept in pots, and made of Achar, in which manner they are carried into Malacca and India. They likewi≈øe di≈øtill water out of the gr√©en Cloues which is verie cordiall and v≈øed in many Medecines. The Indian women v≈øe much to chawe Cloues, thereby to haue a ≈øw√©ete breath, which the Portingales wiues that dwell there, doe now begin to v≈øe, the leaues of the Cloue-trees, are altogether like Bayleaues.

They are full of branches, and haue aboundance of blo≈ø≈øomes, which doe turne the≈øe fruites, and are called Cloues becau≈øe in forme and ≈øhape they doe re≈øemble a Birdes clawes.
