The people of Iaua de≈øire the gray Cloues, that hang a whole yere and more vpon the trees, and are no Males, as Auia doth ab≈øurdly adui≈øe, and as we of the common ≈øort doe, who couet the thinne≈øt. When they are greene, they v≈øe to ≈øalt them, with ≈øalt and Vineger in Maluco, and ≈øome they put in Suger, which are verie plea≈øant to bee eaten. The water of greene Cloues di≈øtilled is very plea≈øant of ≈ømel, and ≈øtrengthneth the hart, likewi≈øe they procure ≈øweating in men that haue the Pox, with Cloues, Nutmegges, Mace, long and black Pepper, ≈øome lay the poulder of Cloues vpon a mans head, that hath a paine in it, that proceedeth of colde. They ≈øtrengthen the Liuer, the Maw, and the hart, they further dige≈øtion, they procure euacuation of the Vrine, and ≈øtop la≈øcatiuenes, and being put into the eyes, pre≈øerueth the ≈øight, and foure Drammes being drunke with Milke, doe procure lu≈øt.

div.head: The 66, Chapter. Of Mace, Folie, or flowers of Nutmegges, and of Nutmegges.
div.p:
THe Nutmegge tr√©e is like a Peare tree or a Peach tr√©e, but that they are le≈ø≈øe, and it hath round leaues. The≈øe tr√©es growe in the Iland of Banda, not farre from Maluco, and al≈øo in the Ilandes of Iauas & Sunda, from whence they are carried to China, and Malacca, and al≈øo into India and other places. The fruite is altogether like great round Peaches, the inward part whereof is the Nutmegge. This hath about it a hard ≈øhell like wood, wherein the Nut lyeth loo≈øe: and this wooden ≈øhel or hu≈øke is couered ouer with Nutmeg flower, which is called Mace, and ouer it is the fruite, which without is like the fruite of a Peach. When it is ripe it is a verie co≈øtly meate, and of a mo≈øt plea≈øaunt ≈øauor. This fruite or Apples are many times con≈øerued in Sugar being whole, and in that ≈øort caried throughout India, and much e≈øt√©emed: for in truth it is the be≈øt con≈øerue in all India, and is many times brought ouer into Portingall, and from thence hether. They are likewi≈øe ≈øalted and put in Vineger, which is much v≈øed in India. When the Nuttes begin
to be ripe, then they ≈øwell, and the fir≈øt ≈øhell or hu≈øke bur≈øteth in p√©eces, and the Nutmegge flowers doe continue redde, as any Scarlet, which is a verie faire ≈øight to behold, e≈øpecially if the tr√©es bee full of fruite. Sometimes al≈øo the Mace breaketh, which is the cau≈øe that the Nutmegges‚ñ™ come all together without the Mace, and when the Nutmegge drieth, then the Mace falleth off, and the red changeth into Orenge colour, as you ≈ø√©e by the Mace that is brought hether. The Ilands where they grow, ≈øpecially Banda, are very vnhole≈øome countries, as al≈øo the Ilands of Maluco, many that traffique thether die before they depart from thence, or if they e≈øcape, they are in great perill of their liues, by ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, notwith ≈øtanding great gaine maketh men to trauell thether. The Nutmegge (by the inhabitants of Banda, where they are mo≈øt growing) is called Palla, and the Mace or Nutmegge flower, Buna Palla. The Decanijns and Indians call it Iapatry, and the Mace Iayfol.

p.hi: The trees whereon Nutmegs and Mace do grow,
are not vnlike to Peare trees, but ≈øhorter and rounder leaues, they are good for paine in the head, for the mother and the Sinewes.

The Nut is compa≈ø≈øed about with three kinds of Barkes. The fir≈øt & outermo≈øt is like the greene ≈øhell of an Acorne, and when they are ripe that ≈øhel openeth: then you find a thin ≈øhell or barke like a Nutte, which compa≈ø≈øeth the fruite, and by vs is called Mace, which both in meate and Medicine is verie ≈øeruiceable and whole≈øome. The third ≈øhell is harder and more like vnto wood then the fir≈øt, and is like the Acorne, but that it is blacker, which being opened, you find the Nutmegge therein.

When the fruit is ripe, and that the fir≈øt ≈øhell breaketh open, then the Mace is of a mo≈øt faire red colour, and when the fruit is drie, the Mace likewi≈øe doth change, and becommeth a Golden yellow.
There are two ≈øorts of Nutmegges, one long, which are called Males, the other round, which are better & ≈øtronger.

The Nutmeg comforteth the braine, ≈øharpneth the memorie, warmeth and ≈øtrengthneth the Maw, driueth winde out of the body, maketh a ≈øweet breath, driueth downe Vrine, ≈øtoppeth the Laske, and to conclude, is good again≈øt all colde di≈øea≈øes in the heade, in the braine, the Mawe, the Liuer and the Matrice.
The Oyle thereof is better then the re≈øt, for all the afore≈øaid named infirmities.
Mace is ≈øpecially good for a colde and a weake maw, it procureth dige≈øtion of the meate, drieth vp all euill humors and breaketh wind.

div.head: The 67. Chapter. Of Cardamomum
div.p: CArdamomum is a kinde of ≈øpice which they v≈øe much in India to dre≈ø≈øe with their meates, and commonly they haue it in their mouthes to chaw vpon. It is very good again≈øt a ≈øtincking breath and euill humors in the head, and ≈øerueth al≈øo for other things in medecines: it groweth like other graynes and is verie like to Panyke, but of a white colour drawing ≈øomewhat towards yealow. The hu≈økes are as great as the hu≈økes of Panyke graines, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømal: within there is about 10 or 12 graines of berryes, which is the Cardamomum. There are two ≈øorts of Cardamomum, that is to ≈øay, great and ≈ømall, and called by the Malabares, Etremilly: the Gu≈øurates, Decaniins & Bengalers cal it Hil, and the Mores inhabiting among them, call it Hilachij. This is much v≈øed in India, and is a marchandi≈øe which is caryed into all places of India: mo≈øt of it groweth in Calecut and Cananor, places on the coa≈øt of Malabar: it is likewi≈øe in other places of Malabar, and in the Iland of Iaua, and from the countries afore≈øaid it is mo≈øt caryed into other places, but little brought into Portingal, becau≈øe of the great charges, and long way: yet many times the Saylers and other trauellers bring it. They ≈øieth no fle≈øh in India, but commonly they put Cardomomum into the pot, it maketh the mea ‚Ä¢ to haue as good a ≈øauor and a ta≈øte as any of the other ≈øpices of India.

p.hi: Auicenna ≈øayth there are two kinds of it, the one he calleth Saccolaa quebir, that is, great Cardamomum, and the other Saccolaa Regner, that is, ≈ømal Cardamomum: in Malabar it is called Etremelly, in Seylan Encal, in Bengala Gu≈øaratte, and Decan ≈øometimes Hil, & ≈øometimes Elachi, but that is by the Moores, for the Heathens throughout all India call it Dors Cardamomum: to the auncicient Grecians, as Galen, Dio≈øcorides, and others, it was altogether vnknowne: & although Galen in his ≈øeuenth booke of Simples ≈øaith, that Cardamomum is not ≈øo hot, as Na≈øturcium or water Cre≈ø≈øes, but plea≈øanter of ≈øauour, and ≈ømell with ≈øome ≈ømall bitterne≈ø≈øe, yet tho≈øe ≈øignes or properties doe not agree with the Cardamomum of India. Dio≈øcorides in his fir≈øt booke and fift Chapter commending the Cardamomum brought out of Comagens, Armenia, and Bo≈øphoras (although hee ≈øaith al≈øo that ≈øuch doe growe in India and Arabia) ≈øaith, that wee mu≈øt choo≈øe that which is full, and tough in breaking, ≈øharpe & bitter of ta≈øte, and with the ≈ømell thereof cau≈øeth a heauine≈ø≈øe in a mans head: yet is the Indian Cardamomum caryed into tho≈øe places, from whence Dio≈øcorides affirmeth that his Cardamomum doeth come, although it bee neyther tough in breaking, nor annoyeth the heade, neyther is bitter of ta≈øte, nor ≈øo ≈øharpe as Cloues: the great Cardamomum hath a ≈øhell that is long and three cornered, wherein are certaine pale red kernels with corners: the ≈ømall Cardamomum hath likewi≈øe a three cornered huske, yet ≈øhorter, and with ≈ømaller kernels, parted in the middle with a thinne skinne; & this Cardamomum is of three ≈øorts, as minus, medium, minimum, that is, ≈ømall, ≈ømaller, and ≈ømalle≈øt of all. It heateth the Mawe, dige≈øteth the meat, and driueth away the giddines of the head: it is al≈øo eaten with Bettele, to purge the head & maw of ≈ølime and filthine≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The 68. Chapter. Of Lacke or hard Waxe.
div.p: LAcke by the Malabares, Bengalers, and Decaniins, is called A ‚Ä¢ sii, by the Moors Lac: the men of Pegu (where the be≈øt is found, and mo≈øt trafiqued withall) doe call it Treck, and deale much therewith by carrying it vnto the I≈øland of Sumatra (in time pa≈øt called Taprobana) and there they exchange it for Pepper, and from thence it is carried to the redde ≈øea, to Per≈øia and Arabia, wherevpon the Arabians, Per≈øians and Turkes call it Loc Sumutri, that is, Lac of Sumatra, becau≈øe it is brought from thence into their countries. The manner how it is made is thus: in Pegu, and tho≈øe places from whence it commeth, there are certaine very great Pi≈ømyres with winges, which fly vppe into the tr√©es, that are there like Plum tr√©es, and ≈øuch other Tr√©es, out of the which tr√©es comes a certaine gumme, which the Pi≈ømires ≈øucke vp, and then they make the Lac rounde about the branches of the tr√©es, as B√©es make Hony and Waxe, and when it is ful, the owners of the trees come, and breaking off the braunches lay them to drie, and being drie, the branches ≈øhrinke out, and the Lac remayneth behinde like a Reede: ≈øometimes the woode breaketh within them, but the le≈ø≈øe woode it hath within it, the better it is: the peeces and crummes that fall vpon the ground, they melt them together, but that is not ≈øo good, for it hath filth and earth within it: it happeneth oftentimes that they finde the Pi≈ømires winges within the raw Lac. When the Lac is raw, as it commeth from the Tree, it is a darke red colour, but being refined and clean≈øed, they make it of all colours in India.

p.hi: They beat the Lac to powder,

and melt it, and ≈øo mixe all manner of colours vpon it as they li≈øt, redde, blacke, greene, yellow, or any other colour, & make peeces, thereof, ≈øuch a ‚Ä¢ are ≈øold here to ≈øeale letters withall.

div.p:
Them they dre≈ø≈øe their bed≈øteds withall, that is to ≈øay, in turning of the woode, they take a peece of Lac of what colour they will, and as they turne it when it commeth to his fa≈øhion, they ≈øpread the Lac vpon the whole peece of woode, which pre≈øently with the heat of the turning melteth the Waxe, ≈øo that it entreth into the cre≈øtes & cleaueth vnto it‚ñ™ about
the thickne≈ø≈øe of a mans naile: then they burni≈øh it ouer with broad ≈øtraw or dry Ru≈øhes ≈øo cunningly, that all the woode is couered withall, and it ≈øhineth like Gla≈ø≈øe, mo≈øt plea≈øant to behold, and continueth as long as the wood, being well looked vnto: in this ≈øort they couer all kinde of hou≈øholde ≈øtuffe in India, as Bed≈øteddes, Chaires, ≈øtooles, &c. and all their turned woodworke, which is wonderful common and much v≈øed throughout all India: the fayre≈øt workeman≈øhippe thereof commeth from China, as it may be ≈ø√©ene, by all things that come from thence, as de≈øks‚ñ™ Targets, Tables, Cubbordes, Bores, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch like thinges, that are all couered and wrought with Lac of all colours and fa≈øhions: ≈øo that it maketh men to wonder at the beautie and brightnes of the colour, which is altogether Lac: they likewi≈øe v≈øe Lac to fill their Golde and Siluer workes, that is to ≈øay, haft ‚Ä¢ s of kniues, and other thinges, which they make very fayre outwardly of Siluer, and inwardly full of Lac. The Indians likewi≈øe are ≈øo cunning, that they make Ringes of Gold, which to mans ≈øight ≈ø√©eme very fayre and bright, as though they were all of ma≈ø≈øy Gold, inwardly they are hollow and ≈øtopt with Lac, and cannot bee perceyued, vnle≈ø≈øe a man bee aduerti≈øed thereof. There is Lac likewi≈øe in Ballaga ‚Ä¢
te and Malabar, but very little: the greate≈øt quantitie which from thence is carryed throughout India, and all other places, commeth out of the kingdome of Pegu.

div.head: The 69. Chapter. Of Annil or Indigo.
div.p: ANnil or Indigo by the Gu≈øurates is called Gali, by others Nil: it is a co≈øtly colour, and much caryed and trafiqued into Portingall: it groweth in India in the kingdom of Cambaia: the hearbe is very like Ro≈øemary, and is ≈øowed like other Hearbes, and when time and ≈øea≈øon ≈øerueth, pulled and dryed, and then it is made wette and beaten, and ≈øo certayne dayes after dryed againe, and then prepared. At the fir≈øt it is a fine greene, but after it is a fayre blew, as you ≈ø√©e it when it commeth hether, and the cleaner it is from earth and du≈øt, the better it is to proue if it be good: they burne it with a candle, and if then it fall out like fine meale, it is good; but if it be gro≈ø≈øe like ≈øande, it is not good: al≈øo being throwne into the water if it ≈øwimmeth it is good, but if it ≈øinke it is not good: this Annil was more accounted of‚ñ™ and commonly more worth then Cloues both in India and in Portingall: the King not long ≈øince hath farmed it out, ≈øo that no man may buy it in India, nor bring it into Portingall but onely the Farmers, as they do with Pepper.

p.hi: Annil or Nil, as the learned Doctor Camerarius witne≈ø≈øeth,

which hath had ≈øome of the plantes within his garden, hath sky ‚Ä¢ coloured leaues, being like to the leaues of the Hearbe which in Latine is called Barba Iouis, in Dutch Donder baert, but ≈øomewhat bro ‚Ä¢
der.

div.head: The 70. Chapter. Of Amber, Muske, Algallia or Ciuet.
div.p:
AMber by ≈øome men is thought to be the fome of a Whale fi≈øhe: others thinke it to bee the filth and dung of the Whale, and others a certain kind of Betumen, which floweth out of a well that ≈øtandeth on the ≈øea ≈øide, and ca≈øteth ye Amber vp, but it is to bee thought, that it is neyther of the fir≈øt two, for if it were, men ≈øhoulde continually finde Amber in the≈øe Countries, ≈øpocially on the coa≈øt of Bi≈øcay, where ≈øo many Whales are taken, yet is the ‚Ä¢ e no Amber found in that place: it were rather to bee bel√©eued that it is a Betumen or pitch‚ñ™ proceeding out of ≈øome fountaine or Well‚ñ™ or ≈øome thing that floweth from the bottome of the Sea, & ≈øo driueth vpon the water becau≈øe it is found in ≈øome places, and in ≈øome places not: where it is mo≈øt found, and from whence it dayly commeth is from the coa≈øt of So ‚Ä¢ la, Mo≈øambique, and on the coa≈øt of Me ‚Ä¢ de or Abe ‚Ä¢
: It is likewi≈øe ≈øometimes found by the I≈ølandes of Ma ‚Ä¢ diua, and the c ‚Ä¢ pe de Comorijn, but not much, and not ≈øo commonly as by So ‚Ä¢ la and Mo≈øambique. There are others that thinke it to be a ≈øpungie earth, of ≈øome vnknowne I≈øland, drought or hiddeÃÑ cliffes, and by force of the ≈øea in time broken off by peeces, and ca≈øt vpon the ≈øhore‚ñ™
like driftes or ≈øuch like thinges, for it is often times found floating and driuing in peeces of ten or twelue, and ≈øome of fifty or ≈øixtie pannes broad. They ≈øay that in India there hath bin found whole I≈ølandes of Amber, which being well marked by tho≈øe that found and di≈øcouered them, whereby to come thether againe and lade thereof, when they came to the ≈øame place they could not finde them. In Anno 1555. An. 1555 there was a p√©ece found not far from the cape de Como ‚Ä¢ iin that weighed 30. quintales, and he that found it, thought it to be pitch, whereupon he ≈øold it for a ≈ømall price, but afterwardes being knowne, it was greatly e≈øteemed: likewi≈øe oftentimes there commeth Amber that is mingled with ≈øhels, and all ≈øpotted with the dung of Sea foules, that ≈øit theron. There is Amber of a gray colour, with whiti≈øh vaines, that is the be≈øt: & it is called Amber Griis. There is a kinde of Amber which is perfect blacke, but not ≈øo much e≈øteemed as the gray, to prooue if the Amber be good they thru≈øt pinnes into it and that which yeeldeth mo≈øt oyle is the be≈øt. It is much v≈øed among the Indian Noble men, and kinges in their daylie meates, they v≈øe it likewi≈øe much to prouoke lu≈øt, and to increa≈øe nature, thereby to bee the more apt for the ≈øame, as al≈øo in many faire workes with mu≈øke, Ciuet, Bemoin, and other ≈øweete thinges mixed together, whereof they make fine apples and peares wrought about with ≈øiluer & gold, which they beare in their hands to ≈ømell vppon, and in haftes of kniues, handles of pomyards, and ≈øuch like, which they make of ≈øiluer, and Amber within theÃÑ, which in diuers places ≈øhineth through them. The≈øe and ≈øuch like workes are very common in India among the rich and mightie men of the countrie, as well Indians as Portingales.

p.hi: Ambarium in Latine, Ambar in Arabia, is a kind of pitch, as the Author very well affirmeth, ca≈øt vp out of ≈øome fountaine that ≈øtandeth in the bottome of the ≈øea, which being ≈øet in the Sunne doth pre≈øently become hard like other thinges that are al≈øo taken out of the ≈øea, as Corall, &c. This Ambar by rea≈øon of the ≈øweet & plea≈øant ≈ømell, doth comfort the head and the heart, and by the drynes thereof, it draweth away & con≈øumeth all watery humors out of the ≈øtomacke, and good again≈øt all filthie and foulene≈ø≈øe in a mans body. It cureth ≈øuch as haue the falling ≈øicknes. It is good again≈øt the ri≈øing of the Mother, being receiued in and thru≈øt vp into the body: to conclude it is good for all old men, and for euery cold complection.

div.p: The Almi≈øca ‚Ä¢ , Mo≈ø≈øeliat ‚ñ™ or Mu≈økcat coÃÑ meth from China: They are bea≈øtes like Fores, or little Dogs, which being killed, and beaten and bru≈øed, they let them lie and rot, blood and fle≈øh together: which done they cut them in p√©eces both ≈økinne, fle≈øh and blood, all mixed togeather, and therof make diuers pur≈øes, which they ≈øowe in a round forme, and are in that ≈øort caried abroad & ≈øold to diuers men. Tho≈øe pur≈øes are coÃÑmonly of an ounce waight the p√©ece, and by the Portingales are called Papos, but the right Papos, and perfect Mo≈ø≈øeliat is the ballockes or ≈øtones of that bea≈øt: the others although they pa≈ø≈øe among them for Mo≈ø≈øeliat, are not ≈øo good as the ≈øtones: therefore the Chinars, who in all thinges are very ≈øubtill, and fine workemen, make the pur≈øes cleane round, like the ≈øtones of the bea≈øte, therewith to deceiue the people, and ≈øo the ≈øooner to procure them to buy it. This bea≈øt hath a very ≈øtrange nature, and great vnder≈øtanding, for when it is cha≈øed, and perceiueth it ≈øelfe not able anie longer to continue in breath, it taketh the ≈øtones betw√©ene the t√©eth and biteth them off, and ≈øo ca≈øteth them away, as if it would ≈øay, if you come for them there they are, & while the hunt≈øman is bu≈øie to looke for them, ≈øhee oftentimes e≈øcapeth away and ≈øaueth her life. The Chinaes are very deceitfull in ≈øelling of Mo≈ø≈øeliat or Mu≈øke, for they fal≈øifie it verie much, ≈øometimes with Oxen and Cowes liuers, dried and beaten to powder, and ≈øo mixed with the Mo≈ø≈øeliat, as it is dayly found by experience in ≈øearching of it. When the Mo≈ø≈øeliat beginneth to decay and loo≈øeth the ≈ømel, they take it out of the pur≈øe and beate it verie ≈ømall in a morter, and that done being moi≈øtned with the vrine of a childe, and ≈øo put into an earthen pot that is leaded and cloa≈øe ≈øtopped, it will pre≈øently be good againe, if there were any goodnes or ≈øtrength left within it.

p.hi: Some are of opinion, that muske groweth at certaine times of the yeare about the nauell of a certaine bea≈øt, as if it were ≈øwolne. The pale yellow is the be≈øt, it ≈øtrengtheneth the trembling cold hart, & all di≈øea≈øes of the ≈øame, beeing drunke or ≈øwallowed. It clean≈øeth the white ≈øpots of the eyes, it dryeth moi≈øt catharres, it comforteth the head, & healeth the old aches thereof, proceeding of ≈øleame.

div.p:
Algalia or Ciuet is much found in India, that is to ≈øay in Bengala, but becau≈øe they caÃÑ not leaue their villanie & fal≈øifying thereof, it is not ≈øo much e≈øt√©emed, by rea≈øon they mixeted,
but the be≈øt Ciuet commeth from Myna in the coa≈øt of Guynea, which is very faire and good. It is the ≈øweat that proceedeth froÃÑ the Cats called Ciuet Cats, which are many times brought ouer aliue, both into Spaine, and al≈øo to the≈øe countries, but becau≈øe it is ≈øo ≈øufficiently knowne vnto vs, I will leaue to ≈øpeake thereof, and proceede to other ≈øpices, hearbes, and drugges of India.

p.hi: Ciue ‚Ä¢ groweth in the outermo≈øt part of the coddes of a certaine bea≈øt, which therof hath her name,

& is called a Mu≈øcat, and as Hughin very well ≈øaith, is the ≈øweat that groweth or ingendreth in the hinder part of the bea≈øt, and is hotte and moi≈øt, being laid vpon a womans nauill, it healeth the ri≈øing of the mother, and maketh women apt to leacherie.

div.head: The 71. Chapter. Of Beniom.
div.p: BEnioin is a kinde of ≈øtuffe, like Frankem≈øence & Mir, but more e≈øt√©emed, for it ≈øerueth for manie medicines and other thinges.

p.hi: Benioin by rea≈øon of the ≈øweet ≈ømell, comforteth the heart,
the head, and the braine, it clen≈øeth the head from all ≈øuperfluous humors, ≈øharpneth the wit beeing ≈ømelled vnto, it is good to be v≈øed when di≈øea≈øes begin to goe away.

div.p: As when they make balles or p√©eces of Amber, and Mu≈øke, they mu≈øt alwaies haue Benioin with it to make it perfect, it groweth much in the kingdome of Syan in the Iland of Sumatra, in the I≈ølands of Iauas, & the countrie of Malacca, they are high tr√©es full of branches, with leaues like lemmon tr√©e leaues, with a thicke & high ≈øtemme or ≈øtock in the middle, from whence proc√©edeth the Gumme, which is the Benioin. When the tree is young, then it y√©eldeth the be≈øt Benioin, which is blacki≈øh of colour, and of a very ≈øweet ≈ømell, and is called Benioin, de Boninas, that is to ≈øay, Benioin of the Flowers, becau≈øe of the perfect ≈ømell. The ≈øecond Benioin is called Benioin Amendoado, that is Benioin of Almondes, becau≈øe it is mixed with peeces of white Benioin among the blacke‚ñ™ like to Almondes that are cut in peeces. This Benioin is not ≈øo good, becau≈øe the white Benioin is of the old trees, and is not ≈øo ≈øtrong nor of ≈øo good a ≈ømell as the blacke, but is mixed with the blacke, becau≈øe it ≈øhould be ≈øold the better. The≈øe two ≈øortes of Benioin are the be≈øt, and much v≈øed and caried into Arabia, Per≈øia, the land of Ballagate, China, and other places, as al≈øo into Portingal. Mo≈øt part of this Benioin groweth in the country of Sion, and by Ma ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ , there is other Benioin which is wor≈øe, and groweth in the Ilandes of Sumatra, and Iauas. The inhabitants of the countries where it groweth call it C ‚Ä¢ mingion, the Mores, and Arabians call it Louaniany (which is as much to ≈øay as franken≈øence of Iaua.) The Decaniins and Ballagaters call it Vdo, they cut the tr√©e and branches full of ≈ølits, to make the Benioin the better to come foorth, it is much trafficqued withall throughout India, for it is one of the co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lie≈øt drugges in all the Orient, becau≈øe it excelleth all other in ≈øweetnes.

div.head: The 72. Chapter‚ñ™ Of Franken≈øence and Mirre.
div.p: FRankin≈øence groweth in Arabia, and is called Louan, and by Auicenna Conder: it is the gumme that floweth out of the bodies of the tr√©es, like Benioin: the be≈øt Frankin≈øence groweth vpon the tr√©es that ≈øtande on hilles, and ≈øtony rockes, and ≈øtony places: for tho≈øe which growe in the fieldes and in flat grounds yeeld not ≈øo good Frankin≈øence: they haue ≈øo great quantitie of it, that oftentimes they marke their ≈øh√©epe withall, as if it were Pitch, Tarre, or Ro≈øin: from thence it is carried into India, China ‚ñ™ and other places in great abundance, and very good cheape.

p.hi: Frankin≈øence is of two ≈øorts, one white,

that is round and like vnto drops, which is the be≈øt, and called the ma ‚Ä¢ le: the other blacke, which is not much worth but only in ≈ømell. In India and with vs they v≈øe Frankin≈øence again≈øt the loo≈øenes of the bellie, ≈øickene≈ø≈øes of the head, Cata ‚Ä¢ rlies, ≈øurfeits, and pa ‚Ä¢ br ‚Ä¢ king, & is good for ≈øuch as ≈øpit blood, it filleth vp ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ow ≈øwelling ‚Ä¢ & healeth fre ‚Ä¢ h and bloody wounds.

div.p: Mirre by the Indians is called Bola, it groweth in the ≈øame that Benioin and frankin≈øence doth, and commeth al≈øo out of Arabia F ‚Ä¢ lix, but mo≈øt out of the countrie of Abexin from the inward parts of the countrie, lying betweene Mo≈øambique, and the red ≈øea, which is called Pre≈øter Iohns land, and from thence brought into India. and other places.

p.hi: Mirre is v≈øed in medicines,
to d ‚Ä¢ downe the Flowers and the fruite of women, al≈øo for old coug ‚Ä¢ es, for laskes, & for bloody Flixes.

div.head: The 73. Chapter. Of Manna and Rubarbe.
div.p: MAnna commeth out of Arabia, and Per≈øia, but mo≈øt out of the Prouince of Vsbeke, lying behind Per≈øia in Tartaria: the Manna yt is brought from thence in gla≈ø≈øe V≈øalies is in p√©eces as bigge as pre≈øerued Almonds, but of another fa≈øhion, and haue no other ≈øpeciall forme, but like broken p√©eces: it is whiti≈øh, and of ta≈øte almo≈øt like Sugar, but ≈øomewhat ful≈øome, ≈øweeti≈øh like Hony: the Per≈øians cal it Xerca≈øt, and Xerke≈øt, that is to ≈øay, milke of trees, for it is the dew yt falleth vpon the tr√©es, and remayneth hanging vpon the leaues, like water that is frozen and hangeth in drops at gutters and penti≈øes: It is al≈øo gathered and kept in gla≈ø≈øe Vials, and ≈øo brought into India, and other Countries, for in India they v≈øe it much in all ≈øorts of purgations. There is another ≈øorte of Manna called Tiriamiabiin or Trumgibiin, which they gather froÃÑ other leaues and hearbes: that commeth in ≈ømall peeces as big as Hempe≈ø√©ed, and ≈øomewhat bigger, which is red & of a reddi≈øh colour. Some thinke this Manna groweth on the bodies of the tr√©es as Gumme doth: it is much v≈øed in Ormus and Per≈øia for purgations, but not in India ≈øo much as the fir≈øt ≈øort, there is yet another ≈øorte, which commeth in great peeces, with the leaues among it: it is like the Manna of Calabria, this is brought out of Per≈øia vnto Ba≈ø≈øora, and ≈øo to Ormus, and from thence into India, and is the deare≈øt of all the re≈øt. There commeth al≈øo a Manna that is brought in leather bags, or fla≈øks, which in Turkey and Per≈øia they v≈øe to ride withall, & is melted like Hony, but of a white colour, and in ta≈øte like the other ≈øortes of Manna, being altogether v≈øed for purgations, and other medicines.

p.hi: Manna very gently purgeth the gall: it ea≈øeth and moy≈øtneth the har≈øhnes of the throat, the brea≈øtes and the ≈øtomacke: it quencheth the thir≈øt: but becau≈øe it purgeth but weakely, it is ≈øtrengthened with Tyme or I≈øop mingled with ≈øome ≈øtrong purgations, & maketh them to effect their operations with more perfection and power, by meanes of the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe thereof, which is apter and more plyable vnto nature

div.p: But becau≈øe it is no ≈øpecial marchandi≈øe, I will ≈øpeake no more thereof, but for that wee are nowe in hande with medicines to purge, I wil ≈øay ≈øome thing of the roote called Rhuba ‚Ä¢ be, although there is no certaintie how or in what ≈øort it groweth yet it is mo≈øt certaine, yt it is not to be found in any couÃÑtry but in China, and in the farthe≈øt parts therof, it is mo≈øt brought by land through the Prouince of Vsbeke, whereof I ≈øpake before: which Prouince lyeth in Tartaria, and bordereth on the one ≈øide vpon China, and ≈øo reacheth behinde India vnto Per≈øia. Out of this Prouince it cometh vnto Ormus, and from thence into India: yet it is likewi≈øe brought by water, but becau≈øe it is not ≈øo good, and doth ≈øooner rot and ≈øpoyle by water then by land, therefore mo≈øt part of it is brought by land. That which is mo≈øt e≈øteemed & be≈øt ≈øold, and greatlie≈øt de≈øired, cometh in this manner, that is, fir≈øt from China, through Vsbeke, and ≈øo through Turkie, from whence it is caryed to Venice, & from thence into all the≈øe countries, ≈øo that the Rhubarbe of Venice is better, becau≈øe it cometh ouer land, then that which is brought into Portingall, becau≈øe it cometh by water, as al≈øo all thinges and herbes that belong to Phy≈øicke, becau≈øe they are better pre≈øerued by land then by water, they are little brought by ≈øea, but it is a marchandi≈øe that is mo≈øt caryed by land vnto Venice, as al≈øo becau≈øe the Portingales deale not much therein, and are little giuen to curio≈øities, conteÃÑting them≈øelues to deale with ≈øuch wares as are commonlie knowne to all men, without ≈øeeking further, for they trouble not them≈øelues with other things.

div.head: The 74. Chapter. Of the wood called Sanders.
div.p:
THere are 3. ≈øorts of Sanders, that is, white, yelow and red: the white and the yealow, which is the be≈øt, come mo≈øt out of the IlaÃÑd of Tymor, which lyeth by Iaua. This Iland hath whole woods and wilderne≈ø≈øes of Sanders, both of white and yealow, and froÃÑ theÃÑce it is caryed throughout all India, and other couÃÑ tries, and trafficke much therewith: the red Sanders groweth mo≈øt in the coa≈øt of Choramandel and Tana≈ø≈øariin, which is in the countrie of Pegu: the trees of Sanders are like Nut trees and haue a certaine fruite vpon them like Cheries, at the fir≈øt green, and after black, but of no ta≈øte nor any thing worth, for it pre≈øently falleth off, onlie ye wood of ye tr√©e is accounted of, which is the SaÃÑders. It is called by the Inhabitants of the countrie
where it groweth Chandanacon, the Decannus, Gu≈øurates, Canariins, and other Indians cal it Sercandaa: the Arabians and Per≈øians Sandal, wherevpon the Portingalles likewi≈øe doe call it Sandalo. The yellow and white Sanders is much v≈øed and ≈øpent ouer all India, by all the inhabitantes, both Indians, Moors, Heathens, and Iewes, what≈øoeuer: they beate it or ≈øtampe it in water, till it be as ≈øoft as pappe, that done they be≈ømere them≈øelues therewith, and let it drie vpon their bodies, for it cooleth very much, & al≈øo becau≈øe all the Indians doe much delight in ≈øweet ≈ømelling ≈øauours.

p.hi: The white & yellow or bleaki≈øh Sanders is likewi≈øe v≈øed by vs,

with Ro≈øewater, again≈øt the hotte paines in the head, annointing it therewith: all tho≈øe woods as well the red as the white and yellow, are good again≈øt hotte feauers, being beaten and drunken into the body, they help the hot ≈øtomacke, as al≈øo laid vpon the ≈øtomacke with Ro≈øe water, in burning feauers. This Sanders is not onely good for the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, but al≈øo for ≈øtrengthening the hart, and therefore with great v≈øe it is put into Cordiall medicines, & ≈øuch as are made again≈øt the beating of the hart.

div.p:
The red Sanders is little ≈øpent in India, but they v≈øe it onely again≈øt hot agues, annointing their pul≈øes therewith, as al≈øo the temples, & their foreheads, but it is much ‚Ä¢
ryed into other countries, as being very medicinable for many thinges, and the Indians make their Pagodes and Idoles thereof, becau≈øe they ≈øhould be the co≈øtlier.

div.head: The ‚Ä¢ 5. Chapter. Of Palo de Cebra or Snake-wood.
div.p: SNakewood is mo≈øt in the I≈øland of Seylon: it is a lowe Tr√©e: the roote thereof being the Snake-woode is of colour white, ≈øhewing ≈øomewhat yellowe, very harde and bitter in ta≈øte, it is much v≈øed in India: they ≈øtampe and bru≈øe it like Sanders, in water or Wine, and ≈øo drinke it, it is very good & well proued again≈øt all burning feauers: one ounce thereof brui≈øed and mixed with water is good again≈øt all poi≈øon and ≈øicknes, as the collick, worms, and all filthie humors and coldnes in the body‚ñ™ and ≈øpecially again≈øt the ≈øtinging of Snakes, whereof it hath the name: it was fir≈øt found by means of a little bea≈øt called Q ‚Ä¢ il, or Quirpele, which is of bigne≈ø≈øe very like a Ferret (wherewith in tho≈øe Countries they v≈øe to driue Cunnies out of their holes, and ≈øo ketch them whereof in India they haue many in their hou≈øes, which they play withall to pa≈ø≈øe the time away, as al≈øo to kill their Myce and Rattes, and to driue them away. This bea≈øt by nature is a great enemie to the Snake, ≈øo that where≈øoeuer ≈øhe findeth any, ≈øhe fighteth with them: and becau≈øe it is often bitten by the Snake, it knoweth how to heale it ≈øelfe with this Snake-woode, (whereof there is much in Seylon, where al≈øo are many of tho≈øe bea≈øtes, and great ≈øtore of Snakes) ≈øo that if it be neuer ≈øo ≈øore bitten, hauing eaten of this wood, it is pre≈øently healed, as if it had neuer b√©ene hurt. By this means the inhabitants haue found it out & begun to make account of it, & ≈øince that time it is proued and found to be good for many ‚Ä¢ i≈øea≈øes as afore≈øaid: wherefore nowe it is much traffiqued withall, and carryed into all countries, as al≈øo into Portingall, & from thence hether.

p.hi: Garcius ab horto writeth of three ≈øorts of this wood,

whereof you may there reade two of the≈øe ≈øortes of Snake-wood I haue in my hou≈øe to be ≈øhewen, one is that which Iohn Hughen writeth to bee the root of a tree, white and bitter of ta≈øte, with a rough A≈øh colou
‚Ä¢ barke: the other was ≈øent me ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , from the learned Doctor Simon „Äà‚óä„Äâ Tonar, which is as thicke as a ma ‚Ä¢ ar ‚Ä¢ e, with a barke be≈øprinckled & ≈øpotted like a Snake, which inwardlie is white, and bitter of ta≈øte

div.head:
The 76 Chapter. Of the wood Caiamba or
‚Ä¢ num Aloes.
div.p:
THe
‚Ä¢ ignuÃÑ Aloes which in India is called Calamba and Palo D ‚Ä¢ guilla, is mo≈øt in Malacca, in the I≈ølande of Sumatra Camboia, Sion, and the Countries bordering on the ≈øame: the trees are like Oliue trees, and ≈øomewhat greater‚ñ™ when it is cut off, it ≈ømelleth not ≈øo well, becau≈øe it is gr√©ene, for the dryer it is, the better it ≈ømelleth: the be≈øt and that which ≈ømelleth mo≈øt, is the innermo≈øt part of the wood: ≈øome of it is better then the re≈øt, which the
Indians doe pre≈øently knowe howe to finde out: the be≈øt and fine≈øt is called Calamba, and ye other Palo Daguilla. Now to know which is the be≈øt, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the wood that is very heauie with black and brown veynes, and which y√©eldeth much Oyle or moy≈øtne≈ø≈øe (which is founde by the fire) is the be≈øt, and the greater and thicker that it is, the better it is and hath the more vertue. Of this wood they make many co≈øtly thinges, and it hath a ≈øpeciall and precious ≈ømell, ≈øo that it is greatly e≈øt√©emed: ≈øpecially the Calamba, which if it be good, is ≈øolde by weight again≈øt ≈øiluer and gold. The Palo Daguilla next after the Calamba is much accounted of. There is another kind of Palo Daguilla, which is called Aquilla Braua or wild Aquilla, and is al≈øo much e≈øteemed: for the Indians v≈øe it therewith to burne the bodies of their Bramenes, and other men of account, when they are dead: and becau≈øe it is co≈øtly, therefore it is a great honour to tho≈øe that are burnt therewith, as it is to tho≈øe that with vs are buried in Tombes of marble ≈øtones: but it is not comparable to the other Palo Daguilla, nor the Calamba. The wilde Aguilla groweth mo≈øt in the I≈øland of Seylon, and on the coa≈øt of Choramandel, and the be≈øt Palo Daguilla, and Calamba groweth in Malacca. The≈øe co≈øtly woods are much v≈øed in India for Beades, and Crucifixes, which are holden in great reuerence, and in truth is very much to be e≈øteemed, for without all doubt it hath an excellent ≈ømel, which ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all other woods, and the like can not bee founde but onely in the ≈øore≈øaide places from whence it commeth.

p.hi: Lignum Aloes, Agallochum, Xylo, alias Paradi≈øe-woode,

by the Arabians called Agalugen and Haud, by the inhabitantes of Gu≈øurate and Decan, Vd in Malacca, Garro, and the be≈øt Calamba. Of this wood I haue many ≈øortes, all very plea≈øant of ≈ømell, ≈øpeckled with veines and full of moy≈øture, and withall clo≈øe and very heauie: this wood being taken inwardly, is good for a ≈øtinking breath: it is al≈øo very good again≈øt a watri≈øh and moy≈øt ≈øtomacke, which can receyue no meate, but ca≈øteth it forth: it is al≈øo good for one that hath a weake liuer, that is ≈øick of the red Meli≈øon, or of the Pluri≈øie.

div.head: The 77. Chapter. Of the root China.
div.p:
THe root China came into India, and was there fir≈øt knowne in Anno 1535. 1535 for before that time they knewe it not, for that as then they cured the Pore, which in India is a common di≈øea≈øe) with the woode called Guaiacum, that is brought out of the Spani≈øh Indies, and was at that time in a manner weyghed again≈øt Gold: and as the land of China, is much ≈øubiect to the di≈øea≈øe of the Pore, it ≈øeemeth that God hath giuen them this roote to cure and help the ≈øame, and ≈øince it was knowne and found out in India, they would neuer v≈øe any other remedy, becau≈øe there is great ≈øtore of it, and the be≈øt in all the world, wherby men in tho≈øe countries doe not once make any account of the Poxe, or feare the healing therof, for that it is more ea≈øilier healed then any other di≈øea≈øe: al≈øo it is no ≈øhame with them, although they haue had it at ye lea≈øt 3, or 4. times: this root is now with them in ≈øo great abundance, and common v≈øe, that it is very good cheape, for that it is not worth at the mo≈øt aboue halfe a Pardaw the pound, which in Portingall money is a Te≈øton and a halfe. The ≈øicke per≈øons do v≈øe it in this manner following, they take of the root‚ñ™ & cut it in ≈ømalll peeces or ≈ølyces, the wayght of an ounce, which they ≈øeeth in foure pottes or quartes of water, letting it ≈ø√©eth till it be halfe con≈øumed, whereof they ≈ø√©eth fre≈øh euery day: this water they mu≈øt drink alone, & eat bi≈øket with nothing els but ≈ømal ro≈øted Chickens, without any Butter, ≈øuet, ≈øalt, or any other ≈øauce, but onely drie with the Bi≈øket, and this mu≈øt bee their dinner, at night ≈øome Rea≈øons, and to≈øted breade with Hony and nothing els‚ñ™ euery day twice they mu≈øt lie on their beddes wel couered to make them ≈øweat, euery time an hower, or an hower and a halfe which they mu≈øt continue for the ≈øpace of thirtie dayes, alwaies k√©eping them≈øelues out of the ayre, and from the wind, and lapping their heads and their eares very clo≈øe, ≈øtaying continually within the hou≈øe, and aboue all thinges ab≈øtayning from the carnall company of women. The≈øe pointes afore≈øaid being ob≈øerued, without all doubt they ≈øhall find great profite: and if the roote doth worke within them, they ≈øhall know it by this meanes, for that the paine in their lims, and ≈øpecially in their ioyntes, will grieue them more and more, which is a good ≈øigne
that it worketh in their bodies, and thoroughly ≈øearcheth the ≈øame, and this paine will ≈øtill increa≈øe for the ≈øpace of 15. or 20. dayes, yea and ≈øometimes vntill 25. dayes, and therefore he that will v≈øe it mu≈øt not di≈øpaire, for without faile it wil be ≈øo as I haue ≈øaid, within a day two, or thr√©e more or le≈ø≈øe. The 25. dayes at the furthe≈øt being pa≈ø≈øed, then their paine will begin to demini≈øh, with ≈øo great a lightnes and ea≈øe, that within the other fiue dayes, whereby the 30. dayes will bee accompli≈øhed, the whole paine will be gone, ≈øo that the body and all the members will be as fre≈øh and liuely as if they neuer had b√©ene ≈øicke hauing v≈øed this rule afore≈øaid. And although the roote China being ≈øodden in the water, cau≈øeth a great appetite and a hungry ≈øtomacke, neuerthele≈ø≈øe they mu≈øt in any ≈øorte beware that they eate but little, and with mea≈øure, & that according to the rule pre≈øcribed: for if they break it but one day, nay but one houre, all their labour were lo≈øt, and ≈øo they mu≈øt be forced to begin their diet again. It mu≈øt likewi≈øe bee vnder≈øtood that the older‚ñ™ and longer of continuance the pockes are, ≈øo much the ≈øooner will the roote heale them, as al≈øo the older the per≈øons to be healed are of yeares, becau≈øe that then the humors are not ≈øo ripe as in young yeares. When the 3 ‚Ä¢
dayes are expired, they mu≈øt beware of drinking other drinke, and to that end they mu≈øt keepe the peeces and ≈ølices that were cut and ≈øodden as before, euery ounce by it ≈øelfe, and therof take euery day a heape of the ≈øame roote ≈øo ≈øodden, and ≈øeeth them againe in a pot with as much water as they ≈øhall need to drinke: but this ≈øeething need not to be done as the fir≈øt ≈øeething, with con≈øumption of the water, but only let it ≈øeeth vp once and no more. This water mu≈øt they drinke in this ≈øorte for the ≈øpace of 2 ‚Ä¢ . or 30. dayes more, and beware of fi≈øh, or any goo≈øe or heauie meates, as Oxe, Cow, or Hogges fle≈øh, and ≈øuch like, as al≈øo they mu≈øt keepe them≈øelues from much aire or winde, whereby their bodies beeing healed may returne to their perfect healthes againe, and after the≈øe twenty or thirty dayes are full expired, then they mu≈øt begin to v≈øe all kinde of meates and drinkes, although when the fir≈øt thirtie dayes are out, they may well goe abroad, ≈øo they bee carefull of them≈øelues, and they ≈øhall not neede to ≈øweate any more after the ≈øaid fir≈øt thirty dayes: al≈øo it mu≈øt bee remembred, that ≈øuch as meane to take this diet, for their healthes, it will bee good before they v≈øe it, to take a good purgation, & when the fir≈øt fifteene dayes are out, then take a ≈øecond, and ≈øo at the end of the thirtie day an ‚Ä¢ other, whereby it will worke with more effect, and with Gods help they ≈øhall be as lu≈øtie and ≈øound as euer they were, as it hath beene prooued by many thou≈øandes in India. This roote is not onely good for the Pockes and Piles, but al≈øo for crampes and pal≈øies, and all cold di≈øea≈øes, as for lumites that are ≈øtiffe and benummed with cold, for the Gout: for the Emperour Charles the fift him≈øelfe did v≈øe the ≈øame, and found that it did him good: But it mu≈øt bee vnder≈øtood that it is not good to v≈øe it at all times of the yeare, for in the dogge dayes, and al≈øo in Summer, by rea≈øon of the heat it is not good, neyther in winter becau≈øe of the cold, but it is be≈øt to be v≈øed in Lent and Harue≈øt time: for then it is mo≈øt temperate weather, yet alwaies with the coun≈øell of the learned Phi≈øition, the better to know the di≈øpo≈øition, complection, inclination and age of the per≈øons, together with the time of the yeare, the ≈øituation and climate of the countrie. The manner of healing afore≈øaid is as it is v≈øed in India: but in China which is a colder countrey, and almo≈øt vnder the ≈øame degrees that the≈øe Countries are vnder, they v≈øe to ≈øeeth the water ≈øtronger, for there they put 2, ounces or an ounce and a halfe of the wood into ≈øo much water, and let it ≈øeeth vntill the water be two partes con≈øumed, which in India will not bee borne becau≈øe of the great heate. It is likewi≈øe to be vnder≈øtood, that the per≈øon and the di≈øea≈øe of the per≈øon mu≈øt be well con≈øidered: for that if the ≈øicknes bee not very great, they mu≈øt take le≈ø≈øe roote, and let le≈ø≈øe water con≈øume in the ≈øeething, the younger per≈øons al≈øo mu≈øt haue ≈øtronger drinke then old ‚Ä¢ olkes, becau≈øe they haue more humors in their bodies: And yee mu≈øt con≈øider, that hee which will take or v≈øe this roote, or the water thereof not beeing ≈øicke, it will wa≈øte and con≈øume his fle≈øh and good blood, and doe him≈øelfe great hurt, wherfore good coun≈øell and adui≈øe mu≈øt alwaies be taken before it be v≈øed, and al≈øo i ‚Ä¢ it bee taken too hotte, and too much, it burneth both the liuer and the lunges, and will fill the body full of pyles, ≈øcurffe, and ma ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ es, with other ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes, whereby a man ≈øhall haue worke enough to driue tho≈øe new di≈øea≈øes out of his body, and fall out of one ≈øicknes into another, & rather become wor≈øe then hee was at the fir≈øt. This I thought good in briefe to ≈øhew you thereby to teach ≈øuch as knowe it not, the true v≈øe of his roote if it bee done in time, & when neede requireth: for that many doe ≈øpende their wealthes, and which is more, are all their liues long out of hope for e ‚Ä¢ er to recouer their healthes againe, vpon a di≈øea≈øe, which with ≈øo little co≈øt, is ≈øo ea≈øilie to be cured. The ≈øumme of the fore≈øaid water is likewi≈øe good again≈øt all ≈øcabbes and ≈øwellinges of the ≈øaid M ‚Ä¢ Neapo ‚Ä¢ , „Äà‚óä„Äâ , or ye
French pockes, the be≈øt rootes are the blacke≈øt, with few knots and white within: for the reddi≈øh are not ≈øo good, the wood or tr√©e wherof it groweth is like a Haw-thorne, ≈øtraight, and about three or foure ≈øpannes high, & the roote thereof is called the wood of China, or Pockewood, when they are gr√©ene they eate them raw, and being ≈øodden they ta≈øte almo≈øt like ≈øuger canes but not ≈øo ≈øweet. The tree hath but few leaues, but they are almo≈øt like the leaues of a young Orange tree. The≈øe plants or trees in China are called Lampaton, as the Chinos them≈øelues doe ≈øay. This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for this root of China ≈øo called becau≈øe it is found in no place but in China, what is more to be ≈øaid of it, I leaue vnto the learned Phi≈øitions, & others that deale withall, and haue better experience thereof.

p.hi: The roote of China is commonlie v≈øed among the Egyptians, not onelie for the pockes, but for many other di≈øea≈øes, ≈øpecially for a con≈øumption, for the which they ≈øeeth the roote China in broth of a henne or cocke, whereby they become whole and faire of face.

This roote drieth much and cooleth ≈øweate, it re≈øi≈øteth euill humors, and ≈øtrengthneth the liuer, it healeth watery and filthie Vlcers, and ≈øcurffes & Leprie. Is is good for a man that hath the pockes, and for tho≈øe that are dried vp, and medicinable again≈øt a hard and a great milt.

div.head: The 78. Chapter. Of Am≈øion alias Opium.
div.p:
AM≈øion, ≈øo called by the Portingales, is by the Arabians, Mores, and Indians called Affion, in latine Opio or opium: It commeth out of Cairo in Egypt, and out of Aden, vpon the coa≈øt of Arabia, which is the point of the land, entring into the red Sea, ≈øometimes belonging to the Portingales, but mo≈øt part out of Cambaia, & from Decan, that of Ca ‚Ä¢ o is whiti≈øh, and is called Mece
‚Ä¢ , that of Aden and the places bordering vpon the mouth of the red ≈øea, is blacki≈øh & hard. That which commeth from Cambaia and Decan is ≈øofter and reddi≈øh. Amfion is made of ≈øleepe balles or Poppie, and is the gumme which commeth forth of the ≈øame, to ye which end it is cut vp and opened. The Indians v≈øe much to eat Am≈øion, ≈øpecially the Malabares, and thether it is brought by tho≈øe of Cambaia and other places, in great aboundance. Hee that v≈øeth to eate it, mu≈øt eate it daylie, otherwi≈øe he dieth and con≈øumeth him≈øelfe, when they begin to eate it, and are v≈øed vnto it, they heate at the lea≈øt twenty or thirty graines in waight euerie day, ≈øometimes more: but if for foure or fiue dayes hee chanceth to leaue it, he dieth without faile: likewi≈øe he that hath neuer eaten it, and will venture at the fir≈øt to eate as much as tho≈øe that dayly v≈øe it, it will ≈øurely kill him: for I certainely beleeue it is a kinde of poy≈øon. Such as v≈øe it goe alwaies as if they were halfe a ≈øleepe, they eate much of it becau≈øe they would not feele any great labour or vnquietnes when they are at worke, but they v≈øe it mo≈øt for lecherie: for it maketh a man to hold his f√©ede long before he ≈øheddeth it, which the Indian women much de≈øire, that they may ≈øhed their nature likewi≈øe with the man: although ≈øuch as eate much thereof, are in time altogether vnable to company with a woman, & whollie dried vp, for it drieth and wholly cooleth mans nature that v≈øeth it, as the Indians them≈øelues doe witnes: wherefore it is not much v≈øed by the Nobilitie, but onely for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid.

p.hi: Opium is the iuice of blacke Poppie,

and is of two ≈øortes, one ≈øweet beeing pre≈ø≈øed out of the leaues and heads together, which the Greekes call Meconium: the other floweth or commeth out of the heads being cut, which is the right Opium. That which is heauy, clo≈øe, fa≈øt and bitter in ta≈øte, that which with the ≈ømell of it prouoketh ≈øleepe, & that which ea≈øily melteth in the water and is ≈øoft, white, and without gro≈ø≈øenes or kernels, is the be≈øt Opium, and is by the Turkes called Maslac. They eate thereof daylie the quantitie of a pea≈øe, not thereby to prouoke ≈øleepe, but to giue them courage, ≈øpecially when they goe to war, thinking that thereby they are made more couragious, and that when they ≈øleepe they dreame that they ≈øee many plea≈øant places, and are in company of diuers goodly womeÃÑ: althogh it is commonly ≈øeene, that ≈øuch is dayly v≈øe Opium, are very ≈øtill and ≈øleepie, and very ≈ølow both in wordes and workes, ≈øo that men know not how to deale with them.

div.head: The 79. Chapter. Of Bangue
div.p: BAngue is al≈øo a common meate in India, ≈øeruing to the ≈øame effect that Am≈øion doth. It is a ≈ø√©ed like Hemp≈ø√©ede, but ≈øomwhat ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo white. Al≈øo the thing whereon it groweth is like Hempe, but it hath no ≈øub≈øtance wherof to make any thing. The Indians eate this ≈ø√©ede or the leaues thereof being ≈øtamped, ≈øaying, that it maketh a good appetite, but v≈øeth mo≈øt to prouoke lu≈øt, as it is commonly v≈øed and ≈øold in the ≈øhops, it is mingled with ≈øome poulder of the leaues and the ≈ø√©ede together: They likewi≈øe put gr√©ene Arecca vnto it, therewith to make a man drunke, or in a manner out of his wits: Sometimes al≈øo they mixe it with Nutmegs and Mace, which doth al≈øo make a man drunke: Others (that is to ≈øaye, the rich and welthy per≈øons) mix it with Cloues, Camphora, Ambar, Muske, and Opium, which (as the Moores likewi≈øe affirme) maketh a man plea≈øant, and forgetting him≈øelfe, performing all kind of labour and toyle without once thinking of any paine: but onely laughing, playing, and ≈øleeping quietly. The common women or whores v≈øe it when they meane to haue a mans companie, thereby to be liuely and merrie, and to ≈øet all care a≈øide. It was fir≈øt inuented by Captaines and ≈øouldiers, when they had layne long in the field, continually waking and with great trauell, which they de≈øiring to remedie, and againe to comfort them≈øelues, thereby to ≈øettle their braines doe v≈øe Bangue, in ≈øuch manner as is afore≈øaid. It cau≈øeth ≈øuch as eate it, to r√©ele and looke as if they were drunke, and halfe fooli≈øh, doing nothing but laugh and bee merrie, as long as it worketh in their bodies. It is verie much v≈øed by the Indians, and likewi≈øe by ≈øome Portingales, but mo≈øt by the ≈ølaues thereby to forget their labour: to conclude it is a certaine ≈ømall comfort to a melancholy per≈øon.

p.hi: Bangue is likewi≈øe much v≈øed in Turkie and Aegypt, and is made in three ≈øorts, hauing al≈øo three ≈øeuerall names The fir≈øt by the Aegyptians is called A≈øsis, which is the poulder of Hemp, or of Hemp leaues, which water made in pa≈øte or dough, wherof they eate fiue peeces, each as bigge as a Che≈ønut and ≈øome more, ≈øuch as eate it, for an hower after, are as if they were drunke, without ≈øence, and as it were be≈øides them≈øelues, thinking they ≈øee many ≈øtrange ≈øights, wherein they are much plea≈øed. This is v≈øed by the common people, becau≈øe it is of a ≈ømall price, and it is no wonder, that ≈øuch vertue proceedeth from the Hempe, for that according to Galens opinion, Hempe exce≈øsiuely filleth the head. The ≈øecond they name Bo≈øa, which is ≈øtronger then A≈øsis: It is made of the meale of Lolium, by vs called Dronkaydes weede or Hearbe, and of Hemp≈øeede with water as afore≈øaid‚ñ™ others pre≈ø≈øe out the iuice, and eat that. The thirde is called Bernaui, which is the right Bangue, which they haue readie dre≈ø≈øed out of India (as Hughen writeth) wherof they take about an ounce, & at the fir≈øt are merie, talking much & ≈øinging ple≈øant ≈øongs, laughing without mea≈øure, and v≈øing many fooli≈øh toyes‚ñ™ which continueth with them almo≈øt an hower. After that they are in a manner furious, giuen to chiding and fighting, which continueth likewi≈øe a little ≈øpace, that done they are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with heauine≈ø≈øe, and a certaine kind of feare, that many times they crie out. In the end wheÃÑ they haue played al the≈øe parts they fall in a ≈øleepe, and being awaked, they are as they were at the fir≈øt. This is much v≈øed by fooli≈øh Ie≈øters or Iuglers at fea≈øts and banquets, to delight them. The Aegyptians v≈øe al≈øo an other ≈øorte called Bers, that is to ≈øay, health for an hower. It is made of white Pepper, white Bilzen ≈øeede, of each fiue ounces, and of Opium two ounces and a halfe, Spica Nardi, Euphorbium, Bertram, of each one Mitchell, Saffran, fifteene Scruples, all beaten in a Marble morter, and mixed with Honnie wherof they make a confection.

div.head: The 80. Chapter. Of Camphora.
div.p: THere are two ≈øortes of Camphora, one of Borneo (which is the be≈øt,) the other of China or Chincheu, which is nothing ≈øo good: it groweth on tr√©es as great as Nutte tr√©es, and is the gumme which is within the middle of the tree, and by ≈øweating and dropping commeth out from the ≈øame. This Camphora of Borneo, is likewi≈øe in the Iland of Sumatra, and Sunda, as al≈øo in ≈øome other places there abouts. It is of bigne≈ø≈øe like a ≈øeede called in Portingall M ‚Ä¢ lho, and with vs Barley, of colour whiti≈øh. It is of foure ≈øorts, whereunto the Indians v≈øe certaine Siues with holes purpo≈øely made in them: the fir≈øt hauing ≈ømal holes, and that which pa≈ø≈øeth through them, is the wor≈øt, the next following it is ≈øomewhat greater, and ≈øo forth after that rate, as it is ≈øaid before of Pearles, and ≈øo it is pri≈øed accordingly. It commeth ≈øometimes all ≈øpotted, with ≈øome filth or foulene≈ø≈øe, which the Bamaners of Cambaia know well how to wa≈øh away with water, Sope, and the iuice of Lemons: which done, they ≈øet it to drie in ≈øome ≈øhadow place, wherby it is whiter then it was at the fir≈øt, and keepeth the former waight. It is likewi≈øe fal≈øified with other Gum or poulder of other rootes, as the Indians can well handle all their wares. This is the right and true Camphora of Borneo, yet I belieue there commeth verie little of it into the≈øe countries: but the Camphora of Chyna, which commeth from Chincheu, is in great aboundance, and is brought in cakes or balles, and is much carried into al places, and verie good cheape. For one pound of Borneo is worth a hundred pound of Chincheu, although the Champhora of Chincheu is mixed with Champhora of Borneo, and they know how to giue it a colour, in ≈øuch ≈øorte that it is both taken and v≈øed for good, and becau≈øe it is ≈øo much v≈øed in medicines, I haue particularly ≈øet it downe, in this place, as al≈øo becau≈øe it is one of the principalle≈øt wares in India.

div.head: The 81. Chapter. Of Tamarinio.
div.p:
TAmarinio groweth in the mo≈øt parts of all India, ≈øpeciallie in the land of Gu≈ø ‚Ä¢ ate and the North parts beyond Goa: the Malabares call it Pulu: the Gu≈øurates and the other Indians cal it Anbilii: the Arabians, Tamarindii, becau≈øe Tamaras in Arabia, are the ≈øame that with vs we cal Dates, and becau≈øe they know not what to liken Tamarinio vnto, better then vnto Dates, therefore they call it Tamarindi, yt is‚ñ™ Tamaras or Dates of India, wherevpon the Portingales cal it al≈øo Tamarinio, and the Dates which are in great abundance brought out of Per≈øia & Arabia into India: they name them after the Arabians, Tamaras. The trees of Tamarinio are almo≈øt like vnto Che≈ønuts, or other nut trees, the branches being full of leaues, with a clo≈øe & ≈øtrong wood: the fruite of the Tamarinio is about a finger long, bowing or crooked, hauing greene ≈øhelles, or pilles without, and b√©eing drie are grayi≈øh, hauing within certaine kernels of the greatnes of a Beane, which are couered about with that which they call Tamarinio: it ≈øticketh to mens hands (for it is like lime) & therewith they prepare all their compo≈øitions throughout India, for it hath a ≈øowri≈øh and ≈øharp ta≈øte, and is the be≈øt ≈øauce in all India, like vergis with vs, and they neuer ≈øieth Rice but they put Tamarinio into it, wherewith their compo≈øition called Cariil is made, as in many places it is alreadie declared: yet tho≈øe that ≈øee it dre≈øt will haue no great de≈øire to eate it, for they cru≈øh it through their fingers, whereby it ≈øheweth like rotten Medlers: yet it giueth the Rice & the meate a fine ≈øharp ta≈øte. Tamarinio is likewi≈øe proued to be a very good purgation, for the poore that are of ≈ømal habilitie, and are not able to be at charges of Rhabarbo, Mann ‚Ä¢ , and ≈øuch like co≈øtlie Apothecaries ware, doe onlie v≈øe Tamarinio pre≈ø≈øed out into a little water, which water being drunk fa≈øting in a morning, is the be≈øt purgation in the world, which is to be done when the Tamarinio is ripe or when it is greene: it is v≈øed likewi≈øe in dre≈ø≈øing meate, to put in among their fle≈øh in ≈øteed of Vineger, for it is much ≈øowrer then Vineger, much like gr√©en goo≈øeberries or grapes: the Phy≈øitians v≈øe it in purgations & medecines coÃÑpouÃÑded with other
herbes and ≈øpices, and it worketh well: it is likewi≈øe ≈øalted to ≈øend for Portingal, Arabia, Per≈øia, & other places, yet the Indians k√©epe it in their hou≈øes, in the hu≈økes, as it commeth from the tree, and it haÃÑgeth on the tr√©es like ≈øheathes of kniues, but that they are ≈øomewhat bowed, as I ≈øaid before: there is likewi≈øe ≈øugar coÃÑ≈øerues made therof, which is verie good. The nature of this tree is to be wondered at, for that the Tamarini ‚Ä¢ , that is to ≈øay, the long crooked hu≈øke wherein it is, in the night time ≈øhrinketh it ≈øelf vp vnder the leaues, to couer it from the cold of the night, and in the day time it vncouereth it ≈øelf again all naked and outright, as I haue often ≈ø√©ene and beheld it: when it is caryed abroad or ≈øold, it is out of the ≈øhelles or hu≈økes, and b√©eing put together they make balles thereof, as bigge as a mans fi≈øt, but it is clammie and ≈øticketh together. It is not very plea≈øant to looke on, nor yet to handle, but verie good cheap throughout all India, by rea≈øon of the great quanttitie thereof.

p.hi: Tamarinde, is by the Aegyptians called Derel≈øide. The tree wheron it groweth,

is as great as a Plumme tree, with thicke branches, and leaues like a Mirtle: The flowers white like Orange flowers, from the middle whereof do proceede fower white thinne threeds, which growe out of the huske, wherein the ≈øeede and the pith is, which wee call Tamarindi. The leaues of the tree doe alwaies turne towards the Sunne, and when it goeth downe, they ≈øhut together and couer the huske in the night time. At Alcayro in their gardens I ≈øaw ≈øome of the≈øe trees, and one by Saint Macarius Cloy≈øter in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, where no other Hearbs nor trees doe grow. The Turkes and Egyptians v≈øe this Tamarinde, much in hotte di≈øea≈øes and Feauers: they put it into faire water, and ≈øo drinke it. I healed my ≈øelfe therewith of a pe≈øtilent Feuer, being in Siria. It is a common Medecine among them, which as they trauel through the drie woods and wilderne≈ø≈øe, they doe v≈øe, and al≈øo again≈øt the Plague and other hot di≈øea≈øes, proceeding of Cholericke burning humors, and again≈øt the heate of the Liuer and Kidneyes, it is verie good. I can ≈øhewe the whole huske or ≈øhell of the Tamarinde with the leaues as they grow, and the Canna Fi≈øtula, which I my ≈øelfe gathered in Egypt. The leaues of Tamarinde trees, are v≈øed again≈øt Wormes in childrens bellies, and the young huskes, as al≈øo the Ca≈øsia Fi≈øtula, are in Egypt v≈øed to be con≈øerued in Honnie o ‚Ä¢ Saint Iohns bread, or Suger, whereof I brought great Pots full ouer.

div.p: The Canna Fi≈øtula which is likewi≈øe much v≈øed for Purgations, and other ≈øuch like Medicines is much found in India, as al≈øo in Cambaia, Sion, Malacca, and the places bordering on the ≈øame: but becau≈øe there is the like in the Spani≈øh Indies, and many other places, and ≈øufficiently knowne, I will ≈øpeake no more of it: but follow on with matters of le≈ø≈øe knowledge.

p.hi: Of the≈øe trees I haue ≈øeene in Egypt at the lea≈øt thou≈øands together‚ñ™

≈øpecially about Damiata, a famous towne in Egypt, lying on the ryuer Nilus, euen in like ≈øort as the towne of Campen lyeth vppon I≈ø≈øel about a mile from the Sea, The Egyptians call it Ca≈øsia Chaiarx-Ambar. The trees whereon Ca≈øsia groweth, are altogether like our Wallnut trees, both for body, branches, and leaues, only the flowers are Golde-yellow, and of a ≈øweete ≈øauor, out of the≈øe groweth the great huskes wherein the Ca≈øsia lyeth. The huskes being ≈ømall and without any woode are con≈øerued likewi≈øe. The Egyptians v≈øe the huske of Ca≈øsia with white Suger, & the iuice of Cali≈øsi-wood, again≈øt grauell, and all di≈øea≈øes of the bladder and the Kidnies, al≈øo again≈øt coughing, and ≈øtopping of the bre≈øt, with Agaricum, al≈øo outwardly again≈øt hotte inflamations laying the Ca≈øsia vpon them. Hee that de≈øireth to know more hereof, let him reade Mathiolus and other Phy≈øitions, that haue written mo≈øt diligently vpon the ≈øame.

div.head: The 82. Chapter. Of Mirabolanes.
div.p:
THe Myrobalanes are found in many places of India, that is, in Cambaia, in the land of Ba ‚Ä¢
gate, in Go ‚Ä¢ , in Malabar, and in Bengalen: whereof there are fiue ≈øortes‚ñ™
The fir≈øt by Phy≈øitions called Citrinos, and by the Indians Ara ‚Ä¢ e, tho≈øe are round, and are v≈øed to purge choller. The ≈øecond which are called Emblicos, and in India Amuale, are v≈øed in India to tanne Leather withall, as Tanners v≈øe Sumach, and when they are ripe and al≈øo gr√©ene, they eate them for an appetite. The third ≈øort in India called Re≈øonualle, and by the Phy≈øitions Indius, are eight cornered. The fourth by the Phy≈øitions called Bellericos, and by the Indians Gu ‚Ä¢ ij, are al≈øo round. The fift & la≈øt are in India called Aretean, & by the Phy≈øitions Quebulus, tho≈øe are ≈øomwhat long, roundi≈øh with points. The tr√©es are almo≈øt like Plumme trees, but they haue ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of leaues, each tree by him≈øelfe. They are commonly one with the other in greatne≈ø≈øe and fa≈øhion like Plummes, but that ≈øome of them are ≈øquarer and rounder, as I ≈øaid before. Thr√©e ≈øorts are onely v≈øed and e≈øt√©emed of by the Phy≈øitions in India, that is Quebulus, which grow in Cambaia, Bi≈ønagar and Bengala, which are likewi≈øe pre≈øerued & eaten in that ≈øort, as al≈øo carried into diuers places, as well to Portingall as el≈øe where, likewi≈øe the Cetrinos and Indius, which al≈øo are pre≈øerued: and they grow in Malabar, Batecala and Bengala, they are much v≈øed, e≈øt√©emed and carried into other countries. The Mirabolans when they are ripe are almo≈øt in ta≈øte like vnripe Plummes, but becau≈øe this matter concerneth Phy≈øitions & Apoticaries, I will ≈øpeake no more thereof, hauing onely ≈øet it downe for a common thing in India.

p.hi: All the≈øe fiue ≈øorts of Mirabolanes are brought vs hether out of India ready dried, and ≈øome con≈øerued in pickle, others in Suger. The fir≈øt wee call Citrinas or Flauas, which are yellow Mirabolans, and the yellower the better, ≈øhewing ≈øome thing greene, clo≈øe, and fa≈øt, and gummie with a thicke ≈øhell. They purge the ≈øtomake from choller, and are good again≈øt Tertians, and other hotte burning Feauers, and verie nece≈ø≈øarie for a hotte nature. The ≈øecond wee call Indus: the≈øe the blacker they are, the better they purge choller, ≈øpecially black choller, they are good again≈øt ≈øhaking of the limmes, they cau≈øe a faire colour and driue away ≈øadne≈ø≈øe. The third is called Cepule or Chebulae, the greater they are the better, blacki≈øh and ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, heauie, and ≈øinking in the water, they purge fleame they ≈øharpen mens wits, and cleare the ≈øight. They are here pre≈øerued in Suger and Honnie, they doe ≈øtrengthen and purge the ≈øtomak, they heale the drop≈øie, and are good again≈øt olde Agues, they likewi≈øe giue a man an appetite, and helpe dige≈øtion. The fourth wee call Emblicas, and the fift Bellericas, they haue in a manner one kinde of operation like the other called Cebulus. They clean≈øe the body from fleagme, ≈øpecially the braines, the Kidnies, and the ≈øtomake, they ≈øtrengthen the hart, giue an appetite, and ea≈øe belching. The Emblice, are al≈øo con≈øerued & eaten to the ≈øame ende. All the≈øe fruites purge, but in an other kinde of manner then doth Ca≈øsia or Manna, or ≈øuch like drugges, but they do it by a≈øtriction or binding, thru≈øting that out which is in the members. They that de≈øire to knowe more hereof, let him reade Mathiolus, and Garcius ab Horto, and others.

div.head: The 83. Chapter. Of other Spices and Hearbes in India
div.p: SPiconardus groweth in the countries of Sitor & Mando ‚Ä¢ , (which are places that border vppon the lands of Decan, Dely, and Bengalen) it is, ≈øowed and groweth on plants, about 2, or 3. ≈øp ‚Ä¢ ns high, (like corne) with great veines, wherein the Spiconardus groweth. They doe commonly come clo≈øe out of the earth by the roote, and by that ≈øort are brought into Cambaia, and other places to ≈øell, and from thence ≈øent into all places.Annota. D. P ‚Ä¢ .

p.hi: The Indian Spica comforteth the mawe, being taken inwardly and al≈øo outwardly applyed, and con≈øumeth cold humors.

div.p:
Aloe, by the Arabians called Sebar, by the Decaners Area, by the Canarijns Cate Comer, and by the Portingales Azeure, is made of the Iuyce of an Hearbe, when it is dried, the Herbe is called by the Portingales Herba Baboza, that is Quil hearbe. There is much of it in Cambaia, Bengala, and other places, but in the Iland called Sacotora
(which lyeth on the mouth of the redde Sea, or the ≈øtrength of Mecca) there is great quantitie, and the be≈øt. It is a marchandi≈øe that is carried into Turkie, Per≈øia, Arabia, and al≈øo into Europe, whereby the Iland is much e≈øteemed, and the Aloes called after the name of the Iland, Aloes Socotrino, or Aloes of Sacotora.

p.hi: Aloes purgeth the ≈øtomacke from choler, and tough fleagme, ≈øpecially a watrie and weake ≈øtomake: it taketh away all ≈øtopping, and con≈øumeth rawe moy≈øtures, pre≈øeruing it from foulene≈ø≈øe: be≈øides this, it ≈øtrengthneth the ≈øtomake, it is made ≈øtronger & of more force by adding to it Cinamon, Mace, or Nutmegges. Aloes is good ≈øpecially again≈øt Kooren and rawne≈ø≈øe, and for ≈øuch per≈øons as haue their ≈øtomakes ful of raw moy≈øture, it is al≈øo v≈øed outwardly again≈øt ≈øores that breake forth of the body, and for the eyes.

div.p: The fruite called Anacardi, is in manye places of India, as in Cananor, Calecut, and the countrie of Decan, and in diuers other places. The Arabians call it Balador, the Indians Bibo, and the Portingall Faua de Malacca, that is Beanes of Malacca, becau≈øe it is like a beane, but ≈øomwhat greater then the Beanes of the≈øe countries, they are v≈øed in India with milke, again≈øt a ≈øhort breath, for the Wormes and for many other things. When they are greene, they make Achar thereof, that is to ≈øay, they ≈øalt them and lay them in Vineger, as they do with the mo≈øt kind of fruites and Spices, as in diuers places I haue ≈øhewed.

p.hi: This fruite hath her name from the hart, becau≈øe in colour and likene≈ø≈øe, it re≈øembleth the heart, ≈øpecially beeing drie. When the fruites are greene and hanging on the tree (as I haue ≈øeene theÃÑ in Sicilia vpon mount Aethna) they are like great Beanes: and are ≈øalted like Oliues, being verie good to eate, within them they haue a certaine iuyce, as thicke as Honnie, and as red as bloud, which is good again≈øt ≈øtains. The ≈øame operation that is in prepared Mirabolanes, is al≈øo in them, they heate & drie, they ≈øtrengthen the memorie, the braines and ≈øinewes, ≈øharpen the wits, and are good again≈øt cold affections of the head.

div.p: The Calamo Aromatico called in Gu≈øurate Vaz, in Decan Vache, in Malabar Va≈øabu, in Malacca Daringoo, in P ‚Ä¢ r≈øia Heger, in Cuncan (which is the countrie of Goa and there abouts Northwards) Vaycan, and in Arabia Ca≈ø≈øab and Aldirira, is ≈øowed in many places of India, as in Goa, the Countrie of Gu≈øurate and Ballagate, where it is ≈øowed and ≈øo groweth, it hath no ≈ømell at all, vntill it be gathered. The women v≈øe it much in India, for the mother, al≈øo for paine in the Sinewes, it is al≈øo much v≈øed for hor≈øes, for when it is cold weather, they giue it hor≈øes in the morning to eate, being beaten and mixed with Garlike, Comin≈ø√©ede, ≈øalte, Suger, and Butter. This receipt they call Arata, which is alwayes v≈øed in India for hor≈øes, wherewith (as they ≈øaye) they doe them great good. The Calamo Aromatico is the ≈øtalke or Reede of the Hearbe, but the inward and ≈øpungious part is of yelowi≈øh colour, the roote of the tr√©e is good for nothing, but onely the ≈øtalke or R√©ede therof, with that which is in the midde≈øt of it.

p.hi:
What the right Calamus Aromaticus is,Annota. D. Pa ‚Ä¢
my verie good friend Doctor Carolus Clu≈øius writeth in his learned Annotations vpon Garcius ab Horto in his 127 leafe, whereof certaine peeces were giuen me, which I brought out of Egypt, where it is found in great aboundance, and much v≈øed. They call it Ca≈ø≈øab Elderira, it is a thinne Reede, being fre≈øhe and vnwithered, of a light Gold yelow colour, with many knots and ≈øplinters in the breaking, within ≈øpungie like Cobwebbes, white & tough in chawing, and a≈øtringent, with a little ≈øharpe bitterne≈ø≈øe, as I can ≈øhew it, and much therof may be had out of Egypt, where they put it in their Treakle, and v≈øe it many other waies, to driue downe the Vrine, and for the ≈øtone.

div.p: Co≈øtus which the Arabians call Co≈øt or Ca≈øt, the Gu≈øurates of Cambaia Vlpor, and they of Malac ‚Ä¢ a Pucho, whether it is much brought, and al≈øo into China and other places. They are trees almo≈øt like Elder-tr√©es with white blo≈ø≈øomes, and very ≈øtrong of ≈ømell. The wood and the roote is the Co≈øtus, it is a great marchandi≈øe in Per≈øia, Arabia, and Turkie where as it is very much v≈øed.

p.hi: I haue many kindes of Co≈øtus, the Indian,

de≈øcribed by Garcius, with all her tokens. The Arabian and Syrian with her right markes, and al≈øo an other ≈øorte, much like Ginger. The Indian Costus is the be≈øt of them all, it healeth, driueth downe the Vrine and the ≈øtone, it clean≈øeth the Mother, being receiued into the bodie, or thru≈øt vp into it, and maketh women apt to conceiue. div.p:
Cabebus ≈øo called by the Arabians, and al≈øo Quabes, by all the other Indians Cub ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ m, or Cubabelum, becau≈øe the Chi
‚Ä¢ ars before the Portingales comming into India, v≈øed to bring it out of the Ilandes of Iaua from Sunda, where they grow, and in no other place. It is much v≈øed ≈øpecially among the Moo ‚Ä¢ es, who put it into their Wine, therwith to make them apter to accompli≈øh their lu≈øtes, whereunto they are much giuen: and the Iauers v≈øe it again≈øt the coldne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtomacke and other di≈øea≈øes.

p.hi: Cubebus is a fruit like Pepper, about the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe, the be≈øt are ≈øuch as are clo≈øe, full, heauie and ≈øharpe, although they be le≈ø≈øe then Pepper, but ≈ø ‚Ä¢ mewhat bitter and ≈ømell well, being i ‚Ä¢ a manner ≈øweete. div.p:
The leaues called Folium Indum which the Indians call Tamalapatr ‚Ä¢
are like Orange leaues, but ≈øomewhat ≈øharper, and of a dark gr√©en colour. They haue 3 veynes that reach vnto the end of the leafe, one in the middle, and two on the ≈øides, that is, on each ≈øide one. They haue a ≈øweet ≈ømell, almo≈øt like Cloues. the Arabians, Cadegi Indi, that is to ≈øay, the Indian leafe: it is likewi≈øe much brought hither, ≈øpeciallie to Venice, and is v≈øed to prouoke vrine, to ≈øtrengtheÃÑ the ≈øtomack & to helpe a ≈øtinking breath.

div.p:
Galanga by the Arabians called Galuegian, is of two ≈øortes, one that is ≈ømall and ≈ømelleth well, which is brought out of China into India, and from thence to Portingal and other places: and this ≈øort is in China called Lauaudon: the other b√©eing greater is found in the Iland Iaua, and by them called Lanquas, and this ≈ømelleth not ≈øo well, as that of China: they grow on ≈ømall plants, a ≈øpanne or 2 ≈øpannes high from the earth, of them≈øelues without ‚Ä¢ ing: that of Iaua is the greate≈øt plaÃÑt, about „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ pannes high: it hath leaues like the point of a ≈øpeare, with a white flower, which bringeth forth ≈øeed: although they ≈øowe it not, yet in India they haue planted ≈øome in their Gardens for plea≈øure, and v≈øe it for Sallets and other medicines, ≈øpecially the midwyues, (which in India are called Da ‚Ä¢ a: it groweth not of the ≈ø√©ed, but of the roote which is planted in the earth, like Ginger: they are great & long, and haue knottes like reeds: it is a thing v≈øed in India for many medicines, & caryed into al places.

div.p: Of the≈øe and ≈øuch like herbes there are manie in India, and in the Orientall parts, the names and properties whereof are to mee vnknowne‚ñ™ becau≈øe they are not ≈øo common, nor knowne among the meaner ≈øort of people, but onlie by Phy≈øitians, Apothecaries, and Herbali≈øtes: therefore I haue onlie ≈øpoken of ≈øuch as are commonlie knowne, and daylie v≈øed.
