div.head: The 84. Chapter. Of all ≈øorts of Pearles, both great and ≈ømall, and of precious ≈øtones, as Diamantes, Rubies, Topaces, Saffires, and other ≈øuch like ≈øtones, called Oriental ≈øtones, and of the Bezers ≈øtone, which is good again≈øt poy≈øon, and ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes, and in what manner and place they are found.
div.p:
PEarles by the Portingales are called Perolas, that is, ≈øuch as are great, and the ≈ømall Alioffar, in Latin, Margaritas: in Arabia, Lulu: in Per≈øia and India, Motu: and in Malabar, Mutiu. The principall and the be≈øt that are found in all the Orientall countries, and the right Orientall pearles are ≈øome betw√©ene Ormus and Ba≈øtora, in the ≈øtraights, or Sinus Per≈øicus, in the places called Bareyn, Cati≈ø≈øi, Iulfar, Camaron, & other places in the ≈øaid Sinus Per≈øicus, from whence they are brought into Ormus. The King of Portingale al≈øo hath his Factor in Bareyn, that ≈øtayeth there onlie for the fi≈øhing of pearles. There is great trafficke v≈øed with them, as well in Ormus as in Goa. There are al≈øo other fi≈øhings for pearle, as betw√©ene the Iland of Seylon, and the Cape de Comriin, where great numbers are yearelie found, for that the King of Portingale hath a captaine there with certaine ≈øoldiers that looketh vnto it: they haue yearlie at the le≈øt aboue 3 or 4 thou≈øaÃÑd duckers yt liue onlie by fi≈øhing for pearles, and ≈øo maintaine them≈øelues, whereof euerie yeare many are drowned or deuoured by ye fi≈øhes called Tubarones or Hayen, whereof I haue alreadie made meÃÑtion: the≈øe pearls are not ≈øo good, nor ≈øo much e≈øteemed as the pearles of Ormus and are of a lower price, which they know likewi≈øe how to di≈øcerne at the fir≈øt ≈øight. There are al≈øo pearles found by the Iland of Borneo, and the Iland of Aynon, on the coa≈øt of Cauchinchina, but tho≈øe of Ormus ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe them all. They are fi≈øhed for by dukers that diue into the water, at the lea≈øt 10 12 and 20 fadome d√©epe. They grow in Oy≈øters, but the great pearls are found in the Oy≈øters that ≈øwimme aloft, and the ≈ømalle≈øt called Alioffar, are commonly in the bottome of the ≈øea. The duckers are naked, hauing a ba≈øket bound at their backes, which being at the bottome (to make the more ha≈øt) they rake full of Oy≈øters and durt together, and then ry≈øe vp againe, and throwe them into boates, that lie readie for the purpo≈øe, with men in them, which pre≈øentlie take the Oy≈øters, and lay them on land to drie, where with the heate of the Sunne they open of them≈øelues, and ≈øo they find the pearles of Alioffar in the fi≈øh: and when they haue made an end of fi≈øhing for that day, all the Fi≈øhers, with the Captaine, Soldiers, laborers and Watchmen for the King, goe together, and taking all the pearles that are caught that day, they diuide them into certaine heapes, that is, one part for the King, an other part for the Captaine and Soldiers, the third part for the Ie≈øuites, becau≈øe they haue their Cloy≈øter in that place, and brought the Countrie fir≈øt vnto the Chri≈øtian Faith, and the la≈øt part for the Fi≈øhers, which is done with great Iu≈øtice and equalitie. This fi≈øhing is done in Summer tyme, and there pa≈ø≈øeth not any yeare but that diuers Fi≈øhers are drowned by the Cape de Comoriin (which is called the Kings fi≈øhing) and manie deuoured by Fi≈øhes: ≈øo that when the fi≈øhing is done, there is a great and pitifull noy≈øe and cry of women and Children heard vpon the land, for the lo≈ø≈øe of their hu≈øbands and friends: yet the next yeare they mu≈øt to the ≈øame worke againe, for that they haue no other meanes to liue, as ‚Ä¢ l≈øo for that they are partlie comp ‚Ä¢ lled thereunto
by the Portingales, but mo≈øt part are content to doe it, becau≈øe of the gaine they get thereby after all the danger is pa≈øt. They finde ≈øometimes many, and ≈øometimes but a few Pearles in one oy≈øter, ≈øometimes two hundred graines and more. The oy≈øters that haue the be≈øt Pearles in them are thinne and white, which the Indians call Cheripo, wherof they make ≈øpoones and cups to drink in. The Pearles are ≈øold by ≈øiues which are made of mettell driuen into thin plate for that purpo≈øe, whereof the holes are round. There are many ≈øorts of the≈øe ≈øiues, the fir≈øt hath ≈ømall holes, and the Pearles that pa≈ø≈øe through them are at one price: the next ≈øiue hath greater holes, and the Pearles that fall through it are at higher price, and ≈øo foorth at the lea≈øt ≈øeauen or eight ≈øiues. The ≈ømall ≈øtuffe that ≈øerue for no Pearles, they call Alioffar, and are ≈øold by the ounce, and v≈øed by Potticaries and Phi≈øitions, and to that end many of them are caried into Portingall, & Venice, and are very good cheape. To giue the Pearles a faire colour, in India they v≈øe rice beaten a little with ≈øalt, wherewith they rub them, and then they become as faire and cleare as chri≈øtall, and ≈øo continue. There is yet an other ≈øort of oy≈øters by the Indians called Cha ‚Ä¢ lia ‚ñ™ & by the Portingales Madre Perol ‚Ä¢ , or in other of Pearle, & are of the ≈øhell fi≈øhes that wee call inkehornes, which they know how to prepare and make cleane. They bring many of them into Portingale to ≈ø ‚Ä¢ rue for to drinke in, and to keepe for an ornament, & for plea≈øure ≈øpecially tho≈øe that come out of China and Bengalen, ≈øome guilt and painted with colours very faire, ≈øome wrought with branches and other figures, as we dayly ≈øee them brought thether. In India they make diuers thinges of them, as de≈økes, tables, cubbards, tables to play on, bo ‚Ä¢ es, ≈øtaues for women to beare in their hands, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch fine deui≈øes, which are all inlaid and couered with this Chanco or Mother of Pearle, very faire to beholde, & very workmanlike made, and are in India ≈øo commoÃÑ, that there is almo≈øt no place in tho≈øe countries but they haue of them. It is likewi≈øe much caried abroad, both into Portingale ‚ñ™ and els where, but they are mo≈øt v≈øed in India, for there the women, ≈øpeciallie tho≈øe of Bengala v≈øe to weare manillias, or bracelets of them about their armes, that is to ≈øay, tho≈øe of mo≈øt account, and they mu≈øt not take a maidens maidenhead from her that is of any e≈øtate or degree, but ≈øhe mu≈øt haue ≈øome of the≈øe mother of Pearle bracelets about her armes, which at this day is yet much v≈øed, and ob≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ued, whereby it is verie much worn ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™

Torteanxes there are likewi≈øe in great numbers throughout all India: of their ≈øhelles they make many curious deui≈øes, as Combes, Cuppes, and Boles to drinke in, with tablemen and diuers ≈øuch like thinges, knowing howe to giue it a faire and ≈øhining colour mo≈øt plea≈øant to behold, and is more e≈øt√©emed of in India, theÃÑ the mother of pearle, by rea≈øon of the beautifull colour they ≈øet vppon it.

div.head: The 85. Chapter. Of Diamonds.
div.p: DIamonds by the Arabians and Mores called Almas, and by the Indians where they grow Iraa, and by the Malagans where they are likewi≈øe fouÃÑd, Itam. They grow in the Countrie of Decam behinde Ballagate, by the Towne of Bi≈ønagar, wherein are two or three hilles from whence they are digged, whereof the King of B ‚Ä¢ ≈ønagar doth reape great profitte: for hee cau≈øeth theÃÑ to be ≈øtraightly watched, and hath farmed them out with this condition, that all Diamonds that are aboue twenty fiue Mangeleyns in waight are for the king him≈øelfe: (euery Mangelyn is foure graines in waight) and if anie man bee found that hideth anie ≈øuch, hee loo≈øeth both life and goods.

There is yet another hill in the Countrie of Decam, which is called Vellia, that is the old Rocke: from thence come the be≈øt Diamonds, and are ≈øold for the greate≈øt price, which the Diamand grinders, Iewellers, and Indians can very well di≈øcerne from the re≈øt.

The≈øe Diamonds are much brought to ≈øell in a Faire that is holden in a Towne called L ‚Ä¢ ≈øpor, lying in the ≈øame countrie of Decam betweene Goa, and Cambaia, whether the Banianes and Gu≈øurates of Cambaia doe goe and buy them vp, bringing them to Goa, and other places. They are very ≈økilfull in the≈øe matters, ≈øo that no Ieweller can goe beyond them, but oftentimes they deceiue the be≈øt Iewellers in all Chri≈øtendome. In this Roca Vellia, there are Diamondes founde that are called Nayfes ready cut, which are naturall, and are more e≈øt√©emed then the re≈øt, ≈øpecially by the Indians them≈øelues.

In the ≈øtraight called Tania pura, a countrie on the one ≈øide of Malacca there is likewi≈øe an old rocke, which al≈øo is called Roca-Vellia,
where many Diamondes are found, that are excellent: they are ≈ømall, but verie good, and heauie, which is good for the ≈øeller, but not for the buyer. Diamonds are digged like gold out of Mynes, and where they digge one yeare the length of a man into the ground, within three or foure yeares after, there are Diamondes founde againe in the ≈øame place which grow there. Sometimes they find Diamonds of one hundred and two hundred Mangelyns, and more but verie few.

There is another ≈øtone called a Topace for colour which is almo≈øt like the Diamond, but darker & of le≈ø≈øe e≈øtimation. There are many of them founde, that are of great valew for that kinde of ≈øtone, and are likewi≈øe digged out of the earth like Diamonds in many places of India. There are al≈øo white Saffires and Rubies, which can hardly bee knowne from Diamonds vnles it be by very good and expert Iewellers, and Diamond grinders. There is likewi≈øe founde in India a kinde of thing much like to Rock-chri≈øtall, but ind√©ede it is none: for there is no Chri≈øtall to be found in India, nor in any of the oriental countries. It is called berylo, and is little different from Chri≈øtall. It is much found in Cambaia, Pegu, and Seylon, and they make many things thereof, as beades, ≈øeales, and diuers other thinges, which they ≈øell vnto the Chri≈øtians, and v≈øe among them≈øelues.

div.head: The 86. Chapter. Of Rubies, E≈øpinelles, Granades, Emeralds and other precious ≈øtones.
div.p: RVbies are of manie ≈øorts, but the be≈øt are tho≈øe that are called carbunckles, which are Rubies that waigh aboue 25. quilates, wherof there are verie few and ≈øeldome to be found. The be≈øt Rubies that are of the be≈øt colour, and water are in India called Tockes, which are like Carbunckles, there are others called Ballax, which are of a lower price then the fir≈øt, and they are red. There are others called E≈øpinellas, that are of colour like fire, and are le≈ø≈øe e≈øteemed then the other two ≈øortes, becau≈øe they haue not the right water of Rubies. There are Rubies al≈øo of manie other ≈øorts, wherof ≈øome are white like Diamonds as I ≈øaid before: other of a Carnation colour or much like white Cherries when they are ripe. There are Rubies found halfe white, halfe red, ≈øome halfe Rubies, halfe Safires, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch other ≈øortes. The cau≈øe thereof is becau≈øe that in the rockes and hils where they grow, their fir≈øt colour is white, and by the force of the Sunne, are in time brought to their perfection and ripene≈ø≈øe, and b√©eing perfect they are of colour red, like the Carbunckle and Tockes afore≈øaid, but wanting ≈øomewhat of their perfection, and being digged out before, that time they are of diuers colours as I ≈øaid before, and how much paler they are, and le≈ø≈øe red then the Tockes, ≈øo much are they le≈ø≈øe in valew: for as they are in beautie and perfection, ≈øo are they e≈øt√©emed euery one in their kinde. Tho≈øe that are halfe Rubies, and halfe Safires, which the Indians call Nilcandi, that is to ≈øay, halfe Safier, and halfe Rubie, proceed of this, that the Rubies and Safiers grow alwaies in one rocke, whereby they are oftentimes founde, halfe one, halfe other. The Rubies by the Arabians and Per≈øians are called Iacut, by the Indians Manica. The Safiers are of two ≈øortes‚ñ™ one of a darke blew, the other of a right blew, the Iacinth, Granades, and Roba≈ø≈øes are likewi≈øe certaine kinds of Rubies, but little e≈øteemed, the Indians call them the yellow and carnation Rubies, and ≈øo foorth, according to their colour. The≈øe Iacinthes, Granadoes, and Roba≈ø≈øes, are in ≈øo great numbers in Cananor, Calecut, and Cambaia, that they are to ≈øell in euerie Market, and corner of the ≈øtreets, by whole corgias, each corgia hauing twentie p√©eces at the lea≈øt in it, they ≈øell the corgia for one ≈øtiuer or two at the mo≈øt as many as you will de≈øire, but you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, they are of the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øort. The Safier is not of ≈øo great e≈øtimation as the Rubie, and yet is one of the mo≈øt precious ≈øtones that are next the Diamond, and the Rubie: the Rubies, Safiers, and other ≈øtones afore≈øaid, doe grow and are found in rockes and hilles like Diamonds: they come out of Calecut, Cananor, and from manie places in the land of Bi≈ønaga, but mo≈øt out of the I≈øland of Seylon, which are the be≈øt: but tho≈øe of the Countrie of Pegu are e≈øteemed the fine≈øt, whereof there is great ≈øtore.

The Emerauldes which the Indians call Pache, and the Arabians Samarrut, there are none throughout al India, yet it is reported yt ≈øome haue bin found there, but verie few & not ofteÃÑ: but they are much brought thether from
„Äà‚óä„Äâ in Aegypt, and are likewi≈øe called Orientall: they are much e≈øteemed in India, becau≈øe there are but few of them. There are many al≈øo brought out of ye Spani≈øh Indies, and carryed into the lande of Pegu, where they are much worne, and e≈øt√©emed of, wherby many Venetians (that haue trauelled thether with Emeraldes and bartered them for Rubies) are become very rich, becau≈øe among them men had rather haue Emeraldes then Rubies: All the ≈øaid ≈øtones are likewi≈øe v≈øed in medicines, and Apoticarie drugges, Turque≈øes are found in great numbers in the Countrey of Per≈øia, and brought into India from beyond Ormus, by hundreth pounds at once, earth and altogether, which in India are little e≈øt√©emed, for that the Indians and Portingals do not weare many of them, and make ≈ømall account of them. The Ia≈øpar is much found in the land of Cambaia, but not much regarded: they make di≈øhes and cups thereof: it is of colour gr√©ene like the Emeralde. Chri≈øolites and Amati≈øtes are many in the I≈øland of Seylon, Cambaia, and Ballagatte, and the ≈øtone called Alakecca, which is al≈øo called Blood≈øtone, becau≈øe it quickly ≈øtancheth blood, and other ≈øtones called Milke ≈øtones, which are good for women that giue milke or ≈øucke. The≈øe and ≈øuch like ≈øtones are in great numbers found in Cambaia and Ballagatte, and are brought to Goa to bee ≈øolde, whereof they make Beades, Seales, Ringes, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch like curio≈øities: they are much e≈øt√©emed, for that a ≈øeale of ≈øuch a ≈øtone is worth two or three Pardaws the peece: there is al≈øo in Cambaia much Alambre, or wherof they make many rings, beades, and ≈øuch like things, which are much v≈øed: there are likewi≈øe ≈øtones, by the Portingalles called Olhos de Gato, that is to ≈øay, Cattes eyes, becau≈øe they are like them (which is the Agat) and are of colour and fa≈øhion like Cattes eyes: they come out of Cambaia, but the be≈øt out of Seylon and Pegu: they are little brought into Portin
‚Ä¢ l, for there they are not e≈øt√©emed, and likewi≈øe becau≈øe they are worth more in India then in Portingall, for the Indians e≈øt√©eme much of them, ≈øpecially the Chinos, and thether they are caryed, better e≈øt√©emed, and ≈øold there then any other ≈øtones: the Indians ≈øay that this ≈øtone hath a certaine propertie and vertue to pre≈øerue and k√©epe a man in the riches which he hath, and that they ≈øhall not le≈ø≈øen, but ≈øtil increa≈øe: the Load≈øtone, which the Portingalles call Ped ‚Ä¢ a de Ceuar is found in great quantity, and in many places of India: the Indians ≈øay, that if a man v≈øe dayly to eate a little of that ≈øtone, it pre≈øerueth him, and maketh him looke yong, and that he ≈øhall neuer looke olde: wherefore the Kinges and great Lordes of India v≈øe it in pottes and ve≈ø≈øelles, therein to eate and ≈ø√©eth their meate, thereby as they beleeue to pre≈øerue their youthes.

div.head: The 87. Chapter. Of the Bezar ≈øtones, and other ≈øtones good again≈øt poy≈øon
div.p:
THe Bezar ≈øtone commeth out of Per≈øia, froÃÑ the land or Prouince called Cara≈ø ‚Ä¢ one, and al≈øo out of other places in India: they grow within the maw of a ≈øh√©epe or Goat, about a little ≈øtraw, that lyeth in the middle of the maw, for by experience the ≈øtraw is often found within them: the ≈øtone is very ≈ølicke & ≈ømooth without, of a darke gr√©ene colour. The≈øe Goats or ≈øh√©epe are by the Per≈øians called Pazan, wherevpon they call the ≈øtone Pazar, and the Portingalles by corruption of ≈øp√©ech call it Bazar or Be≈øar, and the Indians Pedro do Bazar, which is as much to ≈øay, as market ≈øtone: for Bezar in the Indian ≈øpeech ≈øignifieth a market or place where all victuailes are kept and ≈øolde, and for the ≈øame cau≈øe they call the ≈ømalle≈øt money Bazarucos, as if they woulde ≈øay market money. This Bezars ≈øtone is very co≈øtly, and is much v≈øed in India again≈øt all poy≈øon, and other di≈øea≈øes, and is more e≈øteemed then Vnicornes horne in Europe, for it is much tryed and ≈øold very deare: The greater and heauier they are, the better and of more vertue they are: the common ≈øorte are of thr√©e foure or fiue octaues weight, ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe: they are much brought into Portingal, and greatly e≈øt√©emed: the place where they are mo≈øt found, is (as I ≈øaid before) in Per≈øia and al≈øo in the I≈øland called In≈øula das Vacas, or the I≈øland of Cowes: It lyeth before the mouth of the riuer, entering into Cambaia, hard by the coa≈øt where the Portingall nauie often putteth in to refre≈øh them≈øelues, and being there, kill diuers of the ≈øheepe or Goates, wherein they finde many of the≈øe Bezars ≈øtones: likewi≈øe in the lande of Pan by Malacca, there are many found: in the ≈øame countrey of Pan they find a certaine ≈øtone within the gall of a Hogge, which they e≈øteeme more again≈øt poy≈øon and other di≈øea≈øes then ye Bezars ≈øtone: the Portingalles call it Pedra do Porco, that is, Hogges ≈øtone: it is much v≈øed in Malacca,
it is of cleare redde colour, and bitter in ta≈øte, and ≈øauoureth like French ≈øope: when they will v≈øe it and giue it any man to drinke, they throw it into a cuppe of water, and ≈øo let it ≈øtande a little, which done, they take it out againe, and the water will be bitter, and clean≈øe all the venime that a man hath in his body, as by experience hath oftentimes b√©en found. The Bezars ≈øtone is as hard as any ≈øtone, but not very heauie: It is thought that the≈øe ≈øtones doe growe in the mawes of ≈øh√©epe, and galles of Hogges by vertue of the gra≈ø≈øe or hearbes whereon they pa≈øture and f√©ed, as we haue declared of the Rhinoceros, becau≈øe they doe onely br√©ede in tho≈øe places aboue named, and in no place els, where the≈øe kinds of bea≈øtes are. In the towne of Vltabado in the Countrey behind Goa in Ballagatte, there is a ≈øtone found by the Arabians called Hagerarmini, and by the Portingals Pedra Armenia, and becau≈øe there are many of them found in Armenia, they are commonly called ≈øo: it is blew & ≈øomewhat light gr√©ene: the Moores v≈øe it much in purgations and for other di≈øea≈øes: be≈øides the≈øe ≈øtones afore≈øaid, there are al≈øo many ≈øortes of ≈øtones, as well precious ≈øtones, as again≈øt poy≈øon and other di≈øea≈øes, and of many properties & vertues: but becau≈øe they are but little knowne, or trafiqued withall, I haue onely made mention of tho≈øe that are dayly bought and ≈øold, and commonly knowne.

div.head: The 88. Chapter. A briefe in≈øtruction how to know and find out the right Diamantes, Rubies, Emeralds, Pearls, & other precious ≈øtones, and how to value them by waight, at their right prices and values, & fir≈øt of the Diamant.
div.p:
FIr≈øt you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the Diamant is the king of al precious ≈øtones, becau≈øe it is ≈øolde by weight, and hath a very certain thickenes, whereby it is ordinarily wroght, for when it is greater, it is nothing worth, and being le≈ø≈øe it will ≈øoone be perceyued: by the which thickne≈ø≈øe although it ≈øtandeth in a ring, they can both ≈ø√©e and ge≈ø≈øe how much it weighth, within a little more or le≈ø≈øe, and being out of the ring it is weyghed, thereby to value it truely: there are olde and ancient records found in India, wherein are written the prices of the ≈øtones, that is, one Quilat for ≈øo much, two Quilates for ≈øo much, and thr√©e Quilates for ≈øo much after the rate &c. and ≈øo of all prices and weights accordingly: and becau≈øe they are dayly bought and ≈øolde, it is therefore n√©edefull for a man to haue a memoriall about him, that is, of the prices of the perfect and fayre ≈øtones, without fault or ≈øpot, for that being vncleane, or hauing any fault or ≈øpot, they are hardly to be valued. There are ≈øome Princes and great Lordes that de≈øire to know the cau≈øe why ≈øuch precicious ≈øtones are holden at ≈øo great prices, wherevnto no other an≈øwere is made, but becau≈øe men buy and ≈øell them ≈øo deare, for all thinges are e≈øt√©emed no otherwi≈øe of, then becau≈øe they are bought and ≈øold at ≈øuch pryces, and ≈øo is their manner to ≈øell, for if a Diamant of one Quilat alone, bee worth fiftie Duckets, being perfect, their rea≈øon is, that after the ≈øame rate a great ≈øtone or Diamant may be worth 30. or 40. thou≈øand Duckets, being in greatne≈ø≈øe and perfection corre≈øpondent: and the ≈øtones as well great as little, that vntill this time haue b√©ene bought and ≈øolde, haue not b√©ene ≈øo light, that they were ≈øold aboue or vnder their value and e≈øtimation. Now to value the great Diamant as it ought to be, it is nece≈ø≈øarie to know and determine what a Diamant of a Quilat is worth, and a Rubie to match therewith: the like of an Emerald, neyther more nor le≈ø≈øe, & hauing well con≈øidered what or how much hinderance the falts and foulene≈ø≈øe of the ≈øaide Diamant will be vnto the ≈øale thereof, deducting the ≈øame out of the price of the ≈øaid Diamant, Rubie or Emerald being Orientall, of what greatne≈ø≈øe ≈øoeuer they bee, you may value them, and I will fir≈øt beginne with the Diamant, for that other ≈øtones are valued after the rate thereof, and wil declare the perfection which it ought to haue. The diamant yt is perfect in all re≈øpects, mu≈øt be of that proportion, that the two ≈øquares on the ≈øides mu≈øt make the breadth of the vpper parte of the ≈øtone, and that the vnder part of the ≈øtone be no broader, then that thr√©e of the breadths thereof will make the breadth of the vpper part, and d√©epe according to the ≈øame proportion: and the ≈øquares on the ≈øide mu≈øt ≈øtande clo≈øe with the edge of the ring or thing wherin it is ≈øet, being of the whole depth, and ≈øomewhat longer then ≈øquare, and yet no more, then that it may be ge≈ø≈øed, which is the length and breadth thereof, al≈øo it mu≈øt bee without any falts both in corners and ≈øides, and euery one of the foure corners ≈øharpe and cleane cut, and of a good water, Chri≈øtaline & ≈øhining cleare, ≈øo that it may not once be perceiued that it draweth neere any colour, and not of a darke water, but cleare and cleane:
the Diamant with all the≈øe perfections is worth 50. duckets being of one Quilat: but becau≈øe the≈øe perfections are not often found, and that few men vnder≈øtand them, therefore I will ≈øay that a Diamant of goodne≈ø≈øe and perfection according to the common e≈øtimation, being of the waight of one Quilat in worth 40. duckets, and after this rate wee will make our account, and whether it bee a ≈ømall or great Diamant of what wayght goodnes or foulene≈ø≈øe ≈øoeuer it may bee: you mu≈øt fir≈øt con≈øider & know what it waigheth, & if they cannot tell you, theÃÑ you mu≈øt ge≈ø≈øe by the ≈øight thereof, and alwayes e≈øt√©eme it at le≈ø≈øe wayght then you think it weigheth, that you may value it within the price, and hauing e≈øt√©emed the waight, k√©epe that in your memorie, and ≈øay thus, if it were a Diamant of a Quilat waight of this water, and ≈øo perfect, or had the corners le≈ø≈øe then the≈øe, or any foulene≈ø≈øe in re≈øpect of this, and all the qualities, or faultes which a Diamant ought to haue, con≈øider what ≈øuch a Diamant may be worth, being of qualitie like that you will e≈øt√©eme, & weighing no more but one Quilat: which hauing wel thought and con≈øidered vpon, e≈øt√©eme it rather le≈ø≈øe then more, & hold ye price in your memory as afore≈øaid, and thinke vppon the waight that it ≈øhould weigh, be it much or little, & double the ≈øame waight adding as much more vnto it, as if it bee two, take other two, and multiply them together, and ≈øay 2. times 2. is foure: if it weygh 3. multiply it with thr√©e, and they make 9. and ≈øo according to the number you find, and ≈øo you ≈øhall multiply all Diamonds, in waight, of what wayght ≈øoeuer they be, and multiply them as I ≈øaid before with as much againe as they bee e≈øteemed, and the production of your multiplication you ≈øhall multiply by the ≈øumme of money you value the Diamant to bee worth, weyghing one Quilate, and the production of the la≈øt multiplication is the value of the Diamant: & if in the waight there be any halfes, as if it wayghed 2 ‚Ä¢ . Quilate, then you ≈øhall redeeme them into halfe Quilates, which is 5. halfe Quilates, and then ≈øay 5. times 5. is 25. and that ≈øhall you multiply with the price of the halfe Quilate, as you e≈øteeme it, and the production thereof is the worth of ≈øuch a Diamant, and if it chance yt the Diamant were ≈øo ≈ømal, that the waight of a graine ≈øhould be therein e≈øteemed: then you mu≈øt reduce all the waight into graines, and multiply as afore≈øaid, and that which proceedeth thereof is the waight of ≈øuch a Diamant as you ≈øeeke to value or e≈øt√©eme. As for example, there is a Diamant that waigheth 2. Quilates, which is of ≈øuch a qualitie, that being of one Quilate it would be worth
‚Ä¢ 0. Duckets, and being of halfe a Quilate, 10. Duckets, and being of a graine, 2. Duckets and a halfe. Now to know what this Diamant of 2. Quilates is worth, you ≈øhall ≈øay that 2. times 2. is 4. This 4. you ≈øhal multiply with 40. Duckets, which is the value thereof, being of one Quilate, it maketh 160. Duckets, which is the price of that Diamant of two Quilates: now that you haue a Diamant of two Quilates and a halfe, which is fiue halfes, you ≈øhall ≈øay fiue times fiue is 25. this 25. multiplyed by 10. it maketh 250. duckets, becau≈øe the halfe Quilate co≈øt 10. duckets, which is after the rate of 40. duckets the Quilate, then the Diamant of 2. Quilates and a halfe amounteth to 250. duckets. Now if a Diamant weighed 7. graines, you ≈øhall ≈øay 7. times 7. is 49. which 49. you mu≈øt multiply by the value of a graine, which is two duckets and a halfe: ≈øo a Diamant of 7. graines is 127. duckets. In this manner you may alwaies know what a Diamant is worth, hauing rated the price of one Quilate: the waight of the Diamant you will e≈øteeme being thus knowne, as by example is ≈øhewed, and ≈øo you may the ea≈øilier make your account. There are ≈øome Diamants that are faultie and vnperfect, and are not worth 40. duckets, but of a le≈ø≈øe price according to the faultes, and may be worth 36.35.34 & 30. duckets, or any lower price, as the faultes are e≈øt√©emed, & in that ca≈øe it is very trouble≈øome to knowe what half a Quilat or grain ≈øhould be worth: wherin you mu≈øt do thus: wheÃÑ you haue e≈øteemed what a Quilat of ≈øuch a Diamant may be worth & that in ye weight thereof there falleth out a halfe Quilat or grain, then you mu≈øt fir≈øt knowe what value it woulde bee worth being of one Quilate, and then make your account yt the fourth part of ≈øuch a price is the value of halfe a Quilate, ≈øo that when a Quilate is worth 40. duckets, a halfe Quilate is ten duckets, and one grayne two duckets and a halfe: for foure graines is a Quilate, if the Quilate be 36. duckets, the halfe Quilate is 9. duckets, and one graine two duckets and one Te≈øton, and ≈øo after that rate may you know ye price of all Diamants, of what qualitie ≈øoeuer they bee. The like reckening is made with thinne Diamantes, Rubies, and Emeraldes, that is made with tho≈øe which are of greater price, as I ≈øhall hereafter ≈øhew you. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that a Rubie bee of ≈øuch a quantitie, that it may accompany a Diamant of one Quilate it is worth 70. duckets, or that there be any which in weight doe accompany a Diamant of halfe a Quilate or grayne, then you mu≈øt make your account by halfe Quilates, or graynes, and you mu≈øt alwayes knowe the
price of one Quilate, and mu≈øt vnder≈øtande that the fourth parte of 70. duckettes is the value of one halfe Quilate, and the fourth part of a halfe Quilate is the price of a grain, and ≈øo you ≈øhall make your reckening of Emeraldes, each one according to his waight and price. There are ≈øome Diamantes that are thinne, and yet ≈øhew very cleare, which are more worth then they weygh, and le≈ø≈øe then their clearnes ≈øheweth: for a Diamant hauing a very thinne table and hollow, yet on ye vpper ≈øide hauing ye perfection in ≈øquare, as I ≈øaid, ≈øhould be in a thick diamant, which is of ≈øo good perefection both in ≈øides & hookes: ≈øuch a Diamant ≈øheweth to be of two Quilates and weygheth but one: wherefore wheÃÑ your Diamant is of what greatnes ≈øoeuer it may be, being perfect in the vpper parte, and thinne vnderneath, you mu≈øt alwaies make your account, that being thinne vnderneath, it is of le≈ø≈øe wayght then it ≈øheweth for, and if it be not altogether thinne vnderneath, then it weygheth more, yet the waight profiteth it nothing at all: and hauing the vpper table ≈ømaller, and the ≈øides greater, it will al≈øo weigh more, but the wayght auayleth it not: but you mu≈øt alwaies e≈øteeme it to weygh but the halfe of that it ≈øheweth for: and not being wholly thin vnderneath, it will weygh more, but to no end: and hauing the table ≈ømal, and the ≈øides and corners great, it weigheth more, but the weight auayleth not, but you mu≈øt e≈øt√©eme it to weigh but halfe ≈øo much as it ≈øheweth for: for that before it bee made ready it will lo≈øe much of the waight. Now if there bee a Diamant that hath a great table outwardes, & the corners ≈ømall, it ≈øhall not weigh halfe ≈øo much as it ≈øheweth for, yet is it not any thing ye wor≈øe for that, vnle≈ø≈øe the corners were too ≈ømall: nowe if there bee a Diamant thinne vnderneath, and ≈øquare aboue, with the perfections that ≈øhoulde belong vnto it, it is worth being of one Quilate 70. duckets, and hauing any faultes or ≈øpots, euery man may wel con≈øider what hinderance they are vnto it, and after this manner a man may ea≈øily ≈øet the pryce & value of them, and make his account after the rate of thicke Diamantes, his account being made of halfe the weight they ≈øeeme or ≈øhewe to haue: as if they ≈øhew to bee two Quilates, make your reckening of one Quilate: and if it ≈øhew three Quilates, make your account of ≈øixe grams, which is the half: and if there be any halfe Quilates, then ≈øee the price what a Quilate is worth, and ≈øo what a halfe amounteth vnto, and ≈øo make your account as afore≈øaide by thicke Dyamantes, and in graynes the like, for there is no other difference then in the pryce, for that a perfect and cleare thinne Diamant of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Quilate is worth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ckets and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ or le≈ø≈øe waight accordingly „Äà‚óä„Äâ .

div.head: The 89. Chapter. Of Rubies.
div.p:
WHen you haue a Rubie to value or e≈øteeme that is ≈øquared table wi≈øe, as it ≈øhould bee, and that ≈øuch a Rubie is to accompany a Dyamant of the ≈øame waight of Quilates and ≈øo man ‚Ä¢
Quilates in colour, if it hath foure and twentie Quilates in colour and perfection, like Golde of foure and twentie Quilates, then it is certaine, it is both fine and good. The Rubie is not ≈øolde by the waight‚ñ™ becau≈øe it hath no certaine thickne≈ø≈øe, for that many of them are made thinne for plea≈øure to the ≈øight, and the better to lay the grounde or leaues vnder them, and it may very well bee thinne, but not very much, for then it ≈øhould bee a lot and hinderance vnto it: if a Rubie be whole and perfect both in colour, cleanne≈ø≈øe, thickne≈ø≈øe, ≈øquarene≈ø≈øe, and forme, it is worth an hundred duckets: but there are very fewe that are perfect in all pointes, ≈øpecially being great, for they haue alwayes ≈øome faultes or ≈øpottes that are couered and hidden: but right perfect there are none, or very few, and not many men haue any great knowledge therein: therefore I will ≈øay, thereby to make our account, that a Rubie which in common ≈øhew is accounted perfect and good, is worth ≈øeuentie duckets: ≈øo that when a Ieweller or ≈øtone cutter doeth a≈øke another for a Rubie, which hee hath not‚ñ™
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øayth onely, there is a Rubie of greatne≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ o accompany a Diamant of ≈øo many Quilates, and hath ≈øo many Quilates in colour, the other thereby vnder≈øtandeth of what colour and greatne≈ø≈øe it is. Now hauing a Rubie or Rubies with tables or vnground, and are to value them, or knowe what they be worth, you ≈øhall con≈øider with your ≈øelfe and ≈øay thus: if there were a Rubie that were no greater then this, onely ≈øeruing to accompany a Dyamant of one Quilate, and were of ≈øuch colours, clearene≈ø≈øe, and qualities, as this in quantitie and greatnes, & had the faultes in all re≈øpects that this hath, what would it bee worth‚ñ™ and hauing well con≈øidered the qualities, goodnes or badne≈ø≈øe with the faults, how much they imba≈øe the price thereof, and hauing thereafter e≈øteemed
your price, beeing to accompany a Diamond of one Quilate, k√©ep that price in your memorie, and looke on the Rubie how bigge it is, and what waight the Diamond hath, wit ‚Ä¢ the depth which it ≈øhould be compared vnto‚ñ™ and al≈øo if it bee ≈øtill raw and vnground, con≈øider how much it mu≈øt be taken away in the grinding, and how bigge it will be when it is ≈øquared and fa≈øhioned: which hauing done, and knowing the waight of the Diamond it ≈øhall accompany, you ≈øhal then take as much more waight, & multiplie it with the waight you haue alreadie found, that it ≈øhould bee accompanying a Diamond of one Quilate, and the product ‚Ä¢ on thereof, is the valew of ≈øuch a Rubie: to conclude, when you haue determined what the waight of a Diamond is, that it may accompanie, you ≈øhall make your account as if it were a Diamond, and that which proceedeth of the waight, you ≈øhall multiplie with the price which you finde it to be worth, to k√©ep companie with a Diamond of one Quilate: the Rubies that are vngrouÃÑd and can be no tables it is to be vnder≈øtood that they are better in that ≈øorte then otherwi≈øe: Of the≈øe you mu≈øt con≈øider the price after the manner of the Diamond which hee may accompanie, & the height or depth of the ≈øtone, after that the colour, goodnes and faults as it falleth out, and make the account or reckoning thereof as of Rubies with tables, and ground, and al≈øo of the Diamonds. There are al≈øo Diamonds that are not cut ≈øquare in tables, but haue a good fa≈øhion for to ≈øet in anie Iewell, as being pointed with thr√©e corners, harts‚ñ™ and ≈øuch like ≈øorts, thereby to hide their faultes, and are made in that ≈øort to holde the greatnes and waight thereof, and yet one of the≈øe being perfect in that manner, are not ≈øo much worth as tho≈øe with tables: for that many times they haue too much thicknes vnderneath, which maketh the waight not to any profit, but rather hurt: which if it were whole and thin vnderneath‚ñ™ hauing outwardly all other perfectioÃÑs, it were as much worth as a Diamond, that hath a table being thicke with his whole depth, which is 46. duckets being of one Quilate: ≈øo that when you haue any of the≈øe you ≈øhall deale with them, as with the other, that is to con≈øider, what they may be worth, being of one Quilate, and make your reckoning, as with the others afore≈øaid.

div.head: The 90. Chapter. Of the oriental & old Emeralds, for that tho≈øe that are found in the I≈ølandes of the Spani≈øh Indies, are not yet tried nor re≈øolued vpon whether they be fine or not.
div.p:
THe old Iewellers ≈øay, that if a man can finde an Emerald perfect in al points, as in colour, clearenes, fa≈øhion, and thicknes, that ≈øuch an Emerald is worth 3. Diamonds, which according to our account ≈øhold be 120. duckets, and I bel√©eue verily that it is mo≈øt true, but as yet there was neuer any found, eyther little or great that had all tho≈øe perfections, there are ≈øome found that are perfect in colour and fa≈øhion, but of clearenes and cleanenes not one, for they haue alwaies ≈øome fattines within them like gr√©ene hearbs and ≈øuch like, wherefore to make our reckoning, wee will ≈øay, that an Emerauld of coÃÑmon ≈øort, e≈øtimation, and perfection, is worth 80. duckets, being of the bignes, as that hee may compare with a Diamond of one Quilate: for althogh it haue certaine gr√©ene hearbes within it, if they bee not too many it is neuerthele≈ø≈øe e≈øt√©emed perfect, hauing all the other perfections that it ≈øhould haue: therefore when you haue an Emerald to value whether it be vngrouÃÑd or a table, fir≈øt you mu≈øt con≈øider the greatnes‚ñ™ and what waight a Diamond ≈øhould bee that mu≈øt compare with it, then looke vppon the faults or goodnes that it hath, and con≈øidering well what ≈øuch an Emrauld ≈øhold be worth‚ñ™ being no greater than a Diamond of one Quilate, you mu≈øt make your account as with Rubies: which is, take the waight of the Diamond, whereunto you compare it, and multiplie that with as much more, and the production thereof, multiplie by the price that you haue e≈øt√©emed the one Quilate to be worth, and the production is the valew of ≈øuch an Emerauld, and in the ≈øame ≈øort ≈øhall you doe with all the Emeraulds you haue to valew, whether they be great or ≈ømall, good or bad, alwaies con≈øidering the faults or goodne≈ø≈øe it may haue, and after that e≈øteeme it, and ≈øet the price, and if there be half a Quilate or graines in the waight of the DiamoÃÑd you compare it vnto‚ñ™ then you mu≈øt make your account by halues and graines, as I ≈øaide before of Diamonds and Rubies. When you will valew any ≈øtones, you mu≈øt looke well vpon them, and con≈øider if it be a Diamond, of what water and fa≈øhion it is, if it hath all
the depth and more, if it be foule or haue anie other fault in the corners or in the ≈øquares, & what hurt or di≈øaduantage it bringeth to the ≈øtone, that you deceiue not your ≈øelfe in valuing the price it may be worth, beeing of one Quilate, thereby to make your reckoning as before: If it be a Rubie, marke well of what bignes it is, and what Diamond in waight it may be coÃÑpared vnto, & rate it alwaies at le≈ø≈øe greatnes, rather then at more, that you deceiue not your ≈øelfe, and con≈øider well what colour it hath: If there be any Ca≈ø ‚Ä¢ edonia, or vncleane≈ø≈øe, if it be thinne or haue any other fault therein, or any want in the ≈øquarenes, & what hinderance tho≈øe faultes may bee vnto the ≈øtone, in the price, perfection, and greatn ‚Ä¢ s of the Diamond wherunto you compare it, and looke you faile not herein, for if you do, you will cleane ouer ≈øhoote your ≈øelfe: likewi≈øe in ≈øetting the price what it may bee worth being ≈øo great, as to compare with a Diamond of one Quilate, thereby to make your reckoning of the waight, that it maie weigh more or le≈ø≈øe. What I haue ≈øaide of Rubies, you mu≈øt likewi≈øe vnder≈øtand of Emeraulds that are Orientale, all after one ≈øort and manner of reckoning. There are other red ≈øtones called E≈øpinelles, and of diuers other ≈øortes, whereof ≈øome are ≈øo perfect in their kinds, that they are like to Rubies, and this is to bee vnder≈øtood of the good and the be≈øt. There are others called E≈øpinelles da Rouca Noua, or new Rocket: ≈øome of them haue the colour of Rubies, others draw neere the colour of Iacinthes, and it is not knowne whether they be right E≈øpinelles or not: for the good Iewellers e≈øteeme them for no E≈øpinelles, but for Ruba≈ø≈øes, and Iacinthes, and ≈øo good that they are like to E≈øpinelles: wherfore the ≈øtone grinders & Iewellers ≈øay, that they are E≈øpinelles, becau≈øe they would bee better paid for the fa≈øhion, and therefore they doe poli≈øh them with E≈øpinell du≈øt or poli≈øhing. The≈øe E≈øpinelles in their poli≈øh are E≈øpinelles, but in colour Ruba≈ø≈øes, and Iacinthes, and there are manye Rubies, which to polli≈øh well, and grinde well, you had neede poli≈øh with the poli≈øh of E≈øpinelles. If there be an E≈øpinell of the old rocke, which in kind and qualitie is good, being perfect in all parts with a very good table, and were to bee compared with a Diamond of one Quilate, it would bee worth 40. duckets, but hauing any imperfections, euery maÃÑ may well con≈øider what hurt and abate they may doe in the price, and after the ≈øame rate make his account as hee doth in Rubies, the Ballaye≈øes are likewi≈øe ≈øold by waight, but not in that ≈øort as Diamonds and Rubies, but they are e≈øt√©emed according to the waight, that is the be≈øt ‚Ä¢ layes that may be found being of one Quilate, may be worth ten duckets, and hauing any faults‚ñ™ eyther in colour or other perfections, is of le≈ø≈øe valew, but beeing perfect as I ≈øaid alreadie, it is worth ten duckets, and two Quilates twentie duckets, of three Quilates thirtie duckets, and ≈øo after the rate as it is, ≈ømall or great‚ñ™ being of the waight it ≈øhould bee, and beeing imperfect, euery man of≈økill may well con≈øider what it is worth, being of one Quilate‚ñ™ & e≈øt√©eme it thereafter.

div.head: The 91. Chapter. Of Orientale Pearles.
div.p: THe Orientale Pearles are better then tho≈øe of the Spani≈øh Indies, and haue great difference in the price: for they are worth more and haue a better gla≈ø≈øe, being clearer, and fairer. Tho≈øe of the Spani≈øh Indies commonly beeing darker & deader of colour: yet there are ≈øome found in the Portingall Indies that are nothing inferiour to the Orientale Pearles, but they are very few: Now to valew them as they ≈øhuld be, I wil only ≈øet the good Pearles at a price. A Pearle that in all partes is perfect, both of water, gla≈ø≈øe and beautie without knobs, of forme very rouÃÑd or proportioned like a pearle without dents, being of one Quilate is worth a ducket, and after this rate I will make my reckoning, as I doe with Diamonds Rubies and Emeraulds, and if there be any faults in the water, clearenes and fa≈øhion, or that it hath any knobs or other defaults, it may well be con≈øidered what hurt it may bee vnto the ≈øale thereof, and according to the goodnes, or badnes valew the price therof: which hauing valewed, we mu≈øt ≈ø√©e what it weigheth, and then make the reckoning thereof, as with Diamonds, Rubies & Emeraulds, & if there be a whole ≈øtring or a chaine full of Pearles, you mu≈øt looke well vpon theÃÑ for where there are many, they are not all alike: the greate≈øt beeing the be≈øt, & the other after the rate, for the goodnes of the great wil beare the badnes of the ≈ømal: but if it be contrary, then the bargen is not very good. This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for in≈øtruction to ≈øuch as de≈øire to deale therewith, to haue alwaies in their memorie, and what herein is wanting for the better vnder≈øtanding and knowledge hereof, it may be ≈øupplied by true Iewellers and ≈øtone cutters that are ≈økilfull in this point, and with the≈øe in≈øtructions can ea≈øily help, ≈øo that a maÃÑ ≈øhall not need wholly to put his tru≈øt in tho≈øe, that for their owne profit will giue them but bad coun≈øell therein.

div.head: The 92. Chapter. Of ‚Ä¢ rta ‚Ä¢ ne ‚Ä¢ emorable thinges pa≈ø≈øed in India during my re≈øidence there
div.p:
IN the month of December, Anno, 158 ‚Ä¢ . there ariued in the towne and I≈øland of Ormus foure Engli≈øhmeÃÑ, which came from Aleppo in the couÃÑ trie of Suria, hauing ≈øayled out of England, and pa≈ø≈øed through the ≈øtraightes of Gibraltar, to Tripoli a towne and Hauen, lying on the ≈øea coa≈øt of Suria, where all the ≈øhippes di≈øcharge their wares, and marchandi≈øes, and frome thence are caryed by land vnto Alleppo, which is nyne dayes iourney. In Aleppo there are re≈øident diuers marchants and Factors of all Nations, as Italians, Frenchemen, Engli≈øhmeÃÑ, Armenians, Turkes & Mores, euerie man hauing his Religion apart, paying tribute vnto the great Turke. In that towne there is great trafficke, for that from thence, euerie yeare twy≈øe, there trauelleth two Ca ‚Ä¢ ylen, that is, companies of people and Camelles, which trauell vnto India, Per≈øia, Arabia, and all the countries bordering on the ≈øame and deale in all ≈øorts of marchandi≈øe, both to and from tho≈øe Countries, as I in an other place haue alreadie declared. Three of the ≈øaid Engli≈øhmen afore≈øaide were ≈øent by the Companie of Engli≈øhmen, that are re≈øident in Aleppo, to ≈øee if in Ormus they might keepe any Factors, and ≈øo trafficke in that place, like as al≈øo the Italians doe, that is to ≈øay, the Venetians, which in Ormus, Goa and Malacca haue their Factors, and trafficke there, as well for ≈øtones and pearles, as for other wares and ≈øpices of tho≈øe countries, which from thence are caryed ouer land into Ve
‚Ä¢ e. One of the≈øe Engli≈øhmen had beene „Äà‚óä„Äâ before in the ≈øaid towne of Ormus, and there had taken good information of the trade, and vpon his adui≈øe and aduerti≈øement, the other were as then come thether with him, bringing great ≈øtore of marchandi≈øes with them, as Clothes, Saffron, all kindes of drinking gla≈ø≈øes, and Haberda≈øhers wares, as looking gla≈ø≈øes, kniues, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe, and to conclude, brought with them all kinde of ≈ømall wares that may be deui≈øed. And although tho≈øe wares amounted vnto great ≈øummes of money, notwith≈øtaÃÑding it was but onlie a ≈øhadow or colour, thereby to giue no occa≈øion to be mi≈øtru≈øted, or ≈øeen into: for that their principall intent was to buy great quantities of precious Stones, as Diamantes, Pearles, Rubies, &c. to the which ende they brought with them a great ≈øumme of money and Gold, and that verie ≈øecretly, not to be deceyued or robbed thereof, or to runne into anie danger for the ≈øame. They being thus aryued in Ormus, hyred a Shop, and began to ≈øell their wares: which the Italians perceyuing, who≈øe Factors continue there (as I ≈øayd before) and fearing that tho≈øe Engli≈øhmen, finding good vent for their commodities in that place wold be re≈øident therein, and ≈øo daylie increa≈øe, which would be no ≈ømall lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance vnto them, did pre≈øently inuent all the ≈øubtile meanes they could, to hinder them: and to that end they went vnto the Captaine of Ormus, as then called Don Gon≈øalo de Mene≈øes, telling him that there were certaine Engli≈øhmen come into Ormus ‚ñ™ that were ≈øent only to ≈øpy the Country, and ≈øaid further, that they were Heretickes: and therefore they ≈øayd it was conuenient they ≈øhuld not be ≈øuffered ≈øo to depart, without b√©eing examined, and puni≈øhed as enimies, to the example of others. The Captaine being a friend vnto the Engli≈øhmen, by rea≈øon that one of them which had bene there before, had giuen him certaine pre≈øents, would not be per≈øwaded to trouble them, but ≈øhipped them with all their wares in a Shippe that was to ≈øayle for Goa, and ≈øent them to the Viceroy, that he might examine and trye them, as hee thought good: where when they were aryued, they were ca≈øt into pri≈øon, and fir≈øt examined whether they were good Chri≈øtians or no‚ñ™ and becau≈øe they could ≈øpeake but bad Portugale, onlie two of them ≈øpake good Dutche, as hauing bene certaine yeares in the lowe Countries, and there traffiqued. There was a Dutch Ie≈øuite borne in the towne of B ‚Ä¢ gges in Flaunders, that had bin re≈øident in the Indies for the ≈øpace of thirty yeares, ≈øent vnto them, to vndermine and examine them: wherein they behaued them≈øelues ≈øo wel, that they were holden & e≈øteemd for good and Catholick Romi≈øh Chri≈øtians: yet ≈øtill ≈øu≈øpected, becau≈øe they were ≈øtrangers, ≈øpecially Engli≈øhmen. The Ie≈øuites ≈øtil told them that they ≈øhuld be ≈øent pri≈øoners into Portingal, wi≈øhing them to leaue off their trade of marchandi≈øe & to become Ie≈øuites, promi≈øing them thereby to defend them from all trouble: the cau≈øe why they ≈øaid ≈øo, and per≈øwaded them in that earne≈øt maÃÑner was, for that the Dutch Ie≈øuite had ≈øecretlie bene
aduerti≈øed of great ≈øummes of money which they had about them, and ≈øought to get the ≈øame into their fingers, for that the fir≈øt vowe and promi≈øe they make at their entrance into their order, is, to procure the welfare of their ≈øaid order, by what means ≈øoeuer it be, but although the Engli≈øhmen denyed them, and refu≈øed the order, ≈øaying, that they were vnfit for ≈øuch places, neuerthele≈ø≈øe they proc√©ed ≈øo farre that one of them, being a painter, (that came with the other thr√©e for company, to ≈ø√©e the countries, and to ≈ø√©eke his fortune, and was not ≈øent thether by the Engli≈øh marchants) partly for feare, and partlie for want of meanes to relieue him≈øelfe, promi≈øed them to become a Ie≈øuite: and although they knew and well perceiued he was not any of tho≈øe that had the trea≈øure, yet becau≈øe he was a Painter, whereof they are but few in India, and that they had great n√©ed of him to paint their church, which otherwi≈øe would co≈øt them great charges, to bring one from Portingal, they were very glad thereof, hoping in time to get the re≈øt of them wt all their money into their fellow≈øhip: ≈øo yt to conclude, they made this Painter a Ie≈øuite, where he continued certain daies, giuing him good ≈øtore of worke to doe, and entertayning him with all the fauour and friend≈øhip they could deui≈øe, and all to win the re≈øt, to be a pray for them: but the other thr√©e continued ≈øtil in pri≈øon, being in great feare, becau≈øe they vnder≈øtood no man that came to them, nor anie man almo≈øt knew what they ≈øaid: till in the end it was told them that certaine Dutch men dwelt in the Archbi≈øhops hou≈øe, & coun≈øell giuen them to ≈øend vnto them, whereat they much reioiced, and ≈øent to me and an other Dutch man, de≈øiring vs once to come and ≈øpeake with them, which we pre≈øentlie did, and they with teares in their eyes made complaint vnto vs of their hard v≈øage, ≈øhewing vs froÃÑ point to point (as it is ≈øaid before) why they were come into the countrie, with all de≈øiring vs for Gods cau≈øe, if we might by any means, to helpe them, that they might be ≈øet at liberty vpon Sureties, being readie to indure what Iu≈øtice ≈øhould ordaine for them, ≈øaying, that if it were found contrarie, and that they were other then trauelling marchants, and ≈øought to find out further benefite by their wares, they would be content to be puni≈øhed. With that wee departed from them promi≈øing them to do our be≈øt: and in the ende we obtained ≈øo much of the Archbi≈øhoppe, that he went vnto the Vice-roy to delyuer our petition, and per≈øwaded him ≈øo well, that hee was content to ≈øet them at libertie, and that their goods ≈øhuld be deliuered vnto them again, vpon condition they ≈øhould put in ≈øureties for 2000. Pardawes, not to depart the countrie before other order ≈øhould bee taken with them. Therupon they pre≈øently found a Citizen of the towne, yt was their ≈øuretie for 2000. Pardawes, where they paide him in hand 1300. Pardawes, and becau≈øe they ≈øay they had no more ready monie, he gaue them credite, ≈ø√©eing what ≈øtore of marchandi≈øe they had, whereby at all times if n√©ede were, hee might bee ≈øati≈øfied: and by that meanes they were deliuered out of pri≈øon, and hyred them ≈øelues a hou≈øe, and began to ≈øet open ≈øhoppe: So that they vttered much ware, and were pre≈øently well knowne among all the Marchants, becau≈øe they alwaies re≈øpected Gentlemen, ≈øpecially ≈øuch as brought their wares ≈øhewing great curte≈øie and honor vnto them, whereby they wonne much credite, and were beloued of all men, ≈øo that euerie man fauoured them‚ñ™ and was willing to doe them plea≈øure. To vs they ≈øhewed great friend≈øhip, for who≈øe ≈øake, the Archbi≈øhop fauoured them much, and ≈øhewed them verie good countenance, which they knew wel how to increa≈øe, by offering him many pre≈øents, although hee would not receiue them, neither would euer take gift or pre≈øent at any mans hands. Likewi≈øe they behaued them≈øelues verie Catholikely and verie deuoute, euerie day hearing Ma≈ø≈øe with Beades in their hands, ≈øo that they fel into ≈øo great fauour, that no man caried an euill eye, no nor an euill thought towards them. Which liked not the Ie≈øuites, becau≈øe it hindered them from that they hoped for, ≈øo that they cea≈øed not ≈øtill by this Dutch Ie≈øuite to put them in feare, that they ≈øhould bee ≈øent into Portingall to the King, coun≈øelling them to y√©eld them ≈øelues Ie≈øuits into their Cloy≈øter, which if they did, he ≈øaid they would defend them from all in troubles, ≈øaying further, that he coun≈øelled them therein as friend, and one that knew for certaine that it was ≈øo determined by the Viceroyes priuie Coun≈øell: which to effect he ≈øaide they ≈øtayed but for ≈øhipping that ≈øhould ≈øayle for Portingall, with diuers other per≈øwa≈øions, to put them in ≈øome feare, & ≈øo to effect their purpo≈øe. The Engli≈øh men to the contrarie, dur≈øt not ≈øay any thing to them‚ñ™ but an≈øwered, that as yet they would ≈øtay a while, and con≈øider thereof, thereby putting the Ie≈øuites in good comfort, as one among them,Of this ‚Ä¢ Newbery‚ñ™ you may read more in M. Hackluy ‚Ä¢ es boke of Engl ‚Ä¢ ≈øhe voyages. being the principal of them (called Io ‚Ä¢ n Nuberye) complained vnto me often times, ≈øaying hee knew not what to ≈øay or thinke therein, or which way he might be rid of tho≈øe troubles: but in the ende they determined with them≈øelues, to depart from thence, and ≈øecretly by
meanes of contrarie friends, they imployed their money in precious ≈øtones, which the better to effect, one of them was a Ieweller, and for the ≈øame purpo≈øe came with them. Which being concluded among them, they dur≈øt not make knowne to any man, neither did they credite vs ≈øo much, as to ≈øhewe vs their minds therein, although they tolde vs all what≈øoeuer they knew. Which beeing all filled with Pepper, they ≈øhut the holes of tho≈øe places verie clo≈øe, with Ocam and Pitch, and ≈øo are marked with numbers how many there are, and vpon ech place his waight of Peper. The≈øe two Oorloppes being thus laden, there is left a place aboute the maine Ma≈øt to be≈øtow water, wine, woode and other nece≈ø≈øaries for the ≈øhippe, which are dayly v≈øed. In the thirde Oorlop and on both ≈øides therof, there are diuers places ≈øeuerally made that belong vnto the Officers of the ≈øhippe, as the Captaine, Ma≈øter, Pilot, Factor, Pur≈øer &c. and of all the re≈øt of the Saylors that are allowed places: which they ≈øell or let out vnto the Marchants, to lade goods therein, whereof they make good profite. Vpon the ≈øame Oorlop from the Ma≈øt vnto the ≈øterne, are the places wher they put their Poulder, Bi≈øket‚ñ™ Sayles clothes and other proui≈øions for the ≈øhip. The other Oorlopes aboue the≈øe are laden by the Marchants, with all ≈øorts of wares, which are in Che≈øtes, Fattes, Balles, and Packes, and are placed in this ≈øort, that is to ≈øay. As ≈øoone as the Pepper is laden, there is pre≈øently ≈øent into the ≈øhippe two waiters, and one that ≈øtoweth the goodes (as a Porter) on the Kings behalfe: and he hath ten or twelue Porters vnder him, that mu≈øt onely lade and ≈øtow the goodes in the ≈øhippe, the Ma≈øter nor any other not once hauing any thing to doe with it, ≈øauing onely the chiefe Bote≈øwaine‚ñ™ who is to looke vnto it, and yet commaundeth nothing. No goods may bee laden what≈øoeuer, or how ≈ømall ≈øo euer they bee, but they mu≈øt bee Regi≈øtred in the Kinges bookes, and they mu≈øt bring a Billet from the Veador da Fa ‚Ä¢ enda, that is to ≈øaye, the
Surueighor of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, being chief Officer for the King, wherein mu≈øt be certified euerie kind of ware by peece meale, which they lade together with ye name of the ≈øhip, wherein it is to be laden, for without that Certi ‚Ä¢ i
‚Ä¢ at ‚ñ™ the ≈øtowers and Porters will not take it in: and although you haue your Billet, yet mu≈øt you bribe the waiters, before you can get it abord the ≈øhippe, and ≈øome thing mu≈øt be giuen likewi≈øe to the porters be≈øides their duties, if you de≈øire to ≈øtow your goods well, otherwi≈øe they will let it ≈øtand: and he that giueth mo≈øt hath the be≈øt place in the ≈øhippe: yea and they ≈øtow the ≈øhip ≈øo mi≈øerablie full, that there is not a hole or an emptie place to be found, but it is full ≈øtuffed: and for all their profit, it is often times ≈øeene, that the chief Porter, that doth onlie command and looke ouer the re≈øt, getteth for his part in bribes for ≈øtowage of a ≈øhip, ≈øometimes ≈øeuen or 800 Dukats, and the waiters a≈ømuch, and all this onlie by gifts. Tho≈øe offices are giuen by fauor of the Viceroy and the Ve ‚Ä¢ dor de Falenda ‚ñ™ which is the cau≈øe that the ≈øhips are often times laden ≈øo ful that they are in manner ready to ≈øinke: ≈øo that a man would think it were impo≈ø≈øible for them either to row or ≈øtirre: becau≈øe ye ≈øailers & officers of the ≈øhips haue nothing to doe therewith, vntill the la≈øt hour that it ≈øetteth ≈øayl & theÃÑ it is deliuered into their handes, and the waiters and porters goe their waies, leauing the ≈øhip ful in euery place, euen to the vppermo≈øt Oarlop, where there ≈øtandeth commonlie 7 or 8 che≈øtes, one aboue the other, both in the ≈øterne and fore≈øhippe, vpon the cables, in the foreca≈øtell, in the ≈øtirrige, and in euery place, which are all ful of great pots, fattes, che≈øts, hennes cages, and ≈øuch like, ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth rather a Labyrinth or a Maze, then a ≈øhip: and ≈øo they commit them≈øelues to the grace of God and ≈øet ≈øayle: and often times it falleth out, that of „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øaylers which are aboue the ≈øhip (as it did in our ≈øhip) not aboue „Äà‚óä„Äâ of them could tell how to ≈øt√©ere or handle the R ‚Ä¢ ther: & be≈øides that, mo≈øt of them were neuer at ≈øea before, but by fauor get their places, as all the re≈øt doe, ≈øo that when occa≈øion ≈øerueth, being at ≈øea, they ≈øtand looking one vpon an other, doing nothing but cry Mi≈øericordia, and our Lady helpe vs.

In Cochiin there are a great number of boa ‚Ä¢ es called Tones, that are cut out of one peece of wood, and yet ≈øome of them are ≈øo great, that a man may lade 20 pipes of water in them. The≈øe they carrie abord ye ≈øhips, that lie at the lea≈øt a mile within the ≈øea, and there they make price with them for a ≈ømall ≈øumme of money, and then they goe and fill the pipes them≈øelues, with pots which they haue for the purpo≈øe, and it is a great commoditie vnto them. This water is brought out of ye riuer of Cochin called Manga ‚Ä¢ e,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ is verie good. Touching the towne and country of Cochin, I haue already declared in the de≈øcription of the Coa≈øt of Malabar ‚ñ™ ≈øo that this ≈øhall ≈øuffice to ≈øhew you what the countrie of India is: and now I will ≈øhew vnto you the manner that is v≈øed in the ≈øhips when they ≈øayle home againe: which in part I haue alreadie touched, as al≈øo our departure and voyage from India to Li ‚Ä¢ bon.

div.head: The 93. Chapter. Of my voyage and departure from India to Portingale
div.p:
THe fir≈øt of Ian. 1580, 1580 the Santa Ma ‚Ä¢ ia ≈øet ≈øayle, and becau≈øe it was one of the olde≈øt ≈øhippes, it was fir≈øt di≈øpatched away, by rea≈øoÃÑ that the ≈øooner they depart from Cochin ‚ñ™ they come in better time to the Cape de Bona Speranza, and the later they come thether, the more ≈øtorms & foule wether they haue, becau≈øe as theÃÑ the Sunne goeth further into the North, and leaueth the South parts. Therefore commonly they let the be≈øt and ≈øtroÃÑge≈øt ≈øhippes goe la≈øt, becau≈øe they are be≈øt able to hold out: and in the Iland of S. Helena they ≈øtay one for the other vntill the 25. day of May, & no longer, which is the time appointed by the king, and ≈øo goe in company together vnto Portingale, for from India vnto the Iland of S. Helena they need not keepe company, becau≈øe all that way they feare no Rouers, and from thence they haue all their Cannon ≈øhot pulled in, the better to pa≈ø≈øe the foule wether at the cape de bona Speranza. The 6 of Ianuary, the ≈øhip called our Ladie de Con≈øepcao ≈øet ≈øayle, the 10 of the ≈øame, the Admirall called S. Chri≈øtopher: the 12 the S. Anthony: the 15 the S. Thomas, which was the greate≈øt and the be≈øt ≈øhippe in all the Fleet, and riche≈øt of lading: and the
‚Ä¢ 0 of the ≈øame Moneth, wee ≈øet ≈øayle, in our ≈øhip called the Santa Crus, being the la≈øt, where in was about 20 ‚Ä¢
men of all ≈øorts, as ‚Ä¢ aylers, ≈øoldiers and ≈ølaues: for from India there goe but few ≈øoldiers without the Viceroyes pa≈ø≈øeport, by vertue whereof they goe to pre≈øent their ≈øeruices, and to fetch their payes and duties for the ≈øame. And this they doe after they haue ≈øerued in India ≈øome yeares, & al≈øo when they haue abilitie to pa≈ø≈øe ouer:
for when they are poore, and haue no helpe, they mu≈øt ≈øtay in I ‚Ä¢ dia, euen for nece≈ø≈øities ≈øake, becau≈øe they haue no means to procure their pa≈ø≈øage, ≈øo that manie of them are con≈øtrayned to tarrie there, and to marrie with ‚Ä¢ ores and Indian women, the better to maintain them≈øelues although it be with mi≈øerie enough. For the charges of a mans voiage out of I ‚Ä¢ dia into Portin ‚Ä¢ al, is at the l ‚Ä¢ a≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 0 Pardawes, and that onlie for meate and drinke, which a poore ≈øoldier c ‚Ä¢ n hardly compa≈ø≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe he can procure ≈øome gentleman, Captaine, or ≈øome wealthy man in office‚ñ™ to be ‚Ä¢ auorable vnto him, in helping him to performe his iourney. For in the voyages homewards the king giueth nothing to the ≈øoldiers and pa≈ø≈øingers, but free pa≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ge for him ≈øelf and a che≈øt of ‚Ä¢ . ≈øpannes high and broad and ‚Ä¢ in length: and that after they haue bene ‚Ä¢ yeares in India, & for that Che≈øt they pay neither fraught nor cu≈øtome: they likewi≈øe haue a Che≈øt in the roomage, free of fraight, for which they pay cu≈øtome: and this they may ≈øell in India to any Marchant, as they commonlie doe, and is worth vnto them at the lea≈øt, 40 or 5 ‚Ä¢
Pardawes. The≈øe places they call liberties, and hee that buyeth them, regi≈øtreth them in the name of him that he buyeth them of, to the end that in Portingale they may enioy the ≈øame libertie and priuiledge: all the ≈øaylers and Officers al≈øo of the ≈øhippes that ≈øayl in them froÃÑ Portin ‚Ä¢ al ‚ñ™ haue likewi≈øe be≈øides their places in the ≈øhips, the forage of ≈øuch a che≈øt allowed them, full of cu≈øtome and fraight. All the≈øe thinges are very ≈øharply looked vnto: for although the ≈øhips and goods are farmed, yet when they ariue at Lisbon ‚ñ™ all the che≈øts are brought into the Indian hou≈øe, and there vi≈øited, to ≈øee if any goods be in them, that is forbidden to be brought out of India, as pepper‚ñ™ Anill, or Indigo, and other ≈øuch wares as are farmed of the king: & if any be found, it is pre≈øently forfaited, and all the wares that are in ≈øuch che≈øts are likewi≈øe valued, ≈øo that if they amount vnto more then the value of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Milreyes, they mu≈øt pay cu≈øtome for the ouerplus, which in the tyme of the kings of Portingale was not v≈øed: for then they were accu≈øtomed to carrie their che≈øtes home, and to ≈øhew them only to the waiters: and although the poore ≈øaylers and Officers doe much compl ‚Ä¢ yne for the lo≈ø≈øe & breaking of their liberties, yet can they not be heard: and thus there come but few Soldiers out of „Äà‚óä„Äâ , for the cau≈øes afore≈øayd: for I cert ‚Ä¢ nlie beleeue that of 15 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Soldiers and more yt yearelie are ≈øent thether out of Portingal, there returneth not a hundreth again, ≈øome ‚Ä¢ ying there in the countrie, others beeing ca≈øt away, and ≈ølayne by diuers occa≈øions, and the re≈øt by pouertie not able to returne againe: and ≈øo again≈øt their willes are forced to ≈øtay in the Countrie. If anie of them doe chance to come, it is with ≈øome Viceroy, Captaine, or other Gentleman, or per≈øon, that hath borne office or authoritie: and when ≈øuch men come ouer, they alwaies take ≈øome Soldiers with them, to whome they giue meate and drinke, and yet are ≈øuch as are of their acquaintaÃÑce, and that long before had bene at their commandements: which they doe for the mo≈øt part vpon a certaine pryde and vaine glorie: and in this ≈øort there may yearelie come 20 or 3 ‚Ä¢
Soldiers ouer in each Shippe, which haue their Slaues and Blacke Mores with them: ≈øo that they come cleane and ≈øweet home, both for Linnen and other thinges, becau≈øe Linnen in India is verie good cheap: and the Shippes when they returne home, are cleaner then when they ≈øet out of Portingale, becau≈øe they haue fewer men in them, and ≈øuch as come out of India, bring all their nece≈ø≈øaries with them, be≈øides that the ≈øhippe is verie ≈øweete, by rea≈øon of the ≈øpice that is laden in it.

The partition of the ≈øhip is in this manner: the Pilot hath his Cabbin aboue in the hinder part of the ≈øhippe, on the right ≈øide, where he hath two or thr√©e roomes, and neuer commeth vnder hatches, nor downe into the fore≈øhip but ≈øtandeth only and commaundeth the Ma≈øter of the ≈øhip to hoi≈øe or let fall the ≈øailes, and to looke vnto his cour≈øe, how they ≈øhall ≈øteere to take the height of the ≈øunne & euery day to write and marke what pa≈ø≈øeth and how they ≈øaile, with what tokens, winde and weather they haue euerie day: the Ma≈øter hath his Cabin in the ≈øame place, behind the Pilotes Cabins, on the left hand, with as manie places and roomes as the Pylot hath, where he ≈øtandeth and commandeth, with a ≈øiluer whi≈øtle‚ñ™ & looketh onlie to the Mayne Ma≈øte and her Sayles, and ≈øo backwards: yet he hath the care of all the Shippe, and what≈øoeuer belongeth to it, and commandeth all thinges, as to make & mend the ≈øayls, which he cutteth out, & the ≈øaylers ≈øow them: he looketh al≈øo if there be any fault in the ≈øhippe, and cau≈øeth it to be mended, & as need requireth, to draw their Cannon in, and againe to put it out. If hee wanteth any thing, as cloth for ≈øailes, nailes, ropes, or any ≈øuch like thinges as are needful, ≈øhe mu≈øt a≈øke them of the Factor and pur≈øer of the ≈øhippe, which pre≈øently are deliuered vnto him, with a note of his hand in the booke to be accountable for it. The chiefe Bote≈øon hath his Cabbin in the foreca≈øtle,
and hath commandement and gouernement ouer the Fouke ma≈øt, and the fore ≈øayles: h√©e hath al≈øo a ≈øiluer whi≈øtle like the ma≈øter, and taketh care for all thinges belonging to the Fouke ma≈øte, and for the fa≈øt binding of the ankers. The Guardian or quarterma≈øter hath his Cabbin clo≈øe by the great ma≈øt outward on the left hand, for on the right hand ≈øtandeth the ≈øcullerie and kitchin, where they dre≈ø≈øe their meat, he weareth a ≈øiluer whi≈øtle and hath charge to ≈ø√©e the ≈øwabers pumpe to make the ≈øhip cleane, to looke to the ropes & cau≈øe them to bee mended, and to the boate which he commonly ruleth: the Gunner hath his Cabbin inward from the ma≈øt, hard by the Ruther vnder the fir≈øt Oorlope, and mu≈øt alwaies ≈øit by the maine ma≈øt looking vppon the ma≈øter both night and day, that as the Ma≈øter whi≈øtleth to will the Gunners to draw in their p√©eces, or to thru≈øt them out, he may b√©e readie ≈øo to doe: he likewi≈øe taketh ca ‚Ä¢ e for the peeces and the thinges belonging to them: when they haue cau≈øe to v≈øe them, the vnder Pilot doth nothing but helpe the chiefe Pilot & watch his quarter: they haue likewi≈øe two or three of the be≈øt ≈øaylers, that doe nothing els but command in the Pilots roome wheÃÑ he ≈øl√©epeth. The ≈øaylers haue mo≈øt of their Cabins in the foreca≈øtle, and there abouts, & the Gunners behinde by the ma≈øter Gunner, vnder the vpper decke, & doe nothing els but with their in≈øtruments put the great peeces forth, or draw them in as they are coÃÑ manded, the ≈øwabers mu≈øt doe all what≈øoeuer they are bidden to doe by the officers, but neuer touch the Ruther: for the ≈øaylers doe only ≈øt√©ere and rule the ≈øhip when n√©ed requireth, but not the pumpe, neyther doe they hoy≈øe vp the maine ≈øayle, for the ≈øouldiers and ≈ølaues v≈øe to doe that, the ≈øwabers pumpe, & the Carpenter doth ≈øuch worke as is to bee done, the Cooper in like ≈øort and the Calker, ≈øo that if the ≈øhippe were ≈øincking, not any of them will doe more than belongeth to his charge, and what further is to bee done, they will ≈øtand ≈øtill & looke vppon it: the Captaine hath the Gallerie and the Cabbin behind, he commandeth onely ouer the ≈øouldiers, & ≈øuch as watch by night, the Pilot, Ma≈øter, and the Bote≈øon, are ≈øerued in very good ≈øorte with their ≈øiluer lampes, beakers, cups, & bowles, euery man by him≈øelfe, and are waited on by their ≈ølaues and ≈øeruants, and haue enough of euery thing, but the other ≈øaylers, & ≈øwabers haue not ≈øuch ≈øtore, but indure more hardnes, for euery man mu≈øt prouide for him≈øelfe, as we told you before. Now you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that in their ≈øhips there is no aueridge: for that when there happeneth any lo≈ø≈øe, or that any goods are throwne ouer board, h√©e ≈øtandeth to the lo≈ø≈øe that oweth the goods, without any more accounts, and that commonly falleth out vpon the poore ≈øwabers, for they v≈øually haue their che≈øtes ≈øtanding vppon the hatches‚ñ™ becau≈øe they haue nothing to giue vnto the Porters that they might haue a good place for them, as the others of greater abilitie v≈øe to doe, and when any ≈øtorme or hurt chanceth, than they throw the thinges ouerboard that fir≈øt comes to hand, without re≈øpect of per≈øons ‚Ä¢ nye aueridge to bee made.

In this ≈øort ≈øetting ≈øaile, we held our cour≈øe ≈øouth ≈øouth Ea≈øt for the ≈øpace of 150. miles, till we came to the Equinoctiall line, & from thence till we were vnder ≈øeauen degr√©es in the ≈øame cour≈øe, and from thence ≈øouth We≈øt and by We≈øt, vnto the cape de Bona Speranza, which way was neuer v≈øed before that time, for they v≈øed to ≈øaile from Cochiin ≈øouth we≈øt, and ≈øouth we≈øt and by South, betw√©ene the I≈ølands of Maldiua, and a thou≈øand other I≈ølands and ≈øands, vnto the Iland of Saint Laurence, and ≈øo to the cape: but after that the Pilot had lo≈øt the Saint Iames vpon the ≈øhallowes of India, and e≈øcaped aliue (and was now Pilot in the Saint Thomas, b√©eing the be≈øt ≈øhippe in all our Fl√©ete) hee had the fore Voyage, and kept aloofe two or thr√©e hundred miles out into the Sea, cleane from all I≈ølandes, ≈øandes, or cliffes: ≈øaying that the ca≈øting away of ≈øo many ≈øhips (whereof no newes or tidinges could euer be heard) was, that they were ca≈øt away vpon the ≈øands, euen as it chanced vnto him, and to auoide the dangers thereof, as al≈øo to winne the fauour of the King and the officers of the Admiraltie, he was the fir≈øt that tooke vpon him to di≈øcouer that way, with the ≈øhip wherein my Lord the Archbi≈øhop ≈øayled, and is almo≈øt the ≈øame way that the ≈øhippes that come from Malacca ‚ñ™ do hold when they ≈øaile to Portingall, where they ≈ø√©e neither Ilands nor Sandes, nor any other thing but onelie the plaine ≈øea, & ≈øo hee came into Portingale, certifying the Admiraltie of that new way, and although hee was ca≈øt in pri≈øon for the ≈øame cau≈øe, yet by fauor he was pre≈øently relea≈øed, and the Admiraltie perceauing it to be ≈øo great a danger for the ≈øhips to ≈øaile amoÃÑg≈øt the I≈ølands and Sands, (which they thought to b√©e the chiefe cau≈øe of the lo≈ø≈øe of ≈øo manie ≈øhips) haue expre≈øly commanded that the Pilots ≈øhould v≈øe that new di≈øcouered way, according to the ≈øaide Pilots information, therby to auoide all danger: but that is not the cau≈øe of their ca≈øting away, although many times they are the means of much mi≈øchiefe: but the chiefe rea≈øon is the vnrea≈øonable lading, and charging of the ≈øhips, the vn≈økilfull
≈øeamen, and the ≈ølacke vi≈øiting or ≈øearching of the ≈øhips, to ≈øee if they bee fit to ≈øayle, and haue all thinges that they want.

By the≈øe and ≈øuch like meanes the ≈øhips are dayly lo≈øt, as in other places by examples and true witne≈ø≈øes I haue already declared, and as the ≈øame Pilot that fir≈øt founde this new way, did well approue and verifie to b√©e true, in the Saint Thomas, that the Sands or I≈ølands did him no hurt, but onely the ouerlading of her, wherewith the ≈øhip was by the Cape bur≈øt in p√©eces, as hereafter I will ≈øhew. Notwith≈øtanding this way is not therefore to be di≈øliked, although it bee ≈øomewhat further about, but it is a very good way and wholly out of all danger of Sandes and I≈ølandes, whereby they doe auoid the I≈øland of Maldiua, with other droughtes and ≈øands about the ≈øame.
