Thomas, as being in the Iland of S. Helena, as we were afterwards aduerti≈øed.

The 15. of April we had an other great calme, which continued till the 17 day, and taking the hight of the Sunne, we found our ≈øelues to be vnder 37 degrees, to the great admiration of al the company, for that being (as I ≈øaid) vnder 35 degrees, and hauing ≈øayled for the ≈øpace of 5 dayes with ≈øo great a wind and ≈øtormy weather towards Mo≈øambique, we ≈øhould rather by al mens rea≈øon, haue le≈ø≈øened our degrees, & by e≈øtimation wee made account to haue bene vnder 30 or 32 degrees at the highe≈øt: but the cau≈øe why our ≈øhippe went backward in that ≈øort again≈øt wind and weather towards the Cape, thinking wee made towards Mo≈øambique, was by the water, which in tho≈øe countries carieth with a verie ≈øtrong ≈øtreame towards the cape, as the Pylot tould vs he had proued at other times: yet he thought not that the water had runne with ≈øo great a ≈øtreame, as now by experience he found it did: ≈øo as it ≈ø√©emed that God miraculou≈ølie again≈øt all mans rea≈øon and iudgement, and all the force of wind and ≈øtormes would haue vs pa≈ø≈øe the Cape, wheÃÑ we were lea≈øt in hope thereof: whereby we may plainelie perceiue that all mens actions without the hand of God, are of no moment. The ≈øame day againe we ≈øaw gr√©ene water, and the birdes called Mangas de Velludo, or veluet ≈øl√©eues, which are certain ≈øignes of the cape de bona Speranza, which put vs once againe in hope to pa≈ø≈øe it: and about euening a ≈øwallow flew into our ≈øhippe, wherat they much reioiced, ≈øaying that it was a ≈øign and fore≈øhowing, that our Lady had ≈øent the Swallow on bord to comfort vs, and that we ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe the Cape: wherewith they agreed once againe to proue if we could pa≈ø≈øe it, ≈ø√©eing we had ≈øuch ≈øignes and tokens to put vs in good comfort, that God would help vs. This being concluded, we ≈øung the Letany, with Ora pro nobis, and gaue many almes, with promi≈øes of pilgrimages and vi≈øitations, and ≈øuch like things, which was our dayly worke. With that the ≈øaylers & others began to take courage, and to be lu≈øtie, euery man willinglie doing his office, offering rather to lo≈øe life and welfare in aduenturing to pa≈ø≈øe the Cape, then with full a≈ø≈øurance of their ≈øafetie to returne vnto Mo≈øambique: we had as then great waues, and very bigge water in the ≈øea, which left vs not till wee came to the other ≈øide of the Cape.

The 18 of Aprill we fell againe into the wind, with as great ≈øtormes and foule weather as euer we had before, ≈øo that we thought verily we ≈øhould haue bene ca≈øt away: for that at euerie minute the ≈øea couered our ≈øhip with water, & to lighten her, we ca≈øt diuers che≈øtes, and much Cinamon, with other thinges, that came fir≈øt to hand, ouer bord, wherewith euerie man made account to die, and began to confe≈ø≈øe them≈øelues, and to a≈øke each other forgiuenes, thinking without more hope, that our la≈øt day was come. This ≈øtorme continued in this ≈øort, at the lea≈øt, for the ≈øpace of 24 houres: in the mean time great almes were giuen in our ≈øhippe to many Virgin Maries, and other Saints, with great deuotion & promi≈øe of other wonderfull things when they came to land: at the la≈øt God comforted vs, and ≈øent vs better weather for that the 19 of A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ill the wether began to cle√©ere vp, and therewith we were in better comfort‚ñ™

The 20. of Aprill we tooke the hight of the Sunne, and found it to be
‚Ä¢ 6 degr√©es: and againe we ≈øaw greene water, and ≈øome birds which they call Alcatraces, and many Seawolues, which they hold for certain ≈øignes of the cape de Bona SperaÃÑza, & as we thought were hard by the land‚ñ™ but yet ≈øaw none: the ≈øame day we had the wind ≈øomewhat fuller,
and were in great hope to pa≈ø≈øe the Cape, ≈øo that the men began to be in better comfort, by rea≈øon of the ≈øignes we haue ≈øeene. All that day we ≈øaw greene water, till the 22 of Apr. vpon which day twice, and in the night following, we ca≈øt out the Lead, and found no ground, which is a good ≈øigne that wee had pa≈ø≈øed the Cape called das Agulhas, or the cape of needles, which lieth vnder 35 degrees, and is about 20 miles from the Cape de bona Speranza, which lieth vnder 34 degr√©es & a half. And becau≈øe that about this cape Das Agulhas, there is ground found, at the lea≈øt 30 or 40 miles from the land, we knew wee were pa≈øt it: as al≈øo by the colour of the water, and the birds, which are alwaies found in tho≈øe countries: and the better to a≈ø≈øure vs thereof, the great & high ≈øea left vs, that had ≈øo long tormented vs, and then we found a ≈ømoother water, much differing from the former: ≈øo that as theÃÑ we ≈øeemed to be come out of hell into Paradice, with ≈øo great ioy, that we thought we were within the ≈øight of ≈øome hauen, and withall had a good winde, though ≈øomewhat cold.

The 23 of Aprill we pa≈ø≈øed the Cape de Bona Speranza, with a great and generall gladnes, it being as then 3 months and three dayes after we ≈øet ≈øayle from Cochiin, not once ≈øeeing any land or ≈øand at all, but onelie the≈øe a≈ø≈øured tokens of the ≈øaid Cape, which happened very ≈øeldome: for that the pilots doe alwaies v≈øe what meanes they can to ≈øee the cape, and to know the land, thereby to know certainlie that they are pa≈øt it: for then their degrees mu≈øt le≈ø≈øen, and there they may as ≈øoone make towards Mo≈øambique, as to the Iland of S. Helena: for although they can well perceiue it by ye water, yet is it nece≈ø≈øary for them to ≈øee the land, the better to ≈øet their cour≈øe vnto S. Helena, wherein they mu≈øt alwaies k√©epe on the left hand: otherwi≈øe it were impo≈ø≈øible for them to come at it, if they leaue that cour≈øe: for if they once pa≈ø≈øe it, they can not come to it again, becau≈øe there bloweth continually but one kind of wind, which is South ea≈øt: and thus hauing pa≈ø≈øed the Cape, we got before the wind.

The 24 of Aprill the Pilot willed vs to giue the Bona viagen vnto the Cape de Bona Speranza, according to the cu≈øtome, with great ioy and gladnes of all that were in the ≈øhippe: for that as theÃÑ they a≈ø≈øure them≈øelues that they ≈øayl to Portingal, and not to turne againe into India (for ≈øo long as they are not pa≈øt the Cape they are alwaies in doubt) and as then we were about 50. miles beyond the Cape. The ≈øignes and tokens whereby they know them≈øelues certainly to haue pa≈ø≈øed the Cape, are great heapes and p√©eces of thicke r√©edes, that alwaies thereabouts driue vppon the water, at lea≈øt 15 or ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ miles from the land: as al≈øo certaine birds by the Portingals called Fey ‚Ä¢ oins, ≈øomewhat greater then ≈øea m ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢ s, being white & full of blacke ≈øpots ouer al their bodies, & very ea≈øie to be known from al other birds. The≈øe are certain ≈øignes whereby the Pilotes doe certainly per≈øwade them≈øelues that they are pa≈øt the Cape, and hauing pa≈ø≈øed it, they ≈øet their cour≈øe for S. Helena Northwe≈øt, & Northwe≈øt & by we≈øt. The 27 of Apr. we were right in the wind, and ≈øo continued till the next day, and theÃÑ we had a calm, being vnder 3 ‚Ä¢ degrees on Portingal ≈øide. The
‚Ä¢ 9 of Apr. w ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ t before the wind, which is the generall wind yt alwaies bloweth in tho≈øe countries al the whole yere, vntill y‚Ä¢ come to the Equinoctial line, and is a Southea≈øt wind: ≈øo yt they may wel let their ≈øayles ≈øtand, & lay them down to ≈øl ‚Ä¢ ep, for in ye greate≈øt wind yt bloweth there, they need not ≈øtrike their maine yard aboue half the ma≈øt.

The 12 of May, in the morning betimes‚ñ™ we di≈øcouered the IlaÃÑd of S. Helena, whereat there was ≈øo great ioy in the ≈øhip, as if we had bene in heauen: & as then we were about 2 miles from ye land, the Iland lying from vs We≈øt, ≈øouth we≈øt: whereunto we ≈øayled ≈øo clo≈øe, that with a caliuer ≈øhot we might reach vnto the ≈øhore: being hard by it, we ≈øayled about a corner of the land, that from vs lay Northwe≈øt, which hauing compa≈ø≈øed wee ≈øayled clo≈øe by the land. We≈øt, North we≈øt: the land on that ≈øide beeing ≈øo high and ≈øtill, that it ≈ø√©emed to be a wall that reached vnto the ≈økyes. And in that ≈øort we ≈øayled about a mile and a half, and compa≈ø≈øed about ye other corner that lay we≈øtward from vs, which corner b√©eing compa≈ø≈øed, we pre≈øentlie perceiued the ≈øhippes that lay in the road, which were tho≈øe ≈øhips that ≈øet ≈øayle before vs out of India, lying about a ≈ømall half mile from the fore≈øaid corner, clo≈øe vnder the land, ≈øo that the land as then lieth South ea≈øt from them: and by rea≈øon of the high land the ≈øhippes lie there as ≈øafe, as if they were in a hauen: for they may well heare the wind whi≈øtle on the top of their maine yards, but lower it can not come: and they lie ≈øo clo≈øe vnder the land, that they may almo≈øt ca≈øt a ≈øtone vpon the ≈øhore. There is good ground there, at 25 and 30 fadomes deep, but if they chance to put further out, or to pa≈ø≈øe beyond it, they mu≈øt goe forward, for they can get no more vnto ye land: and for this cau≈øe we kept ≈øo clo≈øe to the ≈øhore, that the height of the laÃÑd took the wind froÃÑ vs, & the ≈øhip wold not ≈øteer without wind, ≈øo that it draue vpon the land, wherby our hore≈øprit touched ye ≈øhore, & therwith we thought that ≈øhippe & goods had all
beene ca≈øt away: but by rea≈øon of the great depth, being 1 ‚Ä¢ . fadomes water, and with the help of the Boats, and men off the other ≈øhips that came vnto vs, we put off from the land, without any hurt, and by tho≈øe Boates wee were brought to a place wher the other ≈øhips lay at Anker, which is right again≈øt a valley, that lyeth betw√©ene two high hilles, wherein there ≈øtandeth a little Church called Saint Helena. There we found fiue ≈øhippes, which were, the ≈øhip that came from Malacca, and the S. Mary that had b√©ene there about 15. daies, which came both together to the Cape de Bona Speranza, the S. Anthonie, and the S. Chri≈øtopher being Admiral, that had arriued there
‚Ä¢ 0. daies before, and the Conception, which came thether but the day before vs, ≈øo that ther wanted none of the Fl√©et but the S. Thomas, and by the ≈øignes and tokens, that we and the other ≈øhips had ≈ø√©ene at Sea, we pre≈øumed it to be lo≈øt, as after we vnder≈øtoode (for it was neuer ≈øeene after) for the other ≈øhippes had ≈øeene Ma≈øtes, Deales, Fattes, Che≈øtes, & many dead men that had bound them≈øelues vpon boards, with a thou≈øand other ≈øuch like ≈øigns. Our Admiral likewi≈øe had b√©ene in great danger of ca≈øting away: for although it was a new ≈øhip, & this the fir≈øt Viage it had made, yet it was ≈øo eaten with Wormes, that it had at the lea≈øt 20 handfuls d√©epe of water within it, and at the Cape was forced to throw halfe the goods ouer bord, into the Sea, and were con≈øtrained continually to Pumpe with two Pumpes, both night and day, and neuer holde ≈øtill: and being before the Iland of S. Helena, had ther al≈øo ≈øunke to the ground, if the other ≈øhips had no ‚Ä¢ holpen her. The re≈øt of the ≈øhippes coulde likewi≈øe tell what dangers and mi≈øeries they had indured. About thr√©e Monthes before our arriuall at S. Helena, there had b√©ene a ≈øhip which the yere before ≈øet out of Ormus, with the goods & men that remained in the S. Saluador, that had b√©ene ≈øaued by the Portingal armie, vpon the coa≈øt of Abex, and brought vnto Ormus, as in an other place I haue declared. That ≈øhip had wintered in Mo≈øambique, and had pa≈ø≈øed verie ≈øoone by the Cape, & ≈øo ≈øayled without any companie vnto Portingall, hauing left ≈øome of her ≈øicke men in the Iland, (as the maner is) which the next ≈øhips that came thether mu≈øt take into them. The≈øe gaue vs intelligence, that about foure monthes before our arriuall, there had b√©ene an Engli≈øh ≈øhip at the Iland of Saint Helena, which had ≈øayled through the Straights of Magel ‚Ä¢ anaes, and through the ≈øouth ≈øeas, & from thence to the Ilands of Phillippinas, and had pa≈ø≈øed through the Straights of Sunda, that lyeth beyond Malacca, betw√©ene the Ilands of Sumatra and Iaua: in the which way ≈øhe had taken a ≈øhippe of China (≈øuch as they call Iunckos) laden with Siluer and Golde, and all kind of Silkes, and that ≈øhee ≈øent a letter with a ≈ømall pre≈øent to the Bi≈øhop of Malacca, telling him, that ≈øhee ≈øent him that of friend≈øhip, meaning to come her ≈øelfe and vi≈øite him. Out of that ≈øhip of China, they tooke a Portingall Pilot, & ≈øo pa≈ø≈øed the Cape de Bona Speranza, and came to the Iland of Saint Helena, where they tooke in fre≈øh water and other nece≈ø≈øaries, and beate downe the Alter and the Cro≈ø≈øe that ≈øtoode in the Church, and left behind them a Ketle and a Sword, which the Portingales at our arriual found there, yet could they not conceiue or thinke what that might meane. Some thought it was left there for a ≈øigne to ≈øome other ≈øhips of his companie, but euerie man may thinke what he will thereof. In the ≈øhip of Malacca came for Factor of the Pepper, one Gerrit van Afhuy≈øen, borne in Antwarpe, and dwelling in Lisbone, who had ≈øayled in the ≈øame ≈øhip from Lisbone about two yeares before, for that they ≈øtaied in Malacca at the lea≈øt fourt√©ene Monthes, by rea≈øon of the warres and troubles that were in that countrie, vntill Malacca was relieued, as I ≈øaide before: whereby they had pa≈ø≈øed great mi≈øerie, and b√©ene at great charges. And becau≈øe it is a very vnwhole≈øome countrie‚ñ™ together with ye con≈øtraint of lying there ≈øo long, of 200. men, that at the fir≈øt ≈øayled from Lisbone in the ≈øhip, there were but 18. or 20. left aliue, and all the re≈øt dyed, ≈øo that they were enforced to take in other vn≈økilfull men in Malacca, to bring the ≈øhippe home. This Gerrard van Afhuy≈øen, being of mine acquaintance and my good friend, before my departure out of Portingall for India, maruelled and ioyed much to find me there, little thinking that we ≈øhould m√©ete in ≈øo ≈øtrange a place, and there we di≈øcour≈øed of our trauels pa≈øt. And of him among diuers other things, I learned many true in≈øtructions as well of Malacca, as of the countries and Ilands lying about it, both for their manner of dealing in trade of Marchandi≈øe, as in other memorable things. By the pictures following, you may ≈ø√©e the true de≈øcription of the Iland of Saint Helena, and of the thr√©e ≈øides therof, as we pa≈ø≈øed by it, and as we ≈øayled about it to the road, as al≈øo of the Iland of A≈øcention. The de≈øcription of which two Ilands you may here perceiue and learne, as I my ≈øelfe could marke the ≈øame.

div.head: The 94. Chapter. A briefe de≈øcription of the Iland Saint Helena.
div.p:
THe Iland of Saint Helena is ≈øo named, becau≈øe the Portingales di≈øcouered it vppon Saint Helens day, which is the twentie one of May. It is in compa≈ø≈øe ≈øixe miles, little more or le≈ø≈øe, and lyeth vnder ≈øixt√©ene degr√©es and a quarter, on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctall 550. Spani≈øh miles from the Cape de Bona Speranza, and from the coa≈øt called Angola or Ethiopia 350. miles, & from Bra≈øilia 510. miles. The≈øe are the two n√©ere≈øt lands adioyning to it. It is a verie high and hillie countrie, ≈øo that it commonly reacheth vnto the cloudes: the countrie of it ≈øelfe is verie a≈øhie and drie: al≈øo all the trees that are therein, whereof there are great ≈øtore, & grow of them≈øelues in the woodes, are little worth but only to burne: for it hath no ≈øpecial ≈øub≈øtance, but ≈øheweth as if it were halfe con≈øumed, ≈øo that it ≈øhould ≈øeeme that ≈øome mines of Brim≈øtone, hath in times pa≈øt b√©ene in that Iland, as commonly all the Ilands are all much ≈øubiect to the ≈øame: for that in ≈øome places thereof they find Sulphur and Brim≈øtone. When the Portingales fir≈øt di≈øcouered it, there was not any bea≈øts, nor fruite, at all within the Iland, but onely great ≈øtore of fre≈øh water, which is excellent good, and falleth downe from the mountaines, and ≈øo runneth in great abundance into the Valley, where the Church ≈øtandeth, and from thence by ≈ømall chanels into the Sea, where the Portingales fill their ve≈ø≈øels full of fre≈øh water, and wa≈øh their clothes: ≈øo that it is a great benefit for them, and a plea≈øant ≈øight to behold, how cleare & in how many ≈øtreames the water runneth downe into the valley, which may bee thought a myracle, con≈øidering the drine≈ø≈øe of the country, together with the ≈øtonie Rockes and hilles therein. The Portingales haue by little and little brought many bea≈øtes into it, and in the valleyes planted al ≈øorts of fruites: which haue growne there in ≈øo great abundance, that it is almo≈øt incredible. For it is ≈øo full of Goates, Buckes, wild Hogges, Hennes, Partridges, and Doues, by thou≈øands, ≈øo that any man that will, may hunt and take them: & ther is alwaies plentie and ≈øufficient, although there came as many ≈øhippes more into the Iland as there doe: and they may kill them with ≈øtones and ≈øtaues by rea≈øon of the gret numbers of them. Now for fruites, as Portingall Figges, Pomgranets, Oranges, Lemons, Citrons, and ≈øuch like fruites, there are ≈øo many, that growe without planting or ≈øetting, that all the valleyes are full of them, which is a great plea≈øure to beholde, ≈øo that it ≈ø√©emeth to bee an earthly Paradi≈øe. It hath fruite all the yeare long, becau≈øe it raineth there by ≈øhowers at the lea≈øt fiue or ≈øix times euerie day, and then againe the Sunne ≈øhineth ≈øo, that what≈øoeuer is planted, there it groweth verie well: but becau≈øe the Portingales are not ouer curious of new things, there groweth not of al ≈øorts of fruites of Portingall and India in that Iland: for a≈ø≈øuredly without any doubt
they would growe well in that land, becau≈øe of the good temperature of the ayre, be≈øides this, they haue ≈øo great abundance of Fi≈øh, round about the Iland, that it ≈ø√©emeth a wonder wrought of God: for with crooked nayles, they may take as much Fi≈øh as they will, ≈øo that all the ≈øhippes doe prouide them≈øelues of Fi≈øh, of all ≈øorts in that place, which is hanged vp and dried, and is of as good a ta≈øte and ≈øauor, as any Fi≈øh that euer I eate: and this euery man that hath beene there, affirmeth to be true. And the better to ≈øerue their turnes, vpon the Rockes they find ≈øalt, which ≈øerueth them for their nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øions, ≈øo that to conclude, it is an earthly Paradi≈øe for ye Portingall ≈øhippes, and ≈øeemeth to haue been miraculou≈øly di≈øcouered for the refre≈øhing and ≈øeruice of the ≈øame, con≈øidering the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe and highne≈ø≈øe of the land, lying in the middle of the Ocean ≈øeas, and ≈øo far from the firme land or any other Ilands, that it ≈ø√©emeth to be a Boye, placed in the midle of the Spani≈øh Seas: for if this Iland were not, it were impo≈ø≈øible for the ≈øhippes to make any good or pro≈øperous Viage: for it hath often fallen out, that ≈øome ≈øhippes which haue mi≈ø≈øed thereof, haue endured the greate≈øt mi≈øerie in ye world, and were forced to put into the coa≈øt of Guinea, there to ≈øtay the falling of the raine, and ≈øo to get fre≈øh water, and afterwardes came halfe dead and ≈øpoyled into Portingall. It is the fa≈øhion, that all the ≈øicke per≈øons, that are in the ≈øhippes, and can not wel ≈øayle in them, are left there in the Iland, with ≈øome proui≈øion of Rice, Bi≈øket, Oyle, and ≈øome Spices, for Fi≈øh and fle≈øh they may haue enough, for when the ≈øhips are gone, then all the bea≈øtes (which by rea≈øon of the great number of people fly into the mountaines) come downe againe into the valleyes, where they may take them with their handes and kill them as they li≈øt, tho≈øe ≈øicke men ≈øtay there till the next yeare, till other ≈øhips come thether, which take them with them, they are commonly ≈øoone healed in that Iland, as being a verie ≈øound and plea≈øant countrie: and it is verie ≈øeldome ≈øeene that any of them dyeth there, becau≈øe they haue alwaies a temperate ayre, and coole winde, and alwayes fruite throughout the who ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yeare. The king will not ≈øuffer any man to dwell in it, becau≈øe they ≈øhould not de≈øtroye & ≈øpoyle the countrie, and holde it as their owne, but will haue it common for euerie man to take what he hath neede of. In time pa≈øt there dwelt an Hermet in the Ile, who continued there for certaine yeares, vnder pretence of doing penance, and to vphold the Church, hee killed many of the Goates and Buckes, ≈øo that euerie yeare hee ≈øold at the lea≈øt fiue or ≈øixe hundred ≈økinnes, and made great profit therof: which the King hearing, cau≈øed him pre≈øently to bee brought from thence into Portingall. Likewi≈øe vpon a certaine time two Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ares or blacke people of Mo≈øambique, and one Iauer, with two women ≈ølaues ≈øtoale out of the ≈øhippes, and hid them≈øelues in the Rockes of this Iland, which are verie high and wilde, whereby men can hardly pa≈ø≈øe them. They liued there together, and begot children, ≈øo that in the ende they were at the lea≈øt twentie per≈øons, who when the ≈øhips were gone, ran throughout the Iland and did much hurt, making their hou≈øes & dweling places betweene ≈øome of the hilles, where not any of the Portingales had beene, nor yet could ea≈øily come at them: and therein they hid them≈øelues vntill the ≈øhippes were gone, but in the end they were perceiued, and the Portingales v≈øed all the meanes they could to take them‚ñ™ but they knew ≈øo well how to hide and defend them≈øelues, that in many yeares they could not be taken: in the end, fearing that they might in time be hurtfull vnto them, and hinder them much, by expre≈ø≈øe commaundement of the King, after long and great labour, they tooke them all and brought them pri≈øoners into Portingall: ≈øo that at this pre≈øent no man dwelleth therein, but onely the ≈øicke men, as I told you before. When the ≈øhips come thether, euerie man maketh his lodging vnder a tr√©e ≈øetting a Tent about it: for that the trees are there ≈øo thicke, that it pre≈øently ≈ø√©emeth a little towne or an armie lying in the fielde. Euerie man prouideth for him≈øelfe, both fle≈øh fi≈øh, fruite and woode, for there is enough for them all: and euerie one wa≈øheth Linnen. There they hold a generall fa≈øting and prayer, with Ma≈ø≈øe euerie daye, which is done with great deuotion, with proce≈ø≈øion, and thanke≈øgiuing and other Himnes, thanking God that hee hath pre≈øerued them from the danger of the Cape de Bona Speranza, and brought them to that Iland in ≈øafetie. There they v≈øe oftentimes to Carus their names, and markes in trees & plants for a perpetuall memorie: whereof many hundredth are there to be found, which letters with the growing of the tr√©es, doe al≈øo grow bigger and bigger, we found names that had been there ≈øince the yeare of the Lord 1510. & 1515. and euerie yeare orderly following, which names ≈øtoode vpon Figge tr√©es, euery letter being of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a ≈øpanne, by rea≈øon of the age and growing of the tr√©es. The 26. of May in the Euening, wee ≈øpake with the Saint Mary, and the next day with the Gallion of Malacca: the ≈øame Morning and in the after noone with the Admirall, who willed vs to follow him vnto the Iland of the A≈øcention. div.head: The 95. Chapter. Of the Iland called the A≈øcention.
div.p:
THis Iland was di≈øcouered vpon A≈øcention daye, and in ≈øhew ≈ø√©emeth as great as the Iland of Saint Hellena, but not ≈øo high. It is ful of hilles and dales, lying vnder eight degr√©es and a halfe, on the South≈øide of the Equinoctiall line‚ñ™ and lyeth Northwe≈øt di≈øtant from Saint Helena, 19 ‚Ä¢
Spani≈øh miles, and from the Equi ‚Ä¢ octiall line 140. miles. There is not any fre≈øh water in the Iland, nor one greene leafe or branch. It hath many hilles of a reddi≈øh colour, which ≈øhew like a certaine Earth in Spaine called Almagro, and is full of ≈øtonie hilles, and dryed land, it is like Saint Helena. There hath beene ≈øome ≈øhippes there, that mi≈ø≈øed Saint Helena, and ≈øought for fre≈øh water in that Iland, but could find none. It hath certaine faire and white Sandes about it, and great ≈øtore of Fi≈øh, wherein it ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth S. Helena, but in it there are no bea≈øtes at all, onely by rea≈øon of the great quantitie of Fi≈øhes. Ther are ≈øo many Birds in it yt it is ≈øtrange, and they are of the bigne≈ø≈øe of young Gee≈øe, & came by thou≈øands flying about our ≈øhips, crying and making great noy≈øe, and ranne vp and downe in the ≈øhippe, ≈øome leaping and ≈øitting on our ≈øhoulders and armes, not once fearing vs, ≈øo that wee tooke many of them, and wrung of their neckes, but they are not good to eate, becau≈øe they ta≈øte mori≈øh. I thinke the cau≈øe they are ≈øo tame is, becau≈øe they ≈øee but few men, and ≈øome de≈øire to goe to them. About that Iland and the Iland of Saint Helena, vnto the Equinoctiall line, there are flying Fi≈øhes, as great as Herings which flie by great flockes together, two or thr√©e Fadome aboue the water, and flie in that manner at the lea≈øt a quarter of a mile, vntill their wings or finnes be drie, and then they can flie no longer, but fall into the water, and there wet them≈øelues, and then flie againe aboue the water. The cau≈øe why they flie in that ≈øort is, becau≈øe they are cha≈øed by the great fi≈øhes, that eate them, and to e≈øcape from them, they flie aboue the water, and ≈øome times into the ≈øhippes: for many of them fell into our ≈øhip, which flew too high, for wheÃÑ their wings are drie they mu≈øt needes fall.

From that I≈øland of A≈øcention the ≈øhippes held their cour≈øe Northwe≈øt and by We≈øt, til they be a degree pa≈øt the Equinoctiall line on the North ≈øide, where there lyeth a cliffe called Penedo de Sam Pedro, which many times they ≈ø√©e, and to it from the I≈ølande of A≈øcention are 300. miles. The 5. of Iune we pa≈ø≈øed againe the Equinoctiall line, and then again began we to ≈øee the North ≈øtarre, which we had lo≈øt vnder ten degr√©es, on this ≈øide Cochijn, and now began to lo≈øe the ≈øight of the South ≈øtarre, and there we had the ≈øun in the South at twelue of the clocke at noone, in which on the other ≈øide of the line at the ≈øame time is in the North. The 8. of Iune being 4. degr√©es in the North, we lo≈øt our generall South ea≈øt winde, that had ≈øerued vs from the Cape de bona Speranza thether, & then began the raines and calmes: for as then we began to come neare the coa≈øt of Guinea, which continueth to 9. degrees. The≈øe calmes and raines helde vs till 11. degr√©es, being the 20, of Iune, whereby the ≈øhips ≈øeperated them≈øelues, by rea≈øon of the calmes which made them not able to ≈øt√©erre: and in the 11. degrees they met againe, and there we had a North ea≈øt wind, which is called the generall winde, becau≈øe it floweth continually in tho≈øe Countries, and holdeth to 30. and
‚Ä¢ 2. degr√©es, beginning many times at 6. and 7. degrees: but wee had it not till wee were vnder 1 ‚Ä¢ . degr√©es. This wind is ≈øomewhat ≈øcant, for wee mu≈øt of force ≈øaile in the wind, becau≈øe our chiefe cour≈øe is Northwe≈øt and by North.

The 23. of Iune we pa≈ø≈øed the point of Capo Verde, which is vnder 15. degr√©es, and the 26. of the ≈øame month we pa≈ø≈øed the I≈ølands of Capo Verde, which are ten in number. They beginne vnder 15. degr√©es, and end in 19. degr√©es, and are di≈øtant from the firme land of Capo Verde, from 70. to 1 ‚Ä¢ 0. miles inwards to the ≈øea. Then wee entred into the ≈øea, called Serga≈ø≈øo, which is all couered with hearbes, ≈øo that it ≈ø√©emeth to be like a gr√©ene fielde, & ≈øo thicke that a man can not ≈øee the water, neyther can the ≈øhips pa≈ø≈øe through them, but with great labour, vnle≈ø≈øe they haue a ≈øtrong wind. The hearbe is like Samper, but yellow of colour, & hath berries like Goo≈øe berries, but nothing in them. The Portingalles call it Sarga≈ø≈øo, becau≈øe it is like the herbes that groweth in their welles in Portingall, called Sarga≈ø≈øo: wherevpon that ≈øea is called Sarga≈ø≈øo. It is not knowne from whence it commeth: for there is no land nor I≈øland that is knowne to bee neare that ≈øea, but the coa≈øt of Africa, which is at the lea≈øt more then 400. miles from thence. It is thought it commeth from from the ground, and yet there is no ground in that place to bee founde: and in ≈øayling to India, the ≈øhippes come not into that ≈øea (for then they k√©epe clo≈øer to the ≈øhore, ≈øo that it is not once ≈ø√©ene) and it is not found in any place but there, beginning at 20. degr√©es, & continuing to 34. degr√©es, ≈øo thicke, and ≈øo full as if they were whole I≈ølandes, mo≈øt ≈øtrange to beholde. In that countrey it is as cold in winter, as it is here with vs when it fr√©ezeth not, which the Portingalles e≈øt√©eme a great cold, and cloath them≈øelues again≈øt it as we doe in a mightie great fro≈øt. The la≈øt of Iune wee were vnder 23. degrees, being right vnder the Sunne: for yt the Sun was then in the ≈øame height, and we al≈øo vnder ye Tropike of Cancer, which is the furthe≈øt part that the Sunne goeth Northwarde, and then it turneth againe vnto the Equinoctial line, and from thence into the South. Wee pa≈ø≈øed ye line of Tropicus Capricorni twice, once on the South ≈øide, by the ende of the I≈øland of S. Laurence, and then againe vnder 23. degr√©es, after we had pa≈ø≈øed the Cape de bona Speranza. The 2. of Iuly wee were vnder the height of the I≈ølands of Canarie, which lie vnder 28. and 29. degr√©es, and are di≈øtant from the coa≈øt of Barbarie and Africa from 30. to 80. miles, which I≈ølandes lay on our right hande: and becau≈øe in tho≈øe I≈ølandes there are many things that are worthie the noting, therefore I thought it conuenient to make a briefe de≈øcription of them.

div.head: The 96. Chapter. A briefe de≈øcription of the I≈ølands of Canaria.
div.p:
THe I≈ølandes of Canaria are ≈øeuen, which in times pa≈øt were called the Fortunadas, and at this day by the Spaniards are called the Canaries, by rea≈øon of the great numbers of dogges which they founde in them, when they were fir≈øt di≈øcouered. The names of the I≈ølands are, great Canarie, Teneriffe, La Palma, La Gomera, El'Hierro, Lan≈øarotte, and Fuerte Ventura. In the I≈øland of Teneriffe there is a hil called Pico de Terraira, which is thought to bee the highe≈øt hill that euer was found, for it may ea≈øily bee ≈ø√©ene at the lea≈øt three≈øcore miles into the ≈øea, before they come at it. It cannot be climed but in the monthes of Iuly and Augu≈øt: for all the other
monthes it lyeth full of ≈ønowe, although below in the I≈øland, and in other I≈ølands thereabouts, they ≈ø√©e no ≈ønow. It is thr√©e dayes iourney to clime vp into it, and on the toppe therof it is flat, and when it is clear and faire weather, a man may from thence ≈ø√©e all the I≈ølandes round about it, although ≈øome of them are at the lea≈øt 50. miles di≈øtant, and as much in compa≈ø≈øe. The two monthes in which they v≈øe to clime vp vpon the hill, they bring downe certaine peeces of brim≈øtone, from whence it is much caried into Spaine: and at my being in the I≈øland of Tercera, a ≈øhipper one of my acquaintance that came from Teneriffe, gaue me a p√©ece thereof, for a remembrance of him. In one of tho≈øe I≈ølandes called Hierro, or of Iron, there is a wonderfull and ≈øtrange thing to be ≈ø√©ene, and I verely thinke it is one of ye ≈øtrange≈øt things in the world. This I≈øland is on of the greate≈øt of all the ≈øeuen: but it is an vnfruitful and barren land, and ≈øo drie, that in all the I≈øland there is not one droppe of fre≈øh water to bee found, but onely in ≈øome places vppon the ≈øea ≈øide, which is farre from hand, ≈øo that it profiteth the inhabitants but very little. But God of his mercie hath prouided for the want of water both for men and bea≈øtes, in this maner: for there is a great tr√©e, which no man knoweth, (for the like is not found in any other place) the leaues whereof are ≈ømall and long, and alwaies gr√©ene without chaunging colour: this tr√©e is couered and compa≈ø≈øed about with a ≈ømall cloud, which alwaies continueth in one forme, and neuer altereth nor dimini≈øheth: and this cloud ca≈øteth dew vpon the leaues of the tr√©e, which hang down, and drop continually (without cea≈øing) a mo≈øt cleare, thinne and fine water, which falleth into certaine Ce≈øternes, that by the inhabitants of the I≈øland are made round about & vnder the tr√©e, therein to k√©epe and pre≈øerue the water.

p.hi: The I≈øland of A≈øcention, ≈øo called, becau≈øe it was di≈øcouered vppon the day of Chri≈øts a≈øcention into heauen, is not inhabited becau≈øe of the vnfruitfulnes therof, & becau≈øe it wanteth fre≈øh water: which is al≈øo the cau≈øe that it is not vi≈øited by the ≈øhips, for that they hope for no refre≈øhing in the ≈øame. The hilles of this Iland are redde like Bolus. About this Iland are many birds, becau≈øe of the great numbers of fi≈øhes that are about it, ≈øpecially ≈ømall flying fi≈øhes, which in Portingall are called Pi≈øce Bolodor. Reade more hereof in the booke, in Folio 175.

div.p: And this water is in ≈øo great abundance, that it ≈øerueth all the I≈øland for their nece≈ø≈øarie v≈øes, not onely for the people, but al≈øo for their cattle throughout all the I≈øle, and no man can remember when that wonder fir≈øt began.

On the right ≈øide of this I≈øland about an hundred miles di≈øtant: there is yet an other wonder to be noted, which is, that oftentimes there is an I≈ølande ≈ø√©ene thereaboutes, called San Borondon, where diuers men haue been on lande, being onely ≈øuch as fell vppon it on the ≈øodaine, and not looking for it‚ñ™ who affirme it to bee a very fayre, plea≈øant, and gr√©ene Countrey full of tr√©es, and all kinds of victuaile, and that it is inhabited by people that are Chri≈øtians: but no man knowes of what nation they are, neyther what language they ≈øpeake. The Spaniards of the I≈ølandes of Canaria haue many times ≈øayled towardes it to view it, but they could neuer find it: whereupon there goeth diuers opinions of it: for ≈øome think it to be inchanted, and that it may not bee ≈øeene but vppon certaine dayes: ≈øome thinke it to bee very ≈ømall, and alwaies couered with cloudes, and that therefore it can not bee ≈ø√©ene nor founde out: and al≈øo the great ≈øtormes and ≈øtrength of the water driueth the ≈øhippes from it: but to conclude, it is holden for a truth, that the Ilande lyeth thereaboutes, as all tho≈øe that come from thence doe certainly affirme. The Ilandes of Canaria are very fruitfull, and plentifull of all thinges, both victuailes and other nece≈ø≈øaries. They haue of all kinds of corne, ≈øpecially excellent good Wine, which from thence is caried into all places. There is likewi≈øe great ≈øtore of Sugar, which is much e≈øteemed, and al≈øo caryed into all countries of Chri≈øtendome, which cau≈øeth great trafficke vnto tho≈øe Ilands, as well by Spaniardes and Portingalles, as other nations, and is the common ≈øtaple for the ≈øhippes that ≈øayle out of Spayne into the We≈øt Indies, and refre≈øhe them≈øelues there, and al≈øo take in ≈øuch Wyne as they commonly v≈øe to carry with them to the We≈øt Indies. They haue al≈øo great abundance of Cattle and Cammelles, and are now inhabited by Spanyardes, hauing yet therein many of the naturall borne inhabitantes, which they doe call Guanchas, who by rea≈øon of their long conuer≈øation with the Spaniardes, doe wholly v≈øe their cu≈øtomes, and manner of apparell. The chiefe of the≈øe I≈ølands is great Canaria, where there is a Bi≈øhop, and the inqui≈øition with the tribunal Royall, and it hath the gouernment ouer all the other I≈ølandes, that are called the Canaries.

The 6. of Iulie wee were vnder 32. degrees, where wee lo≈øt the generall North-Ea≈øt wind, and had a calme, and ≈øaw much of

The ≈øame night pa≈ø≈øing hard by the I≈øland of Fayarl, the next day being betw√©ene the I≈øland of S. George that lay on our right hand, and the ≈ømall I≈øland called C ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ o on our left hand, we e≈ø≈øpied the thr√©e Engli≈øh ≈øhips ≈øtill following vs that tooke coun≈øell together, whereof one ≈øayled backwards, thinking that ≈øome other ≈øhip had come after vs without company, & for a ≈ømall time was out of ≈øight, but it was not long before it came againe to the other two, wherewith they tooke coun≈øell, & came all thr√©e together again≈øt our ≈øhippe, becau≈øe we lay in the l√©e of all our ≈øhips, and had the I≈øland of S. George on the one ≈øide in ≈øteede of a ≈øconce‚ñ™ thinking to deale ≈øo with vs, that in the end we ≈øhould be con≈øtrained to runne vppon the ≈øhore, whereof wee wanted not much, and in that manner with their flagges openly di≈øplayed, came lu≈øtily towardes vs, ≈øounding their Trumpets, and ≈øayled at the lea≈øt three times about vs, beating vs with Mu≈øket and Caliuer, and ≈øome great p√©eces, and did vs hurt in the body of our ≈øhippe, but ≈øpoyled all our ≈øayles and ropes, and to conclude, we were ≈øo plagued by them, that no man dur≈øt put forth his head, and when wee ≈øhot off a peece, we had at the lea≈øt an houres worke to lade it againe, whereby wee had ≈øo great a noi≈øe and crie in the ≈øhip, as if we had all bin ca≈øt away, whereat the Engli≈øh men them≈øelues beganne to mocke vs, and with a thou≈øand ie≈øting words called vnto vs. In the meane time the other ≈øhippes hoi≈øed all their ≈øailes, & did the be≈øt they could to ≈øaile to the I≈øland of Tercera, not looking once behinde them to help vs, doubting they ≈øhould come too late thether, not caring for vs, but thinking them≈øelues to haue done ≈øufficiently: ≈øo they ≈øaued their own ≈øtakes, whereby it may ea≈øily be ≈ø√©ene what company they k√©epe one with the other, & what order is among them. In the end the Engli≈øh men perceiuing ≈ømall aduantage again≈øt vs, (little knowing in what ca≈øe and feare we were, as al≈øo becau≈øe we were not far froÃÑ Tercera) left vs, which made vs not a litle to reioyce, as thinking our ≈øelues to be ri≈øen from death to life, although we were not well a≈ø≈øured, neither yet voide of feare till we lay in the road before Tercera ‚ñ™ & vnder the ≈øafetie of the Portingales fort, & that we might get thether in good time we made all the ≈øailes we could: on the other ≈øide we were in great doubt, becau≈øe wee knew not what they did in the I≈øland, nor whether they were our friendes or enemies, and wee doubted ≈øo much the more, becau≈øe wee found no men of war nor any Caruels of adui≈øe froÃÑ Portingal, as we made our accounts to doe, that might conuay vs from thence, or giue vs adui≈øe, as in that countrie ordinarilie they v≈øe to do, & becau≈øe the Engli≈øh men had bin ≈øo victorious in tho≈øe parts, it made vs ≈øu≈øpect that it went not well with Spaine: they of the Iland of Tercera, were in no le≈ø≈øe feare then we, for that ≈ø√©eing our deer, they thought vs to be Engli≈øhmen & that we came to ouer run the Iland, becau≈øe the 3. Engli≈øh meÃÑ had bouÃÑd vp their flags & came in company with vs: for the which cau≈øe the Iland ≈øent out 2. Caruels that lay there with adui≈øe from the King, for the Indian ≈øhips that ≈øhould come thither. Tho≈øe Caruels came to view vs, and perceiuing what wee were, made after vs, wherevppon the Engli≈øh
≈øhips left vs, & made towardes them, becau≈øe the Caruels thought them to be friends, and ≈øhunned them not, as ≈øuppo≈øing them to be of our company, but we ≈øhot foure or fiue times and made ≈øignes vnto them that they ≈øhould make towards the I≈øland, which they pre≈øently did. The Engli≈øh men perceiuing that did put forwards into the ≈øea, and ≈øo the Caruels borded vs telling vs that the men of the I≈øland were all in armes, as hauing receiued adui≈øe from Portingall, that Sir Francis Drake was in a readines, and would come vnto tho≈øe I≈ølands. They likewi≈øe brought vs newes of the ouerthrow of the Spani≈øh Fl√©et before England, and that the Engli≈øh men had b√©ene before the gates of Lisbone: wherupon the king gaue vs commandement that we ≈øhould put into the I≈øland of Tercera, and there lie vnder the ≈øafetie of the Ca≈øtle vntill we receiued further adui≈øe what wee ≈øhould doe, or whether we ≈øhould ≈øaile: for that they thought it too dangerous for vs to goe to Li ‚Ä¢ bone. Tho≈øe newes put our fleet in great feare, and made vs looke vppon each other not knowing what to ≈øay, as being daÃÑ gerous for them to put into the road, becau≈øe it lieth open to the ≈øea: ≈øo that the Indian ≈øhips, although they had expre≈ø≈øe commandement from the king, yet they dur≈øt not anker there, but only v≈øed to come thether, and to lauere to and fro, ≈øending their boates on land to fetch ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øaries as they wanted, without ankering: but being by nece≈ø≈øity coÃÑ pelled thereunto, as al≈øo by the kinges commandement, and for that wee vnder≈øtood the Earle of Cumberland not to bee farre from tho≈øe I≈ølands with certaine ≈øhips of war, we made nece≈ø≈øitie a vertue, and entring the rode, ankered clo≈øe vnder the Ca≈øtle, ≈øtaying for adui≈øe, and order from the king to performe our voyage, it being then the 24. of July, & S. Iames day. We were in al 6 ≈øhips, that is 5. from Ea≈øt Indies, & one from Malacca, & lay in the rode before the Towne of Angra, from whence we pre≈øently ≈øent three or foure Caruels into Portingal, with adui≈øe vnto the king of our ariuall. There we lay in great daunger, and much feare, for that when the month of Augu≈øt, commeth it is very dangerous lying before that Iland, for as then it beginneth to ≈øtorme. The ≈øhippes are there ≈øafe from all windes, ≈øauing onely from the South and Southea≈øt windes: for when they blow, they lie in a thou≈øand dangers, ≈øpecially the ea≈øt IndiaÃÑ ≈øhips, which are very heauily laden, and ≈øo full, that they are almo≈øt readie to ≈øinke, ≈øo that they can hardly be ≈øt√©ered.

The fourth of Augu≈øt in the night we had a South winde out of the ≈øea, wherewith it began ≈øo to ≈øtorme, that all the ≈øhips were in great danger to be ca≈øt away, and to run vpon the ≈øhore: ≈øo that they were in great feare and ≈øhot off their p√©eces, to call for help. The officers and mo≈øt of the ≈øailers were on land, none but pugs and ≈ølaues being in the ≈øhips: for it is a common cu≈øtome with the Portingales, that where≈øoeuer they anker, pre≈øently they goe all on land, and let the ≈øhippe lie with a boy or two in it. All the bels in the Towne were hereupon rung, and there was ≈øuch a noy≈øe and crie in euerie place, that one could not heare the other ≈øpeak: for tho≈øe that were on land by rea≈øon of the foule weather, could not get aboard, and they in the Shippe could not come to land. Our Shippe the Santa Crus was in great danger, thinking verily that it ≈øhuld haue run vpon the ≈øands, but God holy them. The ≈øhip that came from Malacca brake her Cables, and had not men enough aboard the ≈øhippe, nor any that could tell how to ca≈øt forth another anker: ≈øo that in the end they cut their ma≈øtes, & droue vpon the Cliffes, where it ≈øtayed, and brake in p√©eces, and pre≈øently ≈øunke vnder the water to the vpper Dorlope, and with that the winde came North We≈øt, wherewith the ≈øtorme cea≈øed, and the water became calme. If that had not b√©ene, al the ≈øhips had followed the ≈øame cour≈øe: for that ≈øome of them were at the point to cut their Ma≈øts, and Cables to ≈øaue their liues, but God would not haue it ≈øo. In that ≈øhip of Malacca were lo≈øt many rich and co≈øtly Marchandi≈øes: for the≈øe ≈øhips are ordinarily as rich as anie ≈øhips that come from India, as being full of all the rich wares of China, M ‚Ä¢ luco, Laua, and all tho≈øe countries, ≈øo that it was great pittie to ≈ø√©e what co≈øtly thinges, as Silkes, Dama≈økes, clothes of gold and ≈øiluer, & ≈øuch like wares) fleeted vpon the ≈øea, and were torne in p√©eces. There was much goods ≈øaued that lay in the vpper part of the ≈øhip, and al≈øo by duckers, as pepper, Nutmegs, and Cloues, but mo≈øt of it was lo≈øt, and that which was ≈øaued, was in a manner ≈øpoyled, and little worth: which pre≈øently by the kinges officers in the I≈øland was ≈øea≈øed vpon, and to the Farmers v≈øes, ≈øhut vp in the Al≈øandega, or Cu≈øtome hou≈øe, for the Kinges cu≈øtome, not once regarding the poore men, nor their long and dangerous Voiage that had continued the ≈øpace of three yeares, with ≈øo great mi≈øerie and trouble by them indured in Malacca, (as in another place I haue alreadie ≈øhewed:) ≈øo that they could not obtaine ≈øo much fauour of the king nor of his officers, that of the goods that were ≈øaued and brought to land, they might haue ≈øome part, although they o ‚Ä¢ fered to put in ≈øuerties for ≈øo much as the cu≈øtome might amount vnto, or els to leaue as much goods in
the officers hands as would ≈øati≈øfie them, and although they made daily, and pittifull complaintes, that they had not where with to liue, and that they de≈øired vppon their owne aduentures to fraight certaine ≈øhippes or Caruels at their owne charge, and to put in good ≈øuerties to deliuer the goods in the Cu≈øtome hou≈øe of Lisbone, yet could they not obtaine their reque≈øts: but were an≈øwered that the king for the a≈ø≈øurance of his cu≈øtome, and of all the goods, would ≈øend an Armado by ≈øea to fetch the goods: which fetching continued for the ≈øpace of two yeares and a halfe, and yet nothing was done, for there came no Armado.

In the meane time the poore ≈øaylers con≈øumed all that they had, and de≈øperately cur≈øed both them≈øelues, the king, and all his officers: yet in the end by great and importunate ≈øute of the Farmers of the pepper, euery maÃÑ had licence to lade his goods in what ≈øhip hee would, after it had laine there for the ≈øpace of two yeares and a halfe, putting in ≈øuerties to deliuer the goods in the cu≈øtome hou≈øe of Li≈øbone, where they mu≈øt pay the halfe & more of the ≈øame goods for cu≈øtome to the King, without any re≈øpect of their hard fortune and great mi≈øerie, during their long and dangerous Voyage, and he that will be di≈øpatched in the Cu≈øtome hou≈øe there, mu≈øt ≈ø√©e the officers, otherwi≈øe it is mo≈øt commonly three or foure monthes before the goods are deliuered vnto the owners, and the be≈øt thinges, or any fine deui≈øe that the Marchants for their own v≈øes bring out of India, if the officers like theÃÑ they mu≈øt haue them, yet they will promi≈øe to pay for them, but they ≈øet no day when: ≈øo that the poore Marchants are forced to giue them re≈øt, and wel contented that the officers are ≈øo plea≈øed, and v≈øe no more delaies.

The eight of Augu≈øt, the officers of the ≈øhips tooke coun≈øell together, with the Gouernour of the I≈øland what they were be≈øt to doe, thinking it not good to follow the kinges adui≈øe, con≈øidering their long ≈øtaying, and fearing ≈øome other hard fortune if they ≈øhould ≈øtay, and becau≈øe a great Gallion being a maÃÑ of warre, and very ≈øtrong, lay as then before the I≈øland, wherein was the Gouernour of Bra≈øil ‚Ä¢ a, who by foule weather had put in there: they concluded that this Gallion being well appointed ≈øhould ≈øayle with them to Li≈øbone, and although they did it without the adui≈øe and commandement of the king, yet bad they rather ≈øo to aduenture their liues vpon the ≈øeas, then againe to ≈øtay the danger of the Hauen, for that the winter did daylie more and more increa≈øe, ≈øo that they were not to looke for any better weather, and in that ≈øort appointing them≈øelues as well as they could, and taking in all nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øions, the ≈øame day they all ≈øet ≈øaile with no ≈ømall feare to fall into ≈øome mi≈øfortune by the way: but becau≈øe many that were of the ≈øhip of Malacca, ≈øtayed at Tercera to ≈øaue ≈øuch goods as by any meanes might be ≈øaued, and by that meanes to help them≈øelues, (among the which was the Factor of the pepper, b√©eing one of my acquaintance, at who≈øe reque≈øt, as al≈øo becau≈øe the Pepper of that ≈øhip, and of all the other ≈øhips belonged all to one Farmer, by whom I was appointed Factor, and ≈ø√©eing the nece≈ø≈øitie he bad, and that he alone could hardly di≈øpatch ≈øo great a matter,) I tooke order for mine owne affaires, and hauing di≈øpatched it by other ≈øhippes, I ≈øtayed there to help him, till wee had further adui≈øe, and order from the Farmers of the Pepper and other ≈øpices and wares, of the which goods we ≈øaued a great quantitie by meanes of Duckers and other In≈øtruments that we v≈øed, hauing adui≈øe from the Farmers & the King that it ≈øhuld not be long before they ≈øent for vs, willing vs to ≈øtay there, and to looke vnto the goods. This ≈øtaying and fetching vs away continued (as I ≈øaid before) for the ≈øpace of two yeares and a halfe, whereby you may con≈øider the good order, and pollicie of the Admiraltie of Portingall, and with what diligence and care they ≈ø√©eke for the common profit of the land, and the poore Marchantes of the Countrie, whome they ought to fauor and help, as much as po≈ø≈øiblie they may, but they do cleane contrarie, as tho≈øe which deale in Portingall doe well finde.

The 13. of Augu≈øt the ≈øhips came back againe vnto the I≈øland of Tercera, becau≈øe they had a contrarie wind as al≈øo for want of fre≈øh water, but they ankered not. The day before the Earle of Cumberland with ‚Ä¢ . or 7. ≈øhips of warre, ≈øayled by the Iland of Tercera, & to their great good fortune pa≈ø≈øed out of ≈øight, ≈øo that they di≈øpatched them≈øelues in all ha≈øte, & for the more ≈øecuritie, tooke with them 4. hundred Spaniards, of tho≈øe that lay in Garri≈øon in the I≈øland, & with theÃÑ they ≈øayled towards Lisbon, hauing a good wind: ≈øo that within a 11. dayes after they arriued in the riuer of L ‚Ä¢ sbone with great gladnes, & triumph: for if they had ≈øtayed but one day longer before they had entred the riuer, they had all b√©ene taken by Captaine Drake, who with 40. ≈øhips came before Ca≈øcalis, at the ≈øame time that the Indian ≈øhips ca≈øt anker in the riuer of Lisbone, being garded thither by diuers Gallies. Now by the di≈øcour≈øe of this long and perilous voiage‚ñ™ you may ≈øufficiently perceiue, how that onely by the grace and ≈øpeciall fauour of God, the Indian ≈øhips doe performe their voiages, yet with great mi≈øerie, paine, labour, lo≈ø≈øe, and hinderance: wherby men may likewi≈øe con≈øider the manner
of their NauigatioÃÑ, ordinances, cu≈øtomes and gouernments of their ≈øhips, ≈øo that in coÃÑ pari≈øon of many other Voyages, this pre≈øent Voyage may be e≈øt√©emed a happy & pro≈øperous voyage: for oftentimes it chanceth, that but one or two ≈øhips (of the fiue that yearely ≈øaile to India come ≈øafe home, as of late it hath bin ≈ø√©ene, ≈øome being taken, and ≈øome lo≈øt, altogether by their owne follies, & bad order, as herin at large you may perceiue, &c.

div.head: The 97. Chapter. Of the de≈øcription of the I≈ølands of Acores of the Flemmi≈øh I≈ølands.
div.p:
THe I≈øles of Acores, or the Flemmi≈øh I≈ølands are ‚Ä¢ . that is, Terce ‚Ä¢ a, Saint Michael, S. Mary, S. George, Gratio≈øa, Pico, & Fay
‚Ä¢ el. There are yet two I≈ølands called Flores and Cora ‚Ä¢ , which are not contained vnder the name of Acores, but yet at this day are vnder the gouernment of the ≈øame I≈ølands, ≈øo that they are in all accounted ‚Ä¢ . I≈ølands. They are called Acores, that is to ≈øay, Sparhaukes or Haukes, becau≈øe that in their fir≈øt di≈øcouerte, they found many Sparhaukes in them, whereof they hold the name, although at this day there is not any there to be found. They are al≈øo called the Flemmi≈øh I≈ølands, that is, of the Neatherlanders, becau≈øe the fir≈øt that inhabited the ≈øame, were Neatherlanders, whereof till this time there is a great number and of≈øpring remaining, that in manner and behauiour are altogether like Neatherlanders, and there is yet in the ≈øame I≈øland a running water, that i≈ø≈øueth out of a hill, & ≈øo runneth into the ≈øea, where as yet tho≈øe i≈ø≈øues or of≈øpringes of NeatherlaÃÑders inhabite, & is called Ariber ‚Ä¢ dos ‚Ä¢ ramengos, that is the Flemmi≈øh riuer. The principall Iland of them al, is that of Tercera, called Iu≈øu ‚Ä¢ de Ie≈øus C ‚Ä¢ ≈øtus of Tercera. It is betw√©ene 1 ‚Ä¢ . or
‚Ä¢ 6. miles in compa≈ø≈øe, and is altogether a great Cliffe of land, whereby in it there is little roome: for it is as it were walled round about with Cliffes: but where any ≈øtrand or land is, there ≈øtandeth a ≈øort. It hath no Hauens nor entrance of waters, for the ≈øecuritie and ≈øafetie of the ≈øhips, but only before the chiefe towne called Angra, where it hath an open Hauen, which in forme is like a halfe Moone, by the Portingales called Angra, whereof the towne hath her name. It hath on the one ≈øide in manner of an elbow ≈øticking forth, two high hilles, called Bre≈øyl, which ≈øtretch into the ≈øea, ≈øo yt a far off they ≈ø√©eme to bee deuided from the Iland. Tho≈øe hils are very high ≈øo that being vpon them, a man may ≈øee at the lea≈øt 10, 12 and ≈øometimes 15. miles into the ≈øea, being cleare weather. Vpon the≈øe hils there ≈øtand two ≈ømall ≈øtone pillers, where there is a CeÃÑ tinell placed, that continually watcheth to „Äà‚óä„Äâ what ≈øhips are at ≈øea and ≈øo to aduerti≈øe tho≈øe of the I≈øland: for that as many ≈øhips as hee ≈ø√©eth coÃÑming out of the we≈øt, that is from the Spani≈øh Indies, or Bra≈ø ‚Ä¢ , C ‚Ä¢ bo v ‚Ä¢ Guinea, and the Portingal ‚ñ™ Indies, and all other waies lying ≈øouth or we≈øt, for euerie ≈øhip he ≈øetteth a flagge vppon the piller in the we≈øt, and when the ≈øhips which he de≈øerieth, are more then 5. then hee ≈øetteth vp a great auncient, betokening a whole fleet of ≈øhips‚ñ™ the like he doth vpon the other piller, which ≈øtandeth in the Ea≈øt, for ≈øuch Shippes as come from Portingall, or other places out of the Ea≈øt or North partes, the≈øe pillers may bee ea≈øily ≈ø√©ene in all places of the towne, by rea≈øon of the highnes of the hils, ≈øo that there is not one ≈øhip or ≈øayle that is at ≈øea, or maketh towards the I≈øland, but it is pre≈øently knowne throughout all the towne, and ouer all the whole Iland: for the watch is not holden onely vppon tho≈øe two hils iutting into the ≈øea, but al≈øo vpon all corners, hilles and cliffes throughout the Iland, and as ≈øoone as they perceiue any ≈øhips, the Gouerner and Rulers are pre≈øently aduerti≈øed therof, that they may take ≈øuch order therein as need requireth. Vpon the furthe≈øt corner into the ≈øea ≈øtandeth a ≈øort, right again≈øt another fort that an≈øwereth it: ≈øo that tho≈øe two forts doe ≈øhut and defend the mouth or open hauen of the towne, where the ≈øhips lie in the road, and ≈øo no ≈øhip can either goe in or came forth, without the licence or permi≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe two forts. This towne of „Äà‚óä„Äâ is not only the chiefe towne of „Äà‚óä„Äâ , but al≈øo of al other townes within ye Ilands thereabouts. Therein is re≈øident‚ñ™ the Bi≈øhop, the Gouernour for the King, and the chiefe place of iudgement, or tribunall ≈øeate of all the I≈ølands of Acores.

Three miles from this towne lieth another towne towards the North, called V ‚Ä¢ de Prava for P ‚Ä¢
is as much to ≈øay, as ≈øtrand becau≈øe it lieth hard by a great ≈øtrand, and for that cau≈øe there is little traffique thether, as not hauing any conuenient place for ≈øhips to come at it: yet ≈øome times there coÃÑ meth ≈øome one, that by rea≈øon of contrarie wind cannot get before the towne of Angr ‚Ä¢ , and ≈øo by con≈øtraint di≈øcharge their goods in that Towne, which from thence are carried by land to Angra, and yet ≈øome part thereof is ≈øpent and v≈øed there. It is walled and well hou≈øed, but not many people „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and ≈øuch as are in it, doe get their liuings mo≈øt by hu≈øbandrie: for there are „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ corne lands. The I≈øland is likewi≈øe very fruitful and plea≈øant, it hath much corne and wine, but the Wine is not verie good to carrie into other Countries there abouts, becau≈øe it is
≈ømall, and will not long continue, ≈øo that it is v≈øed in the Countrey by the common people: but ≈øuch as are of wealth, for the mo≈øt part drinke wines of Madera and Canaria. It aboundeth in fle≈øh fi≈øh, & all other nece≈ø≈øaries and meats for mans body, where with in time of neede they might helpe them≈øelues. Oyle there is none, but it commeth out of Portugall. Al≈øo Salt, pottes, pannes, and all kinde of earthen ve≈ø≈øelles, Chalke, and ≈øuch like are brought thether out of other places, for there they are not to bee founde: for fruites they haue (be≈øides Peaches of diuers kindes‚ñ™ and in ≈øo great abundance that it is ≈øtrange Cherries, Plummes, Walnuttes, Ha≈øle nuttes, Che≈ønuttes but tho≈øe not very good: of Apples, Peares, Oranges and Lemons with all ≈øuch like fruites there are ≈øufficient. Of all ≈øorts of Hearbs and plants, as Cole worts, Radi≈øhes and ≈øuch like they haue at their certayne tunes of the yeare. And becau≈øe the towne of Angra, in the Iland of Tercera is the chiefe towne and ruler ouer al the Flemi≈øh Ilands, I thought good to ≈øet it downe in this place, in the full proportion, with all the ≈øtr√©etes, Forts, and Road or open Hauen, together with the hilles called Bre≈øil, where the ≈øentinell is holden, for all ≈øhippes that come into tho≈øe Ilands: al liuely de≈øcribed as in my ≈øimple ≈økill I could comprehend and deui≈øe it.

div.head: The 98. Chapter. Of the Ilands of Coruo and Flores.
div.p: FRom Tercera we≈øtwarde to the Iland named Flores are ≈øeuentie miles: it is aboute ≈øeauen miles compa≈ø≈øe, it is al≈øo inhabited by Portingales, and hath no ≈øpeciall marchandi≈øe, but onely ≈øome wood, it is full of Cattle, and other nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øions, and lyeth open to all the world, and to who≈øoeuer will come thether, as well Engli≈øhmen as others: for that the inhabitants haue not the power to re≈øi≈øt them. A myle from thence Northward, lyeth a little Iland of two or three miles in compa≈ø≈øe called De Coruo. The inhabitants are of the ≈øame people that dwel in Flores. Betw√©ene tho≈øe two Ilands and round about them, the Engli≈øhmen doe commonly ≈øtay, to watch the ≈øhips that come out of the We≈øt: for tho≈øe are the fir≈øt Ilands, that the ≈øhippes looke out for and de≈øcrie, when they ≈øayle vnto Tercera, wherby the inhabitants doe but little pro≈øper, becau≈øe they are at the plea≈øure and commaundement of all that will come vnto them, and take their goods from them, as oftentimes it happeneth. Yet for all their pouertie, not to loo≈øe both landes and goods, they mu≈øt content them≈øelues, and Sayle with euerie winde.

The Ile of Tercera lyeth vnder thirtie nine degrees, in the ≈øame height that Lisbone lyeth: and is di≈øtant from Lisbone lying right Ea≈øt and We≈øt two hundred and fiftie Spani≈øh miles. This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the de≈øcription of the Flemmi≈øh Ilands, called the Azores, which by dayly traueling vnto them are ≈øufficiently knowne: for that at this time many of our nation doe ≈øayle thether, ≈øo that euerie Marchant knoweth them. This briefe de≈øcription therfore is by me ≈øet town for the in≈øtruction of ≈øuch as deale not in the trade of Marchandi≈øe, and know them not‚ñ™ whereby they may ≈ø√©e what manner of Countries they are‚ñ™ &c.

div.head: The 99. Chapter. Of cer ‚Ä¢ aine notable and memorable accidents that happened during my continuance in Tercera.
div.p: THe ≈øecond of October An. 15 ‚Ä¢ 9. at the towne of Villa dan Praya, in the Iland of Tercera, two men being in a field hard without the towne were killed with lightning.

The ninth of the ≈øame month there arriued in Tercera fourteene ≈øhippes, that came from the Spani≈øh Indies, laden with Cochenile, Hides, Golde. Siluer, Pearles, and other riche wares. They were fiftie in companie, when they departed out of the Iland of Hanana, whereof, in their comming out of the Channell, eleauen ≈øunke in the ≈øame Channell by ≈øoule weather, the re≈øt by a ≈øtorme were ≈øcattered and ≈øeperated one from the other. The next day there came an other ≈øhip of the ≈øame companie, that ≈øayled clo≈øe vnder the Iland, ≈øo to get into the Roade: where ≈øhe met with an Engli≈øh ≈øhippe, that had not aboue three ca≈øt peeces, and the Spaniyard twelue. They fought a long time together, which we being in the Iland might ≈øtand and behold: whereupon the Gouernour of Tercera ≈øent two Boates of Mu≈øketiers to help the ≈øhippe: but before they could come at her, the Engli≈øh ≈øhippe had ≈øhot her vnder water, and wee ≈øaw her ≈øinke into the Sea, with all her ≈øayles vp, and not any thing ≈øeen of her aboue the water. The Engli≈øhmen with their Boate ≈øaued the Captaine and about thirtie others with him, but not one penie worth of the goods, and yet in the ≈øhippe there was at the lea≈øt to the value of two hundred thou≈øand Ducats in Golde, Siluer, and Pearles, the re≈øt of the men were drowned, which might bee about fiftie per≈øons, among the which were ≈øome Fryers and women, which the Engli≈øhmen would not ≈øaue. Tho≈øe that they had ≈øaued they ≈øet on land: and then they ≈øayled away. The twentie ≈øeauenth of the ≈øame month, the ≈øaide fourteene ≈øhips hauing refre≈øhed them≈øelues in the Iland, departed from Tercera towards Saul,
‚Ä¢ nd comming vpon the coa≈øt of Spaine‚ñ™ they were taken by the Engli≈øh ≈øhips, that laye there to watch for them, two onely excepted which e≈øcaped away, & the re≈øt were wholly carried into England.

About the ≈øame time the Earle of Cumberland, with one of the Queenes ≈øhippes, and fiue or ≈øixe more, kept about tho≈øe Ilands and came often times ≈øo clo≈øe vnder the Iland, and to the Road of Angra, that the people on land might ea≈øily tell all his men that hee had a bord, and knew ≈øuch as walked on the Hatches: they of the Ilande not once ≈øhooting at them, although they might ea≈øily haue done it, for they were within Mu≈øket ≈øhotte both of the towne and Fort. In the≈øe places he continued for the ≈øpace of two Moneths, and ≈øayled round about the Ilands, and landed in Gratio≈øa, and Fayael, as in the de≈øcription of tho≈øe Ilands I haue alreadie declared. Here he tooke diuers ≈øhippes and Caruels, which he ≈øent into England: ≈øo that tho≈øe of the Iland, dur≈øt not once put foorth their heads, at the ≈øame time about three or foure daies after the Earle of Cumberland had beene in the Iland of Fayael, and was departed from thence, there arriued in the ≈øaide Iland of Fayael
‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ e Indian ≈øhips, whole Generall was one Iuan Doryne ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ & there they di≈øcharged in the Iland 40. myllions of Gold and Siluer. And hauing with all ≈øpeed refre≈øhed their ≈øhippes, fearing the comming of the Engli≈øhmen, they ≈øet ≈øayle, and arriued ≈øafely in Saint Lucas, not meeting with the enemie, to the great good lucke of the Spaniards and hard fortune of the Engli≈øhmen: for that within le≈ø≈øe then two daies, after the Golde and Siluer was laden againe into the Spani≈øh ≈øhippes, the Earle of Cumberland, ≈øayled againe by that Iland: ≈øo that it appeared that God would not let them haue it, for it they had once had ≈øight thereof, without doubt it had beene theirs, as the Spaniardes them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øed.

In the Moneth of Nouember‚ñ™ there arriued in Tercera two great ≈øhips, which were the Admirall and Viceadmirall of the Fleete laden with Siluer, who with ≈øtormie weather were ≈øeperated from the Fleete‚ñ™ and had beene in great torment and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and readie to ≈øinke: for they were forced to v≈øe all their Pumps: ≈øo that they wi≈øhed a thou≈øand times to haue met with the Engli≈øhmen to whom they would willingly haue giuen their Siluer, and all that euer they brought with them, onely to ≈øaue their liues. And although the Earle of Cumberland, lay ≈øtill aboute tho≈øe Ilands, yet they met not with him ≈øo that after much paine and labour they got into the Road before Angra, where with all ≈øpeed they vnladed, and di≈øcharged aboue fiue myllions of Siluer‚ñ™ all in peeces of 8. and 1 ‚Ä¢
pound great: ≈øo that the whole Raye lay couered with plates and Che≈øts of Siluer, full of Ryales of eight, mo≈øt wonderful to behold: each myllion being 10. hundred thou≈øand Ducats, be≈øides Pearles, Gold, and other ≈øtones,
which were not regi≈øtred. The Admiral and chiefe commaunder of tho≈øe ≈øhippes & Fl√©ete called Aluaro Flores de Quiniones was ≈øicke of the Neapolitan di≈øea≈øe, & was broght to land, whereof not long after he dyed in Syuilia. He brought with him the Kings broad Seale and full authoritie to be Generall and chiefe commaunder vppon the Seas, and of all Fl√©etes or ≈øhips, and of all places and Ilands, or lands where≈øoeuer he came‚ñ™ wherevpon the gouernor of Tercera, did him great honour, and betw√©en them it was concluded, perceiuing the weakne≈ø≈øe of their ≈øhips, and the daunger of the Engli≈øhmen, that they would ≈øend the ≈øhips emptie with Souldiers to conueye them, either to Syuil or Lisbone, where they could fir≈øt arriue, with adui≈øe vnto his Maie≈øtie of all that had pa≈øt, and that he would giue order to fetch the Siluer, with good and ≈øafe conuoy. Whereupon the ≈øaide Aluaro Flores ≈øtayed there, vnder colour of keeping the Siluer, but ≈øpecially becau≈øe of his di≈øea≈øe, and for that they were affraide of the Engli≈øhmen. This Aluaro Flores had alone for his owne part aboue 50. thou≈øand Ducats in Pearles, which hee ≈øhewed vnto vs, and ≈øought to ≈øell them, or barter them with vs for Spices, or bils of exchange. The ≈øaid two ≈øhippes ≈øet ≈øayle with thr√©e or foure hundred men, as well Souldiers as others, that came with them out of India, and being at Sea had a ≈øtorme, wherewith the Admirall bur≈øt and ≈øunke in the Sea, and not one man ≈øaued. The Vice Admirall cut downe her Ma≈øt, and ranne the ≈øhip on ground hard by Sentuual, where it bur≈øt in p√©eces, ≈øome of the men ≈øauing them≈øelues by ≈øwimming, that brought the newes, but the re≈øt were drowned.

In the ≈øame month, there came two great ≈øhips out of the Spani≈øh Indies, and being within halfe a mile of the Road of Tercera, they met with an Engli≈øh ≈øhippe, that after they had fought long together, tooke them both. About 7. or 8. Monthes before, there had b√©ene an Engli≈øh ≈øhippe in Tercera, that vnder the name of a Frenchman came to traffique in the Iland, there to lade woode, & being di≈øcouered was both ≈øhippe and goods confi≈øcated to the Kings v≈øe, and all the men kept pri≈øoners: yet went they vp and downe the ≈øtreetes to get their liuings, by labouring like ≈ølaues, being in d√©ede as ≈øafe in that Iland, as if they had beene in pri≈øon. But in the end vpon a Sunday, all the Saylers went downe behind the hils called Bre≈øil: wher they found a Fi≈øher boate, whereinto they got, & rowed into the Sea to the Earle of Cumberlands ≈øhip, which to their great fortune chanced at that time to come by the Iland, and Ankered with his ≈øhippes about halfe a mile from the Road of Angra, hard by two ≈ømall Ilandes, which lye about a Ba≈øes ≈øhot from the Iland and are full of Goates, Buckes, and ≈øh√©epe, belonging to the inhabitants of the Iland of Tercera. Tho≈øe Saylers knew it well; and thereupon they rowed vnto them with their Boates, and lying at Anker that day, they fetched as many Goates and ≈øh√©epe as they had neede of: which tho≈øe of the towne and of the Iland well ≈øaw and beheld, yet dur≈øt not once goe forth, ≈øo there remained no more on land but the Ma≈øter, & the Marchant, of the ≈øaid Engli≈øh ≈øhip. This Ma≈øter had a brother in lawe dwelling in England, who hauing newes of his brothers impri≈øonment in Tercera, got licence of the Qu√©ene of England, to ≈øet forth a ≈øhip‚ñ™ therewith to ≈ø√©e if hee could recouer his lo≈ø≈øes of the Spaniards, by taking ≈øome of them, and ≈øo to red√©eme his brother, that laye pri≈øoner in Tercera, and he it was, that tooke the two Spani≈øh ≈øhips before the towne. The Ma≈øter of the ≈øhip afore≈øaid, ≈øtanding on the ≈øhore by me, and looking vpon them, for he was my great acquaintance, the ≈øhips being taken, that were worth 300. thou≈øand Ducats, he ≈øent all the men on land ≈øauing only two of the principal Gentlemen, which he kept a borde, therby to ran≈øome his brother: and ≈øent the Pilot of one of the Indian ≈øhips that were taken, with a letter to the Gouernour of Tercera: wherein hee wrote that he ≈øhould deliuer him his brother, and h√©e would ≈øend the two Gentlemen on land: if not, he would ≈øayle with them into England, as indeed he did becau≈øe the Gouernor would not doe it, ≈øaying that the Gentlemen might make that ≈øuite to the King of Spaine him≈øelfe. This Spani≈øh Pilot we bid to ≈øupper with vs, and the Engli≈øhmen likewi≈øe, wher hee ≈øhewed vs all the manner of their fight, much ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mmending the order and manner of the Engli≈øhmens fighting, as al≈øo for their curteous v≈øing of him: but in the end the Engli≈øh Pilote likewi≈øe ≈øtole away in a French ≈øhip, without paying any ran≈øome as yet.

In the month of Ianuarie 159 ‚Ä¢ . there arriued one ≈øhippe alone in Tercera, that came from the Spani≈øh Indies, & brought newes, that there was a Fleete of a hundreth ≈øhippes which put out from ye Firm land of the Spani≈øh Indies and by a ≈øtorme were driuen vpon the coa≈øt called Florida, where they were all ca≈øt away, ≈øhe hauing only e≈øcaped, wherin there were great riches, & many men lo≈øt, as it may well be thought: ≈øo that they made their account that of 22 ‚Ä¢ . ≈øhips, that for certaine were knowne to haue put out of Noua Spa ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ a, Santo Domingo, Hauana, Capoverde, Bra≈øilia, Guinea &c. In the yeare
1589. to ≈øayle for Spaine and Portingall, there were not aboue fourteene or fift√©ene of them arriued there in ≈øafetie, all the re≈øt being either drowned, bur≈øt or taken.

In the ≈øame Moneth of Ianuarie, there arriued in Tercera 15 or 16 ≈øhippes that came from Siuilia, which were mo≈øt Flieboates of the lowe countries, and ≈øome Britons that were arre≈øted in Spain: the≈øe came full of ≈øoldiers, and well appointed with munition, to lade the ≈øiluer that lay in Tercera, and to fetch Aluares de Flores by the kings commandement into Spain. And becau≈øe that tyme of the yeare there is alwaies ≈øtormes about tho≈øe Ilandes, therefore they dur≈øt not enter into the road of Tercera, for that as then it blew ≈øo great a ≈øtorme, that ≈øome of their ≈øhippes that had ankered, were forced to cut downe their ma≈øtes, and were in danger to be lo≈øt: and among the re≈øt a ≈øhippe of B ‚Ä¢ lcay ranne again≈øt the land, and was ≈øtriken in p√©eces, but al the men ≈øaued theÃÑ≈øelues. The other ≈øhippes were forced to keepe the ≈øea, and ≈øeparate them≈øelues one from the other, where wind and weather would driue them, vntill the 15 of March: for that in all that time they could not haue one day of faire weather to anker in, whereby they indured much mi≈øerie, cur≈øing both the ≈øiluer and the Iland. This ≈øtorme being pa≈øt, they chanced to meet with a ≈ømall Engli≈øh ≈øhip of about 40 tunnes in bignes, which by rea≈øon of the great wind could not beare all her ≈øayles: ≈øo they ≈øet vpon her, and tooke her, and with the Engli≈øh flagge in their Admiralles ≈øtern they came as proudly into the hauen, as if they had conquered all the Realme of England: but as the Admirall that bare the Engli≈øh flagge vpon her ≈øterne, was entering into the road, there came by chance two Engli≈øh ≈øhippes by the Iland, that payd her ≈øo well for her paynes, that they were forced to cry Mi≈øericordia ‚ñ™ and without all doubt had taken her, if ≈øhe had bene but a myle further in the ≈øea: but becau≈øe ≈øhe got vnder the Fortre≈ø≈øe, which al≈øo began to ≈øhoot at the Engli≈øhmen, they were forced to leaue her, and to put further into the ≈øea, hauing ≈ølayne 5. or 6. of the Spaniardes. The Engli≈øh men that were taken in the ≈ømall ≈øhippe were put vnder hatches, and coupled in boltes, and after they had beene pri≈øoners three or foure dayes, there was a Spani≈øh En≈øigne-bearer in the ≈øhippe, that had a brother ≈ølayne in the fleet that came for England, who as then, mynding to reuenge his death, and withal to ≈øhew his manhood to the Engli≈øh captiues, that were in the Engli≈øh ≈øhippe, which they had taken, as is afore≈øayd, tooke a poinyard in his hand, and went downe vnder the hatches, where finding the poore Engli≈øhmen ≈øitting in boltes, with the ≈øame poinyard hee ≈øtabbed ≈øixe of them to the heart: which two others of them perceyuing, cla≈øped each other about the middle, becau≈øe they would not bee murthered by him, threw them≈øelues into the ≈øea, and there were drowned. This act was of all the Spaniardes much di≈øliked and verie ill taken, ≈øo that they caryed the Spaniard pri≈øoner vnto Lisbon, where b√©eing ariued, the King of Spaine willed he ≈øhould bee ≈øent into England, that the Queene of England might v≈øe him as ≈øhee thought good: which ≈øentence his friends by intreaty got to be reuer≈øed, notwith≈øtanding he commanded he ≈øhould without all fauor be beheaded: but vpon a good Fryday, the Cardinall going to Ma≈ø≈øe, all the Captaines and Commanders made ≈øo great intreaty for him that in the end they got his pardon. This I thought good to note, that men might vnder≈øtand the bloodie and hone≈øt mindes of the Spaniardes, when they haue men vnder their ≈øubiection.

The ≈øame two Engli≈øh ≈øhippes, which followed the Spani≈øh Admirall, till he had got vnder the Fort of Tercera, as I ≈øaid before, put into the ≈øea, where they met with an other Spani≈øh ≈øhip, b√©eing of the ≈øame Fl√©et, that had likewi≈øe bene ≈øcatered by the ≈øtorme and was onlie mi≈ø≈øing, for the re≈øt lay in the road: this ≈ømall ≈øhippe the Engli≈øhmen tooke, and ≈øent all the men on ≈øhore, not hurting any of them: but if they had knowne, what had beene done vnto the fore≈øaid Engli≈øh captiues, I beleeue they would ≈øoone haue reuenged them≈øelues, as afterwards manie an innocent ≈øoule payed for it. This ≈øhip thus taken by the Engli≈øh men, was the ≈øame that was kept and coÃÑfi≈øcated in the Iland of Tercera, by the Engli≈øh men that got out of the Iland in a fi≈øher boate (as I ≈øayd before) and was ≈øold vnto the Spaniardes, that as then came from the Indies, wherewith they ≈øayled to S. Lucas, where it was al≈øo arre≈øted by the Duke, and appointed to goe in company to fetch the ≈øiluer in Tercera, becau≈øe it was a ≈øhippe that ≈øayled well: but among the ≈øpaniardes fleet it was the meane≈øt of the company. By this meanes it was taken from the Spaniards, and caryed into England, and the owners had it againe, when they lea≈øt thought of it.

The 19 of Marche, the afore≈øaid ≈øhippes, being 19 in nuÃÑber, ≈øet ≈øayle, hauing laden the Kings ≈øiluer, and receiued in Aluaro Flores de Quiniones, with his company, and good proui≈øion of nece≈ø≈øaries, munition and ≈øoldiers, that were fullie re≈øolued (as they made ≈øhewe) to fight valiantly to the la≈øt man, before they would yeeld or lo≈øe their riches: and
although they ≈øet their cour≈øe for S. Lucas, the wind draue them vnto Lisbon, which as it ≈øeemed) was willing by his force to helpe them, and to bring them thether in ≈øafetie: although Aluaro de Flores, hoth again≈øt the wind and weather would perforce haue ≈øayled to Saint Lucas, but being con≈øtrained by the wind, and importunitie of the Saylers, that prote≈øted they would require their lo≈ø≈øes and damages of him‚ñ™ he was content to ≈øayle to Lisbone: from whence the Siluer was by land carried into Siuilia. At Cape Saint Vincent, there lay a Fleete of twentie Engli≈øh ≈øhippes, to watch for the Armada, ≈øo that if they had put into Saint Lucas, they had fallen right into their handes, which if the wind had ≈øerued they had done. And therefore they may ≈øay that the wind had lent them a happie Viage: for if the Engli≈øhmen had met with them‚ñ™ they had ≈øurely beene in great danger, and po≈ø≈øibly but few of them had e≈ø
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ped, by rea≈øon of the feare wherewith they were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, becau≈øe fortune or rather God ‚Ä¢ as wholly again≈øt them. Which is a ≈øufficient cau≈øe to make ye Spaniards out of hart, to the contrarie to giue the Engli≈øhmen more courage, and to make them bolder for that they are victorious, ≈øtout and valiant: and ≈øeeing al their enterpri≈øes doe take ≈øo good effect, that thereby they are become Lordes and ma≈øters of the Sea, and neede care for no man, as it well appeareth, by this briefe di≈øcour≈øe.
15 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .In the month of March 15 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . There was a bla≈øing Starre with a tayle ≈øeene in „Äà‚óä„Äâ , that continued foure nights together, ≈øtretching the taile towards the South.

In the Month of May, a Caruel of Fay
‚Ä¢
arriued at Tercera, in the Hauen or Roade of Angra, laden with Oxen, ≈øheepe, Hennes, and all other kinds of victuals, and full of people, which by a ≈øtorme had broken her Ruther whereby the Sea ca≈øt her about and therewith ≈øhee ≈øunke, and in her were drowned three children, and a Frier Franci≈øcan, the re≈øt of the men ≈øaued them≈øelues by ≈øwimming, and by helpe from the ≈øhore, but all the Cattle and Hennes came drowned to land: the Frier was buried with a great proce≈ø≈øion and ≈øolemnitie, e≈øteeming him for a Saint, becau≈øe hee was taken vp dead with his Booke between his armes: for the which cau≈øe euery man came to looke on him as a myracle, giuing gret offerings to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øes for his ≈øoule.

The fir≈øt of Augu≈øt, the Gouernour of Tercera, reeceiued adui≈øe out of Portingall and Spaine, that two yeares before the date of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , there were ≈øayled out of England „Äà‚óä„Äâ great ≈øhippes wel apointed, with full re≈øolution to take their fourme, ≈øeuen of them into the Portingall Indies, and the other fiue to Ma ‚Ä¢ : of the which fiue, two were ca≈øt away in pa≈ø≈øing the Straightes of Magellane ‚Ä¢ , and three ≈øayled to Malac ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
but what they had done there‚ñ™ was as then not knowne. The other ≈øeuen pa≈ø≈øed the Cape de Bona Speranza, and arriued in India, where they put into the coa≈øt of Malabar, and there tooke ≈øixe Foi≈øtes of the Malabares, but let them goe againe: and two Turki≈øh Gallies, that came out of the Straightes of Mecca or the redde Sea, to whome likewi≈øe they did no hurt. This Emperour Pre≈øtor Iohn is not rightly named, for that his name is Belgian, Bel ≈øignifying the highe≈øt, perfecte≈øt, and excellente≈øt of all things, and Gian Lorde, or Prince, which is proper to all that commaund or gouerne ouer others: ≈øo then Belgian ≈øignifieth the chiefe or highe≈øt Prince, which name being ≈øo ioyned, is proper to none but to the king, hauing al≈øo a ≈øurname of Dauid, as our Emperours the name of Cae≈øar or Augu≈øtus.

Here I mu≈øt alittle di≈øcour≈øe of the riuer Nylus, which hath not her i≈ø≈øue in Belgians land, neither from the hilles of the Moone, nor as Ptolomeus ≈øaith, from the two lakes which he placeth in the midle between ea≈øt and wea≈øt, with the di≈øtance of almo≈øt foure hundred and fiftie Italian miles one from the other, for that vnder the ≈øame pole wher in Ptolomeus placeth the ≈øaide two lakes, lieth the two kingdoms of Congo and Angola, towardes the wea≈øt, and on the other ≈øide towards the ea≈øt the kingdome of Monomotapa and Sofala, with di≈øtance from the one ≈øea to the other of about twelue hundred Italian miles: and Odoardus ≈øaieth, that in the≈øe countries there is but one lake, which lieth on the bordures of Angola, and Monomotapa, which is in bigne≈ø≈øe about a hundred ninety fiue Italian miles: of the which lake wee are well a≈ø≈øured, and truely certified by tho≈øe of Angola, but on the ea≈øt ≈øide of Sofala and Monomotapa, there is no mention made of any other lake, whereby it may be ≈øaide, that vnder the ≈øame degrees there is no other lake. True it is that there are yet two other lakes, but they lie clean contrary to tho≈øe whereof Ptolomeus writeth, for hee (as I ≈øaide before) placeth his lakes right in the middle betweene ea≈øt and wea≈øt, and tho≈øe whereof I ≈øpeake, lie right by direct line betweene north and ≈øouth, di≈øtant about foure hundred miles.
