Some men in tho≈øe countries are of opinion, that Nilus ≈øpringeth out of the fir≈øt lake, and then againe hideth it ≈øelfe vnder the earth, and i≈ø≈øue out againe in another place, which ≈øome men deny, and Odoardus ≈øaith that right the opinion therein is, that Nylus pa≈ø≈øeth not vnder the earth, but that it runneth through certayne fearefull and de≈øart valleis, where no man commeth or inhabiteth, (without anye certaine channell) and ≈øo it is ≈øayd that it runneth vnder the earth.

Therefore it is mo≈øt certaine that Nyl ‚Ä¢
floweth out of the fir≈øt ≈øake, which lieth vnder twelue degrees, by the pole antartike, which lake is almo≈øt compa≈ø≈øed about with hils, whereof tho≈øe that lie ea≈øtward, are called Ca ‚Ä¢ ates, with rockes of Saltpeeter, and of ≈øiluer on the one ≈øide, and on the other ≈øide hilles, through the which Nylus de≈øcendeth about foure hundred miles right north, and then runneth into an other lake that is greater, which the inhabitantes doe call a Sea or Meere, becau≈øe it is greater than the other, being in breadth about twoo hundred and twentie miles, lying right vnder the equinoctiall line. Of this ≈øecond lake we are truely aduerti≈øed by the people of Arzich ‚Ä¢
the which bordure vppon Congo, who traffiking in that country reporte, that in that lake there are people that do ≈øaile in great ≈øhippes, that can write, v≈øing weights and mea≈øures, which they haue not in the bordures of Congo, which al≈øo build their hou≈øes of ≈øtone and chalke as it groweth in the earth, much like the people of Portingale, whereby it may be ≈øaide, that Pre≈øtor Iohns land is not farre from thence. Out of this ≈øecond lake afore≈øaide, the riuer Nylus runneth to the I≈øland of Meroe, being di≈øtant from the lake 240. Dutch miles (whereunto other Riuers haue their cour≈øe, as the riuer of Colues, &c. lying on the bordures of Melinde,) and comming to the ≈øaide I≈øland of Meroe, it diuideth it ≈øelfe in two partes, compa≈ø≈øing about a high land called Meroe: on the right ≈øide of Meroe towardes the ea≈øt runneth an other riuer called Abagni, ≈øpringing out of the lake Bracina, which riuer runneth through Pre≈øtor Iohns land to the ≈øaide I≈øland: and on the other ≈øide towardes the we≈øt runneth other riuers, among the which is Saraboe. This riuer entring into Nilus, and running about the I≈øland of Meroe, runne together in a broder ≈øtreame through Ethiopia, which is called Ethiopia, lying aboue Egypt, and reacheth to the de≈øcending thereof, where the riuer Nylus, meeteth againe with both the ≈øtreames, together, in a high valley, and ≈øo with a great fall runs to the I≈øland of Siene, with ≈øo horrible a noy≈øe, that the people thereabouts by that means are mo≈øt part deafe, and thence running through Egypt, it watereth al the countrey, and maketh it fruitfull, and from thence runneth into the Mediterranean ≈øea, right ouer again≈øt Cipres, and that with two notable ≈øtreames, be≈øides others, whereof one at
Ro≈ø≈øetto a dayes iourny from Alexandria runneth into the ≈øea, the other at Pelu≈øio, now called Damiata: ≈øo that hereby I conclude, that the riuer Nylus in Egypt, the riuer Zaire in Congo, and the riuer Nigri in E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iopia‚ñ™ are the cau≈øes of the fruitfulne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe countries: al at one time increa≈øing and ouerflowing, by meanes of the exceeding great raines, that for the ≈øpace of fiue moneths do continually fall in the countrie of Congo, and the places borduring on the ≈øame. Touching the coa≈øt of Aden, the coa≈øt of Arabia Felix, and the country running along by the gulfe of Per≈øia, vntil you come to Goa, it is ≈øufficiently already declared in this booke, whereunto I refer you.

div.head: The de≈øcription of America, and the ≈øeuerall partes thereof,

argument.p: as, Noua Francia, Florida, the I≈ølandes called Antillas, Iucaya, Cuba, Iamaica, &c. with the ≈øituations, degrees, and length, how farre they are di≈øtant one from the other: likewi≈øe the fruitfulnes and ab ‚Ä¢ undance of bea≈øts, birdes, fi≈øhes, and fruits of the ≈øame countreyes, with the manners fa≈øhions, apparrels, and religions, together with the principall actions of the people inhabiting therein.

When the authour of this booke, as al≈øo the Printer, had be≈øtowed and v≈øed great labor and charges herein, to ≈øet forth ≈øome perfect Cardes of America, becau≈øe that often times the Indian ≈øhippes in their ≈øailing out, or returning home, do fall vpon tho≈øe coa≈øts, ≈øpecially Bra≈øilia, which herein is mo≈øt di≈øcouered, they thought it expedient therewith to place a briefe di≈øcription of the ≈øame countries, thereby to ≈øhew the readers the principall places therein, whereunto at this day mo≈øt ≈øhips do traffike, hoping they wil take it in good part.

div.p: THe fourth parte of the world, which at this day we cal America, or we≈øt India, was becau≈øe of the great di≈øtance vnknowne to the ancient Co≈ømographers til the yeare of our Lord 1492. that Chri≈øtopherus Columbus a Geneuois di≈øcouered the ≈øame, and fiue yeeres after that one Americus Ve≈øpacio, by the King of Ca≈øtilliaes commandement, ≈øailed thither, and called al the countrey America after his owne name, and for the greatnes therof, is al≈øo called, the new world, reaching as Po≈øtillus is of opinion, from the one pole to the other, beeing diuided by the ≈øtraigths of Magellana, where it endeth vnder 52. degrees on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctial line. This countrie by diuers men is diuer≈øly parted, ≈øome making it a parte of the whole worlde, and cal it the fourth part by the name of America: others make out of that countrey in generall, two other parts of the world, diuiding the world in ≈øixe parts, as A≈øia, Affrica, Europe, Mexicana, or the new Spaine, Peruana, and Magellanica, as the ≈øixt part which as yet is but litle di≈øcouered: others diuide it into three parts, in Peru, newe Spain, others Mexico, & new France. They that fir≈øt found it, accounted it but for one part, after that, the Spaniardes di≈øcouering more land, diuided it into two parts, into Mexico, (or new Spaine) and Peru: after that the Frenchmen di≈øcouering more countreyes, called that which they di≈øcouered Noua Frauncia, which in time beeing by the Spanniardes, woonne from the Frenchmen, was accounted for a p√©ece of newe Spaine: at the la≈øt the ≈øtraights of Magellana being founde out, was by Petrus Plantius, a mini≈øter of the worde of God, added as a ≈øixt parte, but becau≈øe our Card extendeth no further then to certaine limits of Noua Frauncia, namely to the prouince or countrey of Florida, we wil not ≈øpeake much of the re≈øt, and proceede with the other partes, with certaine Ilandes in our Carde, called Antillas or foure landes, becau≈øe they lie before the firme lande, defending and couering the ≈øame, as a henne with her wings couereth her chickens.

The land then which ≈øtretcheth towards
the pole Arcticum, or northward is called new Fraunce, for that in Anno 1524.
‚Ä¢ 524. Iohannes Verrazanus of Florence, being ≈øent by the King and Queene mother of France into the new world, did almo≈øt di≈øcouer al that coa≈øt, beginning from Propicus Cancri, about 24. degrees, til he came to 50. degrees, and ≈øomewhat further into the north, where he erected the French ≈øtandard, ≈øo that from thenceforth that countrey was called by the name of Noua Frauncia, and Villagagno Frauncia Antarctica. The breadth of this countrey is from 24. degrees to 54. degrees towardes the North. The length from 280. to 330. miles, whereof the Ea≈øt part by the writers in the≈øe dayes, is called Norumbega, reaching to the gulfe Gamus, where it is ≈øeperated from Canada. About this land, which is not le≈ø≈øe in compa≈ø≈øe then Europa, or whole Chri≈øtendome, lie diuers I≈ølands, & among the re≈øt Terra di Laborador, ≈øtretching towards Groenland, whether diuers ≈øhips, both Spaniards, French, and Engli≈øh, do often times re≈øort, ≈øeeking ≈øome pa≈ø≈øage through the ≈øame to enter into the Ea≈øt Indies, but al in vaine, for the mo≈øt part con≈øuming and de≈øtroying them≈øelues therein, & found much ice and ≈ønow. The people of this I≈øland are wel proportioned of bodie and limbes, wel made, and fitte to labour: they paint their bodyes, thereby to ≈øeeme faire, and weare ≈øiluer and Copper rings in their eares, their apparrel is ≈øpeckled furres and marternes, and ≈øuch like, in winter they weare the furs inward, and in ≈øummer outward, like the Lapelanders and Vinnen: they gird them≈øelues with cotteÃÑ girdles or with fi≈øh ≈økins, and ≈øuch like things: their cheefe foode is fi≈øh, ≈øpecially Salmon, although they haue both birdes and fruit inough: their hou≈øes are made of w ‚Ä¢ od, whereof they haue great quantities, and couered with the ≈økinnes of bea≈øtes or fi≈øhes. In this land are griffons, white beares, and birdes. There is a countrey vnder 44. degrees and a halfe, called Baccalao, taking the name of ≈øome kind of fi≈øhes, which thereabouts are ≈øo aboundant, that they let the ≈øhippes from ≈øailing. This countrey of Baccalaos reacheth nine hundred miles, that is, from the Cape de Baccala ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
to F ‚Ä¢ orida, which is accounted in this ≈øort, from the point of Baccalao to the bay of the riuer, are 70. miles, froÃÑ the bay of the Riuer, to the bay de los I≈ølos, 70. miles, from thence to Rio Fundo 70. miles, from thence to Cabo Baxo 160. miles, and again to the riuer of Saint Anthony. 100. miles, from thence to the furthe≈øt Cape 180. miles, and againe to the Cape of ≈øaint Elena, 110. miles, and from Saint Elena to the poynt of Canauerall, or the Reedlyooke 100. miles, then to Florida 40. miles, which is in all nine hundred miles, which is the greatnes of this land, whereof the lea≈øt latitude from the Equinoctial line is 48. degrees and a halfe: this country both on the ≈øea coa≈øt and otherwi≈øe, is verie populous, and like the low countries, becau≈øe it lyeth in a corner. This Land hath many I≈ølandes lying about it, as Curia, Regia, Baya Bica Stella, the Cape of Hope, and the Brittons Cape. Before you come to Florida, the prouince Cichora, lyeth by the Riuer Iordan, and another hard by it, called Guada Lupa. The we≈øt ≈øide of Noua Frauncia hath diuers prouinces now di≈øcouered, as Quiui a, ‚Ä¢ euola, A≈øtaclan, Tethchichimichi. The ≈øouth ≈øide of Florida is called by the Spaniards Floridum Pa≈øcha, becau≈øe Iohannes Pontio Legionen≈øi founde it out on Ea≈øter day, in Anno 1512. and not becau≈øe of the greenne≈ø≈øe and budding of the trees in the ≈øame land, as Theue ‚Ä¢
writeth. The north ≈øide of noua Frauncia is as yet not di≈øcouered, and becau≈øe our Carde di≈øcouereth no further then to Florida, we wil begin therwith, and de≈øcribe ≈øome part of the ≈øituation thereof, becau≈øe it is worthie memorie, as beeing a place wherein many Spaniards & Frenchmen haue lo≈øt their liues, as al≈øo becau≈øe it is the fir≈øt, & be≈øt knowne of al new France, whereunto the Frenchmen haue v≈øed to ≈øaile, and therein in the time of Charles the ninth, had a certaine fort, which was called by his name, Charles burg ‚Ä¢ , but was after taken by the Spaniards, and al the Frenchmen ≈ølaine, contrary to their fayth and promi≈øe, ≈øpecially ≈øuch as yeelded them≈øelues into their hands. But becau≈øe my meaning is not to recite hi≈øtories, I remit the reader to the bookes which make mention thereof. Florida hath a Cape lying far into the ≈øea ≈øtretching Southward, in maner of a tong reaching an hundred miles, the mea≈øure being taken from the lowe≈øt northerne corner, to the ≈øouth poynt. This Cape or hooke as I ≈øayde, is long and narrow, like Italy: in length an hundred miles, and in breadth twentie or fiftie miles, where it is broade≈øt. On the Ea≈øt ≈øide it hath the I≈ølands of C ‚Ä¢
ehora Banama, and Lucaya, on the we≈øt ≈øide towardes Spaine and the gulfe of Mexico, it is diuided from new Spaine, by the land of Anauaca. On the north ≈øide it bordureth on the firme land, it lieth right again≈øt the point towards the ≈øouth: 25. miles into the ≈øea, lieth the famous I≈øland Cuba, otherwi≈øe called I≈øabell ‚Ä¢ : the ≈øea that runneth between this poynt of Florida and Iuc ‚Ä¢ tan,
is called Mare Catayum, by other, the gulfe of Ferdinando Corto≈øi, or the gulfe of Florida, or of Mexico. It is a flat lande, wherein are many riuers, which moy≈øture the land, and make it fertile, the ≈øea ≈øide being ≈øandie, whereon there groweth diuers pine trees, without nuts or ≈øhels, al≈øo many acornes, wild cherries, mulberies, che≈ønuts, but ranker of ta≈øte then oures in the≈øe countreyes, many Ma≈øtike, Cedars, Cipres, Bayes, & Palme trees, Nuls, and wild vines, which grow vppon the trees that are next them, bringing forth grapes that are good to be eaten, al≈øo a certain fruit of Medlars, greater and better then ours, there are al≈øo plums verie faire to behold, but not good of ta≈øte: there are al≈øo Framboi≈øen or Hinnebe≈øien, and ≈øome verie ≈ømall round berries, of a plea≈øant ta≈øte, not much vnlike our Clappe beries: there groweth rootes which in their ≈øpeech they cal Hatle, whereof in time of dearth they make bread. Fourefooted bea≈øts are there likewi≈øe in great aboundance, as Harts, Hinds, rain Deare, Goats, Beares, Leopards, Fores, & many kind of Wolues, wild Dogs, Hares, Conies &c. Their birds are Peacocks, Partriges, Parrats, Pigeons, ring Doues, Turtledoues, Meerelens, Crowes, Hauks, FalcoÃÑs, Marlens, hearns, Cranes, Storkes, wild Gee≈øe, Ducks, water Rauens, white, red, & blacke, and a≈øh coloured, Reighures and many other water foules, & Crocadiles in ≈øo great aboundance, that it is incredible, which ofteÃÑ times do eat and deuoure men ≈øwimming in the water: there are likewi≈øe many kindes of ≈ønakes, and a certain kind of bea≈øt not much vnlike the lion in Affrica.

Golde and ≈øiluer wherewith they traffike, they haue it (as they ≈øay) out of the ≈øhips which fal on ground vpon the Cape, which is not vnlikely, becau≈øe mo≈øt of the ≈øhips are ca≈øt away vpon that Cape ≈øo that there is more money thereabout, then in the north parts. They ≈øaid likewi≈øe that in the hils Apalatcyaeris, there is gold to bee found: in this countrie al≈øo groweth the roote China, which by meanes of the Emperour Charles, hath gotten a great report, and is much v≈øed by phi≈øitions, which ≈øome al≈øo v≈øe to heale the French pocks. Be≈øides al the≈øe things afore≈øaid, there are diuers ≈øortes of ≈øeedes and hearbes, whereof many kindes of collours are made, very profitable for painters: the inhabitants knowe well how to v≈øe them, therewith to die al kindes of leather. The people are in a manner a black yellow, and euil fauoured, yet ≈øtrong, of good proportion of bodie. They couer their members with verie faire dre≈øt hart ≈økins: mo≈øt part of them paint their bodies, and al≈øo their armes and thighes, with many figures, which colour wil not off, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee wa≈øhed, it is ≈øo printed and ≈øunke into the fle≈øh: they haue black haire downe to theyr hippes, being long, which they verie cunningly bind vp: in their dealings they are wholly light, and not to bee credited, but verie bolde and valiant in armes, and in the warres, wherein they v≈øe bowes and arrowes, whereof the ≈øhafts are made of hartes, goates, or ≈økinnes finely painted, and ≈øo cunningly wrought, that in the≈øe countries they cannot be mended, and in ≈øteede of heades, they take fi≈øhes teeth, or ≈øharp peeces of wood: they exerci≈øe their boyes in leaping, ≈øhooting in bowes, and playing with balles: they haue great delight in hunting and fi≈øhing: their kings holde continuall warres, not ≈øparing any of theyr enemies, if they ouercome them, but pre≈øently cutte off theyr heades to bee no more troubled with them: which comming home, they ≈øet vp in certaine places for a triumph and victory. Women and children they will not hurt, but keepe and nouri≈øh them among them: and returning from theyr warres, they call all theyr ≈øubiects together, where for the ≈øpace of three dayes, they doo nothing but banket and make good cheere, with ≈øinging and dauncing.

To the olde women that are among them, they giue the ≈økinne and the haire of the heades of their enemies that are cutte off, compelling them to daunce, and ≈øing ≈øongs in pray≈øe and thank≈øgiuing to the Sunne, as hauing by his meanes obtained victorie. They haue no Religion, nor any knowledge of the true and liuing God, but in ≈øteede of him, (as other Americans) they honour the Sunne and the Moone. They feare theyr Prie≈øtes, and put great credite in them, becau≈øe they are great coniurers, ≈øouth≈øayers, and inuocaters of Diuelles, which by mo≈øt feareful meanes they cau≈øe to appeare.

Their prie≈øtes are likewi≈øe theyr phi≈øitions and ≈øurgeons, for the which cau≈øe they v≈øe continually to beare a ≈øacke full of hearbes and ≈øalues to heale theyr ≈øicke people with, for the mo≈øt parte haue the pocks, as beeing verie hot of nature, and much addicted to lecherie, whereby often times they v≈øe women, maydes, children and Boyes. Euerie man hath but one wife, onely the king, to whome it is permitted to haue twoo or three, but with this condition, that the fir≈øt hee marrieth ≈øhall bee honoured before
the re≈øt, and onely holden for Qu√©ene, and her children to inherite his goods, and to be heires of the crowne. The women doo al the worke about their hou≈øes, and when they are once with child, their hu≈øbands neuer deale with them vntill they be deliuered, and eate no meate of their dre≈ø≈øing, at ≈øuch time as they haue their flowers. Be≈øides this, al the countrey is ful of Flermophroditers, which of nature are both man and woman, tho≈øe are kept to labour, and to carrie their munition and weapons when they go to warres: they paint their faces, and put certaine birds feathers into their haires, thereby to ≈øeeme the fairer and more fearful. Their proui≈øion of virtuals is bread and Meele of wheate and hony: they ro≈øt their Meele of Maiz, becau≈øe it may continue the longer, & cau≈øe ≈øome broiled fi≈øh dried to be carried with theÃÑ. In time of dearth they eate many bad things, putting ≈øande and coales among their meale. When they go to warres the king goeth fir≈øt, hauing in one hand a ≈øtaffe, in the other a bow, with arrowes in a ca≈øe hanging on his ≈øhoulder: the re≈øt follow him with bowes and arrowes, either in ca≈øes or el≈øe ≈øtucke in their haire: at their meeting with the enemie, and al≈øo in fight, they v≈øe great and fearefull cries, like other Barbarians, Turkes, and Tartarians. They neuer beginne war before they haue taken coun≈øell together, meeting about it in the morning: in which their a≈ø≈øemblies they v≈øe a very ≈øtrange cu≈øtome, which is to be noted, for that being a≈ø≈øembled, they lette them≈øelues downe on both ≈øides of the king, in maner of a half Moone, the king ≈øitting alone in the middle of them vppon a ≈øtoore made of nine peeces of round wood, higher then the re≈øt, that hee may bee knowne, which done, they come and do him honour, ≈øaluting him, the olde≈øt beginning fir≈øt, and lifting their handes aboue theyr heades, ≈øpeake and ≈øay, Ha, He. Ya, Ha, Ha: the re≈øt an≈øwering Ha. Ha which done, each man ≈øitteth downe. And if there be any matter of great importance to bee handled, the king cau≈øeth the prie≈øts (by them called lauas and the auncients to be ≈øent for, a≈øking their aduice, meane time he cau≈øeth certain women to ≈øeethe Cacinam, which is a certain drink pre≈øt out of leaues, which being ≈øodden and clarified, the king being ≈øet with his Lords & others, each man in his place, there commeth one in pre≈øence of them all, and lifting vp his hands, and ble≈ø≈øing, and wi≈øhing them al good lucke, filleth a cuppe of mother of pearle, ful of that hot drinke, which he fir≈øt pre≈øenteth to the king, which hauing drunke, he willeth him giue it to the re≈øt. This drinke they make great a ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ at of, and giue it not to any man that ≈øitteth in councell, before he hath ≈øhewed ≈øome valiant act in the fielde again≈øt the enemie: which drinke is of ≈øuch force, that pre≈øently after they haue drunke it, „Äà‚óä„Äâ maketh them ≈øweate, and ≈øuch as drinke it „Äà‚óä„Äâ it vp againe, are not imployed in an great affaires, nor may not ≈øerue as Captaine or other officer in the fielde, as being vnfit for ≈øuch a place, for that when they are in the field they mu≈øt of force often times fa≈øt two or three dayes together, to the which ende this drinke is verie good, for that who≈øoeuer drinketh it, may wel fa≈øt foure and twentie houres after, and neither eate nor drinke: wherefore when they go to warre, they cau≈øe the Hern o ‚Ä¢ hrediter to carry diuers bottles of that drinke with them, which ≈øu≈øtaineth, feedeth, and ≈øtrengthneth the body, not once making their heades ‚Ä¢ le nor light. They ≈øow their wheate twice euerie yeare, that is, in the moneths of March and Iune, & all vpon our land, in three moneths being ripe and readie to reape. The other ≈øixe moneths they let the earth he vntitled: they haue very great Pumptans, melons, & very good beanes: they neuer dung their ground, but burne off the Stubble, which in the ≈øixe monethes con≈øumeth, and with tho≈øe a≈øhes fatten the ground, as they do us ≈øome places of Italy, they plow and dig vp their ground with a woodden ≈øpit or ≈øhouel, and throw two or three graines of wheate into one hole, as wee v≈øe to ≈øet beanes or pea≈øe: when their corne is to be ≈øowed, the king ≈øendeth one of his ≈øeruants to a≈ø≈øemble the people, that they may plow and dig the earth, and then cau≈øeth much of the afore≈øaide drinke to be made, to giue it to the labourers. The wheate being reaped, they carrie it into a common barne, or place made for the purpo≈øe, whereof euerie man according to his de≈øert hath a parte. They ≈øow no more then nece≈ø≈øarily wil ≈øerue, keeping the re≈øt to ≈øerue theÃÑ for the ≈øix months wherein they ≈øow not, and for longer time they prouide not: al≈øo euerie yeare in winter time they withdraw them≈øelues into the woods for three or foure moneths together, continuing there in certaine places made of Palme tree branches, meane time feeding vpon Acornes, fle≈øh of Darts, fi≈øh, and oy≈øters, peacocks, and other foules. All their meate is broyled vpon coales, making it ≈øomewhat hard, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømoke and extreame heate: among other meate, they are verie de≈øirous of Crocodiles fle≈øh, which ≈øheweth very white and faire like veale, but ta≈øteth like rotten Mo≈øchus:
if any man be ≈øicke, in ≈øt√©ed of letting bloud, their prie≈øts do ≈øuck the place where their paine lyeth, vntil the bloud doth i≈ø≈øue forth.

The women in Florida are great and verie wi≈øe, and coloured like men, and pinked on their bodies, legges, and armes, putting ≈øuch colour into the places, that will not ea≈øily come forth: but the women kind when they come fir≈øt into the world, are not ≈øo blacke, but verie white: the blacke yellowi≈øh colour is made vpon them by a certaine oyntment, as the Tartarians and other heathens v≈øe to do, which oyntment they v≈øe to make of a certaine ceremoniall oyle by them v≈øed. Their colour likewi≈øe changeth becau≈øe they go naked, and with the burning heate of the ≈øunne. The women likewi≈øe are verie quicke and ≈øubtile, like the women of Egypt, and can ≈øwim ouer great riuers, holding their children fa≈øt vnder one of their armes, and will likewi≈øe climbe vppe the highe≈øt trees that are in all tho≈øe countries.

The chiefe prouinces in Florida, which the Spaniards, both in the beginning, and ≈øince at other times haue founde out, are the≈øe: fir≈øt Panuca, lying on the borders of Noua Spaigna, di≈øcouered by Franco de Gray, in An. 1518. 1518. who left many ≈øpaniards bohind him, being ≈ølaine, eaten and deuoured by the wild people, who≈øe ≈økinnes being dryed, they hung for a memorie and euerla≈øting triumph in their Iools Temples. Tho≈øe people are verie vncha≈øte, and helde open ≈øtewes, where by night they meete and lie together. They bore holes in their no≈øes, and al≈øo in their eares, to hang rings at theÃÑ: they ≈øcrape their teeth to make them cleane, and marrie not before they be fortie yeares of age, although their daughters are deflowred at the age of ten or twelue yeeres. There are in Florida other prouinces, as Anauares, Albardao≈øia, Iagua≈øia, Apalachia, Autia, Samouia, and diuers others, al ob≈øeruing one kinde of religion & cu≈øtomes, wholly without any feare of God, pollicie, manline≈ø≈øe, or rea≈øon. The be≈øt and fruitfulle≈øt part of Florida bordereth on Noua Spaigna, to the riuer and prouince of Panuca, which riuer runneth with ≈øo great a ≈øtreame into the ≈øea, that it is a verie good hauen for ≈øhips.

div.head: Here followeth the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt of Florida, fora≈ømuch as is contained in the Carde hereunto annexed.
div.p:
THe length of the furthe≈øt poynt of Terra di Laborador, vnto the Cape of Saint Elena, lying in Florida, is before declared, nowe ≈øhall follow that which is furder ≈øette downe in the Carde, beginning from Saint Elena, which lyeth vnder 32. degrees: This is a verie faire and broade riuer, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing al others what≈øoeuer in the north coa≈øtes: wherefore by the Frenchmen it is called Porto Real or kingly hauen, hauing found it to be tenne ≈øeadom water: about this riuer there are many woods of Dakes and Ceder tr√©es, wherein are many Harts and other wilde bea≈øtes, and Peacocks. The mouth of the riuer is three miles broade, and hath two Capes or hookes of land, one ≈øtretching We≈øt, the other North: vppon this riuer the Frenchmen haue built a fort, called Charles fort: ≈øome ≈øay this riuer runneth vnto the riuer Iordan, and ≈øo into the other ≈øea. Betw√©ene both the≈øe hookes of lande, in the mouth of the Riuer, there lieth a fayre I≈øland full of trees: from Saint Elena to Rio Secco, is fortie Spani≈øh miles, whereof ≈øeuent√©ene and a halfe make a degree, and this Riuer lieth vnder 31. degrees: from Rio Secco to Santa Cioce, and from thence to the point of Cannaueral, which lyeth vnder 20. degr√©es, are forty miles. Here I mu≈øt pau≈øe a while, & follow the Frenchmens rule, becau≈øe this countrey was likewi≈øe di≈øcouered and al≈øo de≈øcribed by them. So then the Frenchmen recon from Saint Elena, ≈øayling ≈øouthward along the coa≈øt foure French miles, where you come to the Riuer Magnus, or Grandis that is the great Riuer: then Guade or as it is in our Carde Guate, and further Bellum or Bellus, from thence to Gironda, then to Garumna, and ≈øo to Charenta, from Charenta, to Ligetim, or the Loire, ≈øixe miles, from Loire to Axona in the mouth whereof lyeth an I≈øland, in our Carde called Rio di S. Pero, from Axona to Sequana or Seine, becau≈øe it was like the riuer that runneth throgh Paris vnto Roan, lieth ≈øixe miles, and all the≈øe nine riuers lie within the ≈øpace of ≈øixtie French miles, leauing the Seine, and ≈øailing ≈øouthward by the ≈øhore, you pa≈ø≈øe certaine ≈ømall Riuers, as Ay & Serrauahi, then you come to the great Riuer Maius (≈øo called by the Frenchmen) that is the Riuer of May, becau≈øe it was found by one Landometo vpon the fir≈øt day of May, and is di≈øtant from Sequana or Seine 14. miles: thereabout grew certaine redde and white mulberie tr√©es, vppon the highe≈øt branches whereof, hung great numbers of ≈øilke wormes: from this riuer you come to a gulfe that reacheth ≈øomewhat inward into the land, beeing the place where Landonerius fir≈øt arriued, when hee ≈øayled out of France into tho≈øe countreyes, and there hee ≈øaw in the mouth
of a certaine riuer, many ≈øea Swine or Dolphins, wherevpon he called the ≈øame Riuer by the name of tho≈øe Dolphins: on the South ≈øide of the gulfe lyeth the French Cape, about thirtie degrees from the line, ≈øo called becau≈øe the Frenchmen did fir≈øt land there. This Cape is not high, but a flatte ≈øtrand, al ful of high trees and thick woods. From the French Cape you come to Cannaueral, another Cape, fiue & thirtie miles di≈øtant, taking the name form the reeds that grow thereon. The Spaniards and al≈øo our Carde doo not ≈øet downe many of the≈øe Riuers, and the greate≈øt parte of them that are de≈øcribed, are altered in their names, for the Riuer of May by them is called Maranca, the Seine Saint Augu≈øtin, the Ga ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mna S. Matheo, & the great riuer S. Pero. From Cannauer ‚Ä¢ l to the cape of Florida are fortie miles, and betweene the≈øe two Capes lie many flats. The cape of Florida lyeth vnder fiue and twentie degrees, and before it lie many cliffes, which they name Martires or Ma ‚Ä¢ ti ‚Ä¢ s, and on the other ≈øides litle I≈ølands, called Te≈øtudines, that is Torteaux, becau≈øe they are in forme like tho≈øe kindes of bea≈øts. The Cape of Florida is in breadth twentie miles, and from thence to Ancon B ‚Ä¢ xo are 100. miles, and lieth fifty miles ea≈øt and we≈øt from Rio Secco, which is the breadth of Florida.

div.head: The de≈øcription of ≈øome I≈ølands that lie ouer again≈øt the coa≈øt of Florida.
div.p:
FIr≈øt you mo≈øt note that the whole coa≈øt of Florida is ful of I≈ølands, cliffes, banks, flattes, and ≈øuch like dangerous places, and as touching the I≈ølandes, they are at the lea≈øt foure hundreth in number, be≈øides the great I≈øland called Luca ‚Ä¢ ae, that giueth the name to al the re≈øt, and Bahama, which lie al north from C ‚Ä¢ ba, and ≈øaint Do ‚Ä¢ inic ‚Ä¢ . The common opinion is, that the≈øe I≈ølandes were all one land, and ioyned to the great I≈øland, and by the force of the ≈øea ≈øeperated one from the other, as it is thought of I ‚Ä¢ aly and Cici ‚Ä¢ ia. They lie vnder ≈øeuenteene and eighteene degrees: the people of tho≈øe I≈ølands are whiter, and better proportioned then tho≈øe of Cuba, and Spaignuola ≈øpecially the women that are verie faire, for the which cau≈øe many of the firme land went thither to dwel, as from Florida, Cachora, and Iucatan, becau≈øe there they founde more plea≈øure among the people, then in other I≈ølands, and great difference in their ≈øpeech, whereupon hath ri≈øen the common opinion, that in tho≈øe I≈ølands the Amazons did dwell (beeing women that burnt their right brea≈øts, the better to ≈øhoote in bowes, when they went to fight again≈øt their enemies) and that there was a fountaine that made olde women yong. The men go naked, onely when they go to wars, and when they keepe any fea≈øtes, or v≈øe to dance, then they put on a certaine cotten garment, and other garments of diuers coloured feathers, finely wrought, with a great plume of feathers on their heades. Touching the women, they haue verie ≈øtrange cu≈øtomes, for the married women, or ≈øuch as haue had the company of a man: they couer their priuie members from the Nauel downe to the knees, with certaine mantils of cotten, made in manner of nets, wherein they ≈øticke certaine leaues, otherwi≈øe they go naked, vntil ≈øuch time as they fir≈øt perceiue their flowers, and then they inuite al their friendes, and make a great fea≈øt or banket, as if they were married, with great ≈øignes of ioy, and then they beginne to hang that kinde of mantle before them, wearing the ≈øame as long as they are vnmarried. They are in great ≈øubiection to their mai≈øters, in ≈øuch maner, as that if they ≈øhould command them to throw them≈øelues headlong from off a hil, or to do any other thing what≈øoeuer, they wil not refu≈øe to do it, what danger ≈øoeuer con≈øi≈øteth therin, not once a≈øking wherefore they ≈øhould doo it, but only, becau≈øe the ma≈øter commandeth it. Here al≈øo you mu≈øt note wherein their kings gouernment con≈øi≈øteth, which reacheth no further then only concerning ≈øowing or planting the ground, hunting, & fi≈øhing, for that what≈øoeuer is ≈øowed or planted, hunted, or fi≈øhed in any re≈øpect, is onelie in the kings power, and done by his commandement, which diuideth tho≈øe kindes of labours among the people, directing euerie man what he ≈øhould do. The fruit that is reaped and gathered, is brought all into a place appointed, and from thence it is yearely deliuered vnto euerie man according as his hou≈øhold and nece≈ø≈øarie v≈øe requireth, ≈øo that their Lords are nothing el≈øe but kings of Bees, ≈øtuards, & di≈øtributers of the common goods of the countrey: thinke then (I be≈øeech you,) what a golden time tho≈øe people had, where neither this is mine, or this is thine, was euer heard among them. The only wel ≈øpring of ≈øtrife & contentioÃÑ. Tho≈øe in the ea≈øt parts v≈øing nothing els but playing at the ball, fi≈øhing, and hunting, where neither law nor proce≈ø≈øe was v≈øed nor decided, where onely the kings will was a lawe, and in all things were content to obey it. They found certaine red ≈øtones in
≈øhels of fi≈øhes much e≈øteemed and accounted of among theÃÑ, which they weare at their cares, and others more e≈øteemed, of which they took out of ≈ønakes Her≈øenen or ≈ønailes, (whereof the fle≈øh is very good to eate) of a fire red colour, cleare, and ≈øo like rubies, that they could hardly be di≈øcerned from them, whereof the Snakes in their ≈øpeech are called Coho ‚Ä¢ o, and the ≈øtones Cohibici. They gather likewi≈øe in the ≈øande vppon the ≈øea ≈øide, certaine cleare ≈øhining ≈øtones, yellow, blacke, and other colours, whereof they make necklaces and ≈øuch like Iewels, to weare about their necks, armes, and legs: in many places of tho≈øe I≈ølands they haue no fle≈øh, nor eate it not, their meate is fi≈øh, breda of wheate, rootes, and ≈øome fruites. The people of the≈øe I≈ølands being carried to ≈øaint Dominico or Cuba, died there with eating fle≈øh, it beeing giuen them by the Spaniards. In ≈øome of tho≈øe I≈ølands there are ≈øo many pigeons & other birues, which build their ne≈øtes in the Trees, that many out of the firme land, and al≈øo from the other I≈ølands, come thither and load whole ≈øcutes ful, and take them with them: the trees wherein they breed are like Youngarnet trees, the barke hauing a certaine ta≈øte like Cinamon, and ≈øomwhat better, and hot like ginger, ≈ømelling like cloues, yet are they not accounted for ≈øpices: among other fruites they haue a certaine kind by them called Ia ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ma, both ≈øauorie and hol≈øome, about a ≈øpan and a halfe long, like a fig when it is greene: the leafe likewi≈øe not much differing from the fig leafe, and of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a willow tree: not clo≈øe like other trees, nor hollow like reedes, but fa≈øt like Elders, the leaues beeing excellent good to heale wounds, as the Spaniards haue wel tryed. To ≈øpeake more hereof is needele≈ø≈øe: tho≈øe I≈ølandes of Lucaya are more de≈øolate and not inhabited, for becau≈øe they haue no gold. The Spaniards carried many thou≈øandes of them into other places, and in ≈øeeking for Golde ≈øpoyled and de≈øtroyed them.

div.head: Hereafter followeth other I≈ølands lying about that coa≈øt, and fir≈øt Cuba, being one of the principal I≈ølands vnder the Antillas.
div.p:
CVba another verie great I≈ølande, accounted among the Antillas, was by Columbus fir≈øt foundout, and di≈øcouered in An. 1492. 1492. which he called Fernandinam and I ‚Ä¢ hannam, as al≈øo Alpha and Omega, as Peter Martin ≈øaith, and by others the I≈øland is called ≈øaint Iacob, after the name of the cheefe≈øt towne therein, which by rea≈øon of the great hauen as al≈øo the ≈øituation therof, hath a verie great traffike, as hauing on the Ea≈øt ≈øide the I≈ølande of Saint Domingo, on the We≈øt Iucatan, on the North the great Cape of Florida, and on the South the I≈øland Iamaica, all ≈øet downe in this Carde. It is in forme like vnto a willow leafe, becau≈øe it is longer theÃÑ broad, being in length from ea≈øt to we≈øt three hundred miles, and from north to ≈øouth ≈øeuenty miles, in breadth in ≈øome places but fifteene and in ≈øome nineteene miles. The middle of the I≈øland lieth in longitude 19. degrees, and in latitude or height twentie degrees. It was long time accounted for firme land, becau≈øe of the greatne≈ø≈øe, which is no maruaile, for the inhabitants them≈øelues knew no other, but that it had no ende (and al≈øo long after the Spaniards comming thither) becau≈øe the people are poore and naked, contented with a little, and with their own, not ≈øeeking any further, neither caring what their neighbours did, and therefore knew not if there were any other lande vnder the heauens, then that wherein they dwelt. The ground is high, rough, and ≈øharpe of hils, the ≈øea in many places being white, and the riuers ≈ømall, and good water, rich of golde and good copper, the aire temperate, yet ≈øomewhat colde: therein is found much Mather, ≈øeruing to die wooll, cloath, and leather: it is al≈øo ful of thicke woods, fi≈øhponds, and faire Riuers of fre≈øh water, al≈øo of ponds that naturally are ≈øalt water: In the woods are many hogges and oxen, the riuers do oftentimes ca≈øt foorth gold: in this I≈øland are ≈øixe townes inhabited by Spaniards, whereof the fir≈øt & principal is Saint Iacobs, the re≈øidence and ≈øea of the Bi≈øhop, but Hauana is the cheefe towne of marchandize, and where all their Shippes are made. Twoo principal and notable things are by Gon≈øalo Onetano written of this I≈øland, the fir≈øt, that therein is a valley ≈øituate betweene two hils, in length about two or three Spani≈øh miles, wherein nature of it ≈øelfe bringeth foorth certaine round balles, ≈øuch as by art cannot po≈ø≈øibly bee made rounder, and in ≈øo great aboundance, that they may balli≈øt or loade whole Shippes therewith, and are v≈øed in the ≈øhippes in ≈øteede of Iron or Leaden bulltes. The other is a certaine hil not farre from the ≈øea, from whence there floweth pitch in great aboundance, and runneth unto the ≈øea, where it driueth vppon the ≈øhore from place to place, as the winde and weather ≈øerueth. This pitch
is v≈øed by the inhabitants and Spaniards, to pitch their ≈øhippes. The people of the I≈øland are like tho≈øe of Hi≈øpaniola, onely differing in ≈øpeech: both men and women go naked, and k√©epe their bridalles in verie ≈øtrange manner: for that he which is married lieth not the fir≈øt night with his wife, be if it be a Lord, he biddeth all the Lordes, and one of them doth it for him, and if it be a Marchant, then Marchants take the paines to helpe him, but if it be a countreyman, either one of the Lordes or the prie≈øt doth ea≈øe him of a labour. They leaue their wiues for verie ≈ømal occa≈øions, but the women may not for≈øake their hu≈øbands for any cau≈øe what≈øoeuer. The men are very vncha≈øte, and wicked liuers: there are great wormes and ≈ønakes in the I≈øland, and not venimous, but ea≈øie to be taken, the fle≈øh whereof they eate, and are neuer hurt therwith, which ≈ønakes do liue by eating certaine bea≈øtes, called Guabiniquinazes, whereof many times there are ≈øeauen or eight found within their mawes: they are in greatne≈ø≈øe like Hares, in form like fores, onely that their feete are like Conies feete: the head like a We≈øell, a Fores taile, long haire like a Badger, of colour ≈øomwhat red, the fle≈øh ≈øauorie and hol≈øome. This I≈ølande was verie populous, but nowe hath verie few, onely certain Spaniards, the re≈øt beeing almo≈øt cleane rooted out, and dead for want of meate.

div.head: Iamaica.
div.p: RIght again≈øt Cuba lyeth another I≈øland, which ≈øtil holdeth the name, it alwaies had, and is called Iamaica and of the Spaniards ≈øaint Iacob, it lieth betw√©ene ≈øeuent√©ene and eight√©ene degr√©es, on this ≈øide the Equinoctiall line, on the Ea≈øt ≈øide it hath Saint Dominico, about fiue and twentie miles di≈øtant, on the We≈øt ≈øide the Cape or corner of Iucatana, on the north Cubam, al≈øo fiue and twentie miles di≈øtant and ≈øomewhat more, and on the South another ≈ømal I≈øland, called Lacerana, of fiue and twentie miles di≈øtant as the re≈øt. This I≈ølande was di≈øcouered by Chri≈øtopherus Columbus, in his ≈øeconde nauigation into tho≈øe countreyes, and was taken by his ≈øon Don Diego, gouerning the I≈øland Saint Dominico, by one Iohan de Squibel, a captaine.

The breadth of the I≈ølande ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth the length, for it is from Ea≈øt to We≈øt about fiftie miles, and from north to ≈øouth twentie miles, it is mo≈øt inhabited by Spaniards, the inhabitants al≈øo being burnt and de≈øtroyed by them, like tho≈øe of Lucaya. The middle of the I≈øland hath the longitude of 191. degrees, and latitude or height eighteene degrees, and is di≈øtant from the line ≈øeuenteene degrees, on the north ≈øide. It hath a hill that rai≈øeth it on al ≈øides, inward to the middle of the land, and ≈øo proportionably and euen, that it can hardly bee de≈øcerned: it is verie fruitfull both on the ≈øea ≈øide, and within the land, and in times pa≈øt verie populous, ≈øuch as were very wittie and ≈øubtile, more then other of the I≈ølanders thereabouts, both in wars and other labours. There is likewi≈øe gold, and verie fine cotten wooll, and at this pre≈øent it is ful of bea≈øts brought thither by the Spaniards, and there haue increa≈øed. The ≈øwines fle≈øh is better in that I≈øland, then in any other place. The cheefe towne in this I≈øland is called Hi≈øpalis of Siuilia, becau≈øe of the abby which therein is erected, the fir≈øt abbot being Peter Marti ‚Ä¢
borne in Milan, an excellent learned man, and hee that wrote mo≈øt concerning this Hy≈øtorie.

div.head: Hi≈øpaniola or Haiti.
div.p:
THe ≈øeconde great I≈ølande accounted among the Antillas, was by the fir≈øt inhabitants called Qui≈øqueia, or Qui≈øque≈øia, and after that Haiti, and then Cipanga: Haiti is as much to ≈øay, as roughne≈ø≈øe or ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe, and Qui≈øqueia great land, Chri≈øtopherus Columbus called it Hi≈øpaniola, and now it is called Saint Dominico, after the cheefe Towne in the ≈øame I≈øland: it was di≈øcouered in Anno 1493. 1493. on the ea≈øt ≈øide thereof lyeth the I≈øland of Saint Iohn, and many others, on the We≈øt Cuba and Iamaica‚ñ™ on the north the I≈øland of the Canibals, and on the ≈øouth the firme land, which is the Cape of Vela by Venezuela, or little Venice. The coÃÑpa≈ø≈øe of this I≈øland is 350. miles, Benzo ≈øaith 400. French miles, which is in a manner al one, and it is broader then long, for in length it is from Ea≈øt to we≈øt 150. miles, and from north to ≈øouth 40. miles, the middle of the I≈øland lyeth in the longitude of 300. degrees, in latitude 19: in it there are verie many and great hauens, as Hatibanico, Iuua, Ozoma, Neyua Nizao, Nigua, Hayna, and Iaques, which do, al runne into the ≈øea. There are others that are ≈ømaller, as Macorix, Ciba ‚Ä¢ , & Cotui, wherof Macorix is verie ful of fi≈øh, the other two abounding in gold. In this I≈øland are two very ≈øtrange lakes, the one becau≈øe of the goodnes and profitablenes therof, the
other, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe, the one comming out of the hilles, from whence the Riuer Puizao hath her i≈ø≈øue: it profiteth no man, onely it giueth a feare, and a little ≈øinder ≈øulkes.

The other of Xaragua is ≈øalt, although many ≈øweete riuers runne into it, and hath many fi≈øhes, among the which are verie great Tortuxes and Tiburones or Hayen: it is hard by the ≈øea, and is eleuen miles in compa≈ø≈øe: the riuer ≈øides and ≈øhores were much inhabted, except the Saline a verie faire hauen, and the Riuer Iaques, where there is a great ≈øalt hil: There groweth in this I≈øland great ≈øtore of very fine blew colour, and much bra≈øill wood, cotten wooll, (but they know not how to make any thing of it) amber, rich mines of gold, and is al≈øo fi≈øhed out of lakes and riuers, and likewi≈øe ≈øiluer and other mettals, great abundance of ≈øugar: it is verie fruitful ground, Reddi≈øh, Lettice, and Coleworts beeing ≈øowed therein, are within ≈øixteene dayes after ripe, and to bee eaten: Melons, Cucumbers, and Gourdes, within ≈øixe and thirtie dayes are al≈øo ripe and verie ≈øauory, aboue al others what≈øoeuer. The forme of the I≈øland is like a che≈ønut tree leafe, in the middle of the I≈øland there pa≈ø≈øeth a ≈øtony or rough hil, in forme of a mans backe, which is called Cibam or Cipangi, where in times pa≈øt much gold was founde: out of this hil runneth foure great riuers, diuiding the I≈øland into foure partes, wherof the one is in the Ea≈øt, and is called Iunna: the ≈øecond in the we≈øt, called Attibunicus, the third in the north, called Iachem, and the fourth in the South, called Naxban, whereabouts there is much bra≈øile wood, and woods of diuers ≈øpices, but not like our ≈øpices, which they barter for other wares, ≈øpecially for ≈øtooles and di≈øhes of blacke ebanny. Vppon the hil of Cibano, lyeth the Ca≈øtle of Saint Thomas. There are likewi≈øe many townes within this I≈ølande, the principall called Saint Dominico, made by Bartholomeo, Columbo‚ñ™ and by him ≈øo named, becau≈øe they arriued in that I≈øland vpon ≈øaint Dominicks day: it lyeth on a plaine ground, vpon the ≈øea ≈øide, and hath aboue fiue hundred hou≈øes, built after the ≈øpani≈øh maner, on the We≈øt ≈øide therof runneth the riuer Ozama, or Ozonca, into the ≈øea, where there is a good hauen, in the which manie ≈øhippes may anker: about this Riuer lyeth verie great and thicke woodes: the greate≈øt traffike next their golde is ≈øugar, and hides, for that al ≈øorts of foure footed bea≈øts being brought thither out of Spaine, haue ≈øo much increa≈øed therein, that there are ≈øome ≈øpaniards in the I≈øle, that haue ≈øixe thou≈øand or eight thou≈øand bea≈øtes.

I≈øabella and another towne lying on the other ≈øide of the ≈øame I≈ølande in a valley, concerning the ≈øituation, the people, their Religion and cu≈øtomes, you may ≈øufficiently reade in the ≈øpani≈øh Hi≈øtories thereof ≈øet forth, yet will I note ≈øome that are verie ≈øtrange: in this I≈øland are certain wormes verie common among them, and by the inhabitants called Cuuero, in greatne≈ø≈øe as bigge as a ioynt of a mans finger, with foure wings, two verie little, the other two ≈øomewhat greater, and harder, and are as couers to the ≈ømaller, the≈øe wormes ≈øhine by night as the ≈øloe wormes here with vs, which light doth not onely appeare like a ≈øtarre, ca≈øting forth ≈øtreames and ≈øhining out of their eies, but al≈øo in the whole body, ≈øo that when they flie and ≈øpreade their wings, they giue much more light out of their bodyes, then when they ≈øitte ≈øtill: in which wormes men may well beholde the great workes and ble≈ø≈øings of God, by his ≈øtrange gifts be≈øtowed vpon his creatures: for by the light of this little worme, the darke≈øt chamber that is in the night time, may be made cleare and bright, whereby a man may reade, write, or do any thing, not n√©eding any other light: and likewi≈øe if a man beare that worme in his hand, he ≈øhall haue as great a light as if he bore a torch or lanterne, and many light others therewith, and the more wormes there are, the greater will be the light.

Not farre from Hy≈øpaniola lyeth another ≈ømall I≈ølande, called Mona, betweene Hi≈øpaniola and Boriquena, or Saint Iohns vnder ≈øeuenteene degr√©es on the North ≈øide of the line. This I≈ølande is ≈ømall and flatte, and euen lande, in bigne≈ø≈øe about three miles, and inhabited by a fewe Indians, and Chri≈øtians, it hath verie good water, and is ful of fi≈øh, ≈øpecially of verie good creui≈øhes.

div.head: Boriquen.
div.p:
FRom this I≈øland you come vnto Boriquen, now named S. Iohn a rich hauen: on the Ea≈øt ≈øide it hath the I≈øland of Sancta Croce, on the We≈øt other ≈ømall I≈ølandes, Northwarde the I≈ølande of Saint Dominico, which is fiue and twentie miles di≈øtant, and on the South, the Cape of Paria, di≈øtant aboue three hundreth thirtie and ≈øixe miles. The length of this I≈ølande is more then the breadth, for from Ea≈øt to We≈øt it is fiftie miles, from north to South eighteene miles, and
is diuided into twoo partes, that is, the North and the South quarter: the middle of the I≈øland lyeth vnder 303. degrees longitude, and 18. degrees latitude: in forme almo≈øt ≈øquare, populous and wel hou≈øed, hauing many good hauens and woods. The inhabitants haue continual warres again≈øt the Canibals, or ≈øuch as eate mens fle≈øh. This I≈øland was rich of gold on the north ≈øide, and towardes the ≈øouth, fruitfull of bread, fruit, gra≈ø≈øe, and fi≈øh: it is ≈øaid the≈øe people v≈øed not to eate any fle≈øh, which is to be vnder≈øtood of wilde fle≈øh, but they eate many birdes, as Pigeons, and ≈øuch like: in other things they are like tho≈øe of Hi≈øpaniola, onely that they are better ≈øouldiers, and v≈øe bowes and arrowes: in this I≈ølande there is a certaine gumme, by them called Ta ‚Ä¢ unuo, vnhol≈øome and fatty like tallow, wherewith and with oyle they dre≈ø≈øe their ≈øhippes, and becau≈øe it is bitter, it pre≈øerueth the ≈øhips from wormes. There is likewi≈øe much por wood, which is v≈øed to heale the pore and other di≈øea≈øes. This I≈øland was di≈øcouered by Chro≈øtopherus Co ‚Ä¢ umbu ‚Ä¢ , in his ≈øecond voyage into India: There is a verie ≈øtrange and notable Hi≈øtorie written of the inhabitants hereof, which is, that at the fir≈øt arriual of the Spaniards in that I≈øland, they thought the Spaniards to be immortal and neuer died, whereof to be a≈ø≈øured, vppon a time, one of their Cariquen or Lords, called Vraioa de Yaguara, cau≈øed one of the Spaniards to be taken, and to prooue if he were immortal, cau≈øed him to be put into a Riuer vnder the water, and there holden, to ≈øee if hee would come foorth aliue, but being dead, and brought before the king, he was thereby a≈ø≈øured of their mortalitie, whereupon he ro≈øe again≈øt them, and ≈ølew 150. of them, that were bu≈øie in ≈øeeking of gold.

div.head: Saint Crus, Hay, Hay
div.p:
FRom Borequien you come to the I≈øland S. C ‚Ä¢ us, in time pa≈øt by the inhabitants called Hay, Hay, being inhabited by Canibals, or eaters of men, as al≈øo the next vnto it, called Guadalupea, by them called Qui ‚Ä¢
ra, or Quera, which Caribes or Canibales had in ≈øhort time deuoured at the lea≈øt 5000. men, which they ≈øtole and tooke out of the I≈ølandes rounde about them: from thence you come to diuers other I≈ølandes, which lie like an Archipelago, hauing the ≈øame name, but many of them are likewi≈øe called after the forme or fa≈øhion that they beare, as Anguilla, which is an eele, as being long and ≈ømal‚ñ™ Redonda Maria becau≈øe it is like a ≈øpheare, & verie round Mon ‚Ä¢
ratu ‚Ä¢ , that is, a clo≈øed hil, becau≈øe the I≈øland hath high hils round about it, ful of people and victuals, ≈øome of ≈øaints, as S. Mi „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , S. Bartholmew, S. Barbara, Beata ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ Antigua, till you come to the olde Virgin Maryes, which lie together in a rowe, verie plea≈øant to beholde, ≈øome greene, others red‚ñ™ blew, yellow, and violet, mo≈øt wonderful to ≈øuch as ≈øaile by them, wherof many colours are made.

div.head: Guadalupea.
div.p:
BY Antigua lieth Guadal ‚Ä¢ pe ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ the cheefe and greate≈øt I≈ølande of Canibals foure degrees di≈øtant from the Equinoctiall line‚ñ™ it is round aboue 130. miles, and diuided by two ≈øtreames, like Engl ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢
and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth almo≈øt to be two I≈ølands it hath many goodly hauens the na ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ; giuen it of our Lady of Guadalupe it is ‚Ä¢ ul of villages, each of twentie or thirtie hou≈øes, all wood, and rounde, made of certaine great okes which they thru≈øt into the earth, and tho≈øe ≈øerue for the doores of their hou≈øes, then they place ≈ømaller, which hold the re≈øt from falling. Their branches on the toppe being bound together like tents, which they couer with Palme tree leaues, to keep them from the raine, within they fa≈øten ropes made of cotten wool, or of B ‚Ä¢ e≈øen‚ñ™ wherupon they lay cotten mattre≈ø≈øes, and hanging beddes therein to ≈øleepe. This I≈øland hath ≈øeuen faire riuers, the inhabitants were called Ca ‚Ä¢ uc ‚Ä¢ erum, it hath verie great Parrots, much differing from others, being red both before and behind, with long feathers the wings ≈øpeckled with red, ≈øome yellow, ≈øome blew, al mixed together whereof there are as great abundance, as of Spree „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ er in our countryes: there groweth in this I≈øland a certaine gumme called A „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ m: not much vnlike Amber: the ≈ømoke or aire of this gumme being let vp into the head, driueth out the colde: the tree bringeth foorth a fruit like dates, but of a ≈øpanne and a halfe long, which beeing opened, hath a certaine white and ≈øweete meale. This fruit they keepe for winter, as we do che≈ønuts, the trees are like figge trees: they haue likewi≈øe in this I≈øland al kind of orchard fruit, and ≈øome are of opinion that al kindes of ≈øweete fruites were fir≈øt brought out of this I≈ølande into the other I≈ølandes round about it, for they are hunters of men, which hauing taken, they eate them, and for the ≈øame cau≈øe they trauaile abroade many hundreth miles, both farre and neare, and in their trauell what≈øoeuer they finde, they bring it home and plant it. They are not friendly, but
fierce and cruell. They indure no ≈øtrangers among them, both the men and the women are verie ≈øubtile, and expert in ≈øhooting with their bowes, and their arrowes being poy≈øoned: when the men are gone abroad, the women keepe their places and countreyes, mo≈øt ≈øtoutly defending them from al inua≈øion: to conclude, al parts of that I≈ølande both hils and dales, are verie fruitfull, and in the hollow trees and clifts of hilles, and rocks, they find home.

div.head: De≈øiada, or De≈øiderata ‚Ä¢
div.p: ABout eighteene miles from Guadalupa towards the Ea≈øt, lieth De≈øiada, another I≈øland, being twentie miles great. De≈øiada‚ñ™ or De≈øiderata, that is de≈øire, ≈øo called by rea≈øon of the fairene≈ø≈øe of the I≈øland: ten miles from Guadalupa towards the ≈øouth, lyeth Galanta, being in compa≈ø≈øe aboue thirtie miles, it is an euen and faire country, wherof the I≈øland hath taken the name, for Galanta in Spani≈øh betokeneth faire. Therein are diuers ≈øweete ≈ømelling trees, both in barks, rootes, & leaues. There are likewi≈øe many great Hor≈øleaches. Nine miles from Guadalupa towards the Ea≈øt, there lieth ≈øix ≈ømal Ilands, called Todos los Sanctos‚ñ™ or al Saints, and Barbara ≈øpokeÃÑ of before. Tho≈øe I≈ølandes are verie full of cliffes, ≈øtonie, and vnfruitful, which the Pilots are to looke vnto to auoyde the danger that may en≈øue. A little further, lyeth Dominica, taking the name from the day, becau≈øe it was di≈øcouered vpon a ≈øunday, and al≈øo an I≈ølande of Caniballes, ≈øo ful and thicke of Trees, that there is ≈øcant an elle of free land. Thereabouts al≈øo is another I≈øland called Madannina, or the womens I≈ølande, where it is thought that women onely inhabited in maner of Amazons, whither the Canibales often times re≈øorted to lie with them, and if they had daughters, they kept them, but boyes, they ≈øent vnto their fathers: it lyeth fortie miles from Mons Serratu ‚ñ™ After that lyeth yet thr√©e I≈ølands, (be≈øides other little I≈ølands and diuers cliffes) called S. Vincent, Granada, and S. Lucia. Comming further towards the coa≈øt of Florida, where we left‚ñ™ right again≈øt it there lyeth certaine ≈ømal cliffes, called Martires, and the little Ilands called Tortugas, becau≈øe they are like a Torteauxes. From this poynt of Florida to Ancon Baxo are 100. miles, and lyeth fiftie miles di≈øtant Ea≈øt and We≈øt from Rio Secco, which is the breadth of Florida, from Ancon Baxo 100. miles to Rio di Nieues, from thence to the riuer Flores 20. miles and ≈øomewhat more, from the riuer of Flores to the bay called Bahya del Spirito Sancto, which is likewi≈øe called La Culata, being in the entrance thereof thirtie miles broade: from this Bahya which lyeth vnder 29. degr√©es, are 70. miles to the riuer called Rio del Pe≈øcadores, from Rio del Pe≈øcadores (which lyeth vnder 28. degrees and halfe, there is 100. miles to the Riuer called Rio de las Palmas, from whence Tropicus Cancri beginnneth: from Rio de las Palmas to the Riuer Panuco are 30. miles, and from thence to Villa Rica, or Vera Crus, are ≈øeuentie miles, in which ≈øpace lyeth Almeria: from Vera Crus, that lyeth vnder 19. degrees‚ñ™ to the riuer of Aluarado, (by the I≈øland called Papa Doapan, are thirtie miles: from the riuer Aluarado to the riuer Co ‚Ä¢ z ‚Ä¢ coalco are fiftie miles: from thence to the riuer Grital ‚Ä¢ a are fortie miles. The ≈øaid two riuers lying about eighteene degr√©es: from the riuer Gritalua, to Cabo Redondo, are eightie miles, as the coa≈øt ≈øtretcheth along wherein are contained Champoton and Lazaro: from Cabo Redondo to Cabo di Catoche, or Iucatan are 90. miles, and lyeth about 21. degr√©es, ≈øo that there are in al nine hundred miles in the length of the coa≈øt of Florida to Iucatan, which is another Cape or hooke, which ≈øtretcheth from off the land northward, and the further it reacheth into the ≈øea, the more it crooketh or windeth about, and is ≈øixtie miles from Cuba. The I≈øland whereof we haue alreadie ≈øpoken, which doth almo≈øt inclo≈øe the ≈øea that runneth betw√©ene Florida and Iucatan, which ≈øea by ≈øome men is called Golfo de Mexico, of others Golfo de Florida, and of ≈øome others Cortes: the ≈øea that runneth into this gulfe, entreth betw√©ene Iucatan and Cuba with a mightie ≈øtreame, and runneth out againe betweene Florida and Cuba, and hath no other cour≈øe.

div.head: A breefe de≈øcription of Noua Hi≈øpania, or new Spaine.
div.p:
THe ≈øecond part of America is called Noua Spaigna‚ñ™ or new Spaine, it beginneth towards the North, about the Riuer of Panuco, vppon the borders of Florida, on the South ≈øide it reacheth to the prouince Darien ‚Ä¢ , where it is diuided from Peru on the Ea≈øt it hath the maine Sea, and on the we≈øt the South ≈øea called Mare Au≈øtrale: this whole Prouince was in times pa≈øt by the Inhabitants called Cichemecan Cathuacan, or Co ‚Ä¢ acan, which peple came out of the land of Culhua, which lieth aboue Xali≈øco, & made their habitation about the Moores
of Tenuchtitlan, where at this pre≈øent lyeth the towne of Mexico, which people hauing neither countrey nor dwelling place, cho≈øe that for the be≈øt and mo≈øt profitable, therein building diuers hou≈øes and habitations, and in that manner placed both their new and old villages vnder the commaundement of Culhuacan, giuing the ≈øame name to all that countrey.

This land is great and hath many people and countries vnder it, but the principall and chiefe prouince which the Spanyardes holde therein is Mexicana, al≈øo
‚Ä¢ enu≈øtiran or Culhuacan, as I ≈øaide before, the other prouinces are Guatimala, Xali≈øcus, Hondura, Cha'cos, Taic ‚Ä¢ , Chamo ‚Ä¢ la, Claortomaca, Hu ‚Ä¢ cacholla, and the kingdomes of Michuacan, Te≈øcuco, Utazcalia, Tenuacan, Maxcalcinco, and Mix ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ apan. Mexico or Culhuacan was brought vnder the ≈øubiection of the kings of Spaine, by Fernando Cortes Merches deila Valo in the yeere of our Lorde, one thou≈øand fiue hundred and eighteene,1513 which countrey is very rich of golde and ≈øiluer, for that many riuers haue golde in the ≈øand. The Sea ≈øhore in tho≈øe Countries yeeldeth manye pearles, mu≈øtles, or oy≈øters, wherein they finde the pearles, whereof there is a great fi≈øhing, and much traffike for them. There are likewi≈øe in this countrey many lakes or meeres that are ≈øtil and haue no i≈ø≈øue, which by the heate of the Sunne tourne into ≈øalt. There is likewi≈øe no le≈ø≈øe aboundance of Ca≈øsia Fi≈øtul ‚Ä¢
then in Egypt, growing on trees, with leaues like walnuts, and yellow blo≈ø≈øoms, from whence the pipes or ca≈øes of Ca≈øsia do i≈ø≈øue forth, which are v≈øed to purge in hote feuers, to coole and clean≈øe the gall and heart blood, as al≈øo very good again≈øt the ≈øtone in the bladder and kidneys, and other di≈øea≈øes. There is likewi≈øe in that countrie a kinde of fruit that groweth in great abundance called Cacao, altogether like an almond, which is taken out of the hu≈øke, and couered with a thinne ≈økinne, whereof the kernel is diuided into three or foure partes, of a darke yellow with blacke veines, being har≈øh in the mouth, and of an euill ta≈øte, but with them is much e≈øteemed, whereof, being beaten with ≈øome of their countrey pepper, they make a certaine drinke, which they e≈øteeme of great price, giuing it vnto great Lordes, and ≈øuch as are their e≈øpeciall friends, as we e≈øteeme of mu≈øcadel or malue≈øie. The ≈øea bordering vpon this countrey, as al≈øo the riuers running through it are ful of fi≈øh, wherein al≈øo they finde diuers Crocodiles, as in Egypt, the fle≈øh whereof is ≈øo much e≈øteemed before al other meates, that they account it for a princely di≈øh, whereof ≈øome are aboue 20. foote long. The country is full of hilles, and ≈øtony rockes, and great difference in their ≈øpeeche, ≈øo that they hardly vnder≈øtand each other without Interpreters. The places wherein the Spaniardes fir≈øt placed their men were Compo≈øtella, where the Bi≈øhop and the Kings coun≈øell are re≈øident, and Colima, which they call the Purification: in new Galicia is the chiefe Guadalahara. and the head or principall part of the kingdome. Mecheocan al≈øo a Bi≈øhops ≈øea, Cacatula the towne of Angels, a chiefe towne and bi≈øhopricke, M ‚Ä¢ x ‚Ä¢
a kingly citie, and Queene of al cities in the new world, lyeth vpon the border or ≈øide of a lake: the market place of the Towne lying ful vpon the lake, whereby they can not come at it but they mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe ouer bridges. This lake is l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t, and is in length ≈øixe lucas, or twelue miles, and is in breadth tenne miles, without fi≈øh, onely a ≈ømal kind that may rather be called wormes than fi≈øhes, from the which lake in ≈øummer time there ari≈øeth ≈øuch a ≈øti ‚Ä¢ ke, and infecteth the ayre in ≈øuch manner, that it is vnwhole≈øome to dwel there, notwith≈øtanding it is inhabited by as many marchants, as any towne in Europe, the cittie is great, at the lea≈øt three miles in compa≈ø≈øe, wherein are ≈øo many temples that it is incredible: the particularitte whereof, before it be long ≈øhalbe tran≈ølated out of Spani≈øh into our mother tongue, by the author therof, whereunto I referre you.

Not farre from this cittie lieth an other fre≈øh lake very ful of fi≈øh, whereon, as al≈øo vpon the ≈øhore, lie many townes. When this towne was fir≈øt taken by the Spaniards, there raigned a king called M ‚Ä¢ ntez ‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢ , being the ninth in degree, and as then the towne was but 140. yeares old, which is to bee wondered at, howe it is po≈ø≈øible that ≈øo great a citie in ≈øo few yeers ≈øhould be ≈øo famous. The marchandi≈øes that are mo≈øt carried out of this countrey, are golde, ≈øiluer, pearle bal≈øam, cochenilia, the white roote Macheocan, which is good to purge, Salla Pariglia, and an other roote which maketh men ≈øweate, brim≈øtone, bea≈øts ≈økinnes, and fi≈øh. And thus much for new Spaine in generall, and of Mexico in particular.

Not minding at this pre≈øent time to make any longer di≈øcour≈øe, becau≈øe that our Carde ≈øheweth little thereof, and now returning to our owne Carde, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the lower ende of Cuba hath an out Hooke, called P. de Santa Anthonio, which is very fitte for to
take in fre≈øh water, and to calke and mend the ≈øhippes.

Sailing from this hooke ≈øixtie fiue miles, to the firme land, you come to the hooke of Iucatan, which runneth into the ≈øea like a halfe I≈øland. Iectetan is in Indian ≈øpeech, I vnder≈øtand you not, for that vpon a time when certaine Spaniards put out of the hauen of Saint Anthony, to di≈øcouer newe countries, and arriued in that I≈øland, they made ≈øignes vnto the people to knowe the name of the country, whereuppon the Indians an≈øwered them and ≈øaide, O Tectetan, Tectetan, that is, We vnder≈øtand ye not: and ≈øo the Spaniards corrupting the name Tectetan call that land Iucatan, yet the furthe≈øt point therof in their ≈øp√©ech was called
‚Ä¢ ecampi. This point of Iucatan lyeth vnder 21. degrees, vnder the which name a great countrey is comprehended, by ≈øome called Pein≈øula, that is, a place almo≈øt compa≈ø≈øed about with water, for that the further this point reacheth into the ≈øea, the broader it is, being in the narrowe≈øt part 80. or 90. Spani≈øh miles broad, for ≈øo farre it is from Xicalanco.

Therefore the ≈øea Cardes that place this land nearer or ≈ømaller, do erre much, for that it is in length from Ea≈øt to We≈øt twoo hundred miles, being di≈øcouered by Franci≈øco Hernandez of Cordua, in the yeare of our Lord 1517. 151 ‚Ä¢
but not al of it, for that ≈øailing from out of Cuba from Saint Iacobs, to di≈øcouer new countries, or (as ≈øome ≈øay) to fetch labourers to trauell in his mines, he came about the I≈øland Guanaxos, (herein called Caguan x ‚Ä¢ to the cape di Honduras, where good, hone≈øt, ciuill, and ≈øimple people dwelt, being fi≈øhermen, hauing no weapons, nor v≈øed to the warres: and proceeding further, ≈øayled to an vnknowne point of land, where hee found certaine ≈øalt pannes, whereunto he gaue the name of Donne, that is, women, for that there were certaine ≈øtone towers with ≈øtaires & chappels couered with wood and ≈øtraw, wherein were placed diuer≈øe Idols that ≈øhewed like women, whereat the Spaniardes maruelled, to finde ≈øtone hou≈øes, which till then they had not ≈øeene, and that the inhabitants were rich and well apparelled, with ≈øhirtes and mantles of cotten white, and coloured, with plumes of feathers, and iewels of precious ≈øtones ≈øette in golde and ≈øiluer: their women likewi≈øe appareled from the middle downewardes, as al≈øo on the head and brea≈øt, which hauing ≈øeene, hee ≈øtayed not there, but went vnto an other poynt, which hee named Cotehe, where hee met with certayne Fi≈øhermen, who with feare fled from him into the countrey aun≈øwering or calling vnto him, Cotehe, Cotehe, that is to ≈øay, home, home, thinking hee a≈øked them the way into the land, whereby this poynt hath holden the name of Cotehe. There vpon the ≈øea ≈øide they found a great towne, which for the greatne≈ø≈øe thereof, they called Alkair, after a Towne of the ≈øame name, lying in Egypt (yet I thinke it not to be halfe ≈øo great as they affirme it to be) where by the Inhabitantes they were friendly receiued, and being entered into the town, they meruelled to ≈øee hou≈øes with high towers, goodly churches, paued ≈øtreets, and great trade of marchandi≈øe. The hou≈øes were of hewen and carued ≈øtones wo ‚Ä¢ kmanlike made and built with chalke, but couered with ≈øtrawe and leaues, the chambers within them of tenne or twelue ≈øteps high: they were likewi≈øe apparelled, but not with wollen cloth, becau≈øe they had no ≈øheepe, but with cotten wouen in diuer≈øe ≈øortes, very finely coloured: the women likewi≈øe apparelled from the middle downe to the foot, couering their heads and brea≈øts in diuers ≈øorts, very carefully ≈øeeking to couer their feete that they might not be ≈øeene: going diligeÃÑtly to church, to which end ≈øuch as were rich & of authoritie had their owne paued ≈øtr√©et from their dores to the church, but were Idolaters, & although they offred men vnto their Idolles, yet they did not eate mans fle≈øh. They were likewi≈øe circumci≈øed, but it is not knowne why they v≈øed it, vnle≈ø≈øe it were the diuell that ruled ouer them willed them ≈øo to do: in their dealings they were vpright, and kept their promi≈øes: they traffiked without mony, by bartering, ≈øpecially for cotten and apparell, or gownes made therof, all without ≈øleeues, which is the greate≈øt riches they bring vnto their Lordes, and which they carry to Mexico, Capo di Hondura ‚Ä¢
and Cuba they haue likewi≈øe many Bees, hony and ware, but they knew not how to v≈øe ware before the Spaniardes came thither: golde and ≈øiluer mines they had none, although the Countrey was a rough, ≈øharpe, and ≈øtonie land, yet it is fruitle≈ø≈øe, ful of Ma ‚Ä¢ z or Turki≈øh wheate, and aboundant in fi≈øh: there was in tho≈øe Countries before the Spaniardes arriuall, at the lea≈øt foure hundred thou≈øand Inhabiters, whereof there are ≈øcarce eight thou≈øand left, they haue beene ≈øo rooted out by the Spaniards, ≈øome ≈ølaine, ≈øome ≈øolde for ≈ølaues, and carried into wild vnhabited places, to ≈øee for golde, and others by hiding them≈øelues from the cruell Spaniardes.

div.head: Guatimala.
div.p:
BY Iucatan inward to the land, lieth the prouince of Guatimala, wherein there was a towne, hauing the name of the Prouince, which vppon the eight day of September An. 1541.
‚Ä¢ 541. by meanes of continuall ≈øtormes and raine was wholy ouerthrown and de≈øtroyed, wherein were killed about a hundred and twenty Spaniardes. The day before it hapned, ≈øome of the Indians went vnto the Bi≈øhop of Guatimala, who≈øe name was Franci≈øcus Ma≈øoquin, teling him that at the foote of the hill whereon the towne ≈øtoode, they had heard a mo≈øt horrible and fearefull noy≈øe: whereunto the Bi≈øhop an≈øwering them ≈øaide, haue I not often times willed and in≈øtructed you not to thinke vppon ≈øuch thinges, and pre≈øently after about two houres after midnight, there fell an vnme≈øurable water downe out of the hill, that ranne with ≈øo great a force, that it carried ≈øtones and all thinges with it, diuers fearefull ≈øightes and horrible cries beeing heard and ≈ø√©ene in the aire: after the which the Towne was new built, & placed in a plaine field about 3. miles di≈øtant from the place, wherein it ≈øtood, hauing about 80. or 90. hou≈øes in it all of free ≈øtone, & couered with tiles. In this Prouince are many Earthquakes, as Benzo writeth, who continued long in tho≈øe countries, otherwi≈øe the countrie is of a good and temperate aire, fruitful of corne, and of tr√©es that were brought out of Spaine thether, yet fewe of them pro≈øper, onlie Figge tr√©es and Apricockes, but the fruit is not very ≈øauorie. There are likewi≈øe many Cacauaren: as touching the Religion and manner of tho≈øe people, they are much like tho≈øe of Mexico, and of Nicaragua, whereof I wil ≈øpeake, they likewi≈øe deale together, but becau≈øe this Prouince ≈øtandeth not in our Carde, I haue ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently thereof.

div.head: Fonduras.
div.p: NExt to Guatimala, is the great countrie of Fonduras, wherein before it was inhabited by Spaniards, there were at the lea≈øt, 410000. Indians, whereof there are not at this pre≈øent (nor many yeares ≈øince) aboue 8000. left aliue, part of them ≈ølaine by the Spaniards, part led Captiues and con≈øumed in their golden mines, and part ranne away to hide them≈øelues in de≈øert places and holes vnder the earth, ≈øo to auoide the Spani≈øh tirranie. In this Prouince the ≈øpaniards haue erected 5. townes, which are not in all aboue 120. or 130. hou≈øes, mo≈øt part built of reedes and ≈øt ‚Ä¢ aw, and at this pre≈øent not much inhabited, becau≈øe the gold which is their onlie de≈øire beginneth to faile. The chiefe of the≈øe townes in our Card is named Truxillo, of others, Trugillum, or Turtis Iulia, wherein there is a Bi≈øhop, this Towne is ≈øituate vpon a litle hil, on the ≈øea ≈øide in the north part the re≈øt of the townes ≈øhall likewi≈øe bee ≈øpoken of in the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt. And returning againe to the Cape of Iucatan, right again≈øt it there lieth a mo≈øt ≈øweete and plea≈øant Iland, by a king named Cozumela ‚Ä¢ , who≈øe ance≈øtors dwelt therein, called Co≈øumell, which from the further corner of Cuba Porto di Sa ‚Ä¢ nt Anthoni ‚Ä¢ , is ≈øeuenty miles, and from Iucatan fiue miles, it is round 45. miles, being a flat and euen couÃÑ trie, very fruitfull they haue gold, but it is brought from other places, and great abundance of honie and war, and all kind of fruits, hearbs, birds, and foure footed bea≈øts, for other thinges, as Churches, Hou≈øes, ≈øtreets, traffique, apparrell, and cu≈øtomes, altogether like Iucatan, ≈øome of the hou≈øes are couered with ≈øtraw, becau≈øe they want ≈øtones, yet there are many ≈øtonie places, & in ≈øome places pillers of Marble as they haue in Spaine.

At the fir≈øt entrie of the Spaniards into that Iland they were not receaued, but after the ruler thereof entertained them very curteou≈ølie, and brought them vp into a tower, where they erected a Cro≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe that they arriued there vpon the 5. of May, being as then holie roode day, and called the Iland S. C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, but in our Carde it keept ‚Ä¢ h the old name. In this Tower they found certaine chambers, wherin they ≈øaw many Idols, lying among other Images, which they with great noy≈øe called vpon & prated vnto, offering certaine ≈øweet ≈øauours and incen≈øe vnto them, as other Idolaters and Heathens v≈øe to doe, therein fulfilling their Heatheni≈øh Ceremonies, they are likewi≈øe circumci≈øed.

From this cape to Rio Grando are 100. miles, wherein are contained La Punta de las Mugeres, and the Baliya de la A≈øcention. Rio Grando lieth vnder 16. degrees, and from thence are 150. miles to C ‚Ä¢ uo di Camaron, which are accounted in this manner: fir≈øt, from the great riuer to the hauen of Higueras are 30. miles, from Puerto Higueras to the hauen et Puerto di Cauallo ‚Ä¢ , other thirtie miles. This is the ≈øecond place by the Spaniards diuided into a colonie: a dayes iournie from thence lieth Saint Pedro in a plaine field clo≈øe to certaine hilles,
being the third Colonie of the Spaniardes, not farre from thence runneth the riuer Vilua, and the lake in the middle: from whence he certaine hard groundes like Ilandes couered ouer with weedes, which as the wind bloweth, fleet from place to place.

From Puerto de Cauallas to Puerto del triumpho de la Crus are thirtie miles betweene, the which lieth next to Guamareta, Saint Iacob, and Truxillo. From Puerto del triumpho de la Crus to Capo de Honduras are 30. miles, and from thence to Cabo del Camaron 20. miles, from thence to Cabo de Gatias a dios lying vnder 14. degr√©es, are accounted 70. miles: this is likewi≈øe a Spani≈øh colonie or towne builded by them, and betweene them on the ≈øame coa≈øt lieth Carthago, al≈øo a Spani≈øh towne from Gracias a dios are 70. miles to del Aguadera, which ≈øpringeth out of the lake or ≈øea of Nicaragua, and is heere called Aguadaco: now againe for a time we will leaue ≈øpeaking of the coa≈øt, to declare the Prouince and Countrie of Nicaragua.

div.head: Nicaragua.
div.p:
DEparting from Fondura, and pa≈ø≈øing the borders of Chiulutecca, you come to the Prouince Nicaragua, ≈øtretching towardes the ≈øouth ≈øea, which is not verie great, but rich, fruitfull and plea≈øant, but of ≈øo vnrea≈øonable a heate, that in Sommer time the heate cannot be indured in the day time, but only in the night, it raineth there for the ≈øpace of 6. whole monthes together beginning in Maie. The other ≈øixe moneths are exceeding drie: the day and night being all of a length, honny, waxe, cotton, wool, and bal≈øam growe there in great aboundaunce, and many kindes of fruites, which are not found in other prouinces, neither yet in Hi≈øpaniola, nor any other place: and among the re≈øt a kind of apple, in forme much like a peare, within it there is a round nut, almo≈øt twice as bigge againe as one of our common nuttes, very ≈øw√©ete and plea≈øant of ta≈øte, the tree is great, with ≈ømall leaues. There are few kine, but many hogges, which were brought out of Spaine to br√©ede therein. The country is ful of Indian villages, all with ≈ømal hou≈øes made of reedes, and couered with ≈øtrawe: they haue no mettall: yet at the fir≈øt entraunce of the Spaniards, the inhabitants had certaine common and ba≈øe gold among them, which was brought out of other places thither: there are many parrats, which doe great hurt vnto the ≈øeedes, and would doe more, were it not that they are driuen away by ≈ølings and other meanes. The Spaniards at their arriuall in tho≈øe countries, by rea≈øon of the great abundance of al things, called them the Paradi≈øe of Mahomet. There are many Ginny hennes, and a certaine fruit called Cacauate, which they v≈øe in≈øteed of mony, it groweth on an indifferent great tree, and onely in warme and ≈øhadowe places, as ≈øoone as the Sunne commeth vpon it it withereth, and therefore it is ≈øowed in woodes vnder tr√©es, and in moy≈øt places, and al little enough, but the tr√©es whereby it is planted mu≈øt be higher than it, and bound clo≈øe together, that they may defend and couer them from the heate of the ≈øunne: the fruit is like almonds, and being taken out of their ≈øhels, are couered with a thinne blacke ≈økinne, and the piths being taken out it may be diuided into two or thr√©e partes, hauing browne and gray veines, but of a hard ta≈øte. When they make drinke thereof, they drie it in a pot by the fire, and then brui≈øe it with ≈øtones, which done, they put it in a cullender, or potte made with holes, mixing it with water, and putting thereto a litle of their pepper, and ≈øo drinke it. This drinke is ≈øomewhat bitter, it cooleth the body, not making them drunke, and by them throughout all the country, it is e≈øt√©emed for a mo≈øt pretious thing, which they pre≈øent to men of great account, as we do malue≈øey or hypocra≈øe. The maners of this people are not different from tho≈øe of Mexico, they eate mans fle≈øh, their clokes and garments are without ≈øl√©eues: they kindle their fire by rubbing two p√©eces of wood one again≈øt an other, which is their common cu≈øtome throughout al India: and although they haue great ≈øtore of waxe, yet they knew not how to v≈øe it, for that in ≈øteede of candles they v≈øed lights made of pine tr√©e boughes: their ≈øpeech is diuer≈øe, but the Mexican ≈øp√©ech is the be≈øt, and that is furthe≈øt knowen, for that therewith men may trauell through the country aboue fift√©ene hundred miles, and is very ea≈øie to learne: when they daunce, they v≈øe a very ≈øtrange manner, for they are at lea≈øt three or foure thou≈øand together, ≈øometimes more, according to the number of inhabitants, in the fielde where they wil daunce, being all together, they make the place very cleane, then one of them goeth before leading the daunce, commonly going backeward, turning in and out, all the re≈øt following by three and foure together, v≈øing the like api≈øh toyes, their min≈øtrels and drummes, ≈øinging and playing certaine ≈øongs, whereunto hee that leadeth the daunce aun≈øwereth, and after him all the re≈øt, ≈øome bearing Wayerkens
in their hands, & ≈øome rattles ful of ≈øtones, wherewith they rattle, others haue theyr heades al ≈ølucke with feathers, ≈øome their legs and armes bound about with ≈øtringes full of ≈øhels, ≈øome ouerthwart, and ≈øome crooked, turning their bodies, ≈øome opening their legs, ≈øome their armes, ≈øome counterfeiting the deafe man, and others the blind man, ≈øome laughing, others grinning, with many ≈øtrange deui≈øes, they keep their fea≈øts al that day till night drinking nothing but Cocauate.

The ≈øhips that ≈øaile ouer the ≈øouth ≈øea to Nicaragua, pa≈ø≈øe thorow the narow ≈øtream about fiue and twenty miles inwards, towards the land, til they come to a dorp called Re ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ gio, where there are certaine reed hou≈øes, inhabited by Spaniardes, where the ≈øhips anker by rea≈øon of the good hauen, and becau≈øe of the wood. A dayes iourney from this place ea≈øtward lieth Legio or Leo ‚Ä¢
the Bi≈øhops ≈øea of Nicaragaa, ≈øtanding vpon the border of the lake of Franci≈øco Fernandez, as al≈øo Granaten and other Spani≈øh townes lying vpon the ≈øame lake, fifty miles from each other almo≈øt, at the other ende where the lake i≈ø≈øueth into the northerne ≈øea. Tho≈øe two townes are both ≈øcarce foure≈øcore hou≈øes, part made of lime and ≈øtone, and parte of reedes and ≈øtrawe. Fiue and thirtie miles from Leon lieth a hill, that ca≈øteth out fire, in ≈øuch abundance, that by night they may beholde at the lea≈øt 100000. ≈øparks of fire flying into the aire: many Spaniards are of this opinion, that therin mu≈øt be gold, which giueth the fire a continual e≈ø≈øence, wherby they haue ≈øought many meanes to trie it, but al in vaine, and therefore needele≈ø≈øe to rehear≈øe.
