Returning againe to the lake of Nicaragua. therein are great fi≈øhes, and amonge≈øt the re≈øt a certaine kinde of fi≈øh, in Spani≈øh called Man ‚Ä¢ , hauing finnes hard by their heades, like two hands, this fi≈øh is almo≈øt like an otter of 35. foote long, and twelue foote thicke, the head and tayle like an oxe, ≈ømall eies, hard and hairie ≈økinne, of colour light blew, with two feete like elophantes feete: the ≈øinnes ≈øtanding out like Kopen, feeding their yong ones with their dugges. This fi≈øh feedeth both on land and in the water, they are very familiar with men, whereof the Indians tell a mo≈øt wonderful thing, which is, that there was a king called Ca ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ amavuis, that had taken a yoong M ‚Ä¢ nate which for the ≈øpace of ≈øix and twenty yeres he kept and broght vp with bread, in a lake called Guamabo, that bordered vpon his hou≈øe, which fi≈øh in time became ≈øo tame, that he ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed the dolphin, wherof we reade ≈øo many hi≈øtories, for that at what time ≈øoeuer the kings ≈øeruants called him Matto, Matto, which in Indian ≈øp√©ech is Mani≈øecale or curteous, hee would pre≈øently come out of the lake, and eate meate out of their handes, and woulde likewi≈øe come out of the water, and goe into the hou≈øe, to fetch his meate, and there woulde play with the children: and when any man was de≈øirous to go ouer the lake, he would oftentimes take eight or tenne of them together, and ≈øwimming beare them lightly on his backe ouer the water, in which manner playing with him, the Indians kept this fi≈øh long time, til by ≈øome iniury done vnto him he became angry, for that vppon a time as a Spaniard would prooue if his ≈økinne were as hard as they reported it to be, threw an arrow or dart at him, and although it hurt him not, yet he felt the ≈øharp point of the arrow, and from that time perceiuing that men with beards and in apparel were there, they might wel call him, but al in vaine, for he would neuer come vp againe, but in the end, when the riuer A ‚Ä¢
bunicus chaunced to flowe ≈øo high, that it ranne ouer the bankes, and ≈øo into the lake Guaniabo, the fi≈øh folowed the ≈øtreame, and ≈øwamme into the ≈øea, the≈øe kindes of fi≈øhes are much ≈øeene and taken in that countrey, for that their fle≈øh is of a very good ta≈øte, like hogs fle≈øh, which being ≈øalted is carried to Nombre de Dios, and other places. The lake of Nicaragua lyeth not farre from the ≈øouth ≈øea, and about a hundred miles from the north ≈øea, running through a riuer that is ful of ≈øhips, which the Spaniardes called De≈øaguadera that is, falling of water therein. Thereabouts, & in that riuer there are many crocadiles, that lay their egges vpon the ≈øands on the riuers ≈øides, as bigge as gee≈øe egs, which being throwne again≈øt a ≈øtone wil brui≈øed, but not breake, and in time of hunger, are eaten by the ≈øpaniards, their ta≈øte is like a Mo≈øchu ‚Ä¢
halfe rotten, and by the Indians is accounted for an excellent kinde of meate: by Nicaragua the country is rough and ≈øharpe, becau≈øe of the thicke woodes, and vneuen hilles, where not onely hor≈øes, but men can hardly pa≈ø≈øe ouer, vnle≈ø≈øe it be with great paine and labour: about this countrey for the ≈øpace of foure months, there are certaine Torte ‚Ä¢ ux that doe continue in the ≈øea, as al≈øo vppon the ≈øhoare, which lay their egges as the crocadiles doe, in the ≈øand vppon the ≈øhoare, whereof pre≈øently by rea≈øon of the great heate of the ≈øunne, there commeth yoong Torteaux the fle≈øh of this bea≈øt being fre≈øh, is whole≈øome and plea≈øant to eate.

From Cabo de Gratias a dios, to the Rio Grande, or De≈øaguadera (as I ≈øaid before) are ≈øeuenty miles, from De≈øaguadera to Corobaro are fortie miles, from Corobaro to Nombre de Dios fiftie miles, betw√©ene Corobaro and Nombre de dios lieth Veragua, and the riuer Swerus: the≈øe 90. miles lie vnder nine degrees and ¬Ω, ≈øo that from the poynt of Iucatan to Nombre de Dios are 500. miles.

As touching the maners of the Indians of Sweren that are about the riuer Swerus, & dwelling by Veragua they are not much different from the re≈øt, onely that they eate no mans fle≈øh: in their countrey are many beares, tigers, and lions, that are very fearfull, and flee when they ≈øee a man: there are likewi≈øe very great ≈ønakes, but not venomous, and many ≈øea cats: there is likewi≈øe an other kinde of bea≈øt called Ca≈øcui, in a manner like a blacke pigge, hairie, with a hard ≈økinne, ≈ømal eies, open eares like an elephant, but not ful ≈øo open, nor hanging down, clouen feet, and a litle ≈ønowt, armed like an elephant, and of ≈øo ≈øhril a voyce, that it maketh men deafe, and is of a good and ≈øauory fle≈øh. There is likewi≈øe an other wonderful and ≈øtraunge bea≈øt, of Ge≈ønerus called a Foxe ap ‚Ä¢ , on the belly whereof Nature hath formed an other belly, wherein when it goeth into any place, it hideth her young ones, and ≈øo beareth them about her. This bea≈øt hath a body and member like a foxe, feete like mens hands, or like ≈øea cattes feete, eares like a batte, it is neuer ≈øeene that this bea≈øt letteth her yong ones come foorth but when they ≈øucke, or ea≈øe them≈øelues, but are alwayes therein, vntil they can gette their own meate: al≈øo there is another kind of bea≈øt called Iguanna or Iuanna, not much vnlike our eftes, hauing a thing hanging at his chinne like vnto a beard, and on her head a combe like a cockes combe, vpon his backe certaine ≈øharpe quilles, ≈øticking vpright like thornes, and amonge≈øt the re≈øt, ≈øome hauing teeth like a ≈øawe, with a ≈øharp taile, and ≈øtretching out, ≈øometimes winding like the adder. This bea≈øt is accounted among the vnhurtfull ≈ønakes, euery time it layeth it hath fortie or fiftie egs, round, and as big as a nut, whereof the yellow is ≈øeperated from the white, like hennes egs: they are good to eate, and very ≈øauory fle≈øh, but not roa≈øted either in oyle or butter, onely in water: this bea≈øt feedeth both on land, and in the water, it climeth trees, and is fearful to behold, ≈øpecially to tho≈øe that knowe not the nature thereof, yet it is ≈øo gentle & quiet that it maketh not any noy≈øe, and being taken and bound, it liueth at the lea≈øt tenne or twelue dayes without meate, it is of a good and ≈øauoury fle≈øh, and is kept for likori≈øhne≈ø≈øe, ≈øpecially the women, onely ≈øuch as haue had the pox, if they eate it, their paine reneweth.

div.head: Nombre de Dios.
div.p:
NOmbre de Dios, is a towne of traffike lying on the north ≈øea, ≈øo named by Diego de Nique≈øa. a Spaniard, that had indured ≈øome hard fortune, and landing in that hauen with the re≈øt of his men ≈øaide,
‚Ä¢ n Nombre de Dios, that is, in the name of God, and ≈øo began his worke againe which before he did pretend, and there erected certaine hou≈øes, giuing the place the name afore≈øaid: this towne lieth ea≈øt and we≈øt vpon the ≈øea ≈øide, in the middle of a very great wood, in a very vnwhole≈øome place, ≈øpecially in winter time, by rea≈øon of the greate heate and moy≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the earth, as al≈øo, becau≈øe of the moori≈øh ground that lieth on the we≈øt ≈øide of the towne, whereby many of the Indians die: the hou≈øes are built after the Spani≈øh maner, as al≈øo tho≈øe of Panama, wherein many Merchants dwel that ≈øell their wares by the great: the re≈øt of the hou≈øes are for ≈øtrangers, like Innes, as al≈øo for Grocers, handicraft≈ømen, and ≈øuch like, mo≈øt part of the merchants of Nombre de Dios, haue hou≈øes likewi≈øe in Panama, for that the traffique out of Peru commeth to Panama, and out of Spaine to Nombre de Dios, and there they are continually re≈øident, vntill they become rich, and then they goe to other places, or el≈øe returne into Spaine. On the north ≈øide of this towne lieth the hauen wherein many ≈øhips may a ‚Ä¢
ker: touching ≈øuch fruits as they bring „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Spaine into tho≈øe countries, there g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
eth ≈øome in that vntemperate and vn ‚Ä¢
≈øome ayre, as lemons, oranges, re „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hes, coleworts, and lettuce, but very ≈ømall, few, & not very good, other victuals are brought thither out of Hi≈øpaniola, Cuba, and the prouince of Nicaragua, as India wheat or maiz, bread called Cazab ‚Ä¢ , ≈øalt fi≈øh, hogges, batatas, and from Panama kine, and fle≈øh vn≈øalted, all other kind of wares are broght out of Spaine thither, for that euery yeere there commeth ≈øhippes out of Spaine laden with wine, meale, bread, bi≈øket, oliues, oile, figs, rea≈øins, ≈øilks, woollen and linnen cloth, and ≈øuch wares nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øu≈øtenance of man: which wares being arriued in that country, are carried in little ≈øcutes through the riuer Chiara, to a place called Ciu ‚Ä¢ ce, fifteene miles di≈øtant from Panama, where it is deliuered to a Spani≈øh Factor, which
regi≈øtreth all the wares, and k√©epeth them, vntill they be carried by bea≈øts vnto Panama, a Towne lying on the other ≈øide of the Lake, from whence by ≈øhips they are conueyed into other places, thorow the whole country of Pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , C ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ s, and Chila. as al≈øo northward in the out places of the Spaniards. The breadth of the country betweene N ‚Ä¢ mbre de Dio ‚Ä¢ , and Panama, from the one ≈øide to the other, is not aboue ≈øeuenteene miles, whereby Peru is no I≈øland. The Spaniards compare this towne to Venice, but I think they nere ≈øaw it, for if they had, doubtles they would be of another opinion.

But letting Panam ‚Ä¢
re≈øt til another time I will proceede with the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt, from Nombre de Dios to Farallones del Darien, lying vnder eight degr√©es, are ≈øeuentie miles: touching the towne of Dariene. til you come to the old virgine Mary, it heth in an vnwhole≈øome place, therefore all the inhabitants are of a pale yellow collour like tho≈øe that haue the yellow iandi≈øe, yet it proceedeth not from the nature of the land, for that in places of the ≈øame height there is whol≈øome dwelling, that is, where they haue fre≈øh water, and cleere fountains and where vnder the ≈øame height they dwel vpon hilles, and not as Dariene which lieth in a valley: the ≈øides of the riuer being compa≈ø≈øed with high hilles, and by that means they haue the ≈øunne but at noone time, only right ouer them, and on both ≈øides, both before and behinde they are no le≈ø≈øe troubled with the reflexion of the ≈øunne beams, cau≈øing a mo≈øt vn≈øupportable heat, in ≈øuch ≈øort that the dwelling in Dariene is not hurtful, by rea≈øon of the nature of the land, but becau≈øe of the ≈øituation thereof: it is likewi≈øe deadly, by rea≈øon of the moori≈øhne≈ø≈øe of the ground, beeing wholly compa≈ø≈øed about with moori≈øh ≈øtincking water, the Towne it ≈øelfe being a very pitte or moori≈øh plotte of ground: and when they throwe water vpon the floores of their hou≈øes, it doth pre≈øently ingender toades, and when they do digge but a ≈øpanne and a halfe deepe in the earth, pre≈øently there appeareth Adders out of the poy≈øoned water, that are within the filthy earth of the riuer, which floweth with filth, and full of durt. Out of this deepe valley, euen vnto the ≈øea, in Dariene are Tygars, Lions, and Crocadiles, Oxen, Hogges and Hor≈øes, in great abundaunce, and greater than tho≈øe that are brought thither out of Spaine, many great trees and fruit, and all kindes of fruits and hearbs that are to be eaten: the people are of colour betweene darke and red yellow, of good proportion, with little haire, or beardes, onely vpon the head and the eiebrowes, ≈øpecially the women, which with a certaine hearb make it fall off, they goe all naked, ≈øpecially vpon their heades, they haue their members hidden, eyther in a ≈øhell, or in a ca≈øe, or el≈øe they couer it with a cotten linnen, the women are couered from the middle to the knees, all the re≈øt is naked and bare: in that countrey there is no winter, for that the mouth of the riuer Dariene lieth le≈ø≈øe than eight degrees from the equinoctiall, ≈øo that day and night is there of a length: from the furthe≈øt point that reacheth into the ≈øea, lieth a village in the Prouince of Caribana, nine miles from Dariene called Futeraca and from thence about three miles lieth Vraba, wherof the whole ≈øtream hath her name, and in time pa≈øt was the chiefe Towne of the kingdome: ≈øixe miles off lieth Fe ‚Ä¢ , from thence to Zereme are 9. miles, from Zereme to Sorache, are twelue miles. The≈øe places were all full of Camballes, and when they had no ennemies to fight withall, they fought one again≈øt the other, that they might deuoure the men.

The gulfe of Vraba is 14. miles long, and in the entrie ≈øixe miles broade, and the nearer it runneth to the firme land, the narrower it is, into this riuer runne many waters, and one that is muche more pro≈øperous then the Riuer Nilus, what≈øoeuer is ≈øowed or planted in Vraba, it ≈øpringeth very ≈øpeedily, for that within 28. daies they haue ripe Cucumbers, Goardes, Melons, &c. In Dariene and Vraba there groweth much fruit that is verie plea≈øant and ≈øweete of ta≈øte, & much aboue our fruits, whereof who≈øoeuer is de≈øirous to know more, let him reade the hi≈øtories thereof, as Peter Martir in his ninth book of the de≈øcriptioÃÑ of the firme land.

In the mouth of the gulfe of Vraba lyeth a ≈ømall I≈øland called Tortuga, that is, the I≈øland of Torteaux, becau≈øe it is formed like a Torteaux, or becau≈øe there are many Torteauxes therein, and further on the ≈øame coa≈øt lyeth the I≈øland l. Fuerte, which is in the middle betweene Vraba and Carthago, wherein al≈øo are Canibals, mo≈øt cruell villaines, and from thence you come to Puerto de Caribana, the hauen of Caribana, or of Cambals, whereof the Caribes haue receiued their name. From thence you come to the riuer de Guerra, and then to the riuer of Zenu, which is a great hauen, the town being about ≈øeuen or eight ≈øpani≈øh miles and a half from the ≈øea, wherin is great traffike of fi≈øh, fine gold & ≈øiluer works. They gather gold out of the riuers in great floods & rains placing great nettes in the water, wherein they ≈øtay the gold, which is in great grains:
it was di≈øcouered by Roderigo de Ba≈øtidas, in the yeere of our Lord 1502. 1502 And within two yeares after by Giouanni de la Co≈øa: And then againe in the yeare of our Lorde 1509. 1509 by Don Anci≈øus: and after him followed Alon≈øo de Hoieda, who de≈øiring to di≈øcouer their ≈øands, or barter with the inhabitants, as al≈øo to learne their ≈øpeech, and to know the riches of the country, ≈øought to come acquainted with them, but the Indians with≈øtoode them, and determined to fight: wherewith the Spaniardes ≈øhewed ≈øignes of peace, cau≈øing an interpreter (that Franci≈øcus Pizairo had brought from Vraua) to ≈øpeake vnto them, ≈øaying that h√©e and his companions the Spaniards were chri≈øtians, peaceable and quiet people, and ≈øuch as hauing by long voyages pa≈ø≈øed the great Ocean ≈øeas, had as then need of all nece≈ø≈øary proui≈øions, and of golde, de≈øiring them to barter the ≈øame with them, for other co≈øtly wares, which they had neuer ≈øeene. Wherevnto the Cariben of Zenu an≈øwered them, that it might well be they were ≈øuch quiet people, but yet they ≈øhewed not the ≈øigns of peace, and therefore they willed them pre≈øently to departe out of their countrey, for they ≈øaide they were not minded to be mocked by them, neither meant they to indure an enemies or ≈øtraungers weapon within their country. Wherevpon D. Anci≈øus replying an≈øwered them and ≈øaide, that he could not with honour depart from thence, before he hadde deliuered his me≈ø≈øage vnto them for the which he was ≈øent thither, making a long oration, thereby to per≈øwade them to the chri≈øtian faith, grounded onely vpon one God maker of heauen and earth, and of all creatures therein: in the end telling them that the holy Father the Pope of Rome Chri≈øts lieutenant throughout al the world, hauing ab≈øolute power ouer mens ≈øoules, & religion, had giuen their countrey to the mighty king of Spaine his ma≈øter, & that he was purpo≈øely ≈øent thither, to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, wi≈øhing them therefore not to oppo≈øe them≈øelues agen≈øt him, if they meant to become chri≈øtians and ≈øubiects to ≈øo great a Prince, onelie paying a ≈ømall yeerely tribute of golde. Whereunto they in ie≈øting manner, and ≈ømiling, aun≈øwered much after the ≈øame manner, as it is written of Attabalipa, that they liked well of his propo≈øition touching one only God, but as then they were not minded to argue therof, neyther yet to leaue their religion, & that the Pope might well bee liberall of other mens goods, that belonged not to him, or at lea≈øt that he ≈øhould giue that which was in his power to deliuer, as al≈øo that the king of Spaine was either very poore, to de≈øire that which was none of his, or very bold to ≈øeeke that which he knew not, and that if he came to inuade their countrey, they would ≈øet his head vpon a ≈øtake, as they had done manie other enemies his like: but the Spaniardes not e≈øteeming their words, entred vpon the land and ouercame them.

From the gulfe Vraba to Carthagena are 70. miles, betweene the which two places the hauens and riuers afore≈øaide do lie, the partition being pa≈ø≈øed ouer, as al≈øo Puerto de Naos, that is, the hauen of Ships, it is from Carthagena to S. Martha fiftie miles.

div.head: Carthagena.
div.p:
CArthagena was ≈øo named, becau≈øe that in the mouth of the hauen there lieth an I≈øland in Indian ≈øpeech called Codego, as al≈øo new Carthago, in Spaine Scombria, or els bicau≈øe al the Spaniards dwelling therin, came out of the Cittie of Carthago in Spaine: the I≈øland is about two miles long and a mile broad. When the Spanyardes came fir≈øt into that countrey, they found it ful of Fi≈øhermen, whereof at this time they can hardly find any remnant, which is not to be wondered at, for that not onely in this prouince, but in al the other I≈ølands, wherin the Spaniards haue b√©ene, there is hardly any Indians left, becau≈øe, the Indians as long as po≈ø≈øibl they might wold neuer haue any dealings with the Spaniardes, becau≈øe of their tyranny. This Countrey is rich of fi≈øh, fruites, and all kinde of victualles nece≈ø≈øary for men: they couer their priuy members with clothes of cotten wooll: both men and women go to the wars, for in the yeere of our Lorde 1509. as a Spaniard called Martinus Ami≈øus made warre vppon tho≈øe of Zenu, bordering vpon Carthegena, hee tooke an Indian woman of the age of twenty yeeres, that with her owne hands hadde ≈ølaine 28. Chri≈øtians: their arrowes are poy≈øoned, and they eate their ‚Ä¢ nue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tes fle≈øh, and ≈øpoiled many Spanyards: at their fea≈øts which in times pa≈øt they v≈øed to hold they beautifie their bodies in the be≈øt maner they can deui≈øe, with iewells, and golden bracelets, mingled with pearles, and ≈øtones called ≈ømaragdes, wearing them about their faces, armes, legges, and other parts of their bodies: their chiefe merchandi≈øes are ≈øalt, fi≈øh, and pepper, which groweth in great abundance all along the coa≈øt, it is of forme long, and ≈øharper than the ‚Ä¢ ≈øt Indian pepper, and much ≈øweeter and plea≈øanter of ≈ømell than the common Bra ‚Ä¢ ilia pepper, which wares they carrie into ≈øuch
places as want it, where they barter for other things, before they were vnder the ≈øubiection of the Spaniards: they had many kindes of fruites and trees, cotten wooll, feathers, golde bracelets, gold, many pearles, ≈ømaragdes, ≈ølaues, and diuers rootes, wherwith they traffiked, bartering them without any re≈øpect, de≈øire or couetou≈ønes, v≈øing the≈øe wordes, Take this, and giue me ≈øome other ware for it, but no ware was more e≈øteemed with them than victualles, but now they likewi≈øe beginne to couet after golde and other thinges, whiche they haue learned of the Spaniards. Benzo in his ≈øecond booke of the Indian hi≈øtorie and fift chapter ≈øheweth a notable example, ≈øaying, that vpon a time he being very hungry, went into an Indians hou≈øe, praying him to ≈øel him a chickin, and the Indian a≈økt him what hee would giue him, he pulling foorth a ≈øpani≈øh riall of ≈øiluer, gaue it him, which the Indian taking, helde betweene his teeth, and ≈øaide, Then I perceue you would haue my victualles, and giue mee that which no man can eate, neither is it of any account, therefore take you your peece of ≈øiluer, and I wil keep my victualls.

Betweene Carthagena and ≈øaint Martha, there runneth a great ≈øwift riuer called Rio Grande, which ≈øtandeth in our Carde, which i≈ø≈øueth with ≈øuch force into the Sea, ≈øpecially in winter, that it beats the ≈øtream of the ≈øea backe againe, whereby the ≈øhipps that pa≈ø≈øe by it, may ea≈øily take in water. Sayling vpwardes into this riuer to the kingdome of Bogota, by the Spaniards called Granada, there are certaine mines of emeraldes found in the valley of Tunia, in this Carde called Tomana, whereabouts the ≈øpaniards haue builded new Carthage. The inhabitantes of the valley of Tunia, and the people bordering on the ≈øame doe wor≈øhip the ≈øunne for their chife god, with ≈øuch reuerence, that they dare not ≈øtare or once looke ≈øtedfa≈øtly vpon it: they likewi≈øe wor≈øhip the Moone, but not ≈øo much as the ≈øun: in their wars, in≈øteed of Ancients they tie the bones of certaine men (who in their liues were valiaunt in armes) vppon long ≈øtaues, and ≈øo carry them before them to incorage others to be the like, and make them the readier to fight. Their weapons are arrowes, pikes made of palme tree wood, and ≈øtone ≈øwordes. They bury their kings with golden neckelaces, ≈øette with emerauldes, and with bread and wine, wherof the Spaniards haue fouÃÑd many ≈øuch graues, which they haue opened. The people that dwell vpon the afore≈øaid great riuer, are all Caniballs or Caribes, as al≈øo tho≈øe that dwell about ≈øaint Martha, and in time pa≈øt were Caribes. The inhabitants of the I≈ølandes of Boriquen, Dominico, Matitini, Cibuchine (now called ≈øaint Croce) and Guadalupe, as it is already declared, which rowe on the water with ≈øcutes made of a certayn wood called Canois, and that fought again≈øt tho≈øe of Hi≈øpaniola, and the people of the firme land, whome they ≈øpoyled and eate.

The common opinion is, that they came fir≈øt out of the firme land of Caribana, by Vraba, and from Nombre de Dios, in Indian ≈øpeech called Caribes, and all ≈øtrong and valiaunt menne, are nowe by them called Caribes, which are very expert in bowes and arrowes. The Bra≈øilians name them Prophets, or Sooth≈øayers, and Caribes Prie≈øts.

The people inhabiting in the valley of Tunia, poi≈øon their arrowes, and before the Spaniards ouercame them they hadde continuall warres again≈øt the people of Bagota, or Bogota, they are good ≈øouldiers, cruel, and very reuengeatiue: when they goe to warres, they carry their Idoll Chiappen with them, as a iudge of the victorie, vnto whome before they enter into the field, they offer many ≈øacrifices and offerings of certaine liuing men, b√©eing the children of ≈ølaues, or of their ennemies, painting all the Image with bloud, which doone, they doe eate the fle≈øh: when they retourned victorious, they helde great fea≈øts with dauncings, leapings, and ≈øingings, ≈øome drinking them≈øelues druncke, and agayne be≈ømeering their Image with blood, and being ouercome, they were ≈øorrowfull, and heauy, ≈øeeking by new ≈øacrifices to intreats theyr Chiappen, that h√©e woulde helpe and a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, and ≈øend them victory again≈øt theyr enemies.

div.head: S. Martha.
div.p: SAint Martha is al≈øo a Towne and Hauen of the Spaniardes lying on the firme land vnder eleuen degrees, on the north ≈øide of the Equinoctial line about fiftie Spani≈øh miles, from Carthagena, it lieth at the foote of certayne hills, ≈øo mon≈øtrous high, that it is, incredible, howe in ≈øo great extreame heate, ≈øo great quantitie of ≈ønowe ≈øhould lie vpon the toppes of tho≈øe hills which is ≈øeene a great way off, and whereby the hauen is knowne.

This country was di≈øcouered and taken by Roderigo de Ba≈øtidas in 1524. 1524. where it co≈øt him his life, not by the enemy, but by
his owne men, that when he was a≈øleepe, killed him, and gaue him fiue woundes in his body. The people of this country are ≈øo cruell and fierce, that they haue oftentimes driuen the Spaniards from their countrey, not caring for the ≈øhippes, but running into the ≈øea, till the water mounted as high as their brea≈øts, ≈øhooting with thou≈øandes of poy≈øoned arrowes, and neuer would giue ouer, were it not by meanes of the great ≈øhot, together with the cries of ≈øuch as were afraid, and ran away, thinking them to be thunder claps, which oft times happen in tho≈øe countries, by rea≈øon of the euenne≈ø≈øe of the countrey, with the height of the hills. The compa≈ø≈øe of this hauen is three Spanni≈øh miles, and ≈øo cleere that they may ≈øee ≈øtones lying on the ground within the water, although it is at the lea≈øt twentie elles deepe: into this hauen there floweth twoo running waters, but not fit for great ≈øhips, but onely for little boates, cut out of peeces of wood: it is a great plea≈øure to heare what they report of the great numbers, and goodnes of the fi≈øhes that are taken thereabouts both in fre≈øh and ≈øalt water, for the which cau≈øe they found many Fi≈øhermen thereabouts, with many nettes made of packethreede, hanging on cotten ropes, which was their greate≈øt liuing, for that for fi≈øh they had what≈øoeuer they de≈øired of their neighbours. In this country they found ≈øaphires, emerauldes, calcedonies, ia≈øpers, amber, bra≈øil wood, golde and pearles, that is, in the two prouinces Caramaira and Sacurma, wherein the two hauens Carthagena and S. Martha do lie. Caramaira is a very fruitfull and plea≈øant countrey, wherein there falleth neither hard winter, nor ouer hote ≈øummer, day and night being there almo≈øt of a length. The Spaniardes hauing taken in this country, found gardeins ready planted, moy≈øtned with ≈øtrange waters like the gardeins in Italie: their common meate is Ages, luca, Maiz, Batatas, and ≈øome fruites of trees, ≈øuch as other Indians therabouts do v≈øe, they eate fi≈øh al≈øo, and mans fle≈øh, but not often. Ages are rootes, of the greatne≈ø≈øe of long turnopes in Italie, plea≈øant of ta≈øte, not much vnlike che≈ønuttes, which they v≈øe in banquets in≈øteede of fruit. Iuca is al≈øo a kinde of roote whereof they do make bread: the Iuca that groweth in Cuba. Hayti, & other Ilands, is very hurtful being eaten raw: and to the contrary that of S. Martha is very whol≈øome, being otherwi≈øe eaten, it is very good of ta≈øte: the≈øe roots are planted & not ≈øowne, which being ripe, are as great as a mans arme, or the ≈ømal of his leg, & ripeneth in halfe a yere, but if it ≈øtand two y√©eres in the ground, it maketh better bread, being ripe, they are pre≈øt betweene 2 ≈øtones, wherby the ≈øap runneth forth, which is very hurtful in the I≈ølands, vnle≈ø≈øe it be ≈øodden, as we doe milke: otherwi≈øe being drunke of men or bea≈øts, it kills them as being a ≈øtrong poi≈øon, but ≈øod till it con≈øumeth to the half, & ≈øo let ≈øtand til it be cold, it may be v≈øed in≈øteede of vineger, & being ≈øod til it be thick, it becoms ≈øweet like hony, & ≈øo they v≈øe it in the firm land, being raw, for drink, and ≈øodden, for vineger & hony. I ≈øaid in the firme land, for that in the I≈ølands it is very dangerous & venomous: of the material ≈øub≈øtance of the roote being pre≈øt, which is like almonds that are ≈øtampt, they make round cakes as big as dollars, which they bake, & is their Cacaui or bread, wherewith they ≈øo long haue nori≈øhed them≈øelues: this bread is ≈øomwhat har≈øh in the throat, if it be not tempered with water, or mixed with other meate. Yet I had rather eate bread made of Maiz, that is, Bra≈øilia wheate, for that it giueth no le≈ø≈øe ≈øu≈øtenance than our wheate, & is very whol≈øome, agreeing with ye ≈øtomak, wherof they make bread, as we do of wheat Batatas are al≈øo common, & in great aboundance in this country, which are roots of the thickne≈ø≈øe of a mans arme, & ≈øome ≈ømaller, plea≈øant of ta≈øte, and procuring good nori≈øhment, yet they cau≈øe wind, vnle≈ø≈øe you ro≈øt theÃÑ, then they loo≈øe that effect, ≈øpecialy when they are eaten with any good wine: of the≈øe rootes they al≈øo make con≈øerues, not much vnlike that which is made of Quinces, and cakes, with other ≈øuch kinds of deui≈øes. div.head: Curiana.
div.p:
CVriana hath a hauen like that of Callice in Spaine, where on the ≈øhore there are about eight hou≈øes, but not farre from thence within the land there was a v ‚Ä¢ llage, full of people, that went naked, but very friendly, for ple, innocent, and familar, and receiued the Spaniards w ‚Ä¢ th great ioy, and for pinnes, n√©edles, Lels gla≈ø≈øes, and beads, they gaue them many ≈øtrings of pearles: receiuing them into their hou≈øes, ≈øeruing them with al kinds of meates, and for foure pinnes gaue them a peacocke, for two pins a phe≈øant, for one pinne a turtle doue, or hou≈øe pigeon, for a ≈øtone, g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe, or a pin or two, a goo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ : & they a≈øking them what they would do with the pinnes, ≈øeeing they were naked, they ≈øaid they were good to pick their teeth, and for the belles they tooke great delight to heare them ring: the country is very ful of the birdes before rehear≈øed: al≈øo of hartes, wilde ≈øwine, and cennies, of colour and greatne≈ø≈øe like our hares, which birdes and deeres fle≈øh is their meate, as al≈øo the pearle oy≈øters, whereof thereabouts are great aboundance, and much eaten: they are al very ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ful in ≈øhooting at wild bea≈øts and birds, their beates are hewed out of a peece of hard wood, but not ≈øo well proportioned as tho≈øe of the Canniballes, and in H ‚Ä¢ ≈øpani ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ , which they call Gall ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, their hou≈øes are made of wood, and couered with palme „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ues, wherein, when they are at re≈ø ‚Ä¢ , th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ may ea≈øily heare the fearefull cries of wilde bea≈øts, which hurt not any man, for „Äà‚óä„Äâ inhabitants go al naked, and without campany into the wooddes, onely with their be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s and arrowes, and not it was neuer heard that any of them was euer ≈ølaine or deuoured by wild bea≈øts. They likewi≈øe brought the Spaniardes as many hartes and wilde ≈øwine as they de≈øired, all killed with theyr arrowes, their breade is of rootes or Maiz like other Indians: the people haue blacke and halfe curled hayre, and ≈øomewhat long: they make their teeth white with an hearb which all the day they chawe in their mouthes, which hauing chawed, they ≈øp ‚Ä¢ tte out againe, wa≈øhing their mouthes. The women are better for keeping of a hou≈øe, than to labour in the fieldes, and the men v≈øe to worke in the groundes, and to hunt: al≈øo to goe to warres, to dance and to play. In their hou≈øes they haue many earthen ve≈ø≈øels, as cups, pots, & ≈øuch like, which are brought them from other places.

They keepe certayne y√©erely fayres, euery one carrying to ech other, ≈øuch things as they want. They weare ≈øtrings of pearles about their necks, as common as the countrey women in Italie weare cri≈øtall beades, whereon hangeth many bea≈øtes and birdes made of ba≈øe gold, like Rheins gold, which is brought vnto them from Carichieta, ≈øixe dayes iourney from thence, towardes the ≈øouth: and when the Spaniardes a≈øked of them where they had the golde, they made ≈øignes which way, ≈øhewing them it was in an other countrey beyond them, but coun≈øelled them not to go thither, ≈øaying they were Canniballes, and ≈øuch as eate mans fle≈øh. The men bore a goard which they weare for a codpeece, and tie about their middles with a ≈øtring, hiding their members therein, or in a Snakes ≈øhel, the re≈øt of theyr bodies are al naked. Thus much for the cu≈øtomes and manners of Curiana. Betweene the Cape of Saint Roman, and Golfo Tri≈øte lieth Core Taratara, and P. Secco. From Golfo Tri≈øte to Cariari are a hundred miles, the coa≈øt lying vnder tenne degrees: betweene them lieth manie hauens and riuers, ≈øpecialy Puerto di Canna Fi≈øtola, P. Fle ‚Ä¢ chado, that is, the point where they were ≈øhotte at with arrowes. Punto Muerte, the dead hauen. Cabo de Ioan Blanco, the cape of Iohn White, Cabo la Colhera, Rio Dunari, Illa de Pirico, Maracapana, Chelheribiche, St. Fee, that is, holy Faith, Rio de Cumana, Punta D'ara ‚Ä¢ a C ‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

div.head: A certaine de≈øcription of Maracapana, and Cumana.
div.p:
CVmana ≈øignifieth a Prouince and a Riuer, wherin there is a towne and a cloi≈øter of grey Friers, becau≈øe of the great numbers of pearles that are found thereabouts. The people of this countrey went naked, onely that they couered their members, eyther in a gorde, or Snakes ≈øhels, or el≈øe with bandes of reedes or cotton wooll: in wars they weare mantles, and decke them≈øelues with feathers: at fea≈øts and bankets they paint them≈øelues, or el≈øe ≈øtroke them≈øelues ouer with certaine gum, and ≈øalues that be clammy, wherein they ≈øticke feathers of all colours, which is no ill ≈øight: they cut their haire aboue their eares, and if any haire grow vpon their knees, or on their faces, they pul them out, and will haue no haire vpon any place of their body, although they are by nature mo≈øt of them without beards or haire, and ≈øuch as let their haire grow after the Spani≈øh manner, they call them bea≈øts: the≈øe people make great meanes to make their teeth blacke, and ≈øuch as haue them white, they e≈øteeme them to be women, becau≈øe they take no paines to make them blacke, which they do with the powder or ≈øap of a certaine hearbe, by them called Hay, or Gay, which leaues are very ≈øoft like turpentine leaues, and in fa≈øhion like Mortella, being of the age of 15. yeers, and that their courages began to ri≈øe: they begin to beare tho≈øe leaues in their mouths, and to chaw them, vntil their teeth become as blacke as coles, which blackne≈ø≈øe continueth vntill they die, which likewi≈øe pre≈øerueth the teeth from rotting, ≈øpoyling, or any paine, they mire the powder of that leafe with another ≈øort of powder of a kinde of wood, and with chalk of white ≈øhells burned, in which ≈øort tho≈øe of the Ea≈øt Indies v≈øe their betele and Arrecca, with chalke of oy≈øters, which is already declared in the de≈øcription of the Ea≈øt Indies: the powder of the≈øe leaues, woodde and chalke they beare continually in their mouthes, ≈øtill chawing it, which they keepe in ba≈øketts and boxes made of reedes, to ≈øel and barter the ≈øame in the markets round about them, for gold, ≈ølaues, and cotten, and for other wares: al the maides goe naked, only they weare certaine bandes about their knees, which they binde very hard, that their hips and thighes may ≈øeeme thicke, which they e≈øt√©eme for a beauty: the married women weare ≈øhooes, and liue very hone≈øtly: and if they commit adultery, they are for≈øaken by their hu≈øbands, & puni≈øhed. The lords and rich men of the country haue as many wiues as they li≈øt: and if any man come to their hou≈øes to lodge, they giue them one of the faire≈øt to lie by them: the re≈øt haue but one, and ≈øome none: the women till the land, and looke to the hou≈øe, and the men not being in the warres, doe fi≈øh and hunt: they are highminded, reuengeatiue, and ha≈øtie: their chiefe weapons are poy≈øoned arrowes, which they prepare in diuers maners, as with the blood of ≈ønakes, the iuice of hearbes, and mixtures of many other things, whereby there is no means to heale ≈øuch as are once wounded therewith. The children, women, and men from their youth vpwards learne to ≈øhoote in bowes: their meate is hor≈øleaches, battes, gra≈øhoppers, creui≈øhes, ≈øpiders, bees, and rawe, ≈øodden,
and ro≈øted lice, they ≈øpare no liuing creature what≈øoeuer, but they eat it, which is to be wondered at con≈øidering their country is ≈øo wel repleni≈øhed with good bread, wine, fruite, fi≈øh, and all kinde of fle≈øh in great aboundance whereby it commeth that the≈øe people haue alwaies ≈øpots in their eyes, or el≈øe are dimme of ≈øight, which ≈øome notwith≈øtanding impute to the propertie of the water in the riuer of Cumana: they clo≈øe their gardens or lands with cotteÃÑ yarne, by them called Bexuco, placing it about the height of a man, and among them it is accouÃÑted for a great offence, if any man ≈øhould venter either to climbe ouer, or creep vnder that cotten, holding for certaine that who≈øoeuer doth teare it, ≈øhal die pre≈øently after it. The men of Cumana, as I ≈øaid before, are much giuen to hunting, wherein they are verie ≈økilful. They hunt and kil Lions, Tigers, Goates, Ileren, Hogs, and al other kinde of foure footed bea≈øts, which they kil with bowes, or take with nettes. There are likewi≈øe in the≈øe prouinces many verie ≈øtrange bea≈øts, part whereof are alreadie de≈øcribed, and part not: he therefore that de≈øireth further in≈øtruction heerein, let him reade the Spani≈øh hi≈øtoriografers, that write larger. The women as I ≈øaid, til the ground, ≈øow Maiz, and all kinde of corne, plant Batates, and other trees, watering them, ≈øpecially the Hay, wherewith they make their teeth blacke: they plant tr√©es, which being cutte, there i≈ø≈øueth a white liquour like milke, which changeth into a ≈øweete gumme, verie good to ≈ømell vnto. They plant likewi≈øe other trees called Guare ‚Ä¢ ma, whereof the fruit is like a Mulberie, but ≈øomewhat harder, whereof they make a certaine kinde of ≈øodden Mu≈øt, which healeth colde, and out of the wood of the ≈øame tree they make fire. They haue another kind of high and ≈øweete ≈ømelling tr√©e, which ≈øeemeth to be Cedar, whereof the wood is verie good to make che≈øts & ca≈øes, & by rea≈øon of the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the wood, good to keep things in: but putting bread into them, it becommeth ≈øo bitter, that it is not to be eaten: the wood is likewi≈øe good to make ≈øhips, for that it neuer con≈øumeth in the water, by wormes, or any other meanes. There are other trees from whence they haue lime, wherewith they gette birdes, and annoint their bodyes therewith, wherein they ≈øtick feathers. The land of it ≈øelfe bringeth forth Ca≈øsia, but they eate it not, neither knowe how to v≈øe it. There are ≈øo many Ro≈øes and ≈øweete flowers in that countrey, that the ≈ømel thereof maketh mens heades to ake, in ≈ømel exceeding mu≈øke: wormes, as gra≈øhoppers, Caterpillers, and ≈øuch like, there are verie manie, which de≈øtroy the ≈øeed. There are likewi≈øe vains of ≈øea coles burning like pitch, whereof they make great profite. Thus much concerning the fruitfulne≈ø≈øe of the countrey, their manners and cu≈øtomes in planting, hunting, &c. Be≈øides this, the≈øe people take great plea≈øure in twoo things, that is, dancing and drinking, often times ≈øpending eight dayes together in banquetting, dancing, and drinking them≈øelues drunke: be≈øides their ordinarie dancings and meeting together, at the fea≈øts and coronations of their Kings and Lordes, or in common a≈ø≈øemblies and publike bankets: many of them meete together, euerie one dre≈øt in a ≈øeueral maner, ≈øome with crowns of feathers, others with ≈øhelles or fruits about their legges, like Iuglers heere in our countrey, v≈øing al kinds of toyes and deuices, ≈øome ≈øtraight, others crooked, ≈øome backwards, ≈øome forwards, grinning, laughing, counterfetting the deafe, blind, and lame man: fi≈øhing, weauing, and doing al kinde of workes, and that for the ≈øpace of fiue or ≈øixe howres together, for that hee which continueth longe≈øt in that manner is the be≈øt man, and he that drinketh wel is a lu≈øtie fellow: hauing danced, they ≈øitte down cro≈ø≈øe legged like a Taylor, and make good cheare, drinking them≈øelues drunke at the kings charges, of which their dancing I haue ≈øpoken in another place, ≈øo that to ≈øpeake any more thereof it were needle≈ø≈øe. They are great Idolaters, praying to the Sunne and the Moone, thinking them to bee man and wife, and to be great Gods: They feare the Sunne verie much when it thundereth or lightneth, ≈øaying that it is angry with them: they fa≈øt when there is any eclip≈øe of the Moone, ≈øpecially the women, for the married women plucke theyr haires, and ≈øcratch their faces with theyr nailes, th ‚Ä¢ maides thru≈øt thornes of fi≈øhes into their armes, and therwith draw bloud, thinking that when the Moone is in the full, they thinke it is to be ≈øhot or hurt by the ≈øunne, by rea≈øon of ≈øome anger or greefe he hath conceiued again≈øt it: when any blazing ≈øtar appeereth, they make a great noi≈øe with Drummes, and hallowing, thinking by that meanes it will bee gone, for they thinke a blazing ≈øtarre ≈øignifieth ≈øome great hurt or euill fortune. Among many Idols and figures which they honour and inuoke for Gods, they haue a certaine thing like a Burguinion Cro≈ø≈øe, which they hang vpon their new borne children, thinking thereby they are pre≈øerued in the night from all euill things. Their prie≈øts are called P ‚Ä¢ aces,
who in tho≈øe countries haue the maidenheades of their Daughters when they marrie. Their office likewi≈øe is to heale the ≈øicke, and to ≈øay truth, to call vppon the the diuel, and to conclude, they are ≈økilful in the blacke art and coniurers. They heale with hearbes and rootes, both ≈øodden and raw, beaten, and mi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed with fat of birdes, fi≈øh, or bea≈øts, with wood and other things vnknowne to the ≈øimple men, v≈øing certain darke wordes and ≈øentences, which they them≈øelues do not vnder≈øtand. They ≈øucke and ≈øicke the place where the paine ‚Ä¢ s, therby to draw out the euil humours, and if the paine or feuer increa≈øeth, the prie≈øts ≈øay that their patients are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with euil ≈øpirits, wherewith they rubbe their bodyes all ouer with their handes, v≈øing certaine wordes of coniuracion and charmes, ≈øucking after that very hard, often making them beleeue that by that meanes they cal the ≈øpirit, which done, they take a certaine wood, wherof no man knoweth the vertue but onely them≈øelues, wherewith they rub their mouthes and throats, ≈øo long vntil they ca≈øt al what≈øo ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ r they haue within their ≈øtomackes, and with ≈øo great force, that ofteÃÑ times they ca≈øt forth bloud, mean time ≈øtamping, ≈øtammering, calling‚ñ™ and knocking with theyr feete again≈øt the earth, with a thou≈øande other toyes needle≈ø≈øe to rehear≈øe.

div.head: Cub ‚Ä¢ gua, or Margaritha.
div.p: CVbagua or Margaritha is the I≈øland of pearles, and is in compa≈ø≈øe three miles, lying vnder twelue degrees and a halfe, vpon the north ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line, foure miles from the point „Äà‚óä„Äâ , a count ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wherein there is much ≈øalt, & although the grounde is both flat and euen, yet it is vnfruitfull and drie, both without water and trees, and wherein there is little els found, then onely Comes, and ≈øome Sea foules. The inhabitants paint theyr bodies, they eate the oy≈øters wherein the Pearles are founde, and fetch all their fre≈øh water from the firme land, giuing pearles for it: there is not any I≈øland in the world ≈øo ≈ømal as it is, that hath rai≈øed ≈øo much profit, and made both the inhabitants and ≈øtrangers rich, as this hath doone, for that the pearles which in few yeares hath bin brought from thence, doe amount vnto aboue two millions of gold, although thereby many Spaniards and ≈ølaues haue lo≈øt their liues.

From the point ‚Ä¢
Arya to the Cape de Salines, that is, to the poynte of the Salt pans, are ≈øeuentie miles, & between them lyeth Ca ‚Ä¢ be, and the Cape de tres Puntas, which is the Cape of three poynts: from the Cape de Salines to Punto Auegado, that is, the drowned hauen, are more then ≈øeuentie miles, and the cea≈øt running along by the gulfe of Pa ‚Ä¢ a, the lande maketh with the I≈øland Trinidad.

div.head: Paria.
div.p:
IN the mouth of the gulfe of Paria, lyeth the I≈øland la Trinidad, taking the name from a certaine promi≈øe made by Columbus in his ≈øecond voyage, in An. 1497. being in danger, or becau≈øe he fir≈øt perceiued three hilles, ≈øeeking for fre≈øh water, his people in a maner dying with thir≈øt. The mouth of this gulf was called os Draconis, yt is, the Dragons mouth, becau≈øe of the great ≈øtreame that runneth therein. The whole countrey and ≈øhore of Paria ≈øtretching towardes the South, is the goodlie≈øt country in all India, and the fruitfulle≈øt, as Benzo and Columbus both doe witne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that by ≈øome it is called the earthly Paradice: it is a great, flatte, and euen land, ouerflowing and aboundant of all things, alwaies bring forth flowers of ≈øweete and vn≈øweete ≈øauour. The trees continually greene, as it were in May or lent, but not many fruitfull or whol≈øome trees, and in ≈øome places thereof is great aboundance of Ca≈øsia Fi≈øtula, the whole countrey is generally hot and moi≈øt, whereby there are diuers wormes, among the which are many Mytes, which by night fall verie heauily vpon the people, and many gra≈øhoppers, that doo much hurt, the inhabitants beare there members in a goord or reede, as it were in a ≈øheath, letting their ≈øtones hang out, before the Spaniards came into the countrey, they wore ≈øuch kind of codpeeces bordered with gold & pearles, and ≈øuch like things, which cu≈øtome the Spaniards made them to leaue: the marrted women couer their ≈øecret parts with an apron, by them called Pampanillas, and the maides tie a peece of cotten before their bellies, their kings haue as many wiues as they will‚ñ™ yet one of them is accounted for the right Queene, and hath commandement ouer all the re≈øt: the common people haue three or foure, as they think good, and when they are olde they put them away, and take yong for them. They likewi≈øe let theyr Piacchos or prie≈øts he with their gentlewomen and their maids the fir≈øt night of the marriage. This people, as al≈øo mo≈øt part of the Indians, maintaine them≈øelues with fi≈øh, and wine made of Ma ‚Ä¢ z which is with them in ‚Ä¢ eede of corne, and al≈øo with other fruits and rootes, as all the re≈øt of the Caribes do, and ≈øome eate Lice, Apes, Meerecats,
Frogs, Wormes, and ≈øuch vnprofitable things as tho≈øe of Cumana, they v≈øe a kinde of ≈øalue, to make their teeth black like tho≈øe of Cumana, which is made in this maner: they take ≈øhels wherein the pearles are ≈øound, with the leaues of the tr√©e called Axis, (the fruit of the which tree they eate continually al the yeare like ≈øauce or pepper) which they burne together, and beeing burnt, they put a little water vnto it, wherwith the white looketh like chalke, with the which ≈øalue they make their teeth as black as coles, and therewith pre≈øerue them from ach, their bodyes are painted red and blacke, with colours made of the iuice of Hearbes, and the filthier it ≈øheweth, the fairer they e≈øt√©eme it to bee. Their beddes are like nettes made of cotten, which they make fa≈øt to twoo bordes, and therein they ≈øleepe. Sleeping in the fields they haue on the one ≈øide of their beddes a fire, to warme them in the night: their weapons are arcowes, made either of reeds or palme wood, whereon they putte ≈øharpe ≈øtones or bones in place of iron, which they ≈ømeere with pitch, which is a mo≈øt cruel poy≈øon, made of rootes, hearbs, Antes, fruites, and certaine ≈øtinking iuice, which the olde women do verie diligently ≈øeethe with ≈ønakes bloud, with the venimous aire whereof many of them die while they ≈øeethe it, if any man be ≈øtrucken with an arrow that is new dipt therein, theyr bodye pre≈øently ≈øwelleth, and they die with al ≈øpeede, in a manner rauing, and when the poy≈øon is olde, it loo≈øeth the greate≈øt parte of the ≈øtrength: the remedie again≈øt ≈øuch poy≈øon, is to thru≈øt a hot burning iron into the wound: all the ≈ølaues that the Spaniards take out of this country, they carrie them into the countrey of Cubag ‚Ä¢ a, burning them in the foreheades with a letter C. whom they keepe for fi≈øhers or pearles, by which meanes many of them are carried out of the I≈øland, whereby at this pre≈øent it is almo≈øt de≈øolate, for that the fi≈øhing for pearle is there almo≈øt clean done, and the gold con≈øumed, which maketh the Spaniards not to e≈øteeme of that place.

div.head: Hereafter followeth the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt of Paria, to the ≈øtraights of Magellanes.
div.p:
FRom Punto Anegado which lyeth vnder eight degrees, are fiftie miles, to Rio Dulce, which lieth vnder ≈øixe degrees: from Rio Dulce, that is, the ≈øweet riuer, to R ‚Ä¢ ode O ‚Ä¢ ellana, which is called Rio de la Amazones is 110. miles, ≈øo that there is accounted eight hundred Spani≈øh miles, or 3200. Italian: from Nombre de Dios along to the coa≈øt of the Riuer Orellana, which cunneth into the ≈øea, (as it is ≈øaide) hauing fift√©ene miles in the breadth of the entrie, and mo≈øt vnder the Equinoctial line. From this Riuer I will ≈øhew the coa≈øt as it lieth, yet fir≈øt I mu≈øt tel you the riuers, & their names that lie betweene it and Pun ‚Ä¢ o Anegado, fir≈øt Rio Grando, the great Riuer, then Rio Dulce, the ≈øweete riuer, Rio de Canoas, the Riuer of Canos. Canoas are ≈øcutes, by the Indians made out of peeces of wood, which they make hollow, and therewith they fi≈øh in the riuers, Capo de Corrientes, the point of the ≈øtreame, Aldea the village, Capo de los Farillon ‚Ä¢ z, the point of the cliffes, Rio de Ancones, the riuer of the open hauens, Rio de Laga ‚Ä¢ tos, the riuer of ye Crocadiles, Rio de vincente P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ zon, Rio de Cacique, the K. riuer: for Cacici in Indian ≈øpeech is Kings. Co≈øta Braua the wild poynt, Capo de Corrientes, Rio de Caribes, the riuer of Caribes, or eaters of men. Rio de Canoas, Rio de Arboledas, the riuer of bowes, Rio de Montanna, the riuer of the hill, Rio Apercellado, the riuer of the Bankes, Bayha de Canoas, the bay of Canaos, or Scutes, Atalaya ≈øentinel or watch, Rio dos Fumos, ye riuer of Smoke, Rio de Pracellet, ye riuer of banks, Capo de North, the North point. And there being pa≈øt that point, the great riuer Oregliana (in Spani≈øh Orellana‚ñ™ ) runneth forth which „Äà‚óä„Äâ the greate≈øt riuer in India or in all the world, ≈øome called this riuer the ≈øweete ≈øea, it is at the mouth or entrie fifteene Spani≈øh miles broade, there are ≈øome that ≈øaid this riuer and the Riuer of Maragnon, which hereafter ≈øhall follow, haue all one head or ≈øpring from Quito by Mullubamba, & then this riuer runneth vnder the Equinoctial line at the lea≈øt 1500. ≈øpani≈øh miles, as Orellian & his companions recite, that came out of Peru from the ≈øouth ≈øea, cleane ouerwhart the countrey through this riuer, with great hunger & much trouble, and ≈øo entred into the north ≈øea, not that it runneth ≈øtraight outright, but crooking and compa≈ø≈øing in and out, which maketh it ≈øo long a iourney, for that from the head of this riuer to the ≈øea it is but ≈øeuen hundred Spani≈øh miles, to trauaile right forth ouer the country. This Riuer within the land is in ≈øome places foure and ≈øome fiue miles broade, making many I≈ølands. The common opinion is, that vpon this riuer there dwelleth women that burne off their right brea≈øts, that they be not hundred therby to ≈øhoote in bowes, which they v≈øe in the warres: by the ancient writers they were called Amazons, and had a great parte of A≈øia vnder theyr
≈øubiection: from the riuer Orellana, to the Riuer Marannon, or Maragnon, are 100. miles, which in the mouth or entry is 15. miles broad, & lyeth vnder 3, degrees, on the ≈øouth≈øide of the Equinoctial line, in it al≈øo are many I≈øland: thereabouts likewi≈øe there groweth good Franken≈øence, which is e≈øteemed better then that of Arabia, & there al≈øo were founde certain Emeralds, and tokens of gold, with other riches. They make wine of diuers kinds of fruit, ≈øpecially of great dates, in quantity as big as ≈øpani≈øh Quinces, which is verie good & may be kept, the men weare iewels at their eares, and thr√©e or foure rings through their lips, which they likewi≈øe ≈ø ‚Ä¢ t, as a beautifying vnto them, they ≈øleep in beds ≈øtretched abroad and made fa≈øt to trees, a good height from the ground, without any couerlets, as all the Indians from Nombre de Dios, & ≈øo to the ≈øtraights of Magellana v≈øe to do. There are in this riuer filthy flies which make men lame, being bitten or ≈øtinged by them, vnle≈ø≈øe they doo pre≈øently pul out the ≈øtings: there are many of opinion that this Riuer M ‚Ä¢ ragnon, and the afore≈øaide Riuer of Orellana, doo both ≈øpring out of the countrey of Peru, but no man knoweth the certaintie thereof. From Maranhon to tetra de Humos, or Fumous, that is, the country of Smoke, where the line parteth is 100. miles, & from thence to Angla di S. Lucar, are 100. miles, and from thence to Cabo de S. Augu≈øtin, lying vnder 8. degr√©es and a halfe, on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctial line are 70. miles, the length of the coa≈øt from the riuer of Maragnon to Cabo de S. Augu≈øtin, is as followeth, fir≈øt an I≈øland called I≈øla de S. Seba≈øtian. Acenc ‚Ä¢ o A≈øcen≈øion: P. de Pracell, the hauen of Bankes: P. de Corrientes, the hauen of the Streame, Rio de Il ‚Ä¢ ieo, the riuer of ye I≈ølands, Co≈øta Branca, the white coa≈øt, Rio de Coroa the riuer of the Crowne, Cabo del e≈øte, the Ea≈øter coa≈øt, Rio des Lixos, the riuer of filth, Rio dos Reciffes, the riuer of cliffes, Rio S. Miguel, the riuer of ≈øaint Michael, Bahya dos ‚Ä¢ ortugos, the Riuer of Torteeux, Grand Bahya, the great Bay, Cabo de S. Roque, the point of S. Roche, Cabo de S. Raphael, the poynt of S. Raphael, Baya de Traicam, the Bay of Trea≈øon, Paraiba os Petiguares, Pernambuco, the Cape of S. Augu≈øtin was di≈øcouered in An. 1500. 1500. by Vincentio, Ianes Pinzon, in the fir≈øt month of the yeare.

div.head: Bra≈øilia.
div.p: NOw followeth the Ea≈øt prouince of America, or of Peruana commonly called Bra≈øil the which was mo≈øt di≈øcouered by the Portingales, and by them ≈øubdued and brought vnder ≈øubiection, they had therein from North to ≈øouth, 40. miles, and from Ea≈øt to We≈øt 160. miles, which ≈øtretching along by the coa≈øt, is more then 700. miles. This country hath the name of Bra≈øilia, by rea≈øon of the great aboundance of red bra≈øil wood which from thence is brought into the≈øe countryes: in this countrey are manie prouinces and ≈øundrie people, ≈øome ≈øubiect to the Portingales, & ≈øome to the Frenchmen, as Marga ‚Ä¢ atan, Taba ‚Ä¢ arren, Oueta ‚Ä¢ aten, Tououpi ‚Ä¢ ambaultiem, and Morpions, all cruel Indians, and mo≈øt of them Canibals, whereof in the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt we make mention: not far from the Cape S. Augu≈øtin, lyeth Pernambuco, a place where the Portingales haue great traffike for ≈øugar and Bra≈øil wood. This cape lyeth vnder eight degrees and a halfe, on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line, and was di≈øcouered by Vincente Ianes Pinzon, in the yeare of our Lord, 1500. in the moneth of Ianuary, and is the neere≈øt place to Affrica or Spain, of al the country of America, for yt it is accounted but 500. miles from this pointe to Cabo Verde in Affrica, the common reckoning of the ≈øea Cards, yet ≈øome e≈øteeme it to be le≈ø≈øe. From this cape to Baia de todos Sanctos, lying vnder 13. degrees, are 100. miles: between the which two places, I let pa≈ø≈øe S. Alexio, S. Miguel, Rio de Aguada, that is, the riuer of watering, Rio di Franci≈øco, Rio de cana Fi≈øtola, becau≈øe in that place there groweth much Ca≈øsia, ≈øuch as is in Egypt, Rio Real the kings riuer, Rio de Tapuan A. Pouoacam, the village or commom a≈ø≈øemblie, &c. after the which followeth the Baya de todos Sanctos, From this bay to the Cape dos Abrollios, or dos Baixos, that is, the Cape of the droughts, which lieth vnder 18. degrees, are 100. miles, and between them lieth the≈øe places, Rio de S. Giano, that is the riuer of S. Iulian, os Ilhos, the I≈ølands, Rio de S. Antonio, Rio de S. Crus, P. Seguro, the ≈øure hauen, Rio de Bra≈øil, Rio de Caruelas, &c.

div.head: Margaiates.
div.p:
MArgaiates are certaine people mingled with the Portingales, & are Canibals, the country wherin they dwel is gran both in winter and ≈øummer, as it is with vs in May and Iune, both men and women go naked, as they come out of their mothers wombes, painting them≈øelues with blacke ≈øtrikes, like the Tartarians. The men ≈øhaue them≈øelues like Friers, they make
holes in their nether lippes, wherein they weare certaine greene poli≈øhed Ia≈øper ≈øtones, wherewith they ≈øhutte and open the holes: which ≈øtones they weare for a great ornament, which notwith≈øtanding being taken out of the holes, maketh them ≈øhew mo≈øt vgly, as it they had two mouthes one ouer the other: the women lette their haires grow long like our women, and bore not their lippes, but make holes in theyr eares, wherein they hang certaine white bones, which hang as low as their ≈øhoulders. This countrey yeeldeth much Bra≈øill wood, from the Cape dos Baixos, to Cape Frio, which lyeth like an I≈øland, are an hundred miles: betweene the≈øe two places lye many riuers and hauens, ≈øpecially the≈øe, P. del Agnado, Rio Dulce, Re ‚Ä¢ os Magos Spirito Sancto, where the Portingales haue a Ca≈øtle, which the Margarites or Barbarians call Moab: from Moab you come to Tapenury, where there lieth certaine I≈ølands friends vnto the Frenchmen, from thence you come to Paraiba people that dwell in cottages made like ouens. From thence pa≈ø≈øing along the coa≈øt, you come to certaine running ≈øandes, whereabouts al≈øo are certaine cliffes, that iutte into the ≈øea, whereunto the ≈øailors are to take great regard. Right again≈øt tho≈øe ≈øhalowes or flattes, there lyeth an euen or flat land, about twentie miles great, inhabited by the Ouetacaters mo≈øt cruel Barbarians.

div.head: Ouetacates.
div.p:
THis people make warres, not onely again≈øt their neighbours, but al≈øo one again≈øt the other, as likewi≈øe aga ‚Ä¢ n≈øt al ≈øtrangers. They ≈øuffer no man to deale or traffike with them, and being hardly be≈øette by the enemies (although neuer ouercome) they can runne ≈øo fa≈øt away, that they ≈øeeme in a manner to ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe the wild Hart, as it is ≈øeene by their hunting of wild bea≈øts. They go naked like other Bra≈øilians, and let their haire grow long, downe to the middle of their bodies, coÃÑtrary to al other Bra≈øilians: yet they cut it away on the fore part of their heades, and behinde in their neckes, as the re≈øt doo. The≈øe cruel Canibals dwel in a ≈ømal, but an inuincible countrey: they eate raw fle≈øh like dogs and wolues, they haue a ≈øeueral ≈øpeech different from their neighbours, and becau≈øe of their cruelty they haue but little of our wares brought vnto them, and that they haue, they get it in exchange, for certaine gr√©ene feathers. This exchange is done one ≈øtanding di≈øtant from the other at the lea≈øt an hundred paces, ≈øhewing each other their wares without ≈øpeaking one word, and each of them laying their wares in a certaine place appointed: they take it away, giuing no longer credite one to the other, then for the time that they haue exchanged their wares: after that beeing returned to their places, they to then be≈øt to rob each other of his marchandi≈øe, wherein the Ouetacaters, running fa≈øter then the other, and fa≈øter then hounds, do oftentimes win the pri≈øe. Being pa≈øt this countrey of the Ouetacaters, you come to another prouince called Maq-He, which is likewi≈øe inhabited by cruel Barbarians, which neuerthele≈ø≈øe cannot ≈øleepe nor re≈øt in peace, for their bad neighbours the Ouetacater ‚Ä¢ . Vpon this coa≈øt lyeth a great high ≈øienie rocke made like a tower, whereon when the ≈øun ≈øhineth, it gli≈øters like Sinarag ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢
whereby many haue thought it to be a recke of Sinaragdus ≈øtones, and therefore by the Frenchmen and Spaniards it is called M ‚Ä¢ n≈øis, that is, Sinaragdu ‚Ä¢ . It is not po≈ø≈øible neither by ≈øhip nor on foote, to get vnto that reck, becau≈øe of the cliffes wherewith it is compa≈ø≈øed, and being by it, there is no wayes or meanes to get vpon it. About this country lyeth three ≈ømall vnhabited I≈ølandes, called Maghen≈øis full of birdes, which are ≈øo tame, that meÃÑ take them with their hands, and kil them with ≈øtaues. From thence you go to Cape Frio, a verie good hauen, & well knowne by meanes of the French traffike, whereabouts the
‚Ä¢ ou ‚Ä¢ up ‚Ä¢ nambau ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , friendes to the Frenchmen doo inhabite: about this Cape are many great whales, in Latine called Pre≈øtis, and in Duch Swordfi≈øhes, yet they are no ≈øword fi≈øhes, for that their Iawes are full of teeth like Sawes. There are likewi≈øe on this Cape manie Parrats, in as great aboundance as crowes with vs: about this Cape lyeth the creeke by the Barbarians called Ganabara, and by the Portingales Rio de Gane ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢
becau≈øe it was di≈øcouered in the fir≈øt moneth of the yeare, and the Baya≈øe ‚Ä¢ moza: this creeke is wel knowne to the Frenchmen, becau≈øe they traffike thither, and therin had made a fort, it lyeth vnder three & twentie degrees, on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctial line. right vnder Tropicus Capricor ‚Ä¢
it is in the entrie ≈øixe Spani≈øh miles broad, and further in but three or foure miles broad, and there lyeth ≈ømaller hils then at the entrie. The mouth of this creeke is verie dangerous, for that if you leaue the ≈øea, you mu≈øt ≈øaile by three vnhabited I≈ølandes, where it is great fortune but the ≈øhips doo ≈øtrike in peeces vppon the rocks and cliffes: you mu≈øt likewi≈øe pa≈ø≈øe before a pointe, not
aboue three hundred paces broade, which hangeth from a high hil, hauing the form of a Piramides, which not onely ≈øeemeth verie great, but far off ≈øhewing as if it were made by mans art, which by rea≈øon of the roundne≈ø≈øe, as al≈øo becau≈øe it is like a tower, is by the Frenchmen called le pot de Buere, that is, the Butter potte: a little further in the creeke is an euen rock, about a hundred and twenty paces great, by the Frenchmen called R ‚Ä¢ tier or Mou≈øe fall, to which Villagagno at his fir≈øt arriuall brought all his nece≈ø≈øaries and proui≈øion, thinking thereon to build a fort, but the waues droue him backe againe: about halfe a mile further lieth the I≈ølande wherein the Frenchmen did dwell, which before their arriuall was not inhabited, and is in compa≈ø≈øe about a thou≈øand paces, yet the breadth is ≈øix times more then the length, all compa≈ø≈øed about with cliffes, as al≈øo with water, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that the ≈øhippes cannot come at it but with great danger, onely in one place, and that with ≈ømall boates, whereby it appeareth that this I≈øland by rea≈øon of the ≈øituation, is very ≈øtrong: on both ≈øides of this I≈øland there ≈øtandeth a little hill, whereupon the Gouernour had made his hou≈øe, and on a Rocke about fiftie or ≈øixtie foote high in the middle of the I≈ølande, hee had placed his Court or Ca≈øtle called Coligni, in honour of the Admirall of France, that had ≈øent him thither. In other plaine fieldes about the ≈øame, were the re≈øt of the Frenchmens hou≈øes made rounde, and couered with leaues or boughes, being in all about eighty men. 10000. paces, or two Spani≈øh miles and ¬Ω further from this I≈øland, lyeth another verie fruitfull I≈øland, in compa≈ø≈øe about thr√©e French miles, called the great I≈øland, inhabited by Tououpinamba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ s, great friends to the Frenchmen, to whome they oftentimes went to fetch meale and other nece≈ø≈øaries: there are likewi≈øe in this creeke many other ≈ømall and vnhabited I≈ølandes, where there are many good oy≈øters, the Barbarians diue vnder the water, & with theyr hands bring vp certaine great ≈øtones, whereat there hangeth great numbers of Oy≈øters, and ≈øo fa≈øt cleued to the ≈øtone, that they can hardly gette them off, verie good to eate, ≈øome of them hauing ≈ømall Pearles within them: they are by the Barbarians called Leripes. This water is ful of ≈øtrange fi≈øhes, ≈øpecially Barbels and Sea Swine: there are likewi≈øe whales with verie fatte and thicke ≈økinnes: there runneth likewi≈øe into this creeke out of the middle part of the land, two fre≈øh riuers, vppon both the ≈øides whereof lyeth many villages of the Barbarians: tenne or fift√©ene miles further along the coa≈øt, towards the riuer de Plata, or the ≈øtraights of Magellana, there is another great creeke, by the Frenchmen called Va≈øarum, whereunto they v≈øe to ≈øaile, as they do to the other which they fir≈øt took in.

div.head: Hereafter followeth the manner and cu≈øtomes of the people.
div.p:
THe Toupinambaultii are not much vnlike our people, well proportioned of bodie and limbe, but ≈øtronger and health≈øomer then wee, and le≈ø≈øe ≈øubiect vnto ≈øicknes: among them are found fewe lame cripples, blinde, or mi≈øhapen men, although there are of them that liue to the age of an hundred and twenty yeares, accounting their yeares by the Moones, fewe of them likewi≈øe hauing gray haires, which is a certaine ≈øigne of the temperatenes of that land, as hauing no extream cold, nor exce≈ø≈øiue heate, hauing greene tr√©es, hearbes, and fields al the yeare through, and becau≈øe they liue without care they ≈øhew alwaies of one age, for they haue no hurtful poy≈øon nor foule water to drink, whereby all di≈øea≈øes do grow: they haue likewi≈øe no pa≈ø≈øions or afflictions of minde in their countreyes, which mooue, vexe, and con≈øume both the ≈øpirits and bodyes, as not knowing of any fauours, couetous de≈øires, chidings, hate, or enuie, which (but to our ≈øhame) con≈øumeth the Chri≈øtians. As touching the colour of their bodyes, they are not altogether blacke, but browne like the Spaniards, becau≈øe of the heate of the ≈øim: they go al naked as they came out of theyr mothers wombes, not once ≈øhaming therat, vnle≈ø≈øe it be at bankets, or when they goe to warres: there are ≈øome of them that bind two great leaues together, therewith to couer theyr priuie members, not ≈øo much for their credite, but becau≈øe they haue either ≈øome deformity, or el≈øe di≈øea≈øe therin, which oftentimes happeneth among them, they are not rough nor hairie, as ≈øome men de≈øcribe them, for they ≈øuffer no haire to hang vpon theyr bodyes, for that as ≈øoone as they perceiue it, they plucke it foorth either with theyr nayles, or ≈øheeres, which they haue either of the Frenchmen, or the Portingales, which they pull not onely from their chins, but al≈øo from their eye browes, eye liddes, which maketh them for the mo≈øt part ≈øeeme feareful and vgly. The hinder part of theyr heades is couered with haire: the young boyes vntil they come to mans ≈øtate, we are theyr haire from the crowne of the head, downe to theyr neckes, but al theyr foreheades ≈øhauen, as if it were a Friers
crowne, on the hinder part of their heades they let the haire grow, after the manner of our aunce≈øtors, which were all ≈øhorne only in their necks, and that was rounded. They haue likewi≈øe for a cu≈øtome, that they bore holdes in their boyes vnderlippes, wherein they ≈øtick ≈øharp bones, as white as Iuorie, which they take out and put in as often as they wil, and being older, they take away the bones, and in ≈øteed thereof weare greene Ia≈øpis ≈øtones, being a kinde of ba≈øtard Emerauld, inwardly flat, with a thick ende, becau≈øe they ≈øhall not fall out: ≈øome weare ≈øuch ≈øtones that are ≈øharpe, and of a finger long, when they take out the ≈øtones, they play with their tongues in the hole, which is mo≈øt vgly to beholde, for that it ≈øeemeth they haue twoo mouthes: ≈øome of them weare not onely this ≈øtone through theyr lips, but al≈øo through both their cheekes: touching their no≈øes they are flat, which they cau≈øe to grow ≈øo by force when they are yong, coÃÑtrary to vs, which de≈øire ≈øtraite no≈øes, but they e≈øteeme their flat no≈øes for a beauty, they paint their bodies with manie colours, ≈øpecially aboue al others, their legs with a blacke colour, with the ≈øap of a certaine hearbe by them called Genipat, ≈øo that a farre off they ≈øeeme to haue blacke bootes, or ≈øtraight ho≈øe, like the prie≈øts in our countries, the blackne≈ø≈øe of this ≈øap cleaueth ≈øo fa≈øt on, that if they wa≈øh them≈øelues for the ≈øpace of ten or fifteene daies together, yet it will hardly come off. They haue likewi≈øe necklaces of eight fingers long, made of bones, as white as Alabla≈øter, which they call Iaci, according to theyr forme, which they putte vppon cotten ≈øtrings, and weare them about theyr armes, as al≈øo other flatte and rounde bones, like ≈øtiuers, certaine peeces of money in Holland, which beeing bored through the middle, and hanged one by one vpon ≈øtrings, they weare them in ≈øuch ≈øort as wee weare chaines of gold, which they call Bouze. Be≈øides this, they make certaine rounde beades of blacke ≈øhining wood, which they tie together vpon ≈øtrings, and weare them likewi≈øe about theyr neckes, which ≈øhine as blacke and gli≈øtering as if they were Iet. They haue likewi≈øe many Hennes of our countreyes, which the Portingales brought thither, from the which they pull the ≈ømall white fethers, which with irons they hacke and make ≈øoft, and then colour them redde: which done, they annoint their bodies with gum, and ≈øtrow the feathers therein, wherby they looke like new hatched birds, wherof this opinion hath ri≈øen by ≈øome men that haue fir≈øt gone into tho≈øe Countries, and ≈ø√©eing them dre≈øt in that manner) that they were≈øo by nature. They dre≈ø≈øe theyr foreheades with feathers of diuers colours, verie cunningly placed together, like the French gentlewomen, that ware periwigs of ≈øtrange haire: the≈øe apparrels and ornaments of feathers and ≈øtones, as al≈øo the rattles wherewith they make a noy≈øe, with their woodden halberdes, and many other things to them belonging, you may ≈øee at Doctor Paludanus hou≈øe: tho≈øe crownes on theyr heades they call Iempenambi, in theyr eares likewi≈øe they weare certaine white bones, not much vnlike tho≈øe which the children weare in theyr lips.

In Bra≈øilia there are certaine blacke Birdes like Crowes, by them called Toucan, which haue certaine rings about theyr neckes, of yellow and red feathers, which they flea, and drie the ≈økinnes, and beeing drie, are likewi≈øe called Toucan, which they weare vppon each Cheeke, ≈øticking them on with ware, and when they goe to warres, or to a banket, when they meane to kill a man and to eate him, according to their manner, becau≈øe they will bee after the fine≈øt ≈øort, they putte on that kinde of apparrell made of feathers, with hoodes vppon their heades, and thinges made of greene, redde, blewe, and other colours of feathers, about their armes verie cunningly ≈øette together, which by vs coulde not bee mended, ≈øhewing as if they were of wrought Veluet, as Paludanus can ≈øhewe you. Such feathers likewi≈øe they binde vppon theyr Halberdes, which are likewi≈øe almo≈øt like a blacke Spitte, Lappe of harde woodde, made redde or blacke.

They wearelikewi≈øe on their ≈øhoulders certain mantles of Ea≈øtrige feathers (which is a ≈øigne that they haue Ea≈øtriges) that are verie cunningly ≈øet together, and hang long about them, by them called A ‚Ä¢ aroy: ≈øuch as wil among them be accounted manly and ≈øtout, & haue the report to haue killed & eaten many men, they cut great ≈øla≈øhes in their brea≈øts, hips, and thighs, wherby they make the fle≈øh to ri≈øe, which they couer with a certain pouder, and make them looke blacke, which colour neuer goeth off during theyr liues, wherby a farre off they ≈øeeme to haue cutte leather Ierkins on their bodies, ≈øuch as the Swit≈øers v≈øe to weare. When they will holde any drunken fea≈øt, or dauncing, wherunto they are much giuen, to increa≈øe their mirth, be≈øides the great noy≈øe and crie which they ordinarily make, they haue a certaine kind of hollow fruit, which Theretus calleth Ahonay, the pith whereof
being taken out, ≈øome of them are filled with ≈øtones, and ≈øome without, and ≈øo are put vpon ≈øtrings of cotten wooll, which they tie about their legs, dauncing therewith, as our iuglers and morice dauncers in the≈øe countreyes dance with belles: likewi≈øe they carrie in their hands certaine dryed goords, which they fil with ≈øtones, & hauing a ≈øticke in the ende, make a noy≈øe therewith, as our children doo with a blather full of ≈øtones: which in≈øtrument with them is called Maraca: the women go naked like the men, and pul away their haire from the eyebrowes, and eyelids, but weare it on theyr heades like our women, which they wa≈øh and comb derie often, and tie it vp with redde cotten hairelaces, as our country women v≈øe to do, but mo≈øt parte of them v≈øe to lette it hang downe about theyr ≈øhoulders, wherin they take great plea≈øure: the women neyther bore lips nor cheekes, but onely their eares, with ≈øo wide holes, that a man may thru≈øt his finger through, in theÃÑ they hang certain long things, which reach vnto their brea≈øts or ≈øhoulders, like bloudhoundes or water ≈øpanels eares. They paint their faces with all kinds of colours, which their neighbors and other women do for them: in the middle of the cheeke they make a rounde circle, drawing lines from it of diuers colours, vntill theyr face is ful, not leauing ≈øo much vndone as the eye liddes: they weare bracelets of white bones, cut thin like plates, very cunningly ioyned together with wax and gum, & al≈øo white necklaces, which they cal Bonze, & weare them not about their necks like the men, but onely their armes, for the which cau≈øe they are verie de≈øirous of the gla≈ø≈øe beades of all colours ≈øuch as we haue here in the≈øe countries, by them caled Maurobi, it is to be wondered at, that if any apparrel be giuen vnto theÃÑ, they wil not weare it, excu≈øing them≈øelues & ≈øaying that it is not their cu≈øtome, but had rather weare ≈øtones & other things vppon their bodies, then ≈øuch cloathes: they haue a cu≈øtome that in euery riuer where they come, they ≈øteepe vnto the water and wa≈øh their hands, & many times they duck into the water at yt lea≈øt ten times a day, to wa≈øh them≈øelues like birds, and if they were apparrelled & ≈øhould put it off as often as they do ≈øo, it would be ouer trouble≈øome vnto them: likewi≈øe the women ≈ølaues being compelled to weare cloathes, many euenings to plea≈øure them≈øelues, doo put off theyr cloathes, ≈ømock, and all, and ≈øo runne naked about the countrey: I mu≈øt ≈øpeake ≈øomewhat of their little children, of the age of foure or fiue yeares old, which being fat of body, with white bones in theyr lips, their haire ≈øhorne, and their bodyes painted, runne playing in great numbers about the countrey leaping and dauncing, mo≈øt wonderfull and verie plea≈øant to behold: & la≈øtly it is to be noted, that many are of opinion, that the nakedne≈ø≈øe of their women ≈øhould be an occa≈øion to prouoke them vnto lu≈øt, which notwith≈øtanding is found contrary, for that by rea≈øon of their vn≈øeemly nakedne≈ø≈øe, the men rather haue a loathing then a lu≈øt, and to the contrarie, the great and co≈øtly apparrell, as gownes and peticoates, counterfeit haire, the ≈øumptuous dre≈ø≈øing of the head, the chaines and bracelets of gold, which our women v≈øe, do more prouoke and intice men vnto lu≈øt, then ≈øimple nakednes, although it is again≈øt the ordinance of God, and therfore not to be commended, as not beeing conuenient, but as therein they goe beyonde the limits of Gods worde, our women al≈øo doo pa≈ø≈øe the boundes of godly matrones, and ≈øinne no le≈ø≈øe then they in ≈øuch he atheni≈øh cu≈øtomes.

div.head: Of the meate and drinke of the Bra≈øilians.
div.p:
THe Bra≈øilians haue twoo ≈øorts of rootes, called Aypi and Maniot, which b√©eing planted, in three or foure Moneths become a foote and a halfe long, and as bigge as a mans thigh, which beeing taken out of the earth, are by the women dryed by the fire vppon a Boucano, and then grated vppon ≈øharpe ≈øtones, as wee doo Nutmegs, whereof proceedeth a certaine white meale, and being moy≈øt, is of ta≈øte like our newe ≈øtarch, which to prepare, they haue great earthen Pots, wherein they ≈øeethe it, ≈øtirring it continually, vntill it bee as thicke as pappe, yet they make twoo kindes of meale, one ≈øodden till it bee harde, which they call Ouyentan, that is, hard meale, which becau≈øe it will continue long, is carried with them into the warres, the other is le≈ø≈øe ≈øodden, and ≈øomewhat ≈øofter, called Ouypou, that is, ≈øoft meale, which ta≈øteth like white bread bran, ≈øpecially when it is eaten fre≈øh, and although both the≈øe kindes of meale beeing fre≈øh, are of a verie good ta≈øte, and ≈øtrong meate, yet are they not fit to make bread, they may well knead it as w√©e doo wheats or rie, and it will bee verie white, but being baked, it wil on the out ≈øide burne and become drie, and inwardly continue meals as it was at the fir≈øt: with the broth of fat
fle≈øh. They make good pappe thereof, verie plea≈øant of ta≈øte, ≈øeeming like ≈øodden ryce, by them called Mingant, with their hands they pre≈ø≈øe certaine iuice out of this roote, which is as white as milke, which being putte in earthen pots and ≈øet in the ≈øunne, it runneth together like curds, which they put into earthen di≈øhes, & frie them as we do egs. The roote Aypi is much v≈øed to be ro≈øted and eaten, as being ≈øoft, and ta≈øteth like che≈ønuts, the other mu≈øt be made into meale and ≈øodden, otherwi≈øe it is dangerous to be eaten: both the ≈øteeles of the rootes are not much vnlike each other, being as great as a ≈ømall iuniper tree, and leaues like Poenie, the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe of the≈øe rootes con≈øi≈øteth in the great numbers, for that the branches (that are as brickle as the ≈øtalkes of hemp) beeing broke into diuers peeces, and ≈øo thru≈øt d√©epe into the earth, without any other v≈øage, within three or foure months after do bring forth great quantities of tho≈øe rootes: they haue likewi≈øe much Indian wheate, by theÃÑ called Anati, and by others Maiz, whereof they make meale, which they bake and eat. Touching their drinke, which they make of tho≈øe two rootes, and al≈øo of Maiz, it is made in this ≈øort by their women, being of opinion, that if it ≈øhould wee done by men, that it would haue no ta≈øte. They cut the rootes in ≈ømal peeces, as we do turnops, which they ≈øeeth in yellow pots vntil they be ≈øoft, which done they ≈øet them from the fire, and then ≈øet them≈øelues round about the pots, chawing the ≈øodden rootes, which they throw into another pot made ready for the purpo≈øe, and ≈øet vpon the fire, wherein they are ≈øodden once againe, and continually ≈øtirred, vntil they thinke them to be inough, which done, they are poured into other fattes made of reedes, not being clarifyed, and a third time ≈øodden and ≈økimmed, they couer the reedes, and keepe it to drinke, as their maner is, and as hereafter I will ≈øhew you: in the ≈øame manner the women make a drinke of Maiz or Indian wheate, which they call C ‚Ä¢ ou-in thicke and troubled, in a manner ta≈øteth like milke, and becau≈øe this Maiz and rootes are there in great aboundance they make as much drinke as they wil, which is by them likewi≈øe done, k√©eping it til they come altogether to drink, and wheÃÑ they come to the drunken fea≈øts, and that they meane to kil a man and eate him, theÃÑ the women make fiers about the ve≈ø≈øeles, wherby the drink becommeth warme, and then it is fir≈øt drawne, and the women filling a goord halfe ful, giue it to the men as they are dauncing, which they drink at one draught, and that ≈øo often and ≈øo long, that they emptie al theyr ve≈ø≈øels, as Letio him≈øelfe hath ≈øeene (from whom I gathered this di≈øcour≈øe) that for the ≈øpace of three dayes they haue done nothing but drinke, and neuer cea≈øed, and being ≈øo ful that they coulde beare no more, yet would they not leaue off, but ≈øtill k√©epe companie: at tho≈øe drinkings they are merrie, ≈øinging, leaping, dancing, and exhorting each other to be valiant in armes, and to kill many of their enemies.
