That done, they runne one after the other like cranes in their flight, leaping vntill al theyr ve≈ø≈øelles are emptie, at the which fea≈øts, e≈øpecially when they meane to kill and eate a man, they are dre≈ø≈øed in fine feathers and wt necklaces, and bracelets: in theyr daunces there are no women coupled with them, but euery one daunceth by him≈øelfe, and the≈øe drinkings are ob≈øerued wheÃÑ tho≈øe of one village meete together, and neighbours drinke one with the other, ≈øitting in theyr hanging beds, but with more good fellow≈øhip, wherewith there are twoo things to be con≈øidered, fir≈øt, that the Bra≈øilians do neuer drinke when they eate, as we do, nor when they drinke, they neuer eate: ≈øecondly, that they eat without word ≈øpeaking, and if they haue any thing to ≈øay each vnto other, they do it after their meat, they v≈øe likewi≈øe no certaine houre to eate in, but when they are hungrie they fall to their meate, as well by night as by day, yet they are verie ≈øober in eating, wa≈øhing hands and mouthes both before and after meate, which I thinke they doo to take the clamines of the meat off from their fingers.

div.head: Of certain great bea≈øts and Crocadiles in Bra≈øilia.
div.p:
FIr≈øt you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that in al Bra≈øilia there is not any foure footed bea≈øts like the≈øe in our countries, they haue great numbers of one kind which they cal Tapirou≈ølou, of a midle ≈øtature, between a cow & an a≈ø≈øe, this bea≈øt hath reddi≈øh & long haire, like a cow, but hath no hornes, and a ≈øhorter neck, long & hanging eares, ≈ømaller and longer legs, a whole foot like an a≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that it is not wrong named to be called a cow a≈ø≈øe, yet different from both, fir≈øt becau≈øe it hath a ≈øhort taile (as many bea≈øts in America haue no tailes at al) & ≈øharpe t√©eth; yet without any corage, for it runs from a man: the Bra≈øilians ≈øhoot at this bea≈øt with their arrowes, or el≈øe take them in pits, which they dig for the purpo≈øe, & e≈øteeme much of it, becau≈øe of the ≈økin: they hauing fleyed it off, they cutte the hide in rounde p√©eces, which they drie in the Sunne, whereof they make buklers, wherwith they defend them
≈øelues from the enemies arrowes, for that by rea≈øon of the heate of the ≈øunne they become ≈øo harde, that no arrow will pierce them, be they neuer ≈øo fiercely drawne. The fle≈øh of the bea≈øt ta≈øteth much like our bores fle≈øh, and by the Bra≈øilians it is ro≈øted vpon the coales, and ≈øo kept, for that becau≈øe they haue no ≈øalt, they al broyle theyr meat vpon woodden gardirons, and ≈øo k√©epe it: in euery village you finde ≈øuch girdirons, which oftentimes he ful of mens fle≈øh. Secondly, they haue a certaine kinde of Hart, by them called Seoua≈ølous, yet le≈ø≈øe then ours, and with ≈øhorter hornes, with long haire like goates: and wilde American Swine, by them called
‚Ä¢ aro≈ølou, which is as bigge of bodye, eares, head, and feete, as ours are, as al≈øo the like teeth, which are verie dangerous, but becau≈øe it is leaner and ranker, and grinneth fearefully, therefore it is mi≈ø≈øhapen. This bea≈øt by nature hath a hole in the backe, as the ≈øea Swine haue in theyr heades, whereat they receiue and ca≈øt foorth theyr breath. There is likewi≈øe a fine coloured bea≈øt, called Agouti, which is a kind of hart, with clouen feete, a ≈øhorte taile, with a no≈øe and cares much like a hare, very plea≈øant and ≈øauorie of ta≈øte: there are al≈øo two or thr√©e kindes of bea≈øts called Tapitis, not much vnlike our hares, red of haire: in the woods are great rats, of body and haire like Ekehornes, in ta≈øt not much vnlike our conies, Pag. or Pague, a bea≈øt of the height and greater theÃÑ an indifferent Grayhound, with an euil fauored head, a faire ≈økin, ≈øpeckled white and blacke, of ta≈øte much like veale. There is likewi≈øe another bea≈øt called Sarigoy, which becau≈øe it ≈øtinketh, ye Barbarians wil not eate, yet it is good & ≈øauory fle≈øh, ≈øpecially when the fat of the kidnies (wherin the ≈øtinke lieth) is taken away. There are al≈øo Tatous or Armadillen, wherof in other places I haue ≈øpoken, which are of very white, good, and ≈øauorie fle≈øh: al≈øo there are certaine Crocadiles, which they cal Iacare, as big as a mans leg, and indifferent long, not hurtfull, they come into their hou≈øes, where the children play with them without any danger. The Crocadiles in tho≈øe countries haue a wider mouth, high feet, ye taile neither round nor ≈øharp, but very thin at the end: ther are likewi≈øe diuers kinds of Ea≈øts ≈øpeckled like our little ones, & of foure or fiue foot long, in thicknes corre≈øpondent, feareful to behold, but keepe in riuers & moores like frogs, doing no hurt, they cal them Touous: being ≈øleyed & ≈øoddeÃÑ, they ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe al meates for ta≈øte & goodnes, their fle≈øh being as white as a capons fle≈øh, ≈øweet, ≈øhort, & excelleÃÑt good. They haue great toades, which the Toupinambauiltu eate whole being ro≈øted, ≈øo that they are not poy≈øon like our toades, they eat likewi≈øe ≈ønakes of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans arme, & fiue foote long, but of no great ta≈øte, ther are al≈øo many other ≈ønakes, ≈øpecially in the riuers, that are as gr√©en as gra≈ø≈øe, long & thin, who≈øe ≈øting is very dangerous: there are al≈øo in ≈øome meeres of woods, diuers great and dangerous Ea≈øts. Iohanes Lerus writeth, that pa≈ø≈øing through a wood, he met an Ea≈øt, as bigge as a mans bodye, & of fiue or ≈øix foot long, al couered with white ≈øcales like oy≈øter ≈øhels, which lifted vp one of her forefeete, and ca≈øting vp her head, looked vpon him with ≈øtaring eyes, breathing at the mouth mo≈øt feareful to beholde, and after he and his companie had ≈øtayed a quarter of an houre to behold it, it clome vp ye hil with ≈øuch a noi≈øe ouer and through the tr√©es, that not any Hart running through the wood, could make a greater noy≈øe. There is yet in this countrey another kind of ≈øtrange bea≈øt caled Ian-ouare, feeding only vpon the pray: this bea≈øt for length of legs and ≈øwiftnes, is like the Grayhound, but vnder the chinne it hath a beard or certain long haire, & a ≈øpeckled ≈økin, like a Linx, and in other parts not vnlike the Linx: this bea≈øt is much feared by the Bra≈øilians, for that what≈øoeuer it taketh, it teareth it in peeces, and ≈øpoyleth it like a Lion, feeding therof: the Indians take this bea≈øt in pits, & to reuenge them≈øelues, they cau≈øe her therin to pine to death, wherby they double her paine. M√©erecats are there in great aboundance, that are ≈ømall & blacke, by them called Cay, and among the re≈øt, one kind of M√©erecat called Sagouin. of a verie fayre coloured haire, as big, and of haire as an Ekehorne, but as touching the forme of the chaps, brea≈øt, and necke & other parts, altogither like a lion, being one of the aire≈øt little bea≈øtes in al that country, but for the tendernes therof it cannot be brought ouer ≈øea. There is yet another very ≈øtrange bea≈øt, by the Indians caled Hay. as big as a dog, with a face like a M√©erecat, & a hanging belly like a ≈øow that hath new farrowed‚ñ™ of haire dark white, al black, with a long taile, with rough feet like a beare, long clawes, when it lieth in ye woods, it is very wild, but if they take it, it will be tamed, the naked Tououpinambaultiers play not willingly with it, becau≈øe it hath verie ≈øharpe clawes: no man (as the Indians ≈øay) did euer ≈ø√©e this bea≈øt wild or tame, to eate any thing, but as they think, it liueth by ye aire, wherof I haue ≈øpokeÃÑ in other places. La≈øtly there is yet another ≈øtrange bea≈øt called Coaty, as high as a Hare, with ≈øhort & ≈øpeckled haire, ≈ømal ≈øharpe eies, a head very ≈ømal, & downe
from the eies a ≈ønout that ri≈øeth vp, of a foote long & more, round like a ≈øtick, & ≈øomewhat ≈ømal at the end, in ≈øuch maner, that it is al of one bigne≈ø≈øe, with ≈øo narrow a mouth, that a man can hardly thru≈øt his little finger therein, very ≈øtrange to behold: and being taken, it pulleth all his foure feete together and falleth either vppon the one ≈øide or the other, and wil not ri≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe they giue it mice, whereof it liueth in the wood: this countrey aboundeth with al kinde of foule, whereof ≈øome are to be eaten, and ≈øome not, as Indian Hens, by them called Arignow Ou≈ø≈øou, and common hennes of the≈øe countryes, fir≈øt brought thither by the Portingales, and among them the white hens are much e≈øteemed, to pull out their feathers, and to die them red, therwith to dre≈ø≈øe them≈øelues, yet they eat them not, thinking likewi≈øe that their egs are poy≈øon, which they feare, becau≈øe they ≈øee the Frenchmen eate them: whereby it commeth that in the villages where no ≈øtrangers traffike, there are ≈øo great numbers of hens, that you may buy one for a penie: be≈øides the hens, they bring vp many duckes, which they cal Vpec but becau≈øe they are of this minde, that if they ≈øhould eate ≈øuch ≈ølow birdes, they ≈øhuld likewi≈øe become ≈ølow, and ≈øo might be taken by theyr enemies, therefore they eate none of them, nor any other bea≈øt that goeth ≈øoftly, nor fi≈øhes that ≈øwim ≈ølowly. There are likewi≈øe many ≈øpeckled hens, of three ≈øorts, all blacke, with white ≈øpots, verie plea≈øant of ta≈øt, like phea≈øants: there are al≈øo two kinds of faire cocks called Moutor, as great as pecockes, ≈øpeckled with white ≈øpots, and black feathers. Macocaua & Yamboun-Oua≈ølou. are two kindes of partriges, as big as ducks, and of ta≈øte like phea≈øants, wood Doues, Turtledoues, and yet another kind of partriges, al of one ta≈øt: of foules that are not eaten, there are many, as diuers kindes of parrats, wherof ≈øome are ≈øo faire, that fairer cannot be found, ≈øpecially 2. ≈øorts, called Aras & Canide, the feathers wherof they v≈øe for their apparell, hats, & arme bands. They haue verie faire redde, blewe, and gold yellow ≈øhining feathers, whereof diuers of them ≈øing. Be≈øides tho≈øe, they haue foure other kindes of Parrots, whereof one kinde is very little brought hither, by them called Aa ‚Ä¢ ourous, which haue theyr heades parted in thr√©e colours, as redde, yellow, and violet, the wings all redde, the taile long and yellow, and the body greene, which learne ≈øo perfectly to ≈øpeake, as if it were men: wee reade of one that when it was bidden, would daunce, ≈økippe, ≈øing, and play all the parts of the wilde Barbarians: being carried with them into the wars & commanded to be ≈øtil, it would be as quiet as if it had beene dumbe, neither ≈øtirring ≈øoot nor tongue: ≈øuch Parrats as are brought hither, they call Marganas, and e≈øt√©eme them not, for they are as common there, as pigeons with vs, which although they haue a certaine harde fle≈øh like heathcocks, yet there are many of them eaten in tho≈øe countryes: there are likewi≈øe little Parrots, which are brought hither, but among the cheefe foules of that countrey, there is a very ≈ømal bird called Toucan, as big as a pigeon, blacke like a Rauen, onely the brea≈øt, which is yellow, with a round red ring about her necke, as I ≈øaide in another place, which they weare vppon theyr cheekes, ≈øpecially when they go to any fea≈øtes or dauncings, whereupon it hath the name of Toucan-Tabourace, that is, the feathers to daunce with: the bil of this bird is greater then all the body, and is one of the ≈øtrange≈øt things that euer was ≈øeene: there is another of the greatne≈ø≈øe and colour like a Merlin, onelie vpon the brea≈øt, which is as redde as an ore bloud, it is al≈øo by the Indians fleyed, and the ≈økinne dried like the Toucan. which bird they call Panon: there is another like a Li≈øter, as red as ≈øcarlet, which they cal Quempian.

I mu≈øt not forget a wonderfull ≈øtrange little bird, no bigger then a Scalebiter, or a hor≈øe flie, with white ≈øhining feathers, which hath ≈øo great and plea≈øant a voyce in ≈øinging, yt it re≈øembleth our nightingale, in ≈øuch ≈øort, ye it may be ≈øaid it wer impo≈ø≈øible that out of ≈øo ≈ømal a body, there could i≈ø≈øue ≈øo great a voyce, which bird by the Indians is called Gonambuch. There are yet many other kinds of birds, of colour red, white, violet, & purple, &c. al much differing from ours, & needle≈ø≈øe to rehear≈øe. There is one among the re≈øt which the Indians do much regard, not ≈øuffering it to be hurt, or to be taken, as thinking it a bird of ≈øome ≈øecret diuination, it is as great as a pigeon, of a gray colour, crying verie heauily, which is heard more by night theÃÑ by day: the Touepinambaultii are of opinion, that tho≈øe birdes are ≈øent vnto them by theyr friendes that are dead, to bring them good newes, and prouoke and ≈øtirre them to bee of good courage again≈øt theyr enemies in the fielde, they thinke al≈øo, ≈øo they take good regard vnto this Birds ≈øong, and fortune to bee ≈ølaine in the warres, that after they are dead, they ≈øhal goe vnto theyr forefathers, beyond the hilles there for euer to be merry, and continually to dance: They certainely per≈øwade them≈øelues that tho≈øe birdes bring newes
from their friendes, and that thereby they ≈øhould be merrie, and of better courage, ≈øo that they take great regard vnto their cries. There are likewi≈øe in this countrey many battes as big as crowes, which by night enter into the hou≈øes, and finding any man lying naked, they ≈øucke the bloud out of their toes in great aboundance, whereof in another place I wil ≈øay more. Their Bees are le≈ø≈øe then ours, like blacke flies, and make theyr honey in hollow Tr√©es: the Indians haue good knowledge howe to gette theyr ware and theyr honey: they v≈øe not the wax to burne, but onely to ≈øtoppe their reedes, wherein they keepe their feathers from the wormes. Touching ≈ømal wormes like flies or Mytes, as al≈øo ≈øcorpions and earth creui≈øhes, which are hurtful vnto men, it is needele≈ø≈øe to write: they haue diuers fi≈øhes, wherof many are common here with vs, as twoo ≈øorts of Barbels, the one called Rurema. the other Parati, both beeing ≈øodden or ro≈øted, are of a verie good ta≈øte, which becau≈øe they ≈øwimme in companicars, e by them killed with dartes, ≈øometimes two or thr√©e together. The meate or ≈øub≈øtance of tho≈øe fi≈øhes is verie tender and ≈øhort, wherefore the Indians drie them, and make flower & meale thereof. There are three other kinds of verie great fi≈øhes, wherof one is called Camoroupouy Oua≈ø≈øou, the other Ouara, the third Acara Oua≈ø≈øou, al veeie good of ta≈øte, & good to be eaten: there is a certaine kinde of flat fi≈øh, called Acarapep, which being ≈øodden yeeldeth a certaine yellow fatte, which they keepe for ≈øauce. This fi≈øh likewi≈øe is verie good meat, Acarabouten is a ≈ølymie fi≈øh of a redde colour, it is better then the other, but not ≈øo ≈øauorie in the mouth, Pira-Ipochi is a long fi≈øh like an eele, but not to be eaten: the Rochets which are taken in the Cr√©eke of Ganabara, and thereabouts in the ≈øea, are much greater then ours, with twoo long hornes ≈øticking out before, and fiue or ≈øixe clawes in the belly, which men would think not to be natural, but rather artificiall, with a long thinne venomous taile. In their Riuers are many ≈øtrangs fi≈øhes, ≈øpecially one called Tamouata, which is a handfull long, with a mo≈øt great and mon≈øtrous head, others called Pana, Pana, which likewi≈øe hath a great and mon≈øtrous head, yet both good to eate and verie ≈øauorie.

div.head: A de≈øcription of certain trees and fruits in tho≈øe countries.
div.p: FIr≈øt there are many Bra≈øil tr√©es, wherby the country hath taken the name, this tree by them is called Araboutan, becau≈øe of tha great and thick branches, not much vnlike our oakes, ≈øome of them are at the lea≈øt three fadomes thicke, their leaues are like boxe or palmetr√©es, but yeelde no fruite, the wood would with great labour and paine be conuayed aboord the ≈øhippes, if the wild people did not helpe them, for the marchants ≈øhuld hardly lade a ≈øhip in a whole yeare, becau≈øe of the hardne≈ø≈øe and trouble≈øomene≈ø≈øe in the cleauing, as al≈øo that there are no bea≈øts to draw or carrie it to the ≈øhippes, but mu≈øt be brought downe by men, which for cloathes, ≈øhirts, hattes, kniues, and ≈øuch like things, are hired to cleaue and rounde it, and to bring it out of the woods farre within the lande, vpon their ≈øhoulders, to the ≈øhippes: it is much burnt in that countrie, and is of nature dry, whereby when it it is burnt, it maketh little ≈ømoke, the a≈øhes wherof yeeld a certaine red color: the Tououpinambaultii wondered much what our men doe with all that wood, a≈øking if there were no wood in our countreies for to burne, and an≈øwere was made vnto them, that we v≈øed it to die withall, as they died their ropes or ≈øtrings: this is ≈øhewed in another place.

Be≈øide this Bra≈øill tree, there are fiue kindes of Palme trees, whereof the principall is called Gerau, the other Iri, of the≈øe tr√©es I haue ≈øufficiently declared in the Hi≈øtories of the Ea≈øt Indies, as al≈øo in the de≈øcription of the Affrican coa≈øt: there is a tree called Ayri, a kinde of Eban wood, with leaues, not much vnlike the palme tr√©es, the body couered with thicke thornes, the fruite thereof indiffeeent great, wherein there is a pith as white as ≈ønow, but not good to eate: the wood is blacke and verie hard, whereof the Barbarians make theyr halbeards, coluen & arrowes, it is likewi≈øe ≈øo heauy, that it ≈øinketh vnder the water: there is al≈øo much wood in this countrey, whereof ≈øome is yellow like Box, ≈øome violet, ≈øome white like paper, ≈øome pale red, ≈øome varni≈øh red, and ≈øome darke red, whereof likewi≈øe they make Halberds: another wood is founde therein called Copau, whereof the trees are like our wallnut tr√©es, but beare no nuttes, the wood being plained, hath graines like Walnut tree: there are many other kindes of trees, whereof ≈øome haue leaues rounde like pence, others great, of a foote and a halfe long, as al≈øo a tree which is very plea≈øant to beholde, and ≈øo ≈øweete of ≈ømell, that it excelleth the ro≈øe, ≈øpecially when it is cut: to the contrarie there groweth another tree called Aou-at, which wood beeing cutte or burnt, ≈øtinketh ≈øo vnrea≈øonably, that no man can abide it: it hath leaues like our apple
tr√©e leaues, and a fruit not vnlike the Egiel, the nut whereof is ≈øo venemous, that being eaten, it worketh pre≈øently, but becau≈øe the Indians make their rattles of this fruit, they e≈øteeme it much: Be≈øides this, there groweth in Bra≈øilia many kindes of fruits, and apples, plea≈øant to looke on, ≈øpecially on the ≈øea ≈øide, but not to be eaten, and very daungerous, ≈øome are like mi≈øpelles, whereof the Indians warned our men, that they ≈øhould not eate them.

Hiuourae is a barley about halfe a finger thicke, good of ta≈øte, ≈øpecially being fre≈øh, it is a kinde of pox wood, and by the Indians v≈øed for a certaine di≈øea≈øe called Pians, which is as daungerous with them, as the pox with vs, there is likewi≈øe a tr√©e by them called Choyne, of a rea≈øonable height, for leaues, forme, and greenene≈ø≈øe like the Bay trees, the fruit as great as a childes head, as bigge as an E≈øtridge egge, but not to be eaten: the Tonoupinambaultians thereof make certaine rattles, by them caled Muaracas, & of it al≈øo they make ve≈ø≈øels to drinke, with ≈øuch like things, cleaueing them in the middle. The tree by them called Sabaneay, beareth fruit bigger than a mans two fi≈øts, whereof they make drinking cuppes, and is much like a cup: in this nut there are certaine piths, not vnlike for forme and ta≈øte to the almon. There is an other tree in bigne≈ø≈øe like a Sorben, the fruit wherof is by them called Aca iou, of forme and greatne≈ø≈øe like a hennes egge, which being ripe, is of a golde yellow colour like a quince, very good and ≈øauory to eate, hauing a certayne ≈øharpe ta≈øte, and in it a iuice that cooleth heate, but becau≈øe this fruit is not ea≈øie to be gathered, as being high trees, the meere-cattes eate them, and ≈øuch as fall to the ground, are the Indians parte. Pacoaire is a ≈øprig about tenne or twelue foote high: the body as thicke as a mans thigh, but yet ≈øo ≈øoft that it may be cutte in twoo with one blow: the fruit thereof is by them called Paco, which are of a handfull long, in forme like cucumbers, and being ripe, are of the ≈øame colour: this fruit groweth 20. or 25. vpon a braunch, which the Indians plucke off and carry into their hou≈øes, they are very plea≈øant of ta≈øte, whereof you may reade at large in the Ea≈øt Indian Hi≈øtories: the ≈øprigs that bring foorth cotten, are there in great aboundance, being of an indifferent greatne≈ø≈øe, and haue leaues like the yellow bels of the a≈øh trees, froÃÑ whence there groweth an apple as bigge as Bulken, which beeing ripe, openeth in foure partes, and yeeldeth forth cotten, the Barbarians call it Ameni iou, in the middle of which wool are certain blacke kernels, p ‚Ä¢ e≈øt together like mens kidneyes, and as bigge as beanes, this cotten is gathered by the Bra≈øilian women, which they ≈øpinne, and therof make many things, Citrons and Lemonds by the Portingales brought into tho≈øe countries, grow there in great aboundance, very plea≈øant and good: al≈øo many ≈øugar canes, whereby much ≈øugar is brought from thence into Portingale: it is much to be wondered at, that ≈øeeing there is ≈øo ≈øw√©et a ≈øub≈øtance in tho≈øe reedes while they are fre≈øh and newe gatherd, that being but a little withered or put into the water, they doo pre≈øently conuert into ≈øo ≈øower a ≈øub≈øtance, that it is as good Vinegere as any can bee founde. Be≈øides the≈øe ≈øugar reedes, there groweth other reedes as thicke as a mans legge, which beeing greene, are with one blow ea≈øily cutte in two peeces, but when they are drie, they become verie tough and hard, whereof they make arrowes, & ≈øticks to carry in theyr handes: in that countrie likewi≈øe is much Ma≈øticke, & excellent good Gumme (which was ordinarily brought out of Chio) al≈øo diuers and innumerable ≈øorts of ≈øweete ≈ømelling flowers & hearbes. And although that about this Cabo de Frio there is much thunder, raine, and great winds, as lying vnder Tropicus Capricorn, yet becau≈øe there falleth no fro≈øt, ≈ønowe, nor haile, therefore the trees are there alwayes gr√©ene, as they are with vs in May: and in December when the dayes are ≈øhorte≈øt and colde≈øt here with vs, they are there at the longe≈øt and hotte≈øt, but it is to be vnder≈øtood, that they neuer fal out to be ≈øo long or ≈øhort as they are with vs, for they haue the day and night of an euener length then we, and a more temperate aire. The fruits of this countrey are many, whereof Ananas is the be≈øt, the leaues whereof are like the leaues of Iris or aloes, a little bowing, and in manner rounde, the fruit is long like Cucumbers or di≈øtaues, when they are greene they pre≈ø≈øe a certaine iuice out of them, which ta≈øteth as plea≈øantly as Malue≈øie, of this fruite I haue alreadie ≈øpoken in the de≈øcription of the ea≈øt Indians, ≈øo that at this time it is needle≈ø≈øe to write any more thereof, as being ther to be read: there is an hearb in Bra≈øilia, by ye Tououpinambaulti ‚Ä¢
called Petum, which we call Tabacum or Nicouana, and now it groweth in our gardens, but not ≈øo good, nor ≈øo ≈øtrong as theirs: this hearb is ≈øufficiently de≈øcribed by Clu≈øius and other writers, & very well knowne, it hath leaues like our dock leaues, or Con≈øolida Maior by the Bra≈øilians it is much e≈øteemed, which they gather and make into balles, and being
dried, take foure or fiue of the leaues, and rubbing them togither, they make theÃÑ burne, the ≈ømoake whereof they receiue in to their bodies, which doth ≈øo fill & nouri≈øh them, that hauing receiued in the ≈ømoake, they will goe two or three dayes when they are in the warres, and neither eate nor drinke, which Le ‚Ä¢ ius likewi≈øe hath tried, as al≈øo, that the ≈øame ≈ømoake maketh men auoyde ≈øleugine, out of their heads, & therefore the Indians weare bundles thereof about their neckes, to ≈ømel vnto it: the rootes Maniot and Aypi I haue alredy de≈øcribed. There is likewi≈øe another kind of roote called Hecich, whereof there are three kindes, ≈øome being ≈øodden are blew, others yellow like quinces, and the re≈øt white like par≈øeneps, they are all good of ta≈øte, ≈øpecially the yellow, which being ro≈øted, are as good as peares, & are there in as great aboundance as turnops in Sauoy, about two handfulles thicke, and a foote and a halfe long: the hearb runneth along vpon the ground, and hath leaues like cucumers or great ≈øpinage, but differing in colour, neerer to the broome or white wilde vine leaues: becau≈øe the≈øe roots neuer yeeld ≈øeed, they are cut in p√©eces and planted n the earth: he that de≈øireth to knowe more hereof, let him reade Clu≈øius his workes, and they wil ≈øati≈øfie his de≈øire. There is al≈øo a kinde of nut (by them called Manobi) which groweth vnder the ground and hang by little thr√©edes one fa≈øt to an other, hauing a ≈øub≈øtaunce within them like to our hazel nuttes, of a browne whiti≈øh colour, with hu≈økes like the ≈øhelles of pea≈øe. Touching Bra≈øilia pepper, which al≈øo at this pre≈øent day groweth in our gardeins, and very hot it is, by Mathiolus called S ‚Ä¢ iqua≈øtium, and Bra≈øilia beanes and pea≈øe, whereof n√©edeth no great de≈øcription, as being commonly knowne. To conclude you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that ≈ø√©eing Bra≈øilia hath no wilde bea≈øts, foules, fi≈øhes, nor liuing creatures, ≈øuch as are in Europa, neyther yet trees, nor hearbs, onely pulcelen, ba≈øill, and vaarne or felix, which growe in ≈øome places thereof, we may ≈øay with the Prophet Dauid in his 104. p≈øalme:
O Lord, thy works mo≈øt ≈øtrange and wonderfull,
both far & neere are ≈øeene & known right well
How wi≈øely thou al things do≈øt bring to pa≈ø≈øe,
whereby al creatures thy great goodnes feele,
And who can either number, write, or ≈øhow,
the kindes of beasts that are in land and ≈øea.
And ≈øurely the≈øe people might well be accounted happy, if they had the knowlege of the true and euerliuing God.

div.head: A briefe di≈øcour≈øe of their warres and armes.
div.p: TOuching their warres, they v≈øe them not, thereby to get riches by force, or to inlarge their dominions, but only of meere affectioÃÑ and de≈øire they haue to reuenge the deaths of their forefathers, which by theyr enemies haue from time to time beene taken and deuoured, wherein they are ≈øo zealous, that as many of their enemies as they take are ≈øure to die the like death, and to be eaten by them, and hauing once begunne warres with their neighbours, they wil neuer be friends againe, but where or how≈øoeuer they can intrap or catch each other, they are ≈øure to die: The manner of the Tououpinambaul ‚Ä¢ ers warres are in this

Although they haue no Kings nor Princes among them, not one of them beeing of greater account than the re≈øt, yet they haue this cu≈øtome, that they honour their auncients, by them called Peore ru Picheb, and in euery village they are ready to do as they commaund them, which their auncients many times, walking among them, or el≈øe ≈øitting in their hanging beddes of cotten, take occa≈øion to v≈øe this maner of ≈øp√©ech vnto the people ≈øaying, Are not our forefathers that haue fought with, ouercom, ≈ølain and eaten ≈øo many of our enimies, an example vnto vs, not to ≈øtay coÃÑtinually at home? ≈øhall we ≈øuffer our nation, which in times pa≈øt was ≈øo fearful to our enemies that they dur≈øt not looke them in the face, be thus brought into ≈øo open ≈øhame and reproach? that it ≈øhall be ≈øaide our ennemies came to a≈ø≈øaile vs within our owne hou≈øes? ≈øhal we by our negligence and ≈ølowne≈ø≈øe ≈øtay and watch till the Marga ‚Ä¢ aters and the Peros Engaipa, which are cruell Portingales, doe fir≈øt ≈øhew their powers and execute theyr tirannies vpon vs? & hauing ≈øpoken in that manner, he clappeth his handes vppon his buttockes, and crying out ≈øaith, Erima, Erima, Tououpinambaults, conomi, oua≈ø≈øou, Tan, Tan, &c. that is, Beholde my friends, you ≈øtrong yong men, is this conuenient to be done, let vs rather arme our ≈øelues, and by force be ouerthrowne, or els reuenge our iniuries receiued. The≈øe and ≈øuch like Orations, which indure for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe howers at the lea≈øt do the Elders v≈øe vnto the people, which they with great patience and quietnes hearken vnto, and therewith are ≈øo incouraged, that pre≈øently, with all ≈øp√©ed they a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues togither in a certaine place, and in great numbers with ≈øwordes and holberdes (by them called Tacapes) of red or blacke wood, very heauy like
bore trees, about fiue or ≈øixe foot long, round at the end like a ≈øpit, a foote broad, and the thickene≈ø≈øe of a thumbe in the middle, al the other part ≈øharpe. Be≈øides tho≈øe weapons, they haue orapats, which are bowes, there are likewi≈øe of blacke or red wood, wherewith they can ≈øhoote ≈øo ≈øure and certainly, that no man excelleth them, of the which bowes and arrowes, becau≈øe there are ≈øo many of them brought into the≈øe countries, there needeth no great de≈øcription: withall they haue bucklers of the ≈økinnes of Tapirou≈ø≈øou, broad, flat, and round like the couer of a drumme, wherewith they couer not them≈øelues, but v≈øe them onely to receiue their enemies arrowes: the≈øe are al the wepons they do commonly v≈øe, only that they do put on certayne kindes of apparell made of feathers, wherewith they ≈øet foorth theyr bodies, otherwi≈øe they will not haue any thing vpon their bodies (were it but a bare ≈øhirt) that might be any let or hinderaunce vnto them. And being armed in this manner, they ≈øet forward ≈øometimes eight or tenne thou≈øand men (with certaine women not to fight, but to carry their nece≈ø≈øaries & proui≈øions and being in the field, the anciente≈øt among them ≈øuch as haue ≈ølaine and eaten many of their enemies) are appoynted for captaines and commaunders, after whome the re≈øt folowe, and ≈øet forward towards the enemy, and although they meete all together without order, yet when they march they place them≈øelues in rankes, the ≈øtronge≈øt going before, and the re≈øt after them, wherein it is ≈øtrange, that ≈øo manye men being together without a generall, can ≈øo well place them≈øelues, and know when they ≈øhould ≈øet forward. There are ≈øome of them that blowe in great hornes, like our trumpets, which they call Inabia, wherewith they incourage the people, and giue them ≈øignes of battell, others haue pipes or flutes made of their enemies bones, which at other times they haue ≈ølaine and eaten: whereon all the time of their march they cea≈øe not to pipe, thereby to ≈øtirre their fellowes harts to do the like with their ennemies bones that by them ≈øhould bee taken. And if they a≈ø≈øaile their enemies by water, they keepe clo≈øe to the ≈øhore, not daring enter farre into the ≈øea, becau≈øe their ≈øcutes which are made of the barkes of trees, are not able to indure again≈øt a tempe≈øt, but ≈øerue onely in calme weather, eache ≈øcute holding fiftie men, which may ea≈øily ≈øitte therein and rowe, with ≈øo great ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe, that it is wonderfull.

In the maner before rehear≈øed they trauel ≈øometimes tenne or twelue miles within their enemies countrey, v≈øing to march with their ≈øtronge≈øt men fir≈øt, leauing the weake≈øt with the womeÃÑ a day or two daies iourney behind them, marching very quietly entring into certaine woods, where they ≈øtay & hide them≈øelues for the ≈øpace of half a day, meane time if they meete with any of their enemies, either men, women, or children, they k√©ep them not pri≈øoners, neither take them with them, but pre≈øently kil and ro≈øt them vpon their boncans or girdirons, and ≈øo eate them, which they do, not to bee troubled with them when they ≈øhould enter into the vilages of their enemies, which are all without walles, their hou≈øes being of 80. or 100. pa≈øes long, without doores, placing in ≈øteede thereof certayne Palme trees or branches of the hearb called Pindo: yet there are ≈øome villages among them, ≈øuch as border vpon their enemies, that are paled about with boordes of ≈øixe foote high, again≈øt the which when they meane to doe any exploit, they watch the way that goeth vnto the village, where ≈øuch as i≈ø≈øue foorth or enter in, fighting with them, are taken pri≈øoners, and are killed and eaten. But when they meet in open field, army again≈øt army, it is done with ≈øuch fury and horrible bloud≈øhed, that it is incredible, as Ioannes Lerius a Burgonian hath per≈øonally beheld them, can witnes, from whome this is gathered, for that they run with ≈øo great fiercene≈ø≈øe and boldne≈ø≈øe together, as neuer was heard of: for (as Lerius writeth) when the Tououpinambaultiers fir≈øt perceiued their enemies, they made ≈øo horrible a crie, as greater is neuer heard among vs when we hunt the wolfe, and that ≈øo lowde, as if at that time it had thundred, it could ≈øcarcely haue b√©ene heard: and approching nearer vnto them, they beganne a ≈øecond time to crie, with blowing of hornes, and piping on their flutes, calling to their ennemies, and ≈øhewing theÃÑ the dead bones of their frends, and their teeth, which they do weare about their neckes vpon ≈øtrings, at the lea≈øt twoo elles long: that done, entring into battell, and beginning to ≈øhoote, you may ≈øee theyr arows flee into the ayre as thick as ≈øwarms of flies, with all kinde of coloured feathers, which maketh a mo≈øt plea≈øant ≈øhew, if it might be ≈ø√©en without danger: in the which ≈øhooting, who≈øoeuer is hurt, pre≈øently pulleth ≈øorth the arrow, and like a madde dog biteth it in peeces, yet hee leaueth not off, but ≈øtill fighteth, as being ≈øo cruel and fierce that they neuer cea≈øe fighting as long as any ≈øtrength is in their bodies, neuer flying: and ≈øuch as they ≈øtrike with their woodden holberts, fal pre≈øently dead vnto the grouÃÑd,
like oxen that are kild by the butcher. This manner of fight was ≈ø√©ene by Lerius, to bee done by the Tououpinam baultiers, who after thr√©e houres fight had the victory, and after many on both ≈øides were ≈ølaine and wounded, they brought about thirty men and women pri≈øoners, which they placed in the middle of their battell, the ≈øtronge≈øt of them being tied with ropes: which done, they returned to the Cr√©eke or entry or Ganabara, of the which pri≈øoners ten of them were bought and ≈øent to Henry the ≈øecond king of Fraunce. Lerius him≈øelfe bought a woman and her child, and being with him, he thinking to comfort her, telling her h√©e would ≈øend her into France, ≈øhe aun≈øwered him, that ≈øhe had rather be eaten by her enemies, or to be let loo≈øe, that ≈øhe might once againe helpe to be reuenged on the ennemies that haue taken her, wherein you may ≈øee how ≈øtiffely they are bent vnto reuenge, neuer forgetting or forgiuing anie iniury what≈øoeuer.

div.head: The manner how they v≈øe their pri≈øoners, and what ceremonies they v≈øe in the killing and eating them.
div.p: THe pri≈øoners being brought home by ≈øuch as haue taken them, are not onelie well fed, but they giue the men, women to beare them company (but not the women men to lie with them) and which is more ≈øtrange, diuers of them that haue pri≈øoners wil not refu≈øe to giue him daughter or ≈øi≈øter to wife, which mu≈øt liue truely and hone≈øtly with her hu≈øband, and becau≈øe they ob≈øerue no certaine time of the offerings, or butcheries of their pri≈øoners, but ≈øomtimes ≈øooner, ≈øomtimes later, as they thinke good, therfore the men pri≈øners are kept to hunt, fi≈øh, and catch birds, and the women to garden, plant, and fi≈øh for oy≈øters: and when like ≈øwine they are fat and wel fed, they are ≈ølaine and eaten, in manner as followeth. Fir≈øt they certifie all the neighbours round about, when, and in what place their fea≈øt ≈øhall be kept, where there reforteth a great number, both men, women, and children, con≈øuming all the forenoone with drinking, among the which are the pri≈øoners (which know ful wel that it wilbe vnto their co≈øts) all be≈øet with feathers, who not onely feareth not death, but in dancing, leaping, and drinking excelleth all the re≈øt, in which maner, hauing con≈øumed at the lea≈øt ≈øix or ≈øeauen houres, two or thr√©e of the ≈øtronge≈øt among them lay hold vpon the pri≈øoner, and therewith bind him about the middle with cotten ropes, or with the barks of a certain tr√©e, by them called Iuire, which is like a Linden tr√©e, meane while hee ≈øtandeth ≈øtill and neuer re≈øi≈øteth them, although both his armes & hands are at libertie: which done, they leade him in that manner round about the village for euery man to ≈øee him, he not once haÃÑging down his head (as tho≈øe which in our countries are ready to be executed v≈øe to do) but to the contrary with an incredible boldne≈ø≈øe boa≈øting of his d√©edes, and telling them that leade him, what hee hath done, ≈øpeaketh vnto them in this manner: When I was at libertie, I haue manye times in this ≈øorte bound your friendes and kin≈ømen, and with much more boldne≈ø≈øe commending him≈øelfe, and ≈øetting forth his actions, tourning his face on all ≈øides, and looking about him hee ≈øpeaketh to ≈øome one of them and ≈øaith, Heare≈øt thou friend, It is I that ate thy father, and to an other, ≈øirra, it was I that killd thy brother and broyled him vpon the coles, and haue taken and eaten ≈øo many of your people, that I am not able to number them, and be you well a≈ø≈øured that my friendes the Margaiaters will not leaue my death vnreuenged, and will once catch ≈øome of you, and ≈øerue you in the like ≈øort.

And in this maner being ≈øhewed round about the village, in the end, the two men that holde him, ≈øtepping backe about thr√©e elles di≈øtant from him, pulling the rope wherewith hee is bounde on both ≈øides ≈øo ≈øtrait, that therewith he ≈øtandeth fa≈øt, and is not able to ≈øtirre eyther backward or forward: which done, they bring vnto him certain ≈øtones or peeces of broken pots, and they that hold him bound in that manner, being couered with bucklers of tap ‚Ä¢ rou≈ø≈øou ≈øpeake vnto him, and a≈øke him if before he die he will reuenge his death, wherewith pre≈øently in great fury, he throweth ≈øtones at them, as al≈øo at al others ≈øtanding round about him, which many times are aboue foure thou≈øand people, not once caring how many of them are hurt or wounded, not although he ≈øhould breake any of their legges with a blowe, and hauing ca≈øt ≈øtones, pot≈øhardes, earth, and all what≈øoeuer he can reach: then he that mu≈øt kill him (hauing al that day kept him≈øelfe clo≈øe, and not once come forth) goeth vnto him and ≈øaieth, Art not thou one of the Margaiaters our ennemies? ha≈øt not thou thy ≈øelfe taken pri≈øoners and eaten ≈øome of our kin≈ømen and friends? whereunto the pri≈øoner an≈øwereth him, and ≈øaith, Pa, che, tan, tan, aiouca, a ‚Ä¢ oupaue, that is, I am he that hath ≈ølaine and eaten many of your people, and to grieue them the more, h√©e layeth both his hands vppon
his head, and ≈øaith, O howe lu≈øtily haue I therein behaued my ≈øelfe? howe earne≈øtly haue I pur≈øued you in the battell, and haue eaten an innumerable companie of you? Wherewith he that ≈øhal kil him an≈øwereth him and ≈øaith: Therefore now ≈ø√©eing you are here, and our pri≈øoner, I will kill you, and your body being ro≈øted, ≈øhall likewi≈øe be eaten. Whereunto hee an≈øwereth and ≈øaith, Well, what remedy? a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe my friendes will reuenge my death: and while he ≈øpeaketh he is ≈øtricken down with the wooden holbert: and if he had a wife (as during their impri≈øonment they commonly haue) ≈øhe falleth fir≈øt vpon the dead bodie, and with a few (although crocadiles) teares ≈øhe weepeth ouer him, for that it is ≈øaide the Crocadile weepeth before he deuoureth the dead body he hath ≈ølaine, in the ≈øame maner do they, for that the fal≈øe teares once ≈øhed, ≈øhe woulde be the fir≈øt that ≈øhoulde eate his fle≈øh: which done, the other women, ≈øpecially old womeÃÑ, as being mo≈øt de≈øirous to feed on mens fle≈øh, tell tho≈øe women that keepe the pri≈øoners, that they mu≈øt make ha≈øte to bring the dead body, and hot water with them, wherewith they rubbe, ≈øcrape, and wa≈øh the body ≈øo cleane, that the ≈økinne goeth off, the fle≈øh ≈ø√©eming as white as a roa≈øted pigge: which done, commeth the mai≈øter of the pri≈øoner, with as many companions as he thinketh good, and diuideth the dead body, as quickely as a Butcher with vs ≈øhould cut vp a ≈øh√©epe, or other bea≈øt: and as with vs when the hunters haue killed a Bucke, throw the entrailes and bloud vnto the houndes, ≈øo tho≈øe Barbarians annoynt their children with the bloud of theyr dead ennemy, thereby to prouoke them to cruelty and reuenge: before the Chri≈øtians v≈øed to tho≈øe countries, they cut the body in peeces with certayne ≈øtones, but now they haue kniues. The man in that ≈øort diuided, and the intrailes being wa≈øhed and made cleane, the girdirons are looked vnto by the other women, that are very de≈øirous of maÃÑs fle≈øh, where they fit and licke vp the fat that droppeth off the quarters, therewithal mo≈øt erne≈øtly exhorting and prouoking the yong men and childreÃÑ to take ≈øome more of their enemies, and to bring them ≈øuch meate. In this ≈øort one, two, or thr√©e pri≈øners, or more, as it falleth out, being ≈ølaine and ro≈øted, all the company that are pre≈øent, a≈ø≈øemble about their boucans or girdirons of wood, for that the Indians ro≈øt no meate vppon ≈øpittes, as ≈øome men paynt them to do, for that they thincke it impo≈ø≈øible that euer it ≈øhould be ro≈øted enough being turnd round about, where they make great ioy, leaping, ≈økipping, and with mo≈øt fierce countenances beholding the ro≈øted quarters, euerie man taking a peece, not for hunger, or de≈øire of eating, (as ≈øome would think) or becau≈øe without all doubt mans fle≈øh is verie ≈øauorie, but rather in re≈øpect of reuenge, ≈øpecially the olde women, that are mo≈øt rauenous of mans fle≈øh, for their intent is onely to gnaw the fle≈øh of their enemies to the bare bones, thereby to putte the re≈øt of the pri≈øoners (as then not ≈ølaine) in greater feare, for that to ≈øati≈øfie their mon≈øtrous and greedie de≈øires, there is not one peece of the whole body, not ≈øo much as their fingers endes, no≈øe, and eares, but by them is eaten, (onely the vaines and the ≈øcull, which they keep, as wee doo dead mens bones in our Churchyards) and ≈øhew them as ≈øignes of their dictories and triumphs. The great bones of their legges and armes are kept to make pipes, and their teeth they put vpon ≈øtrings, which they weare about their necks. Tho≈øe that haue killed them, e≈øt√©eme it for an honourable action, and departing from the re≈øt of their companie, cutte certaine ≈øla≈øhes in their brea≈øts, armes, legs, and other fle≈øhie places, wherein they put a certaine ≈øalue, thereby to make ≈øcarres and ≈øignes thereof in their bodyes, vpon the which they throw certaine blacke pouder which neuer goeth off, being of opinion that the more ≈øtrikes he hath in his bodye, the more men he hath murthered, and for the ≈øame is accounted a lu≈øtie fellow, and of great courage. And to fini≈øh their bloudy tragedie, if it fortune the woman (that was giuen vnto the pri≈øoners during his impri≈øonment for his wife) b√©e with childe, they take the childe when it is borne (a thing mo≈øt fearefull and horrible to heare, for they neuer ≈øuffer it to growe to yeares) and eate it, alleadging that ≈øuch children are of their enimies ≈ø√©ed. And tho≈øe Barbarians doe not onely ≈ø√©eke vtterly to extingui≈øh their enemies, but woulde likewi≈øe haue other ≈øtrangers and countrymen that come among them to v≈øe the ≈øame cruelty, and to eate mens fle≈øh, which by ≈øome reiecting all humanitie, hath beene done.

div.head: ¬∂Of the religion of the Bra≈øilians, and the mi≈øery or feare where into the poore men are brought by their Caraiben, not acknowledging any God.
div.p:
IN the hi≈øtorie of Peru, a prouince lying on the ≈øouth ≈øide of Bra≈øilia, and bordering vpon this Countrey whereof I ≈øpeake, is declared that they wor≈øhip the ≈øunne and the moone, but the≈øe Toupins haue no god,
neither heauenly nor earthly, and therefore haue no churches nor temples, wherin they ≈øhould a≈ø≈øemble to wor≈øhip their idols, clean contrary to the cu≈øtome and manner of all Heathens and Idolatours throughout the whole worlde. They vnder≈øtand not what the creation of the world meaneth, neyther do they giue any names to the dayes, or e≈øt√©eme one more than the re≈øt, nor account not their times by w√©eks, months or y√©ers, but onely by the moones: and as touching godly or worldly literature, they are wholy ignorant, not v≈øing ≈øo much as any kind of characters or letters, woondering much at the Frenchmen that wrote vpon paper, and could reade it: wherein we are greatly to prai≈øe god that hath giuen vs the grace that we can certifie each other by letters of our actions being in far countries, and thereby al≈øo attaine vnto the knowledge of the true and liuely God, maker of heauen & earth, wherof when any man ≈øpeaketh vnto tho≈øe ≈øimple people, being in great admiration, they ≈øtand ≈øtill as it were aba≈øhed, and crie I c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and becau≈øe they ≈ø√©emed to be very fearefull of the thunder clappes, by them called Toupan, and that thereuppon the Frenchmen (taking occa≈øion to marke their ≈øimplicitie and little knowledge) tolde them that God, to ≈øhew his great power and maie≈øty, did thereby cau≈øe both heauen and earth to ≈øhake, they aun≈øwered that ≈øuch a God mu≈øt n√©edes be wicked that putte men in ≈øo great feare: Such is the mi≈øerable e≈øtate of tho≈øe poore men. Now if any man a≈øke whether they liue like bea≈øts, without and God, it may be aun≈øwered them, that there is not much difference, for that tho≈øe people are wholy more thaÃÑ other men without any knowledge of God, and yet being in this gr√©euous blindene≈ø≈øe, they bel√©eue the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, and doe mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly per≈øwade them≈øelues, that the ≈øoules of ≈øuch as here in this life haue valiantly and well behaued them≈øelues (which their valiancie and well liuing is meant by killing and eating of their enemies) doe fly behinde certaine high hilles, where being in plea≈øant gardeins (with the ≈øoules of theyr forefathers) they continue in euerla≈øting ioy, plea≈øure, and dauncing: and to the contrary that ≈øuch as are ≈ølacke, (which liue without honour, and will not defend theyr natiue country) are borne away by the Aygnan, for ≈øo they caled the diuel, with whom they liued in euerla≈øting paine. They are likewi≈øe in this life many times tormented by the diuell, which al≈øo they call Kaagerre, for Lerius writeth, that he per≈øonally ≈øawe them, and heard them ≈øpeake to the French men, and raging like madde dogges, began to crie out and ≈øay vnto them, Alas, alas, helpe vs, for the Aygnan beateth vs, and would tell them, that they did oftentimes ≈øee the diuell, ≈øometimes in forme of a bea≈øt, ≈øometimes in likene≈ø≈øe of a bird, at other times in diuers ≈øhapes: and becau≈øe they maruelled that they were not troubled nor mole≈øted by him, they made them an≈øwer, that god who is of greater power than their Aygnan or diuell, did pre≈øerue them from him: wherupon they being tormented promi≈øed to become chri≈øtians, and to beleeue in the onely God: yet their paines were no ≈øooner ended, but they pre≈øently forgot their promi≈øe. And it is mo≈øt certaine, that they are ≈øo tormented, for Lyrius ≈øaith, that hee hath often ≈ø√©ene them, when onely with the remembraunce of their torments, they were in ≈øo great feare, and ≈øighed ≈øo deepely that very griefe made them to ≈øweat, and ≈øitting with their hands vpon their heades, mourning and lamenting ≈øaid, Mair atoura≈ø≈øap, acequere, aignan atoupaue, that is, O my good friend, and my companion, I feare wicked ≈øathan aboue al other things, whereunto he an≈øwered them, that he feared him not, wherewith lamenting their e≈øtate, they would ≈øay, O how happy ≈øhould wee be if wee were fr√©eed from him: if you will be fr√©e ≈øaide Lerius, then you mu≈øt bel√©eue in him that is mightie. Then the Aignan or the diuel which they being in paine promi≈øed him to doe: but their torments pa≈øt, they had cleane forgotten what they ≈øaide.

Herein you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that tho≈øe of Peru and Cu≈øco, did not only beleeue the immortallitie of the ≈øoule, but al≈øo the re≈øurrection of the body, as in the Hi≈øtorie of Peru is already declared, by the example of the Indians, who ≈ø√©eing the Spaniards to open graues of the dead Indians, and to take away their Iewelles, de≈øired them that they wold not ≈øcatter nor throw away the bones, to the end that the dead might not want them when they ≈øhoulde ri≈øe againe.

This is written to the ende that all vngodly men, that are conuer≈øaunt with the ≈øimple Tououpinambaultes, per≈øwading them≈øelues that there is no God, ≈øhoulde learne of the wild mi≈øerable wretches, that there are certaine wicked ≈øpirites, which torment the vngodly (not bel√©euing in the power of God) here in this life. And it they affirme (as many of them doe) that ≈øuch wicked ≈øpirites are nothing el≈øe, but the euill affections and conceites of the minde, and that therefore the Barbarians doe fooli≈øhly
per≈øwade them≈øelues of that which is not true, it may be an≈øwered them (as they may reade in our de≈øcription) that the Americans were openly and certainely tormented by wicked ≈øpirits, whereby it may ≈øufficiently appeare, that ≈øuch torments are no fle≈øhly effects, which torment the ≈øtronge≈øt of them in that maner. Secondly, although ≈øuch vngodly men are altogether vnworthy to heare that which the holy ≈øcripture ≈øpeaketh concerning the re≈øurrection of the body, yet this ≈øecond poynt of the Barbarians may well be propounded again≈øt tho≈øe which bel√©eue the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, as al≈øo the Peruuians that bel√©eue the immortalitie both of ≈øoule and body, whereby they may bee a≈øhamed, and learne of ≈øuch wilde men: and although tho≈øe people knew how to bee quit of all their torments and gr√©efes afore≈øaide, yet are they in great feare of thunder, as fearing a certain power, which they cannot re≈øi≈øt or with≈øtand, yet will they not knowe it, wherefore the Go≈øpel in the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, fourt√©enth Chapter and ≈øeuent√©enth ver≈øe, mo≈øt truely ≈øaith, that God in time pa≈øt ≈øuffered the heathens to walke in their own wayes, although hee cea≈øed not continually to make his power knowne, by doing vs good, ≈øending vs raine from heauen, and giuing vs fruitfull times and ≈øea≈øons, filling our hearts with ioy, and our bodyes with meate, ≈øo that it is the onely wickedne≈ø≈øe of man that will not acknowledge the eternall God and maker of all things. And in another place, in the fir≈øt to the Romanes and twentieth ver≈øe, Saint Paul ≈øayth (for that which is inui≈øible vnto man, which is his eternitie and Godhead) is manife≈øted vnto vs by the creation of the world. Therefore although tho≈øe men wil not confe≈ø≈øe God with their mouthes, yet are they by their own actions ouerthrowne, and made to knowe there is a God, and that ≈øo they are not ignorant, or may once pretend the ≈øame, con≈øidering their bel√©efe of the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, the feare they haue of the thunder clappes, and the wicked ≈øpirits that torment them. They haue likewi≈øe Prophets or Prie≈øtes, which they call Caraibes, that goe from village to village, making the poore people beleeue that they are conuer≈øant with ≈øpirites, and that they can make ≈øtrong whom it plea≈øeth them, and giue them power to vanqui≈øh the enemie, al≈øo that by theyr helpe the fruites and great tr√©es do grow and increa≈øe vpon the earth.

Be≈øides this, euerie thr√©e or foure yeare they come togither, both men, women and children, ob≈øeruing a certaine fea≈øt, but in ≈øeuerall hou≈øes, ≈øo clo≈øe or neare togither, that they may heare each other: where they fir≈øt beginne with fearefull ≈øongs and ≈øome daunces, their Caribens being with them, the women foming at the mouthes, as if they had the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, beating their brea≈øtes, and making a mo≈øt fearefull noy≈øe, as if they were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with euill ≈øpirits, and in like ≈øort the children: which noy≈øe being ended, they are ≈øtill for a time, and then beginne againe to ≈øing ≈øo ≈øweetly, and in mea≈øure, that it woulde delight a man to heare them, withall dauncing a rounde, each following and not leading the other, bending their bodyes forwards, and their right legge ≈øomewhat outwarde and crooked, with their right hande vppon theyr buttocks, letting the left hand hang down, and in this manner they daunce and compa≈ø≈øe thrice about, in each daunce hauing thr√©e or foure Caribes, with hattes, apparrell, and arme bandes of feathers, each Caribe hauing in his hand a Ma ‚Ä¢ aca or rattle, thereby making the people beleeue that the ≈øpirit ≈øpeaketh vnto theÃÑ out of th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e rattles, ≈øtepping forwarde and backewarde, and (not as the people doo) ≈øtanding ≈øtill in one place.

They likewi≈øe often times take long Reedes, wherein they putte a certaine hearbe by them called Petum, which they ≈øette on fire, and turning them≈øelues about, incen≈øe the people with the ≈ømoke thereof, with the≈øe wordes, Receiue the ≈øpirite of ≈øtrength, whereby you may ouercome your enemies: which kinde of ceremonies continue for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe or ≈øeauen houres togither, and with ≈øo plea≈øant melodie, that men that are ≈ø√©ene in mu≈øicke (as tho≈øe people are not) would maruaile thereat, and thinke it impo≈ø≈øible: and at the ende of euerie ≈øong‚ñ™ ≈øtamping on the grounde with their right foote, euerie man ≈øpitting, and with a hoar≈øe voyce often vttering the≈øe wordes, He, He, Hua, He, Hua, Hua, Hua: In the≈øe ceremonies they fir≈øt remember their valiant Predece≈ø≈øors, being in good hope that they ≈øhall goe behinde the hilles, and there with them be merrie and daunce: that doone, they doo mo≈øt earne≈øtly threaten the Ouetacaten (a mo≈øt cruell people bordering vppon them,) that in ≈øhort tune they hope to ouerrunne them, and at the la≈øt ≈øinging ≈øomewhat of Noes floud, that it de≈øtroyed the world and drowned all the people, onely their forefathers, that ≈øaued them≈øelues vpon the tops of high trees, whereby it ≈øhould appeare that they haue hadde a certaine knowledge of Noes
floud, although now cleane forgotten, becau≈øe they haue no bookes, neither yet can reade. The≈øe ceremonies ended, they entertaine their Caribes mo≈øt ≈øumptuou≈øly with daintie meate and drinke, and make good cheere: the ≈øaide Caribes walke likewi≈øe through the villages with their rattles or Maracan, & couering them with feathers, they make them fa≈øt to a ≈øtaffe, which they fixe into the earth, and there offer meate and drinke before it, as if it were an Idole, making the poore men beleeue that the rattles eate and con≈øume the meate and drink, whereby euery hou≈øholder thinketh him≈øelfe bound to ≈øet, not onely fle≈øh and fi≈øh before them, but al≈øo of their Coauin, which is their drinke: the manner of it is thus: their Maracans or rattles being tyed to a ≈øticke, and fixed in the earth, as afore ≈øaid, for the ≈øpace of fifteene dayes, are by the people ≈øerued with great deuotion, and therwith they do ≈øo bewitch the poore people, that they make them beleeue the rattles are holy, and that the ≈øpirits ≈øpeake out of them. The Frenchmen ≈ø√©eking to bring them from that fonde opi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on, were hardly thought of by them, and thereby incurred the Caribes ≈øore di≈øplea≈øure: in like manner Balaams prie≈øts hated Elias, for di≈øcouering their deceits. And thus much concerning the ceremonies and Religion of the≈øe poore ≈øimple people, which at this pre≈øeÃÑt ≈øhal ≈øuffice, and ≈øuch as are de≈øirous to know more, let them reade the hi≈øtories therof, ≈øpecially Iohnes Lerius, from whence for the mo≈øt part this is taken forth, who hath de≈øcribed at large what happened vnto him in his voyage into tho≈øe countries.

div.head: The manner of their marriage, number of wiues, and the degrees of marriage ob≈øerued among them, al≈øo the education of their children.
div.p:
IN marriage they ob≈øerue the≈øe degr√©es of kindered, no man marrieth with his mother, ≈øi≈øter, or daughter, other degr√©es they re≈øpect not, for the vncles marrie with their co≈øins, and ≈øo of other degr√©es: when they match together, they v≈øe no ceremonies, but hee that is de≈øirous to marrie with a widow or a maide, ≈øpeaketh vnto theyr friendes (if they haue any) or to their neighbours, for want of friendes, a≈øking them if it be their wils that ≈øuch a one ≈øhuld marrie with them, if they ≈øay I, then pre≈øentlie he taketh her home without any more ceremony, & keepeth her for his wife, but if ≈øhe be denied him, he neuer ≈øeeketh further vnto hir: but here you mu≈øt con≈øider, that they are permitted to take many wiues, for that euerie man hath as many as hee thinks good, and the more he hath, the ≈øtronger and worthier they e≈øt√©eme him: there are ≈øome of theÃÑ that haue eight, yet the liue in ≈øuch vnitie, that although ≈øome one of them is better beloued then the re≈øt, yet they neuer conceiue any ielou≈øie therein, neither yet once murmur thereat, but liue quietly togither, weauing and making their cotten beds, doing their hou≈øhould worke, looking to their gardens, and planting of their rootes, &c. Such women as commit adulterie, are by nature ≈øo abhominable to the Americans, that it is in the mans power to kill them, or els with ≈øhame to put them from him: it is true that they take no regarde vnto their maids, but let them do as they wil, but being once married, they mu≈øt ob≈øerue their promi≈øe, vpon the paines before rehear≈øed, but they are not ≈øo much addicted to vncleanne≈ø≈øe as the people of Ea≈øt India: the women that are with child ab≈øtaine from great labours, and do nothing but ordinarie worke about the hou≈øes, and commonly the women do more work then the men, for the men only in the morning, ≈øet certaine tr√©es about their gardens, but not al ye day after, but coÃÑ≈øume mo≈øt of their time in the wars, hunting, & fi≈øhing, & to make Bra≈øilia halberds, and weapons of wood, as al≈øo bowes and arrowes: as touching the bringing forth of the child into the world, the men receiue them from the womans body, and with their t√©eth bite off the childes nauill ≈øtring, and then pre≈ø≈øe downe the no≈øe, e≈øteeming it a great beautifying vnto them the child being borne, is pre≈øently wa≈øhed by the father, and painted with red and blacke colour‚ñ™ it is neuer ≈øwadled nor lapped in cloathes, but onely laide in a little cotten bed, and being a boy, the father pre≈øently giueth him a woddeÃÑ knife, a bow, and a little arrow, which are laide by him in his bed, and therewith he ki≈ø≈øeth the childe, ≈øaying vnto him, My ≈øonne, when thou art great thou mu≈øt be ≈øtrong, and reuenge thy ≈øelfe vpon thine enemies: as touching their names, they giue them the names of ≈øuch things as they know, as Orapacen, that is, bow and arrow, Sarigoy, foure footed bea≈øt, Arignan, henne, Arabouten, a Bra≈øill tree, Pindo, a great hearbe, &c. The childrens meate be≈øids their mothers milke, is chawed meale, & ≈øome ≈øow≈øt meat, the womaÃÑ that is deliuered, lieth 2. or 3. daies at the mo≈øt vpon her cotten bed, after that ≈øh√©e putteth a cotten cappe vppon the childes head, and either goeth into the garden or els about the hou≈øe to doo ≈øome worke, which our women cannot do, as being of weaker complections,
and liuing in an vntemperate aire: be≈øides this, we would thinke if our children ≈øhould not be wond or ≈øwadled, they would grow crooked, whereof not any ≈øuch are founde to be among them, but rather goe vprighter then any other people in the world, which is al≈øo by meanes of the temperatene≈ø≈øe of the aire. The children growing great and to mans ≈øtate, are taught no other thing, then onely to be reuenged of their enemies, and to eate them: al≈øo they are bounde (as right followers of Lamech, Nimrod, and E≈øau, to hunting, and to go to the warres, to kill and eate both men and bea≈øts.

div.head: What lawes and pollicies are v≈øed among the Bra≈øilians, al≈øo howe friendly they entertaine ≈øtrangers, together with their weepings, and words v≈øed by the women vnto ≈øtrangers at their fir≈øt comming into their hou≈øes.
div.p:
THe policie of the Bra≈øilians is hardly to be beleeued: howe rea≈øonably and naturally they behaue them≈øelues therein, I mean among them≈øelues for commoÃÑ quarrels, for that as touching their warlike affaires again≈øt their enemies, it is ≈øufficiently declared, but if there ri≈øeth any ≈øtrife or quarrel among them≈øelues, ≈øuch as are pre≈øent will not ≈øeeke to pacifie the matter, but rather lette them fight or deale together as they thinke good, yea, although they ≈øhould plucke each others eyes out of their heads: but if one of them chaunceth to hurte the other, and being taken, he is likewi≈øe wounded in the ≈øame place where he wounded the other, and if it fortune that by the wounde the partie dieth, he that killed him ≈øhall by the kindred of the dead man bee likewi≈øe flame, ≈øo that with them they pay life for life, eye for eye, and tooth for tooth. Theyr goods are hou≈øes and lande, which they haue farre greater then their nece≈ø≈øities requireth: as touching their hou≈øes, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtande that euerie village hath at the lea≈øt
‚Ä¢ 00. hou≈øes, wherby many of theÃÑ mu≈øt of force dwell in a hou≈øe, yet euerie family hath a ≈øeuerall place, although without any di≈øtance, as beeing nothing betweene the hou≈øes, to let them from ≈øeeing from the one ende of all their hou≈øes to the other, although many times they are at the lea≈øt 60. paces long, yet euerie man hath his wiues & children ≈øeuerall to him≈øelf, and it is to be wondered at, that they neuer dwell aboue fiue or ≈øixe moneths in one hou≈øe, but taking the trees and the hearbe P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o, wherof their hou≈øes are made, they carrie them oftentimes at the l√©a≈øt 1000. paces off, yet the villages keepe their ancient names, whereby it may ea≈øily bee gathered what great hou≈øes they build, ≈ø√©eing it oftentimes happeneth that one man in his life time doth remoue his hou≈øe twentie times at the lea≈øt: and if any man a≈øketh them why they ≈øo often remoue their hou≈øes, they make an≈øwer, that changing of place is hol≈øome, al≈øo that their predece≈ø≈øors did the like, which if they ≈øhould leaue, they ≈øhould not liue long: touching their grounds, euerie Mou≈ø≈øacat, that is, hou≈øholder, hath certaine gardens and orchardes to him≈øelfe, which hee v≈øeth as he tihnketh good: but as touching the tilling and dre≈ø≈øing of their groundes, as wee do ours it is not v≈øed among them: as concerning their hou≈øhold worke, the women ≈øpin and work cotten wooll therof to make ropes and hanging beds, which beddes they cal I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, they are about ≈øix or ≈øeuen foot long, made like a net, but ≈øomewhat thicker, like our thin cloath, with ≈øtrong ropes at the head and foote to tie them at, but becau≈øe ≈øuch beds are brough ‚Ä¢ hither and ≈øo well knowne, it is not nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øpeake anie more of them, neither of the manner howe they v≈øe to ≈øpinne the wooll, but touching the≈øe things you may reade Lerius, my de≈øire being onely to ≈øet down their cheefe and principall cu≈øtomes. When the men go to warre, hunting, or fi≈øhing, they take ≈øuch beds with them, and making them fa≈øt to two trees, they ≈øleepe therein, which beddes being foule, either with du≈øt, ≈ømoke, or otherwi≈øe, are by the women made cleane, which is done in this manner: they goe into the wooddes to ≈øeeke a certaine fruite not much vnlike our pumpcons, but greater, for that mo≈øt parte of them are ≈øo great, that a man can hardly beare them in his hand: this fruite they ≈ølampe verie ≈ømall, and put it in an earthen potte, ≈øteeping it in water, which doone, they ≈øtirre it with a ≈øticke, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that it yeeldeth forth a thicke ≈øcumme, which ≈øcumme they v≈øe in ≈øteede of Sope, wherewith they make their beddes as white and cleane, as anie Fuller doth his cloath, and in ≈øummer time or in the wars, it is better ≈øleeping on tho≈øe beddes then vppon ours: as touching their hou≈øholde ≈øtuffe, the women make great earthen Pottes, therein to put theyr drinke Coa ‚Ä¢ in. They make pottes likewi≈øe of many fa≈øhions, ≈ømal and indifferent great cups, broad di≈øhes, and ≈øuch like ve≈ø≈øels, the outward parte not much poli≈øhed, but inwardly ≈øo cleane & white, with a certaine colour layde vpon them, that they far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe our pot makers, they likewi≈øe make
certaine mixture of blacke and white colour together, wherewith they paint and ≈øtripe their earthen ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øpecially tho≈øe wherein they keepe their meate: their manner of earthen worke is much plea≈øanter and better then our wodden di≈øhes, onely the women which paint their pots, haue this fault, they cannot paint one thing twice, becau≈øe they do it not by art, but onely according to their fanta≈øies. The≈øe Barbarians al≈øo haue certaine pumpeons and other fruits, which they diuide into two partes, and cutting the meate out of them, they v≈øe them for drinking cuppes, which they call Cobi, they haue al≈øo great and ≈ømall ba≈økets, made of whole Ru≈øhes, not much vnlike wheate ≈øtraw, cunningly wrought and folded togither, which they cal Panacon, wherin they keepe their meale and other things: theyr weapons are wodden Halberds, bowes and arrowes, feathered coates and caps, with arme bands and rattles by them called Mar ‚Ä¢ , whereof I haue ≈øufficiently ≈øpoken, ≈øo that at this pre≈øent it is needle≈ø≈øe to ≈øay more. Nowe then the Barbarians hou≈øe, with his hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe, and furniture, weapons, bedde, and apparrell, being ≈øufficiently de≈øcribed, I will ≈øhewe you the manner of their entertainment of ≈øtrangers: and although the Tououpinambaul
‚Ä¢ ers doo receiue their gue≈øtes in friendly ≈øort, yet their ≈øtrange manner to ≈øuch as know it not, is verie fearefull, as Lerius telleth it happened vnto him at his fir≈øt going to vi≈øite them, ≈øaying that when he came fir≈øt into one of theyr villages, all the Barbarians ranne about him, and ≈øaid vnto him, Marape derere, Marape derere, that is, what is your name, & howe are you called? one of them taking off his hat, and ≈øetting it on his head, the other hanging his girdle and ≈øword about his naked body, the third putting on his Ca≈ø≈øocke, making a great hollowing: ≈øhowting, and in that maner one going one way, the re≈øt another, with his cloathes and furniture on theyr backs, he verily thought to haue beene quit of them, and in danger of his life, which after he found to be needle≈ø≈øe, as not knowing their cu≈øtomes, doing the like at the fir≈øt to al ≈øuch as come among them, not beeing of their company: & wheÃÑ they haue taken their plea≈øure in wearing their apparrell, they giue it them again, the interpreter al≈øo told him that they were de≈øirous to knowe his name, but ≈øaid vnto him when he told them, he mu≈øt not giue theÃÑ any name in our ≈øpeech, becau≈øe they cannot pronounce it, as in ≈øteed of Ioh ‚Ä¢
they ≈øay N ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n, and becau≈øe they cannot remember ≈øuch words, he ≈øaid hee mu≈øt name him≈øelfe by ≈øome thing that is well knowne to them: and becau≈øe Lerius ≈øignifieth an oy≈øter, he called him≈øelfe Lery ou≈ø≈øou, which they wondered at, and ≈øaid Te ‚Ä¢ Mair, hey Frenchman, this is an honorable name. And ≈øuch as we neuer heard of any Frenchman, and ≈øurely Circes with all her charmes and hearbes did neuer conuert a man ≈øo lightly into an oy≈øter as then it was done, after which time Lerius ≈øpake often with them, and herein you mu≈øt note that they are ≈øo good of memorie, that when they haue once heard a name, they will not lightly forget it. Then Lerius proceedeth further to ≈øhew how he ≈øpedde among them in that his fir≈øt iourney, which is, that going furder with his interpreter, he came into a village of Barbarians called Eurami ‚Ä¢ , by the Frenchmen Go≈øet, wherin his interpreter had dwelt, where they found the Barbarians dancing & drinking of their Coauin, as hauing that day killed one of their enemies, for the which cau≈øe they helde the fea≈øt, the peeces of his bodie as then lying vppon the Boucan, howe this fearefull ≈øpectacle plea≈øed him you may wel iudge, which notwith≈øtanding was nothing at all, con≈øidering what followed, for beeing come into the hou≈øe, and according to their manner ≈øette vppon a hanging bedde, the women as their cu≈øtome is, weeping, and the good man of the hou≈øe friendly entertaining him, his interpreter being v≈øed therunto, & whollie accu≈øt ‚Ä¢ med to their drinke, without ≈øpeaking vnto Lerius, or once bidding him welcome, left him, and went to dance and drink among the Indians, and hee being wearie, and hauing eaten certaine bread and other meate that had beene ≈øet before him, laide him≈øelfe downe to re≈øt, yet by rea≈øon of the noy≈øe which the Barbarians with dauncing and drinking made about him, he was well kept from ≈øleeping, ≈øpecially when one of the wilde men came running vnto him, with a broyled ≈øhinne bone of a man in his hand, a≈øking him if he would eate with him, iudge then I pray you if feare made not ≈øleep to auoyd out of his eies, ≈øpecially (as he writeth) for that he thought (as then not vnder≈øtanding their ≈øpeech) the wild man ≈øhewed him that peece of the broyled fle≈øh, telling him that they would do the like with him, ≈øo that with feare he beganne to be ≈øu≈øpitious, that hee was betraied by his fellow, who in that ≈øort had deliuered him into the Barbarians hands, wherupon he determined if he could to get away, but being compa≈ø≈øed on all ≈øides w ‚Ä¢ h Barbarians (that meant him no hurt) hee fouude it impo≈ø≈øible, ≈øo that with the feare hee hadde receiued,
which ≈øtill increa≈øed more and more, thinking he ≈øhould likewi≈øe be ≈ølaine and eaten, hee pa≈ø≈øed ouer the whole night onely in prayers, in the morning verie early the interpreter came vnto him, that had pa≈ø≈øed al the night in drinking with the Barbarians, and ≈ø√©eing him looke ≈øo pale, and hauing a fitte of an ague then vppon him, a≈øked him if hee were ≈øicke, and whether he had ‚Ä¢ ot ≈ølept well, wherewith hee blamed the interpreter for leauing him alone among the Barbarians, h√©e not vndee≈øtanding what they ≈øaid, and becau≈øe he could not ≈øhake off his feare, he de≈øired his interpreter that hee might pre≈øently depart from thence, but hee to the contrary putting him in good comfort willed him to take courage, ≈øaying that the Barbarians meant him no hurt, and withal di≈øcouered his feare vnto them, who for his ≈øake had watched and made that ≈øport all the night long, becau≈øe they e≈øt√©emed him welcome, which the Barbarians hearing, ≈øayde that they had ≈øomewhat perceiued it, and that it greeued them that he had pa≈ø≈øed the night in ≈øo great ≈øorrow and di≈øea≈øe, and with that they all beganne to laugh, which made him ca≈øt off all feare: after that, hee and his interpreter went into another village, where as the manner is, entering into a Mau≈ø≈øacats hou≈øe (which in euery village they mu≈øt do, and go to no place el≈øe, if they wil haue their loue and fauor) he ≈øate down vpon a hanging cotten bed, and for a little time ≈øitting ≈øtill, pre≈øently the women went vnto him, and ≈øitting downe vppon their h√©eles clo≈øe to the grounde, couering their faces with their hands, bad him welcome, weeping and vttering many words in his commendation‚ñ™ as ≈øaying, you haue taken a great and dangerous voyage in hand, onely to come and vi≈øite vs, you are good, you are ≈øtrong, and if it be a Frenchman, they adde further, you haue brought vs many fine things that we neuer ≈øaw: and to conclude, with ≈øuch counterfeit teares and plea≈øing words they receiue and ≈øalute their gue≈øts, & theÃÑ ≈øtranger ≈øitting vppon the cotten bedde, mu≈øt do the like, holding his hande before his face, which (≈øome good fooles) prouoked by their teares, haue not let to doo, and hee mu≈øt likewi≈øe aun≈øwere them, and ≈øigh as though hee were gr√©eued.

This fooli≈øh entertainement of the women beeing ended, the Mau≈ø≈øacat or good man of the hou≈øe, who all that time is bu≈øie making of his arrowes, and neuer regardeth his gue≈øt, as though hee hadde nothing to doo with him, (which is a verie ≈øtrange manner in re≈øpect of ours) at the la≈øt ≈øteppeth vnto the gue≈øt, and ≈øpeaketh vnto him ≈øaying, Ere Ioube? that is, are you come? how looke you? what is your de≈øire? and what ≈øeeke you? as Lerius hath perticularly de≈øcribed: then he a≈øketh if he hath a ≈øtomake to eate, if hee ≈øay or make ≈øignes that h√©e is hungrie, then pre≈øently hee cau≈øeth all kinde of victualles to bee ≈øette before him, as meale, which is their bread, ro≈øted fle≈øh of certaine bea≈øtes, birds, and fi≈øhes, and ≈øuch like meat, which is brought in earthen di≈øhes, and becau≈øe they haue neither Tables nor Stooles, they ≈øette it on the grounde, and drinke, and if they haue any Caouin in the hou≈øe, they giue it him. In the end when the women haue wept ≈øufficiently, bidding the gue≈øt welcome, they come vnto him, bringing certaine fruites, a≈ø ‚Ä¢ ing, or couertly de≈øiring of him in re≈øpect thereof, either looking gla≈ø≈øes, Combes, or gla≈ø≈øe beades‚ñ™ which they weare about their armes, and if hee meaneth to ≈øtay all night, the Mau≈ølacat commaundeth the women to hang him vp a cleane bedde, about the which he cau≈øeth ≈ømall fires to be made, which oftentimes by night hee cau≈øeth to be blowed with a certaine paire of bellowes, (by them called Tatapecoua) which are made of two rounde beddes, not much vnlike the fannes wherwith the Gentlewomen in our countrie do k√©epe them≈øelues from the heate of the fire, which fiers are not made becau≈øe of the coldne≈ø≈øe of the countrey, but to driue away the moy≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the night, as al≈øo becau≈øe it is a cu≈øtome with them ≈øo to doo: and ≈øeeing wee are nowe in hand with fire, I thinke it not vnconuenient to ≈øay ≈øome thing thereof, they call the fire Tata, and the Smoke Tatatin, and when they trauaile either to the wars, to hunting or to fi≈øhing, they alwayes haue fire with them, becau≈øe of the Aygnan or Diuell, who continually tormenteth them, therewith to driue him away, which they kindle not with Flint ≈øtone and a peece of St√©ele as wee v≈øe to doo, but rubbe twoo p√©eces of woodde one again≈øt the other, one peece b√©eing ≈øoft, the other, harde, which is done in this maner: they take a p√©ece of harde wood of a foote long, which they make ≈øharpe at one ende almo≈øt like a pricke, which poynte they thru≈øt it into the ≈øoft wood, and turne it ≈øo often with theyr handes, as if they would bore the peece of wood therewith, and by that meanes it not onely ≈ømoketh, but taketh fire, which done, they take cotten or dried leaues, and therewith kindle their fire.

The gue≈øt being in this ≈øort entertained,
and layd in a cleane cotten bedde, if he b√©e liberall he giueth the men kniues or ≈øheeres to clip and pull out their haires, to the women combes or looking gla≈ø≈øes, and to the children fi≈øh hookes, and if he chance to haue neede of victuals by the way, agreeing with them for their meat, hee may take it al with him, and becau≈øe in tho≈øe countries there are no kindes of bea≈øtes to carrie men or their wares, they are forced to trauell on foote, if they be wearie, and that the Indians let them haue ≈øome of their maids, they pre≈øently as being verie willing and ready to ≈øerue take vp the burthen, & often times carrie the man him≈øelfe, and if he ≈øpeaketh vnto them to re≈øt them≈øelues, they an≈øwere him ≈øaying, thinke you vs to be as weake and faint as married women, that we ≈øhuld faint vnder our burthen? rather you then ≈øhuld think ≈øo, we would carrie you a whole day long: they are likewi≈øe touching natural loue, better giuen & affected then wee, for that daily they giue each other fle≈øh, fi≈øh, and fruits, & it greeueth them that their neighbour ≈øhoulde not haue as much as they, which liberalitie al≈øo they v≈øe to ≈øtrangers, which in this one example by Lerius him≈øelfe t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d and ≈øet downe, may ≈øufficiently be proued, which is, that as Lerius with twoo other Frenchmen, trauailed through the woods, and was in danger of his life by a fearefull Ea≈øt, as al≈øo that vnadui≈øedly hee and his companions had pa≈ø≈øed hard by the borders of the Margaraters, enemies to their friends the Tououpinambaultiers ‚ñ™ (by whom if they had beene taken, they had bin eaten, and which is more, ≈øticking their bodies vpon thornes, would haue made them p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e in that manner, for the ≈øpace of twoo dayes without meate or drinke) at the la≈øt they came into a village called Pauo, where by the Barbarians they were mo≈øt friendly welcommed, who vnder≈øtanding the great danger they had e≈øcaped, not only from the bea≈øt‚ñ™ but al≈øo of the Marga ‚Ä¢ aters, that v≈øe to ≈øtick their bodies vpon thornes, as I ≈øaide before, did with ≈øuch pittie and compa≈ø≈øion bewaile theyr ha≈ø≈øard, that it might a≈ø≈øuredly be ≈øayde, that tho≈øe ≈øimple Barbarians did not counterfeit, but rather wi≈øhed them all good: and fir≈øt with faire water (according to their maner) they wa≈øhed their f√©et, each of them ≈øitting by him≈øelfe in a cleane bedd: that done, the good man of the hou≈øe that had made ready their meate, ≈øet fre≈øh meale ‚Ä¢ eating like our white bread crums) broyled fle≈øh, fi≈øh, and foules, with all ≈øorts of their be≈øt fruits, making them good cheere, and when night came, he cau≈øed all the children to be conuayed out of the roume where they ≈ølept, that they might not be di≈øea≈øed, and in the morning betimes hee came vnto them, ≈øaying in theyr ≈øpeech, Agite autoura≈ø≈øap, that is, my good friendes haue you re≈øted wel this night, and they an≈øwered, I very well: he ≈øtill as yet (≈øayth hee) for I know that ye≈øterday you had a weary iourney. To conclude, it cannot be expre≈ø≈øed with what friendline≈ø≈øe they were entertained by the Barbarians, wherein you may perceiue that although the wilde men are cruell and reuengatiue again≈øt their enemies, yet they are no le≈ø≈øe louing to their friendes and fau ‚Ä¢ urers.

div.head: Of the healing of the Barbarians di≈øea≈øes, of theyr burialles, with the ≈øorrow and mourning they make ouer them that are dead.
div.p:
