IF any of them bee ≈øicke, hee ≈øheweth in what place hee is pained, cau≈øing it to be ≈øearched by ≈øome one that ≈øtandeth by, or el≈øe by the trauellers about the countrey, which are their cu≈øening Pages, that is, Phi≈øitions, and are another ≈øort of people then the Caribes, who doo likewi≈øe affirme that they can ea≈øe men of their pains, and lengthen their liues: Tho≈øe people are much ≈øubiect to feuers and other kindes of di≈øea≈øes, but not ≈øo common as with vs: be≈øides this, there raigneth among them a certaine incurable di≈øea≈øe, called P ‚Ä¢ au ‚Ä¢ , proceeding from their lecherie, although many of their children are troubled therewith, as yong children with vs are ≈øicke of the ≈ømall por, it maketh bli≈øters greater theÃÑ the ioynt of a mans thumbe, which runne ouer al the bodie and face, and is no le≈ø≈øe ≈øhame vnto them, then the French poxe vnto vs, they giue the ≈øicke per≈øon no meate vnle≈ø≈øe he de≈øire it, although he ≈øhuld die for hunger, and although the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe bee daungerous, yet tho≈øe that are in health ≈øpare not to dance, leape, and drinke, thereby troubling the ≈øicke man, whereof hee neuer complaineth or once di≈øliketh, although it be much greefe vnto him: but if hee dieth, ≈øpecially being a hou≈økeeper, they pre≈øently change thou ≈øinging into weeping and mourning, with ≈øuch a noy≈øe, that all the whole night they neuer cea≈øe, ≈øpecially the women that crie out, not like men, but like wolues and dogs, & with ≈øtammering voyces, vtter the≈øe or ≈øuch like complaints, ≈øaying, Alax the ≈øtrong ma ‚Ä¢ is dead, that v≈øed to bring vs ≈øo many men to eate, others crying, O what a lu≈øtie hunter, and how cunning a fi≈øher man was hee, O
what a ≈øtrong and valiant man was h√©e in de≈øtroying our ennemies the Marga ‚Ä¢ aters and Portingales and in that ≈øort lamenting and crying, they imbrace each other, neuer cea≈øing till the body be carried to the graue, adding many times, he is now gone whom we bewaile, the man Eheu is dead, whome we ≈øhall ≈øee no more before we goe behinde the hilles, there to daunce with him, as our prophets the Caribes teach vs, with many other wordes, which continue for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, for they k√©epe not their dead bodies any longer vnburied, and then they ≈øet the dead body in a round pit or graue, in forme like a winde pipe, wherein he ≈øtandeth vpright: but if the dead man be a hou≈øe keeper, he is lapped in his cotten bed, and ≈øo buried in the middle of his hou≈øe, with fethers & ≈øuch like things put into his graue, as if he were liuing in the ≈øame maner, that the Perunians bury their kings with their iewelles about them, as it ≈øhall be ≈øhewed. The next night after the dead body is buried, they ≈øet certaine di≈øhes of meale, fle≈øh, fi≈øh, and other victualles by the graue, becau≈øe they are of opinion, that the A ‚Ä¢ gnan, or the Diuell would come and digge the body out of the graue, if hee founde not other meate to eate, and withall they ≈øet ≈øome of their Coa ‚Ä¢ in, which they do as long as they thinke the body is not corrupted, from the which opinion they can by no meanes bee per≈øwaded, although in the mornings they finde the meate whole, and in the ≈øame ≈øort it was when they ≈øet it there. This toy, or fooli≈øh deui≈øe ≈øeemes to ≈øpring out of the fal≈øe glo≈øes of certaine Rabines, but he that de≈øireth to ≈øee more hereof, let him reade Lerius: and becau≈øe the Americans do often change their dwelling places, by whole villages together, therefore when they remooue they couer their graues with a great herb called Pindo, whereby ≈øuch as trauell may ea≈øily know where men are buried, by the which places, when≈øoeuer they pa≈ø≈øe, they make a mo≈øt fearefull noy≈øe.
Thus much touching the generall cu≈øtome of all the Bra≈øilians, and now we wil proc√©ede with the de≈øcription of the re≈øt of the coa≈øt from Cabo Frio, to the ≈øtraites of Magellanes.

div.head: Heere followeth the de≈øcription of the ≈øea coa≈øts.
div.p:
FROM Cabo Frio to Punta de Buen Abrigo (in our Carde called Abitrioga) are a hundred miles: Beyond this point reacheth Tropicus Capricornus, and the line of repartition, which beareth the name afore≈øaide, from Buen Abrigo, to the Bay of S. Michael are 50. miles, and fro thence to the riuer of S. Francis, which lieth vnder ≈øixe and twenty degrees are ≈øeuentie miles: from S. Francis to the riuer of Tibiq ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e are a hundred miles, wherein lieth Puerto de Patos, which is vnder eight and twenty degr√©es: and right again≈øt it an I≈øland called S. Catherina, Puerto de Fara ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢
and others: and from Tibiquire, to Rio de la Plata are more than fiftie miles, ≈øo that from Cabo de S. Augu≈øtin, to Rio de la Plata, that is, the ≈øiluer riuer are ≈øixe hundred and three≈øcore miles, which lieth vnder thirty fiue degrees on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line. This riuer by the Barbarians is called the riuer of Parana, or Paranagna ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , that is to ≈øay, great riuer, or a riuer like the ≈øea, hauing certayne entries that are very broade, & many I≈ølands, it is rich of ≈øiluer, pearles, precious ≈øtones, and fi≈øh: it is in breadth xx. miles, and many I≈ølands between both the hookes of S. M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ia ‚Ä¢
and Cabo B ‚Ä¢ anco. This riuer increa≈øeth and flowe≈øh ouer like the riuer Nilus, making the country fruitful at certaine times of the yeere, and as ≈øome are of opinion, it ≈øpringeth out of the hilles in the kingdome of Peru, into this riuer there runneth many other great riuers, as Auanca, Vicas, Purina, and X ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ xa, which ≈øpring out of the high land called Bombon, many of the Spaniardes that dwell vppon this riuer, haue come vp as high as to Peru, and the mines of Poto≈øi. The whole coa≈øt from Cabo Frio, to the Rio de Plata, or rio Solis, is inhabited by goodly men and well proportioned, but all eaters of mens fle≈øh. The country is ful of bra≈øil wood, and of white Anime. From Rio de Plata to Puerto de S. Elena, are thr√©e≈øcore miles, from S. Elena to Arenas Gordas are thirtie miles, from thence to Baros Anagedos forty miles, from thence to Terra Baixa fiftie miles, from terra Baixa to Bahya S ‚Ä¢ n F ‚Ä¢ ndo thr√©e≈øcore and fiue miles: and from this Bay which is vnder one and fortie degrees, to the Arrecifes de Lobos are fortie miles. Vpon this bordereth the country of ye Patagones, where the inhabitaunts paint theyr faces with certaine herbs: froÃÑ Lobos which is vnder fortie foure degrees, to Cabo d ‚Ä¢ S. Dominico, are fiue and fortie miles: from this cape to another called cabo Blanco are twenty miles to the riuer of Iohn Serrano, which lieth vnder nine and fortie degr√©es, and by others called Rio de Traba ‚Ä¢ os are three≈øcore miles, betw√©ene them lieth Ba ‚Ä¢ a de S. Iulian, wherein is a good hauen. The people being wilde, and without weapons, couered with ≈økins, and without any lawe,
but of a great ≈øtature: from thence to the Promontorium or cape de las 11000. Virgins are foure≈øcore miles: from Cabo de las 11000. Virgins which lieth vnder one and fiftie degrees and a halfe, to the entry of the ≈øtraits of Magellanas, which vnder the ≈øame degrees from ea≈øt to we≈øt are accounted 110 miles, ≈øome ≈øay 130. miles, and the ≈øouth and north part from Venezula twelue hundred miles, it is two miles broad, in ≈øome places more, and very deepe, and rather increa≈øeth than dimini≈øheth, and runneth ≈øouthward. In this ≈øtrait are many I≈ølands and hauens. The coa≈øt on both ≈øides verye high, and full of great rockes: the countrie vnfruitful, it hath no greene land, but is very colde, as hauing ≈ønowe the mo≈øt part of the yeare: about it groweth many trees, whereof are diuers cedars, and other tr√©es, bearing fruit like Bi≈ønole or Creken. There they find E≈øtriges, and other greater birds, with many ≈øtrange bea≈øts: al≈øo in that ≈øtrait are many ≈øardines, & flying fi≈øhes, they eate of all kindes of meates: there are likewi≈øe many ≈øeawolues, wherewith they line or furre their clothes, and whale fi≈øhes, the bones whereof they v≈øe to make ≈øhippes, as al≈øo of the barkes of trees. This ≈øtrait was di≈øcouered by Fernando Magellanus a Portingale,1521 in the y√©ere of our Lorde, one thou≈øand fiue hundred twenty and one, and as ≈øome ≈øaye, one thou≈øand fiue hundred and ninet√©ene,1519 entring vpon the one and twentie day of October, and i≈ø≈øuing againe in the moneth of December after, when as then the dayes were there at the longe≈øt, and the nights ≈øhorte≈øt. Touching this ≈øtrait you may reade at large in the hi≈øtories of India, and the nauigations of the Engli≈øhmeÃÑ that al≈øo haue pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øame. The K. of Spaine in the yeare of our Lorde one thou≈øand fiue hundred eightie and two, commaunded a Ca≈øtle to be made vppon the point, or fir≈øt entry into tho≈øe ≈øtraits on the ≈øouth ≈øide towards Peru, from whence mo≈øt part of his trea≈øure commeth, thereby to impeach other Nations to enter or pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øame: about this ≈øtrait dwelleth certayne great giantes of tenne or eleuen foote high, and higher (as ≈øome men write.)

div.head: Magellanica, the ≈øixt part of the worlde.
div.p: MAgellanica is the ≈øixt part of the world which as yet is lea≈øt knowne, but with out al doubt very great, and ≈øtretcheth farre and wide: the prouince in that countrey lying right again≈øt the ≈øtrait of Magellana is called Terra de Fuego. Beach another prouince lying in that part of the worlde, is e≈øteemed to be rich of golde: the furthe≈øt I≈ølands thereof are Iaua minor, or little Iaua, diuided into eight Kingdomes, bringing foorth many kindes of ≈øpices, as yet vnknowen to vs. Iaua maior, Timor, from whence is brought white and redde ≈øanders wood. Banda, from whence nutmegges and mace are brought: the I≈ølands of Moluco, wherin groweth cloues: Los Romeros, and the I≈ølands Salomonis. But hereof I wil leaue to ≈øpeake vntil a more conuenient time, and wil proceede with our de≈øcription to Peru, beginning from Panama, right again≈øt Nombre de Dios, and ≈øo containing our de≈øcription in the briefe≈øt maner to Cabo Deleado, or the de≈øired Cape, lying in the ≈øtraites of Magellana: but before I beginne, I wil fir≈øt make a briefe de≈øcription of Peru in generall.

Peru is a common word, and ≈øignifieth thr√©e things: fir≈øt, a poore ≈ømall countrey and hauen of the Spaniards, di≈øcouered by Pizzarro, and Almagio, lying about Panama vnder two degr√©es, on the north ≈øide of the line: ≈øecondly, by this worde is vnder≈øtoode the whole countrey beginning at that hauen, and following along the coa≈øt within the ≈øouth ≈øeas, til you come to Chile, containing eight prouinces, as Quito, Cagnare≈øia, Porto veio de S. Iacomo, Ca≈ø≈øamalca, Cu≈øcoa, Cagna≈øia, Calloa, and Charca≈øsia. Thirdly, this word Peru or Peruuia ≈øignifieth the ≈øixt parte of the worlde, namely, that which is diuided ≈øouthwarde from America, which is al≈øo ≈øeperated from New Spaine, by a ≈øtraight or narrow p√©ece of ground, not aboue ≈øeuent√©ene miles in breadth, making that Peru (which otherwi≈øe is wholy coÃÑpa≈ø≈øed about with the ≈øea) is not an I≈øland, for that on the ≈øouth ≈øide it hath the ≈øea called the South Sea, whereby men pa≈ø≈øe through the ≈øtraits of Magelana: on the we≈øt part lieth the ≈øtrait it ≈øelf, which diuideth Peru from the land that lieth ouer again≈øt it, as yet not fully di≈øcouered, and by ≈øome called Terra di Fuegos, that is, the land of Fire. This ≈øtrait or narrowe pa≈ø≈øage, was found out by Magellanus, in the yeere of our lord one thou≈øand fiue hundred and nineteene, and as ≈øome ≈øay, in the yeere of our Lord one thou≈øand fiue hundred and twenty one, and reacheth right ea≈øt & wea≈øt 110. miles, and lieth vnder 52. degrees and thirty minutes, being in the greate≈øt part but two miles broad: the ≈øhore on both ≈øides being full of high ≈øtone rockes. In this part of the worlde are fiue principall great prouinces, as Ca≈øtilia del Or ‚Ä¢ , or the Golden Ca≈øtle, Popaiana, Bra≈øilia, Chile, and
Peru, and is diuided from new Spaine, by the prouince of Dariene. Beginning from thence, and reaching to the ≈øtraites of Magellana, you mu≈øt then vnder≈øtand Peru to be a whole ≈øixt part of the world, which reacheth wide and broade to aboue ≈øixty foure degrees and thirtie minutes, namely on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the line to fiftie two degr√©es, and one halfe, and on the north ≈øide twelue degrees to Saint Martha. which is the furthe≈øt part of the country northward: in the furthe≈øt length this part hath fiftie three degrees, accounting from the meridian. Pa≈ø≈øing the Cape Saint Augu≈øtine which lyeth vnder 8. degrees, and thirtie minutes, ≈øouthward to the Meridian, and the head of ≈øaint Francis lieth vpon the poynt of two parts ≈øouthward. The whole ≈øixt parte of the world is in forme almo≈øt like a Hart, or a Triangle, ≈øtanding three equall di≈øtances or lines, being drawne from the three corners or points of the land. The fir≈øt from the Cape Saint Augu≈øtine, to the ≈øtraites of Magellana. The ≈øecond from Magellana to ≈øaint Martha: and the third, from ≈øaint Ma ‚Ä¢ tha again vnto ≈øaint Augu≈øtine, which in this ≈øort may be de≈øcribed, for that placing the one corner of the triangle, being Cape ≈øaint Augu≈øtine, vnder eight degrees and thirtie minutes ≈øouthward, and the length thr√©e hundred forty and one degr√©es, the other corner of the triangle being the ≈øtrait of Magellana vnder fifty two degrees and thirtie minutes ≈øouthward, and the length 303. degr√©es. The line that is betweene the≈øe two heades mu≈øt haue ≈øixtie degrees, as the Meridian three hundred ≈øixtie hath, ≈øo much then, or ≈øomewhat more hath the line that runneth from Magellana to Saint Marcha, which lieth vnder twelue degrees, and in length two hundred ninetie foure degrees: therefore this land hath almo≈øt the forme of a triangle: others ≈øay, it is formed like an egge, which on both ≈øides runneth ≈øharpe downewards, and is broad in the middle, whereof (the better to know it) I will fir≈øt beginne with Peru, and the cour≈øe the Portingales helde from Panama to Peru. In tune pa≈øt by the name of Peru men vnder≈øtoode all the prouinces that lie thereabouts, from Pa≈øtoa vnto Chile, and from the riuer Maul ‚Ä¢
north and ≈øouth, vnto the riuer Ancha≈ømay. Nowe the Spaniards by the word Peru mean the land that lieth between the riuer Argiropilis, or Villa de la P ‚Ä¢ atta, & the prouince Quito, which is a fruitful, ≈øound, populous, and wel inhabited countrey, being in length from north to ≈øouth ≈øeuen hundred miles, and in bredth from ea≈øt to wea≈øt about a hundred miles, ≈øo that the borders ea≈øt and ≈øouth are Argiropolis, towards the we≈øt ≈øea and towards the north the prouince Pa≈øtoa.

This land is diuided into three partes, that is, Planitiem, Sierras, and Andes, that is, an euen flat land lying on the Sea ≈øide, with hilles, or hilly countrey, which pa≈ø≈øe through the middle of Peru lying ea≈øtward ouer the hilles. This land is rich with gold and ≈øiluer, more than any country in al the world, which well appeareth by the yeerely quantitie of golde and ≈øiluer brought from thence, re≈øpecting not the boa≈øtings & brags v≈øed by the Perunians them≈øelues, that ≈øay, The ≈øummes y√©erely brought out of that countrey is nothing in re≈øpect of the quantitie therein, for that it may be e≈øteemed as much as if a man hauing a ≈øack ful of corne, ≈øhould take a few graines out of it: it may likewi≈øe be iudged by the hi≈øtory of Franci≈øco Xere≈øio, who writeth, that in Cu≈øco there were hou≈øes, hauing the gates, walls, and roofe couered with plates of golde. Be≈øides this, Giraua writeth that the inhabitantes of Anzerma hadde their weapons, brea≈øtplates, necke peeces, and peeces for their ≈øhinnes, all of ma≈ø≈øy gold: he likewi≈øe writeth, that about Quito there were gold hilles, that yeeld more gold then earth, the like do all Hi≈øtoriographers witne≈ø≈øe, that write of king Atabalidas ran≈øome, which was ≈øo great, that the like was neuer heard of, for that he cau≈øed the chamber (wherein he was kept pri≈øoner) beeing of twoo and twentie foot long, and ≈øeuenteene foot broad, to be filled ≈øo full of gold, that hee ≈øtanding vpright therein, and ≈øtretching his armes and fingers aboue his head as high as hee could reach, the gold couered them, offering that if they would haue ≈øiluer and leaue the gold, he would fill the Chamber twice full, but the Spaniards tooke the gold, whereof the kings duty being a fift part, amounted to ≈øixe hundred and ≈øeuenteene thou≈øand, ≈øix hundred fortie ≈øeuen Carolus gyldernes, & 30000. marks of ≈øiluer, euery hor≈øeman had 12000. ca≈øtilians, euerie Ca≈øtillian of fourteene rialles be≈øides ≈øiluer, and euerie footeman 1450. ca≈øtillians, be≈øides ≈øiluer, being 180. markes, ≈øo that to conclude, the golde onely ammounted vnto (in Flemi≈øh money) the ≈øumme of three millions, eighty eight thou≈øand; two hundred & fiue carolus gylderns, be≈øides the ≈øiluer, wherby may be knowne the great aboundance of gold and ≈øiluer that is in tho≈øe countries: and although Atabalida payed ≈øo great a trea≈øour for his ran≈øome, yet was it not comparable vnto ye which his elder brother promi≈øed to pay, ≈øo that he might ≈øaue his life, for that he

We reade likewi≈øe, that when the Spaniards fir≈øt entred that country, they ≈øhooed their hor≈øes with ≈øhooes of golde, and what it yeeldeth yeerly at this pre≈øent doth ≈øufficiently appeare by the Armada that came from thence into Spaine the la≈øt yeere, whiche needeth not heerein to bee declared.

But now proceeding to the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt of Panama to Peru, you mu≈øt fir≈øt vnder≈øtand that Panama and Nombre de Dios are two townes, lying one right ouer again≈øt the other, the one on the north ≈øea, or north ≈øide of Peru, the other on the ≈øouth ≈øea ≈øeuenteene miles di≈øtant one from the other, Panama lying in a little valley, ≈øo neere vnto the ≈øea, that when the moone is in the full, the ≈øea entereth into the hou≈øes lying neere≈øt to the ≈øhore: the hou≈øes thereof are part of reeds, and partly made of other ≈øub≈øtances mixed together, mo≈øt couered with tiles, but there are not many hou≈øes in the towne. There is in this towne a very fitte and ≈øafe hauen, but very ≈ømall, where with the ≈øtreame or floud, the ≈øhippes doe enter, and with an ebbe, they go out, but not heauy laden, for that ≈øuch as are deepe laden, would be in danger to fall vpon the flattes: in this hauen there runneth both a great floud and ebbe, ≈øo that where the water is very deepe, within an houre after it will bee drie ≈øand, whereby the ≈øhippes mu≈øt keepe ≈øomewhat from the land, di≈øcharging and lading their ≈øhippes by little ≈øcutes, as well ≈øuch as come out of Spaine thither, as that goe from thence into Spaine. This Towne hath from Peru, maiz, meale, hennes, and hony: it hath of it ≈øelfe, kine, and hogges, oranges, lemons, coleworts, onions, lettuce, melons, and ≈øuch like things in great abundance.

This prouince of Panama, in time pa≈øt was much inhabited, and haunted by the Indians, and al the riuers yeelded gold, but now by the Spaniards are mo≈øt fi≈øhed drie. When men will trauel by land from Panama to Nombre de Dios, the fir≈øt dayes iorney is faire and good way, the next day you enter into woods, which continue till you come to Nombre de Dios. In the middle of this way you come vnto a water, which in three houres can hardly be pa≈ø≈øed ouer, becau≈øe of the many crookings & windings thereof, and many are ca≈øt away therein, the ≈øtreame (≈øpecially in winter when there falleth much raine) running mo≈øt ≈øwiftly. Such as compare this towne to Venice, are much deceiued, for that both of them put together, with many other townes erected by the Spaniardes in tho≈øe countries, wil not make the compa≈ø≈øe or greatne≈ø≈øe of the Cittie of Venice, although euery man may iudge as plea≈øeth him. As touching the maner of ≈øayling from Panama to Peru, as al≈øo at what times of the yeare, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that the be≈øt and fitte≈øt times of the yeere are in the three fir≈øt moneths, that is, Ianuary, February, and March, vntill the moneth of Aprill, for as then the Sea is open, ≈øummer comming on, and many of the Bri≈øen (which are ea≈øt and northwea≈øt windes doe blowe, no wea≈øt or ≈øoutherly windes as then ≈øtirring, whereby the ≈øhips do ea≈øily performe their voyages, and commonly ariue at their de≈øired hauens, before any other winde, ≈øpecially ≈øouth winde, which for the mo≈øt part of the yeare vpon the coa≈øt of Peru) doe blowe. They may likewi≈øe put out in the moneths of Augu≈øt, and September, but make not ≈øo good ariuage, as in the moneths afore≈øaide, and if any ≈øhips do put out of Panama, at other times than in the moneths afore≈øaide, they are ≈øure to haue a long and tedious voyage, and commonly ≈øom one of them is forced to turne backe againe, not being able to gette the coa≈øt, and are (by rea≈øon of the ≈øouthern winds, which for the mo≈øt part of the whole yeere blow vpon the coa≈øt (as I ≈øaid before) as likewi≈øe becau≈øe of the great contrarie ≈øtreame) many of them are brought into great danger. It is very good with the wind blowing from Peru, to ≈øayle to Panama. Nicaragua, and other quarters thereabouts: but to ≈øayle to Peru from Panama it is very dangerous, and vncertayne. The ≈øhips that are laden with Spani≈øh wares, and depart from Panama ‚ñ™ fir≈øt come to
‚Ä¢ aboga, and the Ilands bordering on the ≈øame (which haue receiued their names from the Pearles) where they take in fre≈øh water, in tho≈øe I≈ølands that are at the lea≈øt fiue and twentie or thirtie together.

The Spaniardes in times pa≈øt founde many Pearles, whereof they helde the name of I≈ølas de Pa ‚Ä¢ las.) They lie hardly vnder eight degr√©es northward. The greate≈øt of them in times pa≈øt, was woont to be inhabited: but not now, becau≈øe the fi≈øhing for pearles beginneth to decay, and ≈øuch as are owners of tho≈øe I≈ølandes there: in keepe ≈ølaues of Nicaragua, and Cubag ‚Ä¢ a, that looke to their bea≈øtes, and ≈øowe the ground, as being very fruitfull: from thence they put into the ≈øea we≈øtward, & then ≈øee ye
poynt called Carrachine, which lieth northwe≈øt and ≈øouthe≈øt from the great I≈øland of pearles called Taboga, di≈øtant about thirty Italian miles, which are ≈øeuen Spani≈øh miles and a halfe: as they come n√©ere vnto this cape, they ≈øhall perceiue it to be a high hilly land, lying vnder ≈øeuen degrees and a halfe, from this poynt to the Rio de Pinas, or Pine tr√©e hauen) the coa≈øt runneth ≈øouth we≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by ≈øouth, and is di≈øtaunt from the poynt afore≈øaide foure and twenty miles, which are ≈øix Spani≈øh miles or ≈øixe degrees and a halfe: it is a high land with great hilles and dales: on the ≈øea ≈øide there groweth very great pine trees, and therefore it is called the Hauen of Pine trees: from thence the coa≈øt lieth ≈øouthward and ≈øouth and bywe≈øt, to Cape de las Correntas, that is, the cape of Streames, which is very ≈ømall, and reacheth into the ≈øea, and becau≈øe of the great and ≈øtiffe ≈øtreame that runneth like a ≈øtrong fall of waters, running ea≈øtward like riuers, many times the Portingale ≈øhips which ≈øaile that way, are forced to anker in the night, and in the morning ≈øetting ≈øaile, it happeneth oftentimes, that when they thinke to winde, that they are ≈øtayed, and driuen backe agayne, & ≈øo hang ≈øomtimes 15. or 20. dayes about that Cape before they can pa≈ø≈øe it: but pa≈ø≈øing forward beyond that Cape, you come to the I≈øland lying before the Rio de Palmas, ≈øo called becau≈øe of the aboundaunce of palme or Indian nut tr√©es that do growe thereon. This riuer is in compas ≈øomwhat more than fiue miles, which is one Dutch mile, and a mile and ‚Ä¢ Spani≈øh, which was once inhabited: it is di≈øtant from Cabo de Correntes, ≈øeuentie fiue miles, or foure degrees ‚Ä¢ .

Thereabouts are many riuers, all very good water, and not farre from thence lyeth the land and riuer of Peru, where Piza
‚Ä¢ us arriued, and after his name almo≈øt all the country is called Peru: from the Iland de las P ‚Ä¢ linas folowing along the coa≈øt and the ≈øame cour≈øe, you come to the ≈øtrand of Bonauentura, which is di≈øtant from the I≈øland afore≈øaide ≈øomewhat more than nine miles, which are two Spanni≈øh miles ¬º. Hard by this ≈øtrand (which is very great) lieth a high cliffe or rocke of ≈øtone, and the entry of the Bay is vnder three degr√©es 1/ ‚Ä¢ . All this ≈øide is full of very great hilles, and there runneth into the ≈øea many and verie great riuers that haue their ≈øprings out of the hilles, by one of tho≈øe the ≈øhippes enter into the land or ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n of Bonauentura, but the ‚Ä¢ ilots that pu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h there, ought to haue good knowledge of the riuer, for that if they be not wel acquainted with it, they are like to indu ‚Ä¢ e much danger, as it happeneth vnto many ≈øhippes, that had Pilots to whom the riuer is not knowne: from this Bay the coa≈øt runneth ea≈øt, and ea≈øt and by ≈øouth to the I≈øland Gorgona, which is di≈øtant from the ≈øtrande ≈øeauenty fiue miles, which are ninet√©ene Spani≈øh miles: the coa≈øt al along this cour≈øe, is very lowe, full of trees, and other wilde places and hilles, from whence there runneth many great riuers, whereof the chiefe and greate≈øt is the riuer of Saint Iohn, which is inhabited by Barbarians, hauing builded their hou≈øes vppon great po≈øtes and ≈øtoopes, in manner of houelles, where many dwell in one hou≈øe, (and ≈øome alone by them≈øelues) becau≈øe the hou≈øes are very long and broade. The≈øe Indians are rich of gold, and their country is very fruitfull, the riuers by force of the ≈øtreames abounding with much gold, but it is ≈øo ≈øleeke and moori≈øh that it can hardely bee gotten, but with the lo≈ø≈øe of many people, and with great labour.

This I≈øland of Gorgona is vnmea≈øurable high, wherein for the ≈øpace of eight moneths y√©erely it neuer cea≈øeth raining, and thundering, whereby it ≈øeemeth the Elements fight and ≈øtriue one again≈øt the other, it is in circuite about two miles, or ≈øixe Italian miles, all high hilles, vpon the the trees whereof are ≈øeene many peacocks, phe≈øants, ≈øpeckled cats, great ≈øerpents, many ≈øea crabbes, and night foules, ≈øeeming as if it were not inhabited, it hath likewi≈øe much fre≈øh water. Summer there beginneth at the end of Maie, cleane contrary to Panama, whereas then winter beginneth. In this Iland Franci≈øcus Pizarius with 13 others that had di≈øcouered the countrey of Peru, ≈øtayed certayne days, induring great paine and hunger, before they coulde ouercome the countrey. This country of Gorgona lieth vnder three degrees: and as touching the miles that in this di≈øcour≈øe, as al≈øo in the de≈øcription of Bra≈øilia, and other places I haue ob≈øerued, they are all Spani≈øh miles, whereof ≈øeuenteene 1/ ‚Ä¢ make a degr√©e: from this Iland the coa≈øt runneth we≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt, to the Iland del Gal ‚Ä¢ o, or of the Cocke, all this coa≈øt being lowe and full of vallies, from whence there runneth many riuers: this Iland is ≈ømall, and in compas ≈øcar≈øe a mile, or about three Italian miles, it hath certayne redde Downes. The ≈øame coa≈øt from the firme land thither lyeth twoo degrees from the Equinoctiall: from thence the coa≈øt tourneth ≈øouthwe≈øtward till you pa≈ø≈øe the point called Mangla ‚Ä¢ es, which are trees ≈øo called, and in our Card Manglalos ‚ñ™
which lieth ≈øcarce vnder two degr√©es: and from the I≈øland to the poynt which is ≈øixe Spani≈øh miles, little more or le≈ø≈øe, or foure and twenty Italian miles: the coa≈øt is low and ful of vallies, and thereabouts runneth certaine riuers into the ≈øea, which inwards to the land are inhabited: from thence the coa≈øt runneth ≈øouthwe≈øt to the ≈øtrand called S. Iacob, or S. Iago, and maketh a greate Creeke, where there is an open hauen or roade named by the Sardinians: and from thence runneth the great riuer of S. Iacob, where the gouernement of Pizarro began: and this ≈øtrand is 9. miles ¬º from the point of Manglares, and it happeneth many times that the ≈øhips haue there at the beake head foure≈øcore fadomes water, and at the ≈øterne they touch the ground: and al≈øo it is often found, that ≈øometimes they ≈øayle in two fadomes water, and pre≈øently they find ninetie fadomes, which the ≈øtrong cour≈øe and fury of the riuer cau≈øeth: and although there are ≈øuch banks, yet are they not dangerous, neither do the ≈øhippes refu≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe in and out when they will. The ≈øtrand of S. Mathew, in our Carde Mathias, lyeth full in one degree: from thence the coa≈øt runneth we≈øt to the Cape ≈øaint Francis, which lieth from the ≈øtrand thirtie Italian miles, that is, ≈øeuen Spani≈øh miles and one halfe: this poynt lieth on high ground, and hard by it are certayne red and white Downes, that are of the ≈øame height. This poynt of ≈øaint Francis lyeth vnder one degr√©e, on the north ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line. From thence the coa≈øt runneth ≈øouthwea≈øt, to the poynt Pa≈ø≈øao, which is the fir≈øt hauen of Peru, ouer the which pa≈ø≈øeth the Equinoctiall line. Betweene the≈øe two poynts there runneth foure great riuers into the Sea, which are called Liquixinus, in Latine Qui≈øinuae, and there about there is an indifferent good Hauen, where the ≈øhips finde good water and wood to burne. From the poynt Pa≈ø≈øao, to the firme land are diuers high hilles, that are called De Quaque: the poynt is a land which is not ouer lowe, where you ≈ø√©e certayne Downes as afore≈øaide.

div.head: ¬∂Here followeth the Nauigation from the Line to the Towne of the Kings called Lyma.
div.p:
FRom hence forwarde wee haue declared the coa≈øt of Panama, in the South ≈øea, til you come to the hauen of Quixinus, which lieth in the Countrey of Peru, now I will goe forward with the cour≈øe that lieth betweene Quixinus and the towne of Kings, ≈øo then departing from the poynt de Pa≈ø≈øos the coa≈øt ≈øtretcheth ≈øouth, and ≈øouth and by wea≈øt, to the hauen called Porto veio, or the Old Hauen: and before you come thither, there lieth the ≈øtrand called Charaqui, wher the ≈øhips may put in without any daunger, and it is ≈øo ≈øafe a ≈øtrand that they may there lay their ≈øhips on ≈øhoare, and mend them if they neede, be they neuer ≈øo great, for it is a good hauen of entraunce, onely that in the midle of the entry there lieth certain ≈øtones or rugged I≈ølands, but the ≈øhippes may enter at which ≈øide they wil and pa≈ø≈øe by them without any danger, for there is nothing to be ≈øhunned, but onely that which you ≈ø√©e before your eyes, the Olde Hauen lieth vnder one degr√©e on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line, and is one of the fiue Townes which the chri≈øtians or Spaniardes haue built in the flat land of Peru, ≈øo that Porto Veio ≈øignifieth the towne and countrey lying thereabouts, which is much ouerrunne & wa≈øted, becau≈øe it is a poore vnwhole≈øome country, yet it hath certain mines of Sinaragdes, which they held long time hidden, and by no meanes would di≈øcouer them, as to this day they yet do. They had likewi≈øe in times pa≈øt many golde and ≈øiluer ve≈ø≈øels which are by the Spaniardes all taken and carried away, but now by the kings letters patents being made fr√©e, they pay to theyr ≈øuperiour lords, but onely the tenth parte of all their fruits, whereby many Spaniards withdrawe them≈øelues from thence, ≈ø√©eing their profite to decay. The Countrey about Porto Veio was rich of golde, where the people made their hou≈øes in the tr√©es, like birdes ne≈øts, and becau≈øe the coa≈øt is moori≈øh, there is no being for hor≈øes, whereby it was not ≈øo ≈øoone ≈øubdued by the Spaniardes, as al≈øo becau≈øe that out of theyr ne≈øts, they threw ≈øtones, iauelines, pottes with hot water, and what≈øoeuer came next to hand, whereby they killed many Spaniards, wherewith they were forced to couer them≈øelues with boordes, and ≈øo cut downe the trees, before they could ouercome them, as al≈øo becau≈øe the Countrey is ≈øo rough, ≈øharpe, and wilde, that they could hardely finde proui≈øion for their army: there is yet much country thereabouts vnhabited. By the Old Hauen two miles within the land is the towne of ≈øaint Iacob, or Iago, which for hou≈øes and inhabitants is not inferiour to Porto Ve ‚Ä¢ o: and thereabouts is the pa≈ø≈øage of Gainacaua, by the Spaniards ≈øo called for this occa≈øion, that Ga ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ acaua the father of Attabalida vpon a certain time ≈øent one of his Captain ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th a great army to ≈øubdue that countrey, who minding to pa≈ø≈øe
his people ouer the riuer, commanded them to make a bridge of p√©eces of wood, that ≈øo they might pa≈ø≈øe. Which being made, when his people with their armor and weapons were vppon it, the ennemy cutte the ropes, wherewith the p√©eces of wood were fa≈øtned together, whereby many of them that were vpon it, by force of the ≈øtreame were drowned in the riuer, and the re≈øt ≈øpoyled by the enemy. Which Gainacapa vnder≈øtanding, a≈ø≈øembled a great number of ≈øouldiers, and with them departed from Quito, and being in the plaine field, in open battell he ouercame tho≈øe people: after the which victorie, minding to make a pa≈ø≈øage ouer the riuer, that men might pa≈ø≈øe ouer on foote, to the ≈øame end he cau≈ø ‚Ä¢ great numbers of ≈øtones and earth to be brought thither, and threw them into the riuer, being twentie foote broad, but what≈øoeuer he threw in, al wold not preuaile, by rea≈øon of the great deapth, and ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe of the riuer, that carried it away by force of the ≈øtreame, which hee perceiuing, left off his worke and ≈øo departed, and therfore the Spaniards haue giuen this place the name of the pa≈ø≈øage of Gainacaua: about the which pa≈ø≈øage lieth the towne of ≈øaint Iacob builded by them. About a Spani≈øh mile and a half di≈øtant from this town of ≈øaint Iacob, towardes the ≈øouth lyeth a round hil, by them called Chri≈øts Hil. From Porto ve ‚Ä¢ o further forward the ≈øame cour≈øe almo≈øt foure miles di≈øtant in the ≈øouth, lieth the poynt of ≈øaint Laurence, and two miles, and a quarter from thence ≈øouthwe≈øt lieth an I≈øland of the ≈øame name, which is full a mile in compa≈ø≈øe, wherein the Indians or Peruuians of the firme land, in times pa≈øt v≈øed to make their ≈øacrifices and offerings, killing many lambes, ≈øh√©epe, and ≈øome children, offering their blood vnto their idolles, or diuelles, who≈øe figures were made and carued in ≈øtone, to whome they doe v≈øually pray.

When Franci≈øcus Pizarius with his thirteene companions trauelled to di≈øcouer Peru, they entred likewi≈øe into this I≈øland, where they found certaine iewells of ≈øiluer and golde, many cloakes and ≈øhertes of very faire and fine wooll, ≈øo that from that time forwards, and for the ≈øame cau≈øe this I≈øland was called Siluer. The poynt of ≈øaint Laurence lieth vnder one degr√©e, on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the line. And (as I ≈øayde before) Peru beginneth at the line, and ≈øtretcheth ≈øouthwarde vnto Chile. The people that dwell vnder the line and thereabouts, haue the cu≈øtomes and manners of the Iewes. Whereby many men are of opinion, that they are i≈ø≈øued from the Iews, or of the race of Cham: they ≈øpeake hoar≈øely, and in the mouth, like the Moores, and are much giuen to vncleanne≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially that which is wholy again≈øt nature, whereby they do not well agree with their wiues, but rather de≈øpi≈øe them. where the ≈øhippes put in, by it there is a great riuer and a very good water: all this coa≈øt is without hilles, and (as I ≈øaide before ≈øandy and chalkie vallies. This hauen of Porto Santa lyeth vnder nine degrees: and further ≈øouthward about foure miles di≈øtant lieth another hauen called Ferrol ‚ñ™ a very good and ≈øure hauen, but hath neyther fre≈øh water, nor wood to burne: and about foure miles and a halfe further there lyeth a hauen called Ca≈øina where there is a Riuer of fre≈øh water, and much woodde to burne, where the ≈øhippes doe ordinarilye refre≈øh them≈øelues, it lyeth vnder tenne degrees: From Ca≈øma the coa≈øt runneth ≈øouth to the cliffes called Los Farollones di Guaura: A little further lieth Guarmey, wherein runneth a riuer: and from thence you ≈øayle the ≈øame cour≈øe to the Barranca, or Downes, which is fifteene miles towardes the ≈øouth: and foure miles and one halfe further lieth the hauen of Guaura, where the ≈øhippes may take in as much ≈øalt as they will, for there is ≈øo much that all Spaine and Italie might be furni≈øhed with ≈øalt from thence, and yet they woulde haue ≈øufficient for the country: three miles further lie the Cliffes or Farrollones: From this poynt which ‚Ä¢ utteth out of the land with the ≈øame northea≈øt and ≈øouthwea≈øt cour≈øe, you ≈øaile ≈øixe miles further, to the furthe≈øt cliffe that lyeth into the ≈øea. The≈øe Cliffes lie vnder eight degr√©es and one halfe: from thence the coa≈øt turneth againe ≈øouthea≈øt, till you come to the I≈øland of Lyma, in the middle way, and ≈øomewhat more towards Lyma lieth a rocke which is called Salmarina, and is vnder ≈øeuen or ≈øeuen degr√©es and a halfe. This land maketh a barre of defence before Callao, which is the hauen of the Towne of Kings, or of Lyma, and by this defence from the I≈øland the hauen is very ≈øafe, for the ≈øhippes to harbour in: Callao lieth vnder twelue degrees and a halfe.

div.head: The way by land from Truxillo to Lima.
div.p:
THe towne of Truxillo lyeth di≈øtant from Lima ≈øixtie ≈øpani≈øh miles, which is 48. duch miles, or 240. Italian miles, all the which way is ≈øandie, vnle≈ø≈øe it be when you pa≈ø≈øe certaine vallies. Now when you ≈øet out of Truxillo, you come fir≈øt to the valie of Gu ‚Ä¢ nape, which is full fiue Spani≈øh miles from thence, that is, 21. Italian miles, which in times pa≈øt was wel known becau≈øe of the good drinke called Cica, that was made ther, no le≈ø≈øe then in Italy, Mente, Fra≈øcon, and in Spaine, S. Martin, are e≈øteemed for the good wines that are there to be ≈øolde, and this vallie is inhabited and watered as the re≈øt are, it hath a verie good hauen, where the ≈øhippes take in all theyr proui≈øion: from thence you come to a little valley, where no riuer runneth through, but it hath a ≈ømall water, where tho≈øe of Peru and other trauailers v≈øe to drinke: and going further, you come to the vallie of Santa, which in time pa≈øt was verie populous, and had in it many braue ≈øouldiours, and captaines for commanders, which held ≈øtoutly again≈øt the Kings of Peru, ≈øo that they were forced to ouercome them more by pollicie then force: they were likewi≈øe much e≈øteemed of by their kings, that cau≈øed many hou≈øes & pallaces to be built therin, as being one of the greate≈øt and bigge≈øt vallies in tho≈øe countries, and through it there runneth a verie ≈øtrong and great riuer, which is verie full and high when it is winter in the hilles, wherein al≈øo were manie Spaniards drownde. Nowe they haue a drift to ≈øet ouer their pa≈ø≈øengers, therein in time pa≈øt there dwelt many thou≈øand people, nowe there are not aboue 400. left. They go apparrelled both men and women with certain maÃÑtles and ≈øhirts, with bands or rolles about their heades: all kindes of fruites both of that countrey, and ≈øuch as are brought out of Spaine, do grow therein in great aboundance. There likewi≈øe they take much fi≈øh: the ≈øhippes that ≈øaile along the coa≈øt, do there take in fre≈øh water and other proui≈øions: two daies iourney from thence, lieth another vallie called Guambac ‚Ä¢ o, for fruitfulnes & other things like vnto the re≈øt, & about a daies iourney and a halfe further lyeth the valley of Guarmey, wherin are many bea≈øts, cowes, hogs, and hor≈øes, from thence you go to Parmongo, no le≈ø≈øe plea≈øant then the former: in it are yet ≈øeene certaine faire ca≈øtles, built after theyr manner, wherein vpon the walles are painted the Images of certaine bea≈øtes and birdes: and it is to be wondered at howe they make the water runne out of the riuer ≈øo farre into the land, whereby it moy≈øtneth all the countrey: a mile and a halfe from the vallie, lieth the riuer Guaman, which in our ≈øpeech ≈øignifieth the riuer of the fields, and is by them called Barranca, which vallie is like all the re≈øt, and when it raineth much in the hilles, this riuer is verie dangerous. A dayes iourney from thence lyeth the vallie of Guaura, from the which you go to Lima, the vallie wherin it lyeth is the greate≈øt and broade≈øt of all that are betweene it
and Tumbez, and as it is greate≈øt, ≈øo was it verie populous, wherof at this time there are few left: for when the towne began to be inhabited, the inhabitants of the towne tooke the countrey and land from tho≈øe that dwelt in the vallie, who after that were likewi≈øe de≈øtroyed and cleane rooted out‚ñ™ This towne next vnto Cu≈øco, is the greate≈øt in all the countrey of Peru and the principall, for that at this pre≈øent the Viceroyes of Peru, the Archbi≈øhop, the Councell, and the Chancerie, wherein all proce≈ø≈øes are ≈øued, and the lawes of the whole countrie admini≈øtred, are re≈øident therein, whereby there is great traffike and concour≈øe vnto Lyma, becau≈øe many people come thither out of the townes lying about it. In this towne are faire hou≈øes, ≈øome built with Towers and co≈øtly galleries: the Market place is great, and the ≈øtreetes broade, and entring into the market place, from whence al≈øo you may goe into euerie place of the towne, and to the fieldes, and into mo≈øt of the hou≈øes there runneth certain channels, that conuay water, a great commoditie and plea≈øure vnto the towne≈ømen, wherewith they may water all their gardens and orchards, which are there verie faire and plea≈øant: vpon the riuer likewi≈øe are many water milles, made after the manner of our countrey, wherewith they grinde theyr corne, to conclude, therein dwelleth manie rich inhabitants, ≈øome worth 150000. duckets: and from this towne oftentimes there ≈øaileth ≈øhippes that are worth in value at the lea≈øt 800000. duckets, and ≈øome a Million: on the ea≈øt ≈øide a little aboue the town, lyeth a high hill, whereon there ≈øtandeth a Cru ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fix: on another ≈øide of the towne, the town≈ømen haue certaine places where they keepe their cattell, their douehou≈øes, vineyards, (but no good grapes becau≈øe of the grounde) gardens of plea≈øure, not onely full of all tho≈øe countrie fruits, but al≈øo of Spani≈øh fruites, as figges, poundgarnats, lemons, oranges, melons, beanes, pea≈øe, and ≈øugar canes, all verie good and ≈øauorie, and better then in Spaine, and to ≈øay the truth, to pa≈ø≈øe a mans life in quietne≈ø≈øe (were it not for the reporte that runneth of the Spaniards, that they make warre again≈øt tho≈øe people without a cau≈øe) I thinke it the be≈øt and mo≈øt plea≈øant place in all the world, the aire being ≈øo temperate, that all the yeare long there is no extremitie either of heate or cold, and it was neuer heard that euer they had famine, plague, or any raine, thunder, or lightning, but to the contrarie, alwayes a cleare and faire ≈økie: it was builded by the Admirall Don Franci≈øco Pizarro, in the yeare of our Lord 1535. 1535. and was called „Äà‚óä„Äâ Kings towne, becau≈øe they arriued therein vpon twelfe day, by vs ≈øo called. Touching victualles, be≈øides fi≈øh, which they haue both out of the ≈øea and the Riuer‚ñ™ in great aboundance, as al≈øo fle≈øh and fruits of trees, and of the earth, as I ≈øaide before: they haue no le≈ø≈øe quantitie of wheate: and the foure moneths of ≈øummer in Spaine, are winter with them, onely ≈øomewhat colder then the ≈øummer: in tho≈øe ≈øoure moneths of winter, there falleth euerie day in the forenoone, a ≈ømall dew or mi≈øt, but not vnhol≈øome, as with vs, for that tho≈øe that haue any paine in their heades, wa≈øhing their heades therewith, it healeth the ach: it is verie likelie that this towne of Lima will daily increa≈øe in people and hou≈øes, for many yeares together there were not aboue 500. hou≈øes therein, yet the place is great inough to containe 2000. hou≈øes, for the ≈øtreetes are verie broade, and the market as bigge as a great fielde, euerie hou≈øe is eightie foote broade, and a hundred and ≈øixtie foote long, and becau≈øe there is no conuenient woodde whereof to make chambers, for that al their wood within two or three yeares, is cleane con≈øumed by wormes, therefore the hou≈øes be but of one ≈øtorie high, yet verie co≈øtly and ≈øumptuous, with many chambers, halles, and parlers, both fitte to dwell in, and al≈øo to receiue ≈øtrangers, the walles of the hou≈øes are made of a certaine ≈øtuffe baked hard together, and filled with earth. They couer their hou≈øes with painted mattes, or el≈øe with painted linnen, and round about and aboue vppon the walles they make arbours of greene boughes, wherein they ≈øit to keepe them≈øelues from the ≈øunne, for raine they neede not care, for there it neuer raineth: this Citie hath vnder it al the≈øe townes hereafter named, where there are Bi≈øhops, as Quito, Cu≈øco, Guamanga, Arequipa‚ñ™ Pax, P ‚Ä¢ ata, Trugillo, Guanuco, Chachapo ‚Ä¢ a, Portus, Vetus, Guaiaquil, Popatan, Carchi‚ñ™ Saint Michael, and S. Francis. Before it was ≈øaide that Peru is diuided into three prouinces, in flat or plaine land, on the ≈øea coa≈øt in hillie lande, that runneth through the middle of Peru, & in other lands, lying beyonde the hilles: touching the flat lande on the ≈øea ≈øhore, I haue hitherto ≈øpoken, beginning from the line, and the Cape Pa≈ø ‚Ä¢ ao hitherto, ≈øo you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that from Tumbez, not onelie to Lima but al≈øo further ≈øouthward, the ≈øea coa≈øt is full of many great droughts, and wilde ≈øandie places, where for the ≈øpace often miles it neuer thundereth, lightneth, nor raineth, but beyonde that, or all the ≈øpace that is betweene
tho≈øe tenne miles and the hilles, it thundereth, lightneth, and raigneth. In this flatte land there are no fountaines nor welles, but foure or fiue ≈øtanding waters that are bracki≈øh, becau≈øe they are neare the ≈øea, the inhabitants v≈øe the riuer waters, that run out of the hilles, which ≈øpring of the ≈ønow and raine that falleth on the hilles, and not out of fountaines that ≈øtande among the hils. The di≈øtance of the≈øe riuers are alreadie partly de≈øcribed, lying ≈øeuen, eight, ten, twelue, fifteene, and twentie miles one from the other, yet mo≈øt part ≈øeueÃÑ or eight, wherby ≈øuch as trauaile direct their cour≈øe, becau≈øe they haue no other waters: on both ≈øides of the≈øe riuers about a mile broade or further, and ≈øometimes more or le≈ø≈øe, according to the ≈øcituation of the countrey, are diuers fruitfull trees, and corne landes, which are planted and ≈øowed by the people of the countrey, which they may do all the yeare long, al≈øo there groweth about tho≈øe riuers many wilde trees, cotten, reeds, thi≈øtles, and L ‚Ä¢ s, and ≈øince the Spaniards ≈øubdued the countrey, they ≈øowe wheate, moy≈øtning the lande by certaine channels, made out of the Riuers, and becau≈øe they runne with ≈øo great force out of the high hilles, that without helpe men can hardly pa≈ø≈øe them, and many are drowned: ≈øuch as trauaile in that flat countrey go ≈øo neare to the ≈øea coa≈øt, that they haue them alwayes in their ≈øight: when it is winter in the hilles, and that it raineth much, it is dangerous trauailing in tho≈øe countries, ≈øpecially to pa≈ø≈øe the riuers, which they mu≈øt either do vpon drifts which they haue for the purpo≈øe, or with a net, which they fil with canworden or goords, whereupon the trauailer mu≈øt lie, and one of the Indians ≈øwimmeth before him, drawing the net or drift, and an other behinde that ≈øteereth it. The people in the flat land dwell in hou≈øes made of boughes, the men weare ≈øhirts and cloathes vppon their knees, and ouer it they ca≈øt an vpper garment or mantle, the women weare a kinde of cotten pettiecoate, from the head to the foot, and although their manner of apparrel is in euerie place almo≈øt alike, yet they v≈øe certain differences in the attiring of their heades, ≈øome wearing nothing but plaine hairelaces, ≈øome double and wreathed, others of one colour, and ≈øome of diuers colours, and there is no man but he weareth ≈øome thing vppon his head, and all different, according to the manner of the country. Tho≈øe Peruuians of the plaine countrie are diuided into three manner of people-ech hauing a different name, wherof the fir≈øt are called Iungas, tho≈øe are ≈øuch as dwell in the hot country, the ≈øecond Tallanes, and the third Mochicas, ech hauing a ≈øeuerall ≈øpeech, only that the Lordes could ≈øpeake the Cu≈øcan ≈øpeech, as our Courtiers ≈øpeake French, the cau≈øe thereof is, that their Kinges helde it for a di≈øhonour vnto them, to ≈øpeake to their ≈øubiects by an interpreter, for the which cau≈øe Guaynacapa father to Atabaleba, commanded that all the ble men of the countrey ≈øhoulde ≈øend theyr children to his Court, vnder pretence as he ≈øaide, to ≈øerue him, to learne that ≈øpeech, although his intent was none ≈øuch, but onely thereby to a≈ø≈øure him≈øelfe of his kingdome, again≈øt ≈øuch as might ri≈øe vp again≈øt him, which they would not do, he hauing theyr children in his power, and by this ≈øame meanes al the noble men learned the ≈øpeech commonly v≈øed in the Court, wherewith a man may trauaile cleane through the countrie.

div.head: Of the windes that blow in the plain countrie of Peru, al≈øo the occa≈øion of the droughts, and of the other townes and places which lie in the further de≈øcription of the ≈øea coa≈øt.
div.p:
BEfore I returne to proc√©eding with the de≈øcription of the re≈øt of the ≈øea coa≈øts, from Lyma to Arequipa, I thinke it not vnconuenient to declare why it raineth not in the plaine countrey of Peru, lying on the ≈øea ≈øide, where neuertheles there is ≈øo great occa≈øion giuen of raine, becau≈øe the Sea, (which commonly yeeldeth moy≈øture) lyeth vpon the one ≈øide, and the hils, (whereon there is alwaies ≈øo great quantitie of water and ≈ønow) vppon the other ≈øide: you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that vppon the hils ≈øummer beginneth in Aprill, and continueth May, Iune, Iuly, Augu≈øt, and September, and in October winter beginneth, and continueth the other moneths til March, not much differing from our Countries, or froÃÑ Spain, in that time they both plant, build, and gather in their fruites and ≈øeedes: but day and night are al of a length, onely that in Nouember they differ a little, and in the plaine land it is contrary, for when it is ≈øummer in the hils, it is winter there, ≈øo that in the plaine countrie ≈øummer beginneth in October, and continueth til the moneth of Aprll, where as then winter beginneth: and ≈øurely it is a verie ≈øtrange thing to thinke how ≈øo great difference ≈øhould be in one countrey, where a man may vppon one day in the morning, trauaile from the hilles, where it raineth, and befo ‚Ä¢ e night bee in the plaine
countrie, where it neuer or verye ≈øeldome raineth, for that from the beginning of October, al the ≈øummer long, it neuer raineth in that countrey, onely there falleth certain dew, which in many places hardly layeth the du≈øt of the ≈øandes, wherefore the inhabitants of the plaine countrey mu≈øt continually water their groundes, and not till nor plant any more lande, then they can bring the water vnto: in other places by rea≈øon of the vnfruitfulne≈ø≈øe of the country, there is no gra≈ø≈øe, as beeing all drie ≈øandie and ≈øtonie grounds, the trees growing theron, are vnfruitfull, with verie few leaues, there likewi≈øe groweth diuers thi≈øtles and thornes, and in ≈øome places nothing at all: when it is winter in the plaine countrie, there are certaine thicke and clo≈øe cloudes, onely as if the aire hung full of raine, from whence there onely proceedeth a certaine ≈ømall mi≈øeling, that can hardly lay the du≈øt of the ≈øande, which notwith≈øtanding is a verie ≈øtrange and wonderfull thing, that the ayre being in that ≈øort ≈øo thicke and clo≈øe, there falleth no other moy≈øture, and yet the ≈øunne for many daies becau≈øe of the clouds, cannot be ≈øeene, and as the hilles are verie high, and the coa≈øt low, it appeareth that the hilles draw the cloudes vnto them, not ≈øuffering them to fal vpon the plaine lande, ≈øo that when the waters do naturally keepe their cour≈øe, it raineth much in the hils, and not in the plaine countrie, but therein cau≈øeth a great heat, and when the dew falleth, then it is cleare weather vpon the hils, and raines not there: likewi≈øe it is very ≈øtrange that for the mo≈øt part of the yeere ther bloweth but one kind of wind in the plain countrie, that is, ≈øouthwe≈øt windes, which although in other countries they are commonly moy≈øt, and cau≈øes of raine, there they are cleane contrarie, I thinke becau≈øe they are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by the high hilles, from whence they blow, that they draw no moy≈øture or dampene≈ø≈øe out of the ≈øea into the aire, wherby any great raine ≈øhould folow: by the≈øe windes al≈øo it happeneth that the water in the South ≈øea runneth into the North, and maketh a hard nauigation from Panama to Peru, both again≈øt winde and ≈øtreame, in ≈øuch ≈øort that it cannot be done, without lauering and ≈øtriuing again≈øt the winde.

There is yet another thing to bee marked, which is, that vnder the line in ≈øome places it is moy≈øt, and in ≈øome places colde and moy≈øt, and in tho≈øe plaine countries of Peru, colde and drie, and departing from thence to the other ≈øide, it raineth continually.

div.head: Here followeth the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt of the plaine countrey of Peru (with the hauens and riuers lying therein) between the towne of Lyma, and the prouince of Dechia, as al≈øo the degrees and the manner of the ≈øayling on that coa≈øt.
div.p:
THe Ships that ≈øaile from the towne of Lyma or of Kings, take their cour≈øe towards the ≈øouth, and ≈øo come to the hauen of Singalla, which is verie great, whereby at the fir≈øt the Spaniards were in mind to haue built the town of kings in that place, it lyeth di≈øtant from Lyma 2 ‚Ä¢ . Spani≈øh miles, or 105. Italian miles, whereof fiue make a Duch mile, which is one and twentie Duch miles, it lyeth not ful vnder fourteene degrees on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the line. Hard by the hauen of Sangalta, lyeth an I≈øland taking the name of the ≈øea Wolues: al the coa≈øt from thence forward is very low, although in ≈øome places there are ≈ømal hils of plaine ≈øtone, and ≈øome ≈øandie downes, wherein as yet, neither before, nor til this time it euer rained, where al≈øo there falleth no other moy≈øture, then onely the ≈ømal dewe, whereof I ≈øpake before: about this I≈øland of ≈øea Wolues, there are ≈øeuen or eight other I≈ølandes, which lie in Triangle, wherof ≈øome are high, ≈øome low, and all vnhabited, hauing neither water, wood, trees, gra≈ø≈øe, nor any thing, onely Sea Wolues, and great ≈øtore of ≈øande. The Peruuians of the firme land, (as they theÃÑ≈øelues ≈øay) in times pa≈øt v≈øed to goe into tho≈øe I≈ølands, and there to offer ≈øacrifices, where it is thought much trea≈øor lyeth hidden, the≈øe I≈ølands are di≈øtant from the firme land about three miles. Further in the ≈øame cour≈øe vnder 14. and 1/ ‚Ä¢ lyeth another I≈øland of the ≈øame name, and from thence ≈øailing on, and coa≈øting along the ≈øhore ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by ≈øouth, and being 9. miles beyond the I≈øland, you come to a point called Na≈øca, lying vnder fifteene degrees le≈ø≈øe ¬º vnder the which the ≈øhippes may anker, but yet they cannot land with their boates, neither throw foorth their Bocken: following the ≈øame cour≈øe vnder fifteene degrees, 1/ ‚Ä¢ there is another head or poynt called S. Nicolas, and from this cape the coa≈øt runneth ≈øouthwe≈øt, and when you haue ≈øayled nine miles in that ≈øort, you come to a hauen called Hacan, which lyeth vnder ≈øixteene degrees, from whence following on the coa≈øt, you come to the riuer Diocouna, on which ≈øide the coa≈øt is altogether wilde: A little further there is another riuer called
Camana, and ≈øomewhat further the riuer Quilca, and about halfe a mile beyonde it there is a verie good grounde where the ≈øhips may ride and anker, which hauen is al≈øo called Quilca, like the riuer: and from thence as men put out, they ≈øaile to the towne of Arequipa, which lyeth 12. miles from this towne, the hauen and the towne lying vnder ≈øeuenteene degrees ¬Ω: ≈øayling along the coa≈øt of this hauen, about three miles di≈øtant you ≈øee certaine I≈ølands, in the which certaine Indian fi≈øhermen of the firme lande doo lie to catch fi≈øh: about twoo miles further there is another I≈øland hard by the firme lande, where on the loofe ≈øide the ≈øhips may harber, it is called Chul ‚Ä¢ , from whence there are wares ≈øent to Arequipa and is from Quilca nine miles‚ñ™ it lyeth vnder ≈øeuenteene degrees and a halfe.

div.head: The way by lande from Lyma or Cidado de los Re ‚Ä¢ es to Arequipa.
div.p:
DEparting from Lyma, and following the coa≈øt about three ≈øpani≈øh miles, or twelue Italian miles you come to the vally of Pachacama, in our card Pachamma, a mo≈øt plea≈øant place, and wel known among the Peruuians, becau≈øe of the mo≈øt ≈øtatelie Temple that ≈øometimes ≈øtood therein, for riches exceeding al others in that countrey, being placed vpon a litle hil made of ≈øquare ≈øtones and earth: in the which temple were many painted doores & wals, with formes of wilde bea≈øts: in the middle therof where the idoll ≈øtood, were the prie≈øts, that ≈øhewed them≈øelues to be verie holie, and when they offered ≈øacrifice for all the people, they turned their faces towardes the gates of the temple, and their backs to the Image, ca≈øting downe their eyes, and ful of fearefull demon≈øtrations, made great ≈øtamping (as ≈øome of the old Indians ≈øay) like the maner of the ≈øacrificators of the Idoll Apollo, when the people ≈øtaied to heare the prophe≈øies. Tho≈øe old Indians likewi≈øe ≈øay that they v≈øed to offer many bea≈øtes and ≈øome men vnto this Idol, & at their cheefe fea≈øtes this Idol gaue them an≈øwere to their demaunds, and what he ≈øayd they beleeued: in this temple there was great trea≈øor of golde and ≈øiluer hidden, and the prie≈øtes were greatly e≈øteemed, the Lords of the countrey being much ≈øubiect to their commaundements: rounde about this temple were certaine hou≈øes made for Pilgrims, and no man was e≈øteemed worthie to be buried about that Church, but onely their kings, noblemen, and the prie≈øts that came thither on pilgrimage, bringing certaine offerings with them: when they helde their greate≈øt fea≈øt in al the yeare, there a≈ø≈øembled many people, that according to their manner plaied on in≈øtruments: when the kings of Ca≈øco ≈øubdued the vallie, they hauing a cu≈øtome throughout al their countries, to erect temples in the honour of the ≈øunne: and beholding the greatne≈ø≈øe and auncientnes of that temple, with the per≈øwa≈øion that the common people had of the holine≈ø≈øe of that place, as al≈øo the great deuotion v≈øed therein, they thought it not conuenient to de≈øtroy that church, but appoynted another to be made by it in honour of the ≈øunne, which ≈øhuld be e≈øteemed the greater, which according to the kings commandement being fini≈øhed, be indowed it with great gifts, ≈øending thither certaine women, wherwith the diuell of Pachacan ‚Ä¢ a was verie well plea≈øed, as it appeareth by the an≈øwere h√©e gaue vnto them, being ≈øerued as well in the one temple as in the other, and keeping the poore ≈øoules vnder his power: and now although this temple is defaced, yet hee cea≈øeth not ≈øecretly to ≈øpeake with ≈øome of the Indians, telling them that the ≈øame God which is preached by the Spaniards and hee are all one, thereby to keepe them in obedience vnto him, and not to become chri≈øtians. In ≈øteede of tho≈øe Idols, there are cro≈ø≈øes erected, as they think to plea≈øe the diuel, the name of the diuell was Creator of the world, for Camac is creator, and Pacha world: but God permitting Francis Piza
‚Ä¢ ius to take King Atabaliban pri≈øoner, he ≈øent his brother Fernando Pizarrus to de≈øtroy the temple, and to take away the trea≈øure, although the prie≈øtes before his comming had hidden part thereof, which could neuer be founde, yet a great part was carried away. This vallie is verie fruitful, rich, and ful of trees, abounding with kine and other cattel, as al≈øo good hor≈øes. From the vally Pachacama you come to Cilca, where there is a notable thing to be noted, for the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe thereof, for it neuer raineth there, neither is there any riuer, whereby they may conuay the water, therwith to water their groundes, yet the mo≈øt part of this vallie is ful of Maiz and other rootes that are good to eate, with fruitfull trees: the meanes they haue to helpe them≈øelues therein, is thus, that they make certaine deepe pits within the earth, wherein they ≈øow their Maiz and other rootes and other fruits, and by rea≈øon of the cleare and plea≈øant aire, as al≈øo the ≈ømal dew and moi≈øture that falleth, God ≈øendeth them great aboundance of Maiz and other things, but no other corne, neither would that likewi≈øe
grow therein, if they did not throw one or two heades of the fi≈øh called Sardinia into the ground with euerie eare of corne, which fi≈øh they take with nets in the ≈øea, and by that meanes it groweth in great aboundance, whereby the people maintain them≈øelues. The water that they v≈øe to drinke, they take it out of great deepe pittes, and for the better proui≈øion of their corne, they do euerie yeare fi≈øh for ≈øo many Sardines as they ≈øhal neede, both to eate, and ≈øowe theyr corne. There was likewi≈øe in that country many hou≈øes for proui≈øion and munition, belonging to the King of Peru, therein to lodge and re≈øt them≈øelues when they trauaile through their countryes. Two miles and a quarter from Ci ‚Ä¢ ca is the prouince of Mala, where there runneth a faire riuer, the coa≈øt whereof is ful of trees: and not full foure miles further lyeth Goarco, well knowne in that countrey, being great and broade, and ful of fruitful trees, ≈øpeciallie of Guuyas, a certaine Indian fruit, verie plea≈øant of ≈ømel and ta≈øte, and al≈øo Guauas, and Maiz in mo≈øt great aboundance, with al other things, as wel Indian as Spani≈øh fruites. Be≈øides this there are great numbers of Pigeons, Turtle Doues, and other kindes of foules, in the woods and wilde countrey, which make a good ≈øhadow in the vallie, vnder the which there runneth certaine ≈øtreames of fre≈øh water. The inhabitants of this country ≈øay, that in times pa≈øt that place was verie populous, and that they ruled and hadde commandement ouer ≈øome of the hils, and ouer plaine countries, and when the Ingen or Kings of Peru or Cu≈øco came to ≈øubdue them, they held wars again≈øt him for foure yeares together, minding not to loo≈øe the liberty, which their predece≈ø≈øors before them had ≈øo long maintained. During the which wars, many ≈øtrange things happened, which are herein needle≈ø≈øe to rehear≈øe, becau≈øe my meaning is not to make a Hi≈øtory, but onely to de≈øcribe the coa≈øt: and although the Kings of Peru in ≈øummer time, becau≈øe of the great heate withdrew them≈øelues into Cu≈øco, yet they had their Captaines and Souldiours that helde continuall warres, and becau≈øe they might the better bring their affaires vnto effect, the Ingen in this vally cau≈øed a newe Ca≈øco to be built, whether he and his nobilitie repaired, giuing the ≈øtreetes and other places the names of the olde Cu≈øco, & when he had ≈øubdued that people, the ≈øaide re≈øidence of the King and the towne did both decay, yet in ≈øteede thereof there remaineth a goodly Ca≈øtle, which he left in ≈øigne of victory, ≈øituate vpon a hil within a goodly vallie, the foundation beeing of foure ≈øquared ≈øtones, ≈øo cunningly clo≈øed together, that it could not be perceiued how they were ioyned: froÃÑ the which Ca≈øtle there went a va≈øt vnder the earth to the ≈øea coa≈øt, ≈øo that the waues beat again≈øt the entrie thereof with ≈øuch force, that it is wonderful to think how that p√©ece of worke was made: which Ca≈øtle was mo≈øt curiou≈øly painted, and in it al≈øo there was a great part of the kings trea≈øor, the ruines whereof in regard of the Peruuians perpetual coÃÑmendations ought not further to be ≈øpoyled, as being workes done by ≈øuch people, which vnto vs wold be altogether incredible, if they had not bin ≈øeene: a mile & a half further vpward from the ca≈øtle of Goarco there is a riuer called Lunaguana, in our Card Laguna, which vallie is altogether like the former, and foure miles and a halfe from that is the great vallie of Chincha, much e≈øteemed in Peru, ≈øpecially by the auncient inhabitants. In this vallie there is a cloy≈øter of the order of ≈øaint Dominike. At the ≈øpaniards ariual there were aboue 25000. men in that vallie, where now there are ≈øcarce 5000. and were ouercome by Inga Iupangue, & of
‚Ä¢ opaynga Iupang ‚Ä¢ e, who had their gouernours therein, with many hou≈øes of plea≈øure, and the temple of the Sun, yet the inhabitants le≈øt not off to ≈øerue and honour their olde Idol called Cinciaycama, the king hadde likewi≈øe in this vallie many pentioners and ≈øouldiers, commaunding ≈øome of them for certaine moneths in the yeare to repaire vnto the Court, and goe to warres with him. This vallie of Cincia is one of the greate≈øt vallies in all the countrey of Peru, where it is a mo≈øt plea≈øant ≈øight to beholde the greene trees that grow in the waters that run vnder them, with mo≈øt ≈øweete and plea≈øant Citrons, not like the Spani≈øh Citrons, although in forme not differing much, for that the≈øe being pilled are yellow, and of a good ta≈øte, and ≈øo plea≈øant, that a man can neuer ≈øati≈øfie him≈øelfe therewith: in tho≈øe woods there are many birds, but bea≈øts verie few, becau≈øe of the continuall warres: in times pa≈øt, there was likewi≈øe many graues in this country, wherein the Spaniards found much trea≈øor. Departing from this goodly prouince of Cincia, and trauailing further ouer the plaine countrey, you come to the plea≈øant vally I ‚Ä¢ a, which is no le≈ø≈øe inhabited then the former, through the which al≈øo there runneth a riuer, which in ≈øome times of the yeare is ≈øo ≈ømall, that they ≈øhuld want water, but that they haue a channell of water that commeth out of the hilles: heerein are many fruites, there are likewi≈øe manie
yong hor≈øes, kine, goates, pigeons, and turtle doues: from thence you come to the vallie and riuer of Na≈øca, otherwi≈øe called Caxa Malca, which in times pa≈øt was verie populous, where they till their ground, and water their fruits, in manner before rehear≈øed. The≈øe people for the mo≈øt parte were ≈øpoyled and con≈øumed by the di≈øunion and contention of the Spaniards, in it were many great places and hou≈øes of munition for the kings of Peru, and diuers graues, all ≈øpoyled and de≈øtroyed by the Spaniards: the vallies of Na≈øca are many in number, whereof one of them hath many canes that yeeld much ≈øugar: they haue likewi≈øe much ≈øugar, which they bring to ≈øel in the townes bordering vpon them: through all the≈øe vallies the kings great high way doth pa≈ø≈øe, and in ≈øome ≈øundrie places there are as yet certaine tokens or ≈øignes to ≈øhew the right way, that men ≈øhould not ≈øtray a≈øide, of the which way I meane to ≈øay more heereafter, when I come to ≈øpeake of the kings of Peru: from this vally commonly called Na≈øca you goe to Hacary, and then to Ocuna, Icamanna, and Iquilca, where there are great riuers, and although at this pre≈øent there are but few inhabitants, yet in times pa≈øt they were no le≈ø≈øe populous then the fir≈øt, they are fruitfull and very fatte to feede cattel: in the vallie of Quilca lyeth the hauen of Arequipa, and the towne, ≈øo that from Lima or the Kings towne to Arequipa are ninety Spani≈øh miles, or thr√©e hundred and ≈øixtie Italian miles: the town lyeth about eleuen miles within the vally of Quilca, di≈øtant from the ≈øea in the be≈øt and mo≈øt plea≈øant place of all the vallie to b√©e built vpon, where there is a verie good and temperate aire, whereby it is commended for one of the mo≈øt hol≈øome≈øt places in all Peru, and the plea≈øante≈øt to dwell in, being a Bi≈øhopricke, and vnder the Iuri≈ødiction of Lyma, hauing in it about thr√©e hundred Spani≈øh hou≈øes: the countrey thereabouts is verie fat, and y√©eldeth verie good Corne, whereof they make bread: the limites or Iuri≈ødiction of the towne reacheth from the vallie of Hacari, to Tarapaca, and in the prouince or countrey of Conde≈øuyo: they haue likewi≈øe authoritie ouer certaine places, which are vnder the Spani≈øh gouernment: tho≈øe of Hubnas, Ciqui Guanitta, Quimi≈øtaca, and Colagnas, are all vnder the commandement of this towne, in time pa≈øt very populous, and now mo≈øt part de≈øtroyed by the Spaniards: they pray to the ≈øun, as other Peruuians do, and weare ≈øhirts and mantles, mo≈øt of their ≈øiluer and trea≈øor is brought from Charcas, and the mynes of Potoi≈øi, and Porco, from thence it is carried to Lyma, and ≈øo to Panama and Spaine: about this towne there is a hill of Brim≈øtone, which burneth continually, whereby it putteth the countrey in great feare, doing great hurt vnto the countrey and the town: ≈øometimes by rea≈øon thereof they haue certaine earthquakes: this towne was builded by Franci≈øco Pizarro in his maie≈øties name, in the yeare of our Lord 1536. 153 ‚Ä¢
Many Spani≈øh wares (as wine, oyle, oliues, meale, corne, or wheate. &c.) are brought thither, therewith to ≈øerue the Countrey of Charcas, and the mines of Potoi≈øi & Porco. There al≈øo many of the Inhabitants of the p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne countrey do come and traff ‚Ä¢ ke, concerning the mines afore≈øaide, wherby much ≈øiluer and trea≈øor is brought thither, to be conuayed froÃÑ thence into other places: therabouts on the ≈øea coa≈øt are many great Gieren, that ≈øpread their wings at the lea≈øt fift√©ene or ≈øixteene handfulles broade, that liue vpon Sea Wolues, which they take, picking out theyr eyes, and feeding of theyr bodyes. There are likewi≈øe great numbers of Sea Mewes, by the Spaniards called Alcatraces, that likewi≈øe liue of ≈øea fi≈øh and ≈øea crabs, and ≈øuch like. Their fle≈øh is ≈øtinking and vnhol≈øome, ≈øo that many who for want of meate haue eaten them, died therof. And thus much for the fir≈øt part of the plain countrey of Peru, lying along the ≈øea coa≈øt.

Nowe before I proc√©ede further, I will ≈øpeake ≈øomewhat of the Peruuians dwelling vppon the hilles, and of their townes, withall not forgetting their kings, that ruled ouer all tho≈øe people, and haue ≈øo rich a country of gold & ≈øiluer: Peru is in length 525. Spani≈øh miles, or 420. Duch miles, which are 2100. Italian miles in breadth: in ≈øome places 75. Spani≈øh, or 60. Dutch miles, in ≈øome places broader, and in ≈øome narrower, accounting the length from Quito, to the towne Delia Platta: in this country of Peru are thr√©e ≈øorts of hilles, wherein men cannot inhabite: the fir≈øt parte of the hilles are called Andes, which are full of great Woods, the country being vnfit and vnhol≈øome to dwell in, which likewi≈øe were not inhabited, but beyonde the hilles: the ≈øecond parte of the hilles taketh her cour≈øe from the Andes, which are verie colde, and are great ≈ønow hilles, ≈øo that there al≈øo no man can dwell, becau≈øe of the great colde and aboundance of ≈ønow, which maketh the ground ≈øo ≈øoft, that nothing can grow therin. The third parte of the hilles are the Sandie Downes which runne through the plaine land of Peru, from Tumbez to Tarapaca, where it is ≈øo hot, that neither
water, tr√©es, gra≈ø≈øe‚ñ™ nor any liuing creature is ≈øeene thereon, but onely certaine birdes that flye ouer them. Nowe Peru beeing ≈øo long, and ≈øcituate in this manner, there are many wilde and de≈øart places not inhabited, for the cau≈øes before rehear≈øed, and ≈øuch as were inhabited were great vallies and dales, that by rea≈øon of the hils are throwded and defended from the windes and ≈ønow, wherby tho≈øe vallies and great fields are verie fruitful, ≈øo that what≈øoeuer is plaÃÑ ted therein, y√©eldeth fruit mo≈øt aboundantly: the woods about them bring vp manye bea≈øts and birds: the Peruuians that dwel betw√©ene the≈øe hils, are wi≈øer, ≈øtronger, and ≈øubtiller then tho≈øe in the plaine countrey lying on the ≈øea coa≈øt, and apter to gouerne and for pollicy: they dwel in hou≈øes made of ≈øtone, whereof ≈øome are couered with earth, others with ≈øtrawe, becau≈øe of the raine, whereof tho≈øe in the plaine countrey by the ≈øea ≈øide, haue no care at all, couering theyr hou≈øes, thereby to keepe them from the ≈øun, with painted mattes, or boughs of trees, out of the≈øe vallies lying betweene the hilles, there runneth many ≈øtreames of good water into the ≈øouth ≈øea, and moy≈øten the plain countrey of Peru, cau≈øing many fruitfull Trees, corne, and other things nece≈ø≈øary for mans life to grow therein, as I haue already declared.

div.head: Of the people and countries that are therein lieing from Pa≈øto to Quito.
div.p:
THe village of Pa≈øto lieth in the vallie Atris, which is in the land of Quillacinga, people without ≈øhame and good manners, as al≈øo they of Pa≈øto, little e≈øteemed by their neighbours, trauailing from Pa≈øto you come to Funez, and two miles and ¬º furder to Iles, from thence to Gualnatan are two miles and a halfe, and from thence to Ipiules two miles and a quarter, in al the≈øe villages is very little maiz by rea≈øon of the colde, although they are ≈øo neere vnto the line, but much Papas and other rootes that are to be eaten: from Ipiules you trauaile to Guaca, but before you come at it you may ≈øee the Kings hie-way, which is no le≈ø≈øe to be wondred at, then the way that Hannibal made through the Alpes, whereof hereafter I will ≈øpeak: al≈øo you pa≈ø≈øe hard by a riuer, vpon the ≈øide whereof the King of Peru had made a fort, from whence he made warre vpon tho≈øe of Pa≈øto, and ouer this Riuer there is a bridge, by nature ≈øo artificially made, that arte coulde not po≈ø≈øibly mend it, it is of a high and thick rock, in the midle whereof there is a hole, through the which, with great fury the ≈øtreame pa≈ø≈øeth, and vpon that rocke men may go ouer it, this rocke in their ≈øpeech is called Lu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch ‚Ä¢
ca, that is, a ≈øtone bridge, about that place is a fountaine of warme water, wherein a man cannot endure to holde his handes, although the countrie about it and al≈øo the riuer are verie colde, whereby it is hard trauailing: by this bridge al≈øo the King of Peru ment to haue built another ca≈øtle, therin to keepe garri≈øon, but he was preuented by the Spaniardes ariuall in tho≈øe countries: in this countrie there groweth a certaine fruit as ≈ømall as plumbs, and blacke, by them called Mortunnos, whereof if any man eateth, they are drunke and as it were out of their wittes for the ≈øpace of foure and twentie houres. From this ≈ømall countrye of Guaca you come to
‚Ä¢ u≈øa where ye prouince of Pa≈ø ‚Ä¢ o endeth: not farre from thence you come to a little hill, wherevppon al≈øo the Kings of Peru had a ca≈øtle much defended by the Peruuians, and going furder you come to the riuer of Mira, where it is very hot, an there are many kinds of fruits, and certaine faire melons, good connies, turtle doues, and partriges, & great aboundance of corne, barley and maiz: from this riuer you trauaile downe to the rich and co≈øtly hou≈øes of Carangue, & before you come thither, you mu≈øt fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øe ouer a lake in India called Aguarcocia, in our ≈øpeech the opeÃÑ ≈øea, becau≈øe Guianacapa king of Peru, at the Spaniards ariuall cau≈øed 20000. men of the places thereabout to be a≈ø≈øembled, & de≈øtroyed them all becau≈øe they had di≈øplea≈øed him, and threw their bodies into that lake, making the water red with their blood. The hou≈øes of CaraÃÑgue are in a little place, wherin there is a goodly fountaine made of co≈øtly ≈øtone, and in the ≈øame countries are many faire hou≈øes belonging to the kings of Peru, all made of ≈øtone, and al≈øo a Temple of the ≈øame, wherein there was alone 200. maides, that ≈øerued the temple, and are verie narrowly looked vnto, that they commit no vncleanes, if they did they were cruelly puni≈øhed, and hanged, or buried quicke, with them al≈øo were certaine prie≈øts yt offered ≈øacrifices and offerings, according to their religious manner. This Temple of the ≈øunne in time of the kings of Peru was holden in great account, being then very carefully looked vnto, and greatly honoured, wherein was many golde and ≈øiluer ve≈ø≈øels, iewels and trea≈øure, the walls being couered with plates of golde and ≈øiluer, and although it is cleane de≈øtroyed, yet by roums you may ≈øtill behold the great magnificence
thereof: in times pa≈øt the kings of Peru had their ordinary gari≈øon in the hou≈øes of Carangue, with their Captaines, who both in time of peace and warre, continued there to puni≈øh offenders. Departing from the hou≈øes of Carangue, you come to O ‚Ä¢ aballo, which is al≈øo rich and mightie, and from thence to Co≈øe≈øqui, and before you come thither, you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe certaine ≈ønowie hills, where it is ≈øo colde, that men trauaile ouer them with greate paine: from Co≈øe≈øqui you goe to Guallabamba, which is three miles from Quito, and becau≈øe the countrie thereabout is lowe and almo≈øt vnder the line, therefore it is there very hot, yet not ≈øo hot, that men cannot dwell therein, or that it hindereth the fruitfulnes thereof: by this di≈øcour≈øe you may perceiue the eror of many ancient writers, that ≈øay that vnder the line by rea≈øon of the great heate no man may dwell, but to the contrary you ≈øee that after their maner they haue both ≈øummer and winter, in ≈øome places colde, and in ≈øome places hot, as al≈øo that vnder it there dwelleth many people, and there many fruites and ≈øeeds do grow, In this way you pa≈ø≈øe many riuers by bridges, whereabouts are greate hou≈øes, and ≈øtrange things to be ≈øeene, and to conclude, at this pre≈øent the Spaniards by them maintaine their cattaile.

div.head: The de≈øcription of Quito.
div.p:
AMong the towns that lie in the hills of Peru, and at this time inhabited by the Spaniards, Quito is one of the chiefe≈øt, it lyeth in the valley Annaquito, about fiue miles beyonde the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctial line, in time pa≈øt it was a very faire, rich, and plea≈øant towne, ≈øpecially in the yeares of our Lorde 1544. 1544 and 1545. then it flori≈øhed, becau≈øe the gold mines (which euerie man regardeth) were fir≈øt found out, but by the warres that Pizarro made, it is almo≈øt de≈øtroyed, the earth thereabouts ≈øeemeth to be vnfruitful, yet it is found contrary, for in it are many catell, as al≈øo al other proui≈øion of corne, fruit, and foule: the ≈øituation of the countrie is very hole≈øome and plea≈øant, not much vnlike Spaine both for hearbes, and ≈øea≈øons of the yeere, for that ≈øummer beginneth there in the moneths of March and Aprill, and continueth til halfe Nouember, & although there is much cold, yet they haue no le≈ø≈øe ≈øeede then in Spaine: there is likewi≈øe much ≈øpani≈øh fruite, tho≈øe people are coÃÑmonly friendlyer, and ciuiler then tho≈øe of Pa≈øto, and of a meane ≈øtature, and go apparrelled at this time like other Peruuians.
