About Quito there v≈øed to be great numbers of ≈øheepe, yt were not much vnlike camelles, but not ≈øo great, only in forme, fit both to carry men and other burdens, but not aboue three or foure miles a day, and being wearie they lie downe, ≈øo that they can hardly be forced to ri≈øe again: there are likewi≈øe many hogs and hennes, that are bred of our countrie hens, & great abundance of connies, very ple≈øant of ta≈øte, and no le≈ø≈øe quantity of goates, partridges, pidgions, turtle doues, and ≈øuch like foule: among other things which are by the Peruuians laid vp for proui≈øioÃÑ (be≈øides maiz) one is Papas, which is rounde like a turnup, which being ≈øodden or ro≈øted are altogether like che≈ønuttes, another is a kinde of fruit called Quinua, ye truncke of the tree or ≈øprig being as high as a man, with leaues like beetes, whereon grow certaine ≈øeeds, ≈øome red, ≈øome white, wherof they make their drinke, and eate it likewi≈øe as wee do rice: the people are very ≈økilful in tilling the land but not after our manner, for there the women do it, the men ≈øpinne, weaue, & make clothes, and looke to their armes. From Quito you come to another town caled FraÃÑ ci≈øco del quito it lieth on ye north ≈øide in the lowe≈øt prouince of Peru, this town is much colder then warme, and hath but few fields about it, lieing in a ≈ømal valley like a pit, al compa≈ø≈øed with hills: from S. Franci≈øco you go to ye pallaces of Tomebamba (being about 30 miles di≈øtant) and from thence to Panzaleo: the inhabitants of this countrie differ ≈øomething from their neighbours, as touching the binding of their heades where by the Indians of all places are knowne: they had likewi≈øe another ≈øpeech differing from their neighbours, yet al of theÃÑ learned the Cu≈øcan ≈øpeech, which if the fathers did not teach their childreÃÑ they were puni≈øhed, the men weare long haire tied vp with a hairelace, they go in ≈øhirts without hands or ≈øleeues, and clo≈øe all about them, onely where they mu≈øt put forth their heads and armes, ouer the which they weare long wollen mantles, and ≈øome of cotten, the Lords wear ≈øuch as be verie fine, and painted of diuer≈øe coulours, their ≈øhooes were made of leaues, the women goe in long gownes couering all their bodies, tyed about them with a wollen bande, going many times about their bodies, and therewith make them≈øelues a long body, ouer the which they weare a fine wollen gowne pinned about their neckes with certaine golden and ≈øiluer pinnes, which they call Topos, hauing great flat heads, and very ≈øharp pointes, about their heads they tie a
faire fillet or headband, by them called Nin
‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢
: to conclude, the manner of their apparrel and al≈øo that of Cu≈øco, is the faire≈øt and be≈øt in al America. They are verie careful to combe their haire, which they weare long: they are white of face, of good complection and manners, wherein they differ much from the women of the plaine country: two miles from Pancalco lyeth Mulahallo, in times pa≈øt al≈øo verie populous, but at this pre≈øent mo≈øt con≈øumed: on the right ≈øide of this villag lyeth a hill of brim≈øtone, which wheÃÑ it bur≈øteth out, it ca≈øts forth many great ≈øtones, with feareful ≈øights: a little further lyeth I'acunga, in time pa≈øt not le≈ø≈øe then Quito, as well for hou≈øes as other things, as by the ruines may yet bee ≈øeene.

From Tacunga you come to Muliambato, and from thence to the riuer Ambato, and two miles further to Mocia, and froÃÑ thence to Rio Bamba, lying in the Prouince of Puruaes, where there are goodly fields and good hearbes and flowers, altogether like Spaine: from Rio Bamba you come to Caiambi, and then to Tumb ‚Ä¢ z, or Teocallas, and Ticiquiambi ‚ñ™ and from thence to Thomebamba, in the Prouince of Canares there were likewi≈øe great hou≈øes of ammunition, as al≈øo throughout the whole countrey, at euery eight, ten, or twelue miles, wherein was al things that belonged to the wars, and thereabouts likewi≈øe were certaine of the Kings garri≈øons and captaines, hauing commandement of the countries, thereby to hold the countrey in peace, and to puni≈øh ≈øuch as rebelled, though they were their owne ≈øons. Thomebamba lay in a plaine countrey, where twoo riuers met together, and ranne into the ≈øea, being nine miles compa≈ø≈øe, in a colde place, where notwith≈øtanding were many wilde bea≈øtes, as Goates, Conies, &c. there likewi≈øe was a Temple of the Sunne, made of browne, greene, and blacke ≈øtones, like Ia≈øper ≈øtones.

The gates of the Kings Pallace were brauely guilded, wherein were ≈øet certaine Emeraulds platted in golde. From Thomebamba you goe to Bracamoros, in our Carde Boamo ‚Ä¢ aces, founde out and di≈øcouered by Iohn Porzel, and Captaine Vergara, who therein hadde made two or three fortes, thereby to ouerrunne and ≈øubdue the places lying about it. The Prouince of Bracamoros, is about ≈øixtie miles from Quito: trauailing along the hill about fiue and fortie miles further, lyeth the Prouince of Chichapoyas, or Cachapo
‚Ä¢ as, wherein the Spaniardes haue a towne called Frontiera, on Leuanto, where the countrey is verie fruitfull of all kinde of Spices, and of rich Golde mynes: Leuanto by rea≈øon of the ≈øcituation of the place, is verie ≈øtrong, and well kept, as being almo≈øt compa≈ø≈øed about with a deepe vallie, wherein for the mo≈øt part there runneth a certaine riuer, whereby the towne of Frontier builded vppon Leuanto, is not ea≈øie to bee woonne, if the bridges be once broken downe. This prouince was built with hou≈øes, and peopled with inhabitants of the Spani≈øh nation, by Alonzo de Aluarado, in the yeare of our Lord 1536. 1536. Therin are faire and white women, fairer then in any other parte of Peru, al≈øo very gracious and courteous, and withall, verie well apparrelled. From thence you goe into another Prouince called G ‚Ä¢ ancas, a goodly countrey, both tho≈øe people of Cachapoia and Guanca, are ≈øubiect to the Spaniardes of Frontiera, as al≈øo tho≈øe of Ca≈øcayunga, people of another prouince. In all tho≈øe Prouinces the kings of Peru hadde their hou≈øes of amunition, and in ≈øome of them rich mynes of Golde. Both men and women in the≈øe countreyes go apparrelled: In time pa≈øt they hadde their Temples, and offered to theyr Idols, and were verie rich of Cattell, and made much co≈øtlie apparrell for the king, as yet at this day they doo, and many fine couerlets and carpets. In tho≈øe Prouinces there are manie fruitfull trees, and the countries are ful of Wheate and Barlie.

Touching their ceremonies, cu≈øtomes, burials, and offerings, they are like all the other Indians, they burie much ≈øiluer and golde with their dead, and ≈øome liuing women: they offer vnto the Sunne, as I will declare when I write of the Kinges of Peru. This Andes or hill beeing pa≈øt, you come to Maiobamba or Moyobamba another great riuer, and ≈øome places inhabited: From Mayobamba, you trauaile to Guanuco, a towne inhabited by Spaniardes, and lyeth about fortie miles from Cachapoya, it is likewi≈øe called Leon de Guanuco, hauing the name of a Spani≈øh Towne, by the commaundement of Vacca di Ca≈øtio, borne in Leon. The ≈øcituation of this Towne is verie good and whol≈øome, becau≈øe the morning and night ≈øea≈øons are verie temperate, where al≈øo by rea≈øon of the temperate aire men liue verie healthfull. There they gather much Maiz and other graines, Quinces, Figges, Citrons, Lemons, and other Spani≈øh fruites, as al≈øo much of their own country fruit: be≈øids this there is much Platain, & becau≈øe it is a verie
good ≈øoyle, it is thought the towne will increa≈øe, for all their kine, goates, hor≈øes, and other bea≈øts are kept in the fieldes. There are likewi≈øe many Partriges, Pigeons, and other Birds, wilde Hawkes and tame, therewith to catch the other birdes. In the hilles there are ≈øome Lions, Beares, and other wilde bea≈øts: and in mo≈øt parte of the places that are vnder the gouernment of this towne, the kings high way doth pa≈ø≈øe, and there are likewi≈øe many hou≈øes for amunitioÃÑ: among tho≈øe people were certaine ≈øouth≈øayers and coniurers, that were ≈økilful in the cour≈øe and nature of the ≈øtarres, in time pa≈øt there were ≈øo many of their countrie ≈øheepe, that it was incredible, which by meanes of the Spani≈øh warres were mo≈øt part con≈øumed. Their hou≈øes are of ≈øtone, and couered with ≈øtraw. The liuing womeÃÑ in tho≈øe countries are buried with the dead men, and are not ≈øo vncha≈øte as others are. In their countrey are good mines of ≈øiluer: Fortie miles further from Guanuco de Lion, lyeth another towne, inhabited by the Spaniards, and builded on the hils, by Franci≈øco Pizarro in the kings name, in the yeare of our Lord 1539. 1539. and called S. Iohan dila vitoria di Guamanga: the cau≈øe why it was made, was chiefly to cleare the pa≈ø≈øage betweene Cu≈øco and Lyma, from inua≈øion of the Peruuians, before the countrey was wholly ≈øubdued: by this towne there pa≈ø≈øeth a riuer of good ≈øweete water to drinke, and there are verie faire ≈øtone hou≈øes and ≈øome towers, the market place is plain and verie great, and there it is a whol≈øome aire, for that neither ≈øunne, aire, nor elements do any hurt, but are verie temperate, round about the towne the Spaniards haue their hou≈øes for cattell, which lie in the vallies vpon the riuers ≈øide. The greate≈øt riuer that pa≈ø≈øeth thereabouts is called Vinaque, where there are many ruines ≈øeene, of great foure ≈øquare pallaces, built in other ≈øort then the Peruuians v≈øe to do, that make theyr hou≈øes long and narrow. They ≈øay tho≈øe hou≈øes were built in olde time by ≈øtrange people, but what they were they knew not. There is likewi≈øe goodly wheate, whereof they make as good bread as any in Spaine, and all kindes of fruites in great aboundance: from Guamanga to Cu≈øco are fiue and fortie miles, little more or le≈ø≈øe, in this way you pa≈ø≈øe the fields of Chiupas, where the cruel battell was fought betw√©ene Vacca di Ca≈øtra, and Dondiego di Almagro, and being eight miles beyond Guamanga, lyeth Vilcas, which is ≈øayd to be in the middle of all the countreyes, that are vnder the gouernment of the Kings of Peru, for that Vilcas lyeth in the middle betw√©ene both, and is as farre from Quito as from Chile, where al≈øo were great and co≈øtly hou≈øes for the king, and a temple of the ≈øunne, from whence fiue miles further you keepe on the kings high way to Vramarca, whereabouts there is a bridge of two arches, verie cunningly made, that pa≈ø≈øeth ouer a riuer: in breadth 166. paces. The Riuer of Vilcas runneth out of the Prouince of Soras, verie fruitful and aboundant in victuals, golde and ≈øiluer mines, and of warlike people, apparrelled in wollen clothes, and wel e≈øteemed of by the kings of Peru. From thence to Andagnayla vpon the Riuer Abamcay, are ≈øeuen miles: and trauailing ≈øixe miles further, you come to another Riuer called Apurim ‚Ä¢ , there the wayes are verie badde, rough, and ≈øharp, ouer hils and ≈øtony waies, dangerous to de≈øcend, for that many hor≈øes laden with gold, do ≈øtumble and fall into the Riuer, & ≈øo are ≈øpoyled: from Apurima you come to Ma ‚Ä¢ ambo, and pa≈ø≈øing the hilles of Vilca conga, you come to Xaqui Xaguana, which is verie euen, but neither long nor broade: in this vallie were certaine goodly hou≈øes and pallaces of plea≈øure for the kings of Cu≈øco, who v≈øed to go thither to recreate them≈øelues, and is ≈øcarce 4 miles from Cu≈øco, through the which al≈øo pa≈ø≈øeth the kings high way, and otherwi ‚Ä¢ e it wold hardlie be trauelled, as hauing certain moori≈øh grouÃÑds which cro≈ø≈øe the way clo≈øe by the wals: and from thence you come to Cu≈øco, in times pa≈øt the cheefe of all Peru, and the whole countrey gouerned by the kings, made by Mango Capo, the fir≈øt king of that race, in a verie rough and ≈øharpe place, compa≈ø≈øed with hilles and betweene two ≈ømall riuers, whereof one runneth through the middle of the towne, and is inhabited on both ≈øides it hath a vallie on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, & the ≈øtreame that runneth through the towne, taketh her cour≈øe on the we≈øt ≈øide: in this vally becau≈øe it is colde, there are verie few fruitful trees, onely certaine Molles, whereof hereafter I will ≈øpeake, becau≈øe therewith they make their drinke. On the north ≈øide this towne had a Ca≈øtle vpon a hil, which for the greatne≈ø≈øe and ≈øtrength thereof, was much e≈øteemed, but now mo≈øt part de≈øtroyed, although the foundation and ≈øome towers thereof are yet to be ≈ø√©ene: it hath likewi≈øe on the ea≈øt and north ≈øide, the Prouince of Ande≈øuyo and Cincia≈øuyo, on the ≈øouth ≈øide the countreys of Callao, and Conde≈øuio, vnder the which lyeth Callao, betw√©ene Ea≈øt and South, and Conde≈øuyo betweene ≈øouth and we≈øt: a part of this Cittie was called Hauan Cu≈øco, & the other Oren Cu≈øco, places
where the Noble men, and Gentlemen, and principall of the towne dwell: on the other ≈øide the hill Carmenga, where there ≈øtoode certaine ≈ømall towers, wherein they noted the cour≈øe of the ≈øunne: in the middle where mo≈øt of the people dwell was a great place from the which there pa≈ø≈øed foorth high wayes, that went into the foure partes of the kingdome: and this towne onely was orderly and fairely built with ≈øtone hou≈øes, and richer and mightier then all the other Townes of Peru, for that vpon paine of death no man might carrie any gold out of the ≈øame: therein was the riche≈øt temple of the ≈øunne in all the world, which was called Curicanche, & in it was the high Prie≈øt, by them called Villaona, and part of this citie was inhabited by M ‚Ä¢ timaes, which are ≈øtrangers, that all were holden vnder good policie, lawes, & ceremonies of their Idols, mo≈øt wonderfull to heare: the Ca≈øtle was made of ≈øo great foure ≈øquared ≈øtones, that ten paires of oxen could hardly drawe one of them, ≈øo that it cannot be imagined howe by mans handes tho≈øe ≈øtones were brought thither, hauing neither oxen, hor≈øes, nor any other bea≈øts to draw withall. The hou≈øes at this time inhabited by the Spaniards, are mo≈øt built by people of the countrie, but are ≈øomewhat repaired and made greater: in the time of their kings this citie was diuided into foure parts, according to the foure partes of the worlde, and hadde the names from the foure prouinces that lay vpon each corner of the Cittie, and when the Kings were liuing, no man dwelling in one quarter of the Citie might remooue hou≈øhold into another, vppon great paine and puni≈øhments inflicted: and although this Citie lyeth in a colde place, yet it is very hol≈øome and better prouided of all ≈øortes of victuals, and greater then any other thorowout all Peru: round about it there v≈øed to be certaine mines of gold, but now con≈øumed, and are left for the ≈øiluer mines of Poto≈øi, becau≈øe now the profit is greater by ≈øiluer, and le≈ø≈øe danger. In this towne was great re≈øort from the parts of Peru, for till the nobilitie were forced to ≈øend their children thither vnder pretence of learning the ≈øpeech, and to ≈øerue the king, but were there rather for pannes, that in the meane time their fathers might not ri≈øe vp again≈øt the kings: other people dwelling about it, were forced to come thither to build hou≈øes, to make cleane the Ca≈øtles, and to doo other kindes of workes, what≈øoeuer they ≈øhould be commaunded: about this Cittie there lyeth a great hil, called Guanacaure, of great account with the kings, wher they offered both men and bea≈øts: and although in this Citie there were people of all nations, as of Chile, Pa≈øto, Cagna ‚Ä¢ es, B ‚Ä¢ acamo ‚Ä¢ o, Chacapoyas, Guancas, Charcas, Collao, &c. yet euerie nation dwelt in a place by them≈øelues, appoynted for the purpo≈øe, and helde the ceremonies of their auncetors, onely that they were forced to pray vnto and honour the ≈øun, as the high God, by them called Mocia. There were likewi≈øe in this Cittie many great buildings vnder the earth, wherein there dwelt certain coniurers, ≈øouth≈øayers, and ≈øuch as told fortunes, who as yet are not all rooted out, and in tho≈øe holes there is daily found great quantities of trea≈øor. About the Citie are many temperate vallyes, wherein there groweth certaine trees and corn, although in times pa≈øt euerie thing was brought thither in great aboundance. Vpon the riuer that runneth through the towne they haue their corne milles: nowe they haue likewi≈øe many Spani≈øh capons and hens, as good as any are in Spaine, as al≈øo kine, goates, and other cattell: & although there are but fewe trees, yet there groweth much pea≈øe, beanes, tares, fitches, and ≈øuch like, becau≈øe therin was the mo≈øt rich and ≈øumptuous temple of the ≈øunne and high prie≈øt. I think it not vnconuenient to ≈øpeak ≈øomething of their Religion, and of the Pettigree of the Kings of Peru, and then in br√©efe manner to go on with our cour≈øe, of ≈øhewing the ‚Ä¢ ownes lying on hilles, til you come to Arequipa, as al≈øo the coa≈øt reaching to the ≈øtraights of the Magellanes.

div.head: The Religion of the Peruuians.
div.p:
TOuching their Religion, they acknowledge, and after their manner wor≈øhipped a creator of heauen and earth, whome they caled Pachacama, which ≈øignifieth creator, & a ≈øon of the Sun & Moone, like that in the vallie of Pachacama, where they had made a great temple, yet they accounted and held the Sun for the greate≈øt God, as a creator of all liuing creatures, which in Cu≈øcan ≈øpeech they caled Ticebiracoce, and although they had this knowledge and vnder≈øtanding, yet they v≈øed their olde cu≈øtomes, not onely to pray vnto the Sunne and Moone, but al≈øo to tr√©es, ≈øtones, and other things, the diuell through them giuing them an≈øweres, and becau≈øe they had no certaine knowledge out of any writings or bookes of the ≈øcriptures, or of the creation of the worlde, neither yet of the floud, therefore they ob≈øerue that which their forefathers told them, which was that
a notable and worthy man (which they call Con) in times pa≈øt came out of the north, into their countries, with mo≈øt ≈øwift pa≈øe, that had no bones nor ioynts in his body, neyther was it knit together by any kinde of ≈øub≈øtance, that in one day could throwe downe, or rai≈øe hilles, and fill deep vallies, and pa≈ø≈øe through a place where no wayes nor meanes to pa≈ø≈øe was found, and that this man had made their predece≈ø≈øors, giuing them hearbs and wilde fruits to liue vpon, and that he being offended with the Peruuians inhabiting the plaine countrey, conuerted their fruitfull land into ≈øandie grounds, and cau≈øed raine not to fall therein, yet being moued with pittie, becau≈øe of the bea≈øts, and to water the drie fieldes hee opened diuers fountaines and riuers, whereby the people might moi≈øten theyr groundes. This Con being ≈øonne of the Sunne and Moone, in times pa≈øt they honoured for the highe≈øt God, vntill an other came out of the ≈øouth called Pachacama, (which ≈øignifieth Creator) who al≈øo was ingendered by the Sunne and Moone, and of greater power than Con, at who≈øe comming Con departed away: and this Pachacama conuerted the people made by Con into Sea coltes, Beares, Lions, Parats, and other birdes, and made other men that were the predece≈ø≈øors of the Peruuians now liuing, and taught them the manner of planting and tilling the earth, whome they after that e≈øteemed for their God, building Churches for him, and praying vnto him, and called a whole Prouince after his name Pachacama, lying foure miles from Lyma, as already is declared, where in times pa≈øt the Kings and noblemen of the land were commonly buried: which theyr god Pachacama was long time wor≈øhipped by them, til the comming of the Spaniardes into Peru, and after that he was neuer ≈ø√©ene. Againe‚ñ™ it is to be thought it was a Diuell, who v≈øed that manner of ≈øubtiltie, thereby to deceiue and blinde the people, who in tho≈øe times appeared in forme of a man, as it is euident, that before the Spaniards arriuall, he ≈øhewd him≈øelfe in that great co≈øtly temple, in forme of a man, and an≈øwered the Prie≈øts, which an≈øwere the Prie≈øtes deliuered vnto the poople. They do generally beleeue and tell, that once there was a great floud, whereby all the worlde was drowned, onely a few per≈øons, that hidde them≈øelues in certayne high hollow tr√©es, and hauing prouided victualles, ≈øtopping the holes, by that meanes ≈øaued them≈øelues from the common mi≈øery of al mankind: and that when th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe men thought the raine and waters to be gone, they ≈øent out two dogges, who returning all wet backe againe, they ge≈ø≈øed the water not to be con≈øumed, and ≈øo thought it not time to goe foorth. After that they ≈øent the two dogges forth againe, and perceiuing them to come home all dirtie, they then knew the water to be gone, and came foorth, where they found great numbers of ≈ønakes, which the ≈ølime earth had bred, whereby they hadde worke enough to kill and de≈øtroy them. They likewi≈øe ≈øay that the world ≈øhalbe de≈øtroyed, but not before there ≈øhal fir≈øt come a great drought, and in manner a burning of the ayre, whereby the ≈øunne and moone ≈øhal be darkened and taken away, wherefore when there happeneth any Eclip≈øes or darkene≈ø≈øes of the ≈øunne or moone, but ≈øpecially of the ≈øunne, then they ≈øing ≈øorrowfull ≈øongs, and make great mournings, thinking the world ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed, and that the end approcheth. What are the≈øe but cloudes of their religion? which the diuel in ≈øo great blindne≈ø≈øe could neuer driue out of the≈øe poore peoples hearts, ≈øo that tho≈øe of Bra≈øilia beleeue the immortallitie of the ≈øoule, and the Peruuians beleeue not onely the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, but the re≈øurrection of the body, as it appeereth not onely by the manner of their graues, but al≈øo by the reque≈øt made by them vnto the Spaniardes, (when they opened their predece≈ø≈øors and Kings graues, to take out the trea≈øure) de≈øiring them not to take away or ≈øcatter the bones of the dead, that they might not want them at their re≈øurrection. Touching the manner of their graues, their Kings and Nobilitie are buried with great magnificence, being ≈øet in ≈øeats within their graues, apparelled with their be≈øt cloths, one or two of their liuing wiues buryed with them, being the faire≈øt, and ≈øuch as in his life time hee loued be≈øt, for the which when time ≈øerueth, great controuer≈øie ri≈øeth among the women (which by the king in his life time is ordained and appoynted) they bury likewi≈øe with him two or thr√©e of his ≈øeruauntes, and much golde and ≈øiluer, and the be≈øt they had, al≈øo fruit, bread, maiz, and ≈øuch like things: and which is more, the la≈øt ≈øeruice the friendes doe for him, is, that with reedes or pipes they powre a certaine mea≈øure of theyr drinke called Cicha into the dead mannes mouth, to this ende, that hee may not want drincke before hee commeth into the other worlde: in which his iourny he v≈øeth that meate, and the company of his wiues and ≈øeruantes, which manner is v≈øed almo≈øt
through all Peru and Mexico, onely that euery one dooth more or le≈ø≈øe according to his e≈øtate: but they v≈øe mo≈øt in Peru to burye liuing women, which mi≈øchiefe ≈øprang from the diuell that blinded them, that at ≈øome time appeared vnto them in ≈øhape of tho≈øe that were dead, walking vpon the earth, and women with him. So great is the power and blindene≈ø≈øe of Sathan in the children of the vnbeleeuing. In Ea≈øt India the diuell ≈øo wrought, that hee got them to burne liuing women with the dead, & here in Peru hath per≈øwaded them to bury liuing women with dead bodies. They mourne many dayes for theyr dead, and vppon the graue they place the Image of the dead per≈øon. The common people and handiecrafte≈ømen place ≈øomething of their handiecraft vpon their graues, and the ≈øouldier ≈øome kinde of weapon v≈øed in the warres, whereby it may be ≈øeene who lyeth buried in that place.

So then the Peruuians pray vnto the Sunne and the Moone, and acknowledge them for the highe≈øt gods, and ≈øweare by them, as al≈øo by the earth, which they e≈øteeme to be their mother: and if at anie time they ≈øpeake with the diuell, a≈øking coun≈øell, and attending an≈øwere of him, they did it more for feare they hadde to bee hurt by him, than for any wor≈øhippe: that they held and accounted the Sunne for the chiefe and highe≈øt God, fir≈øt it appeereth by many and ≈øo co≈øtly temples, by them erected, throughout al the kingdom of Peru, as al≈øo by the an≈øwere of king Atabalida, made to the Dominican Friar Vincentius de Valle Viridi (after fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Peru) who ≈øhewing him of the creation of the world by God, and the redemption thereof by the death of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, he an≈øwered him, that no man made the world, but onely the Sunne his god, that died not as Chri≈øt did, and ≈øaid, that he might bel√©eue in the crucified and dead Chri≈øt, if it plea≈øed him, but for his part, he would beleeue in his owne god, and his Guacas which dieth not: this Guacas were certaine ≈øtones, that with weeping they honoured and called vpon.

div.head: Their maner of praying to the Sun.
div.p:
THe Peruuian (as I ≈øaide before) had diuers great and ≈øumptuous Churches of the Sunne in al places of the countrey, many of them hauing the walls and Pillers couered and plated with gold and ≈øiluer, with mo≈øt co≈øtly ≈øtooles and benches, and when the Prince, Lords, or Prie≈øts would de≈øire any thing of the ≈øunne, they ri≈øe betime in the morning, before the ≈øunne ri≈øeth, and get them vpon a high ≈øtone ≈øcaffold made for the purpo≈øe, where holding downe their heades, and with wringing and folding their hands, and then pre≈øently lifting vp and ≈øpreading their armes, as if they would receiue the Sunne into them, they murmure certaine wordes, ≈øhewing their reque≈øts, and in the ≈øame manner they v≈øed to pray vnto the ≈øunne ≈øince they were ≈øubdued: they fal downe before the Spaniardes, and de≈øire them to be mercifull vnto them, and not vtterly to de≈øtroy them: in ≈øome places, ≈øpecially vnder the Line and thereabouts, they placed the gates of their temples in the E≈øt, and couered them with certaine cotten linnen: in euerie Church there ≈øtood two grauen Images, of fa≈øhion like blacke Buckes, before the which they kept a continuall fire of ≈øweete wood, which I thinke to be Cedar, becau≈øe the barke being taken off, there i≈ø≈øueth a certaine ≈øweete gumme, which is mo≈øt excellent to pre≈øerue the bodyes of dead men, and to the contrarie corrupteth the bodie of a liuing man. Likewi≈øe there are in tho≈øe Churches certaine Images of great Serpents, which they pray vnto, but this is only about the line in Peru and Cu≈øco, and not where they haue the Guacas, which are ≈øtones, about the which no man may come, but onely the Prie≈øtes, that are apparrelled al in white: and comming to them, they take in theyr handes certaine white cloathes, and fal vppon the ground, ≈øpeaking to the Image in a ≈øtrange ≈øpeech, becau≈øe the common people may not vnder≈øtand it. Tho≈øe Prie≈øtes receiue all the offerings that are giuen vnto the Idol, burying the tenth part thereof in the Church, and keepe the re≈øt for them≈øelues: and you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that all the offerings mu≈øt be wrought with golde and ≈øiluer, and of ≈øuch forme and fa≈øhion as the thing is which they de≈øire to haue of their Guaca. They offer al≈øo liuing men, and all kindes of bea≈øtes, looking in the hearts and intrailes of the men or bea≈øtes which they did offer, for certaine ≈øecret tokens, which if they founde not vpon the offerings, they ≈øtill offered newe men or bea≈øts, vntil they founde the tokens, thinking the Idoll not to be plea≈øed with ≈øuch offrings as had them not. When the prie≈øts ≈øhould offer ≈øacrifices, then they ab≈øtaine from the company of their wiues, and cea≈øed not all night to doo nothing but crie out, and pray to the diuell, running into the fieldes, and to the places where the Guacas ≈øtande, whereof there were ≈øo many, that euerie man hadde
one before his dore, and the day before they ≈øhould ≈øpeake with the diuell, they fa≈øted, ≈øome binding a thing before their eies, and ≈øome thru≈øt them cleane out, and it hath often bene ≈øeene that ≈øome of them haue done it of meere deuotion. The kinges and noble menne enterpri≈øe not any thing before they haue con≈øulted with the Prie≈øtes, and the Prie≈øts with the Idoles: in their ≈øacrifices, they v≈øe not onely bea≈øtes but menne and children, but they eate not mans fle≈øh, as the Caniballes do. When the Spaniardes ≈øpoyled their Temples, they founde therein many pottes full of the dried bones and fle≈øh of dead children, that had bin offered to their Idolles: they offer likewi≈øe birdes and other bea≈øtes, and with the bloud of their offerings they annoint the mouthes of their Idolles, and the dores of their churches. There was likewi≈øe among the golde that lay by their idolles certaine ≈øtaues and myters for Bi≈øhops, ≈øuch as our Bi≈øhops v≈øe when they are in their robes, or as the Painters v≈øe to ≈øet foorth Saint Nicholas ‚ñ™ with his Cro≈ø≈øe and Myter: and being a≈øked what tho≈øe things meant, they knew not what to an≈øwere, neyther from whence they came. Be≈øides tho≈øe great temples of the Sunne and Guacas, there were in all places of the countrey of Peru, many other Churches and Cloy≈øters, for yong maides, wherein ≈øome had one hundred, ≈øome two hundred, and ≈øome more, al ob≈øeruing cha≈øtitie, or at the lea≈øt, vowing to keepe it, and to honour the Sunne, like the Va≈øtal virgins in Rome, or our Nuns. Tho≈øe they called Mamacomas, and were bound to ≈øtay in the cloy≈øter during their liues, and neuer to depart from thence, dooing nothing but ≈øpinne, weaue, and ≈øowe, very fine cloth of cotten and wooll, apparell, and furnitures for their Idolles, or as others affirme, the clothes by them made, were burnt with the bones of white ≈øheepe, the a≈øhes whereof as a ≈øigne and token of godly honour they threw into the ayre again≈øt the Sunne. Tho≈øe maides were verye narrowely looked vnto by certaine Prie≈øtes, and other men, appoynted for the purpo≈øe, wherof ≈øome were gelded, becau≈øe they ≈øhould not ≈øeeke to defile them, which if the maides once committed, they were eyther put to death, or buried quicke, but if the maide with childe would take her othe that it was begotten by the Sunne, then the childe was free from death: and euerye yeere in the moneth of Augu≈øt, when they had gathered in their corne, or maiz, the Per ‚Ä¢ uians that dwelt in the hilles made a great fea≈øt, they ≈øet vp in the middle of their Market place two great hie trees, like our Maie-poles, and in the top of them they placed certaine Images, made like men compa≈ø≈øed about with flowers, and ≈øo in roundes, yet in good order, comming thither they ≈øtrike vp drummes, throwing and ≈øhowting one after the other with ≈øtones and arrowes at tho≈øe Images, making great noy≈øe with whooping and hallowing and euery man hauing ≈øhott and thrown. The Prie≈øts brought an other Image, which was ≈øet belowe on the neather part of the trees, whereunto they offered, either a man or a ≈øheepe, annoynting the Image with the bloud thereof, and after they perceiued the tokens in the heart or intrailes, they certified it vnto the people, and the tokens being found, the fea≈øt was ended, eyther with ioy or ≈øadnes, mo≈øt part in drinking, wherunto they are much addicted, and ≈øo daunced, turning and pa≈ø≈øing vnder each others armes, each man hauing either a bill, clubbe, or ≈øome other weapon in his hand: ≈øuch as are de≈øirous to know more of their ceremonies and fal≈øe wor≈øhippings of Idoles, let them reade the hi≈øtories of the Spani≈øh Indies.

The countrey of Peru was fir≈øt ruled by Iudges, which are Kings or Rulers, that come from the great lake called Titicara, or as ≈øome write, Titicaca, lying in Charcas, being foure ≈øcore miles in compa≈ø≈øe which runneth we≈øtward through a great riuer, which in ≈øome places is halfe a mile broad, and then runneth into an other ≈ømall lake fortie miles di≈øtant, and it is to be wondered at, how the abundaunce of water that runneth out of the great lake, is comprehended in ≈øo ≈ømall a place, where it is not once perceiued to increa≈øe. The lake beeing ≈øo ≈ømall, and the water ≈øo great: but it is reported, that in that lake there is no botome or ground, and that the water runneth vnder the ground thorow the earth into another ≈øea or riuer, as it is ≈øaide of the riuer Alpheus, that it runneth from Peioponces or Moica to Cicilia, vnder the ground: and from this lake or thereabouts the kings of Peru had their originall, the petegree of which kings is by Iacob Fernando, a Spaniard, declared in this manner. Fr≈øt Mango Capa, who according to the Indians report, was not borne of a woman, but ≈øprang out of a ≈øtone, which vntill this day is yet ≈øhewne by them about the towne of Cu≈øco, hee by his wife Mama Guaco, had i≈ø≈øue one ≈øonne called Sicheroca, that ruled after his father, and was the ≈øecond Ingen or king, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the inheritance
of the kingdome continueth in the i≈ø≈øue ≈øons ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely, and not vnto the children of the ≈øonnes, before all the brothers haue raigned one after another, but fir≈øt the elde≈øt ≈øonne is King, then after his death his ≈øecond brother ≈øucceedeth in the kingdome, and not the elde≈øt brothers ≈øonnes, and the ≈øecond brother dying, there being no more brethren, the crowne falleth vnto the elde≈øt brothers ≈øonnes, without alteration or change: this Sicheroca was a valiant ≈øouldier like his father, and broght many of his neighbours to ≈øubiection, and by Mama Cura he had i≈ø≈øue a ≈øonne called Locuco Pangue, the third king, who ≈øtudied rather to holde tho≈øe landes he had vnder his ≈øubiection, then to win or increa≈øe more vnto them: and being aged, he married a wife Mama Anauerque, by whom he had a ≈øonne called Maita Capa, that augmented his kingdome, and thervnto ioyned the prouince of Cu≈øco, and by his wife Mama Iacchi Dela he had i≈ø≈øue a ≈øonne, called Capa Cyupangu, of whom there is nothing worthy memory, onely that he left a ≈øonne (by his wife Mama Cagna) called Inga Ruca, who likwi≈øe did no ≈øpeciall thing during his life, but onely by his wife Mama M ‚Ä¢ cay he had diuers ≈øonnes, and one among the re≈øt called Iaguar Guacinga Iupangue, of whome there is a ≈øtrange hi≈øtory recited, which is, yt he being a child of ye age of thr√©e monthes, was taken by certaine Caciquen that are likewi≈øe Lordes or kinges, that thought to kil him, and while they coÃÑ≈øulted among≈øt them≈øelues coÃÑcerning his death, it chanced that as the childe cried, certaine drops of blood i≈ø≈øued out of his eyes, whereby they were aba≈øhed, e≈øt√©eming it for a miracle, they left the child and departed, which being taken vp by a ≈øtranger, was caried to the king, and after that became great and proued a braue ≈øouldier, ≈øo that he ouercam many of his neighbours, and brought them in ≈øubiection vnder him, he had to wife Mama Chipuia, and by her had his elde≈øt ≈øonne named Vi ‚Ä¢ a Cocham, that ≈øucc√©eded him in his kingdome, and much increa≈øed his dominions: after him raigned Pachacoti his ≈øonne, borne of Mama Yunta Cayan, this Prince was much valanter then al his predece≈ø≈øors, whereby he ouercame many people, and by him the foundation of the ca≈øtle of Cu≈øco was fir≈øt begun: and dying, he left for heire and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of his kingdome
‚Ä¢ opa Inga Iupangue his ≈øonne, borne of Mama Anaberque, that followed his fathers ≈øteppes, and ouercame many people, and brought them in ≈øubiection, and fini≈øhed the ca≈øtle of Cu≈øco begun by his father. The prouinces by him won, were C ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ e, and Quito, and he cau≈øed the kinges hie-waye (≈øo much wondered at of all the worlde to be made from Cu≈øco, through the prouince of Charcas vnto Chile, in the which way, from halfe mile to halfe mile, he had placed po≈øtes by them called Cha≈øquis, which were Indians that went fa≈øter then any of our hor≈øes, to the great ea≈øe and contentment of trauailers, for by that means they might ≈øhorten their way, and in three dayes trauaile 120 L ‚Ä¢ uken (that is 240 miles) by rea≈øon of the ≈øwiftnes of the men that bare them and ≈øtoode for po≈øtes,, after the A ‚Ä¢ trican manner in the kingdome of Congo, as I haue already declared, for that after the ariual of the Spaniardes, there were neither hor≈øes, a≈ø≈øes, nor mules within the country whereon men ≈øhould ride or trauaile withal. This king dying, left i≈ø≈øue aboue 150. ≈øonnes, among the which one of them named Guaynacapa, begotten vpon Mama Oclo his wife, ≈øucceeded him in his kingdom, not any thing inferior for valour, wi≈øedom, and councell, both in peace and war, much augmenting and increa≈øing the limites of his countrie, ob≈øeruing great order and equitie in all thinges, both concerning the gouernment of the countrie, and the people, appointing better orders, and manie olde and ancient lawes that were vnfit and not conuenient, he cau≈øed to be abrogated, and newe deui≈øed in their place: hee maried a wife called Coyam Pilico vaco, by whom hauing no children, he maried diuers other wiues, ≈øo that the number of his children was much greater then his fathers, who notwith≈øtanding had 150 ≈øonnes. Among his children the elde≈øt was called Gua≈øcar Inga, his mother being called Raua Oclo, and as I ≈øaid before this king Guainacapa much increa≈øed in his kingdome, and ouercame many people, among the which hee helde ≈øo good gouernment and order, as it ≈ø√©emed in manner vnpo≈ø≈øible, ≈øpecially among ≈øuch rude & ≈øimple people, that were wholy without learning, wherein appeered a mo≈øt manife≈øt example of great ≈øubiection and loue in his ≈øubiects towards their naturall Lordes: and herevpon to his great honour, they made the two notable and co≈øtly hie-waies (≈øo much e≈øteemed in al couÃÑtries) and may well be accounted for one of the ≈øeauen wonders of the world, for when Guainacapa was gon from Cu≈øco with his armie to make warre again≈øt the prouince of Quito, di≈øtant from thence at the lea≈øt 500 miles, he was forced to pa≈ø≈øe ouer high hills, whereby both he and his people indured great trouble and mi≈øerie, becau≈øe
„Äà‚óä„Äâ war was full of hard and rough ≈øtones, before his returne againe being victorious, his ≈øubiects in token of great ioy, as al≈øo for his further ‚Ä¢ a≈øe and comoditie, becau≈øe hee and his ≈øouldiers had indeed ≈øo hard and labour≈øome a ‚Ä¢ ourn ‚Ä¢ e) cut downe and digged vp all the „Äà‚óä„Äâ waies and ≈øtonie cliffes, making the waye euen and plaine, ≈øo that in ≈øome places there were vallyes of twentie or thirtie mens height, that were filled vp and made euen with the hilles, which way they made in that maner for ye length of fiue hundred miles, ≈øo plaine and euen that any cart or wagon might trauell theron, which way, after the Spaniards ariual in the contrie was in diuers places ≈øpoiled and de≈øtroied, to let the Indians from traueling that way, and thinking this not ≈øufficient, when the ≈øaide Guainacapa went to vi≈øit his country of Quito, and tooke his waie through the plain country, they likewi≈øe made him another way, to fill all the vallies and ‚Ä¢ ri≈øh places therein, and to make them euen, which way they made about fortie foote broad on both ≈øides with high walles, and in the ≈øandy waies they ≈øet great ‚Ä¢ roughes with ropes tied vnto theÃÑ, becau≈øe men ≈øhould not lo≈øe them≈øelues in the wa ‚Ä¢ e, which ≈øtretched likewi≈øe 500, miles, the walles as yet in ≈øome places are to be ≈øeene, but by meanes of their warres the Banks for the mo≈øt part are taken away and burnt, and be≈øides all this, he him ≈øelfe cau≈øed many temples of the ≈øunne and other Idoles, and diuers Ta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bo ‚Ä¢
which are hou≈øes of munition and of plea≈øure (for the benefit and commodity of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors in time of warre) to be made and builded as wel on the hils, as in the plain countrie, both on the riuer ≈øides, as in euery way, the riuers whereof are at this day in many places to be ≈øeene, whereby may be coniectured the greatnes and riches of tho≈øe kings, and the great care they had for the defence, and ≈øafetie of their countries, for that heereby when they trauailed through the countrie, not only they and all their companie might lodge in tho≈øe hou≈øes, but the hou≈øes were ≈øtill furni≈øhed and prouided (by the people inhabiting about them) not only with victuals ≈øufficient for a whole armie, but al≈øo with apparel and al kinde of weapons that were v≈øed in the warrs, therewith pre≈øently to apparell their ≈øouldiers, and to make them ready for the warres, as bowes, arrowes‚ñ™ pikes, halberds, clubbes, bils, &c. for 20000. or 30000 men pre≈øently to bee rai≈øed, wherof there was no want, and tho≈øe hou≈øes were ≈øome 8 or 10, and ≈øome twentie miles at the furthe≈øt one from the other, neuer further di≈øtaÃÑt then a days iourney. As touching the ornaments of the kings of Peru, which they in ≈øteed of crownes and princely ≈øepters v≈øed to weare therby to ≈øhew their power and maie≈øtie, they ware certaine ta≈ø≈øels of red woole bound about their heads, hanging downe vppon their ≈øhoulders, almo≈øt couering their eies, whereat there hung other threeds, which they v≈øed when they would haue any thing done or executed, giuing that thrid vnto one of the Lordes that attended on them, and by that commandement gouerned the prouinces, and by that token they commaunded al what≈øoeuer they would de≈øire, which by their ≈øubiects was with ≈øo great diligeÃÑce and dutiful obedience fulfilled, that the like was neuer knowen in any place throughout the world: and if hee chanced to command that a whole prouince ≈øhuld be clean de≈øtroyed, and vtterly left de≈øolate both of men and all liuing creatures what≈øoeuer, both yong & old, if he ≈øent but one of his ≈øeruants to execute the ≈øame, although he ≈øent no other power or aide of men, nor other commi≈ø≈øion then one of the theerds of his Qui≈øpell, it was ≈øufficient, and they willingly yeelded them≈øelues to all dangers of death or de≈øtruction what≈øoeuer. The≈øe kings were borne in chariots or ≈øeats made of beaten golde, borne on the ≈øhoulders of 1000. Lordes and councelours at times thereunto appointed, wherof if any of them vnadui≈øedly ≈øtumbled & ≈øtaggered, he was pre≈øently put to death, and no man ≈øpake vnto the king at any time, but they brought him certaine pre≈øents, and if they went to ≈øpeake with him ten times in a daie, ≈øo often mu≈øt they pre≈øeÃÑt him with new gifts, it was likewi≈øe accounted for a great fault, ≈øo looke ye king in the face. Being in the wars, and hauing ouercome any countrie, or prouince‚ñ™ they ob≈øerued the ancient cu≈øtom of Rome, which was, to take the people with them that they might not ri≈øe vp or rebell again≈øt them, yet with great diffrence from the Romaines, for that hauing won ‚Ä¢ ame land or prouince, they tooke many or ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ we out of it, according to the number of people that were therein, & if the≈øe whom they had conquered inhabited in a hot countrie, they were placed in another warme country, & if theirs were cold, they likewi≈øe went into a cold countrie, where they had the lands deuided among theÃÑ, that each man might liue vpon it. And it the naturall count ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ men of any prouince or place w ‚Ä¢ to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bel again≈øt their prince, the kings Li ‚Ä¢ tenants and CoÃÑmaunders v≈øed the „Äà‚óä„Äâ as ‚Ä¢ hat is the ≈øtrange people to keep them in ≈øubiection,
and to the contrarie, if the Mitimaes ≈øeemed once to ≈øtirre or ri≈øe vp, they kept them in ≈øubiection by the naturall inhabitants, and by this policie they maintained their countrie in great peace and quietne≈ø≈øe. Be≈øides this they v≈øed another meanes, not to bee hated of their ≈øubiects, for that they neuer tooke the rule or authoritie (of any people that were ≈øubdued by them) from the Caciquen or Lords that were nobly borne, if any of them di≈øliked thereof, they puni≈øhed him, yet gaue his office either to his children or to his brethren, commaunding them to bee obedient when they went to hunt and take their plea≈øures, which they call Chico, they a≈ø≈øembled many men together, according to the ≈øcituation of the countrey, ≈øome times foure or 5000. men, whom they placed in a ring together, that many times compa≈ø≈øed at the lea≈øt two or three miles, and ≈øo ≈øinging a certain ≈øong, they followed each other foote by foote, vntil they were ≈øo neare togither, that they might reach hands, and yet nearer till they could imbrace each other, & the nerer they went together, the clo≈øer they made the ring, by which meanes al the bea≈øts by them inclo≈øed, they killed as they thought good, with ≈øo great a noy≈øe and crie, as ≈øeemed incredible, not much vnlike the maner of the Duch Princes, in their general huntings, ≈øpecially of the Wolues, onely that they haue not ≈øo many men, nor ≈øing not, yet make a great noy≈øe. The bea≈øts that they take are wild Sheepe, Rheen, Foxes, Lions, blacke Beares, Cattes, many Hogges, and other bea≈øts, & foules, as Turtle doues, Quailes, Spetchten, Parrots Hawkes, &c. The tributes and talages, that the kings receiued of their ≈øubiects, were things of their owne increa≈øe: out of the countreyes that were vnfruitfull they brought him Hoopwik, of Crocadiles, by them called Caymans, and many other wormes. This Guaynacapa renewed the temple of the ≈øunne in the Citie of Cu≈øco, couering the wals and ruffes with plates of gold and ≈øiluer, and as I ≈øaid before, the prouince and countrey of Quito was woon by him, which countrey plea≈øed him ≈øo well, that for a time hee continued therein, meane time leauing his elde≈øt ≈øon Gua≈øcar, Iuga Mango and other of his children in Cu≈øco, to gouerne the countrey, and in Quito hee married another Wife, daughter to the Lord of the ≈øame prouince, and by hir he had Atabalipam, a ≈øon whom he greatly loued: and when he trauailed to Cu≈øco, hee left him and others in Quito, yet before he dyed, he went once againe to Quito, partly becau≈øe the country liked him ≈øo well, and partly to ≈ø√©e his ≈øonne Atabalipam, and there before he dyed, hee ordained that the countrey and towne of Quito ≈øhuld remaine to his ≈øonne Atabalipam, and his heires for euer, as beeing taken from his forefathers, which his ≈øonne Gua≈øcar after his fathers death would not permitte, and for the ≈øame cau≈øe rai≈øed warres again≈øt his brother, which in the ende was the ouerthrow and ≈øubiection of Peru, whereof, as in the life of Gualca ‚Ä¢ , (that after his fathers death ruled all the countrey vnto Quito) it appeareth. Gua≈øcar ≈øignifieth a cord or cable, for that at the time of his birth, the king cau≈øed a cable of gold to be made, as great as two hundred Indians could carry, hee v≈øed likewi≈øe a plate of golde whereon hee ≈øate, worth at the lea≈øt 25000. duckets (which after fell into the hands of Franci≈øco Pizarro, fir≈øt gouernour of Peru) and all his ve≈ø≈øel was of golde, whereby it appeareth that golde was likewi≈øe much e≈øteemed by them.

The Kings in Cu≈øco had many golde≈ømiths ≈øhoppes, therein to make and worke al kinde of ve≈ø≈øels, Iewels, and images of men, bea≈øtes, foules, and hearbes of golde, al in good proportion: and although theyr Gold≈ømithes v≈øed not any iron tooles, yet they make mo≈øt excellent workman≈øhippe, although ≈øomewhat gro≈øer and plainer then ours. The manner of working was in this ≈øort, fir≈øt they tooke the ≈øiluer or golde that they would melt, and put it in rounde or long melting ve≈ø≈øels, made of cloath, pa≈øted about with earth and beaten colours, which being drie, they ≈øet it in the fire, with as much golde and ≈øiluer therein as they would melt, or as it would hold, and ≈øo with fiue or ≈øixe reedes blowe ≈øo long about it, vntill the mettall melted and became redde hot, and the ≈økimme being taken off, it being taken out of the melting ve≈ø≈øell, euerie man had his part, which they ≈øitting vppon the earth, with blacke Ke ‚Ä¢ ci ‚Ä¢ ick ≈øtones (made in form like hammers) they forged & framed theyr images of Gods, ve≈ø≈øels, and Iewels of gold, chaines, and formes of all kinde of bea≈øtes, birdes, and hearbes, with all manner of things.

But to returne vnto our former matter, the Sonnes of Guaynaca ‚Ä¢ a called Gua≈øcar and Atabalipa, were the cau≈øe of the de≈øtruction, ruine, and ouerthrowe of the countrey of Peru by rea≈øon of the wars by them made one again≈øt the other, for the gouernment of the country, which was ≈øo cruell, that they once met & fought for the ≈øpace of thr√©e whole dayes together and neuer cea≈øed, where many people were ≈ølaine ‚Ä¢
and Atabalipa taken in the battel and kept pri≈øoner in the prouince of Tomebamba, and there very ≈øtraightly kept in one of the Kings Ca≈øtles, yet by ≈øubtiltie, and intreatie made to certaine women: he had a copper in≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ment brought vnto him, wherewith hee brake the walles of the Ca≈øtle of Tomebamba, and gote out of pri≈øon, at the ≈øame time that his brothers ≈øouldiers and captaines were making good cheere, drinking their Cicha, whereunto they are much addicted, and dauncing for ioy of the victorie: and being at libertie, he fled vnto Q ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
to, telling his people, that he was by his father conuerted into a ≈ønake, and ≈øo crept out of pri≈øon at a little hole, his father promi≈øing him victorie, ≈øo that his men would once againe returne with him to battaylet whereby his people were ≈øo well incouraged, that they went with him agayne into the fielde, where Fortune fauouring him, and being victorious, hee tooke his brother Gua≈øcar pri≈øoner, (to whome not long before he hadde beene pri≈øoner) and therewith obtained all the Countrey, making him≈øelfe chiefe ruler thereof, keeping his brother pri≈øoner within Cu≈øco.

About the ≈øame time Franci≈øcus Pizarrus arriued in Peru, being Oyuaer of tho≈øe two mightie kings, and by rea≈øon of theyr di≈ø≈øen≈øion, made him mai≈øter of ≈øo great and rich countries of gold. Hee that de≈øireth a larger de≈øcription hereof, may reade the Spanni≈øh Hi≈øtories, that write of the de≈øcription of the new worlde. Pizarius being in the Countrey, made warre again≈øt Atabalipam, and in thend ouercame him, and for a time kept him pri≈øoner: and during his impri≈øonment hee agr√©ed with Pizario for a certaine ran≈øome, and when it was ready, h√©e cau≈øed his brother Gua≈øcar to be ≈øent for out of Cu≈øco, and by the way, before he came at him, he cau≈øed him to be ≈ølaine, fearing (and not without a cau≈øe) that if Gua≈øcar once came before the Spaniard, and ≈øhould declare his mi≈øfortune, he would without all doubt offer a greater ran≈øome (as he had done) then h√©e ≈øhould pay, and by that meanes he ≈øhoulde remaine in pri≈øon, and his brother at libertie, hauing hadde al the trea≈øure of his predece≈ø≈øours, as al≈øo his fathers. But A ‚Ä¢
tabalipa hauing brought his ran≈øom which amounted vnto 3088235. gilderus, was not long after, by crueltie of the Spaniards without any cau≈øe, and al≈øo again≈øt theyr othe and promi≈øe, mo≈øt ≈øhamefully by certaine Moores, at the commaundement of Pizarius, openly ≈øtrangled in the Market place: and as ≈øome write, his body was after burned to a≈øhes. This was the „Äà‚óä„Äâ able end of the mightie K. Atabalipa, a man of a meane ≈øtature, wi≈øe, and high minded, wholly giuen to rule. Twenty dayes before his death there appeared a blazing ≈øtarre, which when he perceiued, he prophecied, that in ≈øhorte time after a gr ‚Ä¢ at Prince of that country ≈øhould die, not thinking it to be him≈øelfe. Gua≈øcar and Atabalipa being both dead, the gouernment f ‚Ä¢ l vnto Mango Inga the third brother, who dying, left his kingdome to his ≈øon Xaires Topa Inga, that maried a wife caled C ‚Ä¢ ya daughter of a noble man called Cuxi V ‚Ä¢ rcay Gua≈øcaris: and he before he entred into the gouernement, chaunged his name to Mango capa Pachuti Iupan, withall making him≈øelfe ≈øubiect vnto Philip King of Spaine, which hapned 1557. 1557 on the ≈øixt of Ianuary being Twelfe day. Thus much touching the kings of Peru.

div.head: A de≈øcription of the places or townes lying among the hils.
div.p:
THr√©e miles from Cu≈øco, lieth the valley Iucay, a very plea≈øant valley, lying betw√©ene two hilles, very fre≈øh and whole≈øome aire, as being therin neither ouer hot, nor colde: and two miles beyond it lieth Tambo, another valley, wherein are ≈øeene great ruines, of the kings munition hou≈øes. And trauelling further, you come to Conde≈øuyo, a prouince, where in times pa≈øt there dwelt certaine warlike people, their townes ≈øtanding betw√©ene high hils, where there were many wilde and tame bea≈øts. Their hou≈øes were of ≈øtone, couered with ≈øtrawe: therein al≈øo were many hou≈øes and pallaces of noble men. They haue all one maner of liuing with the re≈øt, the Peruuians offering lambes and other bea≈øtes in their churches, wherein at certaine times the diuell ≈øhewed him≈øelfe: the riuers are rich of golde, and there are made certayne couerlets of fine wooll cunningly wrought in diuers colours. This way before called Andes, is very long, for it runneth cleane through Peru, to the ≈øtraites of Magellanas wherein there lieth many prouinces and townes, and diuers high trees, ≈øome couered with ≈ønowe, others with flames of burning brim≈øtone, whereby it is very hard to be trauelled, ≈øpecially, becau≈øe therein for the mo≈øt part, it commonly raineth. Trauelling many miles further, you come to the countrey called Collao, wherein is the lake called Ti ‚Ä¢ icaca,
where there is an I≈øland, and therein a Temple of the Sunne, wherein they ≈øowed their maiz, and kepe their trea≈øure.

Round about this lake are many villages, and therein much good fi≈øh is taken. Somewhat further you come vnto the town of Plata, which is a hundred and fiftie miles from Cu≈øco, in the prouince of Cha ‚Ä¢
cas, in a colder aire then any other place in all the hilles: there are but fewe inhabitants, but ≈øuch as are verie rich‚ñ™ and mo≈øt becau≈øe of the mynes of Porco and Poto≈øi, for Poto ‚Ä¢ i is not aboue eighteene miles from the towne of Plata, di≈øcouered by the company of Captaine Caruaial, for that as ≈øome of the Indians with one Ian de Villa Roel a town≈øman of Plata trauelled thorow the countrey, they found a high hil lying in a flat and euen vallie wherein perceiuing certaine tokens of ≈øiluer‚ñ™ they melted a peece of the Minerall, and found it ≈øo rich, that one quintal made four≈øcore marks ≈øiluer, the like whereof was neuer heard of.

This newes being come to Plata, pre≈øently the cheefe gouernours of the towne went thither, where they diuided vnto euerie man as much as he could doo or labour in, whereby ≈øuch re≈øort came thither, that in ≈øhort time the place was inhabited by more then 7000. men: the Indians working and making contract with the Spaniards their mai≈øters, how much ≈øiluer they wold weekly deliuer. This mine is of a wonderfull ≈øtrange nature, becau≈øe it wil not be molten by blowing with the bellowes, neyther in fornaces like other mynes, but only in ≈ømal furnaces by them caled Guairas, which they ≈øette vppon the highe≈øt parte of the hill, placing the mouthes ≈øouthwarde from whence the winde dooth continually blowe, throwing into the mine fire, coales, and ≈øheepes dongue, whereby the winde made the fire to burne ≈øo hot and cleare, as that not any bellowes or other in≈øtruments coulde doo more: and the Peruuians working in this maner, by ≈øo ea≈øie means had ≈øo great gain, that ≈øome of them got weekly be≈øids theyr mai≈øters parte, fortie thou≈øande Pezos, but by re≈øort, it became likewi≈øe to be ≈øcar≈øe, for that they left other mines, as Pero, and the riuer of Caraba ‚Ä¢ a, wherein they founde golde, to come thither, becau≈øe there they made more profite.

In tho≈øe hilles, and al the land thorow, there are many vaines of all colours, wherof men may make faire colours: the ≈øiluer found in this myne, and which belongeth to the king for his parte, is carried by lande to Arequipa, and from thence to Lyma, Panama, Nombre de Dios, and Spaine.

div.head: A further de≈øcription of the ≈øea coa≈øt from Arequipa to Chile, and from thence to the ≈øtraights of Magellana.
div.p:
CHulli a Hauen of Arequipa, lieth vnder ≈øeuenteene degrees and a halfe, and one mile and a halfe from thence the Riuer of Tambopalla, and ≈øeuen miles and a halfe further, there reacheth a poynt into the ≈øea: not ful a mile beyond, or further out then the other lande, vpon the which poynt there are three cliffes: about this poynte not ful a mile from it, there is a goodly hauen called Illo, in our Carde Rio de Vl ‚Ä¢ e, and there runneth a riuer into the ≈øea that hath good water, and is al≈øo called Illo, lying vnder eighteene degrees and ‚Öì: from thence the coa≈øt lyeth ≈øouthea≈øt, and ≈øouthea≈øt and by ea≈øt: and fiue miles & a halfe further, there is a poynt which the Sea men call Moro del Diauolo, that is, a rounde hou≈øe or houel of diuels. This coa≈øt is al wild and de≈øert, and with great Ba ‚Ä¢ zen: not full foure miles further from this poynt, there is another riuer not verie great, but good water. From this riuer Southea≈øt, and Southea≈øt and by ea≈øt, ≈øayling ≈øeuen miles and a halfe, there reacheth another round houel, which is verie high, and maketh certaine downes: beyond this poynt is an I≈øland, and therabouts lieth the hauen of Arica, which lieth vnder 19. degrees and 1/ ‚Ä¢
: from whence the coa≈øt reacheth Southwe≈øt: not ful ≈øeauen miles further, there runneth into the ≈øea a riuer called Pizagua, and in the ≈øame cour≈øe ≈øayling along the coa≈øt, you come to the hauen Taracapa, which is 19. miles ¬º: harde by Taracapa lyeth a I≈øland, little more then a mile in compa≈ø≈øe, and is di≈øtant from theÃÑ about one mile and a halfe, and there maketh a ≈øtrand or bay of Sand by the hauen, vnder 21. degrees: from Taracapa you ≈øaile along the coa≈øt ≈øouth & by we≈øt, about foure miles, and then you come to the poynte of Decacanna, and 12. miles beyond this point you come to the hauen Moxillioni, which lyeth vnder 22. degrees and a halfe: from this hauen ≈øailing vpwardes ≈øouth ≈øouthwe≈øt about 67 miles and a halfe, the coa≈øt lyeth in a manner ≈øtraight, and therein are ≈øome poyntes, creekes, and ≈øandie baies, at the ende whereof there is a great creeke, where there is a good hauen, called Copayo lying vnder 27 degrees, aboue the which lieth a ≈ømal I≈ølande, about halfe a mile from the firme land, & from thence beginneth the country of Chile, inhabited with people: being
pa≈øt this hauen of Copaypao, a little froÃÑ thence, there lieth a point which makeh another creeke, wheron ≈øtandeth two cliffes, & at the end therof is a riuer of good water, called E ‚Ä¢ Gla≈øco, this point lieth vnder 28. degrees & ‚Ä¢ : following the coa≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt on, about eight miles and a half, there is another poynte, which maketh a great hauen for ≈øhips, but therein is neither fre≈øh water nor wood: and hard by this hauen lieth the hauen of Coquinbo, & betweene this and the poynt pa≈ø≈øing by ≈øeuen I≈ølands, there is a hauen vnder 29. and a half, & ≈øeuen miles and a halfe further, following the ≈øame cour≈øe, there is another poynt, about the which there is a great creeke or bay called Antogayo, in the Carde Bahio de Tage, about foure mile further lieth the Riuer Limara, in the Card Lemare, from this riuer, you keepe the ≈øame cour≈øe to another creeke or bay about 7. miles di≈øtant, which hath a cliffe, but no fre≈øh water, lying vnder 31. degrees, and is called Choapa, in our card Cupa: further in the ≈øame cour≈øe, about 15. miles, there is a verie good hauen, called de Q ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ nic ‚Ä¢ o, in our Card Cutero at Quintero: it lyeth vnder 32. degrees, & ≈øeuen miles and a halfe further, is the hauen Val Paraize, and from the town of S. Iacomo by vs called Chile, after the name of the country. Touching this country of Chile it is very great, ≈øtretching along the ≈øea coa≈øt, reaching aboue Chaicas and Peru, a cold countrey, which is by rea≈øon of the ≈øcituation thereof, as lying by the Pole Antartico, wherefore it is called Chile, that is the cold countrie, partly becau≈øe of the great cold which men indure, trauailing ouer the Andes, vnto this countrey, and partly becau≈øe of the coldnes of the countrey it ≈øelfe, although it is much like Spaine, touching the temperatene≈ø≈øe of the aire. This countrey was fir≈øt di≈øcouered by Petro de Valdiuia, in the yeare of our Lorde 1539. 1539. and is all inhabited: in ≈øome place it is hillie, and in other places plaine fieldes, poynted and running very crooked, by rea≈øon of the inflection and crooking of the ≈øea. Touching the re≈øt of the ≈øcituation, as I ≈øayde before, it is verie temperate, hauing winter and ≈øummer, as it is in Spain, yet at contrary times, for their ≈øummer is winter in Spaine, and the Spaniards winter theyr ≈øummer. The ≈øouth ≈øtarre that ≈øhould an≈øwere and be right di≈øtant to our ≈øtarre, being there on land cannot be ≈øeene, but onely a ≈ømall white cloude, betweene day and night making a ≈ømal circuite or compa≈ø≈øe, about certaine places of the Pole Antarctike. There likewi≈øe you ≈øee foure ≈øtarres, in forme like a cro≈ø≈øe, with three other ≈øtars following them, which make ≈øeauen ≈øtars, like ours, without any difference‚ñ™ that may be perceiued, onely that the foure which in the ≈øouth make the form of a cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øtand clo≈øer together then tho≈øe of our Pole Antarctico. Touching their day and night, they are in Chile according to the ≈øcituatioÃÑ, ≈øhort and long, as with vs, yet contrarie to ours, for that our ≈øhorte≈øt dayes are theyr longe≈øt daies. Their apparell and meates are altogether like tho≈øe of Peru, both men and women are of good complection and behauiour, vpon the coa≈øt of this countrey are many riuers, which by day do runne with water, and by night they are without water, becau≈øe the ≈ønow by day melteth, by rea≈øon of the heate of the ≈øunne, and ≈øo runneth downe from the hils, which by night by rea≈øon of the cold aire, congealeth, and ≈øo runneth not. In Chile and Chaicas they haue many ≈øheepe, that are like camels, but that they haue not a hill vppon their backes like the Cammel. The Spaniards v≈øe them to ride vppon, as being able to beare a man foure or fiue miles a day, but being wearie, they lie downe, and will not ri≈øe what≈øoeuer they doe vnto them, be they neuer ≈øo much beaten: and who≈øoeuer rideth vppon them, the ≈øheepe being wearie, ≈øhee will ca≈øt vp the head towardes him that ≈øitteth vpon her, and blowe a filthie ≈øtinke into his face, thereby to bee ea≈øed of her burthen. The≈øe bea≈øtes are verie profitable and nece≈ø≈øary, no le≈ø≈øe then Cammels in Egypt & Affrica, and are fedde with a little Maiz and other meate, ≈øpecially tho≈øe that they v≈øe to ride vpon, to labor, and to carry burthens. They goe likewi≈øe as Cammels doo, foure or fiue dayes together without drinking, and but little meate: ≈øome of them called Pachos haue verie fine wool, with long fleeces, wi ‚Ä¢ h verie good, hol≈øome, and ≈øauorie fle≈øh, like our gammons of Bacon. The hauen of Chile or S. Iacomo lieth vnder 32. degrees, and 2/ ‚Ä¢ parts: ≈øayling further along the coa≈øt in the ≈øame cour≈øe, you come to the riuer of Calma, di≈øtant from Chile eighteene miles: it is here al≈øo to be con≈øidered, that all the coa≈øt from Tumbez to this place, is verie good to ≈øayle by, and a calme ≈øea, without tempe≈øtes or foule weather, whereby the ≈øhippes may lye at anker where they think good. Nine miles from Calma you ≈øee the poynt of the riuer called Manque or M ‚Ä¢ ule, in our card Maole and ten miles and a half further there is another riuer called I ‚Ä¢ ata, in our Carde Rio Tatu ‚Ä¢ a, and ≈øo ≈øailing ≈øouth and ≈øouthwe≈øt eighteene miles, there is another called Biobio, lying almo≈øt vnder eight and thirtie degrees, in the ≈øame
cour≈øe, k√©eping along the ≈øhore, full eleuen miles di≈øtant, there is a great I≈øland about foure miles di≈øtant from the firme land caled Lucengo, and ≈øomwhat further beyond this I≈øland is a great broad cr√©eke called Valdiuia, in our carde La Baldibia, wherein there runneth a great riuer caled Ayntlendo, in our Carde Rio Aymlendos, this Cr√©eke lieth vnder 39. degr√©es and ‚Öî. towards the ≈øouth, and from (as the Pilots report) the coa≈øt reacheth ≈øouth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt to the ≈øtraits of Magellana, and betweene them lie many hauens and places needle≈ø≈øe to rehear≈øe, as being noted in the carde: inwarde in the land there is the Countrey of Patagonen, wherein there are Giantes of nine and of tenne foot high, that paint their faces with diuer≈øe colours made of hearbs, pre≈ø≈øing out the ≈øap. George and the droughtes of Canaciera, where you ≈øhal find 7.8. and ≈øometimes 9. fadome when it is high water, and being as farre as the Iland, ≈øo that in your ≈øight the Iland of Saint George, and that of Saint Iames are all one, then you are right again≈øt the I≈ølandes, and from thence putting in, you ≈øhall ≈øet your cour≈øe right vpon the ≈øtrand of S.
