This Bay of Mo≈øambique lyeth ≈øcarce vnder 15. degrees: in this hauen of Mo≈øambique the Compa≈ø≈øe windeth not a ≈øtrike Northwe≈øtward, and from thence to the a Ilha do Comoro, you mu≈øt run northea≈øt, which Iland lyeth vnder 11. degrees, 1/ ‚Ä¢ . that is, in the end of Southwe≈øt, the cour≈øe from this I≈øland, or to the line is Northea≈øt and northea≈øt and by ea≈øt from hence to the line, certaine nightes you ≈øhall ≈øee ≈øhyning or white water till you come to three or foure degr√©es, and ≈øhall haue the wind Southea≈øt, and from thence forwarde you ≈øhall beginne to haue it Southwe≈øt and ≈øouth, ≈øo you begin to come from India in the winter time, from the Equinoctiall line, or to the height of Coa, that is vnder 15. degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . you mu≈øt runne Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, and in this way the Compa≈ø≈øe will lie a ≈øtrike and a halfe Northwe≈øtwarde, and as much as it lyeth Northwe≈øtwarde mu≈øt be ≈øayled north-Ea≈øtward vnto the afore ≈øaid height of Goa: the ≈øignes you alwaies find in this way, are alwaies about ten degr√©es, in the night time you haue white and ≈øhining water, and from tho≈øe ten degrees to the coa≈øt of India, ≈øometimes you ≈øee many birdes that come from the ≈øhore, that is from the coa≈øt of Arabia, as Quartelles, and other ≈øuch like ≈ømal birds, and 180. or two hundred myles from the coa≈øt of India, then the Compa≈ø≈øe beginneth to le≈ø≈øen in the Northwe≈øt, for that in the hauen of Goa it lyeth but one ≈øtrike to the Northwe≈øt, and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . part, and rather le≈ø≈øe then more.

div.head: The 6. Chapter. To ≈øayle from Goa to Cochin.
div.p:
FRom Goa to Batecola, you mu≈øt ≈øaile two or three miles from the land, from twentie to fiue and twentie ≈øadom deep, for it is deeper there then neerer to Cochin, for about halfe a mile from the I≈ølande of Batecola you finde ≈øixe and twentie fadome deepe: from thence it is good to runne Southea≈øt, and Southea≈øt and by South, to the fortre≈ø≈øe of Barcelor, and to know if you be by Barcelor, or in the height thereof, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that there are high hils, which beginne at Batecola, and continue to Barcelor, and right aboue Barcelor there is a round houell like darke mi≈øte or clowde, which ≈øtandeth in the end of ye high hilles: on the South ≈øide of Batecola to this hauen it is foure or fiue miles, and halfe a mile from the ≈øhore it is all ≈øtonie. By Barcelor you may anker at ten fadome deepe, about a mile and a halfe from the ≈øhore, and de≈øiring to ≈øayle vnto Cochin you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe South, ≈øouthwe≈øt and ≈øomewhat more into the ≈øea, as the winde will permit you, for there are other I≈ølandes and cliffes, being where you may pa≈ø≈øe by, (as I ≈øaide before) at fourteen fadome water: it is a good cour≈øe to keep at ≈øixteene fadome: from tho≈øe Ilands three or foure miles forwarde there are nothing but Ilandes and cliffes, which hauing pa≈øt, you come to ≈øee the Fort of Mangalor, as you pa≈ø≈øe by the ≈øhore at fifteene fadome deepe, from thence you ≈øayle to the Fortre≈ø≈øe of Cananor: from Cananor to the I≈ølandes as Ilhas Cagidar, which is ‚Ä¢ . miles, let your cour≈øe here be ≈øouth ≈øouthea≈øt, & at 18. fadom deep: from the I≈ølands of Cagadas to Chale are 7. miles, & ye cour≈øe is ≈øouth ≈øouthea≈øt & 18
fadome deepe, from Chale to Panane are 9. miles in the ≈øame cour≈øe, and from Panane to Cochiin are 10. miles, the cour≈øe beeing ≈øouth, ≈øouthea≈øt, and at twelue & ten fadome deepe, which is a good way.

div.head: The 17. Chapter. The cour≈øe or Nauigation from Cochin to Portingall, written by the ≈øaid Rodri ‚Ä¢ de Ligos.
div.p:
THe towne of Cochiin lieth vnder nine degrees, and ‚Ä¢ / ‚Ä¢ rather le≈ø≈øe than more, and departing out of Cochiin towards Portingall, you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe We≈øt and as much Frorth till you come ‚Ä¢ miles from Cochiin, and being there you ≈øhall ≈øo ≈øet your cour≈øe, that as you pa≈ø≈øe through the I≈ølandes of Maldina and Ma ‚Ä¢ ale, you may come to the height of 8. or eight degrees and not to fall vppon anie I≈ølands, although the ≈øea card in this cour≈øe hath certaine I≈ølandes, yet to ≈øay truth there are none. Tho≈øe I≈ølandes being pa≈øt, it is good to take your cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, till you come to foure degrees, and from thence ≈øouth ≈øouthwe≈øt, to three degr√©es, on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctiall, from Cochin all the way afore≈øaid to this place. The compa≈ø≈øe lieth northwe≈øt a ≈øtrike and a halfe, beeing vnder three degrees on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the line, then you begin to haue the thunder out of the we≈øt, and northwe≈øt, with a ≈øtiffe winde, and from thence you ≈øhall hold ≈øouth and ≈øouth, & by we≈øt, to ten or twelue degrees, in which you ≈øhal haue the wind ≈øouthea≈øt vnder the≈øe twelue degrees, the compa≈ø≈øe holdeth northwe≈øtward a ≈øtrike and ‚Ä¢ parts, but ≈øhall not therfore be made any abatement in your reckoning: for it is often found that the water or ≈øtreame doth there run to the we≈øt, which would then be two faults: for that as I vnder≈øtand it in this cour≈øe, you mu≈øt account all that is ≈øaid the ≈øhip hath gone, becau≈øe you ≈øhall likewi≈øe find ≈øtreames that draw to the ≈øouthea≈øt being at 12 degrees, (as I ≈øaid before til you be vnder 15. degrees, theÃÑ you haue the winde ≈øometime ≈øouth ≈øouthea≈øt, then you mu≈øt not lie we≈øtward for it is not good, but rather runne ea≈øt and ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt, alwaies keeping good watch to the eight√©enth degr√©e, vnder the which lieth the droughtes called
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Baxios dos Garagiaus, and hauing a ≈øouth-Ea≈øt wind, then it is good to hold your cour≈øe ≈øouthwe≈øt, vntill you di≈øcouer the I≈øland of Diego Rod ‚Ä¢ ges, and if it lieth right before you then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e ≈øome of the birdes called Alcatra≈øes, and ≈øome hearbes called Sa
‚Ä¢
driuing in the water, and there the compa≈ø≈øe goeth no higher, but beginneth from thence againe to dimini≈øh or le≈ø≈øen, when you are pa≈øt this I≈øland or the point thereof, then runne ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt, and by we≈øt to 26. degrees, vnder the which height lieth the fir≈øt point of the I≈øland of S. Laurence, & as ≈øoone as you are vnder this height, then you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe we≈øt, ≈øouthwe≈øt to 29. degrees, and from thence we≈øt and we≈øt and by ≈øouth, and to know when you are north and by ≈øouth with the I≈øland of Saint Laurence, that is with the middle of the vttermo≈øt land on the ≈øouth ≈øide, then marke the compa≈ø≈øe well‚ñ™ and if you bee by the countrey afore≈øaid, then your compa≈ø≈øe will bee a ≈øtrike and 1/ ‚Ä¢
one from the other, northwe≈øtward, from thence you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe, as winde and weather ≈øerueth, for being from about the 15. of Aprill, till the la≈øt of May, it is nece≈ø≈øary to haue the Firme land on boarde: for that there, at tho≈øe times you haue the winde North, and northwe≈øt‚ñ™ and being in the monthes of Februarie and March, then the winde is ea≈øt and ≈øouth, where you mu≈øt rule your cour≈øe as the wind ≈øerueth, and being right with the land north, & ≈øouth, then the compa≈ø≈øe ≈øhall leaue a ≈øtrike rather more than le≈ø≈øe to the Northwe≈øt, which is a certaine ≈øigne to bee right again≈øt it, but if it be more, then a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe you are not by the land, then beeing 30. or 40. miles from thence and though you be but 30 miles from the land, you ≈øhall ≈øee gr√©ene water, but you finde no ground. The compa≈ø≈øe that I ≈øpeake of ≈øhall be ≈øixe, and euen at the Cape das Agulhas, with tho≈øe that make them leane northea≈øtward in Portingall, a halfe ≈øtrike rather le≈ø≈øe then more, and when you come to the Cape das Agulhas, and hetherwards, as long as you haue not muddie ground, you are not at the Cape das Agulhas: wherefore ≈øpare not often to ca≈øt your lead, for it will be for your owne good. Pa≈ø≈øing the Cape das Agulhas to the cape de Bona Speranza, it is not good to ≈øaile northwe≈øt, as long as you haue ground, for that therewith you ≈øhould not pa≈ø≈øe the Cape de Bona Speranza, but being pa≈øt it, then runne northwe≈øt, til you come to 16. degrees, vnder the which height the I≈øland of Saint Helena doth lie, or to 16. degrees and 1/ ‚Ä¢
and when you come to that height, then run we≈øt and ≈øomewhat ≈øoutherlie, or the fir≈øt meale tide we≈øt, and by ≈øouth, becau≈øe of the compa≈ø≈øe of the ≈øea in ≈øome ≈øtreames, for I thinke you ≈øhall finde no more heights, although you ≈øhould ≈øayle we≈øt, and by ≈øouth, and ≈øayling on that cour≈øe you ≈øhall continue it 50. miles further, but no more, and when you perceiue the I≈øland and cannot reach it by day, then ≈øtrike all your ≈ømall ≈øayles, holding about 5.
miles from thence, in ≈øuch manner, that in the night time you hold we≈øt, and we≈øt, and by north, there the compa≈ø≈øe beareth full northea≈øt halfe a ≈øtrike, and as you make your reckinng well in your cour≈øe from the cape de Bona Speranza, to this I≈øland, with the aduantage of the compa≈ø≈øe as it ought to be, you ≈øhall find that it lieth aboue ≈øeauentie miles more we≈øtward, then it ≈øtandeth in the Sea Card, departing from this Iland to ≈øaile to Portingall, and to ≈ø√©e the Iland called A≈øcention, you ≈øhall run northwe≈øt, and northwe≈øt, and by we≈øt for 70. miles, then you ≈øhal goe ≈øomewhat Ea≈øternly as ≈øome doe then it wil be needful to ≈øaile 100. miles northwe≈øt, and by we≈øt, and from thence northwe≈øt, vntill you come by the generall wind, but come no nearer vnto the land, for then you ≈øhould not make a good voiage, and although the ≈øouth winde doth continue longer in this cour≈øe, which bringeth you to twelue & fourt√©ene degr√©es, on the north ≈øide, yet leaue it not for that, neyther put clo≈øe vnder the coa≈øt of Guinea, when you haue the general wind although you might more we≈øternly, neyther leaue off therefore to follow your cour≈øe, for it will be large enough, althougl, ≈øometimes it ≈øcanteth, becau≈øe you are clo≈øe by the land. It is good to k√©epe 150. or 200. miles from the coa≈øt: for although that by the ≈øea cardes you finde your ≈øelfe to bee two hundred miles from the land, notwith≈øtanding you are a good way nearer, the rea≈øon whereof is, that you ≈øayle from the point of the I≈øland of S. Helena, which lieth in the ≈øea carde, and not from the I≈øland that lieth 70. miles we≈øtward, as afore≈øaid, and although the pointes doe a≈ø≈øuredly lie towards the I≈øland Flores, it therfore maketh no rea≈øon that it is not ≈øo, as I ≈øay, for that in the cour≈øe through the ≈øea, where you finde the hearbe Sargo≈ø≈øo, the winde being there alwaies northea≈øt, the ≈øea or ≈øtreame runneth to the Antilhas, or fore Iland of the Spani≈øh Ilandes, whereby the ≈øhips doe ≈øo little multiplie in the cour≈øe of Sargo≈ø≈øo, & if the≈øe waters and ≈øtreames doe chance to meete the ≈øhips when they are in the cour≈øe of Sargo≈ø≈øo, it happeneth often times that the ≈øhips beare too loofeward, but very ≈øeldome, and it happeneth oftentimes, that by Guinea the ≈øtreame runneth northward, and being ≈øomewhat neere the land, then the water draweth you pre≈øently to the land, al≈øo the winde comming mo≈øt out of the northwe≈øt and north, which letteth you from ≈øayling northwe≈øt, and being to Seaward you ≈øhal rather haue a northea≈øt wind, and although you haue many meanes to k√©epe you from going clo≈øe vnder the coa≈øt of Guinea, I ≈øet this downe here, becau≈øe I haue noted it my ≈øelfe: for that all the ≈øhips, in what cour≈øe ≈øoeuer they be, which pre≈øently winde them≈øelues to k√©epe aloofe from the coa≈øt of Guinea, being in the cour≈øe of Sargo≈ø≈øo, they haue no full winde, but onelie northea≈øt windes, and ≈øometimes calmes, which ≈øailing to lee ward you find not, where you haue the winde ea≈øt, and ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt. All the ≈øhippes that come from the Antilhas or Spani≈øh Ilandes, the ≈øcar≈øe≈øt windes that they finde are out of the Ea≈øt, whereby you may vnder≈øtand, that when you hold farre off from Guinea, it is no cau≈øe of hauing a longer Voyage: but you ≈øhall the ≈øooner finde a better and fuller winde, and ≈øo when you come vnder twentie degrees, and that the compa≈ø≈øe keepeth ≈øteedie to twentie fiue degrees, then you are not to lee ward, there you beginne to ≈ø√©e the hearbe Sargo≈øso, whereby that hearbe is called Sargo≈øso, and make no reckning of being too loofeward or too l√©eward, for there is no certaintie thereof: ≈øo when you ≈øaile north and northea≈øt, and that the n√©edle of the compa≈ø≈øe lieth not north we≈øtward, theÃÑ be wel a≈ø≈øured that the Iland Flores is right before you, continuing ≈øo till you come to the Iland of Fayael, (which is one of the Flemmi≈øh Ilands called as Ilhas dos Alcores.) The compa≈ø≈øe that within S. Helena was full halfe a ≈øtrike Northea≈øtward, will be full if you marke it well, and when you come vnder thirtie ≈øire, or thirtie nine degrees, and ‚Öì then you ≈øhall ≈øee the Iland Flores, with ≈øome Torteaur in the water, and being fortie miles from the Iland Flores, towardes the coa≈øt, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the birdes Garagiaus and Duckers, and the compa≈ø≈øe will in a manner be euen, and if there be any difference, it will bee ≈øomewhat northea≈øtward: for from the Iland Flores to the Iland Fayael, the compa≈ø≈øe is full as ≈øix, as I ≈øaid before.

div.head: The 8. Chapter. The cour≈øe and Nauigation from India, to the Cape de Bona Speranza, ≈øet downe by another Portingall Pilot.
div.p:
WHEN you depart from Cochiin, to ≈øayle for Portingall, you mu≈øt doe your be≈øt to get vnder tenne degrees
and a halfe, till you be 50. miles We≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt from it, whereby you will bee ≈øcar≈øe vnder 10. degr√©es, vnder the which hight lyeth the Ilands Mamales, for the ≈øtreame will alwaies drawe you to the middle of the Channel, betw√©ene the≈øe Ilands and the Ilands of Maldiua vnder 9. degr√©es & a halfe, you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe full forward without ≈ø√©eing any of tho≈øe Ilands, and go ≈øhoare vnder 9. degr√©es & a quarter, although in the Cards they place many fal≈øe Ilands. And if you chaunce to ≈øet ≈øayle from Cochin the 20. of Ianuarie, little more or le≈ø≈øe, then run ≈øo that you may pa≈ø≈øe the Ilands on the ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by ≈øouth, vntill you bee vnder the Equinoctial line, becau≈øe you go late to ≈øayle, and it may be that the wind and weather wil not ≈øerue you ≈øo well, to holde to Sea ward from the Iland of Brandaon, then you may hold your cour≈øe betw√©ene the Ilands called Dos Irmaos, lying vnder 4. degr√©es on the ≈øouth, and from thence you mu≈øt take your cour≈øe to the Ilands of Pedro Ma≈øcharenhas, and ≈øo following your way, if it chaunce being vnder 4. degr√©es ≈øouthward you haue much thunder, lightning and rayne, becau≈øe commonly it is found there in the moneth of Februarie, as I my ≈øelfe haue tryed, vntill 14. degr√©es, then doe your be≈øt, to get vnder 14. or 15. degr√©es, for commonly vnder 15 or 16. degr√©es you ≈øhall find ≈øouthea≈øt winds and then put no further into the Sea, but pa≈ø≈øe betweene the Iland Brandaon, and the Iland of Lopo Soares, which is a good cour≈øe and as ≈øoone as you are pa≈øt the Iland, then take your cour≈øe by the Iland of Ioan de Lisboa, betw√©ene the which Iland and the Iland of Pedro Ma≈øcherenhas, you haue a good way, ≈øo that you come to pa≈ø≈øe 14. or 15 miles from the Iland of Saint Laurence, from thence ≈øet your cour≈øe We≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt till you come vnder 29. degr√©es, and then run We≈øt, and We≈øt and by South, to 34. degr√©es or as farre as you will, by this cour≈øe running in this ≈øort, comming within 50. or 6 ‚Ä¢ . miles of the land called Terra do Natal you ≈øhall ≈øee many Birdes, and the more it ≈øtormeth & is foule weather, the more Birds you ≈øhall ≈øee, and if you ≈øee many, then be a≈ø≈øured you are farre from the land, and when you loo≈øe the ≈øight of them, then looke well to your ≈øelfe, for the clo≈øer you are by the land, you loo≈øe the ≈øight of them altogether, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee the blacke Rauens with white billes, & the neerer you are to the land the more you ≈øhall ≈øee of them, although they are likewi≈øe ≈øeene at the lea≈øt 20. miles from the ≈øhore, but feare not, when you begin to come to the Iland of S. Laurence, but hold the cour≈øe aboue≈øaid, and when you beginne to di≈øcouer the mouth of the Chanel, betweene Saint Laurence and Mo≈øambique, then you pre≈øently find the runing of the ≈øtreame towards the Cape de Bona Speranza, and feare not in that country to hold your cour≈øe ≈øouthwe≈øt for commonly after you haue the wind ≈øouth, and as much as you haue runne we≈øt Northwe≈øt, ≈øo much you haue furthered your way, but take heede you keepe ≈øtill from the coa≈øt, and ≈øo you will make a better Viage, for the ≈øtreame will driue you to the Cape although the wind helpeth you not, and this is to bee vnder≈øtoode, that when you come late from Cochin, you ≈øhall alwaies thereabout finde great We≈øt windes, al≈øo you mu≈øt know, that (in March and Aprill, all the way from the furthe≈øt point of Saint Laurence to the Cape) commonly there bloweth North and Northea≈øt winds, and if for a day or two it bloweth out of the Southea≈øt, or South, it is a great wonder, therefore make no account of it, for at tho≈øe times they blowe verie ≈øeldome, in all the way afore≈øaide to the Cape, and the n√©erer you come to the Cape you find the more northerly windes, but when the North wind commeth mi≈øt and fl√©et, then be ≈øure of We≈øt windes, for it is the nature of them in tho≈øe countries, and you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that if you arriue in tho≈øe countries in a Schrickel yeare (for they are much more dangerous then other years, becau≈øe the coniunction of the heauenly Planets and bodies as then are different, as al≈øo the inferiour bodies, that are ≈øubiect to the ≈øuperiour, whereby they are gouerned:) then you ≈øhall finde from 30. degr√©es vpwards, that as ≈øoone as you haue a northerly winde with a ≈ømall or mi≈øeling rayne, that there followeth great and foule weather, then looke well to your ≈øelfe, and take great h√©ede, lea≈øt it fall not ≈øuddainely vppon you, for it by vnadui≈øednes it ≈øhould fall forwards vpon you, it were not po≈ø≈øible for you to find any meanes to keepe your ≈øelfe from being ouerwhelmed in the ≈øea without the ≈øpeciall fauour of God, for that they come with mo≈øt great furie and outragiou≈øly, but if you chance in the beginning of Februarie to bee by the furthe≈øt point of S. Laurence 70. or 80. miles, inward to the Sea, then take your cour≈øe to the Cape Das Agulhas, for then you ≈øhall find the windes alwaies Southea≈øt, ≈øo you pa≈ø≈øe not further into the Sea then 36. degrees, which Nauigation you ≈øhall make departing out of India, in the ninth of December, you haue ground by the Cape Das Agulhas at twentie and twentie fiue miles from the land at a hundred and a hundred and thirtie Fadome d√©epe, vnder thirtie ≈øixe degrees and a halfe.

div.head: The 9. Chapter. The Nauigation or cour≈øe from Monte De ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n to Portingal, which is the chiefe hill in India, and lyeth in the countrie of Malabar, ≈øixe miles Northwarde from Cananor, and from Goa ≈øixtie one miles Southward.
div.p:
DEparting from the hill or Monte Delijn towards Portingall, by the way without the Iland of Saint Laurence ≈øo ≈øet you Northea≈øt, & ≈øouthwe≈øt, with the hill Monte Delijn, taking your cour≈øe Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt, and by South, and then you ≈øhall come by an Iland lying vnder 10. degr√©es and a halfe, fiftie miles from Monte Delijn, and then you mu≈øt take your cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and then you ≈øhal come 25. miles beyond this Iland, vnder the hight of 9. degr√©es and frac34;. taking care not to goe more ≈øouthward towardes the Iland of Maldiua, from whence halfe a mile it is d√©ep and faire, and as ≈øoone as you are pa≈øt this Iland whether it be early or late in the yeare, then runne ≈øouthwe≈øt and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by South, vntill you haue pa≈øt the line, and if there you finde the wind We≈øt, then runne South, and South and by We≈øt, if you can, if not ≈øouthward, which is a good way, and in this cour≈øe you hold fr√©ely without feare, if in this cour≈øe from 13. degr√©es vpwards, you find diuers Birdes called Garagiaus, flying in companies together, feare not therefore to follow your cour≈øe, & being late in the yeare, then alwaies keepe on the South ≈øide, thereby to auoide the drougthes called O ‚Ä¢ Baixos de Lopo Soares, and Garagiaus, lying vnder 16. degr√©es holding this cour≈øe you may boldly ≈øayle both by day and night, for you ≈øhall find no let as I my ≈øelfe haue well tryed. The 16. degr√©es not being pa≈øt, you mu≈øt al≈øo pa≈ø≈øe betweene the drougthes afore≈øaid, and the Iland of Brandaon, and comming to the hight, there loo≈øe a nights ≈øayle to bee the ≈øurer, and make your account that when you find many Birdes called Garagiaus, with other ≈øpeckled Birdes among them, flying in companies together, then you are 40. miles beyond the Ilande, from whence you ≈øhall ≈øaile ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by South, for certaine meale tides, and it being early in the yeare, when you ≈øet ≈øayle from India, then auoide all tho≈øe Ilands and drougthes, and take your cour≈øe to Sea wards towards the Cape Das Agulhas, and if it chance that about the ≈øeuenth of Februarie you find your ≈øelfe 100. miles little more or le≈ø≈øe, from the furthe≈øt point of the Iland of S. Laurence, that is vnder his hight as I haue b√©ene, then runne We≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt vntill you bee vnder the hight of the Cape de Bona Speranza, take h√©ede to the ≈øtreame, that might deceiue you, becau≈øe there in Februarie, they runne verie ≈øwift, by rea≈øon of the Ea≈øt windes which as then blow verie ≈øwiftly, & ≈øo runne your cour≈øe to the Cape de Bona Speranza till you be vnder 36. degr√©es and a halfe, and when you are by the Cape Das Agulhas, then looke when it is noone by the A≈øtrolabe, and if as then it is likewi≈øe noone by the ≈øunne Diall, or not wanting aboue the thickne≈ø≈øe of a thr√©ede, then it is a good ≈øigne, as well outward, as comming backe to Portingall, for ther the n√©edles of the Compa≈ø≈øe are right and a like, and being vpon the one ≈øide or the other, they will lie either Northea≈øt ward, or Northwe≈øt ward, as you are pa≈øt the Meridionall line, and ≈øo much it differeth from equalitie with the Sunne Diall, al≈øo when you come to the Cape Das Agulhas, or further forward, then looke vpon the water, and if it be gr√©ene, then turne backe againe vnder 36. degr√©es and a halfe, and ca≈øt foorth your Lead, and you ≈øhall find 30. fadome deepe, and being vnder 36. degr√©es 2/ ‚Ä¢ . degr√©es you ≈øhall find 90. fadome, and then you ≈øhall not ≈ø√©e many blacke Rauens with white billes, nor Alcatra≈øes, but on both ≈øides of the Cape Das Agulhas you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e many, both on the coa≈øt and 20. miles to Sea ward, but not further, and you ≈øhall find the water (≈øo that you be not vpon the depthes afore≈øaid) light and gr√©eni≈øh, as al≈øo ≈øome of the Sa≈ø-been driuing in the water, and as ≈øoone as you haue found grounds, without ≈ø√©eing the land of Cape de Bona Speranza, then runne ≈øtill along by this ground till you loo≈øe it, and then bee a≈ø≈øured that you are pa≈øt the Cape Das Agulhaas, then holde your cour≈øe We≈øt Northwe≈øt, and ≈øo you ≈øhall find 12. miles from the Cape, and when you begin to leaue it, then you ≈øhall begin to ≈ø√©e thicke Reedes ≈øwimming vppon the water, for the ≈øpace of ten or fift√©ene miles from thence. In the cour≈øe afore≈øaid, and when you ≈ø√©e them, it is a good tooken and you may be a≈ø≈øured to haue pa≈øt the Cape de Bona Speranza, when you are by the Cape Das Agulhas then marke the Sunne Diall, and the water of the ground, and they will ≈øhew you when you are there, for by this Cape, the n√©edles of the Compa≈ø≈øes are fix and euen, and within or without that Cape, they lie either Northea≈øtward or Northwe≈øt ward, as I ≈øaid before, the Nauigation from the Cape
de Bona Speranza to Portingal is without danger to the Equinoctiall, for that you alwaies find a Southea≈øt wind, and from the line to Portingall it is dayly ≈øayled, whereby it is commonly knowne to euerie ≈øimple Pilot, yet ≈øuch as are de≈øirous to know it, may ≈ø√©e it in this Booke, where it is ≈øet downe, as al≈øo in mine owne Viage from India to Portingall where it is particularly declared till you come to the towne of Lisbone.

div.head: The 10. Chapter. Of the right tokens and knowledge of the Cape Das Correntes and the Ilands as Ilhas Premeiras and of all the Hauens and coa≈øts of Mo≈øambique.
div.p:
THe bankes of Soffala begin at the Cape de S. Ba≈øtian, and reach to the Ilands Primeras all along the coa≈øt, and the coa≈øt lyeth North and South to Soffala, and hath ≈øomwhat of North and We≈øt, & South and Ea≈øt, herein are ≈øome ryuers, but onely fit for ≈ømall ≈øhippes, the ryuer called Mataca, or Monemone lyeth vnder 21. degr√©es and a halfe, it is a ≈ømall ryuer, beeing at high water within the Hauen but thr√©e Fadome d√©epe, and for a marke hath a high tr√©e ≈øtanding on the South ≈øide, and along the ≈øhore ≈øome Sandie dounes, which in ≈øight ≈øhew like Ilands without tr√©es, on the North ≈øide lie certaine ≈øhallowes, you enter into the Hauen Northwe≈øt on, that is on the ≈øide where the tr√©es ≈øtand, and there as you are within the point you may Anker at fiue and ≈øixe fadome d√©epe. Quiloan or Quiloane lyeth vnder 20. degr√©es and a halfe, and on the South ≈øide hath a high Palme tr√©e, and the land on the ≈øame ≈øide is like a hooke, and if you de≈øire to put into Quiloane, although it were with a ≈øhippe of foure hundred tunnes, you may well doe it, being high water, but you mu≈øt take heede of a drougth, lying thr√©e myles from the Hauen. This Hauen at high water is fiue Fadome d√©epe, and when you are in hard by the point of the ryuer you find fiue or ≈øixe Fadome water, with muddie ground, you enter therein We≈øt, Southwe≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and the drougthes afore≈øaide lie Ea≈øt, Southea≈øt and We≈øt Southwe≈øt like Quiloane. From Mataca or M ‚Ä¢ nemone to Quiloane you ≈øhall ≈øee land, at thirteene or fourteen fadome d√©epe, and beeing vnder 21 degrees and 60 fadome deepe, then you ≈øhall be fifteen myles from the land, & ≈øhall find Corall vpon the ground, and from thence inward ≈ømall ≈øands, ≈øayling from Quiloane to Soffala you mu≈øt runne North and north and by Ea≈øt, without the poynt or hooke, til you be at 12 or 13 fadome d√©epe, and till you ≈ø√©e Soffala: and if you de≈øire to ≈øtay there, then runne till you be vnder 6. or 7. fadome, which is 6. or 7. miles from the land: the Hauen of Soffala changeth euerie yeare, therefore you can not put into it without one of the countrie Pilots, and it hath for a marke a companie of palme trees ≈øtanding together on the north ≈øide: & ≈øailing froÃÑ thence to Mo≈øambique, you mu≈øt runne Ea≈øt, till you come to fourty fadome water, and from thence Ea≈øt north ea≈øt, running fift√©ene or ≈øixt√©ene myles from the Ilandes Primeiras, you ≈øhall alwaies in the≈øe countries all along the coa≈øt, find ≈ømal, thinne, blacke ≈øand, mixed with the earth, although you ≈øayle clo≈øe in ≈øight of the land. Soffala lieth vnder twentie degrees, and the Hauen called Bango vnder nynt√©ene and ¬Ω, and the riuer of Cuama vnder eight√©ene and
‚Ä¢ /4: and you runne along the Coa≈øt from Soffala to Cuama, North Ea≈øt and South We≈øt, beeing thirtie myles, and if you haue occa≈øion to enter into the Riuer of Cuama, to take in fre≈øh water, you mu≈øt enter with a ≈ømall Boate, for within it is all fre≈øh water, from Cuama to the Ilandes of Primeiras, you runne along the coa≈øt ea≈øt and We≈øt, and ≈øomewhat Ea≈øt and by north and We≈øt and by South. There are two ≈øights of land, and beeing vnder eighteene degrees, you finde therne fyue fadome deepe in ≈øight of land, for the Bankes in tho≈øe Countries are verie ≈ømall: the cour≈øe is fiftie miles. The Riuer called Dos Bonis Sinais or of good tokens lyeth vnder ≈øeuent√©ene degrees and ¬æ, and hath the≈øe markes, that is vppon the North ea≈øt ≈øyde: at the mouth of the Hauen there ≈øtandeth an heap of tr√©es, and on the ≈øouth ≈øyde it hath a ≈øandie ≈øtrand, and vppon the furthe≈øt poynt outwardes, there is a ≈øand Hill or Downes, which farre off ≈øheweth like an Iland: the entrie is on the South We≈øt ≈øyde, along by the ≈øand: the Hauen at the mouth with lowe water is two fadome, and beeing within it you may ly at 6. or 7. fadome water: you can not ≈øee the entrie as you are without, but on the North We≈øt ≈øyde you ≈øee the begynning of the land, that hath a heape of trees ≈øtanding vppon it, which a farre off ≈øhowe like the Ma≈øte of a ≈øhippe, and the neerer you drawe to the land, the le≈ø≈øe you ≈øee thereof, ≈øo
that beeing in the Riuer, you ≈øee nothing at all, becau≈øe it is hindered by the other branches. The Channell of the Ilandes Primenas, and of the Ilandes of Angoxas are all one, and you ≈øayle Ea≈øt, North ea≈øt, and We≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt, and it is 30 myles, with tenne or twelue fadome deepe, and neerer to the Ilandes then to the firme land, and if you will ≈øtay by one of the≈øe Ilandes with a We≈øt wind, you may freelie inough goe clo≈øe vnto it, for it is deepe and pa≈ø≈øing good ground.

The fir≈øt of ye Ilands of Primeiras lyeth vnder 17 degrees & ¬Ω, & if you de≈øire to run betw√©ene them, then runne Southwe≈øt from the Iland, and you ≈øhall freelie enter the chanell without feare, for it is d√©epe inough, for the drougthes lye a myle and a half di≈øtant from the Iland: and if you de≈øire to put in there with a we≈øt wind, then goe clo≈øe to the Iland, running to the middle therof‚ñ™ towards the ≈øouth ≈øyde, where you may anker, within the length of a great ≈øhot, at 6 or 7 fadome d√©epe, and de≈øiring to pa≈ø≈øe either in or out betw√©ene the droughtes (which lie Northea≈øt) you may very well doe it, and though you beare all your ≈øayles, k√©eping alwaies n√©erer the ≈øand of the Iland, then to the droughthes in the middle Iland, for it is all one vpoÃÑ what ≈øyde of the Iland you ≈øayle, for there is no cau≈øe of feare, but onlie where you ≈ø√©e the water breake: and de≈øiring to anker by the middle Iland, you may fr√©ely doe it, and that clo≈øe by it, for it is 12 fadome d√©epe at low water with a We≈øt wind, but not with an Ea≈øt wind: in the middle way, on that ≈øide which lyeth again≈øt the firme land, there ≈øtandeth a heape of trees, by the which you ≈øhall find a lake of fre≈øh water to ≈øerue you, if nece≈ø≈øitie requireth, and lyeth a little inward from the ≈øtrand, and if you can not well goe farre inward to the lake, doe but digge in the ≈øtrand, and you ≈øhall pre≈øentie find fre≈øh water, but it mu≈øt be when it is an ea≈øt wind‚ñ™ for with a We≈øt wind the water ≈øtriketh with ≈øo great a force vpon the ≈øhore, that you are not able to ≈øtay there with your boate. The middle Iland, which lyeth North ea≈øt hath no pa≈ø≈øage at all to the ≈øea, but from thence to the drouthes called Acoroa de S. Antonio are ≈øeuen miles, and to the fir≈øt Iland of Angoxa fyue miles, and is all one cour≈øe with the Ilandes: you may fr√©elie pa≈ø≈øe by the land, with what ≈øhippe ≈øo euer you will, for it is d√©epe inough: all the Ilandes of Angoxas haue thorow fares, one running through the other, al d√©ep and good ground: ≈øo that there is betw√©ene the Ilandes and the firme land, at the lea≈øt eight fadome d√©epe, but you mu≈øt alwaies ≈øayle n√©erer the firme land then the Ilandes. There lyeth a ≈øandie drougth betw√©ene the Iland of Angoxa, which likewi≈øe is to bee ≈øayled on both ≈øides. The≈øe Ilandes of Angoxas are 4, and betw√©en the two middle Ilandes ly the afore≈øaid ≈øand drougthes, wherfore I wi≈øh you not to go too n√©ere them, for they are dangerous. There lieth a ≈øand drougth 4. miles from the fir≈øt Iland of Angoxa towardes Mo≈øambique, which euerie ≈øpringtide is couered with the ≈øea, hauing other ≈øandes round about it, that are alwaies couered with the ≈øea, therefore I wi≈øh you to take h√©ed of them: you may from thence runne along the ≈øhore, where it is d√©epe water, from the≈øe drougthes 14 or 15 miles towardes Mo≈øambique, there is a haueÃÑ, called Os Coaraias, that is the Corales, from the which hauen about a mile and a half into the ≈øea lieth a clif, which is very dangerous, and which a man can hardly ≈øhunne till he be almo≈øt vpon it, and with a Springtide the water breaketh not ouer it, wherefore you mu≈øt take h√©ed vnto it, for many ≈øhippes haue ≈øtriken vpon it, and Don Ioan Periera fell vpon it: when you pa≈ø≈øe it, you mu≈øt put 3 miles from it into ye ≈ø√©a, North ea≈øt & northea≈øt & by Ea≈øt, being by night, but by day you may ≈øayl wt more ≈øecuritie, and looke about you, yet nothing going neerer to the ≈øhore then 25 fadome d√©epe: in this cour≈øe you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe by the drouthes of Mu≈øicatte, and following your cour≈øe North ea≈øt, you ≈øhall come right vpon the Ilands of Mo≈øambique: if you haue occa≈øion to anker before you come to Mu≈øicatte, then keepe off from the cliffe towards the land, til you be at 15 fadome, and there you may anker, for it is good grouÃÑd, yet but in few places, only vnder the point of Mu≈øicatte, at 20 fadome and more, you ≈øhall haue faire ground: the point of Mu≈øicatte lieth with the Ilands of Angoxas North ea≈øt and South we≈øt, being 18 miles di≈øtant: from theÃÑce to Mo≈øambique you runne North ea≈øt along the coa≈øt: the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Iland Premeira lyeth with the drongthes Northea≈øt & South we≈øt and ≈øome what North ea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and South we≈øt and by We≈øt: the land of the Ilandes Premeiras, on the ≈øide of Mo≈øambique lyeth vnder 16 degrees and and ¬æ & you runne along by tho≈øe Ilands and ≈øands, Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and Ea≈øt by North and We≈øt & by ≈øouth: and if there you find your ≈øelf to bee inwards at 12 or 13 foote and le≈ø≈øe, within a length of a great ≈øhot of the Ilands, yet bee not aba≈øhed, but beware of the out≈øide, which is full of ≈øtones and other filth, whereby no meanes you can anker, as being nothing but wood & ≈øton ‚Ä¢ : if you chance to be in the middle way betw√©ene the Ilands & the drougths, with an Ea≈øt wind, then you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe in
& out betweene the fir≈øt Iland & the drougth, which Iland lyeth in middle way from the Ilands Premieras, on the ≈øide of So ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ala, as al≈øo from the third Iland towardes Mo≈øambique, running along the We≈øt ≈øide at 7.10 & 12 fadome d√©epe: the other drougthes lie in the middle way, vnder the ≈øtone cliffes, therefore you n√©ed not feare them, but betw√©ene the Iland from the trees, that are vpon the Ea≈øt ≈øide, you can by no meanes pa≈ø≈øe, for it is all ouer nothing but droughthes and ≈øhallowes. From the South we≈øt ≈øide of the≈øe Ilands Premieras, and Northea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt, with the fir≈øt Iland, 7 miles from it there lyeth a ≈øand drougth of foure fadome d√©epe, hoth in leÃÑgth & breadth, the cariage of a great ≈øhotte in length tenne or twelue myles from the Ilands Premieras, lieth the Riuer Quilimani, where the Coa≈øt reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and ≈øomewhat Ea≈øt & by North, and We≈øt and by ≈øouth, and you ≈øhall find 6 or 7 fadome d√©epe within three miles of the land, where you find no other drougthes then that of Quilimani, which you mu≈øt take h√©ed of, for they reach 6. or 7. miles into the ≈øea, and if you find your ≈øelf inwards from Cauo das Correntes, you may at all times anker, for it is good ground, becau≈øe you are vpon the banks, and haue no cau≈øe to feare, becau≈øe the wind blowing from the land wil alwaies helpe you, whereby you may put into the ≈øea, as you thinke good.

div.head: The 11. Chapter. The cour≈øe from India to Porto Piqueno de S. Iago, that is the ≈ømal hauen of S. Iacob, which is the mouth of the Riuer Ganges lying in the kingdome of Bengala.
div.p:
HE that de≈øireth to ≈øayle from India to Po ‚Ä¢ to Piqueno or the ≈ømall hauen, lying in BeÃÑgala, I mean outward about the Iland of Seylon, he mu≈øt ≈øet ≈øayle out of the Hauen of Cochiin betweene the which and the 20. of Aprill, holding his cour≈øe along the ≈øhore, to a place called Briniao, which lieth vpon the Cape or poynt of Comoriin, (that is the furthe≈øt poynt or end of the Indian coa≈øt, ≈øouthwe≈øtward) & from thence holding his cour≈øe ≈øouth, till he be vnder 6 degr√©es & ¬æ, and from thence South ea≈øt to 5 degr√©es and ‚Öî, and being ther he mu≈øt runne Ea≈øt, till hee ≈øeeth the Iland of Seylon, for the point of Seylon called A Ponte de Gualla (that is the poynt of the Galley) is the farthe≈øt land from thence lying in the ≈øouth, vnder 6 degrees: therefore if you hold your cour≈øe Ea≈øt, till you be vnder 5 degrees and ‚Öî, you can not fayle to ≈øee the land of the Iland Seylon: this way and cour≈øe you mu≈øt alwaies hold, ≈øetting out of Coch ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , from the 10. of Aprill, to the 20. of the ≈øame, (as I ≈øayd before,) for yf you depart later from thence, you mu≈øt ≈øtay longer, becau≈øe as then the wind beginneth to blow ≈øtifly out of the South, at other tymes hauing the wind Southwe≈øt, and Northwe≈øt, blowing verie ≈øtrong and blu≈øtering: wheÃÑ you ≈ø√©e the Iland Seylon, you ≈øhall ≈øayle along the coa≈øt, Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and ≈øomewhat Ea≈øt & by North, and We≈øt and by ≈øouth, to the fir≈øt drougth lying ≈øcar≈øe vnder 6. degrees, and the other drougths ly farther vnder 6 degr. & ¬Ω 7 miles di≈øtant one from the other, in the ≈øame cour≈øe of Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, and We≈øt and by ≈øouth, from the point A Punta de Gualla to the fir≈øt drougth, are almo≈øt 28 miles. Beeing 10 or 15 myles beyond the drougthes, you ≈øhall ≈øayle Northea≈øt, till you bee vnder 16 degrees and ¬Ω, from thence running North, whereby you ≈øhall come to the Coa≈øt of the firme land, about tenne or twelue myles from the land, called O pagode de Iorganatte (that is the Idole or Idoles Temple of Iorganatte, which is a verie good cour≈øe for this voyage: when you perceiue this land, which hath certaine high Hilles, you ≈øhall ≈øee ≈øome round Houels, that are rounder and higher then the Hilles, ≈øtanding vppon them, called Palur, by the which you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe along Northea≈øt, and Southwe≈øt, and ≈øomewhat northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by ≈øouth, vntill you come to the thinne and low land, and pa≈ø≈øing by it, you ≈øhall come to a Riuer, which hath for a marke a flat high field of ≈øand, and an other plaine with a houell, hauing on the one ≈øide ≈øomewhat further in the ≈øhew of an other thicke Houell with tr√©es, and k√©eping on your cour≈øe til you come right ouer again≈øt ye riuer, theÃÑ the houels ≈ø√©em to be right ouer again≈øt the other thicke laÃÑd: it ≈øheweth thus when you are about a myle & ¬Ω & to the ≈øea ward from it: froÃÑ this riuer to the fir≈øt Pagode or Idole, there is about three or foure myles, and from this Pagode forward you finde no more high hils, like that you haue pa≈øt before, and pa≈ø≈øing ≈øtraight from thence ≈øome of them ≈øhew as if they had tables or plaines vpoÃÑ them: this Pagode lieth ful vnder 20 degr. your be≈øt way is alwaies to looke out for it, as being requi≈øite for you thereby to make a good voiage: beyoÃÑd this fir≈øt Pagode, there ≈øtaÃÑdeth an other Pagode,
as great as the fir≈øt, with 2 or 3 ≈ømall Pagodes ≈øtanding ≈øomewhat further: from ye fir≈øt Pagode to ye ≈øecoÃÑd is about 4 miles, and the coa≈øt from the one to the other lyeth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, here you mu≈øt not k√©epe too clo≈øe to the ≈øhore, for you ≈øhall hardly put off again becau≈øe it maketh a cr√©eke, likewi≈øe before you come to the fir≈øt Pagode you mu≈øt k√©epe off from the land, becau≈øe two miles before you come at it, there lyeth a ≈ømall drougth, ≈øtretching a mile into the Sea. From the fir≈øt Pagode to the ≈øeconde, you ≈ø√©e certaine houels and tr√©es, and from the ≈øecond Pagode to Sataguan, it is a lower land, all wa≈øte and wilde ground, being altogether bare to the point called a Punta das Palmerias (that is the point of the Palme trees, and you run We≈øt along the coa≈øt, from the Pagode afore≈øaid, to a point with a Riffe (lying 12. miles from the point of Palmerias) there lyeth a riuer, the point afore≈øaide reacheth a great halfe mile into the Sea, you runne along the coa≈øt Northea≈øt, and from the afore≈øaid Riffe point to the Palmerias, the coa≈øt runneth Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and to knowe the Riffe and the lande thereof you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the land of the Riffe, is greater and thicker then the other land of the Cliffe, and maketh ≈øhow of an Iland, and pre≈øently ≈øomwhat further you ≈øhall ≈øee nine or ten trees, ≈øhewing like round houels, from the Pagode to this Riffe are about 12. miles, from thence forward you ≈øhall runne along the coa≈øt at nine & ten fadome deepe, vntill you come to the ≈øaid Palmerias, whereof the fore part of the land is verie low, hauing a bare houel, which ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe like the Arenas Gordas, or redde Downes, lying by Saint Lucas de Barameda, in the coa≈øt of Spaine, froÃÑ this donne or houel to the Palmerias, it is altogether a low and bare land without any trees or bu≈øhes, the Palmerias were wont to be ten or twelue Palme trees, now there is but one, hard by the ≈øame Palmerias on the ≈øide of Sataguan there ≈øtande certaine Houels, and from thence forwards, you haue no pointes, hookes, trees, nor any more bu≈øhes, but the land for a mile way is nothing but like a Riffe. And when you ≈øee the point of Palmerias, then you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe Ea≈øt, vntill you bee 12. Fadome deepe, and from thence Northea≈øt, till you find eight Fadome and a halfe, and being in the daye time, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈øee land, which ≈øhal be beneath all the Riffes, and if the land be couered with any dampes or mi≈øtes, you ≈øhall then not ≈øee it before you bee at 4. fadome deepe. This cour≈øe you ≈øhall hold with a Compa≈ø≈øe, that faileth not, for if it doth, you mu≈øt make your reckening thereafter, this land whereby you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe is a flat low land, without either bu≈øh or tree, and pa≈ø≈øing forward along the coa≈øt, you ≈øhall vpon the Ea≈øt ≈øide perceiue a long blacke Houel, like a Champana without a Ma≈øt (which is an Indian Caruell) and ≈øomewhat further from this Houell, there are a companie of tr√©es, which are about thr√©e or foure, that ≈øhew greater then the houell, the≈øe trees ≈øtand ≈øomewhat low, and a little from the≈øe trees beginneth the Riffe of the countrie of Orixa, which hauing ≈øeene, you ≈øhal pre≈øently ≈øee the water to Seaward breake, which is vpon the drougthes of Bengalen, for there the Chanell is ≈ømale≈øt, and behind you leaue many Riffes on the ≈øide of Bengalen, which doe all lie to Sea ward, wherefore you cannot ≈øee them, and pa≈ø≈øing by them, you approach the Riffe of the land of Orixa, for although you ≈øayle clo≈øe by, you neede not feare other then that you ≈øee before your eyes, the depth is three Fadome, with ≈ømall blacke Sand in the bottome. On Bengalen ≈øide you ≈øhall haue foure or fiue fadome water with muddie grounde, on the which ≈øide you mu≈øt not goe, for that beyond that muddie ground, you ≈øhould come to a banke of Sa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , comming from Bengalen, when you find this ground, you ≈øhall (if n√©ed be) come Northea≈øt and by North, vntil you be at thr√©e fadome, for this is the right way, the afore≈øaid Riffe of Orixa being pa≈øt, you ≈øhall pre≈øently find more depth, and if you de≈øire to runne along by the land of Orixa, then ≈øet your cour≈øe right vpon the fir≈øt point, that you ≈ø√©e before you, the lea≈øt depth you ≈øhall find is thr√©e fadome, which is the right way vntill you be clo≈øe by the land, where you ≈øhal find 5. or 6. fadome d√©epe, and if you n√©ede any wood to burne, then goe on the other ≈øide of the land of Bengalen, for there the wood is better then on the ≈øide of Orixa, but hauing done you mu≈øt again put to the ≈øide of Orixa vntill you bee pa≈øt two ryuers, lying on the ≈øame ≈øide of Orixa, whereof the fir≈øt is liker a Cr√©eke then a ryuer, the other lyeth about a mile further in, which hath a great mouth or entrie, two or thr√©e miles further beyond that Riuer, there are ≈øome flowing Beken with trees, & a mile beyond them, there is woode or wilderne≈ø≈øe full of thicke trees, like Palme trees, from the beginning whereof you mu≈øt cro≈ø≈øe ouer to the other ≈øide of the land, called Guinette) right vppon a tree, ≈øtanding on the ≈øame ≈øide, which is higher then all the re≈øt, and ≈øtandeth on the left ≈øide of the riuer called Chandecan, from thence forwarde it is all ≈øhallowes, wherefore you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe
further therabouts with a ful ≈øea, if you de≈øire to pa≈ø≈øe through the channell of the land, you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe as I ≈øaid before, & from Palmieras to the Northea≈øt, you may runne at fiue fadome, and being by day you ≈øhall runne at thr√©e fadomes, and running at this depth along by the land, although you come ≈øometime to le≈ø≈øe depth, yet you n√©ede not feare, with the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the Riffe of Orixa, and when you ≈ø√©e it, you ≈øhal make towardes it, and make 2/ ‚Ä¢ : parts of the way towards the land, and a third part towards the Riffe, and ≈øo you haue the right way as afore≈øaid.

div.head: The 12. Chapter. An other de≈øcription of the ≈øame cour≈øe, from India to Porto Piqueno, or the ≈ømall Hauen of Bengalen, ≈øet downe by an other Pilot, large and better de≈øcribed, with the whole ≈øituation and cour≈øe thereof.
div.p:
SAyling from the coa≈øt of India to the hauen called Porto Piqueno, in the kingdom of Bengalen, outward about the Ilande of Zeylon, you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe along the coa≈øt of India, till you come to ≈ø√©e Briniaon lying by the Cape de Comorin, which is the furthe≈øt point of the land of India, from thence taking your way cro≈ø≈øe ouer, for from thence forward it is a good countrie, and make the ≈øhorte≈øt cro≈ø≈øe you can, thereby to goe ≈øure, and not to fall inwards, or betw√©ene the Iland of Zeylon, and when you ≈ø√©e Barreias, which are the Dounes of Briniaon afore≈øaid then you ≈øhal ≈øayle Southward running ≈øo at the lea≈øt fift√©ene or twentie myles, and from thence forward you ≈øhall ≈øhorten your way, as you thinke be≈øt to get vnder fiue degr√©es, and being there, you ≈øhall ≈øayle Ea≈øtwarde, as much as you thinke conuenient, that you may be a≈ø≈øured to pa≈ø≈øe the point of Gualle. which is the furthe≈øt point of the Iland of Zeylon on the Southwe≈øt ≈øide, lying vnder ≈øixe degrees, when you thinke you are at the point de Gualle, to be a≈ø≈øured thereof, make towards the Iland, to know it, before you come to the drougths, betw√©ene Tanadare (which is fyue myles from Punta de Gualla) and the fir≈øt drouth, where commonlie all the ≈øhippes know the land, ≈øuch I ≈øay as wee ≈øayle to Bengalen, or to any of the Hauens thereof, as Porto Piqueno, or Porto Grande, that is, the ≈ømall or the great Hauen, where the Portingalles doe traffique, and hauing ≈øight of the land of the ≈øayd countrie, goe as clo≈øe vnto it as you will, but not pa≈ø≈øing aboue twelue fadome d√©epe towards the land, becau≈øe there ly certaine cliffes along the ≈øhore, whereof we know not certainely the danger, be≈øides the ≈øandes, betw√©ene the which and the land you may pa≈ø≈øe through, as hereafter ≈øhal be ≈øhewed, and ≈øayling thus as I haue ≈øayd, along the ≈øhore, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the land of Tanadare is for the ≈øpace of fyue myles to the Drougthes on the ≈øea ≈øyde altogether lowe land, and when you are further to landward in, you begin to ≈øee certaine hilles, that is thr√©e great hilles, right again≈øt it, and then you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e the fir≈øt drougth, betw√©ene the which and the laÃÑd you may well pa≈ø≈øe, for that mo≈øt of the ≈øhips that goe and come by the Iland, run through that way: in the middle way you ≈øhall finde betw√©ene it and the land 11. and 12. fadome d√©epe, of faire, & in ≈øome places ≈øtony ground, and you n√©ed not feare any thing, but onelie that you ≈øee before your eyes. This fir≈øt drougth or ≈øand lieth full vnder 6 degr√©es and ¬Ω and right again≈øt it vpon the land, you ≈øee a houell ≈øtanding alone, and no more in all that country to be ≈ø√©ene, 6 miles further from that fir≈øt great drougth: there lieth an other ≈ømall drougth, which is di≈øtant, Northea≈øt, & Southwe≈øt, and ≈øomewhat northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by We≈øt: this ≈ømall drought lieth vnder 6 degr√©es and ¬º, about 2 miles from the land: and if you de≈øire to runne betw√©ene it and the land, you may well doe it, for it is ‚Ä¢ or 6 fadome d√©epe at low water, with ≈øandie ground, which I know by tho≈øe that haue pa≈ø≈øed that way aboue 30. tymes, as well going as comming backe again, but if your ≈øhip be great, then it is better to ≈øayle about further into the ≈øea. Tho≈øe drougths or ≈øandes b√©eing pa≈øt, then runne along by the land, and neuer put from it, for it is your be≈øt cour≈øe to goe clo≈øe by it, and pa≈ø≈øing by the Iland of the hilles, and the high land, you ≈øhall ≈øee a high ≈øharpe Hill among others from whence there runneth a point that lieth out towardes the Southwe≈øt. This hill is called O Capello de Frade, that is, the Fryers coule, and lieth full vnder 8 degr√©es: I ≈øet not downe the cour≈øe you mu≈øt commonlie v≈øe to take along the Coa≈øt to the ≈øaid Capello de Frade, becau≈øe you come vpon no direct line: this fryers coule maketh a point of laÃÑd, froÃÑ ye
whence there runneth a Riffe about halfe a mile into the ≈øea, whereon in ≈øome places you may ≈øee the water breake from this point to Trinquanamale are 17. miles, and you run by the coa≈øt north and ≈øouth, which is all low land with a bankie ground, and from thence you ≈øhall ≈øee no land, but the land that lieth inward fiue miles. Before you come to Trinquanamale you finde a ≈ømall riuer. Trinquanamale is a great hauen, beeing in the entrey more then 3. miles in bredth, & all low land, but very d√©epe round about, he that will anker therein may lie vnder certaine Ilands, and inward it maketh a riuer that runneth to Seyta vaqua, the other to it is all low land, to know Trinquanamale a farre off, at the mouth thereof on the north ≈øide, lieth a yellow Sandie Downe, and hath vpon one of the hookes or pointes, two long hilles ri≈øing vp, and reaching inwardes to the couÃÑtrie, and no other high land, neither behinde them, nor before theÃÑ in all that coa≈øt, comming by Trinquanamale, and hauing knowne it, you mu≈øt then pre≈øently cro≈ø≈øe ouer, for there it is be≈øt to follow your cour≈øe, and from thence you mu≈øt runne North, and North and by ea≈øt, alwaies reckning the declining or winding of the compa≈ø≈øe, and if it be in the mon≈øons of the winds, in the month of Augu≈øt, then you ≈øhall ≈øayle full north, becau≈øe as then the ≈øtreame runneth very ≈øtroÃÑg into the ≈øea, and this cour≈øe you ≈øhall hold till you come vnder 17. degrees, which is the heigth of the point called a Punta de Guado variin, lying on the coa≈øt of Choramandel, which is the beginning of the kingdome of Orixa, and being vnder 17. degrees, from thence you ≈øhall put to the coa≈øt of the Firme land, to make a good voiage, alwaies taking care not to run aboue 19. degr√©es & ¬Ω without ≈ø√©eing land, becau≈øe that vnder 19. degr√©es, there lieth a riuer called Puacota, froÃÑ the mouth whereof 3. miles into the ≈øea, there lieth a rocke or ≈øtonie cliffe of the length of a ≈øhip, which may ea≈øily be ≈øeene, for it lieth aboue the water, you may pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene it and the land without danger of any thing but only that which you ≈ø√©e before your eyes, all this coa≈øt from the point of Guadovariin, is altogether great thicke land, and hilles which may bee ≈ø√©ene far off from the riuer of Puacota, to another riuer called Paluor or Palura are 12. miles, and you runne by the coa≈øt Northea≈øt, and Southwe≈øt, aboue this riuer of Palura there lieth a verie high hill, called a Seira de Palura, that is the hill of Palura, which is the highe≈øt hill in all that coa≈øt. This riuer lieth full vnder 19. degrees, and ¬Ω from this riuer to the point called a Derradeira terra alta, that is, the la≈øt high land, you keep the ≈øame cour≈øe along the ≈øhore, and is in length ≈øeauen miles, and lieth full vnder ninet√©ene degrees, and ‚Öî. I ≈øet downe this de≈øcription of the la≈øt high land, becau≈øe ≈øuch as ≈øayle along by the coa≈øt, may vnder≈øtand that there all the hilles and high landes doe end, and from thence forward it is altogether low land, and ≈øandie ≈øtrandes, till you come to the place called as Palmerias, or Palme tr√©es: from the la≈øt high land, or Derradeira terra alta, to the riuer called Rio de Manicapatan, the coa≈øt runneth northea≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt, and reacheth 5. miles, and to know when you are right again≈øt the Riuer of Manicapatan, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a high tr√©e ≈øtanding alone vpon the ≈øea ≈øide, and is a very flat land on the ≈øea ≈øide, hauing a bankie and ≈øhallow ground, the tr√©e ≈øtandeth on the left hand of the entrey into the riuer, from Manicapatan you runne along the coa≈øt Ea≈øt, Northea≈øt, and we≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt, to the Pagode de Iorganate, that is the Idoll or temple of Iorganate, and reacheth thr√©e miles. This Pagode of Iorganate lieth vnder 20. degr√©es and ¬º, from this Pagode of Iorganate, to another great blacke Pagode or Idoll, the coa≈øt runneth ea≈øt and we≈øt, & ≈øomewhat ea≈øt and by north, and we≈øt & by ≈øouth, and reacheth 7. miles. This blacke Pagode lieth not full vnder 20. degrees and ¬Ω, from this blacke Pagode to the riuer of Cayegare the coa≈øt runneth northea≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and ≈øomwhat northea≈øt and by ea≈øt, and ≈øouth we≈øt and by we≈øt, and reacheth 10 miles, the riuer of Cayegare lieth not full vnder 21 degrees, and about 4. miles before you come to it, there lieth 5. houels which ≈øhew like a Hauen of the Sea, built with Cottages, in the mouth of the riuer afore≈øaid, there lieth two ≈øandes, running a good mile ≈øouthwe≈øtward, and at the entrey therof lieth a Riffe running along by the coa≈øt for halfe a mile into the ≈øea, the entrie of the riuer is 4. fadome d√©ep, and you goe in and come forth northwe≈øt and ≈øouthea≈øt, the ≈øandes afore≈øaid, as you enter, lie on your left hand, and there the depth runneth along. To know Cayegare a farre off, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that when you haue pa≈ø≈øed the houels afore≈øaid, then Cayegare ≈øheweth like an Iland, hauing three or foure tr√©es higher then the re≈øt, and a little beyond it ≈øtandeth a ≈ømall Pagode, and ≈øomewhat beyond this Pagode, there is a little wood, verie thicke with tr√©es, which ≈ø√©emeth to b√©e part of Cayegare, and other wood there is none beyond it, by the ≈øaide Pagode there ≈øtandeth ≈øome Sandie Downes of red colour, with ≈øome water Beecken from the Riuer of Cayegare to the point called a punta das Palmeiras, the Coa≈øt
runneth northea≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øomewhat northea≈øt and by ea≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt, & by we≈øt, and reacheth eleauen miles 2. miles before you come to the point of Palmerias, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e certaine blacke houels ≈øtanding vppon a land that is higher then all the land there abouts, and from thence to the point it beginneth againe to be low ground, and right ouer again≈øt the houels you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e ≈øome ≈ømall, (but not ouer white) ≈øandie Downes, the markes and tokens which you ≈øhall finde being right again≈øt the point de Palmerias are, that vpon the point there is neyther tr√©e nor bu≈øh, and although it hath the name of the point of Palmtrees, it hath notwith≈øtanding right forth, but one Palme tr√©e. If you fall vppon it by day, being by Caijagate, and de≈øire to follow your way, then ≈øaile at the depth of twelue fadomes, northea≈øt, & northea≈øt and by ea≈øt, alwaies with your lead ready in the hand with good care and diligence, and being at 16. fadome, you ≈øhall pre≈øentlie winde northea≈øt, vntill againe you finde 12. fadome, alwaies keeping at that depth, till you finde but 7. fadome, and lie thereon by night, where you ≈øhall anker till it be day, and then hoi≈øe vp anker, running the ≈øame cour≈øe of Northea≈øt, and northea≈øt and by north, till you come to foure fadome, and comming thether you ≈øhall ≈øend a man into the top, to know the land. This coa≈øt reacheth Ea≈øt northea≈øt, till you come to a houell, which ≈øheweth like a Champana without a ma≈øt, with a boat following it, tho≈øe Champanas are Caruels of India, wherewith they ≈øayle in the ≈øea, and along the coa≈øt, this is the be≈øt marke you finde vpon the coa≈øt of Orixa, and alwaies take good h√©ed to your depthes, and if they begin to increa≈øe, that is, aboue fiue fadome, then you ≈øhal pre≈øently turne againe to 3. and 3. fadome and ¬Ω ≈øcar≈øe, and this is the right cour≈øe: for that if you ≈øaile ≈øtill at 5. and 6. fadome, you ≈øhould in the end come on ground, & when you ≈øee the houell called ChaÃÑ pana, (as I ≈øaid before) you ≈øhal runne along by it till you ≈ø√©e thr√©e tr√©es ≈øtanding together, yet ≈øomewhat di≈øtant each from other, which tr√©es are called as Aruores da Conhecen≈øa, that is the tr√©es of Markes. I ≈øet this downe becau≈øe I my ≈øelfe haue pa≈ø≈øed ouer it with great ≈øhips, being pa≈øt the riffe of Orixa, and Bengalen, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the Iland called a Ilha dos Gallos, that is the Ilands of Cocks, & you mu≈øt runne right vpon it without feare, for it is deepe inough, and on the other ≈øide of Orixa it is all banks, therfore I coun≈øell you to goe neere to the Iland of Cocks ≈øayling along by it, whereby you ≈øhall pre≈øently come to a riuer called Rio de Chamdequan, which hauing pa≈øt, you ≈øhall from thence cro≈ø≈øe ouer to the ≈øide of Orixa, where you ≈øhall ≈øee a hooke or point of the riuer Angellijn, this point of land will lie northward, and comming thether you ≈øhal alwaies haue your lead in hand, and the depth that you ≈øhall finde in tho≈øe places, are 3.3. ¬Ω and 4. fadome, but beeing full ≈øea it is deeper, which wil continue till you be right again≈øt the riuer of Angelijn: for from thence forward you haue many depthes, and being right again≈øt the riuer of Angelijn you ≈øhall runne along the ≈øhore till you come to a riuer called Gilingoa, & being right again≈øt that riuer, I wi≈øh you not put too farre from the ≈øhore, towards the right hand, for there you finde a ≈øand drougth, whereon Bartholomeus Rodriges de Moraiis was ca≈øt away with a ≈øhip full laden, as hee put out, therefore I adui≈øe you to keepe on the left hand, for there it is deepe enough, from this riuer to certaine high Beecken or downe falles of water, you may haue wood to burne, and from tho≈øe Beeckens you mu≈øt cro≈ø≈øe ouer on the other ≈øide of Guijnette, where you ≈øhall pre≈øentlie ≈ø√©e 5. or 6. tr√©es higher then the re≈øt, vntill you be clo≈øe to the other ≈øide. Tho≈øe tr√©es ≈øtand at the mouth of the riuer ChandequaÃÑ on the ea≈øt ≈øide, the depthes you ≈øhall finde vppon tho≈øe bankes are 2. & ¬Ω and thr√©e fadome d√©epe, till you be on the other ≈øide, for there you finde manie depthes, from this place forward you n√©ede no other adui≈øe, for the Fi≈øher men as then will bring you where you ≈øhould bee, you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe ouer the water with halfe flood, but I adui≈øe you once againe, that if you ≈øaile in the morning by the afore≈øaid riuer of Cayegare, then runne along the coa≈øt, till you come to the point das Palmerias, and from thence to 17. fadome deepe, froÃÑ thence holding your cour≈øe northwe≈øt, and northwe≈øt and by north, this way mu≈øt be folowed with a Compa≈ø≈øe that yeeldeth one ≈øtrike till you come to 12. fadome deepe, and then running the ≈øame cour≈øe, till you come to 4. and three fadome, and ¬Ω wherewith if it bee cleare weather, you ≈øhall pre≈øentlie ≈øee the laÃÑd of Orixa, but if it be darke and mi≈øtie weather, then runne no more towards the land, keeping ≈øtill at 4. and 3. fadome, and ¬Ω runrunning
Ea≈øt, for the leade and the depthes will bring you well in, and take h√©ede you come not into many depthes k√©eping ≈øtill as I ≈øaide before at the ≈ømall depthes, and if it bee night being at ≈øeuent√©ene fadome, then runne towards the 2. Ilands, and ≈øee you anker not, for it is badde ankering there, and pa≈ø≈øing by the afore≈øaide Punta das Palmeiras, running in by night, you ≈øhal then not pa≈ø≈øe aboue 7. or 8. fadome vntill it be day, wherewith as then you may go in, & if you chance to be there with a ≈ømall ≈øhippe, then keepe at 2. and 2. fadome and ¬Ω. till you be in the ≈øight of the riffe of Orixa: and when you begin to be right again≈øt it, then runne within the length of a great ≈øhot neere vnto, for it is deepe enough, and from the ≈øide of Orixa it is all banks and ≈øhallow ground. div.head: The 13. Chapter. The cour≈øe from India to the hauen of Aracan, which is the ≈øame way that you hold to Porto Grande, or the great hauen, lying in the countrie of Bengalen.
div.p: SAyling from India or Cochijn to the hauen of Aracan, you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe to the I≈ølande of Seylon, in manner afore≈øaid (as in the de≈øcription of the cour≈øe to Porto Pequeno) running ≈øo to the pointe or ende of the ≈øandes or droughtes (lying full vnder 6. degr√©es) and vppon the point of the lande, which runneth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, comming by this point or hooke, you ≈øhall from thence put off from the land, running 7. or 8. miles Northea≈øtward, to come out vnder the I≈ølande, and then let your cour≈øe be Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt & by North, till you be vnder 12. degr√©es, and that Manaco≈øta be ≈øouthwe≈øt from you and from thence you ≈øhall runne Northea≈øt, till you be almo≈øt vnder 20. degr√©es, which is the height of Aracan, and if then you ≈ø√©e no land, you ≈øhall runne Ea≈øt vnto Aracan, vnder the ≈øame height of 20. degr√©es: thr√©e or four miles from the land there lyeth a riffe, whervpon the water breaketh, and at low water is vncouered: it is in greatne≈ø≈øe and length about the length of ≈øeuen ≈øhips, both waies: and when you ≈ø√©e it you mu≈øt take heed of it and goe no nearer then the ≈øhotte of a great peece. The hauen of Aracan lyeth vnder 20. degrees, and being fiue or ≈øixe miles to ≈øeawarde from it, you ≈øhall there find twentie fadome deepe, ≈øandie grounde, and being at 19. degrees and ¬Ω. toward the lande you ≈øhall find deepe muddie ground, at the lea≈øt 6 miles from the ≈øhore, and being but three or four miles from the land thirtie fadome d√©epe muddy ground, you mu≈øt be careful at 19 degrees and ¬Ω. not to runne in with the lande, but do as I ≈øaid before.

div.head: The 14. Chapter. The cour≈øe from India to the hauen of Martauan, lying in the kingdome of Pegu, with the ≈øituation of the coa≈øtes.
div.p:
SAyling from India to Martauan, or to ye kingdome of Pegu, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe (till you be pa≈øt the I≈øland of Seylon) as they doe that ≈øaile to Bengalen, and being about the I≈øland, you ≈øhal make to the Ilands called As Ylhas d' Andemaon, whereof the fir≈øt Iland lyeth ≈øouth vnder 11. degr√©es, and the furthe≈øt land in the North vnder 14. degr√©es, you runne on the Ea≈øt ≈øide of them, Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt, from the Ilands d' Andemaon, to the firme lande, are aboue 60. miles, and running to Andemaon, you ≈øhall v≈øe all the meanes you can to pa≈ø≈øe by them vpon the North ≈øide, and being pa≈øt you mu≈øt (as I ≈øaid before) make towardes Martauan, (which lyeth vnder 16. degrees) and when you are at 14. degr√©es you ≈øhall make with the lande, but better at 13. degrees, becau≈øe of the creeke or winding in of Martauan, (where you finde a very ≈øtrong ≈øtreame alwayes drawing Northwe≈øt, and if you make with the lande being at 14. degrees, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e many I≈ølands which you may freely pa≈ø≈øe clo≈øe by, for it is all ouer very deepe, for there it is 12. and 13. d√©epe muddie ground clo≈øe by the ≈øhore, be≈øides the I≈øland Pulo Comudo, which is about 6. or 7. miles from the hauen of Martauan, betweene this I≈øland and the firme lande there lyeth many riffes, notwith≈øtanding if you chance to fall betw√©ene tho≈øe I≈ølandes, you ≈øhall make towardes the ≈øide of the I≈ølande, but not too clo≈øe, where you ≈øhall find a channell of thr√©e fadome deep, and on the ≈øide of the firme land
you haue many ≈øands and ≈øhallowes, pa≈ø≈øing from thence to the hauen of Martauan (being pa≈øt that Iland) you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe along the ≈øhore, where you ≈øhall ≈øee certaine cliffes lying towards the ≈øea, which ≈øhew like Almadias (which are Indian Scutes, by them v≈øed in ye riuers) which cliffes lie about 2 miles from Pulo Comudo towardes Martauan, and right ouer again≈øt the≈øe cliffes you haue on the firme lande a point or hooke of high land, and on the North ≈øide of this point there lyeth a ≈øandie ≈øtrand vpon the low land: this land belongeth to Xemiin Vegarum, that is in Pegu ≈øp√©ech, the Lord of Vegarum, for Xemiin is Lord, and Vegarum the name of the land: from thence Northward the land is high, in ≈øome places hauing cr√©ekes, cliffes and I≈ølandes: before you come to the hauen of Martauan there is a white houell or land, that ≈øerueth for a marke, hauing clo≈øe by it two Palme trees: and about two miles further you ≈øhall ≈øee a thicke top of lande, vppon the end whereof towardes the ≈øea lyeth an Iland, which cannot be ≈ø√©en nor di≈øcerned from the land, till you be right again≈øt it, and that you haue di≈øcouered the Riuer within where the hauen of Martauan lyeth, and being pa≈øt this Iland, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a white houel, which lyeth likewi≈øe on the South ≈øide: within the Iland there is a lake that hath good fi≈øh, and before you come to the hauen (comming from the Ilande of Comudo) about a mile, or a mile and a halfe to ≈øeawarde from the land, you ≈øhall ≈øee a round I≈ølande full of bu≈øhes, called A Ilhas de Cebollas, that is, the I≈øland of Onions, by the which I≈øland on the ≈øouth ≈øide thereof, there lyeth a cliffe whereon you ≈ø√©e the ≈øea breake: from this I≈øland to the hauen of Martauan, there are about two miles, & comming from Pulo Comudo, you mu≈øt put off from it towards the land, holding your cour≈øe as afore≈øaid, as not hauing any cau≈øe of feare, but onely of that which you ≈ø√©e before your eyes, you mu≈øt likewi≈øe vnder≈øtande that from the I≈ølande Das Cebollas forward towards the North, there is no other Ilands nor cliffes, which is a verie good marke of this creeke, for that being on this ≈øide thereof, you are no ≈øooner pa≈øt one Iland but you ≈øee another, but from thence forward you ≈øee not any, as I ≈øaid before, but you mu≈øt bee ≈øure not to pa≈ø≈øe beyond the hauen of Martauan, for that being at twelue fadome, not long after you ≈øhould fal vpon the drought. This hauen of Martauan is about a mile or a half and a half broad, hauing on the North ≈øide a low flat land euen with the ≈øea, and is an Iland called Momua: you may ≈øee it as you pa≈ø≈øe along the ≈øhore, from Pulo Comuda, towardes the hauen, you mu≈øt ≈øtill keepe at twelue fadome, and comming to 8. or 9. fadome, then you ≈øhall anker, for then you are in the hauen; and put no neerer to the ≈øhore, neither runne not further from the creeke to the banke, for then you ≈øhall find le≈ø≈øe depth: this riuer of Martauan runneth Northea≈øt & Southwe≈øt both out and in, but you may not enter therein without a Pilot, for that within the Riuer vpon the Ea≈øt ≈øide it hath a ≈øtone cliffe or rock, which draweth the water vnto it, therefore you cannot enter without a Pilot: al≈øo in the entrie of this riuer and hauen, on the right hand there lyeth a ≈øandie banke, where in the middle way there runneth a channell of ≈øixe or ≈øeuen fadome deepe, which you ≈øhal knowe by this, that is, in the deepe≈øt parte thereof it hath much fi≈øh, which you may ≈øee, and this hauen of Martauan lyeth vnder 16. degrees and

div.head: The 15. Chapter. The cour≈øe from Cochiin in India to Malacca.
div.p:
HE that will ≈øaile to Malacca in the great Mon≈øon (which is the principall time when the windes ≈øerue to go thether) in the Month of Aprill, then (to make a good voyage) you mu≈øt ≈øet ≈øaile from Cochiin vppon the ≈øixe and twentith of Aprill, and being out of the hauen, you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe ≈øouthward till you be vnder 7. degr√©es, and from thence ≈øouth ≈øouthea≈øt to 6. degrees, and being vnder
that height, then you ≈øhall runne Southea≈øt almo≈øt to fiue degr√©es, and from thence Ea≈øt vntill you are pa≈øt the Ilande of Seylon, and being there you ≈øhall keepe on your cour≈øe till you be vnder 5. and ‚Öì. and 5. degrees, and ‚Ä¢ . from thence you ≈øhall make towardes the Ilands of Gome≈øpola, which lie vnder 6. degr√©es by the point of Achiin, in the Ilande Sumatra, and comming to the Iland of Gome≈øpola, if you feare not the Acherins, (which are ≈øubiects to the kingdom of Acheiin in the Ilande of Sumatra, and deadly enemies to the Portingals) then take your cour≈øe along by the Iland of Sumatra, to the Cape called Taniamburo, lying on the ≈øame coa≈øt of the Iland almo≈øt 30. miles from the Ilandes of Gome≈øpola, and from thence you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe towardes the coa≈øt of Malacca, running as farre to loofewarde as po≈ø≈øible you may to di≈øcouer Pulo Sambilao, which is an Ilande lying clo≈øe vpon the coa≈øt vnder 4. degr√©es, and ‚Öî. and di≈øtant from Malacca 40. miles Northwe≈øt and by North, for that ≈øuch as di≈øcouer and come to this Iland, maketh a quicke voyage to Malacca, and tho≈øe that fall to leeward towardes Pulo Pinan (which is an other Iland vnder fiue degr√©es and ¬Ω. lying with Pulo Sambilao, North and by We≈øt, 12. miles, & neere Pulo Batun there is another Iland lying Northwe≈øt and by North from Pulo Pinaio ten miles, & vnder 6. deg.) might peraduenture find Southea≈øt windes, which blow much on that coa≈øt: therefore he that goeth late to ≈øaile hath a long voyage, wherefore it is be≈øt to depart earlie from Cochiin, to make a better voyage.

div.head: The 16. Chapter. An other & larger de≈øcriptioÃÑ of the cour≈øe to ≈øaile from Goa in India to Malacca, with the de≈øcription of the coa≈øts.
div.p:
SVch as de≈øire to ≈øaile from Goa, or out of India to Malacca, mu≈øt put 20. miles into the ≈øea, that he may ≈øaile without ye Ilande of Seylon, vnto the Ilandes called As Ilhas de Nicobar through the middle of the channell, which lyeth vnder 7. degrees, and ¬Ω. and in that countrey you mu≈øt looke to the ≈øtreame, becau≈øe with a we≈øt wind they run towards the Gulfe of Bengalen, and with an Ea≈øt wind into the ≈øea, about 20. or 30. miles froÃÑ the Ilandes, there is ≈øuch a concour≈øe & breaking of water and ≈øtreames, as if there were ≈øands. WheÃÑ you com to ye middle of ye Ilands of Nicobar, ther you find a channel, lying vnder 6. degrees and ¬Ω. the Ilands being di≈øtant one from the other about a mile and a halfe, where you may pa≈ø≈øe through without feare, as hauing nothing to fear, but yt you ≈ø√©e before you, the depth you find there is 12. & 13. fadom, & at the end this channel, by ye North Ilande of the Ilandes of Nicobar lyeth an Iland, where you may pa≈ø≈øe throgh wt yt greate≈øt ≈øhippe that is: the South end of this Ilande lyeth vnder 6. degr√©es and ¬º. and the channell afore≈øaid vnder 7. degr√©es: if you go through the middle of the channell lying vnder 6. degr√©es, you ≈øhal at the entry to the Ilands ≈øee 4. Ilands, whereof thr√©e lie halfe a mile from the Iland: two of them are great and high, the other ≈ømall: the fourth lyeth di≈øtant from the Ilande about thr√©e miles, and is a great round Iland, flatte on the top, and Northward you ≈øhall ≈øee another Iland, lying vnder 8. deg. the entry of this Iland hath a thicke high backe, flat at the end, and being in the middle of the channel you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e another Iland, lying hard by that vnder 8. deg. a flat land, di≈øtant from the other about two miles: from the Ilandes of Nicobar to the Northerly Ilands are about 7. miles, and there you n√©ed not feare any thing: at the end of this channell the Ilande of Nicobar hath a round houell, at the foote whereof lyeth an Iland, I coun≈øel you not to pa≈ø≈øe by the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Ilande Nicobar, thereby to k√©epe your ≈øelfe out of the daunger of tho≈øe of Acheiin in the Ilande of Sumatra, which are continually thereaboutes, and are deadly enemies to the Portingalles, but rather doo your be≈øt to pa≈ø≈øe the way I ≈øpake of before, although you ≈øhould ≈øaile vnder 8. and ¬º. or 8. degrees and ‚Ä¢ . for you may pa≈ø≈øe without danger, for they are all channelles or thorow fares: being pa≈øt the Ilandes of Nicobar as I ≈øaid before, you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe towards the Iland Pulo Cuto, you runne betweene Pulo Cuto and Nicobar Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and ≈øomewhat Ea≈øt and by South, and We≈øt and by North: the cour≈øe is nyne miles and lyeth vnder 6. degrees and 2/ ‚Ä¢ . to know Pulo Cuto, comming out of the Sea towardes it, vpon the Ea≈øt ≈øide thereof you ≈øhall ≈øee a high round land, on the ≈øhore very low: they are thr√©e Ilands together, hauing on the South ≈øide, on the furthe≈øt point of them 3. or 4. cliffes or rocks that lie vncouered, & on the North ≈øide an other mouth or opening, running between the great Ilande & the Ilande of the ≈øea: in this Ilande on the Southea≈øt ≈øide there is a very good place to take in fre≈øh water, lying by a long point of lande: you may likewi≈øe take your cour≈øe froÃÑ the Ilands of Nicobar to the Ilande Pulo Pera, which is a ≈ømall round Iland, without trees, lying vnder 5. deg. and ‚Öî. the cour≈øe being about 100. miles, you run Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, and We≈øt Northwe≈øt, from Pulo Pera
