From Gualla to the point called Belitote, is fyue or ≈øixe miles, which point hath a thicke wood of Palme trees (and right ouer again≈øt it about half a mile there is a great Cliffe) and betw√©en them both lyeth many ≈øtonie cliffes: along the ≈øhore, by the point of Gualla, are two ≈øandes, whereon the water breaketh, the one is before you come at the point which runneth into the ≈øea, about ¬º of a myle, and the other is right ouer again≈øt the bay, on the North ≈øyde, running a ≈ømall myle into the ≈øea, and of this you mu≈øt take great care: you may well pa≈ø≈øe by it in the night, at twentie fadome deepe, ≈øo that you need not feare: vppon this ≈øame the ≈øea breaketh verie long, ≈øpeciallie when it is high water. From thence you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe vnto Columbo, as the Coa≈øt reacheth, and from the Iland of Verberijn forward, the ground is full of Bankes and ≈øhallowes, and b√©eing hard by Columbo, about three or foure myles towardes Negumbo, you may anker at eight or nyne fadome, but by Columbo you cannot doe it, but if you haue great occa≈øion, then you may anker at eight√©en fadome towardes the land. There you finde ≈øtonie ground, and the ≈øame you finde at the poynt where you haue twentie fyue fadome deepe, inwardes to the ≈øea, and that in mo≈øt places, therefore you mu≈øt bee carefull in throwing out your Anker, fir≈øt prouing with a lead: the grounde of this Countrie is in ≈øome places ≈ømall, and in other places great ≈øand, which is the ≈øure≈øt, and in ≈øome places it hath redde ≈øand, and lykewi≈øe places of white and blacke ≈øand, which are tokens of the ground along the Coa≈øt, vppon all the which ground you may anker. The right markes and tokens of Columbo, (which is the place where the Portingalles holde their fort) are the≈øe, yt is, when you are within the Hauen then the Pico of Adam, ≈øo called (which is a high hill, higher then any other
in al the countrie about it,) ≈øhal be in the Ea≈øt and ≈øetting your cour≈øe to the Hauen of this fortre≈ø≈øe, then you ≈øhall loo≈øe the ≈øight of all the hilles and Houels, and begin to ≈øayle by thinne flat land, which is a marke and a verie good token of the Hauen, the winds that you there ≈øhall finde for the mo≈øt part of that time or Mon≈øon, are North Northea≈øt, Northea≈øt, and ≈øometime Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, and al≈øo Ea≈øt, the Viracoins (which are the winds that blow out of the Sea,) are many times North, and Northwe≈øt, I write this, that men ≈øhould not wonder to find them ≈øo, in that place, likewi≈øe you finde there We≈øt Northwe≈øt, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt windes, according to the coniunctions of the times, when men are in that coa≈øt, the winds that are called Viracoins which commonly blow out of the we≈øt, throughout all India, at ≈øuch time as men v≈øe to ≈øayle vpon the Sea, which is in Summer from noone to twelue of the clocke at night, and come out of the Sea, towards the land, and therefore by the Portingales they are called Viracoins, that is wind out of the Sea, and from midnight to noone, the winds blow out of the Ea≈øt, which come ouer the land into the Sea, as it is at large declared in my Indian Viage, and is onely heere ≈øet downe becau≈øe it ≈øhould not ≈ø√©eme ≈øtrange to any man, to reade of the≈øe winds and their manner of blowing in the≈øe countries, when you will put to Sea by night with the Terreinhos, or land winds, if they be not Northea≈øt, then you ≈øhall not ≈øet ≈øayle before midnight, & if they be not full, to Sea ward, then put not to farre off from the ≈øhore becau≈øe it would not bee good for you, to put to farre into the Sea, for that you could not well get the land againe, becau≈øe the Viracoins or ≈øea winds that come out of the North and Northwe≈øt, doe often ≈øtay late, & blow but ≈ølowly. From Negumbo you ≈øhall cro≈ø≈øe ouer to Cape de Comorijn, to the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Cape, towards the land, called das Areas Gordas, that is of the fat or thicke Dounes, which is 12. miles from Cabo de Comorijn, on the ≈øide of Choramandel, for it is good to put on there becau≈øe of ye ≈øtreame, which runneth verie ≈øtiffe outward with a hard wind by the≈øe Areas Gordas, as al≈øo ≈øome part of the way to the Cape, you finde ground (and many times ≈ø√©e the land becau≈øe it is long) at 40. fadome and le≈ø≈øe, and if you come inward from the Cape, being by night and find ground, then you may fr√©ely pa≈ø≈øe ouer this ground from 12. to 18. fadome d√©epe, for as you come right again≈øt the Cape, then the ground is ful of white Sand, and you ≈øhal not find aboue 20. fadome to Seaward, from Areas Gordas to the Cape, for from Areas Gordas inwards, the ground is ful of banks, and ≈ømall blacke Sand, and you mu≈øt runne a mile, a mile and a halfe, and two miles from the ≈øhore, vpon the ground and depthes afore ≈øaide. And when you pa≈ø≈øe by Cabo de Comorijn, to Coulaon, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe along the coa≈øt, about a mile from the ≈øhore, that you may Anker, and not going n√©erer to the ≈øand then 12. fadome, but it is good to run from 15. to 18. fadome, alwayes taking h√©ede of the ≈øtones of Trauancor, which lie betw√©ene the Cape and Coulaon, and being in the night time, the ≈øure≈øt marke to know if you be before Coulaon, is to find the ground full of bankes, for from Coulaon to Batecola (that is by Onor not farre from Goa) the ground is bankie, and you may Anker at 8. fadome without feare, from Batecola to Goa, the ground in ≈øome places deeper, whereby you may gouerne your ≈øelfe. Touching your Ankerage, from Cochijn to Cananor you n√©ede not feare, onely to take h√©ede of the Iland called Ilha Cagado, lying Southward from Cananor ≈øeuen miles, and thr√©e miles Northward from the fortre≈ø≈øe of Mangalor, there lyeth a row of Ilands, Cliffes, and Rockes, along the coa≈øt vntill you come to the fortre≈ø≈øe of Barcelor, from thence to Batecola you haue certaine Cliffes, but they are clo≈øe to the land, and the two Ilands of Batecola, you may pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene the fir≈øt of them, and the Firme land without feare, for it is 15. or 16. Fadome d√©epe, a little further lyeth the Iland of Honor, clo≈øe to the Firme land, then followeth the Ilandes of Angediua, which reach as the coa≈øt doth, and if it bee late in the yeare, you ≈øhal not put farre into the Cr√©eke of Ancola, for as then there is no Terreinhos or land winds, to driue you out againe, therfore it is then better to runne ≈øomething far from the coa≈øt, for you haue many times the Viracoins or Sea winds ≈øomwhat farre off, and being n√©ere the ≈øhore, they would not much helpe you. This mu≈øt be from the twentie of March forward. If you chance to be by Angediua and had n√©ede of a Road, or harber, you mu≈øt enter into Angediua on the North ≈øide, as far from that land, as from the Firme land, and rather ≈øomewhat n√©erer the Iland, then the Firme land, where you haue a good Road or harber, for there many times diuers ≈øhippes doe winter, being con≈øtrained therevnto, within it is ≈øixe fadome d√©epe, a little further from Angediua, lie foure or fiue Ilands, from the ryuer Sangui≈øijn, clo≈øe by the Firme land, and from thence about halfe a mile further forward lyeth the Iland of Goa
Velha, (that is old Goa) and then there are no other Ilands heerein to bee noted. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that oftentimes it happeneth, that along the coa≈øt, you ≈øhall find the wind Northwe≈øt, and North Northwe≈øt, without chaÃÑging which bloweth very ≈øtrong with the which wind I adui≈øe you not to ≈øet ≈øayle, although it blow out of the North, but if it be cleare day, then you may hoy≈øe Anker, and put to Sea wards and if the wind commeth not about, to Northea≈øt, being foure miles from the land, and before noone, about nine or ten of the clocke, you ≈øhall Anker till it be noone, till the Viracoins or Sea winds come, therewith to ≈øayle againe towards the land, for in this ≈øort you ≈øhall get aduantage to loofeward, although it bee with paine and labour, as likewi≈øe the time will ≈øhewe you what you ≈øhall doe. I mu≈øt further aduerti≈øe you, that when you are by the coa≈øt of Seylon, it being about the fifteene of Februarie or pa≈øt, then you n√©ede not ≈øayle, further then to the Ilands Verberijn, and from thence to the Cape de Comorijn, for as then you n√©ede neither to feare water nor ≈øtreames, to driue you outward, yet you mu≈øt not bee negligent therin, for ≈øome yeares the ≈øtormes come later & ≈øometimes ≈øooner, as the winds blow, whereof you mu≈øt be carefull, and being the fift√©ene of Februarie, or pa≈øt, you mu≈øt remember not to runne inwards, but k√©epe out, for as then the ≈øtreames runne inwards, which might deceiue you, and the later it is in Februarie, the ≈øtronger they draw inward, comming to Cochijn betw√©ene the 15. and 20. of March, you may wel get from thence to Goa, although the Viage is ≈øome thing doubtfull, but being pa≈øt the twentie of March, I would not coun≈øell you to do it for that of late many years together, there hath b√©ene vpon the coa≈øt of India (in Aprill and May) diuers blu≈øtering ≈øtormes of cro≈ø≈øe winds, blowing towards the coa≈øt, with darke and cloudie ≈økies, which would bring you in great danger, therefore again≈øt that time it is be≈øt to chu≈øe a good Hauen, neuerthele≈ø≈øe, God can ≈øend faire weather & winds when it plea≈øeth him. To put into the Hauen of the fortre≈ø≈øe of Barcelor, in the coa≈øt of Malabar afore≈øaide, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtande that when you ≈øee a round Houell vppon the end of the hil of Batecola, towards ye Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, then you are right again≈øt the fortre≈ø≈øe of Barcelor & may put in at 7. fadome, ≈øo you haue the fortre≈ø≈øe Ea≈øt, and halfe a ≈øtricke to Ea≈øt and by North from you, and you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e all the Cliffes lying along the coa≈øt, to the Ilands, as Ilhas de Saint Maria, which are altogether ≈øtonie Cliffes, but they ≈øtand clo≈øe to the land.

div.head: The 19. Chapter. A de≈øcription of all the Hauens, places, coa≈øtes, and Sands vpon the Ea≈øt and South ≈øide of the Ilands Seylon, with their heights, cour≈øes, ≈øtretchings, & ≈øituations, with the cour≈øe from thence to the fortre≈ø≈øe of Columbo holden by the Portingales.
div.p:
FIr≈øt I will beginne with Trinquanamale, which lyeth vnder nine degr√©es, vppon the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Iland Seylon, eight myles from thence Southwarde lyeth a ≈ømal ryuer, and before you come at it, putting from Trinquanamale, ther are ≈øome Ilands that with Birds fileings looke white, and in the mouth of the riuer afore≈øaid lie two ≈ømal Ilands, full of tr√©es, from Trinquanamale to this ryuer the cour≈øe is North and South, and North and by Ea≈øt, and South and by We≈øt, and running along the coa≈øt towards this ryuer, then you ≈øhall leaue the Ilands afore≈øaid on the land ≈øide, ≈øayling without theÃÑ, for that betw√©ene them and the land are many ≈øtones and Cliffes, this ryuer and Trinquanamale lie di≈øtant from each other eight or nine miles at the furthe≈øt. From the ≈øaide ryuer (with the Ilands in the entrie thereof) to the ryuer of Mataqualou are 12. myles, and lieth vnder the hight of ≈øeuen degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . The cour≈øe from the one to the other is Northwe≈øt, and Southea≈øt being pa≈øt this ryuer, comming betw√©ene the Ilands & the mouth therof, you may go as n√©ere the ≈øhore as you will, for it is without danger, & within a great ≈øhotte of the land it is 20. fadome d√©epe. From Mataqualou, about fiue or ≈øixe miles, the cour≈øe is North and South till you come to the point or hooke, and from this point fiue or ≈øixe miles further you runne along the coa≈øt North and South, and North and by Ea≈øt, and South and by We≈øt, further forward towards the fir≈øt Sand about fiue or ≈øixe miles, Northward, there ≈øtandeth a woode of Palme tr√©es, and comming right ouer again≈øt it, the coa≈øt runneth North Northea≈øt, and South ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øomewhat North and by Ea≈øt, and South and by We≈øt, from tho≈øe fiue miles to the fir≈øt ≈øand, the cour≈øe is North Ea≈øt and ≈øouthwe≈øt, and
Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and before you come within foure or fiue miles of the≈øe Sandes, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e ≈øome Houels and hillockes of red Earth, along the Sea ≈øide, & inward to the land there appeareth certaine high hilles, whereof one of them lying mo≈øt Northward hath a Houell ≈øtriking out of the toppe thereof, which ≈ø√©emeth to bee a blocke hou≈øe, being of redde Earth. You may pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene the fir≈øt Sand and the land at ≈øeuen or eight Fadome d√©epe, alwaies k√©eping as farre from the land as from the Sand, for they are a good myle di≈øtant, and running about by the Sea, you ≈øhall find Sandie ground round about it, this Sand lyeth vnder 6. degrees, and from this fir≈øt Sand about 6. or 7. miles ≈øouthward, there is yet an other Sand, and the cour≈øe from this one to the other is ea≈øt, Northea≈øt and We≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt, along the coa≈øt, this ≈øecond Sand lyeth ≈øcarce vnder 6. degr√©es, betw√©ene the which and the Firme land are 12 and 13. Fadome d√©epe, all good ground, and from the la≈øt Sand to a Cr√©eke called A ‚Ä¢ alla the coa≈øt runneth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, and We≈øt and by South, 4. or 5. miles further forward froÃÑ this Cr√©eke, there lieth an other Cr√©eke called Hulpulam from whence to Tanadare are about 7 miles. Tanadare is a point of the land, whereon there ≈øtandeth a woode of Palme trees, and when you are right ouer again≈øt it, you ≈øhall ≈øee a white Pagode (that is a Temple of the Indian Idoles) and on the North ≈øide of this Pagode, ≈øtand certaine Houels, of white and red Earth, and pa≈ø≈øing before it, you ≈øhal not goe to clo≈øe to the ≈øhore, for there abouts are certaine Sands, and beeing pa≈øt this point, then goe pre≈øently at 20. Fadome deepe, for it is al good and cleare ground, and if it ≈øhould be calme there you may Anker. From Tana dare to Belliguon are about ≈øixe myles, Belliguon is a verie great Creeke, on the South ≈øide wherof are certaine Houels of red Earth, that ≈øtand within the Creeke, for that you cannot ≈øee them, before you haue fully di≈øcouered the Creeke, and on the North ≈øide it hath two Ilands, lying clo≈øe by the land, & on the South ≈øide of tho≈øe Ilands along, ther lyeth a Riffe, or Sand. From Belliguon to Gualle are fiue myles, all this way from the one to the other, the land is altogether clo≈øe and full of trees, along the Sea ≈øide, about halfe a mile from Belliguon to Gualle, there lyeth a ≈øtonie Iland, clo≈øe by the land, and an other on the South ≈øide of Gualle, and making towards it, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a high flat land full of tr√©es, and an euen wilderne≈ø≈øe, and on the North ≈øide of the bay, there ≈øtandeth a great wood of Palme tr√©es, vppon the Sea coa≈øt, and within the Hauen you ≈øhall ≈øee a white hou≈øe, which is a ≈ømall Chappell of the Virgin Marie, pa≈ø≈øing from Belliguon to Gualle (and comming right again≈øt this point) on the South ≈øide towards the Bay, you mu≈øt put to Seaward thereby to ≈øhunne a Sand wheron you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the Sea breake, and to Anker you ≈øhal runne North & North Northwe≈øt, in ≈øuch manner that you may alwaies ≈ø√©e certaine Cliffes (that lie on the North ≈øide) and inwards from the Bay, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the Palme tr√©es, which will be vpon the ≈øouth ≈øide towards Belliguon, which lay hidden by the point, there you ≈øhall finde 14. and 15. fadome water, and running till you come to 13. fadome, & finding ≈øandie ground, you may Anker, for to Seaward it is altogether ≈øtones. From Tanadare to this Hauen of Gualle, (which are twelue miles) the cour≈øe is Northwe≈øt, and Southea≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and ≈øouthea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, this Hauen of Gualle lieth vnder 5. degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . from thence pa≈ø≈øing along the coa≈øt, you ≈øayle about the Portingalles Fort called Columbo, this cour≈øe I haue already ≈øufficiently declared, in the Nauigation from Malacca to India, therefore it is n√©edle≈ø≈øe here to be rehear≈øed.

div.head: The 20. Chapter. The righr cour≈øe from Malacca to Macau in China, with the ≈øtretchings of the coa≈øts.
div.p:
DEparting from Malacca, to the Straights of Sincapura, and ≈øo to China, you mu≈øt ≈øet your cour≈øe to the Ilands called Ilha Grande, lying thr√©e miles from the Hauen of Malacca, pa≈ø≈øing (for more ≈øecuritie) without about the Ilands: from tho≈øe Ilands to the ryuer called Muar, are thr√©e miles, which hath for a marke a Houel full of tr√©es, on the ≈øouth ea≈øt ≈øide, without any other high land thereabouts. From the riuer of Muar to the riuer called Rio Fermo≈øo, you run along the coa≈øt Northwe≈øt and ≈øouthea≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and ≈øouthea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, the cour≈øe is nine miles, this riuer of Fermo≈øo is great and faire, hauing in the entrie 6. and 7. Fadome d√©epe, and al≈øo within, you enter into it by the foote of a high hill, on the South ≈øouthea≈øt ≈øide, and it lyeth on the South ≈øide of Malacca, it hath certaine bankes, ≈øticking out into the Sea (from the point lying North
ea≈øt, which is a flat & plaine countrie) which you mu≈øt ≈øhunne. From this Rio Fermo≈øo to the Iland Pulo Picon, the coa≈øt runneth the ≈øame cour≈øe, ≈øouthea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and the Iland Pulo Picon lieth halfe a mile from the coa≈øt, hauing thr√©e Ilands by it, two on the Sea ≈øide, and one vpon the land ≈øide, but you mu≈øt not pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene it and the land, for there are many Sands, it is di≈øtant ≈øeuen miles: ≈øouthea≈øtward towards the Sea from Pulo Picon, there lyeth a great and a verie high Iland, with many Ilands about it, called Pulo Carimon, along by the We≈øt ≈øide of the ≈øame Iland, towards the ≈øtraight of Sabon, which is the way to Sunda, and the Iland of Iaua, the nauigation and cour≈øe whereof I will in an other place ≈øet downe, therefore for this time it ≈øhall not be touched, and will proc√©ede to our matter afore≈øaide. From this Iland of Pulo Picon, to a pointe of land that ≈øtretcheth out, called Taniamburo, you runne Ea≈øt ward by the coa≈øt, being about thr√©e miles, this point maketh a hooke, and from thence forward the coa≈øt turneth inward like an arme, running froÃÑ thence right ≈øouthward, about a mile froÃÑ this point lyeth a riuer, and a little mile further forward there is an other ryuer, with a great mouth, where there lyeth an Iland, called old Sincapura, being deepe and faire ground, this ryuer i≈ø≈øueth out againe in the Hauen of Iantana, where Antonio Mello by chance did once enter with a ≈øhip of eight hundreth Bhares great (each Bhar waighing thr√©e Quintals and a halfe Portingall waight) & came out againe at the ryuer of Iantana, from this ryuer the land runneth downe towards the South (as I ≈øaide before) which maketh a hooke, where the mouth or entrie of the fir≈øt ≈øtraight (yt you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe through) beginneth. The land on the North ≈øide of this entrie is higher then the South, which is low and flat, hauing a Houell of tr√©es, ≈øtriking out about all the re≈øt, there is the end or furthe≈øt point of that land, for that going Ea≈øtward on, then you finde Ilands and ≈øtonie Cliffes, which fir≈øt reach ≈øouthward, and theÃÑ againe come Ea≈øtward out, making the forme of an arme, from the ≈øaid point of Taniamburo, to the mouth or entrie of this ≈øtraight, the cour≈øe is 5. miles Ea≈øt & We≈øt, at 7. and 8. fadome d√©epe. Hee that will pa≈ø≈øe through Sincapura to China (pa≈ø≈øing by Pulo Picon in the beginning of ye month of Iuly) he mu≈øt go n√©ere to the ≈øide of the great Iland Carymon, becau≈øe ye winds of the Mon≈øon of Iaua (which are at ye time) doe alwaies blow from the ≈øouth ≈øide of Sumatra, likewi≈øe when you keepe by the ≈øide of Carimon (and being pa≈øt it) you pre≈øently haue the mouth or entrie of the ≈øtraight open vnto you, with ye marks afore≈øaid, in this way you find manie depths, & pa≈ø≈øing along by Taniamburo, theÃÑ the land of ye entrie to the ≈øtraightes ≈øheweth as if the one ran through the other, which is a common and certaine marke, but hold you to loofeward, the better to enter at your ple≈øure. Ilands, being long & flat, ful of trees, & lieth ful vnder 10. degrees, which will be on the ea≈øt ≈øide, all this way you mu≈øt take care not to fall to leeward, and being by this Iland afore≈øaid, you ≈øhall run ≈øouthea≈øt, and rather hold aloofe to the ≈øouth, then to fall to the we≈øt, becau≈øe of the ≈øharpe winde which you commonly finde in that part, and in this cour≈øe you ≈øhall ≈øee another Iland greater then the fir≈øt, and reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt beeing on the toppe thicke and flatte land. div.p:
FRom Pulo Condor to Pulo Wy, there are about full 20. miles, lying from each other Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and ≈øomewhat Ea≈øt and by North, and We≈øt and by ≈øouth, and to go to Pulo Wy, hold your cour≈øe right we≈øt, not reckening any abatement for the y√©elding of the Compa≈ø≈øe, and being founde what more theÃÑ halfe way, you ≈øhal finde a banke of muddie
ground, of 8. or 9. fadome deepe, and being northward in the ≈øterne of the ≈øhippe, you ≈øhal ≈øee the trees vpon the coa≈øt of Camboia which is a verie low lande, this banke afore≈øaid being pa≈øt, it will not bee long before you ≈øhall ≈øee Pulo Wy, right ouer again≈øt you, and as ≈øoone as you ≈ø√©e it you ≈øhal make towards it on the north ≈øide: you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand yt this land of Camboia maketh a point froÃÑ whence the banke afore≈øaid runneth of, from this point to ye hauen of Sian, you run along the coa≈øt north northwe≈øt by yt which lyeth many Ilands, ≈øtretching along by it till you bee vnder 12 and 12. degrees and ¬Ω. In this countrie ly the mo≈øt and greate≈øt Ilandes, one by the other, and there make a hooke, for the land hath a cr√©eke called A En≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ da de Lian, which runneth a good way inwardes and lyeth vnder 12 degrees and ¬Ω. the north point of the land of the mouth of this creeke lyeth vnder 12 degrees ¬æ. and the land of this point afore≈øaide which lyeth inwardes, reacheth ea≈øt northea≈øt, and hath many trees, wt a ≈øandy ≈øtrand: froÃÑ this point to ≈øea ward there lyeth 2. high round Ilands without any trees: you cannot pa≈ø≈øe beetweene the fir≈øt Iland and the land, for the channell or pa≈ø≈øage lyeth betweene the fir≈øt and the ≈øecond (or the better to bee vnder≈øtood) betweene them both, there is a ≈ømall channell, but very deep of 60. fadom water, and there runneth a ≈øtrong ≈øtreame vnder the hight of the point afore≈øaid of this creeke, little more or le≈ø≈øe, about half a mile from the land on the inner ≈øide, there lyeth a very long cliffe ≈øtretching as the land doth, which at low water may bee ≈øeene, you run from this point to the hauen of Sian, along by the land north and ≈øouth: the I≈ølandes afore≈øaide are within 10. miles of the hauen as you pa≈ø≈øe along, they are not ouer great, neyther haue they any trees nor fre≈øh water, and all along you find good ground till you be within halfe a mile, and nearer you ≈øhall not goe, neither runne in betweene them and the land, but let them lie on the ea≈øt ≈øide, comming to Pulo W ‚Ä¢
, vntill the tenth of February, there you find much ea≈øt wind, whereby the we≈øt coa≈øt lyeth like an emptie wall, therefore you ≈øhal keepe on the ea≈øt ≈øide of the afore≈øaid Ilands, that ly along by the coa≈øt, being ≈øure not to put in betweene them, keeping this cour≈øe north northwe≈øt, along the ≈øhore, as I ≈øaide before, and comming to the furthe≈øt pointe of the ≈øaid Iland (which is full vnder 12. deg.) without ≈øeeing any more Ilandes, then bee a≈ø≈øured that you are within the creeke of Lyon ‚ñ™ and being there, you ≈øhall pre≈øentlie ≈øet your cour≈øe Northwe≈øt, & Northwe≈øt and by North, to get out of the creeke, lea≈øt the ≈øtreame ≈øhould driue you inward‚ñ™ & with that cour≈øe you ≈øhall come to ≈ø√©e the two Ilandes afore≈øaid, lying on the north point of the afore≈øaid cr√©eke, & it is in cro≈ø≈øing ouer twelue miles, & as you begin to ≈øee the coa≈øt on the other ≈øide, lying before the cr√©eke northwarde, the Iland ≈øtretching in that ≈øort as I ≈øaid before, being pa≈øt the point of the cr√©eke you ≈øhall run thether, & being by it you ≈øhall ≈øayle without it about halfe a mile from the ≈øhore: the≈øe Ilands end about 10. miles before you come to the hauen of Sian, as afore≈øaid, and the la≈øt of them are 4. or 5. ≈ømall Ilands, one running through the other along the coa≈øt: the≈øe Ilands haue no trees‚ñ™ & are of red earth, and comming to the end of the≈øe Ilands, then put to the ≈øhore, vntill the Ilandes bee right ≈øouth from you, then take your cour≈øe right North, wherewith you ≈øhall ≈øee the hauen of Sian, which lyeth froÃÑ the≈øe Ilands 10. miles di≈øtant. The hauen of Sian lyeth in a low land ful of trees, & without any ≈øandy ≈øtrands, but altogether of ≈øoft muddie ground & dirte, & hath likewi≈øe a banke of muddie ground, reaching two miles and a halfe ≈øouthward: wheÃÑ you enter fir≈øt vpon this bank it is hard muddie ground: you cannot enter into this hauen with any great ≈øhips but with a ≈øpring tide: and although you ≈øhold fall vpon this muddie ground, ther is no danger, for you mu≈øt come vpon drie land to put out, or in with the tides, comming from the Ilandes afore≈øaid to the hauen of Sian, in manner as I ≈øaid before, ≈øailing northward, & as they ly ≈øouthward from you, being in the night time, you may boldly anker vpon the muddie grounde, for the next morning you ≈øhal find your ≈øelfe right ouer again≈øt the hauen, ≈øo that you ≈øhall plainly ≈ø√©e it, for it is the mouth or entry of a great riuer, & you ≈øhall ≈øayle therein pa≈ø≈øing ouer muddy ground, & all with the tides and ≈øouth winds, which will bring you vpwards at plea≈øure.

div.head: The 23. Chapter. Of the cour≈øe from the hauen of Camboia to the I≈øland of Pulo Tymon, & Pedra Branq ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .
div.p:
DEparting from the point of ye haueÃÑ of Camboia, & being about halfe a mile or thereabouts in the ≈øea, you ≈øhal hold your cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, whereby you ≈øhall ≈øee two Ilandes lying betweene Pulo Co ‚Ä¢ dor and Pulo Wy, from the which you ≈øhal ≈øaile about halfe a mile ≈øtil running ≈øouthwe≈øt, not once putting Southward, becau≈øe of ye ≈øtrong ≈øtreams, yt run to ye
Iland of Bornon, and if the wind begin to be calme, and that you de≈øire to Anker in the middle of the gulfe, you may well doe it, for it is at the lea≈øt 38. or 40. fadome d√©epe, therfore leaue not ≈øayling Southwe≈øt ward, for with that cour≈øe you ≈øhall come right vppon Pulo Tymon, the Iland of Pulo Tymon is great, high, and full of tr√©es, and hath verie good fre≈øh water, and if you n√©ede, there you may haue it, right ouer again≈øt it in an Iland lying in a Cr√©eke of the ≈øame Iland, when you put to this Iland of Pulo Tymon, on the Northea≈øt point you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a round Iland, and de≈øiring to runne betw√©en it and the Iland, or betw√©en it and the Firme land, you may wel do it, for you may pa≈ø≈øe fr√©ely round about in euerie place, and comming to Pulo Tymon, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe South, and ≈øomwhat South and by We≈øt, towards Pulo Tynge, which is a verie high & rounde Iland, much like a Doune, or a ≈øheafe of Corne, it hath ≈øome ≈ømall Ilands lying by it in the ≈øame cour≈øe of South, and South and by We≈øt, you ≈øhall come to Pedra Branqua or the white ≈øtonie Cliffe, & from thence you begin the cour≈øe to Sincapura, running about thr√©e or foure miles We≈øtward.

div.head: The 24. Chapter. Of the cour≈øe out of the Hauen of Macau in China to the Iland of Pulo Tymon, & the ≈øtraight of Sincapura.
div.p:
WHen you depart from Macau to ye other coa≈øt, you mu≈øt put out at the Ea≈øt chanel, if the wind bee Northwe≈øt, if not, then you cannot pa≈ø≈øe, that way, but you mu≈øt ≈øayle thorough the ≈øouth we≈øt chanel, which is a good way to pa≈ø≈øe out, running from the point of Varella, right vnto the land on the other ≈øide of Macau, to ≈øhunne the cliffe of Belchior Dalmeida, and when you are about a Harquebu≈øh ≈øhot from the other ≈øide, then you ≈øhall runne along to a point of land, which is the end thereof, where the Iland of Ca≈øtro lyeth, from this point the banke hangeth off, for the which cau≈øe you ≈øhall runne neerer to the land of Ca≈øtro, then to the point of land that you runne not on ground, for in tho≈øe countries you haue mo≈øt of the ≈øhallowes in the land that lyeth on the left hand, and the depthes on the right hand, with a ≈øpring tide, at this banke you find 4. fadome and a halfe, and being without the banke, you ≈øhall ≈øayle vnto the mouth or hole, running as then to the point of the banke, to ≈øhunne the Cliffes, which will pre≈øently bee ≈øeen, for that the water breaketh vpon them) vntill they be on your right hand, being out of the mouth of this entrie and being ouer again≈øt it, pa≈ø≈øe clo≈øe by it, for it is a good way, for the north winds which you find there abouts, and becau≈øe the wind on the other ≈øide is verie ≈øcarce, the afore≈øaide Cliffe lyeth in the middle way of the chanell, and you mu≈øt runne on that ≈øide from the north along the coa≈øt, to the Iland of Ca≈øtro, and when you are out of the chanell, you ≈øhal keepe Southwe≈øt along by the Ilands, if it bee cleare weather till you ≈øee the Iland of Sanchon, and when you are within eight miles of it, being to Seaward from it, then you haue good ≈øayling, for I doe alwaies hold this cour≈øe, and pa≈ø≈øe well with it, being 8. miles to Seaward from Sanchon, you ≈øhall runne Southwe≈øt, for the ≈øpace of two miles or that you bee 12. miles as you ge≈ø≈øe from the ≈øomewhat North and by We≈øt, & South and by Ea≈øt, this Iland Pulo Cambir, is long and flat, and on the ≈øea ≈øide it hath ≈øome red ≈øpots or veines, the bu≈øhes thereof being euen and alike, right water for it is verie good. You ≈øhal likewi≈øe vnder≈øtand, that being eight miles to Seaward from the Iland Sanchoan you wil take your cour≈øe from thence South Southwe≈øt, and then you ≈øhall likewi≈øe ≈ø√©e the Ilands of Ieronimo Pretto, but it mu≈øt bee wt a Compa≈ø≈øe yt is fix, I aduerti≈øe you once
more, that when you are in ≈øight of Pulo Cambir, about thr√©e or foure miles from it, there lyeth certaine Ilands, and halfe a mile to Seaward from the South point there lyeth certaine ≈øtonie Cliffes aboue the water, that ≈øhow like Bucks hornes, you may fr√©ely pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene all the Ilands, and that Iland for it is faire and good ground. From thence to the Varella you runne along the coa≈øt North and South, & ≈øomewhat North and by We≈øt, and South and by Ea≈øt, it is twelue miles di≈øtant, this Varella is a verie high tower, you haue no Anker ground, but verie clo≈øe to the ≈øhore, the be≈øt way is, to put into the Bay, for it is a good Hauen, I haue b√©ene in it, and it hath good Harber, for North and South winds, with 14.15. and 16. fadome d√©epe, ≈øandie ground, and if you de≈øire to goe any n√©erer to the land, you ≈øhall finde eight and ≈øeuen fadome d√©epe good ground, this hauen of Varella lyeth vnder 13. degr√©es, in this way from Varella to Pulo Se≈øir, there are ≈øome Ilands lying about 9. or 10. miles from Varella, from the point of Varella to the≈øe Ilands, the coa≈øt runneth North and ≈øouth, and from the≈øe Ilands to Pulo Se≈øir, you begin to runne along by the land North Northea≈øt, and South Southwe≈øt, this Iland Pulo Se≈øir taking the name of the land, (becau≈øe it lyeth on the coa≈øt, for there is an other of the ≈øame name lying to Seaward) is a ≈øtonie Iland, without bu≈øhes, hauing in the middle a pointed hill, like a Varella, it is a flat Iland of yellow colour like the Sea haue ground at ≈øeuen fadome great ≈øand but put not off into the Sea from Pulo Se≈øir, for it is an euill way, becau≈øe you haue but 4 fadome d√©epe, with ≈øtonie ground: Pulo Se≈øir lieth from the land vnder 10. and 13 degrees, and the cour≈øe from Varella to Pulo Se≈øir is about 50 miles: from Pulo Se≈øir to Pulo Condor you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe South ≈øouth we≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt & by ≈øouth, at 18. and 20. fadome deepe, whereby you ≈øhall ≈øee the Iland Pulo Condor: but I adui≈øe you when you come ouer this cro≈ø≈øe way from Pulo Se≈øir to Pulo Condor, to holde your cour≈øe from the ≈øandy point South≈øouthwe≈øt, at 18. or 20. fadome deepe, and when you find 15. fadome, theÃÑ you are right by the coa≈øt of Cambaia, and ≈øhall not ≈ø√©e Pulo Condor, but on the land ≈øide: but for your better way, you ≈øhall ≈øtill hold at 18 and 20. fadome, and by this cour≈øe you ≈øhall goe full vpon Pulo Condor, which is a great Iland, hauing many Ilands rouÃÑd about it, and in euery place much anker ground: there likewi≈øe you haue fre≈øh water on the we≈øt ≈øide: it lieth vnder 8 degrees & ‚Öî from Pulo Se≈øir to Pulo Condor are 50. miles, and from Pulo Condor to Pulo Tymon you ≈øhal hold your cour≈øe ≈øouth≈øouthwe≈øt to 30. and 35 fadome, muddy ground: in this cour≈øe and depth you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e an Iland being right ouer again≈øt the 7. points of the coa≈øt: it ≈øheweth like Pulo Tymon lieth vnder two degr. and ¬Ω on the North ≈øide it is a great Iland, hauing other Ilands lying by it: on the North ≈øyde it hath fre≈øh water, in a ≈øandy ≈øtrand, where the ≈øhips that come from Sunda, to goe for China, take in water: being in ≈øight of Pulo Tymon, you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe on the out ≈øide therof, till you pa≈ø≈øe by the ≈øouth poynt, along through the channell that runneth betw√©en this point and an other Iland, which Iland ≈øhall bee to ≈øea ward from you: and as ≈øoone as you are in the channell, on the ≈øouthwe≈øt ≈øyde, you ≈øhall ≈øee an other high Iland, called Pulo Tinge, to the which you ≈øhall goe, within a mile and a half, or two miles thereof, and being there you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe ≈øouthward to Pedra Branca, or the white Cliffe, at 18. or 20. fadome deepe, alwaies with the lead in hand: & if in this cour≈øe you come to le≈ø≈øe grouÃÑd, theÃÑ put to ≈øea ward, till you be at 18 fadome, about
4 miles di≈øtant from the coa≈øt‚ñ™ to auoyd the riffe that commeth from the point or hook of Iantana, where the Ilands lie, which you ≈øhal pre≈øently ≈ø√©e, hauing good regard that you pa≈ø≈øe not by Pedra Branca: but when you ≈ø√©e, you ≈øhall make towardes it, which you mu≈øt keepe on the lee ≈øide, for yt being with a flood the ≈øtreames runne very ≈øtrongly to the Iland of Binton, wherby you ≈øhuld not pa≈ø≈øe by Pedra Branca, for there I was forced to ca≈øt out 2. ankers, and you ≈øhal ≈øtill ≈øayl with your lead in hand, and when you find 15. or 16. fadom, theÃÑ you are at the end of the riffe, and it may be that as theÃÑ you can not ≈ø√©e Pedra Branca, and comming to 18. fadome, then put no further to the ≈øea: and running in that ≈øort, till you ≈ø√©e Pedra Branca, running as then to the poynt of the land, that you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e on the land of Iantana, which is the land on the North ≈øide, which you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe along by, till you come to ≈øee redde Houels, lying at the Hauen of Ior: and before you come to the hauen of Ior, you ≈øhall hold off from it, not putting into the hauen: for there lyeth a Banke, but you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe the redde Houels, and runne towardes the land, which is a ≈øandie ≈øtrand: and as you pa≈ø≈øe along to the mouth or entrie of the ≈øtraight of Singapura, you mu≈øt be carefull that as ≈øoone as you are within Pedra Branca, you runne to the land of Iantana, without turning to the other ≈øide, for there it is verie bad ground, and the wind would hinder you to get ouer, and if you de≈øire to run on the in≈øide of the Iland Pulo Tymon, you may wel doe it.

div.head: The 25. Chapter. The cour≈øe from Malacca to Sunda, lying in the Iland of Iaua Maior, with the ≈øituation of the countrie.
div.p:
SAyling from the great Iland lying 3. myles ≈øouthea≈øt from Malacca, to the Riuer called Rio Fermo≈øa, your cour≈øe lieth Northwe≈øt & Southea≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by we≈øt, and ≈øouthea≈øt and by ea≈øt, which is 13. miles: all this way, if you will, you may anker, and it is not aboue 30. fadome d√©epe, good muddy ground. This Rio Fermo≈øo lyeth on the Coa≈øt of Malacca, within the entry, on the Southea≈øt ≈øide hath high land, and on the Northwe≈øt ≈øide low land: it is in the Hauen ≈øixe or ≈øeuen fadome deepe: when you enter into it you ≈øhall put to the Southea≈øt ≈øyde, keeping from the Northwe≈øt, for ther you ≈øhall find ≈øhallowes. From this Rio Fermo≈øo to the Iland Pulo Picon, which lyeth in the ≈øame Coa≈øt, a myle from the land afore≈øayd, you runne Northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by north, and Southwe≈øt and by ≈øouth: betw√©ene this Iland and the firme land it is ≈øhalow grouÃÑd, and the cour≈øe is 6 miles: from Pulo Picon to Pulo Carymon, which is a great and high land with trees, with ≈øome Ilands round about it: you runne North and ≈øouth, and north and by we≈øt, and South and by ea≈øt, and are di≈øtant 5. miles: from the Iland Carymon there is about 3. miles to the coa≈øt of Samatra, you mu≈øt make towardes this Iland, and from thence run along by it, on the we≈øt ≈øyde, for it is good way. On the ≈øouth point of this Iland Carymon lyeth certain Ilandes: from the≈øe Ilandes two myles forward, lieth an other ≈ømal long Iland called Pulo Alonalon: there the channell is at the narrowe≈øt. From this Iland beginneth the ≈øtraight called E≈øtrecho de Sabon, that is ye ≈øtraight or narrow pa≈ø≈øage of Sabon, and being as farre as that Iland, you ≈øhall hold about half a mile from it: from Alonalon, to the great Iland of Sabon, are about 2 miles, in the middle of this channel, there lieth other ≈ømal Ilands, that ≈øhall all lie on the Ea≈øt ≈øide from you, hauing good regard not to fall vpon them: wheÃÑ you run through this channel, you mu≈øt be aduerti≈øed, that in the middle thereof there lieth a hidden Cliffe, vnder the water, whereon a ≈øhip did once ≈øtrike with her Ruther. Comming by the Iland Alanolon, on the Southwe≈øt thereof, that is on the ≈øyde of Sumatra, you ≈øhal ≈øee two ≈ømall Ilands, with an other ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe full of tr√©es, bee all rampard, with certaine cliffes lying by them: and wheÃÑ tho≈øe Ilandes are ≈øouthwe≈øt & ≈øouth we≈øt & by we≈øt froÃÑ you: theÃÑ you ≈øhal hold your cour≈øe South, where you ≈øhall find nyne fadome water, alwaies keeping off from the Coa≈øt of Sabon, which is the ea≈øt ≈øyde, for it is ≈øhallow, but run in the middle of the channel, for it is good ground: half a mile off from the Iland Sabon, lieth a ≈ømall Iland, called Pulo Pandha: this Iland in the middle hath a ≈øtonie cliffe, and when you are ≈øo farre that Pulo Pandha lyeth Ea≈øt≈øouthea≈øt from you, theÃÑ hold your cour≈øe ≈øouthward, and you ≈øhal find 9. fadome deepe, running half a myle di≈øtant from the Iland of Sabon: the Iland and cliffe afore≈øaid being pa≈øt, you ≈øhall find hard ground, holding your cour≈øe South vntill the Iland Pulo Pendha lieth northnorth ea≈øt from you, where you ≈øhall pre≈øently find muddy ground and from thence forward you may anker, if you will, and when the afore≈øayd Cliffe lyeth from you as afore≈øayd, then on the We≈øt ≈øyde, you ≈øhall ≈øee two

Ilands, two and two together, at the end whereof to ≈øeaward there is a white ≈øaÃÑd that alwaies lieth vncouered, all the≈øe I≈ølandes you ≈øhall leaue on your right hand, on the land ≈øide, and being on the ≈øouth ≈øide ≈øomewhat pa≈øt this white ≈øand, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e two high hils within the land which lie ea≈øt & we≈øt one from the other, & at the foote of the ea≈øt hill lieth the hauen of Calapa, where you ≈øhall anker, if you wil enter into the hauen, being pa≈øt the fore≈øaid ≈øands, & an Iland that lyeth from thence toward the land, then there wil foure Ilandes lie ≈øouthea≈øtward from you, which teach towards the land, & another clo≈øe by he land, then you ≈øhal take heed of a ≈øand, lying north ea≈øt clo≈øe by the hauen, which you may alwaies ≈øee, and when it is high water it is wa≈øhed away by the flood, you ≈øhal runne towardes the≈øe I≈ølandes which lie to ≈øeaward from the hauen b√©eing day time, to ≈øhunne the droughtes afore≈øaid.

div.head: The 27. Chapter. The cour≈øe from the Iland Pulo Timon, to the Hauen of Sunda in the Iland of Iaua Maior.
div.p:
FRom the Iland of Pulo Timon, you run to the Iland of Binton, to a point of land that from the ≈øame Iland runneth almo≈øt Ea≈øtward into the ≈øea ≈øouth Southea≈øt, and North Northwe≈øt, and hard by this point lieth certaine Riffes of ≈ømall rockes and cliffes, and on the north ≈øide of this point it hath an opening or mouth, wherein there lieth a great Iland with two hilles, and a vallie in the middle, and along by this point, le≈ø≈øe then halfe a mile from the land, there are eight fadome deepe of flatte and cleare ≈øandy ground, and hath no foulenes but the ≈øtone Cliffes, & Rockes that lie clo≈øe by the land: from this point afore≈øaid of the Iland of Binton, to the Southea≈øt point of the Iland Pulo Panion, which hath an Iland lying to ≈øeaward from it, you runne Southea≈øt, and Northwe≈øt, & Southea≈øt and by ea≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by We≈øt: betweene this Iland Pulo Panion, and the Iland of Binton lieth an opening, which in the middle way hath two flat ≈ømall Ilands, full of tr√©es, and if you cannot pa≈ø≈øe Pulo Panion on the ea≈øt ≈øide, then you may pa≈ø≈øe inward betw√©ene it and the land: it hath fiue and ≈øixe fadome d√©epe good ground, and you need feare nothing but that you ≈ø√©e before you. This Iland of Pulo Panion, lieth clo≈øe to the land of Binton, and if you fortune to be ≈øo neare the land, that you may not pa≈ø≈øe by it on the ≈øea ≈øide, then you mu≈øt runne to the northwe≈øt point, where there lieth a rouÃÑd Iland, which you ≈øhall leaue on the ≈øide of the Iland, not running betw√©ene it and the Iland, but round about it clo≈øe to the land, for it is faire running ≈øo inward along by the Ilands as I ≈øaid before, on the ≈øouthea≈øt point of this Iland Panion, there lieth many Ilands and Cliffes, and two miles Southea≈øtward from it lieth a round Iland full of tr√©es, you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene the≈øe two Ilands, towards the Iland of Linga, which is a faire cleare way and ≈øea, and if you chance to be by this afore≈øaid mouth or opening, then you ≈øhall runne on your cour≈øe outward about the Iland, for it is good way: from this round Iland or two miles ≈øouthward lieth a ≈øtonie Riffe, about the length of the ≈øhot of a great p√©ece, and hath but one Rocke that is vncouered, yet you may ≈ø√©e the water breake vpon them, which you mu≈øt ≈øhun. From this Iland to the end of the Ilandes of the land of Linga, (lying clo≈øe on the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the ≈øame Iland) you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe South, and South, and by Ea≈øt, and runne Southward outward, alwaies along the Ilandes, which ≈øhall lie We≈øtward from you, and when you haue ≈øayled twelue miles you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e right before you on the Southwe≈øt ≈øide, a ≈ømall round Iland lying to Seaward ≈øomewhat di≈øtant from the re≈øt, which is almo≈øt of forme like the Iland das Iarras, lying by Malacca, and foure miles before you come at it, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e two other ≈ømal round Ilands, lying along by the land, and ≈øeperated from the re≈øt but not far, and when you are as farre as the fir≈øt round Iland, b√©eing cleare weather, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the high land of the I≈øland of Linga, lying We≈øt, Southwe≈øtward from you aboue, or beyond the Ilandes (whereby you pa≈ø≈øe) which are all low houels and vallies, and in this ≈øort you ≈øhall runne along by the Ilands, & comming about thr√©e miles beyond the round I≈øland, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a ≈ømall I≈øland ≈øomewhat di≈øtant from the land, which at the fir≈øt ≈øheweth like two Cliffes, and there the land hath a point from thence running inwards making a cr√©eke (called a En≈øeada de Linga) and when you are as farre as this ≈ømall I≈øland, then We≈øt, Northwe≈øtward, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the high land of Linga, which ≈øheweth like two high rockes or hils, ≈øeperated from each other, and reach North and South, that in the North hauing two toppes like a Hares eares, and We≈øtward you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e another Land, which maketh a high crooked ridge ≈øomewhat ≈øt√©epe downeward. In all this way to the afore≈øaid round Iland, you ≈øhall finde ≈øeauent√©ene and eight√©ene fadome d√©ep hard and faire ground, to the point or end of the≈øe I≈ølands, and by it you ≈øhall haue twentie eight fadome, and comming by this point, (where you di≈øcouer the land lying We≈øt Southwe≈øt from you) to goe to Pulo Pon, (which is an I≈øland di≈øtant from Linga 8. miles, on the North ≈øide hauing two ≈ømall Ilandes, and when you are on the Northea≈øt ≈øide, it ≈ø√©emeth to be round, with a ≈øharpe hill in the middle, and from the Southea≈øt ≈øide it ≈øheweth two Hilles with a Vallie in the middle, as in effect it is,) then you mu≈øt runne South Southwe≈øt, and being thr√©e or foure miles forward, you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e the Iland of Pulo
Pon lie before you: in it you haue fre≈øh water, and round about it is fayre ground: when you ≈øee it, you ≈øhall make towards it: on the We≈øt ≈øide, and halfe a mile from it you ≈øhall finde 15. fadome deep, and being by it runne South, and ≈øouth and by Ea≈øt, with the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the hill of Manopijn, lying vppon the point of the I≈ølande Banca, where the ≈øtraight of Palimbon beginneth, and the ≈øeuen Ilands, called Pulo Tayo, ≈øhall lie ≈øouthea≈øtwarde from you, which are di≈øtant from Pulo Pon 7 miles, and if in this way you find your depthes to be aboue ten fadom, then you are on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, and hauing ten fadome, then you are 6. or ≈øeuen miles from Banca, and finding 8. fadome, you ≈øhall not be long before you ≈ø√©e the land of Sumatra, and as ≈øoone as you ≈ø√©e Manopijn, then runne within two miles thereof, before you enter into the ≈øtraight or channell, in the ≈øame manner holding your cour≈øe to the mouthes or cr√©ekes of Palimbon towards the coa≈øt of Sumatra, ≈øhunning a great cr√©ek, lying Northwe≈øt froÃÑ ye mouthes of PalimboÃÑ, vpon ye ≈øame coa≈øt of Sumatra, which hath a verie great hauen and entrie, whereby many ≈øhippes haue b√©ene deceyued that entred therein: it hath no ≈øhallowes, and pre≈øently (as you pa≈ø≈øe along the coa≈øt) you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the lande thereof ≈øtretching ≈øouth ≈øouthwe≈øt: from thence forwarde you holde your cour≈øe to Sunda, as in the voyage from Malacca to Sunda and Iaua is alreadie ≈øet down, therfore it is not nece≈ø≈øarie to rehear≈øe it againe.

div.head: The 28. Chapter. The cour≈øe along the coa≈øt of Sumatra, f ‚Ä¢ oÃÑ the out≈øide, beginning at the f ‚Ä¢ rthe≈øt point lying vnder fiue degrees, on the North ≈øide of the Equinoctiall, to the ≈øtraight of Sunda, and ≈øo to the I≈ølande Iaua Maior, with the ≈øituation of the coa≈øts.
div.p:
BEing by the furthe≈øt point or ende of the I≈øland of Sumatra, on the out ≈øide then you mu≈øt runne ≈øouth along the coa≈øt: it is a very high and plea≈øant country to behold, with many great cr√©ekes, and Bayes along by the coa≈øt. From this fir≈øt & further point, (called Achein) 12. miles forward to another point that reacheth into the ≈øea, the coa≈øt runneth South, and from thence to the ≈øands called Os Baixos de Tri≈øtan de Tayde (that is the ≈øandes of Try≈øtan de Tayde,) you mu≈øt runne along the coa≈øt Southea≈øt, and ≈øouthea≈øt and by ≈øouth: the cour≈øe is fiftie miles: by the≈øe Ilandes of Tri≈øtan de Tayde, there are many ≈øandes and ≈øhallows that lie round about them on the we≈øt, Northwe≈øt, and North ≈øides, with many Ilandes and Cliffes on the ≈øame ≈øides: the≈øe Ilandes afore≈øaid are ≈øomewhat like the Ilandes of Pulo, Sambilon, lying on the coa≈øt of Malacca to ≈øeawarde from the≈øe Ilands of Tri≈øtan de Tayde, there lyeth 2. Ilandes called Ilhas d'Ouro, that is, the gold Ilandes, whereof the neare≈øt lyeth at the lea≈øt 10 or 12. myles di≈øtant, the other 12. or 13. miles further into the ≈øea: they lie vnder two degr√©es, and ¬Ω on the North ≈øide of the Equinoctiall line: from thence you runne to the ≈øtraight of Sunda, hauing many Ilandes all along as you pa≈ø≈øe, as fir≈øt thr√©e Ilands lying vnder a degr√©e and a halfe, on the ≈øouth≈øide of the Equinoctiall, Ea≈øt and We≈øt from the≈øe Ilands lyeth a point vppon the coa≈øt of Sumatra, called Cabo das Correntes, (that is, the point of the ≈øtreame) becau≈øe there the ≈øtreame runneth very ≈øtrong towardes the Southwe≈øt, wherefore there is no other remedy then onely to runne clo≈øe by the ≈øhore: if you de≈øire to goe to the ≈øtraight of Sunda, you mu≈øt be verie careful, for there are ≈øo many Ilandes along by the coa≈øt, that they are not to be numbred, from the Iland of Tri≈øtan de Tayde, to the Ilandes of Manancabo are about 100. miles, and your cour≈øe is Northwe≈øt, and ≈øouthea≈øt, & ≈øomewhat Northwe≈øt and by North, and ≈øouthea≈øt and by ≈øouth, you mu≈øt run between the Ilandes As Ilhas d'Ouro, and the lande by which cour≈øe you ≈øhall come to the poynt O Cabo das Correntes, which is verie high, running into the ≈øea further then all the re≈øt of the land, but you mu≈øt not go too neere to the point, for there are certaine ≈øandes and cliffes ≈øticking out from it: this point lyeth vnder one degr√©e and ‚Öî. on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctiall. I ≈øet down no other marke to know the countrie of Sumatra, becau≈øe the ≈øtreames draue to ≈øeaward, without all the≈øe Ilands. & ≈øo I could not take a better cour≈øe then to put to the Iland called Ilha d'Ouro de Manancabo, that is, the golde Iland of Manancabo, and I fel on it vpon the ≈øea ≈øide running for the ≈øpace of 4. or 5. daies, along by it: it is a verie high and faire Iland to behold, ≈øo that you may ea≈øily iudge & well perceyue that it hath Gold: it is altogether of a ≈ømooth ≈øt√©epe grounde, & along by the ≈øea ≈øide it is about 10. or 12. miles in length, you run by it North & ≈øouth, and ≈øomewhat north
and b ‚Ä¢ We≈øt, and ≈øouth and by Ea≈øt: it hath on the ≈øea ≈øide 5. or 6. Ilandes, about a myle and a halfe di≈øtant from the land vnder thr√©e degrees, which is the height that I found, but they are di≈øtant from the firme lande of Sumatra 8. or 9. myles, the Riuer of Manancabo lying on the land of Sumatra right ouer again≈øt this countrie, I think it to be a verie great riuer: for from thence there runneth a great ≈øtreame, and much wood and other tra≈øh driueth from it at the lea≈øt 10. or 12. miles into the ≈øea. The be≈øt marke we found vpon this coa≈øt of Sumatra was, that we neuer left the ≈øight of land, but ran along by it, for by that cour≈øe you come to the Iland Ilha de Ouro, ≈øcarce to 3. and 3. degr√©es and ¬Ω. I write this becau≈øe you ≈øhall not tru≈øt to the running of the ≈øtreame, that draweth Southwe≈øtward, as I ≈øaid before: from the Iland Ilha de Ouro you run to the ≈øtraight of S ‚Ä¢ nda ≈øouthea≈øt, and Southea≈øt and by ≈øouth, and being pa≈øt Ilha de Ouro there lyeth two Ilandes, which reach North and ≈øouth one from the other, in the ≈øame cour≈øe with the I≈øland of Gold about 5. or 6. miles: nowe to runne to the mouth or entry of the ≈øtraight of Sunda, you mu≈øt not leaue the coa≈øt of the firme land, hauing good re≈øpect to the Ilandes and cliffes, whereof there are very many lying by it, that you can hardly know where to find ye mouth of the ≈øtraight, but onely by the knowledge of the I≈ølande, which is very high, lying right ouer again≈øt a point of the Iland of Sumatra, on the north ≈øide: this firme land of Sumatra endeth there, where with the Iland of Iaua Maior, it maketh the ≈øtraight: it hath on the Northwe≈øt ≈øide of this ≈øtraight two or thr√©e Ilands, lying about a mile from the land, and vpon the Ilandes that lie n√©ere≈øt to the lande there was once a ≈øhippe taken with French men, the great ≈øhotte being kept by the kinges of the I≈ølande of Banda, and Cal ‚Ä¢ pa, and a ‚Ä¢ mile ≈øouthwarde from the lande lyeth the Iland that hath a high ≈øharpe pointed hill, as I ≈øaide before, and on the North ≈øide of this high ≈øharp hil or Iland, are 4. Ilands, whereof one is verie high, reaching Northea≈øt and ≈øouthwe≈øt: they lie ≈øomewhat further from it, that is by the afore≈øaid Ilands clo≈øe by the point on the Northea≈øt ≈øide: betweene al the≈øe Ilands & the land there is a great cr√©eke, of man ‚Ä¢ hidden cliffes lying vnder the water, whereof ≈øome are vncouered, and thinke not to enter into this cr√©eke, vnle≈ø≈øe it be with a Fu≈øte, or a very ≈ømall ≈øhip, for it is better to runne towardes the Iland lying on the ≈øouth ≈øide thereof, along by the point, which you neede not feare, for it hath nothing that can hurt you, and then you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e lying before you on the Northea≈øt ≈øide a poynt of lande, which ≈øheweth to haue 2. or 3. Ilands at the end thereof: along by this point lyeth the mouth or entrie of the ≈øtraight of Sunda, where you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe through: this point reacheth North and ≈øouth, hauing in the North a high houell, the ≈øouth ≈øide being the ende of the ≈øame land: clo≈øe by the mouth of the ≈øtraight, for a better marke Northea≈øtward from you, you ≈ø√©e a long Iland, and on the ≈øouthea≈øt part a high land, which land lyeth aboue Bantam, a hauen in the Ilande of Iaua, where the Portingalles lade Pepper, which groweth & is gathered in that Ilande, and behind the afore≈øaide high lande lyeth the towne of Bantam, and before you come to the ≈øaid land that lyeth aboue Bantam, you ≈øhall in the Ea≈øt Northea≈øt perceiue two or thr√©e Ilands, and if you de≈øire to go to Bantam, you may pa≈ø≈øe betweene the≈øe Ilands, but I once againe adui≈øe you of the Iland lying in the mouth or channell or ≈øtraight of Sunda afore≈øaide, which is for a marke of the ≈øaid ≈øtraight, being very high, and deepe withall, and hath this token, that when you are pa≈øt or about the fir≈øt point or hooke, you may then anker at 20. and 25. fadome deepe as you haue occa≈øion, vnle≈ø≈øe it be clo≈øe to the land, where there lyeth many white ≈øtones, and rockes, and further to ≈øeawarde it is altogether muddie grounde, at 20. and 25. fadome, but it is be≈øt for you to anker as neere the lande as you may for your be≈øt ≈øecuritie, for there are many ≈øtiffe bla≈øtes that come out of the land: this high I≈øland or poynted hill lyeth vnder fiue degrees and ¬Ω. for there I haue often taken the height of the ≈øunne as I lay at anker, and the mouth or entry of the ≈øtraight of Sunda lyeth vnder ye ≈øame height: to ≈øea warde you haue the≈øe Ilandes as you pa≈ø≈øe to the mouth or entry of the ≈øtraight, the fir≈øt Ilandes lying We≈øt to ≈øeaward, from the afore≈øaid pointed high hill, or Iland, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt, or ≈øeuen miles from thence there is a rowe of Ilandes, with certaine Cliffes lying about them, and Southward other ≈øixe or ≈øeuen miles there lyeth other high and great Ilands, and al≈øo Southwe≈øtward from thence there are other Ilandes, betweene all the≈øe Ilandes there are many channelles, which are ≈øo narrow, that men can hardly get out of them: the be≈øt channell to runne through I founde by the afore≈øaide high pointed hill or I≈ølande on the South-Ea≈øt ≈øide, reaching Northea≈øt and ≈øouthwe≈øt: in all the≈øe channels you neede feare nothing but that which lyeth before your eies.

div.head: The 29. Chapter. To ≈øaile from Calapa in the I≈ølande Iaua Maior to China, with the cour≈øes and ≈øituations of the coa≈øts particularly ≈øet downe.
div.p:
SAyling out of the hauen of Calapa, you ≈øhall runne to an Iland lying by the poynt of Carauon, that lyeth n√©ere≈øt to the land, wherby you ≈øhal pre≈øently ≈øee two points of ≈øandie downes, which reach towardes the Ilands that reach to ≈øeaward: when they are on your right hande, then you mu≈øt put in betw√©ene the Ilandes, through the channell where the winde giueth you be≈øt way, for it is all fayre and good ground: being pa≈øt the≈øe Ilandes, you ≈øhall runne along by the coa≈øt to the point of Carauon, which lyeth Ea≈øtward about two and a halfe, or thr√©e myles in length, from thence to take your cour≈øe cro≈ø≈øe ouer to the I≈ølande of Lu≈øepara, and from this point of Carauon, lying on the coa≈øt of Iaua, you runne North and South to the Iland of Lu≈øepara or La≈øapara, and ≈øomewhat North and by We≈øt, and South and by Ea≈øt: the cour≈øe being fiftie miles the cour≈øe is holden in this manner, becau≈øe the Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt Southea≈øt winds as then beginne to blowe in tho≈øe countries, that is as ≈øoone as the month of May commeth on, and likewi≈øe as then the waters and ≈øtreams beginne to runne with the Mon≈øon of the year, (which is the coniunction and time of the certaine winds) towards the ≈øtraight of Sunda, the channell of Lampon, which beginneth from the mouth, & reacheth to a thicke point and cr√©eke with a Riffe, lying on the coa≈øt of Sumatra, about 18. or 19. miles from Lu≈øepara, in the Countrey afore≈øaide: by the point Carauon (which lyeth thr√©e myles froÃÑ the hauen of Calapa) you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe North Northea≈øt for 8. or 9. miles, whereby you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a round I≈øland, which will lie on the ≈øide of the land of Sunda or Iaua, and being pa≈øt this I≈øland, We≈øtwarde from thence you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a rowe of I≈ølandes, that do all reach North and ≈øouth, pa≈ø≈øing by the countrey of the mouth or ≈øtraight of Sunda, by this afore≈øaid round Ilande you ≈øhall find ground at 20. fadom, at the which depth you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe North, & North and by We≈øt, whereby you ≈øhall alwaies be within the ≈øight of the aboue named Ilands, to the ende of them, with the afore≈øaid depth of 20. fadome: when you beginne to lo≈øe the ≈øight of the≈øe Ilandes, being pa≈øt them you ≈øhall pre≈øently come to 14. and 13. fadome, and being at 13. fadome, you ≈øhall runne the ≈øame cour≈øe of North, and North and by ea≈øt, vntill as you thinke you are within 15. or 16 miles neere the Iland of Lu≈øepara, and being there, then run North, and there the depthes will begin to le≈ø≈øen to 11. fadome, which is a good cour≈øe, for that running at more depth you ≈øhould go outward at Lu≈øepara, & thus ≈øayling North, and at 1 ‚Ä¢ . fadome, as I ≈øaide before, you are in your right cour≈øe till you come to 9. fadom, and being there then looke about you, for you ≈øhall not runne long, but you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the I≈øland of L ‚Ä¢ ≈øepara, which will open like two ≈ømall houelles, lying Ea≈øt and we≈øt one from the other, yt in the ea≈øt being greater theÃÑ the other: in all this w ‚Ä¢ y in ye Month of May I found Ea≈øt & ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt windes, as I ≈øaid before, and according to the times of the waters, windes, and ≈øtreames, you ≈øhall gouerne your ≈øelfe in ≈øuch manner, that in your cour≈øe you alwaies run Northward, for it is your right cour≈øe, & be≈øt way from the point Carauon to the I≈øland Lu≈øepara, and if you go later to ≈øaile, hauing a ful wind, without any abatement or cutting off, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe right North, for it is very daungerous to ≈øaile without the Iland Lu≈øepara, therefore you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe in ≈øuch manner, that the Ilande may ly Ea≈øtward from you, becau≈øe Lu≈øepara lyeth twelue myles Ea≈øtwarde from the other Ilande, which is called Lu≈øepara fal≈øa, that is, fal≈øe or wrong Lu≈øepara, becau≈øe many ≈øhippes haue been deceyued by it, thinking it had b√©ene the right Lu≈øepara, when they came from the Iland of Iaua, and therefore they haue Ilandes or ≈øtony cliffes, lying 10. miles from Macau forward, to ≈øeaward from an Iland, betw√©en the which Iland and cliffe you may well pa≈ø≈øe, running along by the Iland, for it is a faire and great Channel: or if you will, you may pa≈ø≈øe to ≈øeaward without the cliffes if you de≈øire not to runne between them, you ≈øhall holde the cour≈øe as I heere ≈øet downe.
