Betweene the≈øe two I≈ølands there runneth a ≈ømall Channell: the whole Channell, from the≈øe thr√©e miles to the entery or pa≈ø≈øage of Varella, is thr√©e fadome deepe at full Sea, and that of Varella, as al≈øo the month of the chanell, (which runneth Ea≈øtward through it towards the Sea) is all deep: In the entery of the Channell of this I≈øland (at the foote of Varella) it hath a Cr√©eke with a Sandy baye, which is a good Road. From the South point of this I≈øland of Varella or Chini≈øh Temple to Sea ward, there lyeth thr√©e I≈ølands all on a row clo≈øe by each other, reaching Ea≈øt and We≈øt, which I≈ølands al≈øo are named after the name of Varella, whereby the Channell is knowne. This I≈øland of Varella or Chini≈øh Temple lyeth full vnder thirtie degr√©es, and is di≈øtant from the I≈ølands S ‚Ä¢ ong ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m afore≈øaid eight miles. From the I≈ølands S ‚Ä¢ ongicam eleuen or twelue myles, it is altogether great and high I≈ølands, lying clo≈øe by each other: but from thence to full one and thirtie degr√©es, they begin to b√©e le≈ø≈øe and ≈øomewhat more ≈øeparated. At the end of the≈øe I≈ølands there lyeth two I≈ølands together, whereof the Channell that runneth betw√©ene them hath a verye good harbour, it is called Lepion, they lye clo≈øe by a great Riuer, which is much inhabited and frequented by Marchaunts and other people. In this Hauen of Lepion the Iapons doe often Trafficke: from the end of this I≈øland along by the Sea coa≈øt the land is low and bankey ground, for that a mile from the land it is but a fadome and a halfe d√©epe, being hard ≈øtones. The people of ye country pa≈ø≈øe ouer it with nailed barkes, with pitched or loopes, two p√©eces, ≈øailes of r√©eds or mats, & an yron dreg
with ≈øharpe t√©eth. This coa≈øt reacheth Northea≈øt to foure and thirtie degr√©es, where there lieth a great riuer that commeth from Nanquyn, within the mouth or entry hath an I≈øland that is inhabited by many people, both hor≈øe and footemen. This I≈øland maketh the Riuer to haue two mouths or entries, from thence forward the land reacheth North Northea≈øt, and by Ea≈øt, and comming to that part which lieth Southea≈øt, there the land hath an end or point, and by that meanes it maketh a great Cr√©eke. From this point forward, the coa≈øt runneth North again, after turning again Northwe≈øtward: Into the which coa≈øt tho≈øe of Iapon doe ordinarily come to Trafficke with the Countrey people called Cooray, and there you haue Hauens and harbors, hauing a kind of ≈ømall open p√©eces of wouen worke, which the Iapons fetch from thence, whereof I am certainely informed, as al≈øo touching the nauigation vnto that land by Pilots that haue ≈øailed and ≈øearched cleane through it, as followeth. From this point of the Creeke of Nanquyn twenty miles Southea≈øtward, there lyeth certaine I≈ølands, at the end whereof on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, there lyeth a very great and high I≈øland much inhabited, as well by hor≈øe as footemen. The≈øe I≈ølands by the Portingales are called, As Ilhas de core, but the great I≈øland Core is called Chau≈øien, on the Northwe≈øt ≈øide it hath a ≈ømall Cr√©eke, wherein there lyeth an I≈øland, which is the Hauen, but it is not very d√©epe. There the lord of the country hath his pallace and is continually re≈øident. Fiue and twenty miles Southea≈øt from this I≈øland lieth the I≈øland of Goto, one of the I≈ølands of Iapon, which lyeth from the point of the Cr√©eke of Nanquyn Ea≈øt and by North, to Seaward ≈øixtie miles, or ≈øomewhat more. This in≈øtruction I had from a Nobleman of Portingale, called Pero da cunha, that hath ≈ø√©ene and trauelled through all the Countrey, hauing by him all adui≈øe ≈øeruing for the purpo≈øe, as being of great experience, hauing arriued and ≈øtayed in the Countrey afore≈øaid by tempe≈øt and ≈øtormy weather again≈øt their wils, minding to ≈øayle to Iapon, and from thence againe to the afore≈øaide I≈øland of Goto, the I≈ølands lying from this I≈øland towards the land betw√©ene them, and clo≈øe about them all ouer, are many riffes and ≈øtones. The in≈øtruction of the Cr√©eke of Nanquyn I had from an expert Pilote borne in the lande of Algaine in Spaigne, that lo≈øt his Shippe vpon the Sands that ≈øticke out from the Riuer of Nanquyn, hauing runne round about all this Cr√©eke with a Barke, and h√©e ≈øaide that being within when the Sunne ro≈øe, it came from ouer the land, and that from the riuer of Nanquyn there ranne ≈øome ≈øands and droughts, reaching ≈øouthward to two and thirty degr√©es, and to the middle way of the Goulfe of Iapon. Here endeth the de≈øcription of the furthe≈øt parts that the Portingales haue ≈øailed, along by the Coa≈øts, lands, and I≈ølands of the Kingdome of China, being that part thereof which at this day is knowne and di≈øcouered.

div.head: The 31. Chapter. The de≈øcription of a voiage made by a Portingale Pilote from Liampo to Iapon in a Chinchea Soma, that is a Chinchon ≈øhip, with the de≈øcription of the coa≈øt of Bungo, Miaco, Cacay, & the I≈øland Toca, all countries of Iapon.
div.p:
ON Wedne≈øday the thirty of Iune being the third day of the new moone, in the morning we ≈øet ≈øayle out of the northea≈øt chanell of the I≈øland Siongicam, with a ≈øouthea≈øt wind, and being without the I≈øland, we had the wind South Southea≈øt, and ran ea≈øt, and ≈øomewhat Ea≈øt and by North, about euening we had a South Southwe≈øt wind, running Ea≈øt, Ea≈øt and by South, and Ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt, with very great billowes out of the ≈øouth, whereby we could hardly k√©epe on our cour≈øe, ≈øayling with our ≈øayles but halfe vp, and in the morning we ran halfe a ≈øtrike ea≈øt and by ≈øouth, and ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt, becau≈øe the wind came ≈øome what ful to the South we≈øt, with ≈øhoures of raine and great billowes that ro≈øe very high, by which means the waters and ≈øtreames in the≈øe countries run Northward, we made our account to haue ≈øailed, in the cour≈øe of Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt, and by North 26 miles in one meale tide, which was til thur≈øday at noone, being the fir≈øt of Iuly. We had alwaies great and mighty waues, becau≈øe it was a Spring tyde, all the night
hauing great lightnings out of the Ea≈øt, and in all the points of the Compa≈ø≈øe from North to South. On thur≈øday the fir≈øt of Iuly from noone to night, we had a ≈øouthwe≈øt wind, running Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt and by South, and ≈øomwhat Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, with great ≈øhowres of raine without any high wind: and being two houres within night, the ≈økie clo≈øed round about and became clo≈øe with a great raine, wherwith the wind beganne to be calme, turning Northward, which the officers of the Soma perceiuing (being men of China) they began to be in great feare, for the Chinais doe hold for certaine, that in the Moone of the moneth of Iuly vntill it bee 12. dayes old, all along the coa≈øt of China there will follow great ≈øtormes, and as I thinke it is till S. Iames day, till when they alwaies looke for ≈øtormes and foule weather, for that I my ≈øelfe vpon the ≈øame day haue pa≈ø≈øed two great ≈øtormes. And touching our North wind ye began ≈øtill to encrea≈øe, they perceiuing it, put pre≈øently We≈øtward againe towardes the I≈ølands, and had ≈øayled from noone to that time about ten miles, in ≈øuch manner, that as wee ge≈ø≈øed we were 36. miles from the land of China, and ≈øo w√©e held our cour≈øe in that manner We≈øt and We≈øt and by North: after that hauing a clo≈øe ≈økie with little wind, whereby we made very litle way. On Friday the North wind beganne to blowe higher, wee running ≈øo till noone, and in that We≈øterly cour≈øe w√©e ≈øayled about ≈øixe miles. From Friday at noone we ≈øailed with this North wind all that euening, and by night til Saterday in the morning, & then the wind came Northea≈øt, & then Ea≈øt, and ≈øo We≈øt till noone, whereby wee made our account to haue ≈øailed eight√©ene miles, letting the ≈øhippe goe We≈øt, and We≈øt and by North: and in all that time w√©e had neither Sunne nor Starre to take the height. On Saterday two or thr√©e houres after noone the wind fell South, the weather beginning to cleare vp, and ≈øo w√©e ranne one gla≈ø≈øe, and perceiuing the weather to ≈øettle, we turned againe towards Iapon, being as then in mine opinion about 12. myles from the coa≈øt of China, and ≈øo we held our cour≈øe that euening, and all the next night Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by South, with a ≈ømall wind and calme Sea. The next day being Sonday at noone, we tooke the height of the Sunne at 30. degr√©es 1/ ‚Ä¢ . part le≈ø≈øe, & w√©e ≈øet out vnder 29. degr√©es and ‚Ä¢ . accounting for one mealetide thirt√©ene miles: ≈øo that I ge≈ø≈øed as then to be 25. myles from China. On Sonday after noone we held our cour≈øe in the ≈øame ≈øort, Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt and by South, for all that euening and the night following till the next day at noone, with a ≈øtill winde and water, and had no Sunne to take the height, but I made my account of eight√©en miles for a meale tide at halfe a ≈øtrike to the Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, the wind being ≈øcant South. From Monday at noon we ≈øtill had a calme South wind, which continued ≈øo, that euening, and all night: and about Tue≈øday morning, the wind was ≈øomwhat fuller till noone, wheÃÑ I tooke the height of the Sunne and found vs to be vnder 29. degrees and ¬æ. running Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by South, for the ≈øpace of 22. miles. From Tue≈øday at noone being vnder the height afore≈øaid, I willed them to ≈øaile ea≈øt (hauing the ≈øame wind, but ≈øomewhat calmer) all that night to Wedne≈øday at noone, and then we began to ≈ø√©e driuing in the ≈øea ≈øome Sea-≈øcumme or Cuttle bones, hauing ≈øayled fift√©ene myles, making my account to be yet 30. miles from the I≈øland Tanaxuma, hauing neither Sunne nor Starres to take the heights. From Wedne≈øday at noone the wind began to blow ≈øomwhat full South Southwe≈øt, and becau≈øe it was ≈øignified vnto me that the ≈øtreames in that countrey ranne towardes the I≈øland of Lequeo, and perceiuing likewi≈øe in ≈øome places a certaine yellowe ≈økumme driuing vpon the water (which appeared vnto vs like ripe Limons) I willed them pre≈øently to holde Ea≈øt Northea≈øt: and about euening w√©e ≈øawe many ≈øignes of land, as p√©eces of r√©edes, ri≈øen, and ≈øuch like things. At night I badde them runne Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt and by North, but the fir≈øt watch b√©eing done when the Chini≈øh Pilot ≈øhould watch his cour≈øe, h√©e had gone a great way out of the cour≈øe: hauing runne Ea≈øtward till the morning, when againe I willed them to ≈øayle Ea≈øt and by North (the winde b√©eing as it was) till Thur≈øday at ten of the clocke, and then (although it was darke and clo≈øe weather) wee beganne to ≈ø√©e a land that ≈ø√©emed verie cloudie, and couered with dampie mi≈øtes, lying Southea≈øt from vs, and were about thr√©e myles from it. Along by the ≈øame lande there lay two
I≈ølandes, w√©e holding our cour≈øe in the ≈øame ≈øort, vntill by the fir≈øt land Ea≈øtward, wee ≈øawe another great high and long lande, and at the end of the afore≈øaid high land Ea≈øtward, w√©e ≈øawe two other I≈ølandes, whereof the one was verie great, ≈øtretching Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt, and the other clo≈øe by it ≈øtretching North and South, being the ≈ømalle≈øt, with many pointes. On the North ≈øide of this ≈ømall I≈øland about a mile from thence, there are fiue ≈ømall I≈ølands or ≈øtonie Cliffes vpon a rowe: from the fir≈øt I≈øland that we ≈øawe (which is the la≈øt I≈øland of tho≈øe that are called As Sete Irmaas, that is, the ≈øeuen ≈øi≈øters, lying on the Northea≈øt ≈øide) to the afore≈øaid ≈ømall I≈øland with many pointes, it may be about ≈øixe myles Ea≈øtward, as we were right again≈øt the afore≈øaid fir≈øt I≈øland of Stonie Cliffes, it might b√©e about fiue houres after noone, hauing run as we thought ≈øince wee had ≈øight of land about twentie and foure miles. The Thur≈øday afore≈øaid in the morning, w√©e tooke the height of the North Starre, being vnder thirtie degrees and ‚Öô.

Comming within two myles of the I≈øland (that w√©e ≈øaw fir≈øt) of the I≈ølands of ≈øtonie Cliffes, wee ranne Northea≈øt and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and when wee were right again≈øt it, whereby it laie Southward from vs, b√©eing about thr√©e myles from it, on the North ≈øide thereof w√©e ≈øawe another great high and long Iland with many trees, which (as w√©e learned) is called Icoo: it reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and w√©e were about three miles from it, but by rea≈øon of the darke weather and mi≈øtes wee could not di≈øcerne it: and comming ≈øomewhat n√©erer to it w√©e ≈øawe another I≈øland lying clo≈øe by the We≈øt point of the afore≈øaid Iland, beeing le≈ø≈øe than the other: and becau≈øe w√©e were by the afore≈øaid We≈øt point, (betweene both) wee were fully determined to runne through the channell, that ≈øhewed betweene the ≈øaid two I≈ølandes, but becau≈øe there was no man in the ≈øhippe that had any knowledge thereof, fearing Riffes and ≈øhallowes, wee dur≈øt not aduenture, but wound vp to the Ea≈øt point, to pa≈ø≈øe by the winde about the high I≈øland, running as much as w√©e might with a Southerly winde, hauing great waues that put vs to the lande, and ≈øo wee ≈øayled Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, hauing yet about two myles to pa≈ø≈øe by the I≈øland, but night came on beeing verie darke, ≈øo that wee could di≈øcerne no land, although wee were clo≈øe by it, and to keepe from it, wee ranne the ≈øame cour≈øe till about one of the clocke after midnight, then the moone ≈øhined, yet w√©e could not ≈øee the I≈øland, but made Northward towardes it with fewe Sailes to the I≈øland of Tanaxuma, which (according to my account) ≈øhould lie right before vs: wherewith w√©e pa≈ø≈øed ouer the re≈øt of the night till the morning, when we ≈øawe the I≈øland Tanaxuma, that laye right before vs, beeing about two myles from it, it beeing verie cloudie, and w√©e made Northward towardes it to pa≈ø≈øe by the We≈øt ≈øide thereof, but w√©e could not doe it, by rea≈øon that the winde was Southwe≈øt, and wee were by the South point thereof, running along by the Ea≈øt ≈øide, about halfe a mile from it. This I≈øland reacheth North and South, beeing long and lowe ground, hauing white ≈øandie ≈øtrandes, with a verie gr√©ene countrey of valleyes, it hath many Pine trees, but they ≈øtand ≈øcattering from each other, and verie open: it is about ≈øeuen or eight myles long, hauing in the middle way on the Ea≈øt ≈øide clo≈øe by the land, an I≈øland or ≈øtonie Cliffe, which farre off ≈øheweth like a Foi≈øt vnder Saile. This I≈øland lyeth vnder thirtie degrees and ¬Ω. right in the middle, it is all ≈øaire and cleare ground. From this I≈øland of Tanaxuma Northwarde, w√©e ≈øawe a verie great and high lande reaching Ea≈øt and We≈øt, about eight miles, making as it ≈øeemed on the ≈øame coa≈øt Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by North from Tanaxuma, an opening, which is the mouth of the creeke called Xabuxij. This Cr√©eke hath for a marke, that the lande on the Ea≈øt ≈øide thereof runneth all ≈øt√©eping to the hooke or point of the Creeke, beeing a flatte ground: and on the We≈øt ≈øide the land is as high as the fir≈øt that wee ≈øawe lying North and South with Tanaxuma. This coa≈øt afore≈øaid may lie di≈øtaÃÑt ouerthwart from the I≈øland of Tanaxuma about ≈øeuen or eight myles. From the North point of this I≈øland wee made towardes the Cr√©eke, and b√©eing in the middle of our way, the wind fell We≈øt Southwe≈øt, whereby wee were enforced to lye by it, the weather b√©eing calme, ≈øo that the
water that with the flood ranne Ea≈øtward, draue vs off that w√©e could hardly get the Hauen, but the ebbe that after ranne very ≈øtiffe into it made vs get in, and with the glim≈øing of the euening and the light Moone, w√©e entred into a verie great goulfe, wherein lay the afore≈øaide Cr√©eke on the North ≈øide, and within on the Ea≈øt ≈øide it hath a ≈ømall I≈øland full of tr√©es, lying about the ≈øhot of a ba≈øe from the land. Ea≈øtward from this I≈øland the land hath a high houell, and on the South ≈øide of the ≈øaid houell, there lyeth a great opening, which on the other ≈øide hath a point of low land and white ≈øand ≈øtrands with tr√©es. There is the Hauen called Minatto, which is a riuer better than that of Batecola, lying in the coa≈øt of Malabar. On the North ≈øide of this houell about a ≈ømall myle there is another opening, b√©eing in a land that is ≈øomewhat lower as the houell, with ≈øome tr√©es. This opening right in the middle hath an I≈øland, wherein is the place of Xibuxij, which is a great village full of people, and is a riuer of fre≈øh water, but it is ≈øhallowe, for you can not put into it without a ≈øpring tide. From Xibuxij forward the Cr√©eke runneth We≈øt, all lowe land and ≈øandie ≈øtrandes, for the ≈øpace of two miles from thence it runneth Southward againe till it butteth vpon a high hill, which is that which w√©e ≈øawe comming from the I≈øland Tanaxuma to the foote of the hill, there lyeth a ≈ømall riuer very ≈øhallow: From this riuer the land runneth Ea≈øt againe to the mouth thereof, which may b√©e about halfe a myle broad. The ground of all this Cr√©eke and entrie is ≈øand and bad anker ground. All this high land afore≈øaid is called Quimon≈øiquy. From this Cr√©eke of Xibuxij ≈øeuen myles Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, lyeth the Cr√©eke of Tanora, which is one of the be≈øt Hauens of Iapon: you runne the coa≈øt Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt & by North, in the middle way from Xibuxij to Tanora there is a ≈ømall Cr√©eke or Bay, which at the fir≈øt ≈øhewe ≈ø√©emeth to haue a good harbor, but when you are right again≈øt it, then you may verie well perceiue it, for it hath many ≈øtonie Cliffes and Rockes, and runneth ≈øomewhat to landward. I heare ≈øet downe the de≈øcription of this Cr√©eke, that no man ≈øhould deceiue him≈øelfe therby, that de≈øireth to goe vnto Tanora, as w√©e ≈øhould haue done. B√©eing pa≈øt this ≈ømall Cr√©eke, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e that the land maketh an end or point of high lande, from the which point forward the coa≈øt windeth inward, where you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a ≈øandie ≈øtrand with two Ilandes full of tr√©es lying along by it: At the end of the≈øe I≈ølands you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e other ≈ømaller I≈ølands, that lye off from the land inward to the Sea, with other great ≈øtones and rockes. Within the≈øe Ilands and Stones lyeth the Hauen of Tanora, and to put into this Hauen you mu≈øt run to the point and the end of the≈øe I≈ølands and Stones that reach into the Sea, and b√©eing pa≈øt them, then on the Northea≈øt ≈øide to Seaward there will lie a ≈øtonie Cliffe with an I≈øland without bu≈øhes or tr√©es, b√©eing ≈øt√©epe land, reaching North and South: betw√©ene this I≈øland and the land there is a great Cr√©eke where you may anker, for right ouer again≈øt it, it is 25 fadome d√©epe, but there is not the right Hauen: but when you are about the point and the end of the afore≈øaid I≈ølands and Stones that ≈øticke outward to Sea, then you ≈øhall pre≈øently pa≈ø≈øe along thereby inward towards the land, which you may freely doe without danger, for it is faire and cl√©ere, holding your cour≈øe We≈øtward, and a point of land will be vpon your right hand: and b√©eing pa≈øt this point, you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe clo≈øe by, ≈øhunning the land on the We≈øt ≈øide, and being there you are within the Hauen, which is a long Cr√©eke or Bay reaching North till you be in: you may ancre in the middle thereof at foure fadome d√©epe, and then you are inclo≈øed with a round bowe, it is there altogither muddy ground. Departing from Tanora to Fyunga the coa≈øt runneth North to a point of land, lying about fiue myles from Tanora: betw√©ene this point of land and Tanora there lyeth two Hauens, the one called Gico, not farre from Tanora, the other further forward (by ≈øome ≈øtonie Cliffes and I≈ølands) called Vmbra. The≈øe two Hauens are good harbors for Ea≈øt winds that blowe much on this coa≈øt, from the afore≈øaid point of land to Fyunga, may be fiue miles more, from whence the coa≈øt & land doe turne in againe like a Cr√©eke: comming ≈øomewhat further Northward out, this Cr√©eke is a low land (along by the Sea coa≈øt) with ≈øandy ≈øtrands, and a mile beyond ye afore≈øaid point of land, the coa≈øt hath an opening, and on the South ≈øide of this opening there ≈øtandeth a great round tr√©e clo≈øe by the Sea ≈øide: here is a
good Hauen, which is called Vndo, and further forward there lyeth another Hauen called Tocono≈øuchy, this land is higher then the other hauen: on the South≈øide it hath ≈øome high and great Tr√©es, and on the North≈øide a low land, the which farre off & outward ≈øheweth like ≈ømall I≈ølands with trees. This hauen is not good to put in. A mile beyond this hauen there is another Hauen called Myme, which is a good hauen for ≈ømall ≈øhippes to enter, and hath two enteries, which you pre≈øently ≈ø√©e b√©eing without, and may well di≈øcerne them, in the middle hauing a flat I≈øland full of Trees, the≈øe Trees make two openings, and you may ≈øee ouer the I≈øland on the land (which is higher) a great gr√©ene tr√©e, the land on the South ≈øide hath a high land with a valey.

From this Hauen about two myles and a halfe lieth another ≈ømall I≈øland called Tomxyma, beyond this Riuer a myle and a halfe endeth the low land, and then again it beginneth to be high, from thence two myles further, the land maketh a point or hooke of high land, and a farre off ≈øeemeth to be the point called Cabo de Ramos lying on ye coa≈øt of India by Goa. Sailing about this point, hard by there is a Riuer Northward called Camyco, which is two fadome deepe in the Hauen: this is the furthe≈øt land of the kingdome of Fiunga. From ye point of land afore≈øaid (fiue miles di≈øtant from Tanora) to this point of Camico, the lande is like a Cr√©eke or breech, the water therein making a cro≈ø≈øe ≈øtreame, for along by the land the Water runneth alwaies Southward, you runne this point with the afore≈øaid point of land North and South, and North and by ea≈øt, and South and by We≈øt, and are about eight miles di≈øtant: along by this Br√©ech you may anker at twelue and fift√©ene fadome deepe, faire ≈øandy ground.

From this point called Cabo de Camico forward, the coa≈øt runneth north northwe≈øt, and when you are right again≈øt this point, then you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e Northea≈øtward, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt the land of Toca, which is an i≈øland, and is about fortie myles long, and reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, and We≈øt and by South, it hath on the North ≈øide with the land of Iapon, a ≈øtraight or narrow pa≈ø≈øage which runneth to the Hauen of Saquay, and the land of Miaco, and from the ≈øide of the I≈øland along by it, there are many ≈ømall I≈ølands. The cour≈øe you mu≈øt hold through this ≈øtraight to the Hauen of Saquay or Sacay, is altogether along the coa≈øt and the land of Iapon, which hath many and good Hauens. At the end of this ≈øtraight both the≈øe lands haue each of them a point of land ≈øticking out, being from the one to the other about a mile: by the point of the land of Toca, it is banky ground, and all the people of this land (on the North ≈øide) are not in any ≈øort to b√©e tru≈øted. Likewi≈øe, you may pa≈ø≈øe from the South ≈øide of this I≈øland Toca to the land of Myaco, where all along it is good ≈øayling, and there are very good Hauens. The fir≈øt hauen whereof lyeth on the fir≈øt point of land, on the We≈øt ≈øide of the I≈øland, which clo≈øe by it hath certaine I≈ølands and Cliffes: this Hauen is called Focora, it hath a good harbour for all windes, but not for Rouers, for there they haue many Foi≈øtes wherewith they roue and ≈øteale. At the Ea≈øt end of this I≈øland Toca, lying with the land of Iapon, right ouer again≈øt it there is another ≈øtraight or pa≈ø≈øage like that on the We≈øt ≈øide, where you runne to the Hauen and Town of Sacay. In the middle way from the afore≈øaied Ea≈øt ≈øide of Toca lyeth a Hauen called A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , which is inha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ted by a very fierce and ≈øtout people. There is alwaies a great army of Foi≈øtes prepared for the warres, wherewith they robbe and ≈øpoyle all the Coa≈øt along. The Shippes and Foi≈øtes that de≈øire to pa≈ø≈øe through it, a≈øking leaue, they may pa≈ø≈øe without let or hinderance. On the Ea≈øt ≈øide afore≈øaid, the land of Iapon reacheth much ≈øouthward, making a hooke or end called Cumano, and the coa≈øt that reacheth thether is called Bandol: It hath ≈øome Hauens that were inhabited by very rich and mightie people, but they are neither ≈øecure nor free. The Hauen of Sacay lyeth from the booke or end of the I≈øland of Toca Northea≈øt, about nine or tenne myles.

This Hauen of Sacay with a We≈øt wind is harborle≈ø≈øe, (which make many great tides) and hath a ≈øhallow ≈øandie ground: For the which cau≈øe, the Ships that come laden thether, are pre≈øentlie vnladen, and the people leape on land, leauing the Shippe fa≈øt bound, and ≈øometimes draw it on land.

From the point O Cabo de Camico,
fiue myles to a point of land, you runne along the coa≈øt North Northwe≈øt, and in the way you haue foure or fiue I≈ølands and cliffes along the coa≈øt, and right ouer again≈øt the afore≈øaid point, there lyeth two other I≈ølands clo≈øe by the land, hauing betw√©ene them both a ≈ømal channel, and clo≈øe by both on the North and ≈øouth≈øide ≈øides, there are many I≈ølands and Cliffes both great and ≈ømall. The≈øe two I≈ølands with the I≈ølands and Cliffes lye Ea≈øt and We≈øt with the Hooke and the end of Toca vnder thr√©e and thirty degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . All this coa≈øt is high land, with the I≈ølands lying along by it, and hath ≈øixtie and ≈øeuentie fadome d√©epe clo≈øe by the land. From thence forward beginneth the ≈øtraight or pa≈ø≈øage to be narrow betw√©ene this I≈øland of Toca and the land of Bungo, and if in this countrey you haue n√©ede to anker, then put to the land of Toca, where you ≈øhall finde muddye ground. When you are about the afore≈øaid point of two I≈ølands, then the land beginneth We≈øtward to turne in, all high land, hauing within clo≈øe on the South≈øide a ≈ømall I≈øland, you mu≈øt take h√©ed of this Cr√©eke that the ≈øtreames drawe you not in: being pa≈øt this Cr√©eke, you ≈øhall (in the middle way of the channell in the ≈øtraight) ≈ø√©e right before you a ≈ømal round I≈øland, which ≈øhall lye on the Ea≈øt ≈øide from you, and along by the coa≈øt fiue miles, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e another I≈øland lying hard by the land, which to ≈øea ward from it, hath many ≈øtony cliffes and Rockes. By this I≈øland Northea≈øtward, about a myle and a halfe, there lyeth two other I≈ølands.

Beyond the≈øe two I≈ølands another myle and a halfe, lyeth another long I≈øland with a flat plaine or field on the top thereof, reaching Northwe≈øt and ≈øouthea≈øt, the Southea≈øt and thereof being the highe≈øt. Within this I≈øland towards the We≈øt lyeth the Creeke of V≈øquy, where the king of Bungo holdeth Court. If you de≈øire to put in there, you ≈øhall runne towards the fir≈øt I≈øland, k√©eping from the afore≈øaid I≈øland, and the I≈ølands and Cliffes lying by it, holding your cour≈øe through betweene it and the other two I≈ølands (that lye further forward) being pa≈ø≈øed in by this I≈øland and the I≈ølands and ≈øtony Cliffes, you ≈øhall ≈øee We≈øtward within the Cr√©eke a great, round, and a high I≈øland full of Tr√©es, wherevnto you ≈øhall runne, alwaies k√©eping n√©erer the two I≈ølands, then the I≈øland of ≈øtony Cliffes, for by the Iland of Stony Cliffes, you haue ≈øeuentie fadome d√©epe, and within the two I≈ølands We≈øtward, you finde but 25 fadome, muddy ground, holding your cour≈øe in that manner to the afore≈øaid I≈ølands that lye in the Cr√©eke, k√©eping on the North ≈øide, for there it is faire and cl√©ere, and being right again≈øt this I≈øland, you ≈øhall find twenty fadome d√©epe, where you ≈øhall anker, that from them you may ≈ø√©e the hauens, which are two, the one lying (a ≈ømal mile from this I≈øland towards the Southwe≈øt) by a point of land‚ñ™ whereon there ≈øtandeth ≈øixe or ≈øeuen tr√©es, ≈øeperated one from ye other with ≈øome bu≈øhes, you mu≈øt put to this point, which within it hath a ≈ømall Bay or Cr√©eke, at the end whereof ≈øtandeth a riffe of ≈øtone reaching from thence into the Sea, in the which lyeth the afore≈øaid ≈ømall Cr√©eke, which hath a very good harbour, at thr√©e fadome d√©epe good and fair ground, where you ≈øhall anker, but it is not for great ≈øhippes. The other Hauen is Northwe≈øtward, on the other ≈øide of the Cr√©eke, hauing in it ≈øome I≈ølands and ≈øtones, it is a great Bay which runneth inward to the land, making a bow with very good harbor: This hauen is for great ≈øhips.

From this Cr√©eke of V≈øquy ≈øomewhat further Northward, lyeth another great Creeke, which runneth inwards We≈øt Northwe≈øt. The Land and the point betw√©ene the≈øe two Cr√©ekes, may bee from the one Sea to the other, about the length of the ≈øhot of a great P√©ece in breadth, and halfe a myle from the end of the point We≈øtward on the South ≈øide lyeth a ≈ømall I≈øland clo≈øe by the Land, betw√©ene the which and the land runneth a channell of twelue fadome deepe, with faire ground of great ≈øand, where I haue ankered. Right ouer again≈øt this I≈øland on the Northwe≈øt Land, about the length of the ≈øhotte of a great P√©ece, lyeth a ≈ømall Creeke, with a village called Sanganaxeque, where Don France≈øco Ma≈øcharenhas lay with his ≈øhippe for the mon≈øon: This hauen with a northwe≈øt wind is harbourle≈ø≈øe.

From this Cr√©eke about halfe a myle forward, you beginne to haue lowe land with ≈øandie ≈øtrands and Tr√©es all along the Sea coa≈øt. By all this coa≈øt and the
low land, it is all bankey grounds, wherfore you mu≈øt keepe from it about halfe a myle. In the middle way of this lowe land, there lyeth two mouths or entries of Riuers that are very ≈øhallow, whereby you may not enter into them by any meanes, and at the end of this low land you haue a riuer of fre≈øh water of twelue Spannes in the Hauen at a Spring tide, and within the Riuer at lowe Water the Shippes lie drie, being ≈øandy ground. Clo≈øe by the Roade or entry of this Riuer lyeth a Village called Aquina Fama: Halfe a myle within the Land vpon the Riuer, lyeth the greate≈øt and mightie≈øt Towne in all the Kingdome of Bungo, where the Kings in time pa≈øt held their Courts, where now all the Marchaunts of the Countries round about it, (who are very rich and aboundant in wealth) are re≈øident.

From this Riuer vpon the other ≈øide of the Creeke lyeth a very good Hauen, with harbour again≈øt all windes, it is a ≈ømall Bay, for the points or heights therof doe runne through each other, wherefore they make a good defence again≈øt the South windes. The entry of this hauen is faire, you need but run in through the middle of the Channell, where you haue foure and a halfe, and fiue fadome deepe, and there you haue great furtherance, for you runne in before the winde with the South Mon≈øon, and you put out againe before the winde with the North Mon≈øon: to vnder≈øtand it well, you mu≈øt know that all this Countrey (as al≈øo all China, Malacca, India, and all the orientall places,) doe ≈øayle with the coniunction of the windes, which for certaine months together blowe out of one place, as now in the North then in the South, and that at certaine times and dayes in the yeare without fayling: which coniunction is called (as in other places I haue ≈øaid) the Mon≈øon, as Mon≈øon of the South winde, that is, when the wind bloweth out of the South and mon≈øon of the North Windes in like ≈øort, wherewith through all India they make their accounts to pa≈ø≈øe from the one place to the other. And becau≈øe in this de≈øcription there is oftentimes mention made of ≈øome Hauens, Creekes, Riuers, Bayes and I≈ølands, where you haue good harbor for the Mon≈øon of the North and South Windes when they blowe, which is to b√©e vnder≈øtoode, (that if they b√©e again≈øt you in the way you ≈øhould hold) you ≈øhould know which hauen is good to ≈øtay in for that time, or to winter in: for in the Ea≈øt Countries you mu≈øt Winter when the winde is again≈øt you, ≈øo that you cannot holde on your voyage, and of force you mu≈øt ≈øtay for the wind and weather, that is, the Mon≈øon which ≈øerueth you, and where you haue a good harbour to ≈øtay for the Mon≈øon that you mu≈øt haue, and then to follow on your voyage. Wherefore I thought it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øet this downe, that you might the better vnder≈øtand the meaning of the Portingall and Indian Pilotes, that fir≈øt ≈øet downe, noted, and ob≈øerued the≈øe cour≈øes and Nauigations, v≈øing here the ≈øame manner and de≈øcription of the countrey, not chaunging the word of Mon≈øon, although that in ≈øome places before, I haue ≈øaied ≈øome thing thereof.

But to the matter, you mu≈øt knowe that the afore≈øaid Hauen or Bay is called Fingy, but it is not free from Rouers and theeues. From the afore≈øaid Riuer to this Hauen there is about three myles cro≈ø≈øewaies: In the Roade of the Riuer it is twenty fadome deepe clo≈øe by the land, but it is bad ground, and there it is not good to ≈øtay for the windes, for there you could not ≈øaue any thing. From this point you may ≈øee the Ea≈øt land, and at the end where this great Creeke endeth, it is low land, which is called M ‚Ä¢ ryee, and is all along faire and cleare. The afore≈øaid Riuer and Towne lye vnder 33 degrees and ‚Ä¢ .

From this point or end of M ‚Ä¢ ryee, two myles further, there is another point of land which lyeth with this point North and South, it is a low land with ≈øandie ≈øtrands, at the end whereof lyeth certaine ≈øtones and Rockes, from thence forward you runne Northward along the coa≈øt, and a myle beyond it, there is a Village called Tamboca, and another myle further lyeth another place called Tambico, lying both on the Sea ≈øide, but they haue no Hauens with harbours, al≈øo the people of the ≈øame places are not to bee tru≈øted. Beeing right again≈øt this point of Land, you ≈øhall along the coa≈øt ≈øee a long I≈øland, which a farre off ≈øheweth like two I≈ølands, lying di≈øtant from the land about
two myles, it is called Fimexima, betw√©en this I≈øland and the land it is all ≈øhallows from the point of the Cr√©eke of Bungo, to this I≈øland afore≈øaid. All this coa≈øt along for the ≈øpace of a great myle is bankey ground, Riffes, Stones, and other filth. All this way from the beginning of the Kingdome of Bungo, to this I≈øland, you mu≈øt runne on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, along by the land of Tocaa.

From this I≈øland of Fimexima afore≈øaid, nine myles Northward there is a very high Lande which reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, that is the land of Amanguchen, a great mighty and rich country, for therein is one of the mines of ≈øiluer of the countrey of Iapon.

In this coa≈øt are good Hauens, as al≈øo the I≈øland of Meagima, which in times pa≈øt (before the Portingales trauelled to Iapon) had great Trafficke, for there was the ≈øtaple of all the countrey of Iapon, for all kindes of wares and Marchandi≈øes. Along by this land of Amaguchen, and the country of the I≈øland Fimexima afore≈øaid, beginneth the ≈øtraight or pa≈ø≈øage to Facunda, of the which as al≈øo the other places thereabouts, I will ≈øpeake in another place, together with the Nauigation and ≈øcituation thereof.

To ≈øayle from the point of Moryee, in the Cr√©eke of Bungo to the Hauen of Caminaxique, (lying in the country of Amanguchen) which is very ≈øure and good for all winds, and of great Trafficke: you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, being about ≈øixt√©ene myles. This Lande which you goe vnto is very great and high, and you runne all the afore≈øaid coa≈øt along (to a Hooke or point of Lande) Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, and We≈øt and by South, and from the Hauen of Caminaxique to the afore≈øayed Point about fortie Portingale myles, whereof ≈øeuent√©ene and ¬Ω. make a degr√©e, as all the myles in this de≈øcription likewi≈øe doe, in the which coa≈øt lyeth the Hauens hereafter following, that is, from Caminaxique to Toraque, are about two myles and ‚Ä¢ . from Toraque, to the I≈øland Meagima are ≈øixe myles and a halfe. The Roade of this I≈øland is betw√©ene it and the Firme Lande: from Meagima to Camangary are a myle and a halfe, from thence to the I≈øland of Anooxyma are fiue myles.
From Anooxyma to Toumoo, are al≈øo fiue miles.
From thence to Xynaco are fiue myles.
From Xynaco to the Hauen of Vxymando are fiue myles.

From Vxymando to the Hauen of Muroo are fiue myles. And this Hauen is about fiue myles more from the Hauen afore≈øaid. Beyond the afore≈øaid point thr√©e or foure myles Ea≈øtward, lyeth the Hauen of Fyongo, and from thence ≈øixe or ≈øeuen myles further is the Hauen and Bay of Sacay. All this coa≈øt afore≈øaid is faire and cleare, hauing all ouer anker ground. The≈øe are (as I ≈øaid before) all Portingale myles, and two Iapon myles make iu≈øt a Portingall myle: which is found to b√©e true by the Portingall Pilotes, that haue therein taken the height of the Sunne, and made their account after the Iapon myles.

div.head: The 32. Chapter. The Nauigation from Lampaecon (which lyeth by Macon in the coa≈øt of China) to the I≈øland of Iapon, and from thence to the I≈øland Firando, with the de≈øcription thereof by another Pilote.
div.p:
SAyling from Lampacon to the I≈øland of Iapon, you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe through the fir≈øt i≈ø≈øue or Channell of the South I≈øland, which reacheth South-ea≈øtward, hauing a Cliffe or I≈øland in the middle thereof, betw√©ene the which and the point of the I≈øland you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe of the ≈øcant winde, making as neare as po≈ø≈øiblie you can to the end of the I≈øland, alwayes with your Leade in hande. And comming to the middle way of the Channell of the I≈øland lying vnto Sea-warde, you ≈øhall finde a ≈øandie banke, that in the middle hath not thr√©e fadome deepe: You ≈øhall v≈øe all the meanes you can to pa≈ø≈øe aboue a great and
high I≈øland, which lyeth Ea≈øt Southea≈øt from you. Being about this I≈øland (with the other that lyeth to Sea-ward in the ≈øame rowe,) you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe along by the I≈øland that lyeth to Seaward. Six miles further from this I≈øland, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a row of I≈ølands, ≈ømall I≈ølands, & Cliffes, and are nine, reaching further out to ≈øeaward then all the re≈øt that you pa≈ø≈øe by, and lye North Northea≈øt, and South Southwe≈øt, you cannot pa≈ø≈øe on the out≈øide of them, neither is it nece≈ø≈øary, but you mu≈øt runne betw√©ene them and a great high I≈øland full of Tr√©es, that lyeth to landward from you, which I≈øland as you come n√©ere it, ≈øheweth as if it were round, becau≈øe you goe right vpon the point: Notwith≈øtanding it is long, reaching as the coa≈øt doth. Hauing pa≈øt ≈øomwhat beyond it, there is a channell that pa≈ø≈øeth betw√©ene it and another I≈øland, lying clo≈øe by it. Behind this la≈øt I≈øland Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, there is a Hauen where ≈øome Ships come to lade certain Chini≈øh wares, and is not farre from the mouth or entry of Canton. This I≈øland afore≈øaid, is by the Chinars called Tonquion.
