When you are by the I≈ølands and cliffes, then there are certaine ≈ømall Channels, which you ≈øhall ≈øhunne, k√©eping clo≈øe by the I≈øland of Firando, which is on your We≈øt ≈øide, and is a verie great and long I≈øland, and ≈øheweth (on that ≈øide whereunto you ≈øaile) with a great high Houell, in the middle way vpon a point ≈øticking out of the ≈øame I≈øland: when you are clo≈øe by the ≈øame I≈øland, you ≈øhall runne along by it, where you ≈øhall find an opening, ≈øtretching inwards like a riuer, you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe about a mile beyond it, where you ≈øhall haue a ≈ømall Cr√©eke or Bay called Cochyn, wherein you ≈øhall enter vntill you finde twelue fadome deepe, and there anker: and although there you lie open to the South winde, yet the water goeth whole: beeing there, you ≈øhall ≈øend either by water or by lande to the towne where the Hauen is, for certaine Foi≈øts or Barkes that may bring you into the Hauen, which Hauen lyeth ≈øomewhat further, for the entrie thereof is ≈øomething dangerous, becau≈øe of the great ≈øtreames that haue their Current therein.

If you de≈øire to ≈øaile into this Hauen when it is almo≈øt high water, haue care, for the wind is ≈øtrong at your entring, and when the water beginneth to ebbe, then it helpeth to bring you in: then you ≈øhall runne in ≈øuch maner along by the I≈øland as I ≈øaid before: and being pa≈øt the cr√©eke of Cochyn, to the fir≈øt point of lande that you ≈øhall come vnto, that ≈øticketh out from the ≈øame I≈øland (from the which point Northward there iutteth two ≈øtonie Cliffes) you ≈øhall goe neare the ≈øtonie Cliffes, the better to get into the Hauen, and you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e before you on the ≈øide of Firando, a great and high I≈øland, full of tr√©es, & when you ≈ø√©e it, take your cour≈øe right vpon the We≈øt point of the ≈øame I≈øland, vntill the ≈øaide I≈øland lyeth wholly vncouered to Leeward from you, whereby pre≈øently you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e inwarde the point or end of the towne: and when you beginne to ≈øee the hou≈øes, then put ≈øomewhat neerer to it, right ouer again≈øt the afore≈øaid I≈øland on the South ≈øide and the left hande, and there the I≈øland hath a ≈ømall lo ‚Ä¢ poin ‚Ä¢ of lande comming from a high h ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and ≈øtretcheth into the Sea, from the which point there runneth a Sand or Banke, therefore you ≈øhall put towardes the ≈øide of the hou≈øes or end of the towne to k ‚Ä¢ pe out of the ≈øtreame, and when you are out being in calme water, if the winde be not good, then anker, and from thence be rowed in, either with Foi≈øts, Barks, or your own boat, We≈øt & We≈øt Southwe≈øt into the Hauen.

All this de≈øcription and cour≈øe of Nauigation, is in breefe to conclude, that when you come to the coa≈øt of Iapon, you ≈øhall leaue all the I≈ølandes that lie along vpon the coa≈øt, on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, and vpon the right hand, and runne without them and the I≈ølandes lying to Seaward from thence: whereof the fir≈øt beginneth from the end of the I≈øland of the row, called Saquyn, and the long I≈øland Caroxyma, that lyeth further forwarde, which reach North, and North and by We≈øt, from the ende of the rowe, and the two ≈ømall I≈ølandes with two other ≈ømall I≈ølandes or Cliffes lying further forward, and are ≈øeuen in all, leauing them all on the left hand or the We≈øt ≈øide‚ñ™ with the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall goe directly vpon the I≈øland of Firando, as is before mentioned.

div.head: The 33. Chapter. A voiage made by a Portingale Pilot, (with a Soma, that is, a Chini≈øh ≈øhippe) from Macau, or out of China, to the I≈øland of Iapon and the countrey of Bungo, with the ≈øcituations of the places along the cour≈øe.
div.p:
THe ninet√©enth of Iune b√©eing Saterday, we departed from the I≈øland called A Ilha das Outeas, (lying on the We≈øt ≈øide of the i≈ø≈øue or chanel of Macau) running outward to ≈øea,
putting out at the place where the ≈øhips of Malacca doe v≈øually enter, but becau≈øe we could not get aboue the I≈øland, called A Ilha grande dos Ladronis, that is, the great I≈øland of th√©eues, lying four miles Ea≈øt Southea≈øt to Seaward from the I≈ølande and the Hauen of Macau, therefore w√©e ranne to Leeward thereof. About the length of the ≈øhot of a ba≈øe from it, there are two I≈ølands lying ≈øomewhat di≈øtant from each other, with a very ≈ømall channell running betweene them, thorough the which they pa≈ø≈øed with Banko ‚Ä¢
or Chini≈øh Barkes. From thence about halfe a mile Northward, lieth another long I≈øland full of trees and bu≈øhes, and when you put in there, on the We≈øt Southwe≈øt ≈øide in the middle of the channell, there lieth a ≈øtone which is couered with the Sea.

Sixe miles Ea≈øt Southea≈øtward from the≈øe I≈ølandes, lyeth the I≈øland of Tonquian, which is a high and long I≈øland, full of trees and bu≈øhes, and clo≈øe by it on the ≈øea ≈øide it hath nine or ten I≈ølandes or Cliffes: and becau≈øe wee could not take the height to pa≈ø≈øe betweene the I≈ølandes and the Cliffes, (which is a faire & good channell) w√©e pa≈ø≈øed to Leeward, between it and another I≈øland, about a ≈ømall mile Northward from thence, which is a great Iland, and there lie two Ilands or cliffes, the greater hard by it, and the other further off, which we left on the left hande, running along by the I≈øland of Tonquian, where it is all fair ground. Which I≈øland on the point that lyeth Ea≈øt Northea≈øt on the land ≈øide hath a ≈øandie Bay, which is a very good Rode for the Mon≈øon of the South windes.

When wee were out beyond that I≈øland, then wee helde our cour≈øe Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, vntill wee were as farre to Seaward as the furthe≈øt I≈øland, and being in ≈øight thereof, wee tooke our cour≈øe Ea≈øt and ea≈øt and by North for three≈øcore miles, till wee were vnder the height of the I≈øland Lamon, which cour≈øe we helde thereby to ≈øhunne Rouers and Theeues, who at that time and in tho≈øe countries were continually ri≈øident, making warre again≈øt the Portingales of Macau) and yet wee had the firme Land ≈øtill in ≈øight, I meane, the toppes of the Trees and Bu≈øhes that ≈øtoode vpon the lowe flatte Lande: and comming to the coa≈øt of Lamon (although wee ≈øawe it not) wee pre≈øently ranne Northea≈øt, by the which cour≈øe wee had the ≈øight of the high lande of Chabaquon lying on the coa≈øt of China, and beeing there wee found much badde water and hard ≈øtreames: and at the la≈øt wee e≈øpied the Varella or ≈øtonie Rocke, that ≈øtandeth aboue the Hauen of China, ≈øeeing nothing el≈øe but high hilles: and from thence forwarde wee ≈øawe no more of the coa≈øt of China, and running in that cour≈øe of Northea≈øt (which from Lamon wee alwaies held) w√©e perceiued the I≈øland of Lequeo Pequeno, or, Small Lequeo, which was at the fourth mealetide after our departure from Macau, for w√©e e≈øpied it on Wedne≈øday in the morning, and ankered eight miles from it towards the coa≈øt of China, beeing on the Southwe≈øt point thereof.

This I≈øland Lequeo Pequeno ≈øtretcheth Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt and Northea≈øt and by North, and Southwe≈øt and by South, it is a very high I≈øland and about fifteene or ≈øixteene miles long: the furthe≈øt point or end Northea≈øtward of the ≈øame I≈øland lyeth full vnder 29. degrees ¬Ω. for there I tooke the height of the Sunne, with calme weather, being about fiue or ≈øixe myles from it, and from this Northea≈øt point the coa≈øt of the I≈øland runneth Southea≈øt, at the end thereo ‚Ä¢ hauing another great and high I≈øland, making a ≈ømall Channell that runneth betweene them both: and it ≈øeemeth that on the Nor ‚Ä¢ hea≈øt ≈øide there is a good Rode for the Mon≈øon of South and Southwe≈øt windes: and along by this coa≈øt of Lequeo for the ≈øpace of three daies we had calme weather, and after that wee had a good gale of winde of the Mon≈øon, and I thinke wee had ≈øo great a calme becau≈øe wee kept ≈øo clo≈øe vnto the ≈øhoare.
About fiue and twentie degr√©es and ‚Ä¢ from the point of Lequeo wee helde our cour≈øe Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, till wee came vnder nine and twentie degrees.

Ten miles from Lequeo forwarde w√©e ≈øawe great ≈øtore of Cuttle bones driuing on the water, and many other ≈øhelles that were verie white, ≈øhewing farre off much like vnto Cotton, but it was not long that they draue any thing thicke, for in ≈øhort ≈øpace after wee might perceiue them ≈øcattered abroad verie thinne, and but verie few,
vntill w√©e came vnder 26. degr√©es.

Comming vnder 29. degr√©es, w√©e held our cour≈øe halfe a ≈øtrike Ea≈øt Northea≈øt for the ≈øpace of eight or nine miles till the Sunne-≈øetting, and then w√©e perceiued right before vs a round and high I≈øland, being about ≈øixe miles from it, which was the fir≈øt and furthe≈øt I≈øland We≈øtward of the ≈øeuen I≈ølandes, which at this pre≈øent are called As Sete Irmaas, that is, the ≈øeuen ≈øi≈øters, which lie vnder 29. degr√©es and ¬Ω.

This fir≈øt I≈øland hath a ≈øharpe point on the We≈øt ≈øide, in the middle at the foot thereof hauing a ≈øtone in forme of a Pillar, like the Varella in the ≈øtraight of Singapura by Malacca: and on the Northea≈øt ≈øide about halfe a mile from thence, there lieth a round blacke Cliffe.

B√©eing in the ≈øight of this I≈øland w√©e pre≈øently ranne North and by Ea≈øt, as before, all that night: and in the morning (b√©eing right again≈øt it) wee ≈øawe all the re≈øt of the ≈øeuen I≈ølands, and ≈øtill held our cour≈øe Northea≈øt, vntill we were before the la≈øt of the ≈øaid ≈øeuen I≈ølands: From whence about ≈øixe miles Northward, lyeth two I≈ølands ≈øtretching Ea≈øt & We≈øt, whereof that in the Ea≈øt is verie long and high, full of blacke ≈øhining tr√©es, and that in the We≈øt much le≈ø≈øe and lower: at the Ea≈øt end or point of the le≈ø≈øer Iland there is a high houell that de≈øcendeth We≈øtward, making a long and lowe point. The≈øe i≈ølands are about a mile di≈øtant from each other.

We≈øtward from this I≈øland about two miles and a halfe, there is another i≈øland, as great and high as the other afore≈øaid: the fir≈øt great high I≈øland afore≈øaid is called Icoo, and the afore≈øaid ≈øeuen I≈ølands ≈øhall all lie on the Southea≈øt ≈øide from you, and from the fir≈øt to the la≈øt they may be about ≈øeuen or eight miles: when wee were at the end of the ≈øeuen I≈ølands, we held our cour≈øe Northea≈øt, towardes the channell that runneth betw√©ene the great high I≈øland, and the Iland that hath the long low point, where we pa≈ø≈øed through, comming out againe on the North ≈øide. This channell is faire and deepe without any cliffes or ≈øtones.

Foure miles Northwe≈øtward from this Channell, lyeth a verie high and round I≈øland, which on the We≈øt ≈øide ≈øeemeth to be full of Cliffes. This Iland hath a Mine of Brim≈øtone which lyeth in the middle thereof. A mile Northward from this fiery I≈øland lyeth another ≈ømall and lowe I≈øland, and from the afore≈øaide fiery I≈ølande about eight miles Ea≈øtward, lyeth the I≈øland of Tanaxuma afore≈øaid: the great high I≈øland of Icoo afore≈øaide lying on the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Channell, on the North ≈øide thereof hath a lowe Lande, and all along by it is verie good harbour, b√©eing faire and good ground, reaching foure or fiue miles Ea≈øt and We≈øt.

Thr√©e miles Northward from the Ea≈øt end of this I≈øland of Icoo, lyeth the afore≈øaide I≈øland of Tanaxuma, as it is al≈øo declared in the De≈øcription of the Cour≈øe and Nauigation to the I≈øland of Ferando.

This I≈øland of Tanaxuma ≈øtretcheth North and South, b√©eing altogither low Land and full of Houels and Valleyes, with Pine tr√©es that ≈øtand farre di≈øtant one from the other, and is about ≈øeuen or eight miles long: and in the middle thereof on the We≈øt ≈øide, lyeth a Hauen within certaine Cliffes and Rockes, and a mile and a halfe We≈øt Northwe≈øtward from this Hauen lyeth a very ≈ømall and lowe I≈øland, with a little Houell in the middle. On the North end of this ≈ømal Iland there are ≈øome ≈øtones & rocks ≈øticking out about the length of the ≈øhotte of a great p√©ece, all the re≈øt is faire. Likewi≈øe betw√©ene this I≈øland and Tanaxuma it is all ouer faire and cleere. Seuen or eight miles Northward from the I≈øland of Tanaxuma, lyeth the great and high Land of Iapon, which coa≈øt on the South ≈øide ≈øtretcheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt for the ≈øpace of ten myles from the channell afore≈øaid that runneth betweene the I≈ølandes: you can not ≈øee Tanaxuma vnle≈ø≈øe it b√©e faire and cleere weather: wee ranne Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, and were about three miles di≈øtant from the afore≈øaide Channell before wee di≈øcouered Tanaxuma, as likewi≈øe the great land of Iapon, which (as I ≈øaide before) is verie high, ≈øtretching Ea≈øt and We≈øt about tenne miles, and becau≈øe Tanaxuma ≈øtretcheth North and South, being lowe land, and the land of Iapon high, therefore in that place where w√©e were, they ≈øeemed vnto vs like one Lande, becau≈øe they reach each through other. Wherevpon the Chini≈øh Pilote which wee had at that time aboord our ≈øhippe, thought
then to be all one land, but when we put nearer to it, then w√©e began to ≈ø√©e the Channell that runneth betw√©ene them, beeing di≈øtant one from the other cro≈ø≈øe ouer, about ≈øeuen or eight miles: and in that manner w√©e ranne halfe a ≈øtrike Ea≈øt Northea≈øt towardes the land of Iapon, it being flood, where the tide ranne Ea≈øtward towards the ≈ømall I≈øland that lyeth by Tanaxuma driuing vs thither, whereby we had much labour and paine to get aboue it, pa≈ø≈øing about the length of the ≈øhot of a great p√©ece from it: wherefore it is nece≈ø≈øarie for a man to runne No ‚Ä¢ thea≈øt vntill h√©e be pa≈øt that ≈ømall Iland afore≈øaid.

When we had pa≈ø≈øed about the I≈øland of Tanaxuma, w√©e ranne North Northea≈øt towards the coa≈øt, being three myles di≈øtant from it: and right again≈øt the creeke of Xebuxij we had a calme, beeing the la≈øt of Iune, hauing departed from the I≈øland called A Ilha das Outeas, lying on the We≈øt ≈øide of the mouth or channell of Macau, the nint√©enth of the ≈øame moneth, hauing Sailed toward Iapon about eleuen dayes, whereof we had thr√©e daies calme, ≈øo that our Sailes lay flat to the Ma≈øtes, being vnder the I≈øland of Lequeo as afore≈øaid.

div.head: The 34. Chapter. Another de≈øcription of the cour≈øe from the Hauen of Macau along by the I≈øland of China to the I≈øland of Fyrando, and the I≈ølands lying about it, to the Hauen of Vmbra in the coa≈øt of Iapon: with a de≈øcription of other Hauens lying thereabout, where they ordinarily v≈øe to trafficke.
div.p: IF you de≈øire to Saile out of Macau towardes Iapon, in the Mon≈øons of Iune and Iulie, and if in ≈øetting out you can not k√©ep to loofeward from a cliffe which you may ea≈øily perceiue lying by Macau, which ≈øheweth like a ≈øaile, you neede not feare it, for that leauing the I≈øland Lanton on the L√©e ≈øide, you may runne whither you will, for it is all faire, and you need not feare any thing: when yea are without the I≈øland, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe towardes the I≈øland Branco that is, the white I≈øland, or the white Stonie Cliffes) running Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, towardes the I≈øland of Lamon, and if you haue a faire winde, and that you depart about Euening from the ≈øaid I≈øland, then on the Firme land you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a great high Land, on the Ea≈øt ≈øide de≈øcending ≈øomewhat flat, and in the midde≈øt thereof hauing a round houell like a loofe of bread. The depthes all along by that coa≈øt about two miles from it, is thirtie and fiue and thirtie fadome deepe, being muddie ground: From Ilha Branco to Lamon there are diuers ≈ømall I≈ølandes lying by the coa≈øt of the Firme Land. In this place for twelue miles or thereabouts on this ≈øide Lamon, and ≈øeuen or eight miles from the Firme land, there is ≈ømall black ≈øand with ≈øome ≈øhels, at ≈øeuen and twentie and eight and twentie fadomes water, and being there you ≈øhall ≈øtil runne Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, although you ≈øee no land, for that hauing the afore≈øaid depth and ground, you pa≈ø≈øe fr√©ely and ≈øafely from the Riffe of the i≈øland Lamon, and if it ≈øo fall out that you ≈øee no land, yet by the depthes and ground you may well know where you are, for from the i≈øland Lamon to Macau the depthes of the afore≈øaid ground is from 25. to 28. fadome d√©epe, and by Lamon and thereabouts the ground is white, ≈ømall, and thinne, with ≈øome blacke ≈øande, and if you chance to pa≈ø≈øe by it in clo≈øe and darke weather, then you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe as afore≈øaide Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, for it is the be≈øt way: and when you make towardes the i≈øland of Lamon and finding the depthes of fifteene or ≈øixt√©ene fadome, it is a ≈øigne that you are farre to ≈øeaward (for in that country the ≈øtreame runneth very ≈øtrong Ea≈øt Southea≈øtward) there as then you mu≈øt runne Northea≈øtward, ≈øo to holde your right cour≈øe.

And running at the depthes of fiue and twentie or eight and twentie fadome ≈øandie ground, it is a good way, holding your cour≈øe Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, for in that ≈øort you are in the right way: in the middle way from the channell when you are pa≈øt the I≈øland of Lamon towardes Chinchon then the ≈øtreame runneth with you, and hauing the wind of the Mon≈øon: the next day you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e land on both ≈øides, whereof, that you find on the Stearebord ≈øide is the end or point of the I≈øland Lequeo Pequeno, or, ≈ømall Lequeo: and the beginning of the I≈øland called Ilha Fermo≈øa, that is, the faire I≈øland, and on
the lareboord ≈øide, the Lande lyeth in forme like a hooke, although it is none, but it is the I≈øland of A Ilha dos Cauallos, of the I≈øland of Hor≈øes, which is very high lying vnder fiue and twenty degr√©es and a third part, on the one ≈øide about foure or fiue miles to Sea-ward from it, hauing the I≈øland of Baboxyn, and hauing ≈ø√©ene this Lande, you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe Northea≈øtward, which is a good way, ≈øo to runne outward of all the I≈ølands, for that from this I≈øland of Hor≈øes forward to the Cape of Sumbor, there are many I≈ølands reaching into the Sea, wherfore this is your be≈øt cour≈øe to goe to the Cabo de Sembor, and as you thinke you are right again≈øt ye Cape of Sumbor, although you ≈ø√©e it not, you need not feare it, for that as then you are about eight or ten myles from it.

Being in this country, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe Northea≈øt, ≈øo to ≈ø√©e the I≈øland of Puloma, or Meaxuma, or the I≈øland Guoto for it is a good cour≈øe, for the winds of the Mon≈øon, or if you haue any ≈øtormes or contrary winde, whereby you cannot holde your right cour≈øe, then you mu≈øt gouerne your ≈øelfe in ≈øuch manner, that you may fall againe into your right cour≈øe, and ≈øo to ≈ø√©e ≈øome of tho≈øe I≈ølands. This afore≈øaid I≈øland of Puloma lyeth North North-ea≈øt, and South Southwe≈øt, with the I≈øland Guoto, about tenne or twelue miles di≈øtant from each other, and is deuided into foure or fiue parts, with many holes & p√©eces of ground round about it, yet you need not feare, for clo≈øe by it, there are many other p√©eces of ground, which I knowe, as hauing ≈øeene them all.

From this I≈øland afore≈øaid to the Hauen of Vmbra, or the I≈øland of Firando, you mu≈øt runne your cour≈øe of Northea≈øt, wherewith you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the land lying beneath Vmbra, which is very high, hauing along ye coa≈øt many ≈ømall I≈ølands, among the which are two Cliffes, that ≈øticke out with very hard ≈øharpe Points like Diamonds. From thence to Vmbra are ≈øixe or ≈øeuen miles, and being there, about a mile from the Lande, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe North, and ≈øo runne along by the coa≈øt, and being by it, you ≈øhall k√©epe clo≈øe to it to know the Lande and markes thereof, which are the≈øe: that when you are clo≈øe by the Land on the right hand, there is a Point of Land, from whence there lyeth two I≈ølandes to Seaward, which is hard by the entry of Vmbra, for from this Point inward, you runne Northea≈øt towards it. Vpon this Hooke or point are three Pine Trees: and being right again≈øt this point to Sea-ward from it on the left hand you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a ≈ømal I≈øland with a round cliffe, you mu≈øt runne within this Cliffe, whereby right before, you ≈øhall ≈øee the land of Vmbra.

When you perceiue a great I≈øland or Cliffe, which is very plaine and de≈øcending downeward, lying inward to Sea, then on the Lande ≈øide you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e great ≈øtore of w√©edes driuing vpon the Water. This I≈øland you mu≈øt leaue on the Lareboord or left hand, running betweene it and the Land, for it is about halfe a myle broad: From this I≈øland to the mouth or entry of the channell are two miles, with a Northea≈øt cour≈øe, whereby you ≈øhall pre≈øentlye ≈ø√©e the entry which is very broad.

From this I≈øland or Cliffe there runneth a ≈øtony rocke, reaching to the mouth of the Riuer, ≈øome part of it lying aboue water, and part couered, yet you may plainely ≈ø√©e it, ≈øo that you n√©ed not feare any thing, but that you ≈ø√©e before your eies. Betweene this Rocke and the Lande on the right hand, in the middle way there is fift√©ene or 18 fadome d√©ep muddy ground, when you ≈øee the mouth of the Channell, you mu≈øt put right towards it, without feare, for it is a very good way: And being within this ≈øtraight or channell, whereby you di≈øcouer the Riuer, then you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe on the right hand, whereby you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e a round I≈øland, hauing a Cro≈ø≈øe on the toppe thereof: and although you ≈ø√©e not the entry, yet you mu≈øt put towards that I≈øland: for when you are right again≈øt it, then you ≈øhall preently ≈øee the Road wherein the ≈øhippes doe lye, as al≈øo a Portingale Church ≈øtanding vpon the Lande, and b√©eing within- you mu≈øt runne South-warde, about the length of the ≈øhot of a great P√©ece, where you may anker at tenne fadome d√©epe, being very good muddye ground, and there you ≈øhall make your Shippe fa≈øt on the North Northea≈øt, and South South-we≈øt ≈øides, and euen as the Winde dooth blowe, you ≈øhall winde the B√©eke heade of
the ≈øhippe, making the ankers fa≈øt vnder the ≈øtones, for there it is very narrowe: Notwith≈øtanding, you n√©ed not feare, although the wind be great.

Take h√©ed when you come from Cabo de Sumbor from ye coa≈øt of China towards the land of Iapon, although you ≈øee not the I≈ølands afore≈øaid, leaue not your cour≈øe of Northea≈øt vntill you be vpon the coa≈øt of Iapon, for although you fall by the Hauen of Arima, which is twelue miles from Vmbra, you n√©ede not care, for in tho≈øe places you haue very good Hauens. By the Hauen of Arima afore≈øaid, there lyeth an I≈øland (≈øomewhat n√©erer the North then the South) called Cabexuma, which on the in≈øide hath a very good Hauen, where you may lye and Trafficke freely. And if from thence you de≈øire to runne further inward, then holde your cour≈øe North Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by North, wherewith you ≈øhall come to a Hauen called Cochinochy, lying in the Kingdome of Arima, and departing from Cabexuma, you ≈øhall runne along by the Northpart of the land, about ≈øeuen or eight myles, whereby you ≈øhall come right again≈øt Cochinochy, which is a better hauen then Vmbra, becau≈øe therein the Shippes may anker at plea≈øure, and before you come n√©ere this Hauen, many Shippes and Barkes will come aboord you ≈øhippe, which wil fr√©ely bring you in, and you n√©ed not feare the creeke of Arima, for the old Pilotes were in doubt thereof, becau≈øe they knew it not ≈øo well as I, for that I haue ≈øayled all within and about it with a Foi≈øt, with trouble ynough. Right again≈øt Cochinochy, lyeth another very good Hauen, called Oxy, belonging to the King of Bungo, where you may freely trafficke.

You need not feare the entry of Arima for that be≈øides the hauens afor≈øaid wherin you may lye ≈øafely, there will many Foy≈øtes and Barkes come and boord you Shippe, that will bring you whether you will, and helpe you to your de≈øire.

You mu≈øt likewi≈øe vnder≈øtand, that along by the coa≈øt of China you need not feare any thing, for it is all faire and good ground, keeping without all the I≈ølands, for if you goe betw√©ene them, you ≈øhould hardly get out againe to your de≈øire: therefore it is be≈øt for you to keepe without them, running along by them, and ≈øo there is no feare: for it is all faire way, as well to the I≈øland Firando as to the Hauen of Vmbra, onely that Firando lyeth ≈øeuen or eight myles North-ward from the Hooke or Point of Tr√©es, and being there, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e Firando, and in putting forward to it, you find a Varella, that is a marke of a ≈øharpe ≈øtony hill: & then you ≈øhall gouern your ≈øelfe as afore≈øaid, for then you may pre≈øently perceaue it, being a very high land, which ≈øtretcheth Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, & We≈øt Southwe≈øt, in the middle way hauing many ≈ømall I≈ølands, with channels betw√©ene them, thereby to runne from the one ≈øide to the other: but if you wil go from the I≈øland of Cabexuma to Vmbra, you mu≈øt alwaies k√©epe clo≈øe to the land, for in the I≈øland of Diamonds, or pointed I≈øland, there is another very good hauen, where (as ≈øoone as you are in ≈øight thereof) many Barkes and Foi≈øts will boord you, and ≈øo bring in your Shippe. The Hauens in tho≈øe countries, are the≈øe that follow as well in the Land of Iapon, as the I≈ølandes lying about it: whereof in this de≈øcription I haue alreadie made mention. Fir≈øt in the I≈øland of Cabexuma, there is a very good Hauen, al≈øo Cochinochy lying in the Kingdome of Arima is a better Hauen. The Hauen of Oxy right again≈øt Cochinochy, is al≈øo a better Hauen. In the I≈øland called O Ilha do Diamon, that is, the I≈øland of the Diamond, becau≈øe of the ≈øharpe pointed Rocke, there is likewi≈øe a very good Hauen, which is part of the Lande of Vmbra, al≈øo the Hauen of Vmbra is a good Hauen.

div.head: The 35. Chapter. A ≈øhort de≈øcription of the cour≈øe from Macau in China to Iapon, and the I≈øland Cabexuma to the Hauen of Langa≈øaque or Nanga≈øache, which at this day is mo≈øt frequented of the Portingales: with all the cour≈øes and ≈øcituations, by an expert Pilote, with a declaration of the winds called Tuffon.
div.p:
AS ≈øoone as you are pa≈øt ye I≈øland of Ilha do Leme, which lyeth as you come out from Macau, then hold your cour≈øe Ea≈øt northea≈øt, wherby you ≈øhal pa≈ø≈øe about the I≈øland of Lamon, and if it be in the night time, you
≈øhall ca≈øt out your Lead, and find two and twenty and thr√©e and twenty fadome d√©ep with ≈øhels and blacke ≈øand on the ground, and then you are right again≈øt the Riffe, and when you are pa≈øt it, you ≈øhall finde white and ≈ømall ≈øand. Then holding your cour≈øe Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, alwaies k√©eping from the coa≈øt of Chinchon as much as you may, for the be≈øt way is to runne in the middle of the channell, as far from the I≈øland of fi≈øhers as from the coa≈øt of Chincheo. And if you goe n√©erer the I≈øland of Fi≈øhers called A Ilha dos pe≈øcadores, you ≈øhall finde le≈ø≈øe depth, and therefore you mu≈øt look to your cour≈øe, and when you are pa≈øt the I≈øland Lamao, ca≈øt out your Lead, becau≈øe of the I≈øland of fi≈øhers. And if in tho≈øe countries you haue a ≈øtorme with the winds called Tuffon, and come from the Northea≈øt parts, then hold your cour≈øe to Seaward as much as you may to ≈øhunne the coa≈øt, for the wind without doubt will be ≈øouthea≈øt, which is right vpon the coa≈øt, whereby it lyeth right again≈øt you: and if it driueth you not vpon the coa≈øt, then it were be≈øt for you to ≈øtrike all your ≈øayles, and take them in, and ≈øo lye driuing, vntil the wind come South, and then to follow on your cour≈øe againe. I giue you this coun≈øell, becau≈øe that for the ≈øpace of two yeares one after the other, I haue b√©en in tho≈øe countries with ≈øtorms of the winds called Tuffon, ≈øo that one voiage we were almo≈øt ca≈øt away, by ≈ø√©eking to put vnto the coa≈øt. Nowe to vnder≈øtand the meaning of this word Tuffon, it is a Chini≈øh word, which the Portingales al≈øo doe holde without altering the ≈øame, and ≈øignifieth a ≈øtorme or Tempe≈øt, which you commonly finde in tho≈øe voyages from China to Iapon. If you faile of it at ≈øometime, it is not often, it commeth and beginneth from one point, and ≈øo runneth with a continuall ≈øtorme almo≈øt about all the points in compa≈ø≈øe, blowing mo≈øt ≈øtiffely, whereby the poore Sailers haue worke ynough in hande, and in ≈øuch ≈øort, that not any ≈øtormes throughout all the orientall Indies is comparable vnto it, wherefore it is nece≈ø≈øary to looke well to it, and to chu≈øe your times, that by calmes ≈øodainely you bee not vnadui≈øedly ouertaken, as euery man that hath ≈øayled tho≈øe wayes, can ≈øufficiently ≈øhowe you, and euery one or mo≈øt part of them haue found it to be ≈øo.

When you are right again≈øt the I≈øland A Ilha Fermo≈øa, then runne Northea≈øt, by the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall goe right vpon the ≈øtraight of Arima, which is a good way: and as ≈øoone as you finde ground on the loofe ≈øide, and haue ≈øeuentie fiue fadome water, then you ≈øhall goe right vpon the middle of the I≈øland of Meaxuma, and hauing le≈ø≈øe depth, then your cour≈øe is not good, but of force you mu≈øt ≈ø√©eke another cour≈øe to ≈øayle the better, but being too loofeward, it is good, e≈øpecially when you ≈øee the I≈øland Sancta Clare, which is a ≈ømal I≈øland: on the Northea≈øt ≈øide thereof hauing two or thr√©e Cliffes: and ≈øomewhat farther forward, the I≈øland Co ‚Ä¢ aquyn which is very great, being deuided into thr√©e parts. I haue pa≈ø≈øed by the land ≈øide thereof, which is a very good way, and there you n√©ede not feare any thing, but onely certaine ≈øtones that lye along by the I≈øland, which you may ea≈øily perceiue, for the Sea breaketh vpon them. You mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe along by it, leauing the ≈øtones on the larboor ‚Ä¢ ≈øide, about the length of the ≈øhot of a Ba≈øe from you: and when you are pa≈øt them, then k√©epe aloofe as much as you may inward to Sea, thereby to ≈øhunne thr√©e I≈ølandes or Cliffes which lye on the other ≈øide right ouer again≈øt the thicke and great Lande, for betw√©ene them and it, it is all full of Riffes. And therefore your be≈øt cour≈øe is to runne to Seaward from the I≈øland of Coiaquyn, in the middle way from the afore≈øaid great thicke Lande (that lyeth before the I≈ølandes or Cliffes of the Riffes) lyeth the Hauen of Amacu≈øa, which is very great, where the Cr√©eke of Arima beginneth. From thence North North we≈øtward from you, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e the I≈øland of Cabexuma.

When you are right again≈øt Cabexuma, ≈øomewhat beyond it, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e ≈øixe I≈ølands or Cliffes which you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe on the Sea ≈øide, and then Ea≈øt-warde, and Ea≈øt and by North you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the I≈øland called Ilha dos Cauallos, or of Hor≈øes, which on the Sea ≈øide hath a great houell, and on the other ≈øide towardes the I≈øland of Firando two Cliffes lying along by the coa≈øt, which ≈øhew like two Ships vnder ≈øayle. Al≈øo further forward towards Firando, there is two flat I≈ølands lying along the coa≈øt, called the I≈ølands of Re≈øting as, that is, the I≈ølands of Riffes.

If when you come out of the Sea, you haue cau≈øe to anker‚ñ™ before you put into the Hauen, being by the I≈ølands or Cliffes, then put out newe Cables, making them fa≈øt, that you loo≈øe not your ankers, for there it is very d√©epe and ≈øharpe.

Being right again≈øt the afore≈øaid ≈øix or ≈øeuen I≈ølands or Cliffes, then runne right vpon the I≈øland Dos Cauallos, and when you are by it, that is, inward of the point. You ≈øhall along by the I≈øland ≈ø√©e a Sand aboue the water, all the other I≈ølandes and Cliffes that you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e ≈øhall lye on the lareboord ≈øide, which is vpon the ≈øide of the I≈øland Facunda, and ≈øo you ≈øhall runne till you enter into the Hauen of Langa≈øaque, hauing nothing to feare, then that you ≈ø√©e before your eyes: for there you haue both Sea and ground, as it is vpon the coa≈øt of Spaine.

div.head: The 36. Chapter. A voyage made from Macau in China to the hauen of Langa≈øaque or Nanga≈øache in the I≈øland of Iapon in the ≈øhippe called the S. crus, the captaine being a Portingall called Franci≈øco Pais, and the Gunner Dericke Gerit≈øon of Enchui≈øen in the yeare of our Lord 1585 written by the Pilote of the ≈øame ≈øhippe.
div.p: 1585. THe fift of Iuly Anno 1585 vpon a Friday in the morning w√©e ≈øet ≈øayle from the point that lyeth right again≈øt the Cloi≈øter of S. Frauncis, minding to runne to Loofeward from a round I≈øland or Cliffe, lying Ea≈øt Southea≈øt from thence: but becau≈øe the wind was ≈øo ≈øcant, wee could not doe it, ≈øo that we were forced to driue, ≈øo to get through the Channell of Lanton as wee did. The depth that wee found therein was from fiue to ≈øixe fadome water, and that was clo≈øe by the round I≈øland that lyeth to Seaward from the I≈øland of Lanton, and from thence forward it beginneth to bee d√©eper, being eight√©ene & twenty fadome, and that depth wee found till wee were without the I≈øland called A Ilha de Leme, that is the I≈øland of the Harquebu≈øh.

This I≈øland of Lanton, as you make towards it, hath a point, where the wind fell very ≈øcarce, in ≈øuch manner, that wee could hardly k√©epe of an I≈øland, lying on the left hand of the chanell if the ≈øtreame had not beene ≈øo ≈øtrong, that it draue the ≈øhippe ouerthwart to Loofeward, otherwi≈øe we had indured great labor and trouble to pa≈ø≈øe through the channell, becau≈øe that towards night we were about foure miles from the I≈øland Ilha do Leme, the cour≈øe wee held that night was Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt and by South, becau≈øe wee had a ≈øharpe wind, hauing twenty and ≈øixe and twenty fadome d√©ep muddy ground, about ≈øunne ri≈øing w√©e ≈øawe right before vs the I≈øland of Branco, or the white cliffe: and becau≈øe of the depths afore≈øaid w√©e ge≈ø≈øed that we were about half a mile beyond it.

The ≈øixt of Iuly being Saterday, we could not take the height of the ≈øunne, becau≈øe it was right ouer our heads, hauing a Southea≈øt and South Southea≈øt wind, with very hote weather by day, but by night it was ≈øomewat colder, we held our cour≈øe Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, Ea≈øt, and ea≈øt and by North, as the winde blewe, and about noone we found fiue and twenty and ≈øeuen & twenty fadome water with ≈ømall black ≈øandy ground, being in ≈øight of lande, and at Sunne ri≈øing we ≈øawe the Land of Lamon, which is a long flat land like a Table or plaine field: on the Ea≈øt Northea≈øt ≈øide hauing a thin point of Land reaching inward to the Sea, and on the We≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt ≈øide there runneth out another thinne point of ≈øand into the ≈øea, and hard by again≈øt the thicke≈øt part thereof, you ≈ø√©e the forme of a white place which is the I≈øland of Lamon, to Seaward whereof lyeth thr√©e Cliffes. Lying at the end of the Riffe of the I≈øland of Lamon, there w√©e call forth our Leade, and found 27 fadome water, with ≈ømall, white and ≈øome blacke ≈øand with ≈ømall ≈øhels among it, being about ≈øeuen or eight miles from the land.

The ≈øeuenth of Iuly being ≈øunday, we had a calme, and ≈øomtimes (but not much) Southea≈øt and South Southea≈øt winds, holding our cour≈øe Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by North, at 24 and 26 fadome water: and as ≈øoone as we had pa≈øt the I≈øland of Lamon, we pre≈øently had ≈ømall thinne white ≈øand vpon the ground with ≈øome ≈øhels, being in the morning about ≈øeuen miles from the land of Chincheo, and ≈øaw the I≈øland that is like the I≈øland called Ilha dos Lymoins, that is, the I≈øland of Lemmons, lying by Mallaca, and ≈øomewhat further wee ≈øaw a thinne Lande, with a ≈øharpe point
≈øtanding vpon it, which is ≈øaid to b√©e a Varella do Chinchon, that is, the marke or Rocke of Chinchon being vpon the eight day, which was munday, the next night following wee had a calme, wherewith the wind came North, being ≈øomewhat cold, with ≈øome ≈øhoures of rayne: but with a South-ea≈øt winde we had no raine, yet in the night time we had two claps of thunder out of the South-ea≈øt, with lightning out of the Southea≈øt and North parts.

The ninth being Tue≈øday, wee had the height of the ≈øunne at 23 degr√©es and ¬Ω. in the night hauing had the winde Ea≈øt Southea≈øt with a good gale, and all night w√©e lay driuing without ≈øailes, with an Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt Southea≈øt windes, and a good gale, ca≈øting out our Lead, and found twenty and foure & twenty fadome d√©ep, once hauing eight√©ene fadome, where wee found ≈ømall white Sand with ≈øome ≈øhels. In the morning very earely we had a north wind, wherwith we wound ea≈øtward, hauing nothing but the Fouke≈øaile and the Mi≈øen vp, vntill euening, and at the depths afore≈øaid w√©e tooke in our ≈øailes, minding to driue: the next day we ≈øaw land, which wee had ≈ø√©ene the day before, and it lay Northward from vs, and halfe a point North and by We≈øt.

The eleuenth being Thur≈øday w√©e tooke not the height of the Sun, becau≈øe w√©e lay driuing without ≈øayles, with an Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt Southea≈øt windes, the waues comming Southea≈øt, our Shippe winding Northea≈øt: this was by night, but by day w√©e had a Northea≈øt, and north Northea≈øt wind, in ≈øuch maner, that ≈øomtime we kept on the one ≈øide, and ≈øometimes on the other, as wind and weather ≈øerued, at twenty and foure and twenty fadome deepe, ≈ømall white ≈øand, and ≈øometimes eight√©ene fadome: the night before we had much lightening out of the We≈øt and South parts, being the thirt√©ene day of the new moone, and the day before w√©e had the heigth of the Sunne at 23 degr√©es and ¬Ω. The land we ≈øaw we could hardly di≈øcerne, but we ≈øuppo≈øed it to b√©e the land we had ≈ø√©ene the other day.

The twelfth day being Friday, wee tooke not the height of the Sunne becau≈øe w√©e lay driuing without ≈øayles, with an Ea≈øt South-ea≈øt wind in the night time, and in the day w√©e had it North-ea≈øt, at twentie and foure and twentie fadome d√©epe, and ≈øometimes eight√©ene fadome, with ≈ømall thinne white ≈øand, the ground at foure and twenty fadome, being ≈øomewhat greater ≈øand, with ≈øome ≈øhe is: when it began to be day, we were as we thought about fiue or ≈øixe myles from the land, and the night before w√©e had much lightening round about vs, and in the morning ≈øome ≈øhoures of raine without wind, the ≈økye being thicke and clo≈øe, whereby it ≈øeemed the weather would chaunge. About euening we had a Southea≈øt wind, pre≈øentlie changing South South-ea≈øt, wherevpon we let fall our ≈øailes, holding our cour≈øe North-ea≈øt, and North ea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, and al≈øo Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, but mo≈øt part Northea≈øt, ≈øo that the depths began to b√©e greater, and were fiue and thirty fadome, with ≈ømall white ≈øand, the Moone as then being at the full, and the waues alwayes running out of the South-ea≈øt, and with that winde w√©e ≈øayled for the ≈øpace of fiue daies together.

The thirteenth being Saterday, w√©e tooke the height of the Sunne at foure and twenty degr√©es, that night running Ea≈øt Northea≈øt till morning, then ≈øailing Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt, and by north, and found w ‚Ä¢ had ≈øayled twenty myles, being eight myles from the coa≈øt of China, and in the morning we ≈øaw land vpon the other ≈øide, the ground on that ≈øide was white, thinne, and ≈øome blacke ≈øand, and about ≈øunne ≈øetting we ca≈øt out out Lead, and found fiue and thirtie fadome d√©epe, with very fine black ≈øand.

The fouret√©enth being ≈øunday, we took the heigth of the ≈øun, being ≈øcar≈øe fiue and twenty degr√©es, hauing a ≈øouthwe≈øt wind with very good weather, holding our cour≈øe Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by North, all that night at ≈øeuen and thirty fadome d√©epe, with very thinne ≈øand, & ≈øome black muddy ground, and at the la≈øt watch in the morning wee found muddy ground at the ≈øame depth of
‚Ä¢ 7 fadome, mixed with blacke ≈øand, and when day began to appeare, we ≈øaw Lande, being part of the coa≈øt of
‚Ä¢ hina, being about four, fiue, or ≈øix miles from it, and we di≈øcouered the Lagarto with the two ≈øi≈øters, that is, the cockodril I≈ølands ≈øo called, and ≈øo we ca≈øt out our Lead, and found two and forty fadome d√©epe muddy ground, and ≈øomewhat ≈øandy, and ye ≈øame day al≈øo we ≈øaw the I≈øland Fermo≈øa lying by Lequeo Pequeno, or little Lequeo, and then the winde ≈ø√©emed as
though it would haue blowne fuller.

The fift√©enth day being Munday, w√©e tooke the height of the ≈øunne at 25 degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . and in the night we had the winde North, with very good weather, running about to the northwe≈øt, and we ran Ea≈øt northea≈øt, Northea≈øt & Northea≈øt to ea≈øt, & wheÃÑ it began to be day, we ≈øaw land, being the end of the I≈øland Fermo≈øa, or ye fair I≈øland, which is a long and low land, broken or rent in the middle, which ≈ø√©emeth to be a breach, but it is nothing els but as I ≈øaid before: and pre≈øently after ea≈øtward we ≈øaw another higher land, which is Iands called Ilhas dos Re ‚Ä¢ s Magos, that is, the I≈øland of the thr√©e Kings: we pa≈ø≈øed along by about 7. or 8. miles from them, and that night we had 34 fadome d√©epe, and de≈øiring to know what depth wee found, being in ≈øight of the land afore≈øaid, wee found aboue 40 fadome, the afore≈øaid land lying ea≈øt Southea≈øt from vs, being muddy ground‚ñ™ that day we had a ≈øharpe wind of the Mon≈øon, but it helde no longer then til euening, and then it was calm againe, and ≈øo held till morning, and then we had it Northwe≈øt, ≈øo running about from the We≈øt till it came Southwe≈øt, and continued till night, and then it was calme, being Tue≈øday.

The ≈øixt√©enth being in ≈øight of the I≈ølands afore≈øaid, the ≈øame day wee had the heigth of the Sunne at 26 degr√©es, le≈ø≈øe ¬Ω. degree, and the end of the great I≈øland lay ea≈øt and ea≈øt and by ≈øouth from vs, and the little I≈øland ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt. Wedne≈øday being the ≈øeuent√©enth, we had a North Northea≈øt wind, and then it came North-ea≈øt, and began to blowe ≈øo ≈øtiffe, that we were forced to ≈øtrike all our ≈øailes, letting the ≈øhippe driue all that day Southea≈øtward, and by night wee willed the man at the helme to ≈øteere northwe≈øt, and about morning the winde began to blowe ≈øo ≈øtiffe with ≈øo great waues, that we were forced to go with half our fouke≈øaile, with all our cords wel bound & made fa≈øt, and the ≈øtorm or Tuffon was ≈øo great, that wee were forced to bind all that wee had on boord, els it was pre≈øently ≈øtricken in p√©eces. The day before wee ≈øawe the I≈øland Fermo≈øa, which is a very high Land, and ≈ø√©emeth to reach vnto the cloudes, & there wee had fiue and fortie and fiftie fadome water muddy ground. The fir≈øt token that we had of the afore≈øaid Tempe≈øt, was a ≈ømall Raine-bowe clo≈øe by the Horizon on the Sea ≈øide, being a faire ru≈ø≈øet colour, with two other greater Rainebowes: whereof the point or end ≈øhewed almo≈øt like the cloud called Olhos de Bois (that is, Cats eyes) which are ≈ømall clouds, which at the fir≈øt ≈øhewe, ≈øeeme no greater then a mans fi≈øt: about the Cape De bona Speranza, which by the ≈øailors that ≈øaile in the Ea≈øt Indian Seas are much marked, for they are tokens of ≈øuddaine falling Tempe≈øtes and cruell ≈øtormes, as in the voyage from India to
Portingale is alreadie partly declared: wherefore it is good to b√©e aduerti≈øed thereof, the better to looke vnto it, and to watch for them, to ye which end I thought it not from the matter to ≈øpeake of them in this place. But returning vnto our matter: I aduerti≈øe you that when you are come into tho≈øe countries, as long as the winde commeth out of the North, and ≈øo Southwe≈øt, you are to make no account thereof, for it will pre≈øently b√©e North Northea≈øt and Ea≈øt, but when it is calme, then you ≈øhall haue a Southea≈øt winde, and then South and Southwe≈øt, which are the mon≈øon and windes of that time, but if it beginne againe to be calme, it may ≈øo fall out that it will b√©e Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, but it will pre≈øently be ≈øouthea≈øt againe, with faire weather, which w√©e al≈øo found in this Mon≈øon of Iuly, Anno 1585.

The thr√©e and twentie beeing Tue≈øday, w√©e had verie good weather, in ≈øuch manner, that at that mealetide w√©e ≈øailed about fift√©ene miles, b√©eing about twelue miles from the firme land of China. Thur≈øday the 25. of Iuly, wee tooke not the height of the Sunne, becau≈øe wee lay driuing without ≈øayles with an Ea≈øt wind, winding Southward, and ≈øo helde till the 26. day, and draue We≈øtward, finding two fadome le≈ø≈øe in our depth.

The 26. we wound Northward without ≈øailes, yet not long after wee let our fore≈øaile fall, (but wholly again≈øt my mind) but onely at the importunate de≈øire of the Chini≈øh Pilat, ≈øaying that the ≈øame day wee ≈øhould haue the winde larger, which was not ≈øo, but cleane contrarie, ≈øo that all the way wee made in that ≈øort was more trouble≈øome vnto bs: wherefore it is better for ≈øuch as finde them≈øelues in tho≈øe countries of 29. degr√©es, to ≈øtay for Southea≈øt windes, and then to runne North Northea≈øt, Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by North, becau≈øe the waters and ≈øtreames runne verie ≈øtrong towards Liampo, and when you are vnder 30. and 31. degr√©es, hauing a South Southea≈øt winde, then you ≈øhall haue great labour and much paine to get the I≈øland Meaxuma, for ≈øo it happened vnto vs, becau≈øe the wind was ≈øo ≈øtrong, that we could beare but our fore≈øaile, and halfe the maine top-≈øaile, as al≈øo becau≈øe the Sea ranne very high and hollow, and put our ≈øhippe out of cour≈øe, and that the ≈øtreames ranne Southea≈øt: This is about 25. or 30. miles from the I≈øland Meaxuma.

‚Ä¢ 0. and 75. fadome with ≈ømall thin ≈øand, and a little after that w√©e had 80. fadome deep, but I bel√©eue that chanced becau≈øe the Lead hung ≈øomewhat backewarde. At that ca≈øting, the ground was ≈øomewhat greater ≈øande, and becau≈øe (as wee made account) w√©e were neere vnto the I≈øland Meaxuma, I pre≈øently tooke in the

div.head: The 37. Chapter. The right markes of the I≈øland Meaxuma, as well by the depthes as by the opening of the land, with an aduerti≈øement how you ≈øhall put into the Hauen, and in the Rode of Langa≈øaque or Nanga≈øache in the land of I ‚Ä¢ pan.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, when you are at ≈øeuentie fiue fadome water, you mu≈øt go right vpon the middle of the I≈øland, and ≈øeeing Land at that depth, it will be a high plaine ≈øteepe land, but not verie great, on the vppermo≈øt part thereof hauing two p ‚Ä¢ ps, and when you goe n√©ere it, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e another long land, b√©eing flat and euen on the toppe, betw√©ene them both hauing two great cliffes, with many ≈ømall, lying togither, which you ≈øaile clo≈øe by: about two miles from them, this I≈øland on the Southwe≈øt ≈øide hath a Cliffe, and a little further to Seaward from it, there lyeth another ≈øtonie Cliffe vnder the water, whereon the Sea breaketh, and at the Northea≈øt end it hath another I≈øland or Cliffe. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that comming to Iapon, and finding more depthes then afore≈øaid, and ≈ø√©eing land, then it is not the I≈øland of Meaxuma, but rather the I≈øland called Sancta clara, & if you find le≈ø≈øe depth then ≈øeuentie fadome, then it is Meaxuma, but then it will b√©e on the Starrebord ≈øide. The I≈øland of Meaxuma lyeth vnder 31. degr√©es and 2/ ‚Ä¢ . H√©e that de≈øireth to goe to Langa≈øaque, pa≈ø≈øing from this I≈øland about two miles Ea≈øtward from it, he mu≈øt runne Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, hauing a full wind: but if you ≈øaile by the winde, you mu≈øt rather ≈øaile Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, & with this cour≈øe you ≈øhall get the I≈øland of Cabexuma, and you ≈øhall likewi≈øe ≈ø√©e the hilles of Amacu≈øa, as al≈øo ≈øome ≈ømall cliffes lying right ouer again≈øt Cabexuma, which you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e: and if you de≈øire to be put into Langa≈øaque, then you mu≈øt holde along by the cliffes afore≈øaid to Seaward from them: and b√©eing pa≈øt tho≈øe cliffes, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈øee the end of the I≈øland dos Cauallos, or of Hor≈øes, which on the Northwe≈øt ende hath certaine Pine tr√©es: you mu≈øt put towardes that point, and when you are right again≈øt it, you ≈øhall not pre≈øently fall vpon it, becau≈øe of the billowes that come from ouer the I≈øland Caffury, which commonly you find mo≈øt certainly in that place: and when you find tho≈øe billowes, you ≈øhall put forwarde as much as you thinke conuenient, thereby to put into the middle of the Hauen, and when you are in the middle then you may fr√©ely put on, for there you haue no cau≈øe of feare, and when you begin to put in, then you
≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e the water breake vpon the ≈øtonie place, which lieth as farre as to the middle way of the I≈øland dos Cauallos, ≈øo that in the entrie of Langa≈øaque there is nothing els to doe, then onely to runne in through the middle thereof, till you be in the Rode, where you mu≈øt anker, hauing foure fadome, and ¬Ω. and fiue fadome water, which is when a tr√©e that is right again≈øt the great and principalle≈øt Church is euen with the toppe of the Church, and you ouer again≈øt it, then you are at the right place, and it is a very good place to anker in: but when you are hard by the point of land that commeth right from the Church, you mu≈øt take care to k√©epe on the left hand, thereby to ≈øhunne a Riffe of ≈øand that commeth from the ≈øame point, and ≈øo anker as afore≈øaid.

And if you chance by night to pa≈ø≈øe by the Cliffes afore≈øaid, and de≈øire to anker by them at fortie fadome, (as ≈øome ancient Pilots adui≈øe you) in danger of an Ea≈øt wind, then my opinion is, that you were better runne betw√©ene them and the I≈øland Cabexuma, and certaine I≈ølands that lie in the ranke of the I≈ølands dos Cauallos, which is a verie broad and good channell of twentie fadome d√©epe, and there you may wind and lauere from one bough to the other as he will, ≈øo that you may anker there at twelue or fift√©ene fadome which you will, vpon a flat and euen ground hard by the I≈øland Caffury, wherby you are ≈øafe from the northea≈øt to the Southea≈øt and South, b√©eing in more ≈øafetie and better a≈ø≈øured in the morning to ≈øet faile, betw√©ene the Ilands dos Cauallos and Caffury till you be in, which is a verie good channell of ten fadome d√©epe: you n√©ed but pa≈ø≈øe right thorough the middle, and to be the better a≈ø≈øured, you may ≈øend a boat in before you, which ≈øhall lie there where ye riuer is narrowe≈øt, thereby to ≈øerue you for a Baye or Sea-marke.

div.head: The 38. Chapter. The right cour≈øe to ≈øaile from the I≈øland Meaxuma to the Hauen of Cochinochy and to Facunda, with the ≈øcituation of the Places.
div.p: WHen you ≈ø√©e the I≈øland Meaxuma, go within a mile and a halfe or two miles n√©ere it, or ≈øomewhat clo≈øer if you will, for there you n√©ed feare nothing but what you ≈ø√©e before you, and de≈øiring to ≈øaile from thence to Cochinochy then you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, ≈øtil k√©eping Ea≈øtward, whereby you ≈øhall come to the Cr√©eke of Arima: and if it b√©e by night, and that you de≈øire to knowe when you are by the land, then ca≈øt your Lead continually out, and b√©eing at fortie fadome, then you are about two miles and a halfe or thr√©e miles from the lande, and b√©eing in the mouth of the Cr√©eke, you ≈øhall finde hard and great Sand: and when you are at fortie fadome, you may anker if the weather be faire: if you thinke it b√©e falling water, and ≈øo ≈øtay till it b√©e daye, for there the ≈øtreame runneth verie ≈øtrong into the Sea, your Lead will direct you what you ≈øhall doe.

If it b√©e day, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e the Lande of Cabexuma, to Seawarde from you, lyeth a Cliffe which ≈øheweth like a Saile. This Cliffe you can not ≈ø√©e, but when you are clo≈øe by the point: to L√©ewarde from this point Northward, lyeth certaine ≈øtonie cliffes, but it is not be≈øt for you that you ≈ø√©e them when you goe to Cochinochy, becau≈øe they lie to L√©e-warde, as I ≈øaide before. And wen you ≈ø√©e lande, which is at fortie fadome water, then you ≈øhall pre≈øently di≈øcouer the Cr√©eke of Arima, as al≈øo the point of Cabexuma on the one ≈øide, and the lande of Amacu≈øa and Xiquy on the other ≈øide, which is very high. This lande lyeth on the South ≈øide, and Cabexuma on the North ≈øide, when you ≈ø√©e the point of Cabexuma, goe within a mile of it, becau≈øe of a ≈øtonie cliffe which lyeth in the mouth of the Creeke, holding your cour≈øe clo≈øe by Cabexuma, about a mile and a halfe from it, or along by the land of Amacu≈øa.

If the winde within this Cr√©eke b√©e ≈øharpe, then ≈øtay vntill the floode commeth, which ≈øhall bring you where you de≈øire to be, and being there you haue Cochinochy right before you, where you ≈øhall haue Barks and Scutes great ≈øtore to bring you in.

H√©e that de≈øireth to goe to Facunda, mu≈øt hold his cour≈øe Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by ea≈øt, and when you are clo≈øe by the land, you ≈øhall find the depths
afore≈øaid, and beeing to L√©ewarde from Cabexuma, you ≈øhall there finde harde ground and if it be right ouer again≈øt the mouth of the creeke, you ≈øhall haue ≈øandie ground, as afore≈øaid: and when you ≈øee the point of Cabexuma, then make towards the lande, and by the lande about a mile di≈øtant you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e certaine ≈øtonie cliffes, by the which you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe to Seaward from them: by the≈øe fir≈øt ≈øtonie cliffes lyeth a round I≈øland, with a tr√©e in it, and ≈øomewhat beyond this I≈øland with one Tr√©e, there is another I≈øland, ≈øtretching Northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt, called Ilha dos Cauallos, that is, the I≈øland of Hor≈øes: you mu≈øt make towards the I≈øland to a point of land that lyeth out on the North ≈øide of the ≈øame I≈øland. This I≈øland on the Northwe≈øt ≈øide hath for a marke certaine Pine tr√©es; when you are clo≈øe by the afore≈øaid Northerly point, then from thence hold Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, till you put in where you ≈øhall find a Creeke, and right ouer again≈øt this I≈øland North Northea≈øt, lieth a ≈øharpe pointed Houell, reaching to Seawarde, which you mu≈øt ≈øhun, for half a mile from thence forward lieth two ≈øtones, which you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈øee when you enter into the creeke, going within an I≈øland or cliffe which will be Ea≈øt Northea≈øt from you: you mu≈øt put towards it about the length of the ≈øhot of a great p√©ece, and ≈øo runne along by it till you be in, and within on the right hand vpon the lande you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e certaine downes, and on the left hand a groue, hauing on the ≈øea ≈øide as you pa≈ø≈øe along many ≈øtones like Kefell ≈øtones. Right ouer again≈øt this I≈øland on the left hand, lie the two ≈øtones afore≈øaid, which you can not ≈øee: then with an ebbe of a ≈øpring tide, and running in after this manner, you ≈øhall ≈øee a cro≈ø≈øe ≈øtanding vpon a point of land: and right ouer again≈øt this cro≈ø≈øe is the Rode, and from this cro≈ø≈øe Ea≈øtward there is a verie good Hauen, where you mu≈øt make your ≈øhip fa≈øt and ≈øure from the South ≈øide, that is, the Hauen of Facunda.

div.head: The 39. Chapter. An in≈øtruction of the cour≈øe out of the Hauen of Langa≈øaque or Nanga≈øache, to the cape de Sumber, in the coa≈øt of China, where the Portingales are re≈øident.
div.p: SAiling out of the hauen of Lang ‚Ä¢ ≈øaque to China hauing a North wind, if you haue cau≈øe to anker, below by the thr√©e I≈ølands or cliffes, b√©eing right ouer again≈øt the I≈øland dos Cauallos, on the ≈øide of Facunda, then anker there along, for it is d√©epe enough all ouer, as I with my lead haue prooued: there you ≈øhall ≈øtay the fir≈øt night, that in the morning very early you may haue the winde from off the lande, wherewith you ≈øhall ≈øet ≈øaile, loo≈øing as much as you can vntill you be gotten about the I≈øland dos Cauallos, for becau≈øe we did it not (being in the ≈øhip of Tri≈øtan Vaas da Veiga) we were in danger not to haue b√©ene able to get about the I≈øland.

B√©eing pa≈øt the I≈øland dos Cauallos, you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe We≈øt, We≈øt and by South, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt, and if the wind be bigge then put not towards the I≈øland Guoto, for that there at that time you haue certaine South windes, which I knowe for certaine, becau≈øe I haue b√©en there at other times, in the ≈øhip of Manoel Traua≈ø≈øos in great trouble, becau≈øe it is cro≈ø≈øe wind right vpoÃÑ the coa≈øt, and there you haue no ground, as al≈øo by night not to fall by the Pannellas (which are called Pottes, and by ≈øome Cliffes) wherefore your be≈øt cour≈øe is to runne to Loofeward from the I≈øland Meaxuma. Along by the Southwe≈øt ≈øide of the I≈øland of Meaxuma lieth a cliffe, from thence forwarde you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe We≈øt Southwe≈øt, although you haue the wind ≈øcant, yet you may hold that cour≈øe, for that being halfe way from the gulfe to the coa≈øt, you ≈øhall without doubt finde the wind large enough.

In this way (k√©eping well to Loofewarde) about 35. or 40. miles from the Cape de Sumbor, you ≈øhall find a Banke of 35.37. and 38. fadome d√©epe, which (by ≈øuch as knewe it not) might bee taken for the ground of the land of China.

Being pa≈øt this Banke, you find more depthes, but when after that the depthes begin to le≈ø≈øen, then looke to your ≈øelfe, for then mo≈øt certainly you are by the land. When you ≈ø√©e the land of Sumbor, then in the night time you mu≈ø ‚Ä¢ runne South Southwe≈øt, and by day make towardes the land, thereby at times to k√©epe ≈øomewhat to Seaward from the land, thereby
to ≈øhun the cliffes called As duas Irmaas, or the two Si≈øters, which lie far inward to ≈øea, as al≈øo the I≈øland called do Baboxyn, which lieth cro≈ø≈øe ouer again≈øt you, being di≈øtant from the firme land to Seaward about foure or fiue miles, ≈øtretching Northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt, you runne along all the coa≈øt of Sumbor Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt, and ≈øomwhat Northea≈øt and by North, and Southwe≈øt and by South: When you are pa≈øt the afore≈øaid I≈øland of Baboxyn, then runne the cour≈øe afore≈øaide for the ≈øpace of thr√©e or foure miles, and from thence We≈øt Southwe≈øt, whereby you ≈øhall come to the I≈øland of Chinchon, where you ≈øhall finde ≈øand vpon the ground (which in all the coa≈øt afore≈øaid you can not find) with 18. or 20. fadome water.

From the I≈øland of Chinchon to the I≈øland of Lamon you ≈øhal hold your cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, or as you thinke good, and when you are right again≈øt the I≈ølandes or Cliffes called Os Ilhas de Ruy Lobo, you ≈øhall find vpon the ground great ≈øand with ≈øhelles, and from thence to Lamon, which is twelue miles, you finde the like: by the I≈øland of Lamon you find ≈øhelles, and blacke ≈øand, with oy≈øter ≈øhels among it: if you chance to be in that countrey by night, runne not vnder 22. fadome water, for that along by the riffes it hath 21. and 22. fadome with ≈øhels and blacke ≈øand vpon the ground, and runne ≈øtill Southwe≈øt, without leauing that cour≈øe, and if it chance before day or by day to be clo≈øe aire (running Southwe≈øt) and that you haue ≈ømall thin white ≈øand, then you are by Lamon, and then hold your cour≈øe we≈øt Southwe≈øt, and ≈øo you ≈øhall goe right vpon the middle of the I≈øland called Ilha Branco, and from thence runne We≈øt vnto the Channell, whereby you goe vp to Macau.

div.head: The 40. Chapter. Another voiage made from the Hauen of Langa≈øaque to Macau, which is from Iapon to China, with certaine de≈øcriptions and accidents which happened by the I≈øland Gu ‚Ä¢ to, with the de≈øcription of the Hauens thereof, accompli≈øhed in the yeere of our Lord 1584. by a Portingale Pilot.
div.p: DEparting out of the Hauen of Langa≈øaque the 25. of Februarie, Anno 1584. 15 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . and pa≈ø≈øing along by the I≈øland of Facunda, wee had a We≈øt Northwe≈øt wind, ≈øo that w√©e ankered: the 26. day it began to blowe ≈øo ≈øtiffe, that wee were con≈øtrained to put for harbour into Tomache.

The 27. w√©e hoi≈øed anker, with an Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, and an Ea≈øt winde, and cleare weather, and comming to the I≈øland dos Cauallos, we had a South wind againe, wherewith we made back againe to Facunda, from whence we ≈øet out.
The eight and twentie being Friday, w√©e ≈øet ≈øaile againe from Facunda, it beeing thr√©e dayes before the newe Moone, with a cold Ea≈øt Northea≈øt wind.

And beeing within thr√©e miles of the I≈øland dos Cauallos, we had a Southea≈øt wind, running on the Southwe≈øt bough all that day, and the winde began to bee ≈øomewhat coole, and then we ge≈ø≈øed it to be thr√©e or foure miles beyond the I≈øland of Guoto, but in the morning watch wee fir≈øt e≈øpied the point of Guoto, being a houell lying on the Northwe≈øt part thereof, there we had a ≈øharpe wind and it began to ri≈øe high out of the South Southea≈øt, as much as the ≈øhip with all his Sayles might heare: wee let the maine ≈øaile vp, the better to make way, and not long after the winde came about to the Southwe≈øt, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt, with two thunder claps, and much lightning, wherwith wee hoped it would haue beene ≈øtill weather, but it was not ≈øo, whereat wee woondered.

On Saterday by day light wee were right ouer again≈øt the point of Guoto, almo≈øt vpon the end of the I≈øland that lyeth Northwe≈øt, being about two myles from the lande, hauing with the We≈øt Northwe≈øt winde, a cro≈ø≈øe ≈øtorme, with the waues of the ≈øea out of the ≈øouthwe≈øt, which were verie hollowe and mightie high, which to≈ø≈øed the ≈øhippe mon≈ø ‚Ä¢ rou ‚Ä¢ ly, although the winde was ouer much, but onely the force and power of the waues troubled vs mo≈øt, which fell behind at our ≈øterne, for there wee found a very ≈øtrong ≈øtreame, and becau≈øe the wind was ≈ølack, we doubted we ≈øhould not get aboue the point of the I≈øland, neither from the one ≈øide nor from the other, for wee had the cro≈ø≈øe vpon the I≈øland.

At the end of this I≈øland we ≈øaw another I≈øland of low land, being about two miles long, and was about a mile and a
halfe di≈øtant from Guoto, ≈øome of our ≈øhip affirmed that there was a verie good Hauen, running in on the one ≈øide and comming out againe at the other: wherefore we determined to put in there for our better ≈øecuritie, as we did, and we ranne in We≈øt Northwe≈øt. At the entry there of it hath a verie great houell with two cliffes lying on the Southea≈øt ≈øide of the point. The I≈øland that lieth without, is on the left hand till you be about a mile from it, betweene which and the lande, it is all faire: you may boldly goe as n√©ere the I≈øland of Guoto as you will, and n√©ed feare nothing but what you ≈øee before you: The entry of the Hauen reacheth Northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt, hauing within it a great Bay, which is all ouer verie d√©epe from twentie to thirtie fadome water, and nothing therein to be feared. From this I≈øland to the land you haue all ouer the depthes of thirtie and fortie fadome, and yet I haue tried it from the halfe way to Guoto, and found eight√©ene to thirtie fadome, with ≈øand and ≈øhels on the ground, in ≈øome places hauing good ground: inward in ≈øome places you haue Sand, and in ≈øome places muddie ground: froÃÑ thence w√©e were brought out againe by Scutes about halfe a mile forward, ≈øo that after that the North wind ≈øerued well to ≈øaue vs, and to driue vs forward from the point lying on the South ≈øide, which hath certaine ≈øtonie Cliffes, w√©e ranne along the land Northea≈øtward, and it fell out well for vs, for therby we had twentie or thirtie Scutes of the I≈øland, that for 20. taes Chi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
money holpe vs well, and pulled out our beat: we likewi≈øe gaue them 50. taes, and about 20. depe≈øas to haue our ≈øhippe ankered and ≈øtayed, but they a≈øked vs 30 ‚Ä¢ . whereupon we ≈øent one of our Portingales on land, whome they helde for a p ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢ e, although by certaine practi≈øe we got him out of their hands againe: and when after that wee ≈ø√©emed to complaine, they cried vs mercie, and ≈øent him backe againe, although wee vnder≈øtoode verie well, that they were our friends by force, as perceiuing they had no meanes to hurt vs, becau≈øe wee coulde helpe our ≈øelues without them: but we marked ≈øo much in them, that if they coulde haue hindered vs, they would not haue failed to doe it, or el≈øe w√©e mu≈øt haue ≈øtopped their mouthes with money. There w√©e vnder≈øtood that the I≈øland of Guoto hath ≈øixe or ≈øeuen Hauens that are very good, running from the one ≈øide to the other, but the Hauen afore≈øaid had no i≈ø≈øue, but ≈øo much plea≈øure it did vs, that there we had the new Moone, which was the fir≈øt of March, and the third day wee ≈øet ≈øayle againe, it being Shroue Tue≈øday, with a North Northea≈øt winde, and a verie cl√©ere morning: and b√©eing out, w√©e helde our cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, following on our cour≈øe, wherewith w√©e ≈øawe the I≈øland Meaxuma and the Pannellas, or Pots, lying South Southea≈øt from vs, w√©e tell right vpon the middle thereof. Tho≈øe Panellas are two ≈ømall ≈øtones, and Meaxuma is an I≈øland, and when you are Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt right ouer again≈øt it, it ≈øheweth like two or three I≈ølands, wherof that on the Northea≈øt ≈øide is long, and the greate≈øt, and ≈øheweth as if it had a Cliffe: This I≈øland is the longe≈øt but not verie high, and that in the middle is ≈ømall, hauing thr√©e ≈øharp points like Organ pipes, with a Cliffe likewi≈øe lying Northea≈øtward: The other I≈øland on the Southwe≈øt ≈øide is round and plain ≈øt√©epe lande ≈øhewing higher then all the other, and ≈ø√©emeth to haue Cliffes round about it. On the other ≈øide lie the Panellas a ‚Ä¢ ore≈øaide, and although I ≈øaid before they are but two ≈øtones, yet they are three, two ≈øtanding togither, and the other ≈øomewhat further from them, and lie with the I≈øland Meaxuma Northwe≈øt, and Southea≈øt. From thence forward wee held our cour≈øe to China and Macau, in ≈øuch manner as I ≈øhewed in another place, and hereafter once againe I will declare.

div.head: The 41. Chapter. Another voiage made out of the Hauen of Langa≈øaque from the I≈øland of Iapon to Macau in China, in the Santacrus the Gunner being Diricke Geri ‚Ä¢ ≈øon of Enckehu≈ø ‚Ä¢ n in Ann. 1586.
div.p:
THE 20. of March we departed out of the Hauen of Langa≈øaque, it being the fir≈øt day of the newe Moone, vpon a Thur≈øday with a northea≈øt and North Northea≈øt winde, and by nine of the clocke in the morning, w√©e were as farre as the I≈øland dos Cauallos,
running We≈øt Southwe≈øt, and being two myles beyond the I≈øland Dos Cauallos, wee had a calme, and then the wind came Northwe≈øt, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that wee ranne Southwe≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by we≈øt, and ≈øometimes halfe a ≈øtrike with a ≈ølacke winde. The next day in the morning we ≈øaw the I≈ølands of Corequyn and Guoto, and about eight of the clock in the forenoone, we ≈øaw the I≈øland Meaxum ‚Ä¢ , ≈øo that we ≈øawe tho≈øe three I≈ølands all at once, and about twilight, we were ea≈øt Southea≈øt, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt, with the I≈øland of Meaxuma, and ≈øo helde our cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, hauing a hard Northea≈øt wind with raine, the aire being very darke and clo≈øe, yet the Rackes came out of the Southwe≈øt: Vpon Sunday we ca≈øt out the Leade, and found ≈øomewhat more then forty fadome water, muddye ground, and was about forty myles from Meaxuma. This depth is a banke lying in the middle way betw√©ene the I≈øland Meaxuma and Cabo de Su ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bor, in the firme land of China.

Vpon munday the foure and twentith day w√©e tooke not the height of the ≈øunne, becau≈øe we ≈øaw it not, hauing ≈øo ≈ømall a winde, that the ≈øhip might ≈øt√©ere vpright, and becau≈øe we made little way, wee ca≈øt out the lead, and found forty fadome muddy ground, this was at noone, and at night about ≈øunne ≈øetting we ca≈øt it out againe, and foun ‚Ä¢ fiue and fifty fadome, whereby we perceiued that wee began to pa≈ø≈øe ouer a banke, at that time we had all one wind being Northea≈øt, and North North-ea≈øt, with a good bla≈øt, and yet the clouds came South-we≈øt, and South South-we≈øt, ≈øo ≈øtrong that they put vs in feare, doubting the wind would be there, but we had certaine men in our ≈øhippe that had ≈øeene and found it ≈øo in that place, and yet no alteration, whereby they put vs in ≈øome comfort, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that wee followed on our cour≈øe with that wind. Vpon Tue≈øday at noone, w√©e tooke the height of the Sunne not full nine and twenty degr√©es, hauing not long before as I ge≈ø≈øed, marked one point in the Card, and e≈øt√©emed that wee had ≈øayled a hundred myles from the Hauen of
‚Ä¢ anga≈øaque, but by the Sunne it was not ≈øo.

The ≈øixe and twenty being Wedne≈øday, wee tooke not the heigth of the ≈øunne, becau≈øe it was a clo≈øe day, but wee had a good Northea≈øt wind, and made good way, ≈øo that wee ≈øeemed to make thirtie myles ‚Ä¢ n one mealetide, but I made account but of fiue and twenty myles, becau≈øe wee thought the ≈øhip ≈øailed not ouer fa≈øt, that day we ≈øawe many Cuttle bones driuing vpon the water, & held our cour≈øe Southwe≈øt till morning, and becau≈øe the winde beganne to bee ≈øtiffe, I thought it good to make towards the land to know it, therefore as day appeared wee ran We≈øt till it was euening without knowing Land, by rea≈øon of the mi≈øtine ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of the aire, but by the depths & our ge≈ø≈øing, wee thought wee were about 5 or 6 miles from the land, our depth was 37 fadome, and being towards night with cloudy weather, we ran ≈øouthwe≈øt, and ≈øouthwe≈øt and by ≈øouth, all that night, and when day came being thur≈øday wee ge≈ø≈øed to bee ouer again≈øt the Laga ‚Ä¢ to or Crocodille (a cliffe ≈øo called about fiue or ≈øixe miles to Seaward from it, but wee found it to be ≈øomewhat more.

Thur≈øday being the ≈øeuen and twenty, as ≈øoone as day appeared, we ran ‚Ä¢ e We≈øt towards the Land, and about foure of the clocke in the afternoone, we ≈øaw the land, being the I≈ølands Dos Camaro ‚Ä¢ s that is, the I≈ølands of Granata) tho≈øe I≈ølan ‚Ä¢ s are not too high: as ≈øoone as we ≈øaw them, wee helde our cour≈øe South Southwe≈øt‚ñ™ and hauing ≈øailed a little way, we ≈øaw another round I≈øland called Ilha do B ‚Ä¢ box ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , which lay right before vs, as ≈øoone as wee ≈øaw it, we pre≈øently ran South to ≈øhun it, becau≈øe we were not aboue a quarter of a mile from it, there wee found ≈øo ≈øtrong a ≈øtreame and cour≈øe of water which ranne with vs, that in ≈øhort time we were two or three myles from the afore≈øaid I≈øland, in ≈øuch manner, that all that night wee ranne South, and South and by We≈øt, and South Southwe≈øt, and when the moone ro≈øe, we held our cour≈øe ≈øouthwe≈øt.

The eight and twenty being Friday, about morning we began to runne We≈øt Southwe≈øt, we≈øt, and we≈øt and by South, and at noon or thereabouts, we ca≈øt out the Lead, and found nine and twenty fadome muddy ground, and running ≈øo with that cour≈øe for a little time, we ≈øaw land, but it was ≈øo clo≈øe and mi≈øty, that we could not know it, but about two or three of ye clock in the afternoone it began to cleare vp, and then we knew it to be the I≈øland of Chinchon being North from vs, and there wee ca≈øt out the Lead, and found nineteene fadome water ≈øandy ground, and not long after we ≈øawe the whole coa≈øt and firme Land of China, and ≈øo we ran all night at
the depths of ninet√©ene, twenty, and two and twenty fadome with ≈øo clear & bright a ≈øky, that almo≈øt all the night we ≈øaw the coa≈øt, and when day began to appear, we were ≈øomwhat beyond the I≈ølands called Ruy Lobo, and pre≈øently thervpon we ≈øaw the I≈øland of Lamon, there we beganne to haue certain ≈øtormes, as I ge≈ø≈øe it is from Ilhas de Ruy Lobo, to the I≈øland of Lamon ten miles, by the I≈øland of Lamon we ≈øaw the water ≈øhynne and burne to Seaward, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that wee pa≈ø≈øed clo≈øe by the Riffe: tho≈øe that come from Iapon, mu≈øt fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øe by the I≈øland, and then by the Riffe, this Riffe lieth Northea≈øt, & ≈øouthwe≈øt, and is dangerous, for tho≈øe that ≈øaile from Macau to Iapon, we ran about thr√©e miles from it with a ≈øtrong northea≈øt, and Ea≈øt Northea≈øt winde, ≈øo that wee made good way, whereby it ≈ø√©emed we made fifty miles in one meale tide, but the ≈øtreÃÑgth of ye water and ≈øtreames again≈øt vs were ≈øo ≈øtiffe, that we ≈øailed but fiue and twenty myles in a mealetide. This ≈øtrong ≈øtreame and ≈øtiffe water commeth (as we were informed) out of the Riuer of Tancoan, and continueth till you be pa≈øt the I≈øland Branco, & being pa≈øt it, the ≈øtreame runneth pre≈øently towards the I≈øland Ilha de Leme, which lyeth clo≈øe by Macau, from Lamon we ran We≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt, and in truth we found the way from Lamon to Ilha Branco, very ≈øhort, for by night wee ≈øtroke all our ≈øayles, and ≈øo lay driuing without ≈øailes, winding Southwe≈øt, alwaies at the depths of fiue and twentie and ≈øix and twenty fadome water, and at the midnight watch, we began to hoi≈øe vp our maine ≈øaile and our fouke≈øaile, in that manner running We≈øt to get to twenty fadome deepe, which is the middle of the chanell where we mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe through, and in the morning we ≈øaw the I≈øland Do Leme, (that is the I≈øland of the harquebu≈øh) lying ≈øomwhat on ye lareboord of vs. This I≈øland Do Leme, if you go ea≈øt and We≈øt vpon it, ≈ø√©emeth very ≈ømall, and the d√©eper you are within the channell, the bigger it ≈øheweth, in the entry wherof on the right hand it hath two I≈ølands or Cliffes, and from thence forward, the I≈ølands begin to lye on a rowe till you come to Macau, as I ≈øaid in another place.

div.head: The 42. chapter. An in≈øtruction and large declaration of the cour≈øe from the I≈øland Firando in Iapon, to the coa≈øt of China, & the hauen of Macau, with all the cour≈øes, ≈øituations, and ≈øtretchings of the ≈øame, done by a Portingale Pilote.
div.p: HE that de≈øireth to ≈øaile from the I≈øland Firando, to Macau or Canton in China, as ≈øoone as he is out of the hauen of Firando, if he hath time inough to get to the I≈øland Guoto, he mu≈øt pre≈øently ≈øaile forward, if not, h√©e mu≈øt anker about a mile from Firando, at 28 fadome d√©epe, where hee may prepare him≈øelf, and make fa≈øt his boat, yt the next day in the morning he may ≈øet ≈øaile.

As ≈øoon as you are ≈øet out from Firando to follow on your cour≈øe, you mu≈øt runne along by the land of Firando, till you bee at the end thereof, and as you run ≈øouth we≈øt, vntil you be by the land, you ≈øhal hold ≈øomwhat n√©erer ≈øouth-we≈øt, and then on your We≈øt ≈øide there will bee 3. or 4. I≈ølands, and pa≈ø≈øing by the formo≈øt of them ≈øouthward, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e the channell that runneth betw√©en that I≈øland and the I≈øland Guoto, and through it you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe. The I≈ølandes you ≈ø√©e before you come to Lamon, are called, Os Ilhas de Ruy Lobo, that is, the I≈ølands of Ruy Lobo, from the which, that which lyeth Northea≈øt is the ≈ømalle≈øt, the other being ≈øomewhat greater: Vpon the greate≈øt are ≈ø√©ene certaine Bu≈øhes, from thence to Lamon are ≈øeuen or eight miles, on the Sea ≈øide it is twentie fadome d√©epe with ≈øhels on ye ground, from thence you ≈øhal run ≈øouthwe≈øt, and holde a little ≈øouthwe≈øt and by South, and if it be in the day time, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈øee the I≈ølands lying at the end of the Riffe of Lamon, from whence the ≈øaid Riffe hath his i≈ø≈øue, reaching a myle and a halfe or two miles with this cour≈øe, you ≈øhal make good way, but if it be night, you mu≈øt looke well to your ≈øelfe.

div.head: The 43. Chapter. How you ≈øhall runne in, out, and through the channell betweene the I≈ølands and cliffes of Macau, with all the markes, ≈øignes, and tokens thereof, ≈øo to ≈øaile into the Hauen of Macau.
div.p: IF you de≈øire to ≈øaile out of Macau, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, yt as ≈øoone as you hoi≈øe anker in the road where the ≈øhips lie, which is right ouer again≈øt the Bulwarke of Ga≈øpar Borgies, you ≈øhal pre≈øently ≈ø√©e in the Northea≈øt a white vlacke ≈øtanding vpon the hil, and pre≈øently after towards the Ea≈øt, you haue two houels, which with the Hill of the white vlacke make thr√©e.

The ≈øecond houell which lyeth in the middle, is bare & wholly di≈øcouered, appearing through the rocks & cliffes yt lie vpon the top of ye field called Dos Pa ‚Ä¢ anas, which is in the middle of the chanel, being by the la≈øt hou≈øes of the town: and when you are right again≈øt ye afore≈øaid hou≈øes, then you ≈øhal pre≈øently di≈øcouer the 3. houel, ≈øo that when you are right again≈øt ye ≈øandy point (lying clo≈øe by ye Varella) called Dos Mandorins, then the ≈øaid houel is almo≈øt wholly vncouered, where you ≈øhall find four fadome and a halfe d√©epe, with a full ≈øea of a Spring tide, and as ≈øoone as you are pa≈øt the ≈øandy Point, then you beginne to find

When you are at the depths afore≈øaid, then ≈øouthward from you, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e an opening called En≈øeada de Gon≈øato vaaz, which within it hath a hil on the ea≈øt ≈øide, which ≈øheweth like an I≈øland or Cliffe, and on the We≈øt ≈øide it hath two Points ≈øticking out, and when tho≈øe two Points are right ouer again≈øt each other, theÃÑ you are in the middle of the channell, and you mu≈øt be carefull to ≈ø√©e yt they lye one right again≈øt the other, for by that marke you ≈øhall runne in the d√©epe≈øt and be≈øt place, which is at 27 Spannes of water, with a ≈øpring tide, as I haue found it, in the time of the Mon≈øon, when you ≈øaile to Iapon, hauing an Ea≈øt winde, for with a North wind, you haue le≈ø≈øe water there.

Now to know when you are as farre as the banke, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtande, that Northward towards the I≈øland Do Bugio, there lyeth a ≈øtony cliffe, which ≈øheweth like a houell, which lieth mo≈øt Northward of all the re≈øt, & along by the ≈øtrand it hath a clouen Rocke with two Points, when you haue the afore≈øaid ≈øtony Cliffe like a houell, right ouer again≈øt the middle of the afore≈øaid clouen rocke, then you are vpon the afore≈øaid banke, and when the afore≈øaid marke ≈øtandeth vneuen, on the one or other ≈øide, then you ≈øhall pre≈øently find more depths, which ≈øhall bee thus, that as you run Southea≈øt right vpon the thicke≈øt and greate≈øt land, on the other ≈øide vntill you be at foure and fiue fadome water, which is the point called Varella, and de≈øiring to pa≈ø≈øe through the ea≈øt channell, then you mu≈øt runne Southea≈øt and Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, vntill you haue di≈øcouered the I≈øland Do La≈øtro, wholly by the end of the I≈øland Do Bugio, then it is not good for you to runne more ≈øouthward to ≈øhun the ≈øtone lying right ouer again≈øt the Varella, and when you haue di≈øcouered the I≈øland Do La≈øtro as I ≈øaid before, then you mu≈øt runne along by the afore≈øaid ≈øtone about two cables length from it there you ≈øhall haue the depth of 28. and nine and twenty ≈øpannes of water with a ≈øpring tide: and to know when you are n√©ere≈øt the ≈øtone, it is wheÃÑ you haue wholly di≈øcouered the fir≈øt cliffe of two that lye on the North≈øide of the I≈øland Do La≈øtro, and then you are about a ≈øtones ca≈øt from the afore≈øaid-≈øtone, at the depth afore≈øaid, and when you haue wholly di≈øcouered the ≈øecond Cliffe, then you are beyond the ≈øtone, you may likewi≈øe know it by another marke, which is a white vlacke ≈øtanding vpon the Hill which you ≈øee ouer the Towne, and hath a ≈øtone which ≈øheweth like a mans head.

When you bring the afore≈øaid white vlacke in the middle of the top of the hou≈øe of Don Ioan d Almeyda, then you are right ouer again≈øt the afore≈øaid ≈øtone, and wheÃÑ you are pa≈øt it, it is good to make towards the land on the South≈øide, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that you leaue the two third parts thereof on the ≈øide of the town, and one third part on the South≈øide, and running in that ≈øort, you ≈øhall haue more depths then in the middle way, vntill you be vpon the banke which hath no more then ≈øixe and twenty Spannes Water, with high Water of a ≈øpring tide.
