And de≈øiring to knowe when you begin to be right again≈øt it, it is when you haue the cro≈ø≈øe part or dore of ye great church, right again≈øt the toppe of a hou≈øe, that ≈øtandeth on the ≈øtrand, which commeth vpon the ≈øame way of the ≈øame dore right to the ≈øtrand, ≈øo that ye dore is wholly di≈øcouered, there you haue ≈øeuen & twenty or eight and twenty Spannes water, which ≈øhall bee when you ≈ø√©e or di≈øcouer the clocke hou≈øe or top of S. Paules church, with a hill that ≈øtandeth behind the ≈øame church, and as ≈øoone as the ≈øaid clockhou≈øe is couered, then you ≈øhall pre≈øently finde more depths, as two and thirtie ≈øpannes water, which is foure fadome, which is right ouer again≈øt the place where you fetch fre≈øh Water: and going ≈øomewhat further forward, you ≈øhall finde foure fadome and a halfe & fiue fadome at a ≈øpring tide, this was the Road where the ≈øhippe called S. Crus, of the burthen of fourteene or ≈øixt√©ene tunnes did anker, and when the ≈øaid ≈øhip did wind with an ebbe, then the I≈øland Do La≈øtro lay vncouered, although it was a good way from the Land. You haue a very good token or marke to know when the land on the South≈øide is neere≈øt to you, then you mu≈øt make to the I≈øland Do La≈øtro, and Northward from it, there is two cliffes, and when tho≈øe two cliffes are one again≈øt the other then you are in the d√©epe≈øt of the channell, vntill you bee ouer the banke.

div.head: The 44. Chapter. Of the cour≈øe and ≈øtreames of the water in the way from Malacca, in the time of the Mon≈øon, when they ordinarily trauell thether.
div.p: FRom the I≈øland Pulo Catao (lying on the coa≈øt of Champa part of the Land of Camboia) to the Varella, (which is a place lying in the way from Pulo catao, towards Malacca, in ye ≈øame coa≈øt of Champa or Camboia) ye ≈øtreames run very ≈øtrong towards the ≈øouth: from the I≈øland Pulo Catao fiue miles forward, ye ≈øtreams run very ≈øtrong towards the I≈øland Champello, and the cr√©eke called A En≈øeada de Cauchinchina.
And in the mon≈øon of China, when you ≈øaile from Mallacca, in the months of October, Nouember, and December, theÃÑ the ≈øtreames in that part run Northwe≈øt.

And from the Month of Ianuary forward, they run ≈øouthwe≈øt, that is, towards the ≈øands: therfore ≈øuch as trauel that way mu≈øt ob≈øerue certain times, and that with good adui≈øe, and as they begin to goe n√©ere the country where the ≈øands lie, (that are right again≈øt the coa≈øt of Champa) betw√©ene them and the entery of the coa≈øt, the ≈øtreames run as ≈øwiftly into the ≈øouth as a ≈øtone ≈ølyeth out of a mans hand.
But I adui≈øe you not to goe ≈øo n√©ere the I≈øland Aynao, that you may ≈ø√©e it, vnle≈ø≈øe it be with a Northwind, for with an Ea≈øt wind you would be in great danger.

div.head: The 45. Chapter. Of the tides and increa≈øing of the waters of Malacca.
div.p: IN the entry of the Hauen of Patane, (lying on the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the country and coa≈øt of Mallacca) to the I≈øland of Bintao, (which lyeth by the ≈øtraight of Singa Pura vnder the Equinoctiall line) the ≈øtreames doe alwaies runne Southward in the months of Nouember and December.

From the I≈øland Pulo Condor (lying right again≈øt the hauen and land of Camboia) to the I≈øland Pulo Timao) lying on the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the coa≈øt of Malacca, at ≈øuch time as you come froÃÑ China) holding your cour≈øe halfe a ≈øtrike from the ≈øouth) the ≈øtreams run towards the I≈øland Borneo, and being halfe a ≈øtrike Southwe≈øtward, then the ≈øtreames run towards the coa≈øt of Pan, which lyeth on the coa≈øt of the Ea≈øt ≈øide of Mallacca.

From Pulo Condor, to the I≈øland Pulo Se≈øir (lying right again≈øt the coa≈øt of Camboia) the ≈øtreames run Ea≈øtward, and by Pulo Se≈øir in the way towards China, the ≈øtreames runne to the coa≈øt of Champa, and from the Falce Varella (which is di≈øtant from the right Varella fift√©en miles, lying on the coa≈øt of Camboia) ye ≈øtreames runne Ea≈øtward about fiue or ≈øixe myles from the coa≈øt, which is at the end of Iuly, and in the month of Augu≈øt.

In the Mon≈øon of the South windes, when you ≈øaile from Mallacca to China, the ≈øtreames (from the Gulfe of Pulo Catao ‚ñ™ and the I≈øland Aynao) runne to the cr√©eke of En≈øeada da Cauchinchina, vntill the la≈øt of December, and from Ianuary forward, then the ≈øtreams (in that Gulfe and countrey) runne towards the Sands that lie ouer again≈øt the coa≈øt of Champa, in Camboia) from the other ≈øide, and the later it is in the yeare from the Month of Ianuary forward, the ≈øtronger they run towards the ≈øands.

In the Mon≈øon of China, when you ≈øaile from China to Mallacca, then the ≈øtreams run very ≈øtrong from the I≈øland Pulo Catao, to ye I≈øland Puto Cambir, both lying on the coa≈øt of Camboia or Champa.

It happeneth oftentimes, that from the eight and twenty of Iuly to the fourth of Augu≈øt from the Varella to Pulo Catao you haue calme ≈øea, and then you haue the Terreinhos, which are Windes blowing from the land, out of the We≈øt and northwe≈øt, and the Viracoins, which are winds that come from the Sea, out of the Ea≈øt, Southea≈øt, and ea≈øt Northea≈øt, & being in the North, they pre≈øently change into the ≈øouth, whervpon it becommeth calme till the Terreinhos or land winds doe come again, and thus they hold about two miles from the coa≈øt, and not further, for they are winds that do only blow vpon ye coa≈øt, as in other places it is already ≈øufficiently declared, in ≈øpeaking of the Terreinhos and Viracoins.
When you ≈øaile by the I≈øland of Lequeo Pequeno, or ≈ømall Lequeo, towards the land of Bungo, in the I≈øland of Iapon the ≈øtreames in that country do run ea≈øtward to the I≈øland of Tanaxuma.

From 30 degr√©es Northward, a little further theÃÑ to the middle way to Iapon, the ≈øtreames (from that country to the coa≈øt of China) run northward towards the cr√©eke A En≈øeada de Nanguyn, in the mon≈øon of the ≈øouth and ≈øouthwe≈øt winds.
In this mon≈øon of South and Southwe≈øt winds, the ≈øtreams from the I≈øland Pulo Tayo (lying by the I≈øland Aynao in the coa≈øt of China) run Southwe≈øtward to the I≈ølands of Sanchoan and Cantao.

div.head: The 46. Chapter. Of the tides both for ebbe and flood by the daies and houres of the Moone, in the haueÃÑ of Macau in China, with the height of the ≈øame Hauen, found by experience of an expert Pilot.
div.p: THe 19. of September I marked the cour≈øe of the Tides of China, within the hauen of Macau, it being Full Moone, and I found it to be full ≈øea about halfe an houre and ≈øomewhat more after eight of the clocke in the morning, which I tryed at the Full moone to ≈ø√©e if it would agr√©e with the New Moone.

1585.The 3. of Februarie An. 1585. I tooke the height of the Sunne, which as then was about 13. degr√©es from the line, and I found that the Hauen of Macau lieth full vndec 22. degr√©es, & 1/ ‚Ä¢ . and as then I likewi≈øe tried the tides of the ≈øame hauen and found it to be full Sea a little after 12. of the clock, the moone being thr√©e daies old, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that by the ≈øame account with a new Moone it is full ≈øea in that hauen at ten a clocke and 2/ ‚Ä¢ . in the morning, which I al≈øo tried by the new Moone.

1585.The 16. of Februarie Anno 1585. I marked the Tides within the Hauen of Macau, it being then full moone, and found the fir≈øt day of the full moone that it was high water at eleuen of the clocke and a halfe before noone.

1585.The 2. of Iune Ann. 1585. I marked the tides in the Hauen of Macau, & found it to be full Sea iu≈øt at 12. of the clocke at no ‚Ä¢ ne, the moone being foure dayes old, ≈øo that after the ≈øame account it is full ≈øea at nine of the clocke in the morning, b√©eing new moone: but the≈øe Tides of China fall not out iu≈øtly, vnle≈ø≈øe it be foure daies before and fiue daies after the changing of the Moone, for then there is as much water as vpon the third day, which I affirme to be mo≈øt true, becau≈øe I haue often and many times tryed it to be ≈øo. The cau≈øe is, for that before it, it is all I≈ølands and Channels, ≈øo that when the waters beginne to fall, they ebbe not aboue thr√©e houres, but with an Ea≈øt wind they ebbe with a greater cour≈øe.

div.head: The 47. Chapter. Of the ≈øignes and tokens of the tides, waters, and windes vpon the coa≈øt of China and in the way to Iapon.
div.p: IN the time of the mon≈øon of the South and Southwe≈øt windes, it is mo≈øt certaine in the whole coa≈øt of China and the way to Iapon, that when the winds of the mon≈øon blow, and from thence run into the Ea≈øt, that they turne not againe out of the Ea≈øt into the ≈øouth, but from thence into the North: and hauing continued there for a certaine time, they turne againe into the ea≈øt, and from thence into the South, & if it be a Northea≈øt wind, then it turneth often times into the Southwe≈øt, and not into the Ea≈øt, but not often, but the ≈øure≈øt is as afore≈øaid. It changeth al≈øo often times from North to South, and not into the Ea≈øt, which is very common, and when the Sunne ≈øetteth and hath ≈øome red carnation cloudes about it, and that many beames i≈ø≈øueth from the Sunne, in ≈øuch manner, that it ≈ø√©emeth to blaze, then it is a ≈øigne of great ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts. Likewi≈øe in the ri≈øing and going downe of the Moone, if it ≈øheweth in the like maner, it is a ≈øigne of ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts.

When the Sunne ri≈øeth ≈øo faire and cl√©ere, that you may in a manner ≈ø√©e into it, and perfectly di≈øcerne the compa≈ø≈øe thereof, then it ≈øignifieth good weather, The like doth it ≈øignifie in the ≈øetting of the Sunne: and when the Sunne in the ri≈øing or ≈øetting is red and of a dead couler, and ≈øo darke that you may ≈ø√©e it round about, not ca≈øting forth any beames, it ≈øignifieth calme weather: The like doth the Moone.

In the time of the mon≈øon when the Northea≈øt winds doe commonly blowe, and that the clouds at the Sun-≈øetting b√©e red, then it ≈øignifieth North winds, when in diuers places of the ≈øea you ≈ø√©e ≈økumme driuing vpon the water as white as Cotton, being about a finger long, then it ≈øignifieth tempe≈øts and foule weather: This ≈økum proc√©edeth of the ≈ømall waues that breake, wherof there are many in ye place.

In the moneth of Iuly there bloweth other winds in tho≈øe places then the mon≈øon running from one place to the other, till in the end they be northea≈øt, then it is certain it will be tempe≈øt & foule weather.
If from the I≈øland of Lamao to the Cape of Sumbor, in the man≈øon of the South and Southwe≈øt winds, you find an Ea≈øt winde with great heate, and ≈øame great droppes of water, it ≈øignifieth foule weather.

div.head: The 48. Chapter. In what dayes and moneths you find tempe≈øts and foule weather in the coa≈øt of China.
div.p: FRom the ≈øeuenth to the eleuenth of Iune, often and commonly vpon the coa≈øt of China there are great teÃÑpe≈øts. From the beginning of Iuly to the 26. of the ≈øame moneth, you are neuer fr√©e nor out of danger of tempe≈øts and foule weather, for that all that time you haue foule ≈øtormie weather, the wind neuer ≈øtaying in one place, but running round about the compa≈ø≈øe. From the 12. of Augu≈øt forward, in the whole Moone of September to the end of October, all that time there is continually foule weather.

div.head: The 49. Chapter. Of the times of faire weather vpon the coa≈øt of China.
div.p: THe whole moneth of Iune (except it be from the ≈øeuenth to the eleuenth day) there is very litle ≈øoule weather, for that vnle≈ø≈øe it be vpon the daies afore≈øaid, you haue the windes of the mon≈øon, with faire and cl√©ere weather without ≈øtormes, to ≈øaile from the I≈øland Pulo Cantao to the I≈ølandes Cantao and Macau without ≈øtormes: you mu≈øt ≈øet ≈øaile on the 26. of Iuly, and ≈øaile till the 12. of Augu≈øt, and all that time you are without tempe≈øts. In the middle way from the I≈øland of Iapon to the coa≈øt and land of Liampo, you haue alwaies We≈øt windes, which blowe in Iapon in the moneths of Nouember and December.

div.head: The 50. Chapter. A briefe de≈øcription of the cour≈øe from Macau in China, to Noua Spaigna, with the ≈øcituations of the countries.
div.p:
PVtting out of the Ea≈øt channell of the Hauen of Macau, then you mu≈øt hold inward to ≈øea as much as you may, and hauing a contrarie winde, runne as long as the wind giues you leaue to k√©ep that cour≈øe, but if the winde be ≈øcant, whereby you may not holde your cour≈øe Northea≈øt, or Northea≈øt and by North, then turne on the other ≈øide as long as the wind ≈øerueth, that you may run Southea≈øt for the ≈øpace of thr√©e or foure daies, for it is better to k√©epe Southea≈øt then to run Northward. This cour≈øe you ≈øhall holde as the winde ≈øerueth you, vntill you think you are 300. miles from the land; and being there, you mu≈øt run 200. or more miles beyond Iapon, and although you holde your cour≈øe North, yet you n√©ed not feare any thing, k√©eping good account of the wracking or winding of your compa≈ø≈øe towardes the We≈øt, for it might hinder you much, running as often as you can Southea≈øt, or to Loofeward, as al≈øo not leauing ye cour≈øe of Northea≈øt, as often as you can, vntill you be vnder the height. In the gulfe you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e certaine great blacke birds, which, is a ≈øigne that you are farre to Seaward, and if you ≈ø√©e them about euening, & that they ≈øtretch their legs out along by their tailes, then looke to your ≈øelfe, for it ≈øignifieth foule weather: When you come within 200. miles or more of the other land, then you ≈øhall loo≈øe the ≈øight of tho≈øe birdes, and if the wind and weather driue you vnder many heights, and that you ≈ø√©e many heapes of w√©eds driuing vpon the water, which are commonly ≈ø√©ene when you are 100. and 120. myles inwarde to ≈øea, then you mu≈øt runne on the out≈øide of Iapon Southea≈øtward, till you be vnder 31. and 32. degr√©es, and as then knowing the land, which will lie hard by: wheÃÑ you ≈øee it fir≈øt, you mu≈øt runne without it, and beware you run not vpon the I≈øland called Ilha de Sedros, that is, the I≈øland of Cedar tr√©es, and make no account by the cour≈øe of the Sea or compa≈ø≈øe, for the I≈øland of Cedars lyeth by the Cape of S. Lucas, b√©eing verie fal≈øe in the cour≈øe, becau≈øe the land (if it lay by it) doth come more and likelier out, then it doth towardes the South. The Cape of Saint Lucas, is a high land, and ≈øheweth (when you are hard by it) as if it had ≈øtonie cliffes ≈øticking out of it, the end thereof b√©eing verie blacke ≈øhining and darke, the Land thereof pre≈øently running inwards towards the North, and if you n√©ed fre≈øh water, within the cliffes of the ≈øaid Cape of S. Lucas, there is a great ≈øandie ≈øtrande, where you haue a verie good Rode to anker,
where clo≈øe by the ≈øea you find great ≈øtore of fre≈øh water. From thence you ≈øhall cro≈ø≈øe ouer to the other ≈øide, vpon the Southea≈øt bough, without the Marias, which is a better cour≈øe then inward: all the coa≈øt is faire and good, ≈øo that you may well runne along by it, vntill you come to certaine cliffes lying by the Hauen called El Puerto de la Natiuidad, where within the cr√©eke you pre≈øently finde the Hauen of Saint Iago de Colima, the marks wherof are tho≈øe: On the Ea≈øt ≈øide it hath a round houell that de≈øcendeth downward, if you be forced to put into it, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that it hath a great mouth or entrie aboue two or thr√©e miles wide, wherin you haue no cau≈øe to feare any thing, but that you ≈ø√©e before your eies: you mu≈øt runne into it till you be cleane within the point, where you haue a riuer of fre≈øh water that runneth into the Sea, where you ≈øhall find Spani≈øh Fi≈øhermen: if you de≈øire to ≈øaile further, you mu≈øt froÃÑ thence to the hauen of Acapulco run for the ≈øpace of 80. miles along by the ≈øhore, for it is verie faire and cleare till you be at the end of the high land, that is, to the Hauen called El Puerto del Marques, which a farre off ≈øheweth like an I≈øland, but when you goe ≈øo n√©ere it that you may well di≈øcerne it to be firme land, then on the vpper part thereof you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e ≈øome white ≈øtones, which ≈øhewe like white Runderen, that goe in the way, you may fr√©ely runne towardes it, till you begin to ≈ø√©e the mouth therof, and then put into it. This in briefe in my opinion, is the be≈øt cour≈øe that you may bold in this voiage, which I would likewi≈øe haue holden if I had gone thorough with the voiage.

div.head: The 51. Chapter. A true de≈øcription of the cour≈øe from the I≈ølands of Los Lucones, or to the Hauen of Acapulco in new Spaine, and how you ≈øhould ≈øaile thither from Macau in China, with a note of the commodities and profits made by the wares and merchandi≈øes of China, with the ≈øcituation, cour≈øe, times, and miles of the ≈øame countries: all particularly ≈øet downe for ≈øuch as de≈øire to trauell into tho≈øe countries.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall put out of the Hauen of Manilla lying in the I≈øland of Lucones, vnder 14. degr√©es & ¬Ω. on the North ≈øide of the Equinoctial line, the mouth being Southwe≈øt, in the moneths of Iune and Iuly, as wind & weather ≈øerueth to put out, running along the coa≈øt of the ≈øame I≈øland and betw√©ene the I≈øland of Mindoro, or by the Ea≈øt point, vntill you be out of the Channell (where you enter when you come out of the ≈øea, lying 100. miles from Manilla vnder 13. degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ .) betw√©ene the la≈øt and the furthe≈øt point of the ≈øame I≈øland of Lucones and the point of another I≈øland called Tandaya, betw√©ene the which the afore≈øaid channell doth runne: and when you are out of the Channell, you mu≈øt runne Ea≈øtward as long as the winde ≈øerueth: which cour≈øe you ≈øhall alwaies hold, vnle≈ø≈øe the wind let you, becau≈øe you depart vnder 13. degr√©es and ‚Öì. ≈øailing to the hauen of Acapulco, lying vnder 17. degr√©es, but becau≈øe the winde in tho≈øe countries in Summer (which is the time that men ≈øet ≈øaile as afore≈øaid) is very ≈ølacke, although it be the mon≈øon, in ≈øuch manner, that when it beginneth to ri≈øe, you may not hold your cour≈øe Ea≈øtward, & as long as the winde is not Southea≈øt, you mu≈øt ≈øtill runne Northea≈øt as long as you can, but when it is Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, and Ea≈øt, then you mu≈øt wind Southward, till the wind ≈øerueth to runne Northea≈øt: in this manner you ≈øaile 1700. miles, to the coa≈øt of the countrey of Noua Spaigna, ≈øtill k√©eping to ≈øeaward from the I≈øland of Iapon as much as po≈ø≈øibly you can, becau≈øe that certaine ≈øhippes that went late to Saile (pa≈ø≈øing clo≈øe by Iapon) had ≈øtormie weather, and ≈øaw the I≈øland called A Ilha do Fogo, that is, the fiery I≈øland, one of them putting into the Hauen of Xaxuma in the I≈øland of Iapon, there to ≈øane it ≈øelfe, as it did: therefore ≈øuch as k√©epe 100. miles to Seaward from it, holde a good cour≈øe, for that running farre to Loofeward from tho≈øe I≈ølandes, you fall vpon the coa≈øt of new Spaine vnder ≈ømall heights, but wheÃÑ you fall on the coa≈øt vnder 35. degr√©es, there you hold a good cour≈øe, but when you come to it vnder 38. and 40. degr√©es, which is the furthe≈øt lande that is di≈øcouered or knowne (called El Cabo de Mendo≈øino) you ≈øhall haue great labour and paine, becau≈øe that there you begin to haue high and hollowe waues, by rea≈øon winter is at hand, as al≈øo becau≈øe the ≈øhippes comming from the I≈øland of Lucones, are but ea≈øily prouided of their nece≈ø≈øaries.

When you ≈ø√©e the coa≈øt and lande of Noua Spaigna, then you beginne to haue Northwe≈øt winds, which from thence is
a right fore winde, becau≈øe you runne almo≈øt all along that coa≈øt, although in ≈øome places you k√©epe ≈øomewhat further off, becau≈øe of the cr√©ekes that are therein, you runne along by the coa≈øt, which is all faire and cl√©ere till you come to the Hauen of Acapulco, which is ≈øixe or ≈øeuen hundred miles.

And if you de≈øire to ≈øaile thither from Macau in China, you mu≈øt be ready to ≈øet ≈øaile as ≈øoone as the winde is Southwe≈øt, to put out with the coniunction of the Moone in the moneths of Iune and Iuly, holding your cour≈øe towards the furthe≈øt point or hooke of the I≈øland of Lucones, lying vnder 20. degr√©es, called Cabo de Bo
‚Ä¢ ador, which is nintie miles from the Hauen of Macau.

From the I≈ølands called Ilhas dos Baboranes (lying by the coa≈øt of the ≈øame land and Cape de Boiadar) to the I≈øland of Ca ‚Ä¢ agon, that is, (the I≈øland of the Kettle) you runne Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and when you are pa≈øt tho≈øe I≈ølands, running betw√©ene them, then you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe as you did from the Hauen of Manilla as afore≈øaide, alwaies keeping it as much as wind and weather will permit, which is the way the Spaniards doe now meane to ≈øaile, running to the I≈ølands of Maluco, and from thence cro≈ø≈øe ouer to Noua Spaigna, which is the ≈øame cour≈øe that Franci≈øcus Gualle (Captaine and Pilot of the ≈øhippe that came out of Noua Spaigna into the Hauen of Macau) helde: from whence hee departed againe the 25. of Iuly with a Southwe≈øt wind, in the time and coniunction of a full moone, with whome at the ≈øame time departed the ≈øhippe of Ayres Gon≈øalu ‚Ä¢ s de Miranda, which captaine Gualle is ≈øaid not to haue beene longer in his voiage then thr√©e moneths and a halfe to the coa≈øt, and from thence a moneth and a halfe more to the Hauen of Acapulco, and another ≈øhippe that the ≈øame y√©ere ≈øet ≈øaile from Manilla, was betweene eight and nine moneths at ≈øea, and in the end arriued in the Hauen of Acapulco, all then being almo≈øt dead a ‚Ä¢ the ≈øhips in manner ≈øpoiled, and another ≈øhippe was but fiue moneths on the way, but the ordinary voiage is about ≈øixe moneths, little more or le≈ø≈øe. The rea≈øon why it is better ≈øailing from Macau then from Manilla, is, becau≈øe there you haue no hinderances nor lets, but you may pre≈øently hold on your cour≈øe as you are for the ≈øpace of 10 ‚Ä¢ . miles froÃÑ Manilla along through the chanell, till you be out, wherby ≈øome ≈øhippes haue con≈øumed ≈øo much time, that it was the cau≈øe that ≈øome of them were coÃÑ≈øtrained to put back againe, and could not performe their voiage: but being in the mouth or i≈ø≈øue of the channell afore≈øaid, then it is a better voiage then from Macau, becau≈øe it lieth 150. miles further to Loofewarde, if it had not the other hindrance of comming out, as I ≈øaid before.

When the ≈øhips ≈øaile from Noua Spaigna to Manilla or Macau, then they ≈øet ≈øaile in Lent, alwaies ≈øailing with a forewind, with the windes called Bri≈øas, which are Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt Northea≈øt winds, which doe blowe there with the mon≈øon of the time, and it chanceth often times that many of them ≈øaile 50. or 6 ‚Ä¢ . daies togither without ≈øtriking any of the ≈øailes, ≈øtill hauing a full wind, neuer ≈øeeing any land nor till this day euer any ≈øhip was ca≈øt away in tho≈øe countries.

The ≈øhippe wherewith you will make this voiage mu≈øt be very good to ≈øaile in a wind, as al≈øo very well prouided of all nece≈ø≈øaries, ≈øpecially a Spani≈øh Pilot and 12. Saylors, (becau≈øe that through all the coa≈øts of the Orientall Indies, they v≈øe Indian Saylors, as Arabians and ≈øuch like, that are not v≈øed nor can not ≈økill of other voiages, and would be verie farre to ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ if they ≈øhould be led a new cour≈øe) among the which it were good to haue ≈øome Spaniards (≈øuch as haue ≈øailed that way) to know the land, which you ≈øhall alwa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ find at Macau, if you find them no ‚Ä¢ in
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
dia. For other nece≈ø≈øaries concerning to ≈øhippe, you ≈øhall finde of all things ≈øufficient in China.

The gaines and profits of all ≈øortes of wares of China are verie great, except rawe ≈øilke, whereby they haue verie little gaine, for there they rather de≈øire it readie ≈øpunne: and although there ≈øhould bee much ≈øolde there, yet that were no rea≈øon or cau≈øe why they ≈øhould carrie much thither, becau≈øe it ≈øhould not hinder the voiage and trafficke of them of Iapon into the Ea≈øt Indies, for there are many other kindes of wares great ≈øtore to carrie thither, wherein there is much more profit then in ≈øilke.

Of the common wares and merchandi≈øes that the Spaniards in the I≈ølands of Lucones or Phillippinas doe buy, (and yet they buy them much d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er there then they ≈øhould buy them in China) in newe
Spaine, they gaine but ≈øixe for one, and in Peru ten for one, whereof they are ≈øure, for that the Portingales that haue gone from hence thither, in the ≈øhip that came hither haue gained ≈øo much by the wares they carried with them, that the time that they ≈øtayed for their returne, ≈ø√©emed to them a thou≈øand y√©eres: and as they repo ‚Ä¢ t, the Viceroy of Noua Spaigna and all the other gouernours and gentlemen of the countrie, haue a great de≈øire to v≈øe the trade, and doe much looke after it.

Many are of opinion, that to ≈øaile that way to Peru, it would be a longer voiage, for that when you are at Acapulco, you mu≈øt take another way and hold another cour≈øe of 700. miles long, from Acapulco to the Hauen of Callande Lyma, which is the Metropolitane Cittie of Peru, lying vnder ten degr√©es on the South ≈øide of the Equinoctiall, and you ≈øhould make your voiage in the ≈øame yeere: and further it is a countrey of great charges and expences, whereby you ≈øhould loo≈øe and ≈øpend all that you ≈øhould gaine, more in that countrey then in new Spaine, becau≈øe the countrey of newe Spaine is more aboundant in all kinde of nece≈ø≈øaries & victuals then Peru, and therefore your charges is le≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The 52. Chapter. The true and perfect de≈øcription of a voiage performed and done by Franci≈øcus de Gualle a Spani≈øh Captaine and Pilot, for the Viceroy of new Spaine, from the Hauen of Acapulco in new Spaine, to the I≈ølands of Iu ‚Ä¢ ones or Phillippinas, in the Hauen of Manilla, and from thence to the Hauen of Macau in China, and from Macau backe againe to Acapulco, accompli≈øhed in the yeere of our Lorde 1584.
div.p: THe tenth of March in the y√©ere of our Lord 1582. w√©e ≈øet ≈øaile out of the Hauen of Acapulco, lying in the country of new Spaine, directing our cour≈øe to the I≈ølands of Lucones or Philippinas We≈øt Southwe≈øt,1582. running in that manner for the ≈øpace of 25. miles, till wee came vnder 16. degrees, that ≈øo w√©e might ≈øhun the calmes by ≈øailing clo≈øe by the ≈øhore. From thence forward we held our cour≈øe We≈øt for the ≈øpace of 30. miles, and being there, we ranne We≈øt, & We≈øt and by South, for the ≈øpace of 1800. miles, to the I≈øland called Ilha d'Engano, which is the furthe≈øt I≈øland lying in the South partes of the I≈ølands called de los Ladrones, that is, the I≈ølands of Rouers, or I≈ølas de las Vellas, vnder 13. degr√©es and ¬Ω. in latitude Septentrional, and 164. degr√©es in longitude Oriental, vpon the fixed Meridional line, which lieth right with the I≈øland of Tercera. From thence w√©e held our cour≈øe we≈øtward for the ≈øpace of 280. miles, till we came to the point called El capo de E≈øpirito Santo, that is, the point of the Holy Gho≈øt, lying in the I≈øland Tandaya, the fir≈øt I≈ølaÃÑd of tho≈øe that are called Philippinas, Lucones, or Manillas, which is a cuntry with few hils, with ≈øome mines of brim≈øtone in the middle thereof. From the point afore≈øaid we ≈øailed We≈øt for the ≈øpace of eighteene miles to the point or entrie of the channell, which runneth in betw√©ene that I≈øland and the I≈øland of Lucon. This point or entrie lieth ≈øcar≈øe vnder 12. degr√©es. All the coa≈øt that ≈øtretcheth from the entry of the chanell to the point El capo del Spirito Santo, is not very faire.

Eight miles from the ≈øaid point lyeth a Hauen of indifferent greatnes, called Bahya de Louos, that is, the Baye of Wolues, hauing a ≈ømall I≈øland in the mouth thereof: and within the Channell about halfe a mile from the end of the ≈øaid I≈øland, lyeth an I≈øland or Cliffe, & when you pa≈ø≈øe by the point in the middle of the channell, then you haue 25. fadome d√©epe, with browne Sand: there we found ≈øo great a ≈øtreame running we≈øtward, that it made the water ca≈øt a ≈økum as if it had b√©ene a ≈øand, whereby it put vs in feare, but ca≈øting out our Lead, we found 25. fadome d√©epe.

From the afore≈øaid entrie of the channell North, and North and by Ea≈øt, about ten miles, lyeth the I≈øland of Catanduanes, about a mile di≈øtant from the land of Lucon, on the furthe≈øt point Ea≈øtward, and from the ≈øame entrie of the channell towards the We≈øt and Southwe≈øt, lyeth the I≈øland Capuli about ≈øixe miles from thence, ≈øtretching We≈øt Southwe≈øt, and Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, beeing fiue miles long and foure miles broad, and as w√©e pa≈øt by it, it lay Northward from vs, vnder 12. degr√©es and ¬º. and ≈øomewhat high lande. Foure miles from the afore≈øaid I≈øland of Capuli Northwe≈øtward, lyeth the thr√©e
I≈ølands of the Hauen of Bollon in the I≈øland of Lucones, ≈øtretching North and South about foure miles, di≈øtant from the firme land about halfe a mile, whereof the furthe≈øt Southward, lyeth vnder 13. degr√©es: In this channell it is twentie fadome deepe, with white Sand, and a great ≈øtreame, running Southea≈øt, wee pa≈ø≈øed through the middle of the channell. From this Channell w√©e held our cour≈øe Southwe≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by We≈øt, for the ≈øpace of twentie miles, vntill wee came to the We≈øt end of the I≈øland of Tycao, which reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt 13. miles. This point or hooke lieth vnder 12. degrees and 3/ ‚Ä¢ . In the middle betweene this I≈øland and the I≈øland Capuli there lyeth three I≈ølands called the Faranias, and we ranne in the ≈øame cour≈øe on the North ≈øide of all the I≈ølands, at the depth of 22. fadome with white ≈øand.

From the afore≈øaid We≈øt point of the I≈øland Tycao to the point of Barya ‚Ä¢ , it is Ea≈øt and We≈øt to ≈øaile about the length of a mile, or a mile and a halfe, we put into that channell, helding our cour≈øe ≈øouth and ≈øouth and by we≈øt about three miles, vntill we were out of the channell at ≈øixteene fadome deepe, with halfe white and re ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øh ≈øande in the Channell, and at the month thereof, whereof the middle lyeth vnder 12. degrees and ‚Ä¢ . and there the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ reames runne Northward.

The I≈øland of Bayas ≈øtretcheth northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt, and is lowe land, whereof the Northwe≈øt point is about three mi ‚Ä¢ es from the coa≈øt of Lucon, but you can not pa≈ø≈øe between them with any P ‚Ä¢ ppe but with ≈ømall Foi≈øts and Barks of the countrey. This ≈øhal ‚Ä¢ ow Channell lieth vnder 12. degrees, and running thorough the afore≈øaid channell between the I≈ølands Tycao and Bu ‚Ä¢ yas, as I ≈øaid before, we ≈øailed Southward about 2. miles from the I≈øland of Masbate, which ≈øtretcheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt eight miles long, being in breadth foure miles, and lieth vnder 12. degrees and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . in the middle thereof, and is ≈øomewhat high land.

From the ≈øaid channell betw√©ene Tycao and Buryas, we held our cour≈øe We≈øt Northwe≈øt for thirteene miles, leauing the I≈øland Masbate on the South ≈øide, and the I≈øland Buryas on the North ≈øide, at the end of thirteene miles we came by an I≈øland called Banton, which is in forme like a Hat, vnder 12. degrees and ‚Öî. when we had ≈øailed the afore≈øaid thirt√©ene miles and eight miles more, on the South ≈øide we left the I≈øland called Rebuian, which ≈øtretcheth Northwe≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by North, and Southea≈øt, and Southea≈øt and by South, for the ≈øpace of eight miles, b√©eing high and crooked Lande, whereof the North point lieth vnder 12. degrees and ‚Ä¢ . and there you finde 35. fadome deepe, with white ≈øand.

From the afore≈øaide I≈øland of Banton Southward nine miles, there beginneth and followeth three I≈ølandes, one called Banton≈øilla, which is a ≈ømall I≈øland in forme of a Sugar loofe: the ≈øecond Crymara, beeing ≈øomewhat great in length, reaching Ea≈øt and We≈øt about 2. miles: the third I ‚Ä¢ aa, or the I≈øle of Goates, hauing certaine Houels. By all the≈øe I≈ølandes afore≈øaide you may pa≈ø≈øe with all ≈øortes of Shippes, whereof the foremo≈øt lyeth Southward vnder 12. degrees and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . from the I≈øland Banton≈øilla, or ≈ømall Banto ‚Ä¢ , we helde our cour≈øe Northwe≈øt, for the ≈øpace of foure miles, to the Channell betweene the I≈ølands called de Vere ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ , and the I≈øland Marinduque, the Vere ‚Ä¢ es lying on the South ≈øide vnder 12. degr√©es and ¬º. (which are two ≈ømall I≈ølands like two Frig ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ te ‚Ä¢
) and the I≈øland Marinduque on the North ≈øide vnder 12. degrees and ‚Ä¢ . which is a great I≈øland, ≈øtretching We≈øt Northwe≈øt, and Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, hauing in length twelue, and in breadth ≈øeuen miles. On the North ≈øide with the I≈ølande Lucon it maketh a long and ≈ømall channell, running ≈øomewhat crooked, which is altogither full of ≈øhallowes and ≈øandes, whe ‚Ä¢ y no ≈øhips can pa≈ø≈øe through it. The ‚Ä¢ urth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ point We≈ø ‚Ä¢ ward of the ≈øame I≈øland, lyeth vnder 1 ‚Ä¢ . degrees and ¬º it is high lande, on the Ea≈øt ≈øide hauing the forme of a mi ‚Ä¢ e of brim≈øtone or fiery hill, and on the we≈øt ≈øide the land runneth downeward, at the point thereof being round like a loafe of bread: in the Channell betweene it and the Vere ‚Ä¢ es, there are eighteene fadome deepe, with ≈ømall blacke ≈øand.

From the afore≈øaide Channell of Vere ‚Ä¢ es and Marinduque, we held our cour≈øe We≈øt Northwe≈øt twelue miles, to the lande of Mindoro to the point or Hooke called Dumaryn, lying full vnder thirteene degrees: fiue miles forwarde from the ≈øaid Channell, on the South ≈øide wee left an I≈øland called Ilha del Mae≈øtro del
Campo, that is, the I≈øland of the Coronell, lying vnder twelue degr√©es and ¬º. which is a ≈ømall and flat I≈øland: In this cour≈øe wee had 45. fadome d√©epe, with white ≈øand.

By this point or end of the I≈øland Marinduque, beginneth the I≈øland of Myndoro, which hath in length Ea≈øt and we≈øt fiue and twentie miles, and in breadth twelue miles, whether of the furthe≈øt point Southward lieth vnder thirt√©en degr√©es, and the furthe≈øt point Northwarde vnder thirt√©ene degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . and the furthe≈øt point We≈øtwarde vnder thirt√©ene degrees. This I≈øland with the I≈øland of Lucon maketh a Channell of fiue miles broad, and ten or twelue fadome d√©epe with muddie ground of diuers coulers, with white ≈øande. Fiue miles forward from Marinduque, lieth the riuer of the towne of Anagacu, which is ≈øo ≈øhallowe, that no ≈øhippes may enter into it. From thence 2. miles further, lieth the I≈ølands called Bacco, which are thr√©e I≈ølands lying in triangle, two of them being di≈øtant from the land about thr√©e hundred cubits, and betw√©ene them and the land you may pa≈ø≈øe with ≈ømall ≈øhippes: and from the lande to the other I≈øland are about two hundred cubites, where it is altogither ≈øhallowes and ≈øandes, ≈øo that where the ≈øhippes may pa≈ø≈øe outward about 150. cubits from the land, you leaue both the I≈ølands on the ≈øouth ≈øide, running betw√©en the third I≈øland and the riuer called Rio del Bacco, ≈øomewhat more from the middle of the Channell towards the I≈øland, which is about a mile di≈øtant from the other: the Channell is ten fadome d√©epe, with ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ood and ≈øhelles vpon the ground: the riuer of Bacco is ≈øo ≈øhallowe, that no ≈øhippes may enter into it. From this I≈øland with the ≈øame cour≈øe two miles forward, you pa≈ø≈øe by the point called El capo de Re≈øca≈øeo, where wee ca≈øt out our Lead, and found that a man may pa≈ø≈øe clo≈øe by the land, and there you ≈øhall find great ≈øtrong ≈øtreames: and halfe a mile forward with the ≈øame cour≈øe, lyeth the towne of Myndoro, which hath a good hauen for ≈øhippes of three hundred tunnes. Three miles Northward from the ≈øame Hauen, lyeth the I≈øland called Cafaa, ≈øtretching Ea≈øt and We≈øt, b√©eing Hill ground.

From the ≈øaid towne of Myndoro, w√©e helde our cour≈øe We≈øt Northwe≈øt eight myles, till w√©e came to the point or hooke of the Sandes called Tulen, lying vpon the I≈øland of Lucon, which Sande or Banke reacheth into the ≈øea halfe a mile from the coa≈øt: you mu≈øt k√©epe about an hundred cubites from it, where you finde eight fadome water, muddie and ≈øhelly ground: you runne along by tho≈øe ≈øands North, and North and by We≈øt for the ≈øpace of two myles, till you come to the riuer called Rio de Ana≈øebo, all the re≈øt of the coa≈øt called De los Limbones to the mouth or entrie of the Baye called Manilla, (which are foure miles) is ≈øayled with the ≈øame cour≈øe. The Limbones (which are I≈ølands ≈øo called) are high, in forme like a paire of Organs, with good Hauens for ≈ømall ≈øhippes, running along by the Limbones: and two miles beyond them on the South ≈øide, wee leaue the I≈ølands of Fortan, and foure I≈ølands more, but the thr√©e I≈ølandes of Lubao, which are verie lowe lying vnder thirteene & 13. degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . and the Limbones lie in the mouth or entrie of the Baye of Manilla vnder 14. degr√©es and ¬º.

From thence w√©e ranne Northwe≈øt for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe miles to the Hauen of Cabite, k√©eping along by the land lying on the We≈øt ≈øide, where it is ≈øhallowe, and is called Los Baixos del Rio de Cannas, the ≈øhallowes of the riuer of R√©edes; all along this Baye in the ≈øame cour≈øe, there is from ten to foure fadome deepe.

Beeing by the point or Hooke of Cabite, then wee kept but an hundred paces from it, running Southwe≈øt, South Southwe≈øt, & South, vntill wee di≈øcouered the whole mouth or entrie of the bay, where w√©e might anker at foure fadome about two hundred cubits from the ‚Ä¢ and, and then the towne of Manilla was two miles Northward from vs.

div.head: The 53. Chapter. The cour≈øe and voiage of the afore≈øaid Franci≈øcus Gualle out of the Hauen or Roade of Manilla, to the Hauen of Macau in China, with all the cour≈øes and ≈øcituations of the places.
div.p:
SAyling out of the Hauen of Cubite, lying in the Bay of Manilla, w√©e helde our cour≈øe We≈øtward for the ≈øpace of eight√©ene myles, to
the point called El Cabo de Samballes, and when w√©e were eight miles on our way, w√©e left the two I≈ølandes Maribillas on the South ≈øide, and ≈øailed about a mile from them: the point of Samballes afore≈øaid, lyeth vnder fourt√©ene degr√©es, and ‚Öî. being low lande: at the end of the ≈øame coa≈øt of Lucon, on the We≈øt ≈øide.

FroÃÑ the hooke or point afore≈øaid, we ran North, and North and by We≈øt, for the ≈øpace of fiue and thirtie miles (about a mile from the coa≈øt of Lucon) to the point called Cabo de Bullinao, all this coa≈øt and Cape is high and Hill ground, which Cape lyeth vnder ≈øixt√©ene degr√©es and ‚Öî. From this Cape de Bullinao, w√©e helde our cour≈øe North, and North and by ea≈øt, for fiue and fortie miles to the point called El cabo de Boiador, which is the furthe≈øt lande Northward from the I≈øland Lucon lying vnder 19. degr√©es.

The Cape de Bullinao b√©eing pa≈øt the land, maketh a great Cr√©eke or Bough, and from this Cr√©eke the coa≈øts runneth North to the point of Boiador, b√©eing a land full of Cliffes and Rockes that reach into the Sea, and the land of the hooke or point is high and hilly ground.

From the point of Boiador, we helde our cour≈øe We≈øt Northwe≈øt an hundred and twentie miles, vntill w√©e came to the I≈øland called O Ilha Branco, or the white I≈øland, which is a ≈ømall I≈øland, lying in the beginning of the coa≈øt and Baye of the riuer of Canton vnder two and twentie degrees, hauing foure and twentie fadome browne muddie ground.

From the ≈øame I≈øland Ilha Branco, wee helde the afore≈øaide cour≈øe of We≈øt Northwe≈øt, for the ≈øpace of ≈øixt√©ene miles, to the I≈øland of Macau lying in the mouth of the riuer of Canton, and maketh the riuer two mouths or entries, and is a ≈ømall I≈øland about three miles great.

div.head: The 54. Chapter. The Nauigation or cour≈øe of the afore≈øaid Franci≈øco Gualle out of the Hauen of Macau to new Spaine, with the ≈øcituation and ≈øtretchings of the ≈øame, with other notable and memorable things concerning the ≈øame voiage.
div.p: WHen we had prepared our ≈øelues and taken our leaues of our friends in Macau, we ≈øet ≈øaile vpon the foure and twentie of Iuly, holding our cour≈øe Southea≈øt, and Southea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, beeing in the wane of the Moone, for when the moone increa≈øeth it is hard holding the cour≈øe betw√©ene the I≈ølands, becau≈øe as then the water and ≈øtreames runne verie ≈øtrong to the Northwe≈øt, w√©e ≈øayled through many narrow Channels by night, hauing the depth of eight and ten fadome, with ≈øoft muddie ground, vntill we were about the I≈øland Ilha Branco, yet we ≈øawe it not, but by the height we knew we were pa≈øt it.

Being beyond it, we ran Ea≈øt ≈øouthea≈øt, an hundred and fiftie miles, to get aboue the ≈øands called Os Baixos dos Pe≈øcadores, and the beginning of the I≈ølands Lequeos on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, which I≈ølandes are called As Ilhas Fermo≈øas, that is, the faire I≈ølandes. This I vnder≈øtood by a Chinar called Santy of Chinchon, and h√©e ≈øaid that they lie vnder 21. degr√©es and ¬æ. there it is thirtie fadome d√©epe, & although we ≈øaw them not, notwith≈øtanding by the height and depth of the water we knewe we were pa≈øt them.

Being pa≈øt the faire I≈ølands, we held our cour≈øe Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, for two hundred and ≈øixtie miles, vntill we were pa≈øt the length of the I≈ølands Lequeos, ≈øayling about fiftie myles from them, the ≈øaid Chinar told me, that tho≈øe I≈ølandes called Lequeos are very many, and that they haue many and verie good Hauens, and that the people and inhabitants thereof haue their faces and bodies painted like the By≈øayas of the I≈ølands of Lucon or Philippinas, and are apparelled like the By≈øayas, and that there al≈øo are mines of gold: He ≈øaid likewi≈øe that they did often come with ≈ømall ≈øhippes and Barkes lade ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with Buckes and Hartes bides, and with gold in graines or verie ≈ømall pieces, to traffique with them of the coa≈øt of China, which he a≈ø≈øured me to be mo≈øt true, ≈øaying that he had b√©ene nine times in the ≈ømall I≈øland, bringing of the ≈øame wares with him to China, which I bel√©eued to be true, for that afterward I enquired thereof in Macau and vpon the coa≈øt of China and found that he ≈øaid true. The furthe≈øt or vttermo≈øt of the≈øe I≈ølands both Northward and Ea≈øtward lie vnder 29. degr√©es.

B√©eing pa≈øt the≈øe I≈ølands, then you come to the I≈ølandes of Iapon, whereof the fir≈øt lying We≈øt and South is the
I≈øland of Firando, where the Portingales v≈øe to trafficke, they are in length altogether a hundred and thirty miles, and the furthe≈øt Ea≈øtward, lyeth vnder two and thirty degr√©es, we ran ≈øtill Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, vntil we were pa≈øt the ≈øaid a hundred and thirty miles.

All this information I had of the afore≈øaid Chinar, as al≈øo that there I ≈øhould ≈ø√©e ≈øome mynes of Brim≈øtone, or fiery Hils, being ≈øeuenty miles beyond them, & thirty miles further I ≈øhould finde foure I≈ølands lying together, which I likewi≈øe found as hee had tolde mee: For that being in Iapon hee ≈øaid hee had there ≈ø√©ene certaine men of a very ≈ømall ≈øtature with great roules of Linnen cloth about their heads, yt brought gold in ≈ømall p√©eces, and ≈øome white Cangas of Algodon, (which are p√©eces of Cotton, Linnen ≈øo called by the Chinars) as al≈øo ≈øalt fi≈øh, the Spani≈øh Atun, or Haberdine, which hee ≈øaid, came out of other I≈ølandes Ea≈øtward from Iapon, and by ye tokens and markes he ≈øhewed me, I ge≈ø≈øed whereabout tho≈øe I≈ølands ≈øhould bee, and found them not farre from whence h√©e ≈øaid they lay, hee ≈øaid likewi≈øe that all the I≈ølands of Iapon haue good hauens and Channels, being a country full of Rice, Corne, Fi≈øh, and Fle≈øh, and that they are an indifferent and rea≈øonable people to Trafficke with, and that there they haue much ≈øiluer.

Running thus Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North about three hundred miles from Iapon, we found a very hollow water, with the ≈øtreame running out of the North and Northwe≈øt, with a ful and very broad ≈øea, without any hinderance or trouble in the way that we pa≈øt, and what winde ≈øoeuer blewe, the Sea continued all in one ≈øort, with the ≈øame hollow water and ≈øtreame, vntill we had pa≈øt ye ≈øeuen hundred miles, about two hundred myles from the coa≈øt and land of newe Spaigne, where wee began to lo≈øe the ≈øaid hollow ≈øea and ≈øtream, whereby I mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly thinke and beleeue, that there you ≈øhall find a Channell or ≈øtraight pa≈ø≈øage, betw√©ene the Firme land and new Spaigne, and the Countries of A≈øia and Tartaria. Likewi≈øe all this way from the afore≈øayed ≈øeuen hundred miles, we found a great number of whale fi≈øhes, and other fi≈øh by the Spaniards Atun, whereof many are found in the coa≈øt of Gibraltar in Spaigne, as al≈øo Albacoras and Bonitos, which are all Fi≈øhes, which commonly k√©epe in Channels, ≈øtraights, and running waters, there to di≈øper≈øe their ≈ø√©ed when they br√©ed, which maketh me more a≈ø≈øuredly bel√©eue, that thereabouts is a Channell or Straight to pa≈ø≈øe through.

Being by the ≈øame cour≈øe vpon ye coa≈øt of new Spaigne, vnder ≈øeuen and thirty degr√©es and ¬Ω. wee pa≈ø≈øed by a very high and faire land with many Tr√©es, wholy without Snow, and foure miles from the land you find thereabouts many drifts of roots, leaues of Tr√©es, R√©edes, and other leaues like Figge leaues, the like whereof wee found in great abundance in the countrey of Iapon, which they eat, and ≈øome of tho≈øe that w√©e found, I cau≈øed to be ≈øodden with fle≈øh, and being ≈øodden, they eat like Colewortes, there likewi≈øe wee found great ≈øtore of Sea wolues, which wee call Sea dogges, whereby it is to b√©e pre≈øumed and certainly to bee bel√©eued, that there are manye Riuers, Bayes, and Hauens along by tho≈øe coa≈øts to the Hauen of Acapulco.

From thence wee ranne South-ea≈øt, Southea≈øt and by South, and South-ea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, as we found the wind, to the point called El Cabo de Saint Lucas, which is the beginning of the land of Califfornia, on the Northwe≈øt ≈øide, lying vnder two and twenty degr√©es, being fiue hundred myles di≈øtant from the Cape De mendo≈øino.

In this way of the afore≈øaied fiue hundred myles, along by the coa≈øt, are manye I≈ølands, and although they bee but ≈ømall, yet without doubt there are in them ≈øome good Hauens, as al≈øo in the Firme Land, where you haue the≈øe Hauens following, nowe lately found out, as that of the I≈øland of Saint Augu≈øtine, lying vnder thirtye degr√©es and ¬æ. and the I≈øland called Ilha de Sedros, ≈øcarce vnder eight and twentie degr√©es and ¬º. and the I≈øland lying beneath the Saint Martyn, vnder thr√©e and twentie degr√©es and ¬Ω. all this coa≈øt and Country, as I thinke is inhabited, and ≈øheweth to bee a verye good Countrey, for there by night wee ≈øawe fire, and by day ≈ømoake, which is a mo≈øt ≈øure token that they are inhabited.

From the Point or hooke of Saint Lucas, to the South-ea≈øt ≈øide of Calliffornia, wee helde our cour≈øe Ea≈øt Southea≈øt, for the ≈øpace of eightye myles,
to the point called El cabo de las corrientes, that is, the point of the ≈øtreames lying vnder ninteene degr√©es & ‚Öî. and running this cour≈øe Northward about a mile from vs, we ≈øawe thr√©e I≈ølands called las tres Marias, (that is, the thr√©e Maries) running the ≈øame cour≈øe. About foure miles from the other I≈ølandes, there are other I≈ølands reaching about 2. or thr√©e miles: All this way from the mouth or Cr√©eke of California afore≈øaid for the ≈øpace of the ≈øaid 80. miles, there are great ≈øtreames that runne We≈øtward.

From the point or Cape de las Corrientes, w√©e ranne Southea≈øt, and ≈øometimes Southea≈øt and by Ea≈øt, for the ≈øpace of an hundred and thirtie miles to the hauen of Acapulco. In this way of an hundred and thirty miles, being 20. miles on the way, we had the Hauen of the Na
‚Ä¢ iuidade, that is, the birth of the Virgine Mary: and other eight miles further, the Hauen of Saint Iago, or Saint Iames: and ≈øixe miles further, the ≈øea Strand called la Playa de Culyma, that is, the Strand of Culyma. All this coa≈øt from California to the Hauen of Acapulco is inhabited by people that haue peace and traffique with the Spaniards, and are of condition and qualities like the people of the other places of new Spaine.

div.head: The Conclu≈øion of the Author of this la≈øt Voyage.
div.p: ALl this De≈øcription and Nauigation haue I my ≈øelfe ≈ø√©ene, prooued, and well noted in my Voiage made and ended in the y√©ere of our Lord 1584. 1584. from great China out of the Hauen and riuer of Canton, as I will more at large ≈øet it downe vnto your honour, with the Paralell and Meridian thereof, as God ≈øhall permit me time and ley≈øour, whome I be≈ø√©ech to ≈øend you long and happy daies: and the ≈øame haue I truly tran≈ølated out of Spani≈øh into low Dutch verbatim out of the Originall coppie, that was ≈øent vnto the Viceroy of the Portingall Indies.

div.head: The 55. Chapter. The De≈øcription of a Voyage made by a Pilot called Nuno da Silua for the Viceroy of new Spaine, the 20. of May in the yeere of our Lorde 1579.1579. to the towne of Mexico, from whence it was ≈øent to the Viceroy of the Portingall Indies, wherein is ≈øet downe the cour≈øe and actions pa≈ø≈øed in the Voyage of Sir Francis Drake that tooke the afore≈øaid Nuno da Silua by the I≈ølands of Cabo Verde, and carried him along with him thorough the Straightes of Magellanes, to the Hauen of Guatulco in newe Spaine, where he let him goe againe.
div.p: NVno da Silua borne in Porto, a Citizen and inhabitant of Guaia, ≈øaith, that h√©e departed out of his hou≈øe in the beginning of Nouember in the y√©ere of our Lorde 1577. 1577 taking his cour≈øe to Cabo Verde, or the gr√©ene point, where h√©e ankered with his ≈øhippe clo≈øe by the Hauen of the I≈øland of Saint Iames, one of the I≈ølands of Cabo Verde afore≈øaid, b√©eing the nint√©enth of Ianuarie in the y√©ere of our Lorde 1578. 1578 and lying there, there came ≈øixe ≈øhippes, which ≈øeemed to be Engli≈øh men, whereof the Admirall boorded his ≈øhippe, and by force with his men h√©e tooke him out of his ≈øhippe, bringing him in the boat aboord the Admirals ≈øhippe, leauing ≈øome of his be≈øt men aboord his ≈øhippe: and although the fortre≈ø≈øe of the I≈øland ≈øhot foure or fiue times at them, yet they hurt not the Engli≈øh men: who hauing done, ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ≈øaile from thence to the I≈øland of Braua, that is, the wild I≈øland, taking with them the ≈øhippe of the ≈øaide Nuno da Silua: b√©eing there, they filled certaine ve≈ø≈øels with fre≈øh water, from thence holding their cour≈øe inwarde to Sea, hauing fir≈øt with a boat ≈øet the men of Nuno da Siluas ≈øhippe on lande, onley k√©eping Nuno da Silua in his ≈øhippe, as al≈øo his ≈øhippe with the wines that were therein, and Nuno da Silua ≈øaith, the cau≈øe why they kept him on boorde was, becau≈øe they knewe him to be a Pilot for the coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia, that h√©e might bring them to ≈øuch places in tho≈øe countries as had fre≈øh water.

B√©eing put off from the I≈øland of Braua, they helde their cour≈øe to the lande of Bra≈øilia, which they de≈øcried vpon the fir≈øt of Aprill, vnder the height of 30. degr√©es:
and without landing or taking in fre≈øh water, they held on their cour≈øe to the riuer Rio de la Plata, that is, the riuer of Siluer, lying vnder fiue and thirtie degr√©es, little more or le≈ø≈øe, where they went on lande, and prouided them≈øelues of fre≈øh water. From thence they helde on their cour≈øe till they came vnder nine and thirtie degr√©es, where they ankered: and b√©eing there, they left two of their ≈øixe ≈øhippes behinde them, and ≈øailed but foure in companie (that of Nuno da Silua b√©eing one) till they came to the Baye called Baya de las I≈ølas, that is, the Baye of the I≈ølands, lying vnder nine and fortie degr√©es, where it is ≈øaid, that Magellanes lay and wintered there with his Shippe when h√©e fir≈øt di≈øcouered the Straight, which now holdeth his name. In this Bay being the twentie of Iune, they entred, and there ankered ≈øo clo≈øe to the land, that they might ≈øend to it with a Harquebu≈øh ≈øhot, and there they ≈øaw the land to be inhabited with Indians, that were apparelled with ≈økinnes, with their legges from the kn√©es downwarde, and their armes from the elbows downward couered, all the re≈øt of their bodies b√©eing naked, with bowes and arrowes in their handes, being ≈øubtill, great, and well formed people, and ≈øtrong and high of ≈øtature, where ≈øixe of the Engli≈øh men went on land to fetch fre≈øh water, and before they leapt on land, foure of the Indians came vnto their boate, to whome the Engli≈øh men gaue bread and wine: and when the Indians had well eaten and drunke, they departed thence: and going ≈øomwhat farre from them, one of the Indians cryed to them, and ≈øaide: Magallanes, E≈øta heminha Terra, that is, Magallanes, this is my countrey: and becau≈øe the Engli≈øh men followed them, it ≈ø√©emed the Indians fledde-vpward into the lande, and b√©eing ≈øomewhat farre off, they turned backe againe, and with their arrowes ≈ølewe two of the Engli≈øh Shippers, one being an Engli≈øh man, the other a Netherlander: the re≈øt came backe againe and ≈øaued them≈øelues in the boate, wherewith they pre≈øently put off from the ≈øhoare, and there they ≈øtayed till the ≈øeuent√©enth of Augu≈øt, vpon the which day they ≈øet ≈øaile, running along by the coa≈øt about a mile and a halfe from the lande, for there it is all faire and good ground, at twentie, and fiue and twentie fadome d√©epe, and were about foure or fiue dayes before they came to the mouth or entrie of the Straightes, but becau≈øe the winde was contrarie, they ≈øtayed till the foure and twentie of Augu≈øt before they entred.

The entrie or mouth of the Straight is about a myle broad, on both ≈øides b√©eing bare and flat land, on the North ≈øide they ≈øawe Indians making great fires, but on the South ≈øide they ≈øaw no people ≈øtirring. The foure and twentie day afore≈øaide, they beganne to enter into the ≈øtraights, with an Ea≈øt Northea≈øt wind. This Straight may be about an hundred and ten miles long, and in breadth a mile about the entry of the Straight, and halfe way into it, it runneth right forth without any windings or turnings: and from thence about eight or ten miles towardes the end, it hath ≈øome boughes and windings, among the which, there is one ≈øo great a hooke or running in, that it ≈ø√©emeth to runne into the other land: and there it is le≈ø≈øe then a mile broad from one lande to the other: and from thence forwarde it runneth ≈øtraight out againe: And although you finde ≈øome crookings, yet they are nothing to ≈øpeake of. The i≈ø≈øue of the Straight lieth we≈øtward, and about eight or ten miles before you come to the end, then the Straight beginneth to be broader, and it is all high lande to the end thereof after you are eight miles within the Straight, for the fir≈øt eight myles after you enter is low flat land, as I ≈øaide before: and in the entrie of the Straight you finde the ≈øtreame to runne from the South ≈øea to the North ≈øea: and after they began to ≈øaile in with the Ea≈øt Northea≈øt winde, (being entred) they pa≈ø≈øed along without any let or hinderance either of wind or weather: and becau≈øe the high land on both ≈øides lay couered with ≈ønow, and that all the Straight is faire and cleare, they held their cour≈øe a Harquebu≈øh ≈øhot in length from off the North ≈øide, hauing nine and ten fadome d√©epe, with good ground, as I ≈øaid before, where (if neede require) a man may anker: the hilles on both ≈øides b√©eing full of tr√©es, ≈øome of the hilles and tr√©es reaching downe to the ≈øea ≈øide, in ≈øome places hauing plaine and euen land, and there they ≈øaw not any great riue ‚Ä¢ s, but ≈øome ≈ømall riuers that i≈ø≈øued out of the Riffes and Breaches of the lande: and in the
country where the great Bough or crooking is, on the South ≈øide they ≈øaw certaine Indian Fi≈øhermen in their Canoas or Scutes, being ≈øuch as they ≈øawe fir≈øt on the North ≈øide, but more people they ≈øaw not on the South ≈øide.

Beeing out of the Straight on the other ≈øide, b√©eing vpon the ≈øixt of September of the afore≈øaide yeere, they held their cour≈øe Northwe≈øt for the ≈øpace of thr√©e dayes, and the third day they had a northea≈øt winde, that by force draue them We≈øt Southwe≈øt, which cour≈øe they helde for the ≈øpace of ten or twelue dayes with fewe ≈øailes vp: and becau≈øe the winde began to be verie great, they tooke in all their ≈øailes, and lay driuing till the la≈øt of September.

The foure and twentie day of the ≈øame moneth hauing lo≈øt the ≈øight of their pinnace which was about an hundred tunne, then againe they hoi≈øed ≈øaile becau≈øe they came better, holding their cour≈øe Northea≈øt for the ≈øpace of ≈øeuen dayes, and at the end of the ≈øaid ≈øeuen dayes, they had the ≈øight of certaine I≈ølands, which they made towards for to anker, but the weather would not permit them: and b√©eing there, the winde fell Northwe≈øt, whereby they ≈øailed We≈øt Southwe≈øt.

The next day they lo≈øt the ≈øight of another of their companie, which ≈øhip was about three hundred and ≈øixtie tunnes, for it was very foule weather, ≈øo that in the end the Admirals ≈øhippe was left alone, for the Ship of Nuno da Silua was left in the Baye where they wintered before they entred into the Straights, and with this foule weather they ranne till they were vnder ≈øeuen & fiftie degrees, where they entred into a Hauen of an I≈øland and ankered about the length of the ≈øhot of a great peece from the land, at twentie fadome deepe, where they ≈øtaied thr√©e or foure dayes, and the winde comming Southward, they hoy≈øed anker, holding their cour≈øe Northward for the ≈øpace of two dayes, and then they e≈øpied a ≈ømall vnhabited I≈øland, where b√©eing arriued, they ≈øtroke ≈øayles, and hoi≈øed out their boat, and there they tooke many birds and Sea wolues.

The next day they ≈øet ≈øaile againe, holding their cour≈øe North Northea≈øt, and North, to ‚Ä¢ nother I≈øland lying fiue or ≈øix myles from the firme lande, on the North ≈øide of the Straight, where they ankered about a quarter of a mile from the lande, at twelue fadome water. This I≈øland is ≈ømall and lowe lande, and full of Indians, the I≈øland being altogither built and inhabited by them, where they hoy≈øed out their boate, wherein the Admirall and twelue Engli≈øh men were entred going to fetch fre≈øh water, and to ≈ø√©eke for victuals, and beeing landed vpon the I≈øland, the Indians in exchange of other things, brought two Spani≈øh ≈øh√©epe, and a little Mais or rootes whereof they make bread, and becau≈øe it was late, they returned againe vnto their ≈øhippe, without doing any other thing for that day. The next day the ≈øaid Captaine with the afore≈øaide twelue men being Harquebu≈øhers, rowed to land again, and ≈øet two of their companie on ≈øhore with their ve≈ø≈øels to fetch fre≈øh water, and by the place where they ≈øhould fill their water there lay certaine Indians ≈øecretly hidden, that fell vpon the two Engli≈øh men and tooke them: which they in the boat perceiuing, went out to helpe them, but they were ≈øo a≈ø≈øailed with ≈øtones and arrowes, that all or the mo≈øt part of them were hurt, the Captaine him≈øelfe b√©eing wounded with an arrowe on the face, and will, another arrowe in the head, whereby they were con≈øtrained to turne backe againe, without once hurting any of the Indians, and yet they came ≈øo neare the boate, that they tooke foure of their oares from them. This done, they ≈øet ≈øaile againe, running along the coa≈øt with a South winde, ≈øailing ≈øo for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe miles, pa≈ø≈øing by the Hauen called Saint Iago, or Saint Iames, where they put into a Hauen, and there they tooke an Indian that lay fi≈øhing in a Scute or Canoa, giuing him linnen and Butchers chopping kniues, with other trifles, and not long after there came an other Indian aboord their ≈øhippe called Felippe, and h√©e ≈øpake Spani≈øh, hee gaue the Engli≈øh Captaine notice of a certaine ≈øhippe that lay in the Hauen of Saint Iago, which they had left ≈øixe miles behinde them: with that intelligence the Indian b√©eing their guide, the next day they ≈øet Saile and put to the afore≈øaide Hauen of Saint Iago, and entring therein, they tooke the ≈øaide Shippe, wherein they found a thou≈øand ≈øeuen hundred and 70. Bortigas of Spani≈øh pots full of wine, & other thinges, which hauing done, they leapt on land, where they tooke certaine
≈øackes with meale, with all what≈øoeuer they could find, they tooke likewi≈øe the ornaments and other Relickes out of the Church, wherewith they departed from thence, taking the afore≈øaid ≈øhippe, with two menne (that they found in her) with them, and ≈øo departed from that Hauen, which lyeth vnder 32 degr√©es and ¬Ω. running along by the coa≈øt till they came vnder one and thirtie and thirty degr√©es: which was the place where they had appointed to m√©et, and there to ≈øtay for each other, if by tempe≈øt or foule weather they chanced to be ≈øeperated, and ≈øo loo≈øe each others company.

And comming vnder thirty degr√©es, they found a very good Hauen, wherein they entred, and ankered at ≈øixe fadome deepe, the ≈øhotte of a great P√©ece from the Lande, which was right ouer again≈øt a Riuer, where they tooke in ≈øixe Pipes of fre≈øh water, and to defend them that fetched the water, they ≈øet twelue men vpon the Land, and being bu≈øied in filling of their water, they e≈øpied a company of men comming towards them, wherof halfe of them were Spaniards, being about two hundred and fifty hor≈øemeÃÑ, and as many footemen, but they had no ≈øooner e≈øpied them, but they pre≈øently entered into the Boat, and e≈øcaped away, loo≈øing but one man.

The ≈øame night they ≈øet ≈øaile againe with both their Shippes, running along the coa≈øt about ten miles further, where they tooke in ≈øome fre≈øh water, but becau≈øe they perceiued certaine hor≈øemen, they departed without lading any more water.

FroÃÑ thence they folowed on their cour≈øe along the coa≈øt for the ≈øpace of 30. myles, where they entred into a de≈øert or vnhabited Hauen, yet they went not on Land, for euery day they ≈øawe people vpon the ≈øhore, and there they made out a ≈ømall pinnace, the p√©eces whereof they brought readye framed out of England, and hauing prepared it, they launched it into the Water, wherein the Captaine with fift√©ene men entred, with the cheefe Boate≈øman called Ian de Greicke, (being Mai≈øter of the ≈øhippe which they had taken in the Hauen of S. Iago,) wherewith they went to ≈ø√©e if they could finde the two Shippes that they had lo≈øt by ≈øtormy weather as I ≈øaied before, and likewi≈øe thinking to goe on Land to fill certaine ve≈ø≈øels with fre≈øh Water, they dur≈øt not venture, for they ≈øawe people on all ≈øide of the ≈øhoare, ≈øo that in the end they returned againe without hearing of the other Shippes, being there, they tooke all the Ordinaunce out of their Shippe, and newe dre≈ø≈øed and rigged her, which done, they put a ≈ømall p√©ece of Ordinaunce into the Pinnace, wherewith they ≈øet ≈øaile againe, following on their cour≈øe.

Hauing ≈øayled thirt√©ene daies, they came to an I≈øland lying about the ≈øhot of a Ba≈øe from the Lande, where they ankered, and there they found foure Indian Fi≈øhermen in two Canaos, who tolde them that on the Firme Lande they might haue fre≈øh water, but they vnder≈øtanding that there was not much, and that it was ≈øomewhat within the Lande, they would not ≈øpend any time about it, but ≈øet ≈øayle againe, leauing the Fi≈øhermen with their Canaos, following on their cour≈øe along by the ≈øhore.

The next day being ≈øomewhat further, they e≈øpied certaine Indian Fi≈øhermen that were vpon the Lande in their hou≈øes, which the Engli≈øh Captaine perceauing, pre≈øently entered into the Pinnace, and rowed on Land, where hee tooke three of the ≈øaid Fi≈øhermen, taking with him halfe of the Fi≈øh that lay packed vpon the ≈øhoare ready to bee laden, with the which Indians and booty, they came on boord againe.

The next day following, they ≈øawe a Barke laden with Fi≈øh, that belonged to the Spaniards, with foure Indians in it. This Barke with the Indians and the Fi≈øh, they tooke and bound the Spani≈øh Shippe to their ≈øterne, and ≈øo drewe it after them, leauing the ≈øaid Indians within it, who by night vnbound the Barke, and ≈øecretly made away with Barke and Fi≈øh, and were no more ≈øeene. The next day the Captaine went into the Pinnace, and becau≈øe hee ≈øawe certaine hou≈øes vppon the ≈øhoare, hee made thither, and beeing on Lande, hee found two menne in them, whereof one hee tooke, leauing the other behinde, and there hee found thr√©e thou≈øand Pe≈øoes of ≈øiluer, (euery Pe≈øo being the value of a Ryall of eight,) and ≈øeuen Indian Sheepe, Hennes, and all what≈øoeuer they found‚ñ™
wherewith they departed from thence, following on their cour≈øe, and two dayes after they came by the hauen called Azijcka, where they found two ≈øhippes, the one laden with goods and Spani≈øh wares, out of the which, they tooke only two hundred Bottigas (or Spani≈øh Pots with Wine) and out of the other ≈øeueÃÑ and thirty Bharas of ≈øiluer, which are p√©eces of tenne or twelue pound each Bharre, and thinking to leape on ≈øhore (with two Barkes that they found in the ≈øaid Hauen, with about ≈øeuen and thirty Harquebu≈øhes & bowes) they perceiued on the land certaine hor≈øemen comming towards them, whervpon they left off their pretence, and tooke with them a Moore that they found within the Barkes, with whome they retourned aboord.

The next day in the morning they burnt the ≈øhippe, that was laden with the Spani≈øh wares, and tooke the other with them, pa≈ø≈øing forward with it on their cour≈øe, the Captaine ≈øayling along the ≈øhore with his Pinnace, and the Shippe keeping about a myle from him to Seaward, to ≈ø√©eke for a ≈øhippe whereof they had intelligence, and hauing in that manner ≈øailed about fiue and forty myles, they found the ≈øhippe that lay at anker in a hauen, who about two houres before had beene aduerti≈øed of an Engli≈øh Pirate or Sea-rouer, and had di≈øcharged eight hundred Bharres of ≈øiluer out of her, and hidden it on the Land, which ≈øiluer belonged to the King of Spaine, of the which ≈øiluer the Engli≈øhmen had receiued ≈øome intelligence, but they dur≈øt not goe on land, becau≈øe there were many Indians and Spaniards that ≈øtood to guard it, and they found nothing in the ≈øhip but thr√©e Pipes of water, the ≈øhippe they tooke with them, and being about a mile in the Sea, they hoi≈øed vp all her ≈øailes & let her driue, doing the like with the Shippe that they had taken in Azijcka, as al≈øo the other of Saint Iago, which likewi≈øe they let driue, following on their cour≈øe with their owne ≈øhip, and the Pinnace.

Being ≈øeuen or eight myles from the Hauen of Callan de Lyma, they e≈øpied thr√©e Shippes, and boording one of them, they tooke thr√©e men out of her, and ≈øo helde on their cour≈øe towards Callan de Lyma, where they entred, being about two or thr√©e houres within night, ≈øayling in betw√©ene all the ≈øhippes that lay there, being ≈øeuent√©ene in number, and being among the ≈øhips, they a≈øked for the ≈øhip that had laden the ≈øiluer, but wheÃÑ an≈øwere was made them, that the ≈øiluer was laid on land, they cut the cables of the ≈øhips, and the ma≈øts of two of the greate≈øt ≈øhips, and ≈øo left them. At the ≈øame time there arriued a Shippe from Panama laden with wares and Marchaundi≈øe of Spaigne, that ankered clo≈øe by the Engli≈øh Ship, which was while the Engli≈øh Captaine ≈øought in the other Shippes for the ≈øiluer. As ≈øoone as the ≈øhippe of Panama had ankered, there came a Boat from the ≈øhoare to ≈øearch it, but becau≈øe it was in the night, they let it alone till morning, and comming to the Engli≈øh ≈øhippe, they a≈øked what ≈øhippe it was, wherevpon one of the Spani≈øh pri≈øoners (by the Engli≈øh Captaines commandement) an≈øwered and ≈øaid it was the ≈øhippe of Michiel Angelo, that came from Chile, which they of the boat hearing, ≈øent a man on boord, who climbing vp, light vpon one of the great P√©eces, wherewith hee was afraid, and pre≈øently ≈øtept backe againe into the boate (becau≈øe the Shippes that lay there, and that ≈øayled in tho≈øe Countries, v≈øed to carry no great ≈øhotte) and therewith they were aba≈øhed, and made from it, which the ≈øhippe of Panama hearing, that was newely come in, ≈øhee iudged it to b√©e a Rouer, and therewith cutting her Cables, ≈øh√©e put to Sea, which the Engli≈øhmen perceiuing, ≈øhipped certaine men in their Pinnace, and followed her: and being hard by her, they baddde her ≈øtrike, which they of the ≈øhippe refu≈øed to doe, and with a Harquebu≈øh ≈øhotte, killed one of the Engli≈øhmen, wherewith they turned againe into their ≈øhippe and pre≈øently ≈øet ≈øayle, following after the ≈øhippe, which not long after they ouertooke: which they of the Shippe perceiuing, hoi≈øed out their Boate, and leaping into it, rowed to Land, leauing the ≈øhippe with all the goods, which the Engli≈øhmen pre≈øentlie tooke, and with her ≈øayled on their cour≈øe.

The next day they ≈øawe a boat with ≈øayles making towards them, whereby they pre≈øentlie mi≈øtru≈øted it to bee a Spye, and not long after they perceaued two great ≈øhippes comming towards them, which made the Engli≈øh thinke they came to fight with them, wherevpon they let the Shippe of Panama
driue, therein leauing Iohn de Greicke. With the two that they had taken the ≈øame day, they entred into Callan de Lyma, as I ≈øaid before, and pre≈øently hoi≈øed all their ≈øailes, and ≈øailed forward, not once ≈øetting eye againe vpon the afore≈øaid ≈øhippes, for they made towards the ≈øhippe of Panama, which the Engli≈øhmen let driue. From thence they ≈øayled againe along the coa≈øt, following on their cour≈øe, and hauing ≈øailed certaine dayes, they met a Frigate that went towards Lyma, laden with wares and Marchandi≈øes of the Countrey, from whence the Engli≈øhmen tooke a Lampe and a Fountaine of ≈øiluer, and a≈øked the Pilote being a Spaniard, if they met not with a Shippe, that they vnder≈øtoode ≈øhould bee laden with ≈øiluer, but the one Pilote ≈øaid he met her not, and the other ≈øaid hee ≈øawe her about thr√©e dayes before. This Frigate came not to the ≈øhippe, but to the Pinnace, wherein the Captaine ≈øayled, for the Pinnace ranne clo≈øe by the ≈øhoare, and the ≈øhippe kept a myle and a halfe from the Lande, wherewith they let the Frigate goe, following on their cour≈øe.

Two dayes after they came to the Hauen called Payta, where they found a Shippe laden with Spani≈øh wares, which the Pinnace boorded, and tooke it without any re≈øi≈øtance‚ñ™ for as ≈øoone as the Spaniards perceaued the Engli≈øhmen, they pre≈øently made to Land with their Boat, and two of them leapt into the Sea, none ≈øtaying in the ≈øhippe, but the Mai≈øter, Pilote, and ≈øome Moores, out of the which ≈øhippe the Engli≈øhmen tooke the Pilote, and all the Bread, Hens, and a Hogge, and ≈øo ≈øayled forward with the Shippe: but being about two Harquebu≈øh ≈øhotte to Seaward, they let it goe againe, not taking any thing out of it, and a≈øking after the ≈øhippe which they ≈øought for, they told them that about two daies before ≈øhee departed from that place, wherewith they followed on their cour≈øe, and before night they met with a Shippe of Panama, which they pre≈øently boorded, but tooke nothing from her but onely a Moore, and ≈øo left it, holding on their cour≈øe.

The next day being the fir≈øt of February, they met another Shippe that ≈øayled to Panama, laden with Fi≈øh and other victuals, & fortie Bharres of ≈øiluer, and ≈øome golde, but I knowe not howe much, which they tooke, and ≈øent the pa≈ø≈øengers (with two Friers that were in her) in a boat to Land. The next day they hanged a man of the Shippe, becau≈øe hee would not confe≈ø≈øe two plates of golde that h√©e had taken, which after they found about him, which done, they let the Shippe driue, following on their cour≈øe.

The fir≈øt of March towards noone, they e≈øpied the ≈øhippe laden with the ≈øiluer, b√©eing about foure myles to Seaward from them, and becau≈øe the Engli≈øh Shippe was ≈øomewhat heauy before, whereby it ≈øayled not as they would haue it, they tooke a company of Bottigas or Spani≈øh Pots for Oyle, and filling them with water, hung them by ropes at the ≈øterne of the Shippe to make her ≈øayle the better, and the ≈øhippe that ≈øayled towards Panama, made towards the Engli≈øh Shippe to knowe what ≈øhe was, thinking it to bee one of the ≈øhippes that v≈øed to ≈øaile along the coa≈øts, and to tra ‚Ä¢ ficke in the country, and being hard by her, the Engli≈øh Captaine bad them ≈øtrike, but the other refu≈øing to doe it, with a great Peece hee ≈øhot her ma≈øt ouer boord, and hauing wounded the mai≈øter with an arrowe, the ≈øhippe pre≈øently y√©elded, which they tooke, and ≈øayled with her further into the Sea, all that night and the next day, and night making all the way they could. The third day being out of ≈øight of lande, they began to ≈øearch the ≈øhippes, and to lade the goods out of her into their Shippe, which was a thou≈øand thr√©e hundred Bharres or peeces of ≈øiluer, and foureteene che≈øts with Ryals of eight, and with golde, but what quantity it was I knowe not, onely that the pa≈ø≈øengers ≈øaid that there was great ≈øtore, and that thr√©e hundred Bharres of the ≈øiluer belonged to the King, the re≈øt belonging to certaine Marchaunts, that done, they let the Shippe with the men ≈øayle on their cour≈øe, putting the thr√©e Pilotes in her that they brought with them‚ñ™ ≈øo that as then they had none but their owne men aboord, being the ≈øixt of March, and from thence they helde their cour≈øe towards the Lande of Nicaraga.

The thirt√©enth of March, either the day before or after, in the morning they de≈øcried Land, not being very high, beeing a ≈ømall I≈øland two miles from the Firme
land, and there they found a ≈ømall Baye, wherein they ankered at fiue fadome d√©ep clo≈øe by the Lande, and there they ≈øtayed till the ≈øecond day. Vpon the which day there pa≈ø≈øed a Frigate clo≈øe by the I≈øland, which with their Pinnace they followed, and taking her, brought her to the Engli≈øh Shippe, which Frigate was laden with Sal≈øaperilla, or Pocke-root, and Bottigas or Pots with Butter and Honny, and with other things. The Engli≈øh Captaine went on boord, and ca≈øt the Sal≈øaperilla on the Lande, leauing all the re≈øt of the wares in the Frigate, and then hee put all his P√©eces into the Frigate, that ≈øo he might lay his ≈øhippe on ≈øhore, to new calke and trim her, which continued till the thr√©e and twenty or foure and twenty of March, which done, and hauing made proui≈øion of wood & fre≈øh water, they helde on their cour≈øe along by the coa≈øt, ≈øayling We≈øtward, taking the ≈øaid Frigate and her menne with them, and hauing ≈øayled two daies, they tooke their men out of her, and ≈øet them in the Pinnace, among the which were two Saylers, that meant to ≈øayle to Panama, and from thence to China, whereof one they tooke with the Letters and Sea-cardes that hee had about him, among the which were the Letters of the King of Spaine, ≈øent to the Gouernour of China, as al≈øo the Sea-cardes wherewith they ≈øhould make their voyage, and direct them≈øelues in their cour≈øe.

And ≈øo ≈øailing on till the ≈øixt of Aprill, about euening they di≈øcouered a ≈øhip that held two miles to ≈øeaward from the land, and before the next day in the morning, they were hard by her, and ≈øodainely fell vpon her while her men ≈ølept, & pre≈øentlie made the meÃÑ enter into their ≈øhip, among the which was one Don Franci≈øco Caratte, which done, they followed on their cour≈øe with the ≈øaid ≈øhip, out of the which they tooke certaine packes and other wares, but I know not what it was. They likewi≈øe tooke a Moore out of it, and thr√©e dayes after they both let the Shippe and menne goe whether they would, ≈øetting therein the two Saylers that ≈øhould goe for China, which they had taken in the Frigate, k√©eping onely one ≈øaylor to ≈øhew them where they ≈øhould find fre≈øh water, to the which end they tooke the empty ve≈ø≈øels with them to fill with water, and ≈øo kept on their cour≈øe to the hauen of Guatulco, where they put in, being vpon munday the thirt√©enth of Aprill, and hauing ankered, they ≈øtayed there till the ≈øixe and twenty of Aprill, and being about thr√©e or foure houres in the night, they ≈øet ≈øaile, holding their cour≈øe We≈øtward, and an houre or two before they let Nuno da Silua goe, putting him into another ≈øhippe, that lay in the Hauen of Guatulco. From thence forward the Engli≈øhmen pa≈ø≈øed on their voyage, to the I≈ølands of Malucos, and from thence they pa≈ø≈øed by the Cape De Bona E≈øperanza, and ≈øo to England, as it is well knowne, ≈øo that this is only the de≈øcription of the voyage that they made, while the ≈øaid Pilote Nuna da Silua was with them.

Hereafter followeth the Coppy of a Letter written by Sir Francis Drake (beeing in the South Sea of newe Spaigne, in his ≈øhippe called the golden Hart, with the ≈øhippe of S. Iohn de Anton, which hee had taken) to his companions in the other ≈øhippes that were of his company, and by foule weather ≈øeperated from him, as I ≈øaied before, The Contents whereof were the≈øe:

Mai≈øter Wouter, if it plea≈øeth Godthat you ≈øhould chance to m√©ete with this ≈øhippe of S. Iohn de Anton, I pray you v≈øe him well, according to my word and promi≈øe giuen vnto them, and if you want any thing that is in this Shippe of S. Iohn de Anton, I pray you pay them double the value for it, which I wil ≈øati≈øfie again, and command your men not to doe her any hurt: and what compo≈øition or agr√©ement w√©e haue made, at my returne into England I will by Gods helpe performe, although I am in doubt that this Letter will neuer come to your hands, notwith≈øtanding, I am the man I haue promi≈øed to bee: Be≈ø√©eching God, the Sauiour of all the world, to haue vs in his k√©eping, to whome onely I giue all honour, prai≈øe and glory. This I haue written, is not onely to you Mai≈øter Wouter, but al≈øo to Mai≈øter Thomas, Mai≈øter Charles, Mai≈øter Caube, and Mai≈øter Anthonie, with all our other good friendes, whome I commit to the tuition of him that with his bloud red√©emed vs, and am in good hope, that wee ≈øhall bee in no more trouble, but that hee will helpe vs in aduer≈øitie, de≈øiring you for the Pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, that if you fall into
any danger, that you will not de≈øpaire of Gods mercy, for hee will defend you and pre≈øerue you from all daunger, and bring vs to our de≈øired Hauen, to whom bee all honor, glory, and prai≈øe for euer and euer.Amen.
