div.head: An aduerti≈øement to the Reader.
div.p: ALthough at the fir≈øt it was my only intent to ≈øet downe the voyages and cour≈øes of the oriental coa≈øts, I≈ølands, and countries of the Ea≈øt parts, with ≈øome other Nauigations, of the places therabouts, with the ≈øituations thereof, as I haue already declared: notwith≈øtanding, for that among other my Record, I haue found the Nauigations of all the Hauens, Riuers, and Points of the coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia, and the voiages of the Portingales vnto the ≈øame, together with the cour≈øes, ≈øtretchings, and ≈øituations of the Antillas or fore I≈ølands of new Spaigne, together with all the channels that runne betweene them, and the Hauens, as well of the afore≈øaid I≈ølands as of the Firme Land of new Spaigne, and likewi≈øe of the other ≈øide of the coa≈øt of Angola or Aethiopia, I thought it not vnconuenient to ≈øet them downe in this place, although it bee much different, and from the matter taken in hand. Touching the orientall parts, neuerthele≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe it is vnknowne to our countrimen, as al≈øo commonly ≈øailed by the Portingales and Spaniards, who≈øe voyages and trauels I haue herein onely ≈øet downe, it will not bee out of the matter, but rather very nece≈ø≈øary to be ioyned therevnto, and as I thinke will bee wel accepted, and e≈øteemed off, in≈øomuch, as that at this time, our countrey men doe v≈øe to Trafficke and trauell into tho≈øe countries, hoping it will bee an occa≈øion of further increa≈øing and augmenting of their trauels, to the honour, prai≈øe, and glory of the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt, and all Chri≈øtian Princes, and to the entiching and welfare of the Low countries.

div.head: The 65. Chapter. The Nauigation from the Point of Cabo Verde to Bra≈øilia, with the right cour≈øe and knowledge of the Land and Hauens of Bra≈øilia, to the Riuer called Rio de la Plata, with the ≈øituation thereof.
div.p: SAyling from Cabo Verde (that is, the greene point) to Bra≈øilia, you mu≈øt ≈øaile ≈øouth ≈øouthea≈øt, Southea≈øt, and Southea≈øt & by South, and being vnder fiue or ≈øixe degr√©es (or where≈øoeuer you bee, you ≈øhall take your degr√©es on the South≈øide, and le≈ø≈øen them as much as you can, and you mu≈øt remember, that as ≈øoone as you haue the generall winde, blowing from the South-ea≈øt, then you ≈øhall runne Southwe≈øt, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt, and if the winde bee South and Southwe≈øt, you mu≈øt runne South-ea≈øt, but not too farre, for it helpeth you not, for that the more you k√©epe that cour≈øe, the more way you loo≈øe, and you ≈øhall v≈øe all the meanes you can, not to runne vnder the coa≈øt of Guinea nearer then ≈øixtie or ≈øeuentye fadome from the Sandes, called Os Baixos de Sant Anna, for the winde will helpe you, in ≈øuch manner, that you may ≈øayle towards the Point of Bra≈øilia.

And if with this cour≈øe you will ≈øayle to Pernanbuco, It being from the Moneth of October forward, and that you fall to Loofeward of the I≈øland of Fernan de Noronha, being vnder eight & eight degr√©es, and ¬Ω. You mu≈øt runne We≈øt towards the Lande, and if you ≈ø√©e Lande vnder eight degr√©es, they will bee white downes and then you are on the North-≈øide, from whence you ≈øhall put to the South, that is, from October forward: for as then the Northea≈øt and ea≈øt Northea≈øt winds doe blowe, and if you bee vnder the degr√©es afore≈øaid, you ≈øhall ≈øee the ≈øaid downes, and when you ≈øee the end of them on the South-≈øide, and from thence not ≈ø√©eing any more, then you are by Capig ‚Ä¢ aramirini, and from thence to Pernanbuco are fiue or ≈øixe myles.

And ≈øo if you bee vnder eight degr√©es and a halfe, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a flat Lande, till you bee at tenne and twelue fadome d√©epe, and the Lande on the Sea ≈øide will bee euen bare, which is called Capiragua, when you are Ea≈øt and We≈øt with this Lande, being the Countrey whereof I ≈øpeake, at twelue fadome d√©epe, it beeing in the Moneths of October, or after Februarye, then you n√©ede not
feare any thing, but take h√©ed you put not ≈øouthwards, for you mu≈øt take h√©ede of the Cape of S. Augu≈øtine, and Northward you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e another point called A Punta d Olynda, where the Towne of Olynda lieth, and the coa≈øt of the ≈øame North Point, is ≈øailed North and South.

If you be ea≈øt and We≈øt with the cape S. Augu≈øtine, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a Hill inward to the land, which ≈øheweth like the backe of a Cammell, on the South≈øide hauing thr√©e Houels along by the Sea ≈øide, and the coa≈øt will ≈øtretch North-ea≈øt and Southwe≈øt.

From this point of S. Augu≈øtine, to the towne of Olynda Northward are twelue miles. This point lyeth vnder 8 degr√©es and ¬Ω. and Olynda lyeth vnder 8. degr√©es and ‚Öì. & Pernanbuco vnder eight degr√©es, this voyage is thus to bee ≈øayled, when you ≈øet ≈øayle from Lisbon in the Moneths of October and Nouember.

But when you ≈øaile from Lisbon in February or March, then you ≈øhall looke for land vnder nine degr√©es: for from ye month of March forward, then the Southea≈øt and ≈øouth Southea≈øt winds do blow, and if you chance to bee by the land, vnder the height afore≈øaid, you n√©ede not feare any thing, but ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe at ≈øeuent√©ene and eight√©ene fadome, for it is faire and cl√©ere, and you haue nothing daungerous but the riffes lying clo≈øe by the land, whereon you ≈ø√©e the water breake: & running Northward, if you finde certaine downes along by the ≈øea ≈øide, then feare not to run northward, for therby you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e the point of S. Augu≈øtine, This point lieth on the ≈øea ≈øide, being euen ≈øt√©epe land, ≈øhewing like the muzzell of a Whale, in the toppe hauing a round Hill, compa≈ø≈øed with Tr√©es: and being at the depth afore≈øaid clo≈øe by the Land you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a ≈ømall I≈øland called Ilha de S. Alexus, From this I≈øland to Cape S. Augu≈øtine, are fiue or ≈øixe miles, and lyeth vnder 8 degr√©es & ¬æ.

div.head: The 57. chapter. The cour≈øe and Nauigation to the Hauen, called A Bahia de todos os Santos, or of all Saints, in the coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia.
div.p: IF you de≈øire to ≈øayle to the Bahia de todos os Santos, that is, the bay of all Saints, then ob≈øerue the cour≈øe afore≈øaied, taking the times of the yeare: From the Month of March forward, and from October as I ≈øaid before.

This Bay of all Saints, lyeth vnder thirteene degr√©es, and being from October forward, then you ≈øhall looke for Land at 12 and 12 degrees and ¬Ω. and being in ≈øight thereof, (which will bee white ≈øandy ≈øtrands, which ≈øhew like linnen that lieth too white) then you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe Southward along by the coa≈øt, vntill you be at the end of the ≈øaid ≈øtrands, where you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e an I≈øland (lying on the North≈øide within the mouth of the Bay or Hauen) called Tapoon, From thence you runne along the coa≈øt We≈øt, and We≈øt and South.

And comming to this Bay, from the Month of March forward, then you mu≈øt not pa≈ø≈øe aboue 13 degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . Southward, and when you are in ≈øight of Land, if it be not the afore≈øaid white ≈øtrand, then you ≈øhall v≈øe all the means you can to run Northward, and when you ≈ø√©e the ≈øandye ≈øtrand at 12 degr√©es and ¬Ω. Then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a hill ≈øtanding along by the ≈øea≈øide, and if you chance to be ≈øo n√©ere the lande, that you can find no meanes to get off from it, then you ≈øhall know the Land well, for on the ≈øea ≈øide you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a round houel called O Morro de ≈øan Paulo, from the which houell to the bay are twelue myles: along by this houell on the northwe≈øt ≈øide, there is a very great riuer called Tinhare, which is very good to put into if n√©ed be, and is ≈øix and ≈øeuen fadome d√©ep, and when you are at the afore≈øaid Point vnder 13 degr√©es & ¬Ω. then put not to the Lande, for it hath a cr√©eke that is very dangerous.

And if you de≈øire to ≈øaile from the Bay of all Saints, to Pernanbuco or to Portingale, then hold your cour≈øe Ea≈øtward, and if the wind ≈øerue you, hold Ea≈øt, and Ea≈øt and by North, for the ≈øpace of 30 or 40. miles into the ≈øea, and look not for the land of Pernanbuco from ten to nine degr√©es, for if you be vnder 11 degr√©es, you wil fall into the Cr√©eke called A En≈øeada de vaza Bar ‚Ä¢ ys (that is, the Cr√©eke of emptying of ve≈ø≈øels) and likewi≈øe when you come from Portingall, hauing ≈øight of land at eleuen degr√©es, then put not towards it to ≈øhorten your way, but rather holde your cour≈øe Southward from it.

From this Bay of all Saints to Pernanbuco is a hundred miles, and you runne along the coa≈øt northea≈øt and ≈øouthwe≈øt. From thence to the Riuer Rio dos Ilhas,
or the riuer of I≈ølands, the coa≈øt runneth Southwe≈øt and Northea≈øt, and Southwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and Northea≈øt and by Ea≈øt.

div.head: The 58. Chapter. The cour≈øe or Nauigation to the riuer Rio dos Ilhas, that is, the riuer of the I≈ølands, in the coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia.
div.p: IF you de≈øire to ≈øaile to the riuer of the I≈ølands (you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the I≈ølands lie vnder 14. degr√©es and ¬æ.) ≈ø√©eking to finde them, from the moneth of March forward, then you ≈øhall run to the height of 15. degr√©es and ¬Ω. and although you be vnder 15. degr√©es and 2/ ‚Ä¢ . you n√©ede not feare: and ≈ø√©eing the land vnder the≈øe degr√©es, then you ≈øhall ≈øee certaine high hilles, called As Serras dos Aymores, when you ≈ø√©e tho≈øe hilles, then you ≈øhall come along the coa≈øt Northwarde, not fearing any thing, for from thence Northward there are no ≈øhallows: As ≈øoone as you ≈ø√©e the Ilands (for there are no other) then on the ≈øame coa≈øt you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a rouÃÑd hill ≈øtanding along by the Sea ≈øide, on the North ≈øide whereof you put into the Riuer, and if you chance to be there at ≈øuch time as you can not put in, then hold your cour≈øe to Seaward from the I≈ølands, k√©eping from them, and there by the ≈øaid I≈ølandes you may anker: and if you be in that country when the Northea≈øt winds doe blow, then looke for land vnder 14. degr√©es, and if you ≈øee a flat land, then it is the I≈øland called Camamu ‚Ä¢ , by the which you ≈øhall run ≈øouthward, and being at the end of the flatte land, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a high land along by the ≈øea ≈øide like the other afore≈øaid, all along by the ≈øea ≈øide.

In the place where this lande beginneth to ≈øhew high, there lieth a ≈ømall riuer called Rio das Contas, that is, the riuer of Beads, but it is not to be entered, and hath a white harde ≈øtone for a marke. From thence to the I≈ølands are 9. miles Southward, and comming where the afore≈øaid high land endeth, then you ≈øhall finde a great Cr√©eke, and being We≈øt Southwe≈øt, you ≈øhall ≈øee another high land, at the foot whereof (which is almo≈øt in the middle way to the cr√©eke) you ≈øhall ≈øee certaine white hou≈øes, which are the Ingenies or Sugar hou≈øes where the Sugar is prepared: and being there, you ≈øhal pre≈øently ≈øee the I≈ølands.

div.head: The 59. chapter. How to ≈øaile to the Hauen of Porto Seguro, that is, the ≈øure Hauen, lying in the coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia.
div.p: IF you de≈øire to ≈øaile to the Hauen of Porto Seguro, in the time of the Southea≈øt windes (which is in March and ≈øo forward) you ≈øhall not put higher then to 16. degr√©es & ¬Ω. for there it hath a Reddi≈øh ≈øand called Os Baixos dos Abrolhos, which are very dangerous and run very far into the ≈øea, and when you ≈øaile Ea≈øt & We≈øt you mu≈øt not be negligent to throw your Lead out often times, & being by the land & that you ≈ø√©e a long high hill like a ≈øharpe point, which is called Monte Pa≈øqual, froÃÑ thence you ≈øhall run Northward, & we≈øt, the ≈øame hill is we≈øtward from you, then you mu≈øt hold towards the land, yet with good regard and fore≈øight. And when you ≈ø√©e the land, and that you perceiue a round Houell, then Southward from the ≈øaide Houell you ≈øhall ≈øee a Hill with a great ≈øtrand, on the North ≈øide whereof lyeth the Hauen of Porto Seguro, and running along by the coa≈øt, aboue in the lande you find the towne of Porto Seguro. This height is a white ≈øtonie rocke, and on the North ≈øide of this ≈øtonie rocke there is a great vally: when you are Ea≈øt and we≈øt with this ≈øtonie rocke, then Northward you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the water breake, which is vpon a ≈øand reaching two miles into the Sea, on the South ≈øide whereof you are right ouer again≈øt the towne of Porto Seguro.

If you begin this voyage when the winds are northea≈øt & come to 15. degrees and ‚Öî. not ≈øeeing any hills, then leaue not running along the coa≈øt, & when you are vnder 15. degr√©es, the fir≈øt high land you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e, will be with white ≈øandy ≈øtrands along the ≈øea coa≈øt, & if vnder that height you ≈øee a riuer, then make not towardes the land, for there it hath certaine dangerous ≈øhallowes called Os Baixos de Sant Antonio, from thence Southward lyeth Porto Seguro, and pa≈ø≈øing along the coa≈øt and ≈ø√©eing the water breake vpon the other ≈øand lying two miles further inward to ≈øea, then you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe by it, k√©eping to ≈øeaward from it, and when you are at the end thereof, then the towne will be We≈øtward from you, you may well put to it, alwaies hauing a care how you goe and anker vnder the height afore≈øaid.

Departing from the I≈ølands to Porto Seguro, then you mu≈øt run 10. or 12. miles to Seaward from them to ≈øhun the ≈øands, lying by the riuer called Rio Grande, that is, the great Riuer, and when you are pa≈øt Rio Grande, then make towards the land againe to know it, as afore≈øaid.

div.head: The 60. Chapter. How to ≈øaile to the Hauen called Bahia d ‚Ä¢ E≈øpirito Santo, that is, the Bay of the Holy Gho≈øt, lying in the coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia.
div.p: SAiling to the hauen of Spirito Santo (b√©eing pa≈øt the Sandes called Os Baixos dos Abrolhos) vnder 19. degr√©es and ¬Ω. then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e lande at 20. degr√©es, for in this coa≈øt you haue no mon≈øons, or cour≈øes of certaine winds.

If you chance to ≈ø√©e land at 19. degr√©es and ¬Ω. and that it b√©e on the Northwe≈øt ≈øide from you being flat land, then you are on the North ≈øide of the Hauen of Spirito Santo, which is the land lying aboue Criquare, and aboue ye riuer called Rio Dolce, that is, the riuer of Sw√©et or fre≈øh water, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe along by the land, vntill the land beginneth to ri≈øe, hauing ≈øome Hilles, but tru≈øt not to the fir≈øt that you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e, but you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a high round hill which lyeth along by the ≈øea ≈øide, and is called La Sierra de Me≈øtre Aluaro.

And when you come to this Hill, on the North ≈øide you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a riuer called Rio dos Reis Magos, that is, the riuer of the thr√©e Kings of Cullen, and on the South ≈øide, then the mouth of the Baye will pre≈øently open. At the end of the ≈øaid hill on the South ≈øide, there is a point of ≈øtonie Cliffes called A punto do Tubaron, that is, the point of the Hedge: And on the South ≈øide of the Baye there are two or thr√©e high hilles, being there, you ≈øhall put right ouer to the Bay, and ≈øo run We≈øtward.

If you ≈øhould be in the ≈øame cour≈øe vnder twentie degr√©es, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e many hilles, among the which ≈øtandeth a high ≈øharpe point, called Serra de Guarapari, that is, the hill of Guarapari: it hath likewi≈øe another on the North ≈øide called A Serra de Pero Can, that is, the Hill of Peterwood: the≈øe hils ≈øtand on the South ≈øide of Spirito Santo. From the≈øe Hilles ≈øouthwarde you ≈øhall ≈øee a hill ≈øtanding alone, called Guape, & when you ≈ø√©e it, then you ≈øhall likewi≈øe ≈ø√©e thr√©e ≈ømall I≈ølandes lying togither, on the ≈øouth ≈øide whereof lyeth another ≈ømall, round, & flat I≈øland, and the land lying right again≈øt this rouÃÑd flat I≈øland hath a great Baye, where (if n√©ed be) you may put in and anker: if you de≈øire to goe into it, then you ≈øhall runne Ea≈øt and we≈øt with the hill, and ≈øo runne in, and then the round I≈øland will b√©e on the North ≈øide. This I≈øland is called Ilha de Repou≈øo, that is, the I≈øland of re≈øt, it lyeth very clo≈øe by the land, and betw√©ene it and the land you may well anker.

From the≈øe thr√©e I≈ølands afore≈øaid to the bay of Spirito Santo are 12. miles, and holding your cour≈øe Northward to Spirito Santo, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e another I≈øland lying alone, which you pa≈ø≈øe, running to Seaward by it, and being by it, you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e the mouth or Hauen of Spirito Santo: this bay or hauen lyeth vnder 20. degr√©es.

div.head: The 61. Chapter. To ≈øaile from the Bay or Hauen of Spirito Santo, to the Bay of S. Vincent.
div.p: SAyling from Spirito Santo to ye Bay S. Vincent, you mu≈øt runne along the coa≈øt about 7. or 8. miles from it, to the point called Cabo Frio, that is, the cold point, vntill you come to it: in the way you haue a great bay called A Bayho de Saluador, the Baye of our Sauiour, which is di≈øtant from Cabo Frio 12. miles.

Before you come to Cabo Frio, there are two I≈ølands, from the which you run to ≈øeaward, yet if n√©ed be, or if you de≈øire it, you may pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene them and the land. Cabo Frio hath an I≈øland right ouer again≈øt it, which hath a point where you may anker if n√©ede be on the We≈øt ≈øide, where it is faire and cl√©ere.

This Cabo Frio lieth vnder 23. degr√©es, from thence to the riuer called Rio de Ianero, that is, the riuer of Ianuarie are 18. miles: this riuer of Ianero hath thr√©e or foure I≈ølandes in the mouth thereof: If you will enter into this riuer, you may well goe in, taking your way betw√©ene two of the I≈ølandes that lie in the mouth thereof: on the South ≈øide of this riuer there is a Hill that ≈øheweth like a man with a Friars Coule or Cape vpon his head.

When you are vnder the height of this riuer, you ≈øhall to Landward ≈øee certaine high Hilles, which ≈øhewe like Organs,
which is a good marke to knowe that you are by the riuer, and when you begin to goe n√©ere the lande, you ≈øhall ≈øee a round, high, and bare I≈øland on the South ≈øide: the mouth of this riuer lieth vnder 23. degr√©es and ¬Ω. From this riuer to the Rode or open Hauen by the Portingales called Angra, are fift√©ene miles, and there are two riuers in the way, but being in that country, put not to the land, vnle≈ø≈øe you be compelled thereunto.

From the mouth of this riuer We≈øt Southwe≈øt, and Southwe≈øt & by We≈øt, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a great I≈øland called A Ilha de Sant Seba≈øtian, which on the Southwe≈øt ≈øide hath another ≈ømall high I≈øland called A Ilha dos Alcatra≈øes, that is, the I≈ølande of Seamewes: before you come at it, you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe We≈øtward, to ≈øhunne certaine Sands that lie by it, whereby you ≈øhall come to the mouth of the bay of Saint Vincent, where you ≈øhall ≈øee an I≈øland called Ilha da Muda, that is, the I≈øland of the Dumbe woman: and to put into the Bay of S. Vincent, you ≈øhall leaue the I≈ølandes on the Ea≈øt ≈øide. The Bay of Saint Vincent lyeth vnder 24. degr√©es, and if you be to leeward from it, then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e many I≈ølands, whereof ≈øome ≈øtretcheth outward, which are the be≈øt markes for this Hauen, and being there, you are Northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt with the mouth of the Bay.

div.head: The 62. Chapter. How to ≈øaile from Cabo Frio, or the cold point, to the riuer of Rio de Plata, or the riuer of ≈øiluer, with all the cour≈øe thereof.
div.p: FRom Cabo Frio to the riuer of Ianero or Ianuarie, are eight√©ene miles, and you ≈øaile Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and lyeth vnder 23. degr√©es, and hath the≈øe markes: Fir≈øt, inward to the land it hath certaine high Hilles called Organs, but at this time mo≈øt of them are falne down: and on the We≈øt Southwe≈øt ≈øide towards the Sea ≈øide, it hath the forme of the Ma≈ø≈ø of a ≈øhippe, and in the mouth of the riuer lieth foure I≈ølands, whereof one is high and round which is a good marke, as al≈øo the Sugar loafe, being a houell that is called ≈øo, lying in the Hauen, although you can not ≈ø√©e it when you are at ≈øea: you may ≈øaile along this coa≈øt without daunger, and you need feare nothing but that you ≈ø√©e before your eyes. From thence to Saint Vincent the coa≈øt reacheth Ea≈øt Northea≈øt, and We≈øt Southwe≈øt, and is in length two and fortie miles: and all that way there is neither ≈øhallowes nor Sandes, but there you finde good Hauens for all winds.

Twelue miles from the riuer lieth an I≈øland called Ilha grande, or the great I≈øland, which hath verie good Hauens as well on the Southwe≈øt as the Ea≈øt ≈øides, with very good fre≈øh water, and great fi≈øhing, it is a high lande with many trees, and inwarde to the lande it is verie high and ≈øharpe pointed: if you de≈øire to put in there, you n√©ed not feare to do it, for there is no danger.

From this great I≈øland to the I≈øland of S. Seba≈øtian are eighteene miles, and to the I≈øland A Ilha dos Porcos, that is, the I≈øland of Hogges, are fourt√©ene miles: the I≈øles of Hogges hath a very good Hauen, but it is too farre inward. FroÃÑ thence to the I≈øland of Saint Seba≈øtian are foure miles, which is a great high I≈øland, full of trees, it hath a verie good entrie, as well on the one ≈øide as on the other, it lyeth Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt. From thence to the lande about halfe a mile di≈øtant lyeth the Rode: Southwe≈øtwarde there lyeth another long I≈øland called A Ilha dos Alcatra≈øes, or the I≈øland of Sea-mewes. Clo≈øe by this I≈øland there lyeth three Cliffes, on the South ≈øide whereof lyeth an I≈øland, which is a verie good marke, for the land is ≈øometimes couered with mi≈øte and thicke weather, whereby you can not knowe it, but when you ≈øee this I≈øland, then you may knowe where you are.

From this I≈øland to S. Vincents are twelue miles, which is a plea≈øant way, and in that countrey there are three ≈ømall I≈ølands called As Ilhas de Boa Sicanga. From the≈øe I≈ølandes to the Hauen called A Berra de Birtioga are ≈øixe miles, which is a verie good & a deepe Hauen. Between the I≈ølandes afore≈øaid & this Hauen lieth another rouÃÑd I≈øland called Monte de Trigo, that is, the hill or heape of wheate, which is a verie good marke for ≈øuch as de≈øire to put into the Hauen of Bertioga.

From this Hauen to the Hauen called A Berra d'E≈øteuao da Co≈øta, that is, the hauen of Steuen da Co≈øta, are fiue miles: this is a good Hauen for great ≈øhippes, it hath a very good Bay for ≈øhippes to lie in:
and if you will not put into it, outwarde clo≈øe by the land you haue an I≈øland called A Ilha da Moela, that is, the I≈øland of Ch√©e≈øe, where you may anker.

From this Hauen Southwe≈øtward, lieth an I≈øland called A Ilha Queimada, that is, the burnt I≈øland, which is a flat I≈øland all ≈øtonie, but along by it, it is faire ground, like South ≈øouthea≈øtward. From the Hauen, lyeth a Cliffe, which of many men is not knowne: it lyeth aboue the water, and is in the middle way betw√©en the I≈øland Dos Alcatra≈øes and Ilha Queimada: From thence to the I≈øland called Canaueas, that is, the I≈øland of R√©edes, are thr√©e miles, & you run North Northea≈øt, and South Southwe≈øt along by the coa≈øt. Canaueia is an I≈øland that hath a verie good Hauen and fre≈øh water, and lieth vnder 23. degr√©es and ¬Ω. on the ≈øouth ≈øide it hath two Rockie I≈ølands, whereof the one is ≈øomewhat long and round, and right ouer again≈øt it lyeth the riuer called Rio de Canauea, where you may put in with ≈ømall ≈øhips.

From Canauea to the I≈øland called A Ilha de Santa Caterina, are 48. miles, and you run along the coa≈øt North & South: This is a long I≈øland full of tr√©es, it lieth by the coa≈øt which reacheth North and South. On the North ≈øide at the entry of the Hauen it hath two I≈ølands, and on the South ≈øide another I≈øland called A Galle, that is, the I≈øland of the Gally: on the North ≈øide thereof you can not enter but onely with ≈ømall Barkes and ≈øhips: but on the South ≈øide it hath a very good entrie for great ≈øhips, it hath much fre≈øh water, and great ≈øtore of fi≈øh and wilde Deere. This I≈øland lyeth vnder 28. degrees and ¬Ω.

From thence to the Hauen called O Porto de Don Rodrygo are fiue myles, and fiue miles further forward lyeth the Hauen called dos Patos, that is, the Hauen of G√©e≈øe, by ≈øome called La Laguna, that is, the Lake: This Hauen ≈øerueth for Barkes and ≈ømall ≈øhips that traffique in tho≈øe countries.

From thence to the riuer of Rio de Plata, there is not one hauen where you may put in, the coa≈øt reaching North Northea≈øt and South Southwea≈øt. Sayling from the afore≈øaid I≈øland of S. Caterina to Rio de Plata, you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe ≈øouthward to the height of 34. degrees & ‚Öî. Then you mu≈øt put to the land, & when you ≈ø√©e it, which at the fir≈øt ≈øheweth like an I≈øland called los Ca≈øtillos, then you ≈øhall run along the coa≈øt, which will lie Southwe≈øtward, Southwe≈øt and by We≈øt, and we≈øt ≈øouthwe≈øt from you, and make not your account to ≈ø√©e the Cape de Sancta Maria, for the land there is ≈øo flat, that there you can not di≈øcerne any ≈øigne or token of a point, but there you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e certaine riffes, but you n√©ed not feare any thing more then that you ≈ø√©e before your eies: and if you chance not to ≈ø√©e any land running towardes it, then ca≈øt out your Lead, and there you ≈øhall find 10.14. and 18. fadome d√©epe, therfore feare not for it is all one kind of ground, and you are in a good way. Being there as afore≈øaid, then run as long as you can well di≈øcerne the land, & then you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e an I≈øland called A Ilha dos Lobos, that is, the I≈øland of Wolues, for there you ≈ø√©e many wolues: it is a flat I≈øland all full of ≈øtones, on the ≈øouth ≈øide it hath an I≈øland and on the ea≈øt a Riffe, but you n√©ede not feare any other then that you ≈ø√©e before your eies. This I≈øland is di≈øtant from the Firme land about two miles and ¬Ω. towards the northwe≈øt, & from this I≈øland of Wolues there lieth a ≈ømall flat I≈øland, with a low wood clo≈øe by the land, which hath a good hauen to anker in, if you haue any tempe≈øt out of the Southwe≈øt. If you pa≈ø≈øe along by this I≈øland on the Ea≈øt Southea≈øt ≈øide, then goe n√©ere the point or hooke of the firme lande, which is a lowe ≈øtony point, and betw√©ene this point and the I≈øland lyeth a ≈øand which you ≈øhall pre≈øently ≈ø√©e by the water that breaketh vpon it, and if you enter on the Northea≈øt ≈øide you n√©ede not feare any thing: and to anker, k√©epe clo≈øe by the I≈øland, for there you haue fre≈øh water, and great ≈øtore of fi≈øh vpon the ground.

B√©eing there, you mu≈øt b√©e carefull, for there beginneth the fir≈øt high Lande, and from it about eight or ten myles further, lyeth a ≈øand that is verie dangerous, and is about foure miles from the Firme Lande, being two myles in length: you mu≈øt runne betw√©ene it and the Firme lande, and when you ≈øayle from the high land afore≈øaide, for the ≈øpace of a mile and a halfe or two myles, you mu≈øt k√©epe harde by the ≈øhoare, becau≈øe of the ≈øande afore≈øaide, and from thence with your Leade in your hande, with good watch and fore≈øight, and if it bee not ≈øea≈øonable
weather to ≈øaile by night, then your be≈øt way were to anker and to ≈øtay till it bee day, the better to make your voiage.

And when you thinke you are pa≈øt this ≈øand, then you ≈øhal ≈ø√©e a hill called O monte de Santo Sered ‚Ä¢ o, which is a rounde high hill, the like whereof is not in tho≈øe countries to bee founde: betw√©ene the which hill and the ≈øandes afore≈øaid, lyeth an I≈øland called A Ilha das Flores, that is, the I≈øland of Flowers, which you may pa≈ø≈øe about without danger.

And when you come into the ≈øalt or fre≈øh water, which floweth fiue and twentie miles beneath the riuer called Rio de Buenos Aires, that is, the Riuer of good aire, where the water is verie fre≈øh, then hold your cour≈øe We≈øt, and then you ≈øhal be eight or ten miles beneath the Riuer of good aire, which is the be≈øt cour≈øe you can holde, but I adui≈øe you ≈øtill to haue your Lead in hand, and when you are at thr√©e or foure fadome water, then ≈øaile no further if it b√©e by night, but in the day time you may ≈ø√©e whither you ≈øaile, which mu≈øt be in ≈øight of land, and ≈øo neere, that you may ea≈øily di≈øcerne the tr√©es, holding two miles from the land, for you can not pa≈ø≈øe by the Riuer of good aire without ≈ø√©eing the hou≈øes that ≈øtand vpon the ≈øame. The mo≈øt part of the land of the Riuer of good aire, is a thicke land like a downe, about thr√©e miles along by the ≈øea ≈øide, as ≈øoone as you ≈ø√©e this lande, then you mu≈øt make right towards the hou≈øes, yet ≈øomwhat more towards the ≈øouth ≈øide, where there is a place where the ≈øhippes anker: but if you de≈øire to runne on the North ≈øide, then you ≈øhall take your cour≈øe from the I≈øland las Flores, or from Santa Horodio about a mile and a halfe from the land at three and ¬Ω. or foure fadome, to the I≈ølands of Saint Gabriel, which are thr√©e ≈ømal I≈ølands, but they haue no good Rode: and if you chance to anker there, goe not a ≈øhore but verie warily, becau≈øe the inhabitants haue warres with the Spaniards and Portingales all along the riuer, but the be≈øt cour≈øe is on the South ≈øide, from the fre≈øh water inwards.

div.head: The 63. Chapter. How to ≈øaile from the I≈øland La Gomera, one of the I≈ølands of Canaria, to the Antillas or ≈øore I≈ølandes of the Spani≈øh Indies, and from thence to the coa≈øt of the Firme land to Cartagena and Nombre de Dios, as al≈øo the cour≈øe from thence to the Hauana and the channell thereof, and ≈øo to the Flemi ‚Ä¢ h I≈ølands, and from thence to Spai ‚Ä¢ ne, with the ≈øcituation of the places.
div.p: SAyling from the I≈øland La Gomera to the I≈øland called La De≈ø≈øeada, that is, the De≈øired I≈øland, being one of the I≈ølandes of the Spani≈øh Indies, then you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe South for the ≈øpace of a mealetide, ≈øo to get out of the calme: from thence you mu≈øt runne We≈øt Southwe≈øt till you be vnder 20. or 22. degr√©es, and beeing there you mu≈øt runne We≈øt, and We≈øt and by South, till you come vnder fifteene degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . which is the height of the I≈øland La De≈ø≈øeada: If (when you are there) you haue a We≈øt winde, then run Southwe≈øt as farre as you thinke good, thereby to get againe vnder fifteene degr√©es and ¬Ω. running on the wether ≈øide We≈øt Northwe≈øt, to bring all to one point whereby you ≈øhall find helpe, from North and South, Ea≈øt and We≈øt, becau≈øe you are clo≈øe by the lande, holding your cour≈øe We≈øt and we≈øt and by north, becau≈øe the compa≈ø≈øe windeth a ≈øtrike into the Northwe≈øt, with the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall ≈øee the I≈øland la De≈ø≈øeada. This I≈øland lieth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and ≈øheweth like a Gallie with her tilt vp: on the ea≈øt ≈øide it is a low land, in forme like a bore-≈øprit of a ≈øhippe or galley: from the We≈øt ≈øide it is high land, ≈øhewing like the ≈øterne of a gally, and on the South ≈øide it ≈øheweth like halfe an I≈øland, the hinder part thereof being like a hor≈øe ≈øhoe.

The I≈øland called Ma ‚Ä¢ galante is a low and flat land, and reacheth Ea≈øt & We≈øt, being full of tr√©es, on the Ea≈øt ≈øide beeing highe≈øt, and on the South ≈øide hauing certaine white downes, & on the We≈øt ≈øide about halfe a mile from the I≈øland it hath a blacke ≈øhining cliffe. This I≈øland lyeth full vnder fifteene degrees.

The I≈øland la Dominica is a great I≈øland and reacheth Northwe≈øt and ≈øouthea≈øt, when you ≈ø√©e it fir≈øt (beeing on the out≈øide therof) it ≈øheweth like 2. I≈ølands, by rea≈øon of a great opening it hath in the middle, but when you are clo≈øe by it, then you perceiue it to be all one I≈øland, it is full of hils, on the Southea≈øt ≈øide a lowe land, hauing a ≈ømall or thin point of land
with a houell vpon it, on the North-we≈øt ≈øide it is thicke high Land, hauing a Hill that ≈øeemeth to bee ≈øeperated, and to ≈øtand alone by it ≈øelfe, although it is not alone. Vpon this hil there is a rock which ≈øheweth like a clock hou≈øe, & without the afore≈øaid thicke high Land, there is a Rocke or cliffe which runneth off froÃÑ ye thick point. This I≈øland lyeth vnder 15. degr√©es & ¬Ω.
The I≈ølands called Los Santos, are four I≈ølands which are not very high, lying in Triangle. Betweene the≈øe I≈ølands and the I≈øland La Dominica, there runneth a good channell to pa≈ø≈øe through.

Sayling from the I≈øland La Dominica to the Point of Coquibocoa, lying from the Firme Lande, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe We≈øt, and We≈øt and by South, vntill you bee by the point, and if you ≈ø√©e it not, then runne ≈øouthwe≈øtward towards it, or Southward, vntill you ≈ø√©e it. This Point of Coquibocoa is a low Land, running into Seaward, and within the lande it hath a rowe of Hilles, which are called the Oile Hils, which ≈øtretch along by Veuan≈øuela, where they end, which vpon the coa≈øt of the Firme land. From this Point you runne along the coa≈øt to the Point called Cabo de Vela, and betw√©ene the≈øe two Points there are two hauens, wherof one is called Bahya Honda, (that is, the deepe Bay. This lieth on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, and on both ≈øides where the Sea beateth, it hath downes: The other Hauen lying on the We≈øt ≈øide, within it hath a high Land or Hill, which reacheth North and South. In both the≈øe Hauens you may enter with Ships of two hundred tunnes. All this coa≈øt to Cabo de la Vela is cleare and ≈øafe. The point Cabo de la Vela, is a high land like a ≈øuger loafe, and about half a mile from it, there is a cliffe, which ≈øheweth like a ≈øhip vnder ≈øaile, and therefore this Point is called Cabo de la Vela, that is, the point of the ≈øaile. This Cliffe lieth Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt, with ye Point afore≈øaid it is ≈øaid you may well pa≈ø≈øe betw√©ene it and the lande, and if you depart from the ≈øaied Point, to ≈øaile to the Cliffe and Point called Cabo de la aguia, (that is, the Point of the N√©edle) then you ≈øhall runne We≈øt South-we≈øt, by the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall ≈øee it. They are foure Cliffes together, which ≈øhewe in forme like a Hor≈øe ≈øhooe, and the Lande that is right again≈øt it, is a high Land. Beeing inward to the Lande ≈øome what higher, which is called Las Sierras Neuadas, that is, the Snowe Hils, when the≈øe hils are Southward from you, then you are right again≈øt the foure cliffes.

And comming to the beginning of the foure Cliffes, hauing pa≈øt the Riuer De Palomina lying by the la≈øt Cliffe, then you ≈øhall ≈øee the Cabo de La aguia. This Cape is a ≈øtill Lande, de≈øcending downeward to the Sea ≈øide, but not very high, on the toppe hauing a Dale, which ≈øheweth like a ≈øaddle. It hath likewi≈øe on the out ≈øide (clo≈øe by it) thr√©e blacke ≈øhining Cliffes, which the water dooth almo≈øt flowe ouer: they lye with the Cape afore≈øaid North and South. The ≈øaied Cape is bare, & ≈øheweth blacki≈øh and ≈øhining.

All this coa≈øt reacheth almo≈øt Ea≈øt and We≈øt. From Cabo de Sancta Marta forward, you mu≈øt runne along by the coa≈øt, alwaies looking to your cour≈øe, becau≈øe of the Billowes and ≈øtreames that come from the Lande, which oftentimes fal vpon you. When you di≈øcouer the land of Charthagena, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e two Cliffes, which lye by the Hauen of Charthagena, you mu≈øt runne along by the fir≈øt Cliffe, betw√©ene it and the Lande, alwaies with your Lead in hand, and you mu≈øt not goe n√©erer then ten fadome to the Land, there you ≈øhall find white ≈øandy ground, and being at fift√©ene or ≈øixt√©ene fadome muddye ground, then k√©epe aloofe to the Southea≈øt and South, and ≈øo runne in, for you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the hole open before you.

Sayling from Carthagena to Nombre de Dios, (that is, the name of God) with the winds called Bri≈øas (which are windes blowing from the Ea≈øt and North parts, generally called Bri≈øas) then you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe We≈øt, and ≈øomewhat We≈øt and by South, till you be vnder 9. degr√©es and ¬Ω. vnder the which heigth lyeth the point called Cantina, which are ≈øeuen I≈ølands, whereof fiue ≈øtretch ea≈øt and we≈øt, the other two Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt.

Being ≈øomewhat pa≈øt the≈øe I≈ølandes, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e a low point of Land reaching into the Sea, called A Punta de Lambras, which lyeth on the We≈øt ≈øide, and We≈øtward from it, it hath a Hill which is ≈øomewhat higher then the Point, which you may well di≈øcerne when you make to Sea-warde from it, and that the Point lyeth South-we≈øt-warde from you, the ≈øaid Hill hauing on the Southea≈øt ≈øide certaine lowe Lande, and
≈øomewhat more We≈øtward, the Lande beginneth to bee higher, which endeth at the Riuer of Franci≈øco. At the mouth of this Riuer to Sea-ward from it, lyeth a ≈øtony cliffe, and from this Riuer to Nombre de Dios, it is all ouer a flat and red ≈øhining Lande, to the houell called Niquea, which is about a myle from Nombre de Dios, you ≈øhall likewi≈øe ≈ø√©e the edifices or buildings of Capira, and if a man ≈øhould a≈øk you (when tho≈øe buildings lye Northea≈øt from you) where you are, then you may an≈øwere him, that you are vpon the coa≈øt of the lande North-ea≈øt and Southwe≈øt beneath Nombre de Dios.

Sayling from Nombre de Dios to Carthagena, you ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe Ea≈øt Northea≈øt to the point, from thence you mu≈øt runne Ea≈øt, whereby you ≈øhall di≈øcouer the I≈ølands of Saint Barnard, which are low and yet Hill I≈ølandes, with very faire ground along by them, and if you ≈øhould be in a Frigate, then you may pa≈ø≈øe betweene them and the land. Fiue or ≈øixe miles further you ≈øhall ≈øee the I≈ølands called Braua which are foure ≈ømall I≈ølands, whereof the furthe≈øt outward is the greate≈øt, they are all lowe, and bare Lande, hauing by them faire and cleare ground, and with a Frigate you may pa≈ø≈øe inward, but with a ≈øhippe you mu≈øt not goe neerer then ≈øixe fadome. From thence ea≈øt Southea≈øtward, you ≈øhall ≈ø√©e the Gally of Carthagena, with the markes afore≈øaied, & in the Ea≈øt and Ea≈øt Northea≈øt bough, you ≈øhall ≈øee the Land Cari≈øcos, which is a high and hill land. From thence you mu≈øt runne along by the coa≈øt, vntill you begin to ≈ø√©e the Hauen, then you mu≈øt put in, alwaies ≈øhunning the ≈øands of Carys, running along by the ea≈øt point, being there, if night falleth vpon you, then you may anker betweene Carys and Baru, in the ≈øure≈øt place you can finde, to defend you from the windes called Bri≈øas, by the high Lande of Carys, and if you put out of the Hauen of Nombre de Dios, you ≈øhall lauere till you ≈ø√©e the buildings that are beyond it, and ≈øayling into the Hauen, you ≈øhall doe as wind ≈øerueth.

Sayling from Carthagena to the I≈øland of Hauana, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe North-we≈øt, till you come to thirt√©ene degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ . and when you are vnder thirteene degr√©es, then you ≈øhall let your ≈øelfe driue South South-ea≈øt and South, as the manner is, vntill you bee pa≈øt the heigth, or bee out thereof, or in the depth, and when you are vpon the ground of the Serrana, then you ≈øhall ≈øleepe towardes it as much as you can, and if it bee po≈ø≈øible you ≈øhall hold Northward, for ≈øo you ≈øhall the ≈øooner be there. From the point of Cabo de Camaron to Cabo de Roncador, with the Sea ≈øtrand that ≈øtretcheth from the one to the other, as al≈øo from Serrana and Serranilla, (being I≈ølands and Cliffes ≈øo called) on the we≈øt ≈øide of all the≈øe ≈øands is great ≈øande, with Fi≈øh ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ales vpon the ground, and the lea≈øt depth you find there, is fift√©ene fadome wa ‚Ä¢ r, being all faire and in this depth you ≈øhall runne till you bee ouer it, and being ouer, you ≈øhall pre≈øently begin to multiply or ri≈øe till you bee at fiftie fadome deep and ≈øomewhat more. Serrana lieth vnder foureteen degrees and ¬Ω. and Serranilla vnder ≈øixteene degrees. If you ≈ø√©e Serranilla on the We≈øt ≈øide, on that ≈øide it is a lowe ≈øandye I≈øland, ≈øtretching Northwe≈øt and Southea≈øt. Sayling from Serranilla or Cabo de Roncador to ye point of S. Anton lying in the I≈øland Cuba, yu ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall holde your cour≈øe Northwe≈øt, and Northwe≈øt and by north, wherewith you ≈øhall di≈øcouer the Cape afore≈øaied, or the Cape de coryentes, (that is, the Point of the ≈øtreames) which is a clouen Point towards the ≈øea ≈øide, being lowe Land, on it hauing ≈øome Palme Trees. From thence to Cabo de S. A ‚Ä¢ n, the Land beginneth to b√©e lower, & the coa≈øt ≈øtretcheth Northwe≈øt and ≈øouth-ea≈øt. The cape de S. Anton is a low ≈øandy Point vpon it hauing two or three houels, and lieth vnder 22. degrees. If in this cour≈øe you chaunce to ≈øee the I≈øland called Cayman Grande, that is, the great Cayman. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that it lieth vnder nineteene degrees, and is low land ful of Trees, ≈øtretching ea≈øt and we≈øt, on the ≈øouth-≈øide hauing ≈øome white ≈øandy ≈øtrands. Sailing from the Point of S. Anton, with the windes called Vendaval, (which are We≈øt and South windes, generally called Vendaua ‚Ä¢ es, as the Ea≈øt and North windes are called B ‚Ä¢ ≈øas) to the Hauana, then you mu≈øt runne Northea≈øt to ≈øhunne the droughtes that runne out from this Point, which reach to the beginning of the hils called Los Organos, (that is, the Organs) and when you are pa≈øt the ≈øands, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe along by the coa≈øt, for there you neede feare nothing more then that you ≈øee before you.

The Organs are certaine high Tr√©es, which make manye openings and rents, whereof tho≈øe on the South-≈øide are called the point of Guanico, the≈øe Organs or hils reach to the Riuer called Rio de Por
‚Ä¢
that is, the riuer of hogs from thence begin the Hils called the Cabinas, which are high and doubled, on the highe≈øt of theÃÑ hauing a playne or flat Lande, there you haue a Hauen called El Puerto de Cabanas, Ea≈øtward from this point to the field of Mariam, it is low flat land ful of Trees, where there is another Hauen: From thence to Hauana it is all lowe land without any ri≈øings, except one Houell, lying right ouer again≈øt the Hauana, which is a clouen hill, vpon it hauing a ≈øharpe point, called Atalaya, that is, a guard, and beeing North and South with the Hauen, within the Lande you ≈øhal ≈øee two Hils, which ≈øhew like two teates of a womans dugs, and to put into it, you mu≈øt keepe your cour≈øe along by the houell.

If you depart from the Point afore≈øaid with the winds called Bri≈øas, then you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe to the Cliffes called
‚Ä¢ ortugas (that is, the Torteaux) as winde ≈øerueth, and you mu≈øt ≈øee what depth you find: for if there you finde fortie fadome water, then you are on the South-≈øide thereof, and finding 30. fadome, then you are Ea≈øt and We≈øt right again≈øt it, and being at any of the≈øe depths, you ≈øhal hold your cour≈øe South South-we≈øt vntil you ≈øee the land, which you ≈øhall di≈øcouer from the field or Hauen thereof: and if you ≈øee a Land that is ≈øomewhat high, hauing ≈øome Hils and Dales that ≈øhewe like the fingers of a mans hand, then it is the land ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d Narugo from thence you ≈øhal runne to H ‚Ä¢ ea ‚Ä¢ a, holding your cour≈øe along by the coa≈øt.

Sayling out of Hauana to the Martirs, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe Northea≈øt, by the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall ≈øee the Point, which is three ≈ømall I≈ølandes, whereof that in the middle is the greate≈øt, the vttermo≈øt being the Ea≈øt coa≈øt, and the inwarde≈øt the North-ea≈øt and South-we≈øt coa≈øt. From thence North-ea≈øt-ward to the Cape De Canauerales (that is ye point of Reedes) the coa≈øt ≈øtretcheth North and South and North-ea≈øt-ward you ≈øhall ≈øee no land, and being vnder fiue and twentie degrees, then you are in the mouth of the channel, which to pa≈ø≈øe through, you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe Northea≈øt, and if you ≈øee not the Cape de Canauerales being vnder 28. degrees and
‚Ä¢ /2. then you are without the channell.

Sayling out of the Hauana (with the windes called Bri≈øas) to the channell, you mu≈øt runne outwards till it be noone, and after noone you ≈øhall make to Landward, that towards euening you may bee by it, and to v≈øe the Windes called Terreinhos, (which are Windes that blowe by night from off the land) running in this manner along by the coa≈øt, vntill you bee North and South with the Houell called El Pan de Matancas, (that is, the loafe of Matancas being North and South with ye ≈øame loafe, you mu≈øt runne Northea≈øt, if the winde will permit, if not, you mu≈øt put to the coa≈øt of Florida, where the winde will driue you doing your be≈øt, in that way to goe out of your cour≈øe as little as you may, for the ≈øtreames runne with great force towards that Lande, and when you thinke it time, then you ≈øhall put to the other ≈øide, as the winde will leade you, till you ≈øee the Lande, and when you ≈ø√©e it, then winde, in this ≈øort running through, and being vnder 28. degr√©es and ¬Ω. then you are out of the Channell: hereof I adui≈øe that the ≈øtrikes you make in lauering towards the land of Florida mu≈øt be ≈øhort, and tho≈øe towardes the Coa≈øt of Minare long, for the ≈øtreames driue you to the Lande of Florida. The Hils of Chupiona come out by the loafe of Matancas (and are certaine not too high and euen Hils) flat on the toppe, with certaine white ≈øhining houels. The loafe of Matancas is a high Houell, flat aboue, ≈øtretching northea≈øt and South-we≈øt, and on both ≈øides as well North-ea≈øtward, as ≈øouthwe≈øtward, it hath two low Points, lower then ye ≈øaid loafe, which ≈øhew like the heads of Torteaux. On the North-ea≈øt ≈øide the Lande ≈øtretcheth lowe, and from thence Northward it maketh a ≈ømall Point. Behinde this Point lyeth the Hauen of Matancas, and to enter therein you mu≈øt run Northea≈øt and Southwe≈øt right again≈øt the ≈øaid loafe, and then the Hauen will bee South from you, and you mu≈øt runne ≈øouthward to it, it is a great Bay, and there you haue no Road, but clo≈øe by the Land, comming out you leaue the loafe on the South-≈øide, and you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe north-ea≈øt, till you be out.

And being out of the Channell, if it b√©e in Winter, you ≈øhall run Ea≈øt, wherwith
you ≈øhall holde Ea≈øt and by North, by the winding or declining of the compa≈ø≈øe: By the which cour≈øe you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe on the South-≈øide of the I≈ølands and Cliffes of Bermuda, and this cour≈øe you ≈øhall holde till you bee vnder the heigth of the I≈øland Fayael, one of the Flemi≈øh I≈ølands, which is a great I≈øland, ≈øtretching North-we≈øt and Southea≈øt on the Southea≈øt ≈øide, hauing a thicke Land, and on the northea≈øt ≈øide ≈øomewhat lower land. To ≈øaile from thence to the I≈øland of Tercera, you ≈øhall hold your cour≈øe outward of the I≈øland of S. George, ea≈øt, and ea≈øt & by North. The I≈øland of S. George is a high Lande, ≈øtretching Ea≈øt and We≈øt, as al≈øo Tercera, which on the South≈øide hath a clouen hill, called O Bra≈øil, and a little ea≈øtward from thence, there lieth thr√©e cliffes. The Iland of S. Michael is a great high I≈øland, ≈øtretching Ea≈øt and We≈øt, on the We≈øt ≈øide being lowe, and on the Ea≈øt ≈øide high. It hath likewi≈øe a clouen hil, lying at the end on the Ea≈øt ≈øide. This I≈øland lyeth vnder 38. degr√©es.

div.head: The 64. Chapter. The cour≈øe and right markes from the I≈øland La De≈ø≈øeada, to the lande and coa≈øt of Carthagena, Nombre de Dios, new Spain, and from the channell of Hauana.
div.p: IF you de≈øire to ≈øayle through the Channell that runneth betw√©ene the I≈øland La Antigua, & La De≈øleada towards the coa≈øt, you mu≈øt holde your cour≈øe We≈øt to the I≈øland of Montecerratte, running along by the I≈øland of Guadalupe, which is an I≈øland clouen through the middle, & higher on the We≈øt then on the Ea≈øt ≈øide. The I≈øland La Antigua, (that is, the old I≈øland) you ≈øhal find on the North≈øide of Guadalupe, ≈øtretching in length Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and hath Hils with outward ≈øhew like Ilands, and lieth vnder 16. degr√©es and 1/ ‚Ä¢ .

The markes of the I≈øland Montecerratte are the≈øe. It is round and high like the I≈øland La Gomera in the Canaries, and hath ≈øome Hilles with certaine Water beakes. Sailing from this I≈øland Montecerratte, you mu≈øt runne We≈øt Northwe≈øt, whereby you ≈øhall di≈øcouer the I≈øland Sancta Crus, but you mu≈øt not runne too clo≈øe by it, for there it is foule, and no cleare ground, it ≈øtretcheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and is Hilly, but not verie high, beeing higher on the We≈øt then on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, in the middle≈øt hath a rent or partition, and on the Ea≈øt ≈øide there is a Roade where you may anker, for there it is faire ≈øandye ground. To ≈øayle from Sancta Crus to the I≈øland of Puerto Riquo (that is, the Iland of the rich Hauen) on the South≈øide, you mu≈øt runne We≈øt Northwe≈øt, whereby you ≈øhall di≈øcouer the hill called Sierta de Loquillo, and from thence to Cabo Roxo you ≈øhall ≈øayle We≈øt and We≈øt and by North, keeping along by the land vntill you be by the cape afore≈øaide, which is the vttermo≈øt part of the ≈øame I≈øland.

This point called Cabo Roxo, (that is, the red point) is a thin and lowe lande, on the ≈øea ≈øide hauing certaine redde ≈øhining downes, and on the North-we≈øt ≈øide you ≈ø√©e the hils called I as Sierras de S. German, which are very high, but not ≈øo high as tho≈øe of Loquillo. From this point of Cabo Roxo, you mu≈øt hold your cour≈øe we≈øt, and we≈øt and by North, whereby you ≈øhal di≈øcouer the I≈øland called De la mona, that is, the I≈øland of the ape, and you mu≈øt run along. by the ≈øouth≈øide thereof. The I≈øland La Mona, is a low land, and reacheth Ea≈øt and We≈øt, on the ≈øea ≈øide being a plaine land de≈øcending downward, on the north≈øide it hath a Cliffe or ≈ømall I≈øland called Monica, or the little ape. div.head: Certain que≈øtions & an≈øweres very profitable & nece≈ø≈øarie to be knowne by all Saylers.
div.p: IF a man ≈øhould a≈øke you how many degr√©es are in the Compa≈ø≈øe of the whole world: you may an≈øwer, there are 360. degrees, each degr√©e being 15. Dutch miles, and 17. Spani≈øh miles and a halfe.
Que≈øtion. What are the Poles of the world?
An≈øwer. Two points that are imagined or thought yt the world is born or hangeth vpon.
Q. What is the Equinoctiall line?

A. A ≈øtrike or line placed from Ea≈øt to we≈øt, about the compa≈ø≈øe or roundnes of the worlde, which is the ≈øeperation or middle between both the Poles, and when the Sunne is vpon it, which is the 21. of March, and the 23. of September, (≈øtilo nouo) then the day & night are of a length, and therefore it is called the Equinoctiall line.
Q. What is the Meridian?
A. A ≈øtrike or line placed in the Compa≈ø≈øe of the world, from the one Pole to the other, and when the ≈øhadow is in the middle of this line, then it is your Meridian.
Q. What is the Parallel?
A. All things or places that lie right ea≈øt and We≈øt from you are Parallel.
Q. What is Tropicus?

A. A ≈øtrike or line imagined or placed in the compa≈ø≈øe of the firmament, which is the fixed place, how neare the Sun goeth to the line, & turneth back againe, which is the 21. of Iune (≈øtilo nouo) it coÃÑmeth vpoÃÑ the north ≈øide of the Equinoctiall, to 23. degr√©es and ¬Ω. which place is called Tropicus Canc ‚Ä¢ i, and the 21. of Decemb. it commeth on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Equinoctiall, to the like height of degrees, which place is called Tropicus Capricorni.
Q. How farre is it betw√©ene the Equinoctiall line, and any of the two Poles?
A. 90. degr√©es, which is the fourth part of the compas of ye whole world or firmameÃÑt.
Q. What is the Horizon?
A. It is the compa≈ø≈øe you can ≈øee round about you, as farre as till that you think the earth and ≈øky meeteth together, which is 90. degrees from you and that is the Horizon.
Q. What is the Zenith?
A. All that part of the sky that ≈øtandeth right ouer your head, is the Zenith.
Q. What is the longitude & the latitude?
A. Longitude is the length, and Latitude the breadth of the way you make.
Q. If you be vnder the Pole Articus or the North ≈øtar, whether as then your Compa≈ø≈øe can ≈øhew you & guide you right in the cour≈øe you are to hold?

A. No, for being in that countrey the n√©edle of the Compa≈ø≈øe where it is lined, will be drawne vpwards towards the gla≈ø≈øe, wherby it cannot worke or ≈øhew his nature, but being ≈øomewhat from it, in ≈øuch manner that the Pole hath no more place or power ouer it, to draw it vpwardes, then the Compa≈ø≈øe will pre≈øently worke and ≈øhewe her effect, whereby you hold on your cour≈øe.

That vpon that day you ≈øhall haue the Sunne for your Zenith, that is right ouer your head, and then you ≈øhal find no ≈øhadow on eyther ≈øide, then you mu≈øt looke vppon the declination of the day, and all that you finde from the declination, ≈øo much you are di≈øtant from the Equinoctiall line towardes the ≈øun, and that is your height.

A. At that day the Sun is di≈øtant from the Equinoctiall line 23. degr√©es and ¬Ω. whervnto adding other 23. degr√©es and ¬Ω. they make 47. degr√©es, and then there wanteth 43. deg. to make vp 90. degr. the≈øe 43. degr√©es ≈øhall you take in the A≈øtrolabe, for the height of the Sunne.

A. I, but they mu≈øt be one vppon the North ≈øide, & the other vpon the South ≈øide, of the Equinoctial line, which is to be vnder≈øtood vpon the 22. of March, and the 23. of September (≈øtilo nouo) when the Sunne is in the ≈øame line.

A. 75. degrees and fiue for of declination are 80. degr√©es, then there wanteth 10. degr√©es, to make the 90. degr. & that is the Equinoctial line betw√©ene you and the Sun.

A. Take the height of the Sun by your A≈øtrolabe, and that you find you mu≈øt adde to the height that the place lyeth vnder, and what≈øoeuer it amounteth vnto aboue 90. degr√©es, or that it wanteth of 90. degr√©es, is the declination of the day.

A. Vnder the Poles of the worlde.

A. All that the Sunne ri≈øeth from morning to noone, likewi≈øe the height is the degrees, that you haue from the Pole to the Horizon: al≈øo the height is all the di≈øtance you haue from the Equinoctiall line.

A. A. The great circles, or compa≈ø≈øing lines, which ye Equinoctiall naturally hath, that is, the 32. deg. are altogether eueÃÑ & alike, ech being 15. Dutch, & 17. Spani≈øh miles, and ¬Ω. but the ≈ømal circles or comparing lines haue ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe, according to ye eleuation of ye Pole, in ≈øuch maner, yt the nearer you be to ye Equinoctial line, ≈øo much longer your way wil be, & the nearer you go to the Poles the ≈øhorter will be your way, for the Pole ri≈øeth or de≈øceÃÑdeth one degr√©e, & running along by the line, it neither ri≈øeth nor declineth.

Thomas on the coa≈øt of Choramandel, the towne and fortre≈ø≈øe of Malacca, the Iands of Maluco, which are Tarnate, Tydor Banda, and Amboyna, the land and coa≈øt of Bra≈øilia, ≈øtretching 500. miles in length, and deuided into eight Captaine≈øhips, or gouernements, from whence euery yeare is brought into Portingale about 150. thou≈øand Arroben of ≈øugar, each Arroben waighing 32. pound, the Hauen called de Todos os Santos, or of all Saints, where the Gouernour of Bra≈øilia is re≈øident.

The ordinarie rentes of the Crowne of Portingale, are yearely one million of gold, & 100000. duckets the rents & reuenewes of the Ma≈øter≈øhip of the knights of the Cro≈ø≈øe, the king being alwaies Ma≈øter, to whom belong the Ilands of Acores (or Flemmi≈øh Ilands) Madera, tho≈øe of Cabo verde, Saint Thomas, and de Princepe are yearelie 200000. Duckets, the cu≈øtomes of ≈øpices and other goods receiued out of the Ea≈øt Indies is yearely 600000. Duckets, the other rents, profits, and reuenewes of the Indies, and their townes are ≈øpent and di≈øbur≈øed in defence & maintenance of the ≈øaid Countries and places, ≈øo that the rents and reuenewes of the Crowne of Portingale doe amount vnto the ≈øum of 220000 Duckets, at 5. ≈øhillings 6. pence the Ducket amounteth vnto in Engli≈øh monie, to the ≈øumme of ≈øixe hundreth and fiue thou≈øand poundes.

div.head: The 5. Chapter. Of the yearely charges disbur≈øed by the Kinges of Portingale.

list.item: THe f√©es and payments due to the mini≈øters & Iu≈øtices of the lawes and ordinances of the countrie of Portingale, for the executing of their offices, doth amount vnto yearely the ≈øumme of 100000 duckets.

The rentes which the King be≈øtoweth yearely, as giftes and rewardes vnto ≈øuch as haue done him ≈øeruice, which being dead, returneth vnto him againe, doe yerely amount vnto the ≈øumme of 300000 duckets.

The Iuros which are bought for monie, and fee farme or continuall rents to bee paide out of the kinges reuenewes, cu≈øtomes, and other demaynes yearely, and are neuer relea≈øed, but remaine from heire to heire, are yerely 150000 Duckets.
The charges of Maintayning the ca≈øtles and fortes in Africa and Barbarie, doe yerely amount vnto the ≈øumme of 300000. duckets.
The charges of maintaining fiue Gallies yearely 50 ‚Ä¢ 00 Duckets.
The charges of the armie that doth yerely conuay the Indian ≈øhips thither, & fetcheth them back againe amount vnto 300000. Duckets.

The Moradien, that is the wages which the king payeth to his ≈øeruants called Mocos da Camara, Caualhe ‚Ä¢ , Fidalgos, and other titles, as an honour to ≈øuch as hee will ≈øhew fauour vnto, or els in reward of anie former ≈øeruices, or in re≈øpect their Ancetors were true and faithfull ≈øeruitors to the king, with tho≈øe titles they are called ≈øeruantes of the kinges hou≈øe, which is a great honour, & they doe receiue a yearely ≈øtipend (although not much, towardes their charges of finding proui≈øion for their hor≈øes, although they can hardly ≈øaue a paire of ≈øhooes, and yet neuer come on hor≈øes backe all their life time, but it is onely a token of the Kinges fauour and good will, wherein the Portingales doe more glorie and vaunt them≈øelues, then of any thing in the world, yet is it not of much importance, and verie little paie, it amounteth yearely to 80000. Duckets.

The charge of the king of Portingales hou≈øe is yearely the ≈øumme of 200000. Duc. which was wont to be farmed, as at this day it is: for the charge of hou≈øhold of Don Alberto, Cardinall of Au≈øtria, Gouernour of Portingale, for the defence and maintenance of the Ca≈øtles and Forts of Portingale the ≈øumme of 200000. Duckets.

So that the charges afore≈øaid doe amount vnto in all, the ≈øumme of 1680000. duckets, at fiue ≈øhillinges ≈øixe pence the ducket is in Engli≈øh monie the ≈øumme of foure hundereth ≈øixtie and two thou≈øand pounds, which being deducted out of the receates of Portingale afore≈øaid, that amount vnto 605000. poundes Engli≈øh monie there re≈øteth yearely for the king of Spaine, Coffers, one hundreth fortie and three thou≈øand pounds Engli≈øh monie.

div.head: The 6. Chapter Of the Towne of Lisbone.
div.p: THe towne of Lisbone hath ‚Ä¢ 2. pari≈øh Churches, and aboue eleuen thou≈øaÃÑd hou≈øes, wherin there are aboue ‚Ä¢ 0 thou≈øand dwelling places, accounting the Court and the place thereunto belonging, it hath in people, aboue 120000. whereof 10000. of them at the lea≈øt are Slaues and Mores, which e≈øtimation is made according to the church bookes, which the Par≈øons, Vicars and Curats are bound to doe once euerie yeare, euerie one in his pari≈øh, among the≈øe are not accounted ≈øuch as follow the Court, neyther Cloy≈øters, Cobents, Ho≈øpitalles, nor any other hou≈øes of religion: for that in all they would amount vnto as much as the hou≈øes of the citie: al≈øo of other Churches‚ñ™ Cloy≈øters, and Chappels of the virgin Marie, and other Saints which are no pari≈øhes, there are ≈øo many, that they can not be numbred. The Towne hath aboue 350. ≈øtreetes, be≈øides cro≈ø≈øe waies and lanes, that haue no thorow fare, which are likewi≈øe a great number.

div.head: The 7. Chapter A ≈øhort di≈øcour≈øe of the pettigrees of kinges of Portingale, vntill Phillip now King of Spaine and Portingale Sonne of Charles the fift Emperour of Rome.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt king of Portingale was named Don Alfon≈øo Henriques, ≈øonne of Earle Henry, who (as the Chronicles rehear≈øe) was ≈øonne of the Duke of Lorraine
others thinke hee was ≈øonne of the king of Hungarie: but the true≈øt Hi≈øtories doe report him to be of Lorrane, and that he came into the King of Spaines Court, being de≈øirous to imploy him≈øelfe in the warres of the Chri≈øtians again≈øt the Mores, which as then held the mo≈øt part of the countrie of Spaine, and the whole land of Lu≈øitania or Portingale, warring continually on the King of Spaine, and other Chri≈øtians bordering on the ≈øame: in the which warres hee behaued him≈øelfe ≈øo well, and did ≈øo valiantly, that the King knew not how, or in what ≈øort to recompence him better, then by giuing him his daughter in mariage, & with her for a dowrie gaue him the countrie of Portingale, that was as much as he had conquered, and brought vnder his ≈øubiection, with all the re≈øt if he could win it, with the name and title of Earle of Portingale, his ≈øonne afore≈øaid called Don Alfonzo, was borne in Anno 1094.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 9 ‚Ä¢ . who wan the mo≈øt part of the countrie of Portingale from the Mores, & after his fathers death was called Prince of Portingale, which name and title he enioyed for the ≈øpace of 27. yeares, which title in Spaine no man may beare but the Kings elde≈øt ≈øon, and heire vnto the Crowne, and being of the age of 45. yeares, was crowned king of Portingale, by the fauour & ≈øpeciall priuiledge of the Pope of Rome as then being, & by that meanes Portingale became a kingdome. This fir≈øt King maried when he was 52. yeares of age, and had one ≈øonne and 3. daughters, and be≈øides them one ba≈øtard ≈øon, and a ba≈øtard daughter, he raigned 46. yeres, and died in the towne of Coyinbra, his body being buried in the Cloy≈øter of Santa Crus, erected by him‚ñ™ as al≈øo the Cloy≈øters of Alcobaca and Saint Vincent without Li≈øbone called Saint Vincent de Fora.

This King fir≈øt wonne the Towne of Lisbone from the Mores, by the aide & help of the Flemmings, and Low countrimen, which came thether with a Fleet of Ships, (being by ≈øtormie weather forced to put into the riuer) that were ≈øayling to the holy land, whether for the furtherance of Chri≈øtian religion, they as then trauelled, which as I ≈øuppo≈øe was about the time that the Chri≈øtians won the great City of Damyate in the couÃÑ trie of Pale≈øtina, where tho≈øe of Harlame did mo≈øt valiantly defend them≈øelues, and ≈øhewd great valour, as the Sword & Armes as yet extant doe well bare witnes, which Fleet being come thether at ≈øuch time as the ≈øaid king be≈øieged the ≈øaid towne of Lisbone, hee vnder≈øtanding that onely cau≈øe of comming was to imploy their forces again≈øt the Infidels and vnbeleeuing Chri≈øtians, friendly de≈øired them, ≈ø√©eing it was Gods will they ≈øhould ariue there at ≈øo conuenient a time, to aide him again≈øt his enemies, ≈øhewing them that they might as well imploy their forces there, (as in the holie land,) to increa≈øe the faith of Chri≈øt, and ouerthrow the enemies of the ≈øame, whome if it plea≈øed God to pro≈øper, (as he doubted not but by their helpes to haue the victorie) they might as then fulfill their pretended voiage, both to the glory of God, & their owne honors, which in the ende they agr√©ed vnto, in the which ≈øeruice they ≈øo well imployed them≈øelues, that they not only holp him to winne Lisbone, but many other places, thereby placing the king in his kingly ≈øeat: for which their good ≈øeruice the king acknowledging him≈øelfe much bound and beholding vnto them, in recompence thereof he indowed them with many priuiledges and fr√©edomes more than his natural ≈øubiects ‚Ä¢ nioyed, which hee bound both him and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors kinges of that countrie to k√©epe & ob≈øerue, one whereof was, that all Dutchmen that would dwell within his Countrie, or traffique with in the ≈øame, ≈øhould bee free of all impo≈øtes, and exci≈øes for all things that they ≈øhould v≈øe, and haue in their owne hou≈øes, and for them≈øelues and their familie, that they might weare what ≈øort of apparrell and Iewels they would, and of what ≈øtuffe ≈øoeuer, with their wiues and families, although they were Portingale women, which is forbidden to the naturall Portingales: for that they haue a law concerning apparrell, what kinde of ≈øtuffe euerie man according to his e≈øtate and qualitie ≈øhall weare, al≈øo to goe by night and at vnaccu≈øtomed houres when occa≈øion ≈øerued them, in all places with fiue or ≈øixe ≈øeruants with light or without‚ñ™ and with what armes or weapons they would, which is not permitted to the inhabitantes them≈øelues‚ñ™ that no Iu≈øtice ≈øhould haue power to atach or are≈øt any man in their hou≈øe, or execute any Iu≈øtice vpon them, for what cau≈øe ≈øoeuer it were (trea≈øoÃÑ only excepted) but onlie by their owne law, by the king him≈øelfe ordained & appointed, called Iuis dos-Alemaines or the Dutch law, al≈øo that their hou≈øes might not be taken (whether they were hired or their owne f√©e ≈øimples) for the kinges ≈øeruice or any of his Court, as all other his ≈øubiects hou≈øes are, as n√©ed requireth, that they might not bee compelled to v≈øe or ≈øerue any office in the countrie, or for the king, as the Portingales doe, neyther yet rated to pay any contribution for the common profit of the countrie, & trauelling through the Countrie, ≈øhould for their monie be ≈øerued before any other man, with many other ≈øuch like priueledges, which for breuitie I omit, onely
I haue ≈øet downe the principalle≈øt of them, thereby to ≈øhew (as their owne Chronicles declare) through whome, and by who≈øe help the Portingales, at this day doe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe and enioy that which they hold in the ≈øaid Countrie of Portingale, which priuiledges are yet (as they haue alwaies b√©ene) without anie deniall firmely holden and maintained, and by all the kinges ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely confirmed from time to time, with dayly increa≈øing of the ≈øame, by meanes of the continuall plea≈øures done vnto the ≈øaid kings of Portingale by the ≈øaid Nation, as it is well knowne.

2 Don Sancho. Don Sancho Sonne of: the afore≈øaid king was the ≈øecond king of Portingale, hee was borne in Anno 1154. and crowned king at the age of 31. yeares, hee had i≈ø≈øue 15. children, Sonnes, and Daughters, and raigned twenty ≈øeuen yeares, he died in the towne of Coymbra in the yeare of our Lord 1212. being 58. yeares of age, and lieth buried in the Cloy≈øter of Santa Crus by his Father.

3 Don Afonzo. Don Afon≈øo the ≈øecond of that name, & the third king of Portingale, was crowned at the age of 25. yeares, he had i≈ø≈øue two ≈øonnes, in his time liued Saint Dominick, Saint Francis and Saint Anthonie, he died in anno 1223. & lieth buried in the Cloy≈øter of Alcoba≈ø≈øa.

4 Don Sancho Capello Don Sancho Capello, his ≈øon fourth king of Portingale, was crowned at the age of 16. yeres, and died in the towne of Toledo, in the yeare of our Lord 1247, and is buried in the great Church of Toledo.

After his death was cho≈øe King, his brother the Earle of Bolonhien, 5 The Earle of Bologien. and was the fifth king of Portingale, hee raigned 31. yeres, and died in Lisbone, in the yeare of our Lord 1279. and is buried in the Cloi≈øter of Alcoba≈ø≈øa.

6 Don Deniis. Don Deniis his ≈øonne was Crowned in Lisbone, the ≈øixt king of Portingale, being of the age of 18. yeares, he raigned 46. yeres and died in the towne of Saint Arein, in the yeare of our Lord 1325. the 20. of Ianuary being 64. yeares of age, and lyeth buried in the Cloy≈øter of Oliuellas, which is about 2. miles from Lisbone, which he in his life time had erected, he maried with Donna I≈øabella, daughter to Don Pedro king of ArragoÃÑ, ≈øhe was cannoni≈øed for a Saint, her Sepulcher is in the towne of Coymbra which ≈øhee builded: where her body doth many miracles.

7 Don Afonzo O Brauo.After him raigned his ≈øonne Don Afon≈øo o Brauo, which is the valiant, hee was crowned in the towne of Arem at the age of 35. yeares, and was the ≈øeuenth king of Portingale, hee died in Lisbone in the month of May Anno 1356. he lieth buried in the high quire of the great Church, hee ouercame the Mores in Salado, fighting in aide of the king of Ca≈øtille.

His Son Don Pedro was the eight king of Portingale, 8 Don Pedro. and ruled the land with great Iu≈øtice, temperante, and peace, & died in the yeare of our Lord 1366. and lieth buried in the Cloy≈øter of Alcoba≈ø≈øa, hee had i≈ø≈øue one ≈øonne, called Don Ferdinand, and before hee maried, he had two ba≈øtard ≈øonnes by Dona Ines or Agnes de Ca≈øtro, called Don Ioan and Don Denniis. 9 Don Ferdinand.

After the death of the afore≈øaid king, Don Ferdinand his ≈øon was crowned king, and was the ninth king of Portingale, he maried Dona Lianor Gon≈øalues Telles, whom he tooke by force from her hu≈øband called Larenca Vaaz da Cunha, to whome ≈øhee was maried, and bani≈øhed him the land, neuerthele≈ø≈øe he was verie louing to his ≈øubiectes, and puni≈øhed all offenders, and vagabondes, h√©e raigned 17. yeares, and died without i≈ø≈øue, in the yeare of our Lord 1383. being of the age of 43 yeares, and lieth buried in the quier of S. Francis Church in the towne of S. Arein.

After this kings death,10 Don Ioan. Don Ioan king of Ca≈øtillia, with his wife Dona Beatrix, came into Portingale by force to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Crowne of Portingale, but Don Ioan ba≈øtard ≈øon of the afore≈øaid king Don Pedro, & ba≈øtard brother to Don Ferdinand the la≈øt king with≈øtood him, and fought with the ≈øaid king of Ca≈øtille, whome he ouercame in the field, called S. Ioris, where for a perpetuall memorie of his victorie, he erected a great & rich Cloy≈øter, which hee called the Cloy≈øter of the battaile or victorie, becau≈øe he won the field in the ≈øame place again≈øt the Ca≈øtilians. This ba≈øtard Don Ioan was Crowned king of Portingale, being of the age of 31. yeares, & was the tenth king, he liued 76 yeres, and died in Anno 1433. the 14. of Augu≈øt, and lieth buried in the ≈øame Cloy≈øter of the battaile by him erected, hee wonne the Ca≈øtle and towne of Septa from the Mores, in Barbaria or Affrica, and was Father to the Infant Don Ferdinand, that is Canonized for a Saint.11 Don Duarte or Eduart,

After him raigned his ≈øonne Don Duarte, or Eduart, and was the 11. king of Portingale, he liued 42. yeares, whereof he raigned 5. yeares king, hee died in the Pallace of the couent of Thomar, in Anno 1438. he lieth buried in the Cloy≈øter of the battaile.

Don Alfon≈øo his ≈øonne was borne in S. Arein in the yeare of our Lord 1432.12 Don Afonzo. and becau≈øe he was but 6. yeares of age wheÃÑ his Father died, his vncle the Infant Don Pedro raigned in his place, vntill the yeare of our Lord 1448. Then the ≈øaid Don Afon≈øo was him≈øelfe crowned king, & was the 12 king of Portingale, he died in S. Arein in ye ≈øame chamber where he was borne the 28 of Augu≈øt 1481. and lieth buried by his Ance≈øtors
in the Cloy≈øter of the battaile.

1 ‚Ä¢ Don Ioan:After his death raigned his ≈øonne Don Ioan the great, called the ≈øeconde of that name, being the 13. King of Portingal: he was borne in Lisbone the 4. of May, anno 1455. hee did openly him≈øelfe being pre≈øent, cau≈øe Don Fernando Duke of Be ‚Ä¢ ganca, vpon the market place of the towne of Euora to be beheaded, on the 22. of Iune in An. 1483. & with his owne hand with a Poynyard ≈ølew Don Domingos Duke of Begia, brother to his wife Dona Lianor, pre≈øently calling Don Manoel, the ≈øaid Dukes brother‚ñ™ & gaue him the ≈øame Dukedome, with all that belonged therunto he liued 40. yeres, and died at Aluor in the bath the 25. of October An. 1495. & lieth buried in the Cloi≈øter of the battaile by his Ance≈øtors, & died without i≈ø≈øue.

14 Don Manoell.By his la≈øt Wil and Te≈øtament, he gaue the Crowne of Portingale vnto Don Manoel Duke of Vi≈øeu, who was crowned king of Portingale, & was the 14. king, h√©e was crowned in Alcacer do Sal, the 27. of October, An. 1495. he cau≈øed all the Iewes in his land, eyther willingly, or by force (to ≈øuch as refu≈øed it) to be chri≈øtened, in the yere of our Lord 1499. and cau≈øed all the Mores that dwelt at Lisbone without the gate of Moreria to be bani≈øhed, whereof the gate to this day holdeth the name. In the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me of this king, there happened an in≈øurrection of Portingales in Lisbone, again≈øt the new Chri≈øtened Iewes, whereby they ≈ølew certaine hundereths of them, both men, women, and children, burning ≈øome of them, with a thou≈øand other mi≈øchiefes, robbing their hou≈øes, ≈øhops, and goods: for the which the king did great Iu≈øtice, and finding out the principall beginners of the ≈øame cau≈øed them to b√©e puni≈øhed. This king did fir≈øt di≈øcouer, and by his captaines & ≈øouldiers, conquered ye Countries and pa≈ø≈øages into the Ea≈øt Indies, and ye orientall countries for ≈øpices, & al≈øo the hauens & pa≈ø≈øages in Pre≈øter Iohns land, hee likewi≈øe conquered the towns & fortre≈ø≈øes of Saff ‚Ä¢ in & Azamor in Affrica, he died in an. 1521. vpon S. Luces day, & lieth buried in the Cloy≈øter of Bethlehem, by the dutchmeÃÑ called Roy≈øters.

1 ‚Ä¢ Don Ioan 3.After his death raigned his ≈øon Don Ioan the 3. & was the 15. king of Portingale, he was borne in the month of Iune in Anno 1502. in the citie of Lisbone, where he was crowned in anno 1521. he was ≈øimple, curteous, & mild, and a great friend vnto all religious per≈øons, as al≈øo to all ≈øtudents, he fouÃÑ ded the vniuer≈øitie of Coymbra, and other colledges, & died the 11. of Iune An. 1557. & lieth buried in the Cloy≈øter of Bethelem, or Roy≈øters.

After his death was crowned Don Seba≈øtian, and was the 16. king of Portingale,16. Don Seba≈øtian, he was ≈øon to the Prince of Portingale, elde≈øt ≈øonne to the afore≈øaid Don Ioan, that maried with Dona Ioana daughter to the Emperour Charles the fift, and Si≈øter to Phillip king of Spaine, which Prince dying before his father, left his wife great with childe of this Don Seba≈øtian, who after the death of his Grandfather was Crowned king of Portingale, he was born on Seba≈øtians day, in the yeare of our Lord 1553. hee pa≈ø≈øed with a great armie into Africa to conquere the countrie, in the yeare 1578. where hee with mo≈øt of his Armie was ≈ølaine, the re≈øt taken pri≈øoners, and ≈øo died without i≈ø≈øue.

After this ouerthrow and death of the ≈øaid king Don Saba≈øtian, 17. Don Henricke. was Crowned Don Henricke a Cardinall, vncle vnto the ≈øaide Don Saba≈øtian, and was the 17. King of Portingale, and died without i≈ø≈øue, in Anno 1580. leauing by his la≈øt will and te≈øtament for heire of the Crowne of Portingale Don Phillip king of Spaine, as lawfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øor vnto the ≈øame: for that his Father Charles the 5. maried the elde≈øt daughter of the king Don Manoel, which was mother to Don Phillip king of Spaine, and ≈øi≈øter to the grandfather of Don Seba≈øtian, and of the afore≈øaid Don Henrick, although there had bin another brother of the ≈øaid don Henrick, named Don Luiis, who dying left a ≈øon called Don Antonio, that was Prior de Ocrato, of the order of the knightes of the Cro≈ø≈øe of S. Iohns, whome the Portingales cho≈øe for their king, but by meanes of the great power and might of the king of Spaine, who by monie had gotten the greate≈øt part of the nobilitie of Portingale, to hold with him, partly by monie, and partly by force, he got the kingdome into his hands and ≈øubiection, driuing Don Antonio out of the countrie,18. Don phillip king of Spaine. & ≈øo in anno 1581. he came into Portingale, & in Lisbon was crowned king in the cloy≈øter of Thomar, by all the 3 e≈øtates of the countrie, that is the nobility, ≈øpiritualtie, and commons, & is the 18. king of Portingale, who as yet liueth, & raigneth ouer the ≈øame countrie: whereby the Crowne of Portingale is now fallen into the handes of the kinges of Spaine, hauing continued in the handes of the kinges of Portingales for the ≈øpace of 442. yeares, which their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors till then inioyed, being of the race and progenie of the hou≈øe of Loraine.
